Date: Mon,  1 May 1995 03:05:09 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: 914 randomness...

    It's about that time of year again, as I still have no job it looks
like I'll be leaving Pittsburgh, at least for a while (I'll miss you
guys!) but on the bright side I'll get to spend a little quality time
with my beastie.  Where to begin...
    First of all, I need new fuel lines.  After I replaced one of the
hard plastic lines, the old rubber ones started leaking like crazy
around the fuel pump area (no big surprise to me, I was planning on
replacing them eventually anyway.  Eventually, I have found, often comes
sooner than one expects.)  Any recommends as to where to get a good
price on the braided rubber lines?
    Still need to finish the brakes, I am missing the one front hard
line, still, and am mulling over whether to buy tools or just get the
part from Stoddard.  If anyone has a cheap set of benders/flarers or can
point me to some, that would definitely influence that decision.
    The last time I was home, I was poking around the engine area, in
preparation to undo the whole exhaust system and put it back together
again, hopefully this time sans leaks.  To my dismay, I saw that one of
the tailpipe thingys had some loose from the left side muffler on my
Monza system and was just being held on by the bracket.  i have a nasty
feeling that would not pass inspection. I knew the system was shot (as
evidenced by the "sporty" tone) but like I said, eventually....  So I
need recommends on a new system.  I'm tempted to stick with the Monza as
it seems to be the closest to a true equal-length dual system (with
crossover, natch) of any I have seen... but I have also heard P-philes
speak highly of Bursch exhausts, and was wondering if there was any real
advantage for the extra money.  I have also seen a system called the
Sebring advertised very cheaply, it seems to be similar to a Bursch only
with a replaceable turbo-type muffler (for you non-american car guys,
that's a basic old baffled muffler, designed for low backpressure,
introduced on the Corvair turbo, hence the name...) which seems tempting
but I haven't heard anything at all about it.  Thoughts?
    Also, my dashboard seems to be non-fuctional... all the light
switches and gauges work OK, including the backlighting, but my heater
blower doesn't work, and neither do the backlights for the heater
control thingy.  Any ideas why?  Is there a harness connector that could
have come loose?  I took the ashtray out and sprayed some tuner cleaner
followed by WD-40 on the blower switch part, but that still doesn't
work, nor does it explain the nonfunctional lighting.  hmmm.....
    Other than that, things are going pretty smoothly... it needs a lot
of work, but nothing I can't handle (now affording it, that's something
else...)  but any advice on the above is greatly appreciated.

happy speeding,

Nate

From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Safety Devices...

Okay, well, I figured, y'know, we're talking about all these daytime 
running lights and such... what I figure is:
Daytime running lights... great things, if you live in northern Canada, 
or Sweden where it is dark for 6 months... otherwise, how about not 
painting your car beige, or purple-brown? What about red, and bright 
blue, and yellow cars? Those would catch your eyes... but either way, the 
gov't proably won't tell us what color of car we can have (although don't 
doubt for a second they won't consider it)
Airbags... hm... can we have an on/off switch, for those of us who would 
rather not bump the car next to us and spend $700?
Third brake lights... while they do absolutely no good (because you 
should not be so close at any speed that you can't see the regular ones) 
they are neat, in the fact that it gives the designers something to work 
into the design (note how the 993 has it accomodated into the pop-out 
wing now, vs. the old box out of the deck.)

More as I think of it... you should all look at the cartoon from 2 months 
ago in Automobile (the government safety car)
 -Derek Cahill

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 08:38:45 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Limited Slip Differentials

A limited slip differential couples the driving wheels by controlling the 
relative angular velocity between the drive wheels, i.e., one wheel spinning
causes the other to spin also.  It does this by utilizing fluid shear 
properties.  If you took two flat plates and put oil between them, they would
be separated by the thickness of the film and not touching.  Rotating one
plate would cause the other plate to turn in the same direction at a lower
angular velocity.  The higher the relative angular velocity between the two
plates the more power that can be transmitted from one plate to the other.
This can be controlled by the viscosity of the fluid, which in the case of 
the differential is the transaxel fluid.  Although I've never actually
disassembled a L.S. Diff.,  I believe there are several plates that couple
the drive wheels.  This system allows the wheels to rotate independently
when turning, but when one wheel is spinning, i.e., high relative angular
velocity, power is applied to both wheels.

In a normal diff.  if one wheel is on ice and the other has traction, the car 
will not move because the diff. applies the same torque to both drive wheels.
If the coefficient of friction on one wheel is low - too low to move the car -
the force required to move the car will never be developed because the spinning
wheel limits the torque that can be applied to the wheel that has traction.  A
limited slip will apply torque to the wheel with traction through the plates
and oil that couple the two drive wheels.  

The advantage in racing is in hard cornering when the inside wheel is lightly
loaded the application of power would cause it to spin with a regular diff.
A L.S. Diff. allows the wheel with traction to be able to accelerate the car 
out of the corner. 
~p
jpuzas@astro.ge.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 09:14:09 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Turbos & intercoolers

>        This is probably a dumb question but how much of the bhp gain on a 
>turbo equiped P-car is from the turbo and how much is from the intercooler?


without the turbo, the intercooler does ~squat. With a turbo, I've heard
numbers like +15%. Manufacturers like it because the same reduced charge
temperature (i.e. increased charge density) that gives more hp also
improves engine life. both saab and porsche introduced intercoolers (and
later turbo water cooling) a year (or two?) after the turbos came out.



doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: Mon, 01 May 1995 07:40:05 -0600
From: stephenk@synopsys.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Re: 1973 - Transmission help

>My manual states that the transmission cannot be removed without also 
>removing the engine.  Is this the case?  It appears that there is enough 
>clearance, but being new at this I jus'don't know.HELP??!!
>1973 914/1.7/fi.

Despite what the manual says you can remove the trans without the engine.
Here's roughly what I did (the order is somewhat memory dependant and
arbitrary; do it in the order that makes sense and remember to perform the
steps I forgot to mention :-)

  1. Drop the heat-exchangers and muffler.
  2. Disconnect the trans-to-chassis ground strap.
  3. Disconnect the backup switch wiring (I think that's what it is).
  4. Disconnect the half-shafts at the inner CV Joints and wire them 
     up out of the way.  They'll still be in the way, only less so.
  5. Position a jack under the trans, near the front (about 3/4 of the
     length of the trans should be behind the jack).
  6. Remove the starter and associated wiring.
  7. Remove rear trans-mount nuts.
  9. Support the engine with a couple of jack stands and a block of wood.
 10. Remove the nuts/bolts holding the trans to the engine.
 11. Pull back and lower transmission to ground.

I can't tell you much about putting it back, as I had to subsequently drop
the engine for a rebuild.  I ended up reassembling the engine and trans on
the ground to install them as a unit (per the book).  I suspect clutch
alignment is much trickier to accomplish with the engine up over your head.

Stph
- --------------------------------
Stephen Keller
'73 914 2.0L
stephenk@synopsys.com



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 09:38:28 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 rear trunk height adjustment?

> I can't claim anything near Stan's extensive experience, but that's where
> mine leaks (around the tail lights).  My question is if I pull the tail
> light that leaks and run a bead of silicone around it, will that correct the
> problem?  Or is it time to replace the seal?

Well, the leak can be one of three things:

1) the light body itself

2) the seal behind the light, typically the *TOP* part of the seal (so that 
   run-off from the area around the outside of the trunk lid can run
   down into the trunk)

3) the metal where the light body seats is shot

My worst nightmare car had someone *GLUE* the light bodies into the sockets
using probably some kind of RTV or epoxy. It was so old that it was hard 
to tell. I *DO NOT* recommend gluing them in using RTV.... Figure out exactly
what is leaking, and fix that specific problem.

Stan

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 11:20:52 -0400
From: mdunston@vt.edu (Michael Dunston)
Subject: 88 944 coolant question

I walked out saturday morning to notice some coolant underneath of my 88
944.  It was not very much, but enough to verify that it was in fact
dripping from my car.  The car was barely driven (less than 4 miles / 40
MPH) on friday before parking it.  I moved it to another location and
removed the plate under the engine to get a better look.  It seemed to come
from behind the timing cover where the water pump pulley is located, but
was only a few drops and hard to tell.  The strange thing is that it has
not leaked since.  Not a drop since I moved it saturday morning and removed
the skid plate to inspect it.  The car never runs hot or low on coolant,
yet was definitely dripping some on saturday.  It has been driven
considerably since then and I have been watching it closely but still no
more leaks at all.  Any ideas or suggestions?    Thanks in advance for any
help.

Date: Mon, 1 May 95 11:27:12 EDT
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: Need LOW Floor Jack

>I bought a floor jack from Sears about two months ago & used it a few times
>with no problem. Then, I went & had new springs installed which lowered my
>911 & now I can't get the jack under the car!
>
>Can anyone tell me where I might find a jack that will fit under my car?!

With many floor jacks you can remove the metal cup from the lifting point
of the jack. Without this cup, the jack clearance is much lower. At least
on my Sears floor jack, the remaining fitting fits nicely under the little
dimples (about 1.5" diam) on the bottom of a 914. I don't know about other
Porsche models, but you should still be able to find something to lift by
which doesn't require the jack's original, tall cup.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 11:33:55 -0400
From: JWilli911@aol.com
Subject: Re: 85 Tune up \ Timing

>On a 85 3.2 is the timing self adjusting? I can't move the distributor, I
can
>take it out but moving it in the only way I know how to set the timing on
any
>car is not going to happen. Am I missing something or is the car self
>adjustment on the timing? If not is the timing mark on the suppose to be
>aligned with the top dead center mark?

The only purpose of the distributor on the Motronic engines (your 3.2) is to
direct the spark in turn to each cylinder.  The actual timing of *when* the
spark occurs is determined by the 
DME electronics which gets it's cue from the position of the timing teeth on
the flywheel.  The maps in the electronics then determine the advance curve,
based on RPM and engine load.

Without looking up where the timing should be at idle, I can't say where the
timing mark should be, but I hope this answers your question on why you can't
move the timing by rotating the distributor as you might expect.

Jim Williams
JWilli 911@ aol.com


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 10:45:21 -0500
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spdmail.spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: 928 Clutch Job: DIY?

Carlos wants to know about 928 clutches writes:
>(1) Do I need to drop the transmission to replace the clutch? 

No, the 944 does though. The 928 has a short drive shaft with a
connecting sleeve to the drive shaft. After unbolting everything, slide
this shaft back and the whole clutch will come out.
	
>(2) What special tools do I need? 

None, that I can think of. A pilot bearing removing tool will make
it easier to remove.

>(3) If do it myself, how long should I expect it to take?

If you have done this before and have all of the parts before you start:
about 2-4 hours. If you have good mechanical skills and the parts and
the shop manuals (this is one job where you have to have the otherwise
worthless shop manual) a whole weekend.

I would have a friend help you lower and raise the clutch out of and
into the car. It is heavy and you don't want this thing falling on your
head.

Let me know if you need more info.

Brian Scudder
'83 928S
'70 old blue truck
'93 Redi-the-Cat

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 11:18:03 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 1973 - Transmission help

>My manual states that the transmission cannot be removed without also
>removing the engine.  Is this the case?

        As Stephen Keller says, yes it is possible.  Two important
things that he leaves out of his procedure though:
        Disconnect (and remove???) the rear shift bar.
        Disconnect the clutch cable.

        Removing the heat exchangers may or may not be necessary--
I did both engine and tranny together, and was able to leave them on.
I think the muffler must come off, though.
        One of the bolts that holds the tranny and starter onto the
engine (the upper-left bolt) is a real bear to get to from the tranny
side.  It must be attacked from the engine compartment side.
        It actually isn't *too* bad to take the engine out at the same
time, though.

- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov




------------------------------

Date: Mon,  1 May 95 09:32:03 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; chips and factory tuning

>... Now it is occurring to me that the holy grail of engine
>management would be to calculate engine variables based on closed-loop
>operation.  It seems that a highly optimized engine map is only a snapshot
>of optimal performance based on engine condition at that time.  The
>latest ECUs can adapt, but can they adapt enough?  Or, would it be better
to have another "snapshot" taken?
>Matt Carpenter

    Existing EFI is only truly "closed loop" when its on a Dyno; that     
oxygen sensor only really works at light loads and Idle. Richer mixtures
than the 14.7:1 (like around 11.5:1 at WOT) are programmed into the computer,
the ox-sensor can't really "see" those mixtures. Nor could it sense them
quickly enough for any "throttle" response.
  My other wrong notion was that the aftermarket chips "cheat" on emmissions,
but in fact the EPA doesn't test in that range (high load or WOT) so the
factory is open to do whatever they want at that range. They can program
the computer to act like a "power valve" and richen the mixture at high loads
only; kind of like being able to switch carburetors and jetting on the fly...

    If 14.7:1 ratios were always desirable, and the Ox sensor quick enough,
designing an EFI system would be easy, and you'd never have to worry about
building a big ROM. Instead, the tuners have to rely on Empirical testing
and characterization to build in their curves. The overly rich settings
the factory puts in (like 11.5:1 A/V instead of the "better" 12.5:1)
is a "safe" value put in for warranty; EPA requires 50k miles within spec,
customers demand more. As the fuel pump wears down or the regulators bump
around, the "safe" value is less likely to cause the dealer to replace an
engine.

    Some of the car magazines often feature reviews of "tuners" like Steve
Millen, etc. What I think is amusing in these car tests, depsite huge claims
of extra HP, is that the "expertly modified" cars are rarely much faster
than the factory cars, and sometimes even slower.

     What also interests me is that the aftermarket tuners basically copy the
OEM ROM then modify it a little. This would have to be copyright infringement,
however maybe the factories don't discourage the Chippers as a means of
avoiding having to honor their warranties...

         Lee A.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 13:21:01 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Turbos & intercoolers

>Thanks.  So a big intercooler and a small turbo are the way to go in 
>improving engine life?
>
Not so fast. The big intercooler means that there is more delay (lag) as
throttle input from your foot becomes a pressure wave form the turbo and
works it way through the system. A small turbo on its own gets you less
overall boost. Its a question of optimization, where optimization, is
application specific. The 935 racecar made 800+ (one gazillion) hp and
binary boost: no go at all, and then you rocket down the straight like a
bat out of, (well, you know) while most production cars want more hp from
the same or smaller engine (as in the case of the volvo), with smooooooth
power curves.

For example, the new 911 turbo has twin turbo chargers, specifically to
improve throttle response. 


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Porschephiles #1368                         Mon May 1 15:47:59 CDT 1995
Date: 1 May 1995 10:45:32 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: 911 leaks?

                      Subject:                              Time:  10:20 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         911 leaks?                            Date:  5/1/95


I've heard three generalizations about 911 leaks recently:

1) All targas leak in the rain.  Not so.  My 88 *never* leaked.  (When did
Porsche add that rubber piece at the upper front corners?  My 88 had it
and it made a lot of difference.  Can it be installed on older targas?)
2) All cabs leak in the rain.  My 84 didn't.  It had a later-style top, but
one without the newer rain gutters.  And it fit right.
3) All 911's leak oil.  Not if you maintain them.  I did return tubes on
my 88.  It didn't leak for the following few years (when I sold it).  The
84 never leaked during four years ownership.  An 89 needed a cam tower
fix to correct a leak.  It didn't leak for a year afterwards (again, then
sold).
Our 95 doesn't leak (okay, it's only got 7k on it -- it burns oil instead).
I guess it might be fair to say that there are common maintenance
areas required to repair oil leaks (at least in the later years).  But you
do not have to live with oil on the floor of your garage.

BTW, did you know that all Carrera sway bar braces eventually break?

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
95 993 coupe, guards red
85 535i, everyday grey

(Am I the only one who finds it helpful to see locations on signature lines?)

Date: Mon, 01 May 1995 14:00:54 -0400
From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
Subject: Re: Turbos & intercoolers

At 09:14 AM 5/1/95 -0500, doug dykaar wrote:

>without the turbo, the intercooler does ~squat. With a turbo, I've heard
>numbers like +15%. Manufacturers like it because the same reduced charge
>temperature (i.e. increased charge density) that gives more hp also
>improves engine life. both saab and porsche introduced intercoolers (and
>later turbo water cooling) a year (or two?) after the turbos came out.

The water cooling is only for the bearings. It saves you having to run the
engine for a few minutes to cool it down after a power run, by cooling the
bearings and ensuring the oil doesn't fry in the turbo. It adds nothing to
the "coolness" of the inlet charge.

The intercooler drops the inlet temperature and this increases the density
of the charge at a constant pressure. The density defines the mass of air
and hence the power developed, apart from the benefits of having a cooler
air mass entering the engine.

The way it works is based upon, I think, Boyles law, which states PV/T=k

From absolute zero a cooling effect from say 175 deg to 75 deg  is
effectively 175 + 273 (say 450) to 75 + 273 (say 350)  Hence the mass would
increase by 28%. There would be other complications like pressure drops etc
to reduce the efficiency.
Peter Wales
Superchips Inc                          "Timing is everything"


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 95 15:28 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Turbos & intercoolers

    >improves engine life. both saab and porsche introduced intercoolers (and
    >later turbo water cooling) a year (or two?) after the turbos came out.
    
    The water cooling is only for the bearings. It saves you having to run the
    engine for a few minutes to cool it down after a power run, by cooling the
    bearings and ensuring the oil doesn't fry in the turbo. It adds nothing to
    the "coolness" of the inlet charge.

the 9[24]4 series as well as the 930s?  And how come we haven't seen a 928
turbo?  Will the Boxster have a turbo incarnation?  Why do they have interstate
highways in Hawaii?  What's this little chromium switch?

Date: Mon, 01 May 1995 14:12:59 -0400
From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
Subject: Re: re; chips and copyright

At 09:32 AM 5/1/95 CDT, Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
wrote:

>     What also interests me is that the aftermarket tuners basically copy the
>OEM ROM then modify it a little. This would have to be copyright infringement,
>however maybe the factories don't discourage the Chippers as a means of
>avoiding having to honor their warranties...

The question of copyrights is one I find interesting. If I take a chip out
and copy it, have I broken the law?  If I put the copy in the car, only one
version of the software is being used. I think this is like having software
for your PC. As long as only one copy is in use, whether at the office, on
the train or at home, it's not illegal. You have a licence to use the
software when you buy it.

If I make a different version of that software and sell it, is it against
the law? If the buyer has to discard one set of software, to use another,
surely the same applies in that only one set can be used at one time.

I think (hope) this is why the manufacturers have left us alone.
Peter Wales
Superchips Inc                          "Timing is everything"

Rotating one
plate would cause the other plate to turn in the same direction at a lower
angular velocity.  The higher the relative angular velocity between the two
plates the more power that can be transmitted from one plate to the other.
This can be controlled by the viscosity of the fluid,  <<

Date: Mon, 1 May 95 12:53:57 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: The Details... (long)




Here's what I just bought, and here also are a few questions that 
might help me figure things out.  

1972 911T, Coupe, in very good physical condition.  Except for
some minor chips on the door edges, and quite a bit of fading on 
the two front fenders, even the paint looks great.  It's dark blue  
(I have yet to check the paint code.)  If the faded part polishes 
out OK, I may not re-paint.  No rust anywhere, except the 
beginning of some on the floor pan next to the battery box on 
the passenger side.  The boxes themselves are fine.  I couldn't 
find any other rust anywhere, even around the brake/clutch 
pedal assembly.  The interior needs new black carpet, and the 
tan lowback seats (leather) need redoing or repairing.  A new 
headliner wouldn't hurt either, but is probably not necessary if 
this one cleans up OK.

All the numbers match.  The engine has to be cranked a lot 
before it will start, but once started it runs smoothly and cleanly.  
I'm going to rebuild it anyway, so I'll figure out why starting is 
hard.  It's got lots of oil on it (what's new?), but the exchangers 
are solid and rust-free, as is the muffler.  

The only real problem is that the transmission is stuck in either 
1st or 2nd.  If it weren't for that, the car would be a good driver 
as -is.  It's not simply a matter of the linkage in the floor tunnel.  
It's stuck.  But I've never worked on a 915 transmission (The one 
in the '72 I just restored was OK.) so am looking forward to it.

I keep thinking there is some hidden flaw, like major accident 
damage, but I just can't find any.  In any event, I remember 
Bruce Anderson saying in his book that if the repair work is so 
good you can't tell it's there, what's the difference?

Some small questions (bigger ones to come, I'm sure).  

1) There is no rubber strip, or guard, running along the sides 
beneath the door.  I like the way it looks without it, but is this a 
'normal' configuration?

2) There also is no front bumper rubber strip or bumper over-
riders.  (The rear is standard with the strips and over-riders.)  
Instead, there is a fiberglass air damn, identical to the (steel) 'S' 
damn that was available as an option that year.  The entire air 
damn is painted the same color as the car, and looks real nice.  
This feature is what makes me think there may have been some 
front-end damage somewhere along the line.  Another 
suspicious item is that both headlights lack the big O ring 
around the chrome bezel, and those little 6" lengths of black 
plastic that run between each fender and the body proper up 
near the windshield are also missing.  It makes me think both 
fenders were replaced, but like I said, if there has been real 
damage, I can't see any evidence of it, and it sure drove nicely, 
albeit not more than 40 mph when I brought it home.  Did these 
cars ever come with a fiberglass dam and no front rubber 
bumper strip?

3) The front parking lights on my '72 911E (which I know are 
stock) are orange plastic.  These seem to be white, with a small 
orange portion, now faded, and the rear end of the lens.  Does 
any one else's T have white lenses?

4) There are no door pockets.  Could it have come this way?  If 
so, their place has been skillfully covered with carpet material.  
There are also no sill guards, those aluminum strips you see 
when you open the doors.  There don't appear to have been 
screw holes for them.  Did the 'lowly' T come without this 
'luxury' item?

5) It has the cheaper gauges.  The gas/oil level gauge has only a 
gas level meter, and the temp/pressure gauge has only the temp 
meter.  I assume I can swap in the better gauges together with 
the right senders if I want to.  If someone knows I'm wrong, 
please tell me.

6) Last question (for now).  This might seem to be a small one, 
but I'm trying to deduce what this car's been through.  The hatch 
under the front hood that gives access to the space where the 
jack and tools are stored is painted the same color as the body -- 
dark blue.  The rest
of the trunk is a much lighter blue.  In the '72 911E that I just 
restored, both were the same color.  Does this strike anyone as 
revealing anything important?  Is anyone else's T like that?

Thanks everyone again.  You may be sorry, because you're 
going to have to live through the rebuild!

Regards,

Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa (restored- and now with about 800 miles on it)
'72 911T Coupe 

P.S. Anyone have a '72 911S to complete my collection?  Just 
kidding.  My wife would kill me if she knew I was even 
thinking about it.


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 95 12:58:10 PDT
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: ECU "Chips"

Regarding this post, and another included below.

>Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 15:39:58 -0400
>From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
>Subject: Re: chips
>
>At 02:02 PM 4/28/95 PDT, mwc@lubrizol.com wrote:
>
>>So, how could you mass produce replacement chips to improve performance on
>>a certain model car without putting each particular car on the dyno?

>I am always amazed by the lack of understanding people seem to have about
>manufacturing. As a matter of interest, is statistics taught in High School
>in the US? (I'm English and we get a smattering of it in school). I keep on
>bumping into people who have the impression that the world is a perfect
>place and while I can understand a lack of experience I am amazed at people
>who think that you can make something which works on one car  and then they
>think it will work on every other car. Perhaps I'm just getting old.

>If you manufacture a quantity of anything, then the results will conform to
>the well known bell shaped curve. Whether the criteria is power, weight or
>even sensitivity to tuning, there will always be this curve indicating that
>some are more and some are less, and the further away you get from the
>standard, the fewer deviants there will be. If you set the ignition timing
>at the top of the curve, 50% of the engines will ping! So it is set back so
>that 90% or 95% or even 99.999% won't ping with that timing figure.( I don't
>know what percentage Bosch uses) This means that 40% or 45% or 49.999%,as
>the case may be, of these engines won't ping if the ignition is advanced.

>We move the baseline up a little so that we optimise say 80% of the engines.
>The more performance you go for, the fewer respond and yes, the best way is
>to tune each one on the dyno individually. As manufacturers we have to
>tolerance the chips we make, to balance the performance gains with the
>number of returns we get from customers who, at one end of the scale say the
>increase is not enough because the timing was not aggressive enough, and at
>the other end, from customers who say the car pings because the timing was
>too aggressive.

>Peter Wales
>Superchips Inc                          "Timing is everything"


And here is an excerpt of a second post:
 
>Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 15:56:22 -0400
>From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
>Subject: Re: Chips for Porsches

<stuff deleted>

>The Bosch systems are comparatively easy to reprogram and we can get more
>power out of the engines by doing it. We get 25 HP from the 993 engines and
>it has been done without putting a car on the dyno. Yes we do have a dyno
>here, a very expensive one in fact, but the problem with reprogramming the
>993 was not in getting more power out of it but in defeating the built in
>protection system.

At the risk of being nominated for T*d of the month/year/decade, I'd like to
continue the "ECU chips" discussion.

The second post mentions a +25 HP gain on the 993 attainable with at an  
aftermarket "chip".

I read the included first post with some interest, because it mentions the
normal distribution ("bell curve") observed in measurable characteristics of
manufactured parts.

Why is this relevant?

Let's consider why achieving an additional 25 HP in an engine might NOT be 
a good idea.

One possible answer might be in "bell curve" production tolerances, but with
respect to different tolerances of individual parts to thermal, mechanical,
vibrational stress.

For example, a given oil cooler will have a certain effective radiating area.

Some coolers may have more, some may have less.

It will depend on where a particular oil cooler falls on the normal 
distribution ("bell curve") of "radiating area" of "the population of
oil coolers".

To complicate the issue, the effective "radiating area" is not likely to be 
constant in time as dust/dirt accumulates in the oil cooler as the car is
driven.

And Porsche may factor in some extra "radiating area" for cars driven
on a hot summer day in Phoenix, AZ with the air conditioning on.

What might be an advantage, to a manufacturer, to know within a few percent,
the peak horsepower of an engine?

One answer, I propose, is the manufacturer then can factor this peak 
horsepower number into the design and specifications of the MANY various 
engine parts with MANY different failure characteristics.

The "bell curve" characteristic implies the manufacturer must design to allow
for individual part samples that fail at DIFFERENT applied stress values.

So a given connecting rod will have an certain tensile strength, others may be 
stronger and some may be weaker.  

For example, the 1972 911S, which developed 190 HP, used a "Tennifer" 
treated ( nitrided? ) forged connecting rod.

The 1972 911T, (140 HP, USA model) only had a forged connecting rod.

The engines had different specific HP outputs, RPM limits....

Could the 911S rod be used in the 911T? 

Probably, but it costs more.

Could the 911T rod be reliably used in the 911S?

Maybe some selected "T" rods, but other "T" rods might fail.

So one could argue the lower stress level of the 911T engine allowed Porsche
to use a less expensive rod.

Remember, Porsche had to achieve an acceptable warranty fail rate on
both 1972 model cars.

A less expensive part can be used, and more failures risked, if the cost, 
to Porsche, in customer satisfaction and money, is balanced by the cost savings.

So Porsche could be fully aware of the alleged +25 HP unused in the 993 
engine, but for reliability reasons they locked it out via their "chip".  

Maybe they EVEN designed an engine with parts to tolerate the 25 added HP
but later substituted less expensive parts when they went to production.

The substituted part could even LOOK the same, since possibly only the minimum
acceptable strength specification for the part would be relaxed, allowing 
more "weaker" parts from the "weaker" end of the "bell curve" population 
to be used.

Now let's take a look at the +25 HP number.

First lets convert it to Watts, a standard unit of power measurement.

25HP * 746 Watts/HP = 18.650KW.

To produce this the engine, at 30% thermal efficiency, will need to burn
gasoline at a rate equivalent to 62.16KW.

This requires the engine to radiate an additional 43.5KW to the outside world.

Restated a little differently, 43.5KW is equivalent to drawing 
181 Amps from a 240V AC line. 

To be valuable, the extra HP should occur at the engine's peak HP point,
so it is applied at an already high stress point in the engine's
operating cycle, where it is burning gasoline at the ~highest rate.

So an engine producing an additional 25HP, will have an additional load
placed on it, the cooling system and other components, which were already
stressed, are even MORE stressed.

But, a particular engine has different components that fall on many 
different "bell curves" with respect to capacity for thermal, mechanical,
vibrational stress.

Might a fraction of engine population be able to RELIABLY take the 
additional stress of producing an additional 25 HP?  

Possibly a fraction could.

But can one make the argument that a RANDOMLY selected production engine
can handle the additional 25HP?

Does the aftermarket "chip" supplier have sufficient information to make an 
informed estimate of the expected additional engine fails that MAY
be introduced for the total population "aftermarket chipped" engines?

How would the aftermarket "chip" supplier determine the excess fails
above those which would ordinarily be expected with factory "chips"?

They'd probably need Porsche company private failure data.

I'll allege that IF an aftermarket "chip" customer is able, on average,
to increase their engine's developed HP, they also increase their chances 
of an engine failure.

Unless..

There is some unique quality that ONLY those engines that can produce
the additional HP also happen to be the engines that can reliably take
the additional thermal/mechanical stress.

Is there any reason to believe this?

Let's say we somehow know there are no excess failures, over the normally 
expected failures, introduced by aftermarket "chips" installed in
a large sample of cars.

This may mean no aftermarket "chip" customers EVER access the additional HP, 
or only access the HP for very short time, or there really is no net gain of HP.

BTW, who assumes the risk of additional engine failures induced by aftermarket
"chips"?

Not Porsche, as their engine warranty is voided by the "chip" installation.

Is the aftermarket "chip" manufacturer's liability limited to the return of
purchase price or does the "chip" manufacturer agree to cover the remaining 
time on the manufacturer's warranty?

Lets assume an aftermarket "chip" customer has an engine failure.

For a customer to PROVE to THEMSELVES or OTHERS, that their SPECIFIC failure
was an "excess failure" caused by the aftermarket chip would require 
determining, somehow, that their SPECIFIC failure was one that would NOT have
ALSO occurred with a factory "Chip" installed.

I don't see how this could be proven, with any certainty, by an individual
owner.

But that doesn't mean that "aftermarket chip induced" excess failures 
don't occur.


John Wright

> >avoiding having to honor their warranties...

> and copy it, have I broken the law?  If I put the copy in the car, only one
> version of the software is being used.

rather whether it is legal to, say to buy some software, apply a patch, then 
sell it as your own creation. I think MS and Apple were in court recently 
when Apple accused MS of copy source code from Apple's  video (mpeg?) 
routines.

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 16:06:12 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Turbos & intercoolers

>At 09:14 AM 5/1/95 -0500, doug dykaar wrote:
>
>>without the turbo, the intercooler does ~squat. With a turbo, I've heard
>>numbers like +15%. Manufacturers like it because the same reduced charge
>>temperature (i.e. increased charge density) that gives more hp also
>>improves engine life. both saab and porsche introduced intercoolers (and
>>later turbo water cooling) a year (or two?) after the turbos came out.
>
>The water cooling is only for the bearings. It saves you having to run the
>engine for a few minutes to cool it down after a power run, by cooling the
>bearings and ensuring the oil doesn't fry in the turbo. It adds nothing to
>the "coolness" of the inlet charge.
>


"also improves engine life"

Same thought. manufacturers added the intercooler as much for reliability
as performance, and most (All?) followed that with a cooling pump.

If you figure out how to get more hp from the turbo cooling pump (not
counting turning it off), I'll report you to the thermodynamics police.


doug dykaar

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 15:11:46 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: re; chips and copyright

> The question of copyrights is one I find interesting. If I take a chip out
> and copy it, have I broken the law?  If I put the copy in the car, only one
> version of the software is being used. I think this is like having software
> for your PC. As long as only one copy is in use, whether at the office, on
> the train or at home, it's not illegal. You have a licence to use the
> software when you buy it.

Three issues here:

1) if you make a copy for backup purposes, that maybe legal under the
   fair use rules. As you note, you only have one in play at a time.
   Except for

2) you do *NOT* have any form of license to the *SOFTWARE*. Instead, you
   have an implied license to use the *WHOLE* DME unit. The unit is sealed,
   there are these "hey asshole -- don't open this" notices on it, and
   such. This is *NOT* like a program you buy (or in your case, copy)
   somewhere. Then again, maybe it is...

3) the software in question may also be patented as a "device" given that
   it is just a simplification of a mechanical process. You could do that
   in the US for sure. That would bring *DIFFERENT* laws to play

> If I make a different version of that software and sell it, is it against
> the law? If the buyer has to discard one set of software, to use another,
> surely the same applies in that only one set can be used at one time.

This is what is known as a "derivative work". Most licensing agreements
are pretty clear on this ("you may not modify, network, rent, lease,
loan, distribute or create derivative works based upon..." is a phrase
found explicitly in one manufacturer's license).

International copyright law is also very clear. Copyright to the derivative
works belongs to the original copyright holder. In most cases, selling
something that you do not hold copyright to is felony, and if you have
a business based on that, that would probably also fall under some
of the conspiracy laws which significantly jack up the penalties. Oh, and
then we potentially have the international aspects....

Unless, of course, you're only selling them an unmodified copy of the
software he already owns. In which case, there are probably other
statutes in the Fraud section that apply.

Hope all this helps you Have A Nice Day.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 16:12:34 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Trailbraking

To: TROX???

Sorry for not remembering your name, but I need a "reverse lockout" on my
delete key, and I accidently nuked your letter, name, address etc.  In
response to your question about locking the inside front tire when you try to
trailbrake on an autocross course, I have the following suggestions:

A. Are you certain that it is the inside front, which should be heavily
loaded, and not the inside rear, which should be lightly loaded?  If it is
the rear, you may need to stiffen the front roll resistance (tighten your
front swaybar), back off on the brake bias (use harder rear pads) or run
wider rear tires.

B. You didn't say wether or not it you were only locking one inside front
(i.e. only the left or the right).  If so, it may be mechanical in nature:

1) Check your car for a brake problem.  One side may lock easier than the
other, but not exhibit any pulling under normal braking.

2) Check your car for a defective front shock.

3) Check your car for even weight balance.  This is usually the culprit; one
front wheel having more weight on it than the other.

C. If either front wheel locks it is probably what you are doing (i.e.
driving style):

1) Make sure that you do most of your braking before entering the turn.  You
want to carry enough speed to continue your braking as you turn-in, but you
should ease off the brakes somewhat once you start your turn-in.  Your tires
will not turn-in and sustain maximum braking at the same time.

2) Once the car starts to rotate, pick up the gas immediately.  This is the
general idea for trailbraking; to carry more speed into the corner, and use
the weight shift of the car under braking to start it rotating, and use the
weight shift under acceleration to stop the rotation.

3) Be smooth. Jumping on the brakes violently and turning at the same time
will upset the car, and who knows what will happen.

Let me know how you make out.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 14:11:58 -0700
From: ehab@cisco.com (Ehab Aljandali)
Subject: Re: Edges turned up on Targas


Your Targa top may have turnd its edges up for a couple of reasons:

* Age.. I think the top dries up in time and shrinks.
* Fit in the car, I have seen Targas where the edges of the top are
squeezed when in the top in locked in. This forces the edge to curl up.
However, I have seen this happen to one edge only not both like you
describe.

Tell us how your top fits in the car and may be collectively we can help
you out.
Is the top dry looking, is it too big for the opening in your roof (front
to back, not sideways).....etc.

I replaced my targa top material about a year ago. I did an ok job, but
next time will do better. Someone (Bob Spindel?) had a great article on
targa restoration if you need it (I did).

Hope this helps, Ehab.

84 911 Targa

Date: Mon, 1 May 95 15:44:18 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Adhesive

Bill-

The 3M stuff in the aerosol can is OK -- Super Trim
Adhesive, or something like that, but the 3M stuff
that comes in a tube (like a toothpaste tube) or better
yet, in a can, is better.  The can stuff called vinyl top
adhesive (or something close) is about the best I've
found for carpeting, trim, etc.

The reason there are all those "something like that's"
in the paragraph above, is that I'm at work and can't
remember the excat names or numbers.  If you want them,
let me know and I'll check in the garage tonight.  I suspect
that by then you'll have had a dozen answers anyway.

 -Bob Spindel

Date: Mon, 1 May 95 15:58:51 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: '73 911T CV Joints


Rob-

>How difficult is it to work on CV joints? Is it 'doable' by a 
person of moderate mechanical ability? 

It's not hard.  But what is it you have to do?  Replace?  
Rebuild? Repack?  Put on new rubber boots?

>Are there any special tools required? 

No, except you may need a decent snap ring plier if you don't 
already have one to get the circlips off the axle shafts.

>What time should this project take? 

Depends on what you're doing and how adept you are.  See 
above. But taking them off isn't a big deal, and putting them 
back on isn't either.

>What is the preferred method of working (i.e. tear apart, 
>inspect, order parts, reassemble, etc.) 

Not to be flippant, but the answer is yes.

>Is there anything else that I haven't mentioned.

Can't think of anything, except it's messy, repacking all that 
grease.

 -Bob Spindel

Date: Tue, 02 May 1995 04:25:30 -0400

>Bcc:

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 19:38:50 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@Symtec.com>
Subject: Re: Chips

I'm just amazed that Mr. Wales can say:

> If I make a different version of that software and sell it, is it against
> the law? If the buyer has to discard one set of software, to use another,
> surely the same applies in that only one set can be used at one time.
> 
> I think (hope) this is why the manufacturers have left us alone.

The subject of copyright violation on engine control computers is an
interesting one. I build firmware-based systems to control mass storage
devices. If someone were to buy one of my boxes and reverse engineer the
firmware to make the box operate "better" for their own use, I'd say go
ahead, but don't come crying to me if and when you break the box because
you don't understand the operation of the code under all possible conditions,
or haven't and can't perform a complete parametric test of the code after
the modifications.

On the other hand, if someone buys one of my boxes, makes it "better"
by hacking the firmware and then sells the resulting firmware, I might
be upset because the firmware that they make money on holds lots of
things that cost me lots of money to build. Has this person violated
my copyright? To be sure. Have they hurt my business? That depends. If
the box that is driven by my firmware can only be obtained from me, my
primary concern will be to protect myself from the claims made by people
who buy the "better" chip and then want me to recover their data when it
barfs. So I make it hard to change the firmware without a tamper trail. A
secondary concern will be to see what "better" things have been done
to my firmware. I mean, if the stuff is really better, maybe the box
should ship with the modified firmware to begin with. Maybe I should call
over there and get real technical with the tech support guy and finally
talk to the engineer and offer him a job (any of you chip hackers get
job offers from the OEMs?).

The manufacturers have left you alone because they sell a car no matter
what you do. You're still copying their code and making money off of it.

It would be a different thing if you were reverse engineering the firmware
to determine how to interface with the hardware and then rewriting the
entire thing to incorporate a unique algorithm which makes the car run
better (and better here could be different things to different people)
and then fully testing the entire thing. But my impression from some
reading and the discussion here is that you are mostly modifying a table
of spark and FI timing as a function of RPM, temperature, etc. Will this
modified table perform for all expected operational parameters (load,
altitude, fuel, ambient temperature, etc.)? Guess we just wait for phone
calls to tech support to get the skinny on that one.

Not trying to start a fire or anything, just a different point of view.

Doug Donsbach
'88 951
'88 735i

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 19:44:39 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: chip thoughts

aka. "Why Porsche might not be so retentive on the chip thing" 
 
1) Porsche enjoys tremendous aftermarket support. They realize the their
cars as sold new, are neither affordable nor acceptable to a certain
percentage of Porsche owners. How many new Turbo owners butcher their cars
with adjustable boost knobs? How many 911 owners have added Turbo tie rods?
The company is used to the idea of high-quality aftermarket products. 
 
2) Chipping allows older Porsches to approximate the performance of the
current models. This convinces some owners to stick with the marque,
instead of switching to a 300Z or RX-7. 
 
3) Porsche has a rep as a high performance car. Chips only serve to
propagate that. 
 
4) Chips and cars form a complementary market. The chip does not do much
good without the car. You cannot buy a car with no chip, and then choose
between factory or aftermarket. So Porsche still makes their money. 
 
5) The existence of aftermarket chips for Porsches means that they are
consistent with all the other mass-marketed sports cars out there. If you
don't think Porsche is mass-market, then consider why the Boxter costs only
$40K. 
 
6) Most performance upgrades diminish the car in some way; ride quality,
emissions, maintenance, noise..... So if chips occasionally blow a head
gasket, that life. 
 
The Nomex is on... 
 
- -- 
Triet Le

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 17:04:10 -0700
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: 928 Clutch Job: DIY?

Yo Carlos!

Re: your 928 clutch job, it really is a peice of cake.  Basically, you remove
the slave cylinder, starter and bottom section of bell housing, and 2 allan
bolts (big), slide the sleeve back towards the rear of the car, unbolt the
pressure plate from the flywheel and stand back!  This pack weighs about 40
pounds.  But, why are you replacing the clutch?  

later,
bill

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 17:36:35 -0700
From: ehab@cisco.com (Ehab Aljandali)
Subject: Re: '73 911T CV Joints

Gentlemen;

(If doing only a repack job) The worst part, IMHO, of doing the CV's is if
while cleaning one, it comes apart. It takes a while to put it back
together correctly. It goes in many ways but only one way is correct. This
happened to me while servicing my '84 911 CV joints.
It took me about a day total time to C&R (clean and repack) both sides. It
was fun thu!!!

Stuff needed for C&R:
Average tools?
8 mm hex 3/8 socket
8 CV gaskets
Swepco grease
patience
patience
6 beers
twisty road for test drive


        Ehab.


>Rob-
>
>>How difficult is it to work on CV joints? Is it 'doable' by a
>person of moderate mechanical ability?
>
>It's not hard.  But what is it you have to do?  Replace?
>Rebuild? Repack?  Put on new rubber boots?
>
>>Are there any special tools required?
>
>No, except you may need a decent snap ring plier if you don't
>already have one to get the circlips off the axle shafts.
>
>>What time should this project take?
>
>Depends on what you're doing and how adept you are.  See
>above. But taking them off isn't a big deal, and putting them
>back on isn't either.
>
>>What is the preferred method of working (i.e. tear apart,
>>inspect, order parts, reassemble, etc.)
>
>Not to be flippant, but the answer is yes.
>
>>Is there anything else that I haven't mentioned.
>
>Can't think of anything, except it's messy, repacking all that
>grease.
>
>-Bob Spindel

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 01 May 1995 19:26:26 -0500
From: stamper@interaccess.com (scott sanda)
Subject: Re: 944 engine removal


>I was wondering whether or not a person could pull the engine out from
>above?  In your experience, can it be done, and what is your recommendation?
>
>Any comments would be greatly appreciated.
>
>Much thanks in advance.
>
>Bob Walden
>
Hi Bob:

Well, I've pulled my engine myself several times now, and it has always been
from the bottom. I did some looking, because I had the same thought, but
came to the conclusion that you would have to remove some of the sheet metal
Housing? support? over the radiator, and then un-bolt the bell housing.
Unfortunatly, the drive shaft extends several inches into the bell housing
and clutch, and the engine has to go a good 6-8 inches forward to clear. Ypu
have to pull your radiator. I used the hanes book the first time, and it was
pretty accurate. Make sure you label all the parts and hoses so you can put
them back where they belong. Pulling a 944 engine is a pain in the
"expletive deleted", good luck.

Scott
Scott D Sanda

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 23:48:26 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Hudson Valley, NY PCA Autocross

Hi,

Just a quick note about this event last Sunday, organized
by our own 944 ecology George Beuselinck. It was held 
in New York state not too far from Newburg, at an airport 
with a grippy concrete surface.

George set up a GREAT 50 second course. And the work
and run assignments were excellent, with a semi-heat
system of two runs per heat, and only working one heat
(when your class does not run). I have been autocrossing
for 15 years and this was the best system I've seen yet.

There were only a few Porsches, mostly other cars (about 70?).
If you are within a few hours, I recommend these events.
They are even catered! (My daughter liked the hot dogs served
by "EAT ME HOT DOGS"). And we got done by 2:30 or so!

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S Targa, Danbury CT

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 23:50:15 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Painted latch hardware, 59 A?

Allen Henderson asked 

>Does anyone out there who cares about such things know if the 
>hood latching
>hardware should be painted body color or not?

Mike Willis replied

>Should not be painted it is anodized gold from the factory

To the best of my knowledge, the scissors-type pre-C front latches were
painted body color. The pin and safety catch were white cad or zinc plated. I
don't know of anyplace or any bolt or hardware on a 356 that is gold cad
plated. Some later model VW stuff and 911 stuff is now gold cad.

The later C type latches were white cad or zinc plated. 

This info from a one-owner (before me) 65 C coupe, never wrecked or
repainted.

The pre-C info is from my 61 S90, painted many times but original color is
still visible, and from cars and photos I have seen. All were body color.

At the rear, the receiver bolted to the inside of the engine compartment was
swabbed with black paint. The sheet steel bracket that latched into it,
attached to the engine lid, was painted body color. 

Pete

Date: Tue, 02 May 1995 11:59:33 +1200
From: sar@clearfield.co.nz (Stephen Robb)
Subject: 1981 911SC Questions

Hi,

I finally did it, and am now the proud owner of a GP White 1981 911SC.
Picked it up on Saturday and did 600 miles over the weekend, great fun to
drive.  Thanks to those of you who mailed me during my pre-purchase process.

There are a number of small things I want to fix, and some of you may be
able to help me.

1) The thermostat adjuster dial between the front seats (no AirCon) spins
freely and causes no change to the air temperature.  Is this LIKELY to be
just a connection inside the housing which has come undone?  Should I
attempt to open this box myself, or should I take it somewhere?  OR, is it
really working, but no hot air is coming in because of rust holes(!?!) in
the heat exchangers?

2) The headers/heat exchangers need replacing in the near future.  I am
tempted to replace with standard units (I have access to some secondhand,
will check the state of them first obviously), but may consider after market
items.  Any comments or recommendations.

3) Has anyone installed a QRB/removable face stereo in the standard stereo
location in a 911?  It would appear as though the cigarette lighter, fog
light switch and rear window demister switch will all interfere with the
insertion and removal of such stereos.  Is this the case, if so, are there
any recommended alternative locations, such as in a custom centre console?

4) According to the owners manual the 1981 Targa model has standard two
level rear demister with a two position pull switch for 150w and 300w
heating.  The switch in my car however is a pull/turn type.  I can't seem to
find by trial and error the difference in operation between pulled, turned
and pulled & turned.  Any help?

6) There's an unmarked turn switch (potentiometer (sp?)) type right next to
the steering column on the left (RHD remember).  It's not mentioned in the
owners manual.  Any idea what this might be for (one possibility is some
kind of fader from a previous stereo system).

Any help is appreciated.

TIA.

     Regards, 
     Stephen.

Porschephiles #1370                         Tue May 2 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 00:14:41 -0400
From: FURNANS7@aol.com
Subject: Re: The Details... (long)

Bob,

I will try to answer some of your "small" questions from memory, as I was
selling these things at that time.  These are recollections only and
therefore are not official.

#1 The rubber strip below the door was standard, and was thin on the "T" and
"E". and thicker on the "S".  

#2 The only optional spoiler available was the "S" version in steel.  The
factory did not offer a fiberglass substitute.  The rubber strip and
overriders were also standard, although many were removed by owners.  If I
remember correctly, the overriders were chrome on the 72 and black on the 73
up to January production when they were replaced with the big black rubber
ones.   The fender welt between the cowl and the fender should also be there
as it is on your E.

#3 The front park/turn lenses should be the same as on your 72 E. 

#4 Door pockets and sill guards were also standard.

#5 The "S" gauge package was available and should be able to be added.

#6 I'm not sure on this one, but I think the trunk area was all the same
color, including the hatch area.

I think you are right, this car has had some body/paint work done, but only
you can determine the extent.  

good luck on the resto

Bob
Furnans7@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 22:34:31 -0700
From: Bobjoyce@eworld.com
Subject: Re: Painted Latch on 356

Pete says, "I don't know of anyplace or any bolt or hardware on a 356 that is
gold cad plated....

The later C type latches were white cad or zinc plated.... 

At the rear, the receiver bolted to the inside of the engine compartment was
swabbed with black paint. The sheet steel bracket that latched into it,
attached to the engine lid, was painted body color."


Pete, when I had the mechanicals rebuilt on my one-owner '65 356SC at
Stoddard's about 15 years ago, it was returned with gold cad valve covers,
distinctly different (to my chagrin) from the white cad ones it wore when
delivered to them.  Ostensibly, valve covers were routinely replaced on their
rebuilt engines because "they are prone to warp".  (Mine were not warped,
however.)  Whether the gold cad was Stoddard's touch or a copy of the way
some earlier valve covers left the factory I do not know.  As best I can
remember offhand, that's the only gold cad on the car.

As you point out, and as I responded privately to Allen, all the front hood
latch components on the 356SC are "galvanized", or zinc plated.

All components of the engine deck lid latch on the 356SC, however, were
painted body-color (both top and bottom pieces).

Bob Joyce
Knoxville, Tennessee
Bob356@aol.com
1965 356SC (celebrating its 30th birthday on July 7!)
1988 924S

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 01:36:07 -0400
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: 1981 911SC Questions 


(Stephen Robb asks about some stuff amiss with his new baby, including 
 thermostat and "mystery potentiometer".)

Hi, Stephen,

   Hey, glad to hear about your purchase!  Congrats!  I can help (?) on 
only two things.  It sounds like you have the "Sport" package, which had
this thermostat.  The center thermostat knob is pretty unusual, so many 
of the list may have no idea what you are talking about (am I right?).  
Most 911's have only a red lever between the seats, which controls the hot 
air flow into the cabin (except for T*d's, which had no control over the hot
air flowing in the cabin ;-).  Our (I have one too) thermostat-thing is
merely a motor to move the lever and a control circuit.  The temperature is
read from that strange, rubber-looking device that is mounted just above
the windshield (windscreen for you NZ-ers?) between the seats.  I have 
ahem, "empirically determined" that if this sensing circuit is 
open-circuit, that it thinks it is cold and moves the lever to full hot, 
and if it is shorted, it thinks it is hot and shuts the heat off.  I 
would therefore first try removing the sensor, and disconnecting the connector
(like a little coax).  The heat lever should move up.  Otherwise, your 
problem lies elswhere.  BTW, I *think* you can just actuate the lever 
manually without harm to the system (list?).

    The potentiometer on the dash sounds like it might be the intermittent 
wiper pot.  Mine is on the right of the steering column, between the speedo 
and the clock, and above the headlight washer switch. 

Paul F. Lyman
'82 911SC Targa "Scheistebrun"



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 01 May 95 23:59:41 +0000
From: Ray@arkay.MV.COM
Subject: Problem with '82 930 brakes / vacuum system


Hi,
Having acquired my 930 in last November, I have been furiously reading and 
learning about Porsches in general and this car in particular. I even 
bought the factory manuals, and so far I have fixed lots of little 
problems. But I am very concerned that my stopping power isn't nearly as
good as it should be. All the books and articles claim that the 4-piston
brakes with "racing heritage" are amazingly wonderful. Yet my 2 Toyota
Celicas stop quickly and predictably, but the Porsche requires lots of
pedal power and even then comes more to a gentle stop rather than feeling
suddenly bolted to the ground.

Here is what I already tried:

1) Old pads were ok but got brand new genuine pads. No difference.
2) Bled the brakes many times until I got the hang of it, using all 8 
   valves. Boy the old brake fluid was dirty! Replaced it with new clear
   Castrol GTLMA Dot3/4 fluid. Pedal is slightly harder but no improved
   stopping power.
3) Replaced master cylinder. Put in brand new genuine unit. No difference.
4) Checked the booster check valve. Works fine. 
5) Took out pads, exercised all 16 pistons. When pushing on the brake
   pedal, some came out quicker than others but I selectively used the 
   brake bads to block the ones that came out first, then I cleaned the
   circumference of all pistons with fresh brake fluid and gently pressed
   them back in. Having never worked on brakes before I was surprised how
   much force was required to move the pistons back in. Yes I used
   something that wouldn't scratch the pistons.
6) Per factory manual I turned engine off, pumped brakes many times, then
   pushed on the pedal while I turned the engine on and felt that the pedal
   went in slightly. (Ever so slightly. Maybe less than half an inch). The
   factory manual doesn't say how much it is supposed to go in.
7) Going 40 I really slammed on the brakes, which left some tire marks from 
   the front tires. Nothing in the rear. 

   I ordered new brake rotors for the front, and also ordered seals, dirt
   scraper rings, and spring plates for rebuilding the front calipers, and
   so far I dropped almost $1000 but I have this nagging feeling that the 
   real problem may be the booster or relative lack of vacuum going to it.

   I bought a vacuum gauge and I found that only about 6 lb vacuum is being
   sucked out of the booster. There is a Tee in the vacuum hose which is 
   being used to purge a charcoal canister for gas tank venting, and if I
   plug this vacuum leak that the importers of the car imposed on me then
   my vacuum goes up to 14 lb, my brakes still don't work much better, and
   my engine idles very rough (because the idle mixture was tuned with this
   intentional leak in place)

   Questions, questions, desparate questions:

   1) How much vacuum does the brake booster need to work properly ? None
      of the factory manuals or spec books say this. How can I tell if
      the booster boosts as much as it is supposed to ? 

   2) If I wanted to change the fuel tank venting either to the true US
      standard, or back to the euro standard, how would I accomplish this?
      I traced a hose from the fuel tank to the genuine Porsche "expansion
      chamber" which sits in the left front wheel well above the windshield
      washer tank. Fron this black plastic expansion chamber a hose goes to
      a Purolator charcoal canister which is BMW original equipment, and
      from there the hose goes to the Tee in the brake booster vacuum line.
      Can anyone with a 930 tell me if they have a expansion chamber in
      their wheel well and where the output hose from this thing should go?

    3) Would it be wise to get the "928S4" brake caliper kits advertised by
       Windward or PowerHaus for about $1000, then rebuild the old front 
       calipers and stick them in the back ? I feel very vulnerable with
       my current lousy brake performance. New front calipers at $700 +
       per piece seem to be a significantly worse deal than the "upgraded"
       928S4 kits that are advertised. I don't want used or rebuilt
       calipers. 

	Thanks for any information you may have on the above subject or
	any brake caliper rebuilding advice you are willing to share !

	Ray
      
  ____   ____   ____
 /    | /    \ /    \ Ray Khorram        Ray@Arkay.MV.COM
 \____|    __/ |    | Arkay Tech, Inc.   '82 930 (Adjustable Boost)
      |      \ |    | (603) 425-2149     '92 Harley Sportster 1200
  ____/ \____/ \____/  Fax  434-5674     NH is boring but I have a garage!

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 22:51:44 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: 914 bushing suggestions?

Hi,

	My 914 trailing arm bushing gave out completely, and I need to
replace it ASAP. I am debating between the Weltmeister bushings, or the
stock ones. What are peoples preferences on these? There are pros and cons
to both ideas. 

Poly:	con- road noise
	pro- lateral stiffness
	con- squeaks alot
	pro- cheaper than the stock option
	con- been told that they don't fit well. (by an Automotion tech)

Stock:	con- bonded to arm, need to replace whole assembly (?)($$)
	pro- quiet
	con- not as stiff as poly
	pro- quiet

I know, I wrote quiet twice. But think about how anoying a squeak gets over
time. Yes, it's for an autocrosser, but it's also a daily driver right now.

Any suggestions would be welcome. Thanks...

 -Josh

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 23:42:51 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: E-Z fix??

I think I encountered the same problem on my '75--repeatedly.  I think
the part is basically the same, except that '76 and later had a
plastic lever instead of a metal one.  When my second switch wore out,
I replaced it with a later-type one, since the mechanic thought it
could be the weight of the lever.  Then the turn signal stopped
cancelling on one side, which turned out to be a related problem.

The upshot is a fix that Bruce Anderson had told me about, but about
which the dealer's service people claimed to know nothing.  That is,
to install a relay for the lights.  Evidently it's done that way in
Europe where lights are brighter.  I had it done about eight years ago
and have had no problems since.

The turn signal-dimmer switch is all one unit and cannot be serviced.
Sticking a wad of cardboard in back of the lever is a temporary and
tacky fix.  Replacing the unit works, but if you've had the problem
once you'll have it again.  A generic relay (Bosch or Wehrle) will do
the job, spliced in line with the wiring coming from the headlights to
the fuse box.  But your switch is shot.  The aftermarket places all
carry it, since it seems to be an item that frequently needs
replacement.

> I've got 2 annoyances I'm trying to find out about on my '81 911SC....

As for the window channel, I don't know, but I'd hesitate to Mickey
Mouse anything.  Check with a good glass or body shop.

Hope this helps, even if it's not the greatest news.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu


P.S.  Sorry about the garbled order of things.

> fix this?  Also, the driver's side window rattles- up or down.  I think 
> it's the plastic piece on the back corner of the glass.  Is there any way 
> to fix this, like 'crimping' the window channel at the top?
> TIA for any advice or instruction :)

> the price for half the fun (not to mention, during the test drive, no one 
> looked at the car- but get back in my baby- and the women once again took 
> notice!
> moral to this story:  I NEED a Porsche to get women :)

Porschephiles #1371                         Tue May 2 16:27:45 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 02:59:31 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 356 Latch Hardware

All the Original 356's I've seen have  the front and rear hood latches
painted the same color as the car. This means, of course, that with time and
use the paint gets scratched off, looks ugly and rusts. Also the paint as it
flakes off tends to get into the latch mechanism and gum up the  works. 
    The Late, Great, Herr Dean Pfundstein (bless his soul), always thought
the latches should be Cad plated instead of painted, and I agree- the latches
DO look and  work better when plated rather than painted.
    This was one of several areas that Dean thought the Factory cheaped out.
Another was the bar that goes across the back  of the bottom  of the rear of
the seats. It's painted, but Dedan always chromed them to match the
chrome-plated side rails of the seats. Again, I agree.
KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro
P.S. Jerry Seinfeld's 1958 Speedster is now travelling across the US of A
towards NYC with a 1972 Porsche Industrial Engine (slightly modified), and,
of course, a new .050 to replace the worn-out, sticky, jerky Original. His
mutated, mis-matched, non-Original 1959/1957 356A engine is now on display
with all the Dealer-induced errors in the Maestro's Museum.

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 22:25:22 +1000
From: dhamilto@ozemail.com.au (David Hamilton-Matthews)
Subject: Porsche Targa Info


Danny, 

 3 years ago I came to the end of a 2 year search for my pefect Porsche. It
was, after exhausting research a 1972 911 "E" Targa. Both the 911 and 912
Targa's were introduced at the 1965 Frankfurt Motor Show, It was dubbed
'Targa' in memory of the Targa Floria, the famous long distance race in
Sicily. The very first models came with a zip out rear plastic window,
unlike the fixed glass models that came later. These plastic rear window
models are rare and I have never heard of one in OZ land.

I picked up my car on the Gold Coast for the amazing price of $20k. The car
only needing work because of my desire to own a most pristine example. My
biggest problem was a rust patch in the offside rear seat well, the cause
was a leaky rear window. This problem of course not restricted to Targa's.

When it comes to prices, the year of manufacture is very important. This is
because of the introduction of the impact bumper model for our friends in
the US. Pre-impact bumper models have, in my mind a more classic and
attractive look, but this I'm sure could be the subject of much debate. Yes
late 70's 911 Targas can fetch upto $50k, but for $50k my money would be on
a mid 70's Carrera Coupe. But that's my opinion only.

Hope this helps...

Regards


David.....


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 02 May 1995 09:01:54 -0500 (EST)
From: "Dave J. Andruczyk" <ANDRUC00@SNYBUFAA.CS.SNYBUF.EDU>
Subject: REG: RE: Porschephiles #1367 Mon May 1 12:52:44 CDT 1995

As per compressors.. Don't buy a craftsman!! They make decent hand tools
but cheap compressors.  The oil-less models they sell don't lasat more than
two, years for obvious reasons. Cambell Hausfield does make good compressors
and reliable, but if you want an alternate route.. There is a company that
sells an Aluminum pump (with cast iron cylinders) for about 199.00 (just the
pump only) that will do anything from 6CFM to 12CFM depending on how fast you
run it. But thats only a good route if you have a spare motor and tank lying 
around. (thats what i had)...
If interested I'll dig up the name of the company that sells that pump..

Dave...
'79 924 (in restoration)

Subject: Re: re; chips and copyright

Stan-

	The culture of performance automobiles has a long history of
owner and third party enhancement. No matter how you read the letter
of the law, the established practice is that auto manufacturers allow folks
to modify their products and sell the mods.

        It's not as if the owners of the SUX2000 are snapping up 
modified 'P' car firmware to use on their production line.

         If anyone should be complaining, it's the coach designers 
who have to look at their art with plastic geegaws popriveted to it :-)

 -bob

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 08:14:02 -0500
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Alternator Quirks? Follow-up

I posted a note a while back about my dimmly illuminated battery light, and
the potential cause.  I also mentioned that most of my concern was due to a
previously bad rebuilt alternator from Vertex and consequent damage.  At this
point, I just want to be fair.

Back in September when the original rebuilt alt was a problem, Mike at Vertex
worked with me in an expedient manner to replace the damaged parts and rush a
new voltage reg ASAP.  Last month (7 months later) when I called with concern
about the alternator core, Mike sent a replacement alternator at no cost and
with no questions.

The point:  I think I Vertex originally sold a rebuilt alternator that slipped
through QA unchecked.  (They need to slap thier suppliers around and shape them
up.)  But, they have worked with me in a very professional and courtious
manner to correct the problems, and they deserve credit for that.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 09:21:05 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Painted latch hardware, 59 A?

Pete says, "I don't know of anyplace or any bolt or hardware on a 356 that is
gold cad plated....

The later C type latches were white cad or zinc plated.... 

At the rear, the receiver bolted to the inside of the engine compartment was
swabbed with black paint. The sheet steel bracket that latched into it,
attached to the engine lid, was painted body color."


Pete, when I had the mechanicals rebuilt on my one-owner '65 356SC at
Stoddard's about 15 years ago, it was returned with gold cad valve covers,
distinctly different (to my chagrin) from the white cad ones it wore when
delivered to them.  Ostensibly, valve covers were routinely replaced on their
rebuilt engines because "they are prone to warp".  (Mine were not warped,
however.)  Whether the gold cad was Stoddard's touch or a copy of the way
some valve covers left the factory I do not know.  As best I can remember
offhand, that's the only gold cad on the car.

As I responded privately to Allen, all the front hood latch components on the
356SC are "galvanized", or zinc plated.

Also, all components of the engine deck lid latch were painted body-color
(both top and bottom pieces).

Bob Joyce
Knoxville, Tennessee
1965 356SC (celebrating its 30th birthday on July 7!)
1988 924S

Date: Tue, 2 May 95 9:57:07 EDT
From: BlaineDeLancey <Blaine.Delancey@lambada.oit.unc.edu>
Subject: Re: E-Z fix??

> I've got 2 annoyances I'm trying to find out about on my '81 911SC....
> Does anyone know what to do when my hi/lo switch likes to stay on hi, 
> even when in the lo position- I'm having to gently wiggle the switch 
> every time I turn to keep the brights from staying on.  Will a shot of CRC 

One thing you can do as a temporary fix is to remove the switch and
inspect it.  The thin pieces of wire in the switch sometimes need to be
rebent so they don't contact each other as easily - can't remember the
details but I've been able to figure it out twice and it's saved me a ton
of cash, as the switch is 70+ of those green things I once had.  Be
gentle.  As to the comment about relays being installed, this is a
physical effect from switching the high beams on and off, not an
electrical problem, although it can cause the switch to fry out
eventually.  I tend to 'signal' other Porsche drivers a lot, and that's a
prime cause.  This was documented in an article in either European Car or
Excellence a while back (Euro Car I think), FWIW.  If you want, I can look
the article up in my index of Porsche-related magazine articles.

Blaine
Check out Carolinas PCA page (Sebring photos up Real Soon Now):
http://tta.com/PCA/Carolinas/homepage.html

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 10:23:56 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Turbos & intercoolers

>Hi Doug,
>
>Not so fast, If you have a large thin intercooler there isn't really much
>more turbo lag. 
>

picky, picky, picky. A thin intercooler won't give as low an exit
temperature, and eventually, the inceased inlet surface area will introduce
too much drag on the car. In the limit, you could just have finned aluminum
plumbing-no lag, and virtually no cooling. I assume what ends up in the car
is a compramise of lag, thermal efficiency, and available space.

So why are there a gazillion aftermarket 930 intercoolers, and NO
aftermarket 951 intercoolers?
Could it be the available space is already filled mit intercooler?


>The 935s had twin turbo to improve the throttle response. 
>
>Bruce Anderson 

ok, but didn't the 934 start with a single turbo?

Is this great, or what? where else can I flame Bruce Anderson?



doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 10:58:32 -0400
From: John Moore <jmoore@pluto.ksc.nasa.gov>
Subject: RE: E-Z fix?? ( 911SC Hi Beams )

About your hi beam problem, I had exactly the same problem on my 83 SC.  If you take the cover off the steering column and find the little box at the end of the light stalk you will see that there are several metal reeds that control the headlights.  You have to figure out which one turns on the high beams and flex it away from the reed that activates it.  I took the entire stalk off the column (this requires a little more disassembly) and performed this procedure.  The amount you need to flex the reed is quite small.  Afterwards, the high beams came on only when I moved the lever.


jmoore
