> Yup, I've had the same problem on an '82 SC.  It's simply a cheep switch.  Best
> answer, replace it for about $95 as I recall.  Work under the steering wheel is
> easy once it's removed, but snaking that one wire back to the ignition switch
> is a bear.  Good luck      Alan Bambina

I replaced mine the first time, as the original had melted its plastic by
the time I got around to it, but the replacement went bad a year later.  I
have gotten a year's use from each of my 'temporary' fixes since then.
I would definitely recommend the cheap fix, as it only requires removing
the steering wheel and plastic covers, no cable-snaking.

Blaine

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 09:41:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: 993 CHMSL

Hi all -

Dave Darling writes in response to:
> >Is the "hoop" spoiler mandatory in order to accommodate the
> >CHMSLBS?
> 
>         I dunno if it's mandatory or not, but every one I saw at the
> Dealer (Carlsen Porsche in Palo Alto, CA) has the basket handle one.
> It looks as if they decided not to use the roof-mounted ones.

Seems we have talked about this before.  I don't remember what Bruce
Anderson told me but I do remember what the service tech at a dealership
said during the 993 overview course he went to at PCNA in Reno.  Seems
there was a problem with the "glass" mounted CHMSL on to the rear window
during production of the cars after the initial few were photographed for
advertising.  The "basket handle" was the quick fix.  I love the idea
about putting it into the trailing edge of the roof line but aren't there
ventilation holes in there already?  Maybe there is room for a few bright
lights though.  I seem to remember seeing the new Turbo with the light
again on the rear window.  Will see what happens when it hits stateside. 

Maybe Bruce can respond again if he has time?  It was good seeing some of 
the oldtimers out at the Automotion swap meet last weekend including 
Bruce.


Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 12:45:39 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Water Cooled Turbos

I know that the 944 Turbo has the water cooled turbine. There is also a timer
that keeps pumping coolant through the turbine for a short while after the
engine has been turned off. 

It is still a VERY good idea to let a turbocharged engine run slowly before
being turned off. This can be done as easily as just driving slowly before
the car is shut down. This has a number of benefits, including slowing the
turbine down (it runs as fast as the exhaust gas flowing through it), and
letting fresh OIL circulate through the turbine, which will help cool the
turbine. My last car was a Buick Grand National, which had 110K miles with
all original engine components. Those cars had a reputation for blowing up at
50K miles, if not properly cared for.

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

- ---------------------
Forwarded message:
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Date: 95-05-01 18:51:30 EDT

    >improves engine life. both saab and porsche introduced intercoolers (and
    >later turbo water cooling) a year (or two?) after the turbos came out.
    
    The water cooling is only for the bearings. It saves you having to run
the
    engine for a few minutes to cool it down after a power run, by cooling
the
    bearings and ensuring the oil doesn't fry in the turbo. It adds nothing
to
    the "coolness" of the inlet charge.

Does anyone know on which models Porsche implemented this feature?  Is it on
the 9[24]4 series as well as the 930s?  And how come we haven't seen a 928
turbo?  Will the Boxster have a turbo incarnation?  Why do they have
interstate
highways in Hawaii?  What's this little chromium switch?

~~x.
NO CARRIER



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 09:47:40 -0700
From: ehab@cisco.com (Ehab Aljandali)
Subject: new 911 Turbo wheels, fact or fiction?


Hey Dudes and Dudettes:

        Have you seen the article on the '96 twin turbo C4 in Autoweek? It
is  nice reading material. BUT, have you noticed that the rim design is
(front or rear) bidirectional?  The new 18" alloys (which are of a patented
build process) have a "twist" in the spokes. This twist points to one
direction viewed from the right hand side, and it points to the apposite
direction viewed from the left hand side. I suspect that Porsche may have
made only one mold (one for rear and one for front) so rims can be used on
either side of the car. I personally like symmetry in a car and hence would
prefer if Porsche had made right and left rims. Not a big deal but a
personal taste. I would like to know for sure thu why they opted to do so!
I checked my new 993 porsche book which has the turbo in it to make sure it
is not the photos in autoweek.... the rims are as explained above.

The article teased my senses and I made a promise to get a used one in 1998
(will suffer with the rims). I am putting money aside already and starving
to death....who wants an 84 911 Targa in about two years?


Cheers,

Ehab.




------------------------------

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 13:01:43 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: '59A Latch Hardware

Thanks to all of you who responded to my query re the subject trivia.  I
think at this point Mr. Pellow has got it right: on an "A" all the latch
hardware, upper and lower is painted.  I've stripped my upper hardware for
the front deck lid and a small amount of factory primer still remains,
seeminly help  confirm that these part were originally painted.  Further to
Harry's point, the factory probably should have plated these parts as the
paint scapes off and in fact as Pete points out, his T-6 has plated parts.

Brents book makes no mention of this subject.  However, the 356 Registry
compilation does have a small section on fitting the latch hardware which
implies these things are painted but didn't make specific mention of years or
models.

Naturally, after 35 years pristine examples are hard to come by and confusion
reigns supreme.

For me, I will have all my stuff painted-I can easily strip it off later
should this prove non-authentic.  Thanks again.

 -Allen Henderson-
Silver '59A Normal
Silver '72 911S

Date: Tue, 02 May 95 10:38:00 PDT

Well, on Sunday my 914-6 project actually drove

1980 RoW, 188 HP, 8.6:1 compression with 40mm

street and autox.

30 degrees at 6000 rpm?

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 14:21:59 -0400
From: JOHNM@icac.org (John Mulligan)
Subject: Need LOW Floor Jack - Thanks

I wanted to thank everyone for their help on using a floor jack on a lowered 
911.

Most of the replies I received suggested buying an insert that fits into the 
original jack slot of a 911. Well, I should have said that my 911 is a 95 
model (993) & *doesn't* have the rocker panel slot found in earlier 911s.

Still, I received two suggestions that will work for me: driving the car up 
onto a small ramp of wood planks and/or removing the metal cup from the 
lifting point of my current Sears jack (this might take an inch of its' 
current height).

There is a third option, but my wife has already told me that she will not 
lift the car at the wheel well while I slide the jack under the car! 

Thanks again for the help,

John

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 12:16:05 -0700

>

noticed
>that when I pulled into my parking spot that there was a weird smell 
and I had
>to press extra hard on the brake pedal to stop the car.  I drove it

>they quit?  Sean  '80 928

Thats exactly what happens, called brake "fade". What can alos happen 
is the brake fluid will boil and get air bubbles in it and make the 
padal spongy.

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 17:19:32 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Turbos & intercoolers

>how long of a cool down time?
>
There are aftermarket "oilers" that run for several minutes, as does the
water pump for water cooled turbos. That's what the cool down lap at track
events is for: cool ALL the machinery down. Wouldn't want a driver to
spontaneously combust because he didn't have time to cool down. I hate when
that happens.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 15:19:32 -0700

Subject: 914 Trials and Tribulations

Well, if anyone remembers, I've got the bad left suspension console 
problem. I think I'll end up buying the used piece from Automobile 
Atlanta and getting it installed ASAP, but this had got me thinking...

My '75 is in pretty decent shape, but still needs some notable rust 
repair. I had the rockers and nearby floor replaced when I bought it, 
along with the battery tray, but it still needs the bottom of the 
firewall repaired, the metal under the sail panels fixed, and there's 
some other less-than-ideal places.

The thought currently bouncing around my addled brain is, get it back 
and working, then search in earnest for an affordable, stripped, 
RUST-FREE shell and then spend time transferring all the parts over. My 
interior is perfect, the engine is pretty good, brakes good, etc, 
etc... Basically if I could find a rolling chassis, with no rust, no 
dents (or minimal dings), no interior, and no engine, for a bit under 
$1000, I'd be very happy and able to turn it into a driver with some 
work.

Any thoughts on this? Am I dreaming on the price? (Especially since in 
I'm in upstate NY - not known for rust-free cars.) I'd probably be 
saving money in the long run, compared to what it'll cost to fix the 
rust on mine. Plus, how is interchangability between a '75 and 
earliers? I don't think I could afford to be picky when changing... 
Will the '75 1.8 w/L-Jetronic be usable in an earlier one, without TOO 
much wiring changes? (I'd prefer to get a '73 or newer...)

Any thoughts would, as always, be very welcome.

Date: Tue, 2 May 95 15:28:36 PDT
From: parker@mprgate.mpr.ca (Ross Parker)
Subject: What to look for...

Hi, all...

I'm going out tomorrow to view a '73 914 2.0L, and I'd like to
gather a little wisdom as to what to watch for...

I *have* owned one before (another '73 2.0), and I think I'm aware of
major rust areas (rear fenders, battery area, etc), but that was 10
years ago and I may be a bit 'rusty' on this (heh heh).

Owner claims the motor has been rebuilt though NOT by a recognized shop
("Friend who is Porsche mechanic") - I'm a bit leery about this, though I
think if all looks and feels good I'd be prepared to risk it.

Owner also claims to have replaced the 1st gear synchro recently.

The car has the 'correct' Fuchs alloys, though only 4, not 5 - I presume
that 5 were standard on the '73 as my other one had 5. Other than this,
I'm told the car is stock.

Owner also claims the carpeting needs replacing - any guesses as to what this
might cost?

Thanks - any pointers I can get would be appreciated!

Date: Tue May  2 14:54:06 1995
From: ci.tcpbridge.center2.center1.rae1%smtpgate@ci.berkeley.ca.us (Ralph Elder )
Subject: Re: 993 CHMSL  (SMTP Id#: 13050) - Reply

I'm sure that I read -somewhere- that the CHMSL was supposed to be at the top
of the rear window, but that there had been a production/installation  problem 
having something to do with the window seal.  Therefore -The "baskethandle".
Supposedly, this was to be fixed and the roof/window version (MUCH better
looking IMO) is gonna make it onto the turbo and then on to future 2WD and
4WD 993s.   

I don't like the "baskethandle" myself, but it's still a lot better than the "E.T."
thing on the cabs.  

BTW has anybody seen a 4WD version yet?  Last I heard, they still hadn't
shipped any over here because they are fiddling with the F/R differential settings
or sumthin'. 
 (was this vague or what?...)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 20:01:49 -0400
From: Charl1@aol.com
Subject: Unmarked "turn switch" on 911

Stephen,

    Regarding the unmarked "turn switch" on the 911 dashboard: Sounds like
you're describing the control knob for the intermittent wipers. They are
mentioned in the drivers manual (if you got one). If you turn it until it
just "clicks", the wipers will come on fairly frequently, turning the switch
a little more will make them come on less frequently. 
    My 911 SC is a 1980 but I am assuming that your 1981 is similar enough for
 this to be of some help.
    By the way, congrats on buying a 911. Also, as far as the rear defogger
goes, on mine, (I may be wrong, but...) I think it is strictly push pull and
there are 3 positions: off, low, and high.
    Hope I was of some help.
Charlie

- --Boundary-8533919-0-0--

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 20:58:43 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Entering the Corner

In my last posting, I discussed the importance of learning how to come out of
a corner.  It is the foundation on which the rest of turn is built.  I
explained that there is a point in the corner that you pick up the throttle
and accelerate, as fast as possible, past the apex and out of the corner.
 That point, the transition point, separates the entry from the exit.  Once
you have reached that point, it is all exiting the turn.  That provides you
with 90% of your speed, and once you can accomplish this consistently, and
safely, you are ready for the next step, entering the turn.

Working on entering the turn is the first step for the intermediate driver to
master.  The reason that I urge you novice drivers to not worry about
carrying any entry speed, is that you must know exactly where the transition
point is, and how fast you want to be going at that point, and at what
attitude relative to the apex, BEFORE you can figure out how deeply (read
fast) you can stuff your car into the turn!  You may be able to get into a
groove if your instructor leads you every step of the way, and that is his
job, but I want you to learn how to do this for yourself.  That way, you will
learn it more completely, and you will be able to recognize minor errors
before they turn into big mistakes (read spins).  

Remember that almost every corner is two separate entities, decelerating into
the transition point, and accelerating out from the transition point.  Once
you know where that transition point is, and at what speed you want to be
going, you can work on shortening the time it takes you to get there.  By
this I mean waiting to brake later, and using the weight shift of the car to
improve it's grip, so that you can enter the turn carrying more speed.
 Approaching transition point, you will have the car slowed enough, and
rotated enough, that once there, you can floor the accelerator, and exit the
turn under full power.  If this technique sounds like my discourse on
trailbraking, it is.  Unless your car has terminal oversteer (and if so, fix
it because oversteer on the track is slow) you will find that to carry more
entry speed, you will have to continue your deceleration all the way up to
the transition point.  That does not mean that you will be braking heavily
all the way, it just means that the car will be slowing down until you reach
the transition point.

Some of you will be adamant about braking in a straight line.  You can
certainly brake hard in a straight line, and then ease off the brakes and
turn-in.  This will minimize the weight shift, and leave you in a stable
position to transfer to the gas.  If your car oversteers, you will have to do
this.  But it means that you will be going slower in the entry of the turn
than the "trailbraker", because the rear of your car will slide out when you
make that initial turn-in unless you are going slower.  But, as you improve
on this technique, you will find yourself "leaning on the car " harder, and
will rely more on the weight shift to get your turn-in done.  Then you will
need the transfer to the gas to keep the rear from sliding out.  Remember
that the more speed you carry into the corner, the harder it will be to get
the car to turn-in.  You will need as much of the weight of the car on the
nose as possible to get the front tires to grip.  That means that you must
still do some braking.  As soon as the car rotates, you will have to get on
the gas to give the rear tires grip.

Some final points on this.  There are always some turns that do not apply,
and there are always degrees to which you will apply this technique.  On some
very fast sweepers, I actually brake in a straight line, and step back down
on the gas *before* I turn-in.  The reason for this is that I want maximum
stability and grip on the sweeper, and I want to drive the car through the
turn.  I do not want any rotation, or slide, and I definitely do not want the
rear to get light.  Mild understeer is definitely desirable here.  Now
entering hairpin turns, I will continue braking *very* aggressively deep into
the turn.  I want to brake as late as possible because it's a slow turn, and
get maximum rotation to get through such a tight turn.  I will wait for the
rear to "come around" a little before I pin it with the gas.  This is the
method that the pros use to "slide it " through the turn.  It's the quickest
way through at a hairpin.  For the average turn, it's up to you and how your
car handles that will determine how much you will brake into it.

If anyone has any other specific driving questions for discussion, let me
know.


Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 23:41:19 -0400
From: Red912@aol.com
Subject: Re: E-Z fix??

Buzz asks-"Does anyone know what to do when my hi/lo switch likes to stay on
hi, even when in the lo position"...? This happened to my '89 Carrera and I
found out (through P-Philes) that the dimmer switch on the steering column
was T.U. I paid about $80 for a new one. It's not too difficult to
replace...if you've got really long fingers that bend backwards and you can
see around corners into really tight places : ). Actually it took about an
hour to do and wasn't that bad (in retrospect). One thing; make a real good
drawing of which wires go where on the headlight switch in the dash.
Rich Lambert

'78 SC for.   I don't know what the other folks on Pfiles think, but I find
it hard to believe that an SC as described above has an asking price of
'only' $15k. If it had 59k, 79k, 99k, or greater miles, it would make more
sense.

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 01:47:54 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: E-Z Fix

Blaine says, "...I replaced mine the first time, as the original had melted
its plastic by the time I got around to it, but the replacement went bad a
year later.  I have gotten a year's use from each of my 'temporary' fixes
since then...."

When you melt a switch repeatedly like this, it's usually a sign you're
running too many amps through it.  Have you diddled with the bulbs in the
headlights, or  added driving lights to the same circuit without using a
relay?  If so, a relay will solve your problem (and it's certainly a whole
lot simpler and cheaper than replacing those switches!)

Bob Joyce
Knoxville, Tennessee
1965 356SC
1988 924S

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 02:06:17 -0400
From: FiewVinder@aol.com
Subject: What, A Great Mechanic?

     Recently my 944 needed a cam tower gasket replaced, as well as belts and
oil cooler gaskets replaced.  
    I'm currently residing in Murray, KY, a sprawling metropolis of 10,000 or
so residents, located in western KY.  When I became aware of my need for
service, I wrote off the idea that I could find a competent local mechanic.
 I assumed I would have to have it towed to Nashville (2.5 hrs away) for
service.  But then.......one day I was out and drove by a repair shop that
had two other 944's sitting outside.  I stopped and inquired, and sure
enough, the proprietor, Mike Brothers was an experienced Porsche mechanic.
 In fact he has worked at a total of 5 Porsche dealerships during his career.
 
     He was professional from the beginning and even allowed me to order my
own parts(saving myself approx $200).  He allowed me to shadow him while he
worked on it, and took the time to teach me alot about the car.  His
attention to detail was relentless, and in fact, showed me a couple of
instances of the dealership screwing up on previous service attempts.  
     I realize that a very small portion of this audience lives near Murray,
but to those who do, I highly recommend this mechanic, who is skilled, fair,
and extremely reasonable.  I could go on and on......His number is
502-762-0791.  He is located on Industrial Road in Murray KY near the Land
Between the Lakes Region(2.5 hrs from Nashville, 1 hour from Paducah, 2 hrs
from Memphis, and 3 hours from St. Louis).  Tickled pink in the Boonies,
Casey Fox

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 02:08:46 -0400
From: Mrbill456@aol.com
Subject: Why all this Valve Adj: '71 2.2l E

The recent rash of valve adjustment discussions inspired me to see what
Porsche reccomended for my early 911.

I would like to quote the Service Schedule for the 1971 Type 911E (2.2l). [1]
 This table contains other maintenance items as well. My comments are in ( ).

6,000 to 6,600 mi. from new (or after rebuild) 
 Check valve clearance
 Check compression
 Check rocker arm shaft tightness (torque)
 Check ignition (points, plug gap, etc.,etc)
 Check fuel system (MFI linkage, MFI adj.)
 Change oil/filter, clean strainer, transmission oil,fuel filter
 Check brake system
 Check belt tensions (alt. and MFI pump)
         Check wheel alignment

Then, repeat every 12,000 miles except for brakes, all filters, oil and wheel
alignment which retain the 6,000 mile.

This would mean the valves should stay in adjustment for 12,000 miles for a
normal (whatever that is) 911E. Of course more intensive maintenance is at
the discretion of the owner. I chose to do all of this stuff every spring at
the minimum and I change the oil (Mobil 1) every fall before long periods of
winter (salt on the roads) inactivity.

How many of us have had our rocker arms torqued lately??

Flame Away.....

Bill Hutton
1971 911E Coupe 9111200038

[1] Porsche 911E Owners Manual USA: Type 911E Edition VIII/69, p. 57.

>
>>It is still a VERY good idea to let a turbocharged engine run slowly before
>>being turned off. This can be done as easily as just driving slowly before
>>the car is shut down. This has a number of benefits, including slowing the
>>turbine down (it runs as fast as the exhaust gas flowing through it), and
>>letting fresh OIL circulate through the turbine, which will help cool the
>>turbine. My last car was a Buick Grand National, which had 110K miles with
>>all original engine components. Those cars had a reputation for blowing up at
>>50K miles, if not properly cared for.
>        Hmmm.... I almost bought an '89 951 with a HKS Turbo Timer which
kept the engine on for however long it was programmed, after the engine was
switched off. Unfortunately, it was a lemon and now I'll probably be getting
a '87. For  exactly how long should one let the engine cool down? 1,2,...5
minutes? In the 944t manual, they say that letting the engine idle builds up
excessive heat... then wouldn't this defeat the purpose of a device such as
the Turbo Timer? Anywayz, I just wanna know how long I should drive SLOWLY
before shutting down.:)

Date: Wed, 03 May 95 07:20:10 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 performance upgrades

> My '83 944 is completely stock at the moment.  I'm intersted in milking a
> little extra out of it, however.  It has 60,500 miles on it.  I am most
> interested in retaining its' reliability.  
>      1)  My local mechanic mentioned that the addition of headers on this car
> could add 20HP.  Is this wishful thinking?

Completely wishful thinking.  Unless you completely change the major
parameters of your engine (displacement, cam, larger valves, enlarged ports,
etc.) you're not going to get more than about 5 hp.

And don't waste your time with chipping the car. Your normally aspirated,
sans knock sensor motor will find no more than about 5 hp with the best chip
available (at least that has been my experience...)

>      2)  I would apprecite any suggestions concerning this or other possible
> performance upgrades.  How about carbs?  Can I expect a considerable
> increase?  What kind of headaches am I looking at when scraping FI for carbs?
>  Any response would be greatly appreciated.

Don't do it. Keep your car original. Motronic FI, even the early 944 type,
is vastly superior to just about any carburetor setup you can devise for it,
and, btw, you'll be in mostly uncharted waters...

Bottom line, the best performance increases you can do for your 83 944 are:

1) Brakes - Carbon Fiber Brakes are best for the track. I have had good
experience with Repco Metal Masters for the street.

2) Tires - Get the best tire you can afford. For the track, a lot of people
are very happy with the BFG CompTA R1 and the Yoko A008PRSII tires.

3) Driver - Get as much education that you can afford. PCA Driver ed is just
about the cheapest seat time available.  And, that education is
portable...it doesn't disappear when you sell your old car.

Last, after you have done all of the above and are still dissatisfied with
the performance of your 83 944, sell it and buy a Turbo. It's cheaper to buy
a car with all the goodies than to try to add the goodies one at a time...

- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (needs work)
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 07:59:32 -0500 (CDT)
From: Geert Pallemans <pallemag@daisy.ac.siue.edu>
Subject: Re: re; chips and copyright 



Peter,

	I hope you are right, but it does seem to me that you 
are wearing some heavy-duty rose colored prescription glasses. 
I don't claim to be an expert in copyright/patent-related 
legal matters, but your analogy with computer software licensing 
stops making sense as soon as you add a third party (that profits from 
the copyrighted/patented material by means of non-intended use of the 
material) to the equation. Mainly my point is that if I were to write a 
book on how to make great ice-cream, the instance of the reader who starts a 
parlor and becomes rich is a success-story that I would definitely 
mention on the back-cover of my second edition. On the other hand, the 
individual who copied my description of how to make a unique sherbert, 
added one ingredient, and went to press has violated copyright laws.
Don't get me wrong ; I am all for more varieties of ice-cream and 
sherberts, and feel quite capable of discerning which flavors I like and 
which ones I don't. I did feel, however, compelled to point out the 
seemingly biased logic/non-logic of the matter.  

Geert Pallemans

On Mon, 1 May 1995, Peter Wales wrote:
> 
> >     What also interests me is that the aftermarket tuners basically copy the
> >OEM ROM then modify it a little. This would have to be copyright infringement,
> >however maybe the factories don't discourage the Chippers as a means of
> >avoiding having to honor their warranties...
> 
> The question of copyrights is one I find interesting. If I take a chip out
> and copy it, have I broken the law?  If I put the copy in the car, only one
> version of the software is being used. I think this is like having software
> for your PC. As long as only one copy is in use, whether at the office, on
> the train or at home, it's not illegal. You have a licence to use the
> software when you buy it.
> 
> If I make a different version of that software and sell it, is it against
> the law? If the buyer has to discard one set of software, to use another,
> surely the same applies in that only one set can be used at one time.
> 
> I think (hope) this is why the manufacturers have left us alone.
> Peter Wales
> Superchips Inc                          "Timing is everything"
> 
>

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 10:00:33 -0400
From: BrucePor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Turbos & intercoolers

Hi Doug,

The people who make and use the huge thin intercoolers claim tremendous
efficiencies for these intercoolers when compared to the older styles. I have
to admit I haven't done any testing myself and can only go along with their
claims. 

I have some friends who have made larger intercoolers for the 951 by welding
to of the 951 cores together. If you are going to try to get a lot more power
out of one of those engines you will need more intercooler. They have also
come up with some larger more efficient radiators for the same problem. 

Yes, the 934 and the first 935s had single turbos, but they went to twins to
improve the drivability in 1977 on the factory 935 and 1978 on the customer
cars. 

Bruce Anderson 

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 10:19:00 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Intercoolers

>I looked into this when I was trying to figure where I'd install the
>remote sensor for a radar detector. I finally figured that there was
>precious little exposure to both the radiator and the intercooler and
>that it just wasn't worth robbing any of it for a detector and bracket.
>
>Doug Donsbach, Knoxville, TN
>'88 951
>'88 735i

I know what you mean. Mine is mounted on top of brake cooling duct. its on
the lower outside part of the nose. the detector looks through the plastic
nose. The nose piece is insulating so there is no attenuation of the RF. Of
course you do suffer in sensitivity by lowering the detector closer to the
ground, but its offset by never having to worry about having the damn thing
stolen.

Note- If you do mount an inside type detector on the outside, make sure you
seal it up good, and don't use RTV. RTV contains vinegar, which will rot
your circuit board, and make the quartz crystal go poopy (that's the
technical term).



doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Get thee to a drivers school. That will be the biggest performance gain you
can get for the nut behind the wheel. then you can try wider tires on the
stock wheels, maybe stiffer sway bars, springs and shocks, etc. you want to
keep upgrading yourself as you upgrade the car. there must a place in the
archives for this stuff.

------------------------------

Date: 2 May 95 11:51:49 -0400
From: mvmas@mvujc.att.com
Subject: Re: 914 Brake Caliper Trouble

>	I have a 74  914 2.0 - amongst the list of small quirks my car has
>is a problem with one of the rear calipers.  When adjusting (5mm allen, I 
>think), I cannot get the caliper to adjust properly.  Either the adjustment
>is too tight and the pads won't let go of the rotor or too loose and pads 
>won'tgrab  (BY THE WAY - this is for the parking brake!!!).  I tried 
>adjusting
>the cable and that was to no avail.  
>
>	I'd use a brick when I park, but the DMV in Connecticut wants to
>make sure my parking brake works before they give me a registration.
>
>	Thanks,
>
>	Darrin Lucas
>       74  914  2.0

I can think of 3 things that could cause what you're describing, i.e.
pads are either too loose or too tight, given that you can move the
pad both ways with the adjuster.

1) Forgive me if this is too simple, but you know that there is an
adjustment that must be done through the trailing arm?  If you just
play with the one on the outboard side of the caliper you would get the
symptoms described.

2) The cable is adjusted such that when you pull the handle only one
of the caliper levers is being pulled.  This can happen (even though the
Y-piece behind the seat is there) because the springs on the calipers
can be different strength.  Get under the car and look at the stop pins
for the lever directly on the bottom of the calipers.  Look while the
parking brake is on and when it is off.  On my car you can feel the
difference between them.

3) Something is stuck so that the lever is always "pulled".  Again you
must look underneath at the stop pins when the brake is on and off.

If the pistons can move both ways with the adjustments, you are most
of the way there.  Also, I have found that the spec of .008" of play
on the rear pads is excessive, and makes the brake pedal and parking
brake throw longer, so I get it down to about .002" like the front
brakes.

Mark Skala              '73 914
mvmas@mvujc.att.com     '88 924S  	


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 10:42:25 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Turbos & intercoolers

>I have some friends who have made larger intercoolers for the 951 by welding
>to of the 951 cores together. If you are going to try to get a lot more power
>out of one of those engines you will need more intercooler. They have also
>come up with some larger more efficient radiators for the same problem. 
>
>Bruce Anderson 


I thought about that. Did they just seal up one inlet and one outlet, or
were the ends reshaped?
more lag is just what I need. when I'm really driving, well, on, I find I
can mash the pedal almost as soon as I'm off the brakes (at least in the
sweepers), and the turbo spools up just right.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 08:59:18 -0800
From: s921142@hp720a.csc.cuhk.hk (Chris Robyn)
Subject: water-cooled turbos

Porsche made a big to-do about the 951's internal "cooler" for the turbo
system that would remain on after the engine had been shut off.  Even so, I
let mine idle for a few minutes until the temp gauge drops a tick.  This is
much better than my Dad's '83 Saab turbo--the one without the intercooler.

- --Chris
'86 951

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 14:44:41 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 911T

>what model year range 911T targa would have a 2.2 liter engine decal on the
>rear window- approximate value of the car with 83k miles (5 digit
>odometer), a *few* rust bubbles here and there, and apparently reliable
>enough to be a daily driver?

        70 or 71.  70 has carbs, not sure about 71--either Webers or MFI.
A very cherry example was sold in the SF Bay Area for 10K about 6 months
ago.  It was probably in better shape than the one you describe.
        In the Rust Belt, values *may* be higher--early 70's 911 (and
earlier) tend to rot out easily up there.

Date: Wed, 03 May 95 13:00:00 PDT
From: "Lai, Hubert" <hl@msmail.orsil.ubc.ca>
Subject: Broken-Off Screw


Well, I finally got around to trying to change the burned out foglight bulb 
on my '83 944.  Unfortunately, it turned out that the head of one of the 
screws holding the lens on was badly corroded, so I had to resort to 
drilling the head of the screw off.

That worked fine and I was able to remove the foglight and change the bulb. 
 I even got new factory screws to replace the old ones (since they were all 
starting to look kind of ratty).  I figured it would be a simple matter of 
using a pair of vice grips to remove the remains of the one screw that I had 
drilled the head off of.

WRONG!  The screw was in there good and tight.  No wonder I wasn't able to 
successfully use a screwdriver on it in the first place!  Anyhow, I managed 
to break the screw off flush with the surface into which it was screwed.

Now what?  Any ideas on how to get it out?

Muchos gracias for any advice from the list.

<=- Hubert

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 13:15:35 -0700 (MDT)
From: Wade Guthrie <wade@realm2.realm.net>
Subject: Re: 911T

The original poster said:
>what model year range 911T targa would have a 2.2 liter engine decal on the
>rear window- approximate value of the car with 83k miles (5 digit
>odometer), a *few* rust bubbles here and there, and apparently reliable
>enough to be a daily driver?

Dave Darling said:
> 70 or 71.  70 has carbs, not sure about 71--either Webers or MFI.

The 70 and 71 Ts both had carbs and 2.2 liter engines.

> A very cherry example was sold in the SF Bay Area for 10K about 6 months
> ago.  It was probably in better shape than the one you describe.

You should be able to get a T in 'streetable' shape for $6K or so (YMMV)
in Southern California.  Check out the 911 FAQ 
(ftp://ftp.tta.com/pub/porschephiles/FAQs/911.faq) for further info on
these cars and for places to check for availablility.

Date: 3 May 1995 13:27:16 -0800
From: "Rodger Keesee" <Rodger.Keesee@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re: 78 911SC performance mod

Hi James,
At the suggestion of Stan the list man, I just picked up Bruce Anderson's 911
Performance Handbook.  
Boy, what a wealth of info, a few upgrades mentioned for your engine:
    retrofitting the stock exhaust with a pre 73 one
    Changing the CIS to Webers
    Using 96mm pistons to increase discplacemnt to 3.2l
That's off the top of my head so I'm not sure about the numbers.  There is
alot more info the book.  Enjoy.

there are small rust repairs to be done.  I was wondering if anyone is
familiar with such a substance, what it is best suited for, and where it
can be obtained.

I will be going over my '76 from head to toe and would like to defer small
rust repairs until this winter.  I want to prepare the areas to be worked
on with a wire-brush treatment and a sealer.  I was just wondering whether
or not this foam filler would be a good short-term solution to prevent water
entry on any exposed areas.

		front mount oil cooler plumbing,

		and no major structural rust. :)

wiring is half-assed and I'm surprised it ever passed inspection.  Therefore,

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 18:06:00 -0400 (EDT)
From: "H. Wilson Busby" <m950870@watkins.nadn.navy.mil>
Subject: Re: Broken-Off Screw

Hubert-
	Get something called an easy-out... you drill a small hole in the 
culprit and drive this sucker into it, since it's threaded in the reverse 
direction of the screw- and the bad boy comes out.  I've only seen these 
for bolts- but you might can get one for screws...
or you can do like I did with the door lock knob in my 911- drill a 
SLIGHTLY smaller than the screw sized hole in the old screw, thread it 
with a tap- and fit a smaller screw into it (if all else fails- this'll 
work :)
 -buZZ

Porschephiles #1374                         Thu May 4 02:00:10 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 19:14:16 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Re-Finishing Fuchs

>I was wondering if any of you have tackled the job of refinishing your
Fuchs.

No, but I'm about to.

>Has anyone ever had experience doing this?  Is it truly dipped or are they
set
>in a tub with the paint poured in around them?  It's a semigloss black but
what
>would be the best "type" of paint to use to match the original finish?

I bought some of Wurth's Matte Black Lacquer Spray paint.  It seems to be
a great match for the factory shade of black - not too flat, not too glossy.
 I
have yet to actually paint my wheels, although I did paint one of my hub
caps.  It seems to be a really good match.  The thing slowing me down at the
moment (other than laziness) is that I'm not sure what is the best way to
mask my wheels (7x15s).  Masking off the wheel at the point where the black
stops is right on a curved portion of the wheel.  I am tempted (and would 
like some opinions here - hint, hint) to paint the wheel black all the way
down to within about 10mm of the lip.  This is how my 6x15s are painted
and, if nothing else, the would "match". 

>Any advice would be more than appreciated.

Yeah, uh, me too.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 16:30:35 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Re-Finishing Fuchs

Masking the wheels at the right place is not impossible if you use a
fine tape at the line.  3M makes a fine line tape that works well.

Believe it or not, Orchard Supply's Satin Black isn't bad either.  Not
as authentic as Wurth's, but it's embarrassingly cheap.  I haven't put
my Fuchs wheels to hard use since painting them, but I've used the OSH
paint on the satin black area of one of my inside doors and on a set
of hubcaps.  Still, if I were doing the wheels again I'd use the real
thing!

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

>what model year range 911T targa would have a 2.2 liter engine decal on the
>rear window- approximate value of the car with 83k miles (5 digit
>odometer), a *few* rust bubbles here and there, and apparently reliable
>enough to be a daily driver?

MHO is that it's unlikely to be 83k and more likely to be 183k miles
unless it really looks great.  OTOH if it's not driven in the winter
it could  have relatively low miles.  OTO,OH if it's only driven
in summer why does it have rust bubbles?

Interpreting the signals on an old car reads rather like a mystery novel.  Be
prepared to run away fast. Even a few rust bubbles can mean more rust work
than the car is worth, and if it has a tired engine, it could easily need
twice what it's worth to keep it viable.  A few *visible* rust bubbles probably
means more rust somewhere and it doesn't take  much to make you wish you hadn't
been born (to use Stan's phrase).

Moral of the story:  Be very suspicious and assume there is bad news
to be found until you can prove there is none.

Have fun and good luck,

Vol

- --

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 19:57:24 -0400

Hey,

Just to dampen yours (or your friend's) spirits a little - I looked at a real
low mileage SC a few years ago.  I think it was an '80 model with about
26k miles on it.  I didn't buy it, but did see it one day in the pcar shop I
hang out in every once and while.  Seeing this very low mileage car in the
shop, I asked what was wrong with it - the mechanic replied "Five broken
head studs!".  It seems the car sat around for so long that the head studs
corroded and ended up breaking once the car was used on a daily basis 
again.

Did the '83s have the epoxy coated studs?  Maybe this would mitigate this
problem. It is probably safe to say, though, that extremely low mileage can
have its own set of problems just like extremely high mileage.

Sorry for playing the "devil's advocate"...

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 19:58:24 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 78 911SC performance mods help

> I want to get some more power out of my 3.0 in my 78 911SC.  The engine is 
> totally stock.  I'm not sure what to do and or in what order.  Can anyone 
> recommend some enhancements that I can make that are reasonable $ wise?  

If you're in CA, or any other location with CARB style emissions
restrictions, there are none. Gotta keep the stock intake and exhaust,
and anything else you can do involves serious engine mods and even
more serious bucks.

If you can do it, then going to SSI exhaust and a reasonable low
restriction muffler will add 10-15 HP, and probably not cost more
than $1500 or so. If that doesn't fall in the "reasonable" range,
best get re-calibrated on what it takes to do things with this car.

Stan

the rear spoiler. My mechanic tells me that I can drive the car safely

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 20:50:36 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Campbell & Hausfield any good?

Yo Trond,

Campbell Hausfeld compressors are all over.  I have owned a couple of 
single stage SEARS and they had Campbell Hausfeld compressors on them.  I 
consider them light duty.  They will be alright for my use as a homeowner 
with an advanced garage.  For continueous duty however I would consider 
the following:  Quincy, DeVilbiss, Le Roi, or Ingersoll-Rand.  Top-rate 
names with top-rate prices.  Match your use with CFM rates of delivery at 
pounds of pressure.  

Good luck.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Hey,

I got my copy of the new "1974-1989 911,912E & 930
Porsche Authenticity Series" book today.  It is just like
the authenticity books for the early 911s and the 914, etc.

The book seems to be really thorough - as long as you own
a US SPEC car!  There is very little in the book about the
european models, except some passing references here and 
there.  One item, for instance, is the oil pressure gauges.
The author goes into alot of detail covering all of the
different oil pressure gauges used over the years.  The one
in my car isn't listed.  Mine is labelled "DRUCK" and the
scale is from 0 - 10.  The ventilation controls in my car
don't bear much resemblance to the pictures in the book
either.  Hmmmm.

I'm sure I'm being too picky, but what the heck...

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 00:15:31 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Re E-Z Fix

Blaine, here's the original message:

Blaine says, "...I replaced mine the first time, as the original had melted
its plastic by the time I got around to it, but the replacement went bad a
year later.  I have gotten a year's use from each of my 'temporary' fixes
since then...."

When you melt a switch repeatedly like this, it's usually a sign you're
running too many amps through it.  Have you diddled with the bulbs in the
headlights, or  added driving lights to the same circuit without using a
relay?  If so, a relay will solve your problem (and it's certainly a whole
lot simpler and cheaper than replacing those switches).

Bob Joyce
Knoxville, Tennessee
Bob356@aol.com
1965 356SC
1988 924S

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 23:58:56 -0400
From: ZWRN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Re-Finishing Fuchs

I repainted the Fuchs on my 73 911 using Wirth spray . They really came out
better than I expected.  The secret (at least to me) was given to me by my
expert bodyman.  Use 3M nylon masking tape for the initial maskoff.  This
tape (blue) is only 1/4 inch and very thin. After this is used to follow over
this with 1in regular tape (only 3M, it doesn't leave any residue. The thin
nylon edge gives an almost feathered edge  and if you spray with several thin
coats, it almost duplicates the "dipped" look... Let me know how your's come
out!!
                  
                                              Paul Zwerner
                                        zwerner@rosevc.rose-hulman.edu

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 00:53:46 -0400
From: MitchSF@aol.com
Subject: 911SC Value - Update

1983 911SC, 29K miles.  Asking 15K - South Florida

Thanks for the many replies to my previous posting.

We inspected the car this afternoon, and as usual, it was not as described.  

The first thing I checked was the seats, and they certainly looked like they
had more than 29K miles on them.  But the gauges were the give away.  The
speedometer was cleaner than the other gauges, the white lettering was
obviously not as aged as on the original gauges, so obviously it was replaced
29K miles ago.  How much mileage was put on the car before?  Apparently,
those complete books and records don't go back before 29K miles!.

The car was repainted, and the painter didn't bother to remove the front
fender to windshield frame gaskets ( I guess another 20 seconds of labor
would have been too much to ask for!).

The right rear fender had a small paint bubble, and it was obvious that the
car had some body work.

The A/C didn't work, and the sunroof had its probems opening.

The good stuff:

The car drove well.  The interior is OK (other than seats), and it doesn't
appear that the car was in any major accidents.  A few small oil leaks
(probably oil return tubes).

Some paint work is in order, but probably not a complete repaint.  

Tomorrow it gets checked out by a Porsche mechanic, but since my friend has
the resources to buy something newer, he'll probably pass on this one and
look for a 87+ Carrera. 

Mitch Feig 
1976 911S

(25-30 minutes one way) half highway half city driving.

(realized I can't afford it), BMW 635 csi, Miata, and also the 911.

4. I was going to borrow 11k and buy a '91 Miata (poor substitue), but
realized much to my delight, I could buy an early '80s Porsche 911 instead!

privately or to the list if appropriate.

Date: Tue, 2 May 1995 08:31:49 -0400
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: What's it all about, Bartie...?

Gerry (of Laurel, MD) provides Yer Kindly ol' Unka Bart another opportunity
to beat the drum for the Porschephiles Phund, when he writes: 

[snip]

> Are you in charge of the Porsche fund? Where do I send my contribution?

Thanks Gerry, for this opportunity!  Below, I shall reveal all (read this to
the tune of "Alfie", "What's it all about, Bartie...?"):

You 133 payed-up Patrons and Members can delete this...

To you Old and New Porschephile-members (who are wondering
what all this talk of money for a *free* list is all about...)
Greetings!

Porschephiles has steadily grown to a membership of *OVER* 1200 members,
generating traffic of more than 68,000 messages per *day*, which is more
traffic than MCI handles!

This volume of traffic is eating a significant chunk of Stan's T-1
service.  In addition, it now requires that a machine be dedicated to
handle this traffic.  This machine is old, nearing the end of its service
life, and should be replaced.

Not to put too fine a point of this, this eats into the Listmeister's
livelihood, and, amigos, that ain't right.  We owe Stan an inestimable
debt of gratitude for freely providing this service at no cost for the
past 5.5 years.  The very least we can do to show our gratitude is to
take as much of the capital burden upon ourselves as possible.

We have established a Not-for-profit bank account with my bank in
Crofton, Maryland, to accumulate the funds, and are asking that each
member who is concerned for the survival of Porschephiles, to contribute
what they can.  I have suggest appropriate donations would be $15 for
Students, $50 for Employed people, and $100 for those who wish to be
considered Patrons.

*Nobody* has to contribute anything.  We are trying to acquire the funds
to build the infastructure to ensure the survival of Porschephiles
independent of any member.

I don't have firm figures for the costs we are facing, and that doesn't
bother me a bit. I do know that Stan has made the service available to
the group, using the capital resources that he depends upon to earn his
daily bread, and is begining to feel the strain.

So where do the suggested contribution numbers come from?  Can you say
"Rectal Data?"  It is my sense that a Student should be able to afford
$15.  If a poor starving Stoont can cough up $15, it isn't far out of
line for a Working person, who can afford both a love of Porsches and
access to the 'net, to be able to pony up $50.  If you want to do more,
then $100 seemed like a nice, tidy round number.

I don't think it's anal-retentive to recognize those who dig deeper.  I
have assured all that no one's name or contribution level will be
published *unless* they instruct me to do so.  NOBODY *HAS* TO CONTRIBUTE
ANYTHING!

I also know (I've been investigating the costs of becoming a Service
provider on the 'net, and) it's not cheap.  Last week's InfoWorld has a
comparison of two package servers, one from BBN, and the other a Sun
Netra.  We're looking at $7-10K just for the box and software.  I don't
believe that Mailing list Software was in those figures, but I do know
that they do *not* include T-1 service.  As we determine what the blivid
(5 lbs in a 3 lb bag) of stuff totals out to be, you will be advised.

So what If you don't send anything?  You're *still* a Porschephile, with
all the privilidges and rights pertaining thereto.  As long as the
service survives...

If you want to ensure the survival of this organization, and I sure as
hell do, then send what you can.  Many folks have asked what would be
appropriate to send, and I've tried to offer guidelines.

So What do you get out of this?  How about a nice shiny *Number*,
reflecting the order in which I receive your check?  Whatever
organization we form to shelter the funding under, this number will be
your membership number.  You get to be a *charter* member of whatever it
becomes.  Impress your Friends!  Be *attractive* to Members of your
favorite Gender!  Be known as a *True* Porschephile...

And, how about *Satisfaction* that you've been part of one of the *great*
happenings on the 'net?

Finally, the "membership" issue.  By 3/18/95, we must apply to the IRS
for Non-Profit Organization status. (tick...tick...tick) I'm the guy in
the barrel here.  We need to decide what kind of an organiztion we will
be.  Here, again, you can be a PORSCHEPHILE and not join any more
organizations.  Many of us would like to be the Electronic Frontier
Region of PCA, but this is not universal. Most of the Non-US folks are
not interested in affiliating with PCA, and that's no problem either.

Everyone *Can* send a donation; *NOBODY* has to!  Everybody can Join
(whatever orgainzation we decide); again, *NOBODY* has to...there is
enough interest in the EFR business that we *can* go that route if
required to keep my butt out of the [deleted] grasp of the IRS.

Finally, for you good souls who want to contribute:  The bank folks would
rather that you send the checks to me, made out to

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 01:33:42 -0400
From: MitchSF@aol.com
Subject: Re: Re-Finishing Fuchs

The best way to mask Fuchs weels is to use a liquid mask available at auto
body (and even R/C model) shops.
First, paint the line with the liquid mask, and let it dry.  Don't paint too
much past the paint edge, toward the center.
Then run an Exacto knife around the edge, exactly on the paint edge.
Remove the mask on the paint-side of the edge.
Use masking tape and paper to mask the rest of the wheel.
Paint - If using a spray can, warm to about 100 degrees in water.
If painting with gloss, it's probably a good idea to cut the paint at the
seam with an Exacto knife, before removing the mask.
If you have a steady hand, this will leave a factory-clean seam!

Mitch Feig
1976 911SC  

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1375                         Thu May 4 13:41:33 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 01:06:01 -0600
From: tabel@cyberport.net (Tom Abel)
Subject: Broken Screw

Regarding small broken screws, sometimes it works to file the broken screw 
flush with the part.  Then center punch, drill and tap to the original size 
as though the broken screw were virgin metal.  If you are lucky either the 
scew will turn out after relieving the internal stress by drilling it, or 
the tap will follow the original threads.  You could also end up with a mess 
in which case you should drill it oversize, fill it with epoxy, grease the 
threads of the screw and let the epoxy set around the screw.  Because it is 
greased, you should be able to turn it out again.  Just some things that 
have worked for me if the gods looked upon me favorably and the moon and 
planets were in line at the time.
Tom Abel
Abel Engineering
212 Segiah Way
Kalispell, Mt. 59901   (406) 752-7665


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 03:06:57 -0400
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Refinishing Fuchs Wheels

Dear Mike, Steve et Al:

1. The actual match for the OEM Fuchs Alloy black is the Wurth Gloss Black
Wheel Paint, and the match for the clear coat is Wurth Gloss Clear.  If you
are repainting all four wheels this is probably the best combo to use.  The
paints are specifically formulated to withstand the high temperature environme
nt of wheels.  

2. If you are repainting only one or two wheels and if the black on the
existing wheels had faded, then Wurth Matt Black with clear coat may match.
 Try using 3M Imperial Hand Glaze on the faded wheels, you may be surprised
to find out how much you can improve their appearance. If 3M alone does not
quite do the trick, try adding a little Blue Magic to the 3M and polish out
the existing paint.    

3. A trick for masking wheels or other compound curves, is to use the thin 3M
self adhesive masking (not scotch) tape to define the line.  The thin paper
will deform relatively easily and require less trimming with a razor blade.
 Once you have the tape in place, warm (not heat)  it with a hair dryer as
you press it down.  Try overlaying the tape with another layer of tape to
make removal easier.  Leave a 1/64 " gap between the two layers of masking
tape.  Make sure that the edge of the tape that defines the paint line is
firmly in contact with the wheel. Take your time in this phase.  Cover the
rest of the wheel with paper, including the outside and inside.  Paint will
get into everyting so mask carefully.  An hour spent at this stage will pay
big dividends.  One of the tricks to spray painting is to start the spray off
of the area to be painted.  When first starting a spray of paint, there will
be spatters that will mar your work.  Start off the work surface and move the
spray onto the work and in one smooth motion, sweep across the surface and
past.  Move down for the next path (still keeping the spray going) and move
back onto the work, continue across moving in a smooth motion till you are
off the work on the other side.  Move down and continue the off - on -off
 -down off - on -off motions.  Maintain the spray at a 90 degree angle to the
surface to be painted.  Don't tilt the spray can or gun. 

4. The key to a good looking finish on a wheel or any painting project is
preparation.  You should spend 90% of your time in prep and 10% of your time
painting.  Many people reverse the percentages and wind up with dismal
results.   If the existing black paint is in good condition, other than faded
and the polished/clear coated areas are in excellent shape,  you may get away
with only repainting the black areas.  Slightly rough up the painted area
 with a 1200 grit sandpaper.  Clean down with an organic solvent such as
Wurth Citrus Degreaser and then mask.  You are ready to paint, see #6. 

5. If the wheels have areas that are chipped through the clear coat/black
coat or the polished areas are cloudy or discolored, then you may want to
consider removing all the existing paint.  The best way I have found to
remove the existing paint is plastic media  blasting.  This will remove all
of the paint and leave the surface ready for polishing.  Polish the wheels
using a cloth wheel or you may be able to hand polish them.  Clean them down
thoroughly with an organic solvent such as Wurth Citrus Degreaser and mask.  

6. Hang the wheels with a washer that is just slightly larger than the
diameter of the stud hole (large enough to not fit through the hole but small
enough to fit deep into the stud depression.  Run a wire around the washer
and place in the stud depression.  Hang the wheel at chest level.  Try to do
all four wheels at the same time.  Clean just prior to painting with a Prep
Sol type of cleaner.  Spray a coat of quality primer such as Wurth Rustop
Primer on the areas to be painted (NOT the clear coated areas), allow to dry
and then paint the black areas with several light coats.  This is important,
as the Wurth Paints don't like to be applied in one or two heavy coats.  They
will give the best results with numerous (I apply 8+) thin coats.  Allow each
coat to dry about an hour before applying the next coat.  When the black is
finished and had dried for 48 hours, remove the tape.

7.  If you have not stripped off the existing clear coat from the polished
areas, then do NOT try to repolish these areas.  See #9.

8. Carefully hand re-polish any areas that need it.  If you use a machine,
you may mar the new paint. 

9. Lightly sand the painted areas that are to be clear coated with 2000 grit
sand paper to slightly rough up the surface and allow the new paint better
adhere.   Do not sand non clear coated polished areas.  Clean all the areas
to be clear coated with a Prep Sol type of product and apply several light
coats of Wurth Clear Wheel Paint. Allow to dry for an hour between coats.

 If you have taken you time, you should be pleased with the results.

If anyone wants more information on the details of refinishing wheels, or
can't find the Wurth, 3M or Blue Magic Products locally, please give me a
shout.

Thank you,

 Larry Reynolds
 Car Care Specialties, Inc.
 Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
 Post Office Box 535
 Saddle Brook,  NJ  07663-0535
 Phone (201) 796-8300
 Fax (201) 791-9743
 E-mail carcaresp@aol.com
 Old enough to remember when sex was safe and race cars were      dangerous

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 07:29:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Recommend a good jack?

Hi Scott,

I'm kind of a nut on garage equipment.  I insist that you only buy it once.

On floor jacks my preference in the Walker jack 1 1/2 ton model, any year.

The Blue walker jack is now sold as a Lincoln jack through your auto 
parts store.  It's not cheap.  Originally the jack was manufactured as an 
A-Jax jack and was painted light green.  The jack line was bought by the 
Walker Muffler Co. and painted blue with a yellow handle.  I think that 
Lincoln has maintained that color scheme.  Heres the reasons:

1.  There are a lot of these jacks.  They have been a professional garage 
favorite since I can remember.

2.  Many of the parts are interchangable.  Yes if you need a cast iron 
wheel for a 1960 model a 1995 model will replace it.  Just like some 
Porsche parts.

3.  The hydraulic pump is external.  A New one can be bought from  
Lincoln and screwed into your 1970 model and the pump works like new.  
Parts are available.  I use a mid '60s model and have put brass bushings 
in a lot of the worn pivot holes and have jack that is better than new.  
If I wear out a bushing I just replace it not the jack.  The other jacks 
I have looked at have their pump made internal in the casting base.  If 
it wears out the jack is worthless.  Hein-Warner, Blackhawk, Import etc.

4.  The 1 1/2 has the largest lifting range and it goes the lowest of the 
entire jack line.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974


------------------------------

Date: Thu,  4 May 1995 08:31:02 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: 911: Wheel bearings

Excerpts from mail: 2-May-95 911: Wheel bearings by Chris Bennet@lmcorp.com 
> Even _I_ know this is stupid question and everybody past
> puberty knows the answer to this question...'cept me.
> 
> At my last autocross they said my front wheel bearings were
> a little loose (but they let it past this time).   My records from
> the previous owner said that one of the fronts had been replaced.
> The car is an '86 Carrera with about 70K miles on it.
> 
> Question: Is this something I can just tighten or is the looseness usually
> symptomatic something else (wear, grease loss) ? 

    Sure, you can just tighten them. Just pop off the dust cap on your
front rotor (well, hub, actually, if you ave a 911...)  There will be a
big nut that you just tighten up until you've taken all the play out of
the bearings (no tighter!)  A warning - it will either have an allen
setscrew (like my 914) or else a cotter pit through the bolt that must
be removed/loosened as the case may be before you can adjust this nut (I
think it's pretty obvious why...)

> 
> I intend to fix it myself but have only one project* under my belt so

    If you've done a clutch, this will be a piece of cake.  I repacked
my bearings in my 914 in about 2 hrs.
    If the thought that your bearings have loosened make you nervous (I
don't take any chances with mine) you may want to clean them out and
repack them.  Just remove the aforementioned nut, pull the hub off the
spindle, and everything will come right off.  You may have to use a
small prybar to pop the grease seal out.  Just soak the bearings in
gasoline, let them dry well, and then squish more grease in the bearing
COMPLETELY.  this is a pain to do by hand, but I don't have the litle
tool that fits on your grease gon, and I don't do bearings that often. 
Then scoop out most of the old goo from the hub and put the new stuff in
there, too.  build up a little wedge of grease in he hub behind where
each bearing will sit, to try to keep the grease in them longer.
    After this, just reassemble everything the way it was, making sure
to put  a thin film of grease on the grease seal before assembling.
    If you want new bearings, they're not that hard, either.  Just drive
out the races with a brass punch, and the new ones in the same way. 
Just keep working around the perimeter as you go to keep from cocking
the races.  Don't ever mix bearing/race sets!

> please feel free to state the what seems obvious. I have
> the workshop manuals on fiche (but no reader) and the spec book.

Well, I think that does it....  I tried to get everything I could think
of... Try it, it's fun and you'll learn more about how your P-car works!
> 
>   vrooom,
>    Chris
> 
> 
> * Replaced the clutch and adjusted the valves.
> 
> 

happy speeding,

Nate
>

> When you melt a switch repeatedly like this, it's usually a sign you're
> running too many amps through it.  Have you diddled with the bulbs in the
> headlights, or  added driving lights to the same circuit without using a
> relay?  If so, a relay will solve your problem (and it's certainly a whole
> lot simpler and cheaper than replacing those switches).

No, everything is original configuration, though a couple items, like
cruise control and headlight washers, haven't worked for quite some time. 
The Weissachs came with all options, which, while it doesn't make for a
light car, means no need to fool around with aftermarket additions, etc. 
The switch only melted the first time, the other times the failure mode
was mechanical.

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 10:19:11 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: Re: 914 Shift Linkage Question

>I am having problems adjusting the shift linkage on my 914.  I was having
>trouble getting into first and reverse.  No matter how hard I pulled left I
>could not get it into reverse-first it would drop into secong and third.  So
>I tried to adjust the linkage by disconnecting the linkage from the shifte
>and moving it around but I did not know which way to move it.  Now after I
>tightened it all I get is first and reverse.
>
>I have a side shifter trans.  When I remove the linkage bolt am I suppose to
>put the shifter into a certain gear or move/rotate the link a certain way?
> Like I said I have a sideshifter trans on a 74? engine.
>

Is your chassis pre '73? If so, your outboard engine mounts may be the 
rubber pre '73 version and your side shifter engine/transmission will be 
riding too low in the car, causing the shift rod to bind, resulting in 
aforementioned problem.

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 10:28:30 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: Re: 914 bushing removal

>
>Hi all,
>
>	I am currently in the process of removing my old trailing arm 
>bushings on my 914. This job is a pain. Does anyone out there have any 
>neat tricks that would make the job easier? I belive I thought up an 
>idea, but it won't be built for another couple of days. If anyone is 
>interested in something that makes this job easier, drop me a line and 
>I'll let you know if it was successfull or not. 
>
>-Josh
>
>Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CSP
>Accelerator Operations
>Stanford Linear Accelerator Center
>
>jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu
>
>Everything expresed here is the opinion of the idiot that wrote it, 
>namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...
>

When I removed mine I found the only thing that ended up working was a 
torch. I virtually burned them out. You light them on fire, let them burn 
for five or so minutes, blow them out and they should just pop out with 
vise-grips.

This method does, however, render them somewhat unuseable.

Date: Thu, 4 May 95 9:35:41 EDT
From: BlaineDeLancey <Blaine.Delancey@lambada.oit.unc.edu>
Subject: Re: Fire in my 87 Carrera

> People tell me that this is the condenser fan for the AC unit. Is this 
> normal behaviour on these cars ? I thought the condenser was mounted under 
> the rear spoiler. My mechanic tells me that I can drive the car safely 
> without it and even maybe run the AC still ! I have taken the unit off but 
> it was badly burnt inside out. 
> 
> Should I replace this myself or get an expert to do this ? It was easy to 
> get off but finding the part has been a problem. Noobody seems to know what 
> it is exactly, and I have been quoted $310 to $55. MAybe I can find a used one.

There is also a condenser under the front spoiler, which this fan blows
air over.  I just had mine replaced in my '80 SC, so I knows.  Cost me
$370 at the dealer, but I was in a hurry for a trip with my girlfriend (SO
for the new, hip & politically correct), and wanted to avoid the ensuing
battle over 'this damn Porsche' (it happened anyway).  Looked in Kempton
Bros. (don't do it, find another), and it was $200.  It's easy to replace,
bolts on and off, plug in the connector.  Unless it's really cheap, don't
go used.  I think the fan uses the same bearings as in the heater blower
motor in the engine compartment - can you say "planned obsolescence"?

Blaine

checked twice by the dealer who say's that my brakes are fine.  The problem is
that they squeel when the car is just rolling down the road not when I apply
or release them.  In my experience with other brakes is that they seem to
squeel only when applied or released.  Is this behavior really normal for
p-cars or should I insist that the dealer take them apart and apply brake quit
or lub to the back of the pads?  Could this be a sticking calipier or air in
the system?  The problem comes and goes as it has since new (seems to be the
right front only but I am not sure it always is) Also not as loud now as it
was.  Washing the rotors seems to help for a while which seems to say brake
dust is the problem? Also if I brake really hard for a while it tends to get
better.  Since I don't need to use the brakes to much at legal road speeds
with all that wonderful cornering ability <VBG> do I need to exercise them
more?  I want to get this resolved before my factor warrenty expires at the
end of May :-(  Will this slight squeel wear the rotors out faster?  And why
do the rotors rust so much after every car washing?  Any thoughts would be
appreciated.

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 10:00:19 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 Exhaust Nuts

        So what's the big deal with exhaust nuts?  I did mine last
night--after a few days of hosing them with Liquid Wrench, and using
a hammer and a small flat-headed punch to beat on them, they came
out quite nicely.  (Thanks, Soren!)  The only bad thing was that I
had to use a 1/4"-drive 13mm socket instead of the 3/8"-drive one.
The walls of the larger socket were too thick!
        Only 4 of the 8 nuts were the "correct" nuts, BTW.  The
rest were just 13mm nuts with washers behind 'em...
        I'm beginning to think that I can actually *do* this stuff!

- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 12:34:34 -0400

Subject: 951 poor performance

should be and that the exhaust was sooty and smelled of sulpher. He
suspects the catalytic converter, one of the engine management systems or
the turbo (lack of boost, the dash indicated 1.8 bar) is at fault. The
Turbo has just been replaced under my 1 yr pre-owned Porsche warranty. The
dealer is starting to piss me off because they seem to be of the opinion
that since their instruments indicate no problems that there are none.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 08:33:17 -0800
From: sgmeza@popper.PacBell.COM (Sergio Meza)
Subject: Leaking Targas and Cabs

Several years ago, GGR had a tech session conducted by Rick Bauers at
Carlson Porsche in Palo Alto, CA. He spent about an hour and a half
demonstrating, once you remove the door panel, how easy it is to adjust the
metal window frame on the door. By adjusting the screws on the portion of
the frame in the door, it can be moved in/out relative to the body of the
car and up/down - front/back relative to the Targa or Cab top. With these
adjustments, most leaks around the door can be eliminated. He also handed
out copies of the section from the shop manual that illustrated and
described these adjustments. Unfortunately, I have misplaced my copy. Good
luck on those leaks!

Sergio Meza
Pacific Bell
510.823.3145



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 95 09:33:31 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: 914 bushing removal

I used a friend's hydr. press.  Took the arms to his house and then, with
the proper press pieces to protect the threads, pressed the rod out.  A bit
of work, but it beat the torch method.  Take the arms to a machine shop and
have it done.  The few dollars it will cost will be worth the time you save
(not to mention you can have it done while you're at work and save even more
time).

Pat

the car (including serial number) so that this may be included in the next

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 12:54:56 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Quick Question....

>What is the routing for the transmission ground strap on an early ('68) 911?
>Where on the chassis to where on the trans?

        The tranny end bolts to one of the studs that holds the front cover
on.  I'm pretty sure about this--the 914s have 901 trannies, and that's
where their ground strap goes.  'Course, it's the *rear* cover on them!

- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 13:56:32 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : 911: Wheel bearings

Chris Bennet asked about his loose wheel bearings discovered at an
autocross tech :

>Question: Is this something I can just tighten or is the looseness usually
>symptomatic something else (wear, grease loss) ? 

They are probebly just a bit loose and can be tightened.
Here is something I posted a while back.

>juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas) wrote :

>When the front bearings are **exactly** right, should there be **any** 
>top-to-bottom slop? ie. I find on my SC that I have to tighten the bearning
>nut really tight (certainly much more than specified in the Hayes manual, 
>where you should be able to rotate the thrust washer) to reduce the slop.
>I have not tighted them so tight to have the wheels exibit no slop. Of
>course, the slop is noticed when the car is jacked up with the front
>wheels in the air. So, how tight should the bearing nut be? 

I've never had any luck with the procedure in the Haynes manual (which
I believe was taken out of the Porsche factory manual). If you leave
them slightly loose like Haynes says (able to move the washer under gentle
side force from a screwdriver), they will loosen up more and become way too
loose ("way" is a scientific term, because I am a scientist).

So I tighten them enough so that it takes some force to move the washer,
and the bearings will stay tight for years. There may still be a slight bit
of slop by shaking the top of the wheels, this is normal. But it should
not be much.

While you are in there, it's good to re-grease the outer bearing with
some nice Swepco or other high quality grease. But it's messy!

Good Luck, Mike Piera  '72 911S, '73 914/2.0 (?)


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 14:11:51 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Thread on Refinishing Wheels

>2) Two of the wheels have noticeable dents in the rims.  There was a 
>long thread about a year ago on recommended places to have rims 
>straightened.  Robert Wood was one, of course.  Someplace in 
>Georgia was another?  Anyone recall?
>
>Many thanks.
>
>Bob Spindel

I had a wheel straightened at the wheel collision center in Bath PA (they
advertise in R&T, etc.). came back very straight, and required little or no
weights when I got the wheel/tire balanced. The ding was on the inside rim,
so refinishing was uneccessary.

doug

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 11:11:51 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: RE : 911: Wheel bearings

In my experience, a tech inspector who's out to show his stuff may
well say your bearings are loose when they're probably OK.  It's
happened to me sporadically.  My mechanic says a little play is normal
and that too tight is no good.  He's worked on my car for 20 years and
has no vested interest in saying that, so I'm inclined to believe him.
But you never know, etc....

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 14:43:38 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Re: 911: Wheel bearings


> 
> So I tighten them enough so that it takes some force to move the washer,
> and the bearings will stay tight for years. There may still be a slight bit
> of slop by shaking the top of the wheels, this is normal. But it should
> not be much.

Mike,
If there is any play at all in the the bearings, won't that cause really high
loads during transitions from left to right or vice versa turns?  I tighten
mine by hand till there is no play at all and have experienced no adverse
effects.  I do have a 944 though which may be different and may not have
enough miles since the adjustment to have experienced any ill effects.

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 14:21:21 -0500 (CDT)
From: Christopher S Garner <garnecs@mail.auburn.edu>
Subject: Re: 924: Speedometer/Odometer Quit


I had the same problems with my 77 1/2 924 and a scrapped 82, we (my father
and myself) fixed it by removing the speedo and the odometer from the 
dash. As it happened, all the fuss was over the cable, running into the 
back of the speedo/odometer had manmaged to unscrew itself.  We just 
screwed it back down and that seemed to fix the problem.  Its been a year 
since that fix.  You might want to try it out.

	Shane Garner
        77.5 924 (my "Monique")
        78 Euro-spec 928 (Dad's project)
        79 928 (Dad's baby)

my local specialist. You can probably guess, oil leaks, water pump
power steering pump, belts etc.

A remaining problem is that my heater is stuck on hot. The temperature
dial turns but appears not to be connected to anything. The car is
standard UK spec with heater/ventilation not air con. Can I fix this
easilly myself, or will I have to save more pennies to pay the shop?

86 944 (Great White Tadpole)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 95 16:17:17 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Help with hot heater

> A remaining problem is that my heater is stuck on hot. The temperature
> dial turns but appears not to be connected to anything. The car is
> standard UK spec with heater/ventilation not air con. Can I fix this
> easilly myself, or will I have to save more pennies to pay the shop?
> Please help - summer has arrived here in England!
> 86 944 (Great White Tadpole)

Heater control cable maladjusted - easy fix. Adjust the cable, be cool.
Heater control cable broken - slightly painful, replace, adjust, be cool.
Heater control valve stuck - painful. Replace, cable, adjust, be cool.

Or just ignore it - these Porsches are Hot Stuff.

- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com
