Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 15:26:36 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Odometer readings


>>This sounds like fraud to me! Isn't trying to sell a car with a fixed
>>odometer illegal? Or doesn't that apply to private sellers?
>
It is perfectly legal to sell a vehicle with a fixed spedo. It is totaly
illegal to misrepresent the milage on a vehicle. There are usualy 3 title
brands (dealing with milage) True Milage Unknown, Milage Excedes Mechanical
Limits, and Accual. Beleive it or not anytime there is a broken speedo the
title is required to cary TrueMilageUnknown. This is even the case when there
is a documented, factory exchange. Funny, eh???

Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 17:44:10 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: Re: 914 bushing removal

>I used a friend's hydr. press.  Took the arms to his house and then, with
>the proper press pieces to protect the threads, pressed the rod out.  A bit
>of work, but it beat the torch method.  Take the arms to a machine shop and
>have it done.  The few dollars it will cost will be worth the time you save
>(not to mention you can have it done while you're at work and save even more
>time).
>
>Pat

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 17:50:52 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: Re: 914 Shift Linkage Question

>I don't like that answer too much :(  as I hope it is just an adjustment.  II
>have a 74 engine with a 72 body.  How would I figure out if this is the case?
> I hope this is not the case.  When I first got the car and drove it home it
>worked fine(or I would not have bought it).  Then in the next few days I had
>problems getting the car into first and rerverse so I tried to make some
>adjustments on the linkage but I did not know how...  
>
>
Are you saying that the car is a '72 with a '74 drive train? If the VIN # 
starts with "472...." then the chassis is a '72 (BTW engine codes would 
start with "EC" or "GA" in '74). If so, it is easy to check the engine 
mounts. The '74 outboard engine mounts are solid steel ie, not flexible, and 
the flexible portion is inboard, under the engine itself, pre '73 the 
outboard mounts are rubber, ie. flexible.
Good luck.

__________________________________________________________________________
Christopher Paine                         "Technology is like a steamroller,
Metropolis Pictures, Director              if you're not on it, you become
Editor,Der Auspuff,Rennsport Region PCA    part of the road"

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 95 14:13:29 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: 911 Rear Lid Latch


> 
> From: BanjoChuck@aol.com
> 
> The rear lid on my 80 911SC sometimes pops open after going over a sharp
> bump.  

Ah yes, nothing like a tiny, unglamorous part to cause a public,
unglamorous problem (toll collector saying "I believe your
trunk's open, sir...").  On my car this was caused by the female catch
getting worn and rounded.  Unbolt it from the body and check it out, a
few minutes at the grinder and you'll be good as new again.  The male
part screws in and out to adjust the "tightness" when latched, adjust it
so it latches reliably but the lid has no free play against its rubber
stops.

All you freudians can stop snickering now...

 -Ed
'83 911SC

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 17:08:33 -0500 (CDT)

Hi all!

Last time, and the first time, that I adjusted my valves, I did not 
remove any parts of the engine, i.e. I was able to reach all valves as 
is. The only problem was the uncomfortable clearance of the car (floor to 
underside of car)...
now, before you all start to chuckle by yourselves at the terminal 
like a bunch of weirdos, let me point out that I do not have a lift.<G>
I thought about putting the car on jackstands, but this is where the problem 
comes in. Where do you position them? I would hate to have one poke through 
my floorboard or do other major damage. In fact, I don't even want to scratch
the undercoating! And of course, I don't want to be wearing an engine 
part imprint on my head.
I know there must be some really good and simple ways of doing this, so 
any suggestions, experiences and warnings are very welcome. Please be 
specific.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 15:11:08 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: 911 Rear Lid Latch

I would try this first before tearing latch apart. Back out the top 
"male" latch a turn or two. If this does not cause to  much slack it 
may solve the prob. Also sometimes a quarter of turn will solve the 
problem as you will get different wear points.

Mine did the same thing awhile back turned out to be the cable adj as 
the latch was not closing all way. I don't know how the cable got out 
of adj. but it did.

mike
- -- 
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 18:49:34 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 951 poor performance

Friend of mine went thru hell trying to get his TurboS to run properly. Spent
a bunch trying to find the problem. The mystery was it was making full boost
and everything checked out. The cause turned out to be a clogged(or melted)
catalytic converter. Replaced it and it now runs like the hammers of hell!
Let me know the diagnosis.

very little about the little idiosyncracies associated with the Euro stuff.

 For
instance, I never knew Porsche offered those ugly rubber whale tails from
the factory!

Yeah, I knew this, is was just that in some of the pictures in his book

goes on to say that it was done this way "just like the European cars".

OK, does anyone else's oil pressure gauge read from 0-10 bar?  Is it
labelled "DRUCK" only?  Maybe I'm the oddball here.  No comments, please.

Date: Thu, 04 May 95 19:49:11 +0000
From: Ray@arkay.MV.COM
Subject: Should front brakes lock up first or rear ?

Hi all,
This weekend I'll disassemble my front calipers and will attempt to
"rebuild" them, that is to clean the pistons and reinstall with new 
original seals, dirt scraper rings, spring plates, and factory 
rubber brake hose. (I already have new factory pads, and new rotors
are on order from Vertex, who are selling "original German" 930 
rotors for $125 ea).

Hopefully this will give me the great braking performance that
Porsches are supposedly known for (but which I haven't experienced
yet). Could someone tell me what I should expect from properly 
functioning, well adjusted brakes. If I find a totally deserted 
standard asphalt road, and slam on the brakes while driving at 40 
mph, should I hear screeching tire noises ? Examining the road,
should I see tire marks front and back, front only, or rear only ?

(I have new BF Goodrich Comp T/A tires, standard size of 205 in front
and 225 in back).

I looked at the owners' manual, but it doesn't list the expected
stopping distance. I know that I am currently far from ideal, but
how do I know when my brake job is as good as it is going to get ?

I am also considering replacing my brake booster with the '85 version
which is supposed to have a better boost ratio. Any opinions on that?
According to the factory service manual it should be possible. TIA

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 18:30:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Found perfect 914 2.0 for brother!

138K on a 19-year-old car is really not much at all--slightly over 7K
per year!  22K on rebuild would tell me that the original engine had a
long life, which bodes well for the rebuild.  Original paint--that
would impress me more than anything else.

Invariably there are some components that just get tired, which given
the car's age is, well, a given.  But they can be replaced and
upgraded at the same time.  I'd grab it.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Thu, 04 May 95 20:08:12 +0000
From: Ray@arkay.MV.COM
Subject: How much Vacuum should a healthy 930 engine have ?

While working on my brakes, I bought a Mityvac gauge and connected
it to the brake booster line. I was also reading the little manual
that came with the Mityvac, and it claimed that a healthy engine
should have between 16 and 22 ". Well my engine has substantially 
less vacuum at this location, and I read all the factory manuals and
spec books and haven't found any indication about how much vacuum
is expected. Should I be alarmed ? Should I look for a vacuum leak ?
(I made this measurement with the intentional vacuum leak to the
charcoal canister plugged).

Speaking of the charcoal canister, I asked several times and still
don't know: On a straight US or non-converted euro 930, where does
the fuel tank vent hose actually go ? Mine goes to a BMW charcoal 
canister which just sits in the trunk, and from there a hose connects
to the brake booster vacuum line (for continuous purging, as I learnt
from rading the Haynes Emission Control Equipment book). But I am 
very curious to know what the layout of my fuel tank vent hose was
before it got modified by the original importers. Could this be the
question that actually stumped the net wisdom ? Or is this so boring
that everyone has already proceeded to the next topic. Maybe I'll 
think of something to spark some flames or discussion, like
what do you all think of the new 911 Turbo that is on all the 
magazine covers now ? Could it be considered a worthy replacement 
for the 959 ? Ooops. Backtrack, please. Anyone know anything about
vacuum or vent hoses ? Too late. Everyone's thinking of the turbo 
already. Oh well. Ray

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 21:39:31 -0400
From: BTARGONSKY@aol.com
Subject: Re: 924: Speedometer/Odometer...

You didn't by any chance push the trip odometer reset buton while you were
moving?  This has been known to cause instant spedo death in 924's as well as
other non-Porsche cars.  I also take it that uou have determined tha it is
not the cable or in later models cables or EGR box.  The culprit is the small
plastic gears inside.  This can be fixed, however it requires disassembly of
the unit.  i.e. Not something you wnat to do if this frightens you.  The
easier (read CHEAPER) way is to buy a repalcement from a VDO dealer (Tweeks,
Automotion etc...) or to get a used one from a dismantler (Kempton, etc.).
 Many sources can be found in Excellence magazine and sometiome European car.
 Fixing your speedo is an option, but speedo shops are going the the way of
leaded gas.  If you are interested in fixing it yourself, email me and I will
give you a rundown on how to get the unit out and open safely.

Brian E. Targonsky

'80 924-Being set up for road race.
'79 924-Waiting to go full race (auto-x)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 04 May 1995 09:12:26 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re:  914 bushing removal

Josh <JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU> writes:

>I am currently in the process of removing my old trailing arm
>bushings on my 914. This job is a pain. Does anyone out there have
>any  neat tricks that would make the job easier?

I basically used brute force to get mine out.  I drilled a hole through a large piece of
3/8 inch thick steel plate, put one end of the trailing arm "center rod" through the hole
and bolted it down tight.  I clamped the steel plate tightly to my workbench so that
the trailing arm hung downward.  Then I grabbed the trailing arm and pulled downward
while twisting it from side to side.  It is hard work, the rod moves slowly, but it will come out.
Using the silicone pre-lube grease on the new bushings will not only prevent squeaking,
but also help them slide in much easier.

Pete



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 22:08:28 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Re: 944 Clear sunroof

Hello Phello Porschephilacs,
 
> I have a 1986 944.  Power Sunroof.  Does anyone know if there is an 
> aftermarket replacement for the sunroof that is transparent - ie. glass? 

	Yup, Saratoga made a glass roof for 924/944s but I don't about  
the power sunroof models.  They were known to squeak though, the stock 
fiberglass flexes better.  Also, they went out of buisiness a while back, 
so you'd have to find a used one somehow, usually $300-600. Hope this
answers your question.  Seyalatr :^)

Jay Karolyi
'75 Corvair/914 "The Bastard"
'77 924 NC plate "NOSBST2T"
'80 Toy 'rolla

Date: Thu, 4 May 1995 22:08:24 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Christophorus Ruminations 

The language in the Porsche house organ "Christophorus" often makes amusing
reading.  For those of you who still believe that Porsches are made by Elves
in the Black Forest, or at least  "old world" Craftsman, Porsche's CEO, Dr.
Wendelin Wiedeking apparently confirmed the extraordinary nature of the
workforce in today's climate of participative management..

In the March 95 edition reporting on his speech to the stockholder's General
Meeting in Stuttgart, he was commenting on the turnaround and anticipated
balanced result for the 94/95 business year, stating "the only recognized
constant factor is change". Furthermore: "we are not currently pursuing any
program for humanizing the workplace. We require sacrifices of ourselves and
our colleagues."

Sounds strangely like the radio broadcasts and shortwave exhortations from
Berlin just before the fall of Stalingrad......

Perry

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 00:30:20 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Naresh H. Singh" <nhs1681@is2.NYU.EDU>
Subject: Re: Windshield polishing

On Thu, 4 May 1995, Joe Hunter wrote:

> Speaking of windshield polishing. Is there some compound you can buy to 
> do it yourself? And is it practical to do it by hand?

Yup, there sure is!  Eastwood Co. at (800) 345-1178 offers a "Pro Glass
Polishing Kit" for $32.95 (my catalog is dated so the price my be higher)
it was item # 1917. It is designed to remove scratches that can't be caught
with your fingernail. It includes a glass polishing wheel that fits a 
drill or slow speed polisher 1500 rpm (recommended). It comes with 
enough compound (1 lb) to do 50 jobs.

They also offer a kit to clear up scratched windshields. Item # 1919,
$19.95. Kit includes polishing wheel, mandrel, glass marking pencil,
sponge, as well as 6 ounces of compound (enough for the average car).

I haven't used either method but if you do try it let me know how it goes
because I have a windshield that is in desperate need of polishing.

Hope this helps.


Good Luck,

Naresh H. Singh
(still looking for a 944)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 14:03:25 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 911: Wheel bearings

On Thu, 4 May 1995, Jeffrey Puzas wrote:

> If there is any play at all in the the bearings, won't that cause really
high loads during transitions from left to right or vice versa turns?  I
tighten mine by hand till there is no play at all and have experienced no
adverse effects.  I do have a 944 though which may be different and may
not have enough miles since the adjustment to have experienced any ill 
effects. 
 

you have two choises here, a small amount of pad knock off, or a sheared
stub axle
 
I believe that it is better to have them loose rather than tight - from 
experience, I have had 2 instances where the bearings were too tight, and 
this caused the outside bearing to seize.

when this happens, the stub axle shears, and the wheel falls off - well 
it attempts to, but the disk caliper stops it. In both cases this has 
bent the caliper mounting.

I am not talking about the nut being spannered down hard, I mean that 
there has still been a small amount of free play.

My advise is make sure the but can turn freely on the stub axle, tighten
down by hand, spin the wheel a few times, attempt to rock it , spin it a
few more times, take up any more free play, spin the wheel again and take 
up any more free play, then back the nut off by 32-30 degrees and tighten 
the lock screw/insert a split pin etc.


+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 06:34:46 -0700
From: cjrebbe@rain.org (Chris and Jessica)
Subject: ongoing capacitive discharge dilema

Hello to one of the better subsets of society, Porsche lovers.
  I'm Chris. Been reading porschephiles for about 3 weeks now. Really
enjoying the comradarie, razzing, and sharing of expert and not so expert
information. I'm hoping some of you patient and wise guru's can help me in a
search for some answers to my questions. (BTW I don't know a hellava lot
compaired to you guys) Here's the deal:  
   1970 911T. Rebuilt/restored/redone by a guy who use to race and set track
records at Riverside.(So I'm told by my father who bought the car then sold
it to me). So now it has a '76 911 2.7L flat six, Webber six pac, zero emission
controls, and lots of things I am ignorant of that I'm told if I did ever
take it to the racecource of my local PCA region (Santa Barbara) someone
would want to take it off my hands.(super tricked-out suspension etc.)
Anyway, my problems lies in the ignitoin system. A few years ago the car
wouldn't start after it had been running for a long time.(1hr or longer
trips) I was told that sometimes when starters get hot that they don't
function properly. This was only a minor inconveniece because I didn't go
that far usually. But then the car began a halfway cutting out or a lurching
effect while driving. This went on sporatically for a day or two then the
car would start dying while I was driving it. (I think this is getting to
long winded so I'll start abbreviating). Pull to side of road and car won't
fire, starter ok though. It seemed that if I had someone crank it over while
I banged on the coil or cds unit then it would start again. Anyway, cds unit
finally goes out (no whistling sound, no voltage to coil). Purchase junkyard
Permatune for $100 as well put in new points, rotor, and dist. cap.  Used
cds lasts 2 days.  Coil and rpm sensor both ohm out ok. Call all parts
houses around country from the back of Panorama magazine. Can't afford $1300
Bosche cds so purchase NEW Permatune cds for $190. It lasts 1 week. Decide
to take it to the specialists(local P dealer) They tell me I've got a bad
cds unit(no kidding). $250 for a new "Permatune" cds plus labor. I tried to
tell them that it seemed something was blowing out the cds unit but to no
avail. Of course car runs fine then but unit goes out after a year. Is there
any way to figure out why I'm having this problem??  Ground is good and cds
gets 12v.  I've now purchased a used Bosche for $100 and car runs but still
lurches. Sometimes won't start and seems to want to fire when ignition is
being turned off.( coil is not backwards). Thanks for listening and allowing
a hack like me to partake of the porschephiles.                              
                                               Chris
p.s. please someone answer me! Stan?, Bart?
convertable 356 (dad's)
'84 944 (mom's) almost crashed it in high school.
'70 911T(dad's then mine)

>Friend of mine went thru hell trying to get his TurboS to run properly. Spent
>a bunch trying to find the problem. The mystery was it was making full boost
>and everything checked out. The cause turned out to be a clogged(or melted)
>catalytic converter. Replaced it and it now runs like the hammers of hell!
>Let me know the diagnosis.

without removing things? I imagine that running too long with a partly
clogged exhaust could cause damage to the exhaust valves too.

Date: Fri, 5 May 95 10:13:13 EDT
From: berry@cgi.com (Franklyn Berry)
Subject: Software Copying


On Mon, 1 May 1995, Peter Wales wrote:

>> At 09:32 AM 5/1/95 CDT, Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
>> wrote:
>>
> >     What also interests me is that the aftermarket tuners basically copy the
> >OEM ROM then modify it a little. This would have to be copyright
>infringement,
> >however maybe the factories don't discourage the Chippers as a means of
> >avoiding having to honor their warranties...
>
>> The question of copyrights is one I find interesting. If I take a chip out
>> and copy it, have I broken the law?  If I put the copy in the car, only one
>> version of the software is being used.

I work for a software company; we use rather typical agreements for the
industry, for which I've seen many.

You cannot copy, mutilate, or disassemble our software, according to
its license.

Are Porsche ROM's licensed? I've never looked at a manual.

- --frankb

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 5 May 95 10:35 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Software Copying

    I work for a software company; we use rather typical agreements for the
    industry, for which I've seen many.
    
    You cannot copy, mutilate, or disassemble our software, according to
    its license.
    
    Are Porsche ROM's licensed? I've never looked at a manual.

I doubt they are.  Software embedded in microcontrollers may have a copyright
sticker on the ROMs, but I've never seen it licensed, since you don't buy the
software, you buy the device.  I think licensing & reproduction issues are
pretty much up to the manufacturer of the device to determine.  And since there
are companies making aftermarket chips for everything from Porsches to Ford
Probes, I think it might be difficult for a company to start cracking down on
chip makers.  UNLESS, of course, they *do* start licensing the ROMs, and making
the original buyer sign a licensing agreement.

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 10:35:27 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : 911SC Rookie AutoX questns

Joe Browne <brownej@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com> asked :

>1.  What tyre pressures should I start with?  I am running normal
>Goodyear Eagle streets, 245-55's or so.

That's a strange size. The best wheel/tire combo for an SC or Carrera
is 7 and 8 by 15" wheels with 225/50 and 245/50/15 tires. For your
street tires, try 36 PSI front and 40 PSI rear, as they need high
pressures for autocross. The BFG autocross tires work well at about
10 PSI less than this.

>2.  Should the fuel tank be full or what?  I haven't yet pushed the car
>hard enough to find out how much understeer is there.  
> I know a little about the oversteer problems when lifting in that car.

Don't lift! Your car will actually understeer both under power and 
braking. Lift throttle oversteer is not a "bug" it's a "feature" ;-) 
(Sorry, I'm a s/w geek) Use LTO to your advantage.

I run my '72 911S with an empty (not quite!) fuel tank, but with the
spare in front to add a bit of weight. The extra fuel weighs too much
in my light car with low torque. But in a heavier (especially in the rear)
SC with more torque, you may want to try a full tank after taking a few
runs with a near-empty tank. If you are faster, stick with it!

>Also, does anyone know of a Porsche list on the net?  

Someone replied about Porschephiles. It is a VERY HIGH VOLUME
list with about 5 times the volume of TEAM.NET. So get the digest 
version. There's lots of good info. Please send your requests to 
porschephiles-request@tta.com  . I cross-posted this reply to
porschephiles, so they are looking forward to you joining!

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S, '73 914/2.0 (?)

Date: Fri, 05 May 1995 07:53 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Nevada Highways


  Hey P-filers,

  This is an update on Nevada State Senate bill SB-133, that proposed
  to repeal speed limits on rural highways (i.e. just about the entire
  state).

  Well, our lawmakers balked at the thought of losing $110 million in
  federal highway funds, so they removed the repeal. What remained is
  that the maximum fine for speeds over 70 mph is $100, and no insurance
  companies are notified if the fine is paid on time. Furthermore, the
  transportation committee discussed reconsidering a speed limit repeal
  if the national speed limit is repealed, which a US Senate committee just
  voted on. So, perhaps in the not too distant future, you will be able to
  drive your Porsche fast on the Silver State's 'autobahns' and save your
  greenbacks for gas and maintenance. I guess PCNA knew what they were
  doing when they located here.

  On a related note, I propose that State Senator O.C. Lee, D-Las Vegas
  be given the T*d-of-the-month award for his remarks in wanting assurance
  that the same amount of money will be raised under the new fine schedule.
  To me, there is something fundamentally wrong with a method for
  collecting
  revenue that depends upon people breaking the law. What comes next then,
  encouraging drug trafficking so more property can be seized and auctioned
  off? Well, I'll get off my soapbox now. I'm probably preachin' to the
  choir here
  anyway.

  Regards,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 11:14:59 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: '59A Restoration Report

356ers,

Some may recall that I purchased a yellow '59A coupe that Ted Smith had
reported on in pphiles about 6 months ago and I thought a update was in
order.

Recently I stripped the car of all external and interior parts and sent it on
its way for body work and painting.  I am excited to report that it is now
back in orginal Porsche silver form and looks absolutely gorgeous.

The car was remarkably rust free.  That is not to say there was no rust but
it was very minimal.  In fact, even the battery box required only a very
small repair.  The jack points were rusted out and replaced and a couple
other small areas.  The doors were very solid, especially the bottoms.  A
small amount of surface rust was repaired on the outside bottom of each door.
 Where filler was required my guys used an aluminized bondo called "Al
Metal."  More expensive and harder to work than bondo, I'm told it is as good
or better than lead.

The car was blocked out extensively and several times with most all of the
yellow repaint removed down to bare metal.

Repainted with Glasurit Silver per the original cardex, the paint is
absolutely beautiful and really highlights the special curves of the T-2
coupe.

I must admit that I didn't check the car out as thoroughly as I really should
have when I bought it but Ted had done a good job and I lucked out.  Thanks
Ted.

I will put the car back together and then have the interior redone.  I am
aiming for a street "concourse" driver.  I looking for :1 cherry shine up
Hella license plate light and 2 rear chrome upright bumpers with exhaust
holes and cut-outs for the '59 high overrider bar.

 -Allen Henderson-

Subject: Jack Positions


>Where do you position them?

Under the rear torsion bar covers, i.e., the ends of the
torsion bar that are just behind those little round access
plates.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 5 May 95 12:09:41 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Should front brakes lock up first or rear ?

> Hopefully this will give me the great braking performance that
> Porsches are supposedly known for (but which I haven't experienced
> yet). Could someone tell me what I should expect from properly 
> functioning, well adjusted brakes. If I find a totally deserted 
> standard asphalt road, and slam on the brakes while driving at 40 
> mph, should I hear screeching tire noises ? Examining the road,
> should I see tire marks front and back, front only, or rear only ?

Even a marginal brake system should be able to lock up all four
wheels. This won't stop you as quickly as not-quite-locking-up
all four wheels - for "normal tires" about a 5% slip ratio will
give maximum stopping performance. 4-channel ABS accomplishes a similar
(but not quite as good, in dry conditions) effect by easing off each
brake when that wheel starts to lock up. 

The problem of setting the brake bias is kinda tricky. The exact
optimal bias depends on traction, roadway camber and slope. So
you basically need a slightly different bias for every corner.
The reason for this is that weight transfer front-to-rear is
affected by braking effectiveness, and braking effectiveness is
affected by weight transfer. The more braking force available, the
more weight is transferred to the fronts, which gives the fronts more 
traction and the rears less. If you set up the bias perfectly for
a given surface, if you then try to stop on a surface with less
traction, the fronts will lock up way too soon, and on a surface
with more traction, the rears will lock up way too soon. This is
why, in classes that allow it, racers have cockpit adjustable brake
bias adjusters.

You also asked which should lock up first - the rears or the fronts.
The answer to this depends on your stability requirements. Most folks
want to be able to ease off the pedal and have things go right back
to the way it was before lockup. If you are in a turn and the fronts
lock up, you loose some front-end traction - understeer
is the usual result. Easing off the brake brings the front back
in. You may still be going too fast for the turn, but you didn't spin.
Start your braking sooner next time! If, on the other hand, your rears
lock up first, you loose rear end traction - the back is coming around!
Easing off the brakes (by itself) is unlikely to save it.
If, however, all your braking is accomplished in a straight line, having
the fronts lock up decreases the ultimate stopping force available
(due to the weight transfer, the fronts provide the most braking force),
while having the rears lock up doesn't have as much effect.

To be less equivocal about it, adjust the bias so that the fronts lock
up "just a little" before the rears for normal (dry) driving conditions. Most
of us go around corners sometimes, and you never know when you'll need
to panic stop. And if it rains, the fronts will still lock up first, so
you will still get understeer instead of oversteer.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 12:08:02 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Should front brakes lock ...

>Could someone tell me what I should expect from properly 
>functioning, well adjusted brakes. If I find a totally deserted 
>standard asphalt road, and slam on the brakes while driving at 40 
>mph, should I hear screeching tire noises ? Examining the road,
>should I see tire marks front and back, front only, or rear only ?
>
>Ray Khorram

Ray,

With street compound brake pads (ones that will work well when cold), you
should be able to lock up all 4 wheels at 40 mph.  You will also flat spot
your tires, so don't do this unless you like a constant thumping sound 8{).
 As far as which end should lock first, you always want the front wheels to
lock first.  That way the car will continue to go straight.  I hope this is a
universally accepted fact amoungst you autophiles, but if anyone doubts it,
ask yourself why the auto maufacturers first put anti-lock brakes on the back
of cars.

The problem that I have with what you are saying is the"slamming on the
brakes" part.  You can induce rear wheel locking (on a car that normally
would not) by slamming on the brakes, and violently pitching all of the car's
weight to the front.  On all of the cars that I setup with adjustable brake
bias,  I set them so that a smooth initial press on the brakes, with
increasing pressure will lock the fronts first, and then a little more will lo
ck the backs.  This will produce the most effective use of both front and
rear brakes, and therefore the shortest stopping distances.  Depending upon
use, I may "back off on the rears a little" just to make sure they won't lock
if the brake is hit a little more quickly.

Most street cars are set so that the average driver can jump on the brakes,
and not lock the rears.  This means that under smooth track braking, the
rears will be doing very little.  That is why most trackers/racers add some
bias to the rears; to get more braking effect out of them.  Just be careful
not to go too far.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Fri, 5 May 95 09:15:12 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Front/Rear Brake Lockup


Ray-

The fronts should lock first.  Your suggested test,
drive on flat dry pavement at about 30, hit the brakes
hard, should cause a skid and you should be able to see
if the fronts have indeed locked up first by the marks on
the road.

However, I wouldn't do this with new pads.  You should break them in first, with gentle
brake applications for a bit.  I'm bot sure how much
a 'bit' is, but I'd do it for a 100 miles or so before
I slammed them on.  Also, when you do the test, you might 
want to warm the brakes a bit first by applying them a 
few times.  If you do it first thing in the morning, right
out of the garage, you may not get representative results.

Bob Spindel

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 5 May 95 13:19 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Should front brakes lock ...

    From: HermanHome@aol.com
     As far as which end should lock first, you always want the front wheels to
    lock first.  That way the car will continue to go straight.  I hope this is a
    universally accepted fact amoungst you autophiles, but if anyone doubts it,
    ask yourself why the auto maufacturers first put anti-lock brakes on the back
    of cars.

I *strongly* disagree with this purported "fact".  You *never* want the front
wheels to lock, because then you lose steering control over the car.  The reason
auto manufacturers put anti-lock brakes on the back of the car is because under
hard braking, the weight transitions forward, thereby reducing the loading on
the rear tires, which then proceed to lock first.  I hope this is a universally
accepted fact amongst you autophiles, but if anyone doubts it, ask yourself why
why so many truck manufacturers offer single-channel anti-lock brakes for the
rear wheels only.

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 15:19:19 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Should front brakes lock ...

This is going to be a really ugly flame job, so those of you with a weak
stomach had better delete this now.

Tracy, I've had it with your irritating comments, and half thoughtout
statements.  You, by your own admission have stated that you have VERY LITTLE
track experience, and yet you feel compelled to incorrectly advise me on a
subject that you know not.  I am going to explain this for you in a way that
even YOU can understand.

I wrote:
From: HermanHome@aol.com
     As far as which end should lock first, you always want the front wheels
to
    lock first.  That way the car will continue to go straight.  I hope this
is a
    universally accepted fact amoungst you autophiles, but if anyone doubts
it,
    ask yourself why the auto maufacturers first put anti-lock brakes on the
back
    of cars.

You flamed back:
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
I *strongly* disagree with this purported "fact".  You *never* want the front
wheels to lock, because then you lose steering control over the car.  The
reason
auto manufacturers put anti-lock brakes on the back of the car is because
under
hard braking, the weight transitions forward, thereby reducing the loading on
the rear tires, which then proceed to lock first.  I hope this is a
universally
accepted fact amongst you autophiles, but if anyone doubts it, ask yourself
why
why so many truck manufacturers offer single-channel anti-lock brakes for the
rear wheels only.
- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)


So YOU strongly disagree with what I have written. Lean closely to the screen
and read this:

IF you have to make a choise on which end of the car should lock-up first
(ie. no ABS) it should be the front.  That way the car will go straight.  You
can verify this with an inclined plane, and a toy car.  Try to get it to
slide down the plane with the rear wheels locked.  You'll see what
happens...it spins out.  This happens in the real world too.  So much for
your  premise about steering control.  I personally would rather lose
steering control, and go straight, than lose car control and spin off rear
end first!  THAT is why the manufacturers started with anti-lock brakes on
the rear first...so it wouldn't lock up!!  Obviously, then, the front would
ALWAYS lock first. Once they figured out how to get anti-lock on both ends,
they did.  ALSO carefully read the other two letters concerning this subject,
they say the same thing as I did.


Stick to commentary on what you know...whatever THAT may be.

Incendiarily yours,

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

And to everyone else, I apologize for the ugliness...I'm not usually like
this. It's just that this guy pisses me off.

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 15:38:32 -0400
From: mrf@tiac.net (mrf)
Subject: PCA North East Region Autocross this Sunday

Sorry for sending this twice.  It appears that my othter mail system has 
choked and I wanted to get this out today.

Mark
=======================================================================


Attention all porschephephilers within reasonable driving distance of Boston!

This Sunday, May 7, will be the PCA/NER's first autocross of the 1995 
season.  We are once again planning a five event series which is again 
sponsored by European Performance Engineering.  NER autocross events are 
very well organized and we almost always get 6 runs per driver.  All PCA 
members are welcome and may drive any type of car which passes tech.  
Non-members may also participate but they may only drive a Porsche.

We run up to twelve classes, class 12 being for all non-Porsche's.  If 
you're not sure what class you'd belong in, no worry, we'll let you know 
when you get there.  Trophies are awarded for each class based upon the 
number of entries in the class (based on the PCR's).  We also have a novice 
award for the fastest participant in each class who has never previously won 
a trophy.  The rules of the event are modified PCR's.

We welcome drivers of all skill level.  We have instructors for those who 
would like one.  Newcomers are especially welcome!


   When:      Sunday, May 7th, 1995

   Where:     Bayside Exposition Center
              (about 5 minutes south of Boston)

   Schedule:  Registration opens at 9AM.
              Tech opens at 9:30 (possibly earlier)
              Registration closes at 10:30 *SHARP*
              Tech closes at 10:45 *SHARP*
              Drivers meeting at 11:00.

   Cost:      US$15.00 for PCA members.
              US$20.00 for non-members.


Other notes:
   o We allow two drivers per car.
   o Weather is forecast to be sunny.  Bring sun protection.
   o No on site food (maybe an ice cream truck).  Bring a picnic.
   o If you're not a PCA member we can sign you up on site.

If you have any questions, please give me a call at work (617) 693-5612 or 
at home (617) 277-5295 until 10PM EST.

Hope to see you there!

Mark Forrester
1995 PCA/North East Region Autocross Chair


==========================================
1995 PCA/NER autocross schedule

Date: Fri, 5 May 95 15:49:29 EDT
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: Should front brakes lock ...

>    From: HermanHome@aol.com
>     As far as which end should lock first, you always want the front wheels to
>    lock first.  That way the car will continue to go straight.  I hope this is a
>    universally accepted fact amoungst you autophiles, but if anyone doubts it,
>    ask yourself why the auto maufacturers first put anti-lock brakes on the back
>    of cars.
>
>I *strongly* disagree with this purported "fact".  You *never* want the front
>wheels to lock, because then you lose steering control over the car.  The reason
>auto manufacturers put anti-lock brakes on the back of the car is because under
>hard braking, the weight transitions forward, thereby reducing the loading on
>the rear tires, which then proceed to lock first.  I hope this is a universally
>accepted fact amongst you autophiles, but if anyone doubts it, ask yourself why
>why so many truck manufacturers offer single-channel anti-lock brakes for the
>rear wheels only.

I believe that the anti-lock brake arguements, either for front or rears
locking first, only confuses the issue.


Looking at either street driven or race cars without antilock brakes, I don't
believe you will find many (if any) proponents for having the rear lock first.
The issue is directional stability. If the fronts lock, the car keeps going in
basicly the direction it was going. This may not be what you wanted, but it
is at least  reasonably stable and controlable. If the back wheels lock,
especially on a low polar moment car like a 914, the car can swap ends
virtually instantaneously (don't ask me how I know-). A good reference on
the subject is Caroll Smith (sic?), in the Prepare to Win series.
Alternatively, survey some fast race drivers (like Larry, or any of many 
others in this group).

By the way, the intent is to have the fronts barely lock first under the
appropriate degree of front/rear weight transfer. Thus you need to reconsider
brake balance on different surfaces (like wet pavement), and when you make
changes that would influence weight transfer (like significant lowering).

Most street cars from the factory have substantial front brake bias (i.e.
the fronts lock way before the rears), for just this reason. The designers
want to make sure that the fronts lock first under virtually any set of
conditions. With most Porsches, you can considerably increase the brake
bias to the rear, allowing the rear brakes and tires to share a larger
fraction of the braking (but still nowhere near 1/2) relative to the
factory setting, for track use. This is particularly easy in the 914,
where there is an adjustable rear brake bias regulator. However, keep
in mind that you are dialing out margin for unusual conditions.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Fri, 05 May 95 16:47:51 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: 944 16 Valve Cam Problems

Hi, Frank,

I never forgot your asking about the problems I'm hearing about with the 
valve train and camshafts with the 16 valve 944S and 944S2 motors...

So, I'm starting to construct, via circumstantial evidence (kind of  like
the OJ trial) what's going on in their that could cost you a dollar or two.
I had a chat with PCNA's technical support guy (Brad), kind of questioning 
about the availability of the ramps on the camshaft chain tensioner.

Seems that the ramps are "good for the life of the engine" unless there has 
been a "prior valve-train event".

Bottom line, if you have had a cam belt failure with valve to piston contact
(!) or have over-revved the motor (!), you might see a failure with the
tensioner and/or ramps.  This will usually result in additional cost (!)

BTW, evidently, there is no similar problem with the 968 (Variocam)
valvetrain.

I would suggest checking the ramps on an annual basis, and replacing the
entire chain tensioner when you see impending failure of the ramps...


- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (needs work)
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 17:27:23 -0400
From: cbt@eduplus.ca (Stephen Davies)
Subject: 951 poor performance

>>In my quest to get my 1988 944 Turbo S up to spec performance (and mileage)
>>wise, I took it to an independant shop yesterday. My local dealer recently
>>checked the O2 sensor and adjusted the CO level from 2.0 to 1.2. This made no
>>perceptable change. The independant shop, who incidentally seems to have more
>>experience with 944 Ts, agreed that acceleration was not what it should be
>>and that the exhaust was sooty and smelled of sulpher. He suspects the
>>catalytic converter, one of the engine management systems or the turbo (lack
>>of boost, the dash indicated 1.8 bar) is at fault. The Turbo has just been
>>replaced under my 1 yr pre-owned Porsche warranty.

>Friend of mine went thru hell trying to get his TurboS to run properly. Spent
>a bunch trying to find the problem. The mystery was it was making full boost
>and everything checked out. The cause turned out to be a clogged(or melted)
>catalytic converter. Replaced it and it now runs like the hammers of hell! Let
>me know the diagnosis.

Jerry, 

Thanks for your reply.

I just came from my local dealer. He just tested for exhaust backpresure by
attaching a vacuum guage at the CO test tube by the battery. He found no
back pressure and beleives that I have no problems. I'm still not sure. I
ran a test that I found in Tech Notes from Excellence (1 or 2 years old)
that was suggested by a chip maker. It involves accelerating at full
throttle from 2500 rpm in 3rd gear. You start the clock as you reach 4000
and stop at 6000. I got repeatable readings of 6.2 seconds which is what
the regular turbo is supposed to get. I'm not sure what the Turbo S time is
supposed to be but it must be signifigantly less than that. I'm also
getting only 16 miles per US gallon driving half city half highway with no
stop and go driving. Something must be wrong but I have no idea what. Any
other thoughts ?

Stephen Davies

the car will spin - physics is not a matter of opinion.

> accepted fact amongst you autophiles, but if anyone doubts it, ask yourself why

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 17:18:35 -0400
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Should front brakes lock ...

Come on Tracy, you are being pedantic!

. Larry is absolutely right. 

While we may not wish to lock up the wheels at all, the likelihood is very
great that, on the track at least, we will; given that the objective is to
drive just within, or at, the limits of adhesion.

When and if lock up happens you will want the fronts to lock up first as
stated unanimously by the assembled multitude.

Carroll Smith claims that the scenario of perfect braking into a corner is to
see two little puffs of blue smoke from the front wheels just as the driver
releases brake pressure and turns in. ( No - don't start on at me about trail
braking- that's a whole different discussion!)

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 17:21:52 -0400 (EDT)
From: Michell Feig <mitchsf@shadow.net>
Subject: 1983 911 Valuation - Conclusion


For those following our 1983 purchase evaluation, here is a summary of 
events:
1) Found 1983SC with purported 29K miles, original everything, asking 15K 
negotiable.
2) Looked at car. Repaint (average to below average job), new spedo, bad 
A/C, not original mileage, etc.

Yesterday the car was examined by a mechanic.  The engine is ok, the car 
needs the following:

A/C compressor (rotary conversion, as long as it has to be replaced)
A couple of oil lines
Half shafts
Sunroof motor 
Tires
Tensioner update (the tensioners are ok, but the update isn's a bad idea
Miscellaneous little stuff - alignment, a few seals, etc.
Interior - Leather seats shot

About 2500-3000 estimated by mechanic, who advised not to offer more than 
$10,500 for the car (and we're still left with a bad paint job).

My friend will be buying his first Porsche (something he has always 
wanted).  He wants a perfect car, and has the resources to buy one.  His 
is the type who just wants it to work, without being bothered with this 
stuff.  His is more the typical luxury car owner, not an enthusiast as we 
might consider ourselves (but we need them to supply us with cars!).

I've advised him to pass on this car and buy a 1987+ Carrera, and he 
agrees.  They're available in South Florida starting at about 21K for 
decent condition Coupes.

This might not be a bad car for one of us, if it can be bought at $10,500 
(I doubt that the owner will accept an offer in that range, though)
 
That's all - we'll find a car for him in the next few weeks.

Mitch Feig
1976 911S

Date:  5 May 95 11:37:07 EDT
From: Mark Forrester <Mark_Forrester.LOTUS@crd.lotus.com>
Subject: North East Region Autocross this Sunday

Attention all porschephephilers within reasonable driving distance of Boston!

This Sunday, May 7, will be the PCA/NER's first autocross of the 1995 season.  
We are once again planning a five event series which is again sponsored by 
European Performance Engineering.  NER autocross events are very well organized 
and we almost always get 6 runs per driver.  All PCA members are welcome and 
may drive any type of car which passes tech.  Non-members may also participate 
but they may only drive a Porsche.

We run up to twelve classes, class 12 being for all non-Porsche's.  If you're 
not sure what class you'd belong in, no worry, we'll let you know when you get 
there.  Trophies are awarded for each class based upon the number of entries in 
the class (based on the PCR's).  We also have a novice award for the fastest 
participant in each class who has never previously won a trophy.  The rules of 
the event are modified PCR's.

We welcome drivers of all skill level.  We have instructors for those who would 
like one.  Newcomers are especially welcome!


   When:      Sunday, May 7th, 1995

   Where:     Bayside Exposition Center
              (about 5 minutes south of Boston)

   Schedule:  Registration opens at 9AM.
              Tech opens at 9:30 (possibly earlier)
              Registration closes at 10:30 *SHARP*
              Tech closes at 10:45 *SHARP*
              Drivers meeting at 11:00.

   Cost:      US$15.00 for PCA members.
              US$20.00 for non-members.


Other notes:
   o We allow two drivers per car.
   o Weather is forecast to be sunny.  Bring sun protection.
   o No on site food (maybe an ice cream truck).  Bring a picnic.
   o If you're not a PCA member we can sign you up on site.

If you have any questions, please give me a call at work (617) 693-5612 or at 
home (617) 277-5295 until 10PM EST.

Hope to see you there!

Mark Forrester
1995 PCA/North East Region Autocross Chair


==========================================
1995 PCA/NER autocross schedule
May 7    Bayside Exposition Center
May 13   Autocross school, Orange Airport. Pre-reg required, call me.
Jul 16   Bayside Exposition Center (with Miata Club)
Jul 30   Site TBA
Aug 20   Orange Airport
Sep 24   Orange Airport

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 19:23:32 -0400
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Rear Springs - 914

OK, I did something dumb - in changing my rear shocks(914) I paid no
attention to which end was up on the springs.  I keep looking at them, and
can't see that it makes any difference, but thought I'd take advantage of the
Forum.  Is there a difference in the coil direction?  Which is proper?

By the way, a thought about spring compressors.  I've known for x years that
these damned springs are dangerous, and have done this bit before.  But, I
GOT LAX!!!!!  Wasn't cautious about releasing the compressors and guess what
 - I NEARLY LOST MY F__ING FACE. Believe what the manuals say, and never be
too cautious!  A spring bounced off my chest, hit the wall, and almost killed
the cat, who was sleeping peacefully!

Four ounces of Jack Daniels, and I was fine - and far more learned!

Pat Garvey

Date: Fri, 05 May 95 18:38:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Hot Targa



O wise ones, I beseech thee:

My 73 T targa (no leaks around the top, but the window seals...) runs too
warm for my ease of mind.

On a warm day in the state of Northern California, it hits 200-220 pretty
easily, and on a hot day chasing other cars of same lineage on tours I've
hit 250.

The engine is clean, oil cooler on engine is clean, new thermostat, and the
a/c stuff is out of the car.  From what I've heard, these temps aren't
unusual for this vintage, but it's still too hot.  Eventually I want the a/c 

back in and cooling requirements will be even greater.  So...

I want to add an oil cooler.  I've been thinking about using a multi-row
finned style in the rf cat throw (fender well).  The a/c was probably dealer 

added, since there's no front condenser.  I'm changing to a front S spoiler
when I repaint this summer (before Parade!) so I may mount an additional a/c 

condensor there.

Any thoughts?  Advice?  What can I expect to pay for a used cooler such as a 

Terbotrol?  What about making my own from readily available hoses/tubing and 

coolers?

I have a very happy motor and I want to squeeze as many miles out of it as I 

can.  Thanks for any input.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 18:32:27 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: re: new turbo

Hi all -

Had the chance to see the new turbo up close and personal last night.  
What a beautiful new car.

Some highlights:  the wheels are not left/right as suggested (all the same
except 10" in rear vs. 8" in front x 18" dia. and the spokes are hollow; 
something about fusing the two wheel halfs together to allow for these
hollow spokes), all leather interior including the dash (just like the old
days), the new tail is about two-three inches lower to the ground to help
with top speed and the sides/ends swoop down toward the fender before
forming the traditional lip, no basket handle and with a cabrio sitting
next to it to compare to the basket handle didn't look that bad (although
the glass one looked better; don't know why they couldn't fit it into the
rear edge of the turbo tail), then new non-filament headlights are great
(something about over 10000 volts and its just a bunch of sparks creating
the light in the enclosed glass bulb, very bluish light vs. old yellow
light), sport seats with half sides up near your upper torso area (between
stomach and shoulders), it arrived with only 32 miles on it from factory
testing and twin turbos with the largest intercooler I have seen in a
street car (couldn't see much of the engine below it :-)). 

That's about it that I can remember.  The new owner was on his way to 
pick it up.  The first thirteen from this dealership are already sold and 
with delivery of only one a month if your interested you'll have to wait 
until next April!  Of course, we all know money can talk.

Oh, BTW, they are only around $120,000 for those of you interested and 
can afford it.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR

Date: Fri, 05 May 95 19:04:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Stereo for 73 911 targa


In order to appease the girlfriend, I am installing a stereo in the 911 so 
as to make the trip to Parade more enjoyable.  Sigh.

I'm doing a consulting trade with a friend who owns a stereo store (which 
means no cash out, a big plus) and have tentatively decided on an Alpine 
7822 CD unit.  I may or may not put an additional amp in depending on how it 
sounds.

So the early 911s have the pocket that interferes with speaker installation 
in the door.  My pockets aren't perfect anyway, and I've been thinking about 
updating the door panels, and installing separates (mid-woof and tweeter).

1. Do the doors have a cut-out provision for speakers?  What year panels 
should I be considering?  Or aftermarket?  Custom?

2. Will 6.5" speakers fit or am I limited to 5.25"?

3. I'll probably use Alpine separates in the doors, but my dealer friend has 
  recommended Boston c700 plates for the rear shelf.  Comments?

4. I really like a fair amount of bass (I was going to say bottom end, but 
didn't want to excite Bart) but I have kids that fit nicely in the rear 
seats so I need to keep the rear seats and foot wells.  Any ideas about 
subwoofer placement?  I put Recaros in a year ago so I do have some room 
under the seats...

5. This will require doing something on the order of an antenna, obviously, 
and although I've considered doing the in-the-windshield  version with 
preamp ( I'm replacing the original windshield this summer when I repaint) 
cost makes me lean towards an electric antenna in the stock position in the 
rear of the RF fender.  I recall some posts about this a few months ago, but 
can't find them.  Any quality antennaes that will fit there?

Thanks in advance for any comments/advice.  Andy?  Other stereo pros?

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 22:25:57 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Galvanizing

>I believe, but am not positive, that Porsche partially galvanized all
>of its cars in 1975 and completely galvanized all its cars (including
>the 912) starting 1976.

>Can anyone confirm or deny this?

From what I understand, starting in August 1975, all of the chassis
metal was galvanized, but stuff like the fenders and the top were
the last things to be galvanized (something like 1980 before this
was done).  BTW, this pertains to 911s - I'm not sure about the other
stuff.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911 - with a spot of rust on the left front fender!!

him for giving you "racing room."

Where would true racers be if the rears locked up first?

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 6 May 1995 09:47:04 -0400
From: NPIBob@aol.com
Subject: Re: Cheap rubbers....

I just finished reconditioning and repainting a 1978 SC that I regrettably
had to sell due to my divorce.  Fortunately it went to
a fellow P-filer in MN named Vic Lee (Hi Vic!)  

I also re-did my '80 SC to concours condition a year ago.

My experience with Rubber is as follows:

Vertex - Cheapest reproductions but nearly *no* reproduction 
             rubber  parts fit as well as factory, and the rubber 
             compound is quite hard and seals poorly

Several Others in Pano/Excel - Higher than Vertex but same 
             story on the repro parts.

Tweeks - Had the cheapest OEM parts in nearly every case,
              but they did send me two repro parts and error and 
              exchanged them later.

Dealer - Remarkably, the Dealer (Sunset Porsche) was cheaper
            on some of the parts.  All OEM

Automo/Prof Prod/Stoddards - Higher than Tweeks, but Cheaper
            than the dealer in nearly all cases.

Bottom line - Go with OEM in any critical seal area (less leaks)
                   but ya still ''gotta shop around" 

Bob Dubay / NPIBob@aol.com
1980 SC Triple Black (no way I'll ever give this one up!)
1994 Grand Cherokee Boat Puller
1993 Malibu Echelon Boat Pullee

Date: Sat, 6 May 1995 13:04:19 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: ?Building a Sys Tester 9288

Yes Scott,

I believe that it is possible to build a circuit tester that could employ 
say com1 or your parallel port on your PC.  I envisioned a harness for 
those early models that didn't have test plugs.  It could sample certain 
circuits for voltages and resistances and do so to a master clock so it 
could check things like warm up cycles for the FI unit.  The PC with the 
proper interface could become a great tester for these items.  It could 
check out an FI brain or a motronic unit very quickly.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Sat, 6 May 1995 16:06:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Hot Targa

Hi Bob,

Depending upon the amount of fabrication that you wish to undertake there 
are several things that you can do.
 
Some of the guys here have used a MAZDA oil cooler mounted up front with 
the tubes taken from a '75-'77S cars.  These terminate in the r-front 
fender and with Airquip Metric fittings silversoldered onto tubing or 
hose ends have seemed to solve their problems.

My '72T would run warmer with thinner wt oil in the summer.  I could vary 
the oil temperature about 10-15 degrees with the change in wt.  I would 
like 176 F degrees to run at.

Make sure that your oil tank is clean. (Yeah right especially where its 
mounted)  I looked into a '74 one day and found that there was so much 
dirt between the tank and the body of the car that it had transmitted 
enough heat to the interior panel to melt the plastic!

David R Duffield..Date: Sat, 6 May 1995 20:28:18 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>

very near new (my 924 was like this) as NC has VERY liberal inspections.

I would be suspicious.  But this car looks the part, has a 3 car garage

Date: Sat, 6 May 1995 18:30:25 -700 (MDT)
From: Jim Conforti <jec@us.dynix.com>
Subject: Re: ?Building a Sys Tester 9288


Well, if you want to talk to the diag port (serial) on a Bosch ECU,
take a look at ISO standard 9141 ...

Called ISO-9141 "Road Vehicles - Diagnostic System - Requirments for
                   Interchange of Digital Information"

also ISO/WD 14229 and ISO/WD 124230

PS: The carrera's also have a diag system, but it's based on the 
    "alpha-n angle" [the n is subscript] tuning system .. if you're
    REAL interested, you can build one ;)




------------------------------

Date: Sat, 6 May 1995 21:26:15 -0400
From: Ckull@aol.com
Subject: 911 Valve Adjusting Blues

I just got done adjusting the valves on my 911 for the first time (I've
adjusted them on other cars before).  When I got done, the clicking of the
valves (one in particular) seems to be alot worse.  I mean it is damn
annoying and somewhat worrysome.  I didn't used to be able to really notice
the clicking that bad.  I've been around other 911's before and they were not
nearly this bad either.

Here is what I did:

1. I removed all of the spark plugs.  

2. I adjusted the valves to 0.004" using the valve adjusting tool I bought
from Automotion (little S shaped thingamajig).  I adjusted them to the point
of being fairly snug on the adjusting tool.

3. I followed the firing order (starting with #1) and rotated the engine to
TDC for each of the cylinders.

4. As I was adjusting the valves, I noticed the #2 cylinder exhaust valve
clearance was what I would call very loose.  More so than
the other valves.  Anyway, I adjusted it to the 0.004".

5. After putting everything back together (I also replaced the valve
cover gaskets) I fired the engine up.  

I immediately noticed the engine "ticked" much worse than before.  I could
tell it was coming from the drivers side, exhaust valves.  At least it was
much louder when I place my ear down near the exhaust valves (and I have a
loud exhaust).  I let the car idle for a little while then shut it off.  I'm
afraid to rev it too much.

I have a couple of questions:
*******************************

1. Will valves make more noise if they are adjusted "tight" instead of
"loose"?  Or vice versa.

2.  Would there be a reason why the previous owner would have adjusted the
valves "loose"?


Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

Corbett Kull
'85 911
ckull@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: 06 May 95 22:27:19 EDT
From: Richard Kovach <76253.1567@compuserve.com>
Subject: Fiberglas & Subwoofers -- 944

Since car audio seems to be a current topic...

I've been planning to mount some 8" JL subs in my 944.  They've been in the 
car for a while now, in a temporary box in the back.  But the plan is to mount
them in the spaces behind the rear wheel wells.  
At first I tried building boxes that would fit in these spaces and be just big
enough.
Worked perfectly except that my calculations were off and I couldn't quite get
the
boxes in place (luckily the prototype only took an hour to build...)
A friend who does installs for a living suggests I should use the existing sheet
metal for the enclosure walls, with an MDF top-surface (where the sub mounts)
cut to shape and bonded in place with fiberglas-type body filler.  He says they
do
this a lot and it works well.

Has anyone done such a thing?  I'm a little leery, because of (a) the rear side
signal
lights which could leak out air or have their gaskets "blown out" by the air
pressure,
and (b) the several drain tubes which go through those spaces and out through
rubber
grommets (this would all have to be sealed better).

I'm more inclined to spend a lot more time and create a fiberglas "shell" inside
each
cavity, shaped so that it could be removed.  The thought was that I would line
the
surfaces with foam or some other filler, then lay in the fiberglas and keep
layering it...

As I'm sure some of you have experience using fiberglas for various purposes,
I'd sure
love to hear any helpful hints or advice -- especially if it's obvious to you
that I'm about
to spend a lot of hours on a hopeless idea...

On the more mechanical note, I've FINALLY got my parts and P9201/9202 tools, so 
bright and early tomorrow those belts and motor mounts get swapped!  Wish me
luck!

Richard Kovach
1984 944 Platinum Metallic

1983 944   60,750 miles

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 6 May 1995 10:58:19 -0400 (EDT)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Porsche Quality--Low

I've had a Porsche 951 for 8 years now and I also had a Mercedes SL. I'm 
going to sell the 951 very, very soon as I want a new car. Though my 951 
is in amazingly excellent shape and has been meticulously maintained at 
some of the top Porsche dealers in the country and all service records 
have been kept and the car gets a coat of Klasse every month religiously, 
I'm not going to buy a new Porsche. Simply put, the quality of the car's 
components is awful, when compared to any M-B. The switchgear is almost 
dime-store next to that of a M-B's and the resale value is laughable. I 
think Porsches are almost the ideal car, owing to their performance and 
"okay" reliability, but in a day where a great new car starts at over 60 
grand, one must look for the quality that lies in the details. I looked 
at both a 993 cabrio and an SL500 in the same day, and the M-B is simply 
the better car. Now, for those of you who say you can't toss an SL around 
the track like a 993, I wouldn't do that to any of my personal cars. The 
993 is $75000, the M-B is $83000: with the SL, you're getting the best 
resale value of any car, the best made car in the world, the safest car, 
and a car that reeks of quality, from the carpets to the switchgear to 
the engine to the gauges. Hate to admit this, but owning a Porsche has 
made an M-B man out of me. Anyone else out there with an unbiased view? 
By that I mean, someone who has owned both an M-B and a Porsche?


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 6 May 1995 22:21:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Porsche Quality--Low

With all due respect, the 951, though fast, is still a 944, and was
not built with the same limited-production techniques as are lavished
on the 911 and 928.  The body of my 20-year-old 911 is still tight as
a vault.

There's always going to be a tradeoff between solidity and agility.
As for resale value, that is an elusive matter that has to do with
more than a car's quality or durability.  The SL and SLC were equal in
quality, but the former has always enjoyed a higher resale value.
Similarly, the 911 has held its value better than the 928.  The
Mercedes SL has always held its value exceptionally well, not only
when compared with cars of other makes, but when compared with any
other Mercedes as well.

Not to incite any flames here, but you're comparing an enhanced
version of what was meant to be an entry-level Porsche with something
near the top of the Mercedes line.  When you get past a certain point,
any standard of evaluation becomes highly personal and subjective.
It's like Harvard versus Yale.  Or whether Stanford will ever be more
than just a "Junior University" :-).

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Porschephiles #1381                         Sun May 7 15:42:53 CDT 1995
Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 02:38:46 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Porsche Quality--Low

> By that I mean, someone who has owned both an M-B and a Porsche?

Lots of us. As it turns out.

Here's the scoop: by your own admission, you bought the wrong car.
*NO* Porsche -- EVER! -- was made to compare with the MBZs. (Except
arguably the 928 which was *supposed* to have been a replacement for
the 450 SLC, or so the story goes)

The 911 is bone primitive, the waterpumpers lose about 50% of their
value in the first 3 years. But the last MBZ that I had, a 300E,
was so overengineered and over-refined that it was just not bearable
to own, so it Went Away. This has been a trend in MBZ for a while 
now -- they're great for a couple of years then they're crapped
out. Usually catastrophic accessory failure -- the hydraulic elbow
scratcher or the electric nosehair trimmer or something ELSE that costs 
soooo much to fix that you decide to sell instead.

Plus, you said the R-word: resale value. If that's even a consideration,
go buy some sort of bond or something, not a car. Shit, cars are for
driving, they're *NOT* an investment. If you're thinking that way, you're
really barking up the wrong tailpipe.

Now, the paradox: I drive a 356SC. Daily. As in *EVERY DAY*, rain
or shine. And this is Houston, so unless you're in Seattle, I can
certainly tell you about rain. And lots of miles a day, over 75 on
average. That's no accessories, totally primative, PURE car, nothing
added. I love it. 

Finally, you talked about MONEY and putting cars on the track at the
same time. I *ROUTINELY* used to put over a quarter million dollars
worth of 911 (ONE CAR) on the track at once, in traffic. Most of us don't 
think anything about taking a Plain Old Street Porsche and putting it on 
the track -- that's what they're made for. And if I had the 300SL
gullwing coupe that I've wanted for a few years now, I'd for DAMN SURE
put it on the track.

Now it's time for the Politically Correct part of this lecture: none of
this makes me right and you wrong. Porsche and MBZ make the cars that they
make, and that's that. We're all entitled to our preferences, but what
we're *NOT* entitled -- any of us -- to do is berate any one car for
not being like some other car. Otherwise the assholes at Consumer Reports
would have everything devolve back to being their "perennial bellweather,
the Toyota Camry". (Another OK car, but yoy won't see one in my driveway
now that you can't get the 3.0 V6 with a stick)

So chill out, and be glad that you've learned something important: you
are not cut out to own a Porsche.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 5 May 1995 23:05:30 -0700
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: No Valentines for Us, sniff

>I am still surprised the Mr V does not do club discounts,I mean
>Sales 101 here; "Word of Mouth" is the cheapest form of advertising.

Given the success of the V1, I suspect that Mr. Valentine had to skip
Sales 101 so that he could enroll in the graduate program for
Accelerated Manufacturing to reduce the back orders for his
high-demand product.  "Club discounts" were probably not much of a
priority for him...

>I guess we'll have to do with BELs and Escorts...
>BTW my laser Bel works fine, and was about $200.

Personally, I don't think that my ability to turn on a computer and
subscribe to a mail reflector should necessarily entitle me to
discounts on products from vendors who might also subscribe to the
list.  As long as they do not try to exploit the list, I welcome these
vendors (who might even be genuine Pcar fans like the rest of us) to
participate in discussions that ultimately improve our understanding
and knowledge of our cars and the products designed to
maintain/improve them.  Getting badgered for discounts is not likely
to contribute to such vendor participation.  In this particular
instance, Mr. Valentine responded to the request for a discount with
information about refurbished detectors.  I would not have known about
this if he were not on the list.

I have no problem with asking vendors on the list for a discount on
their products, but trying to retaliate against them by recommending
competitor's products when (for whatever BUSINESS reason they might
have) they decline to offer one (or as large a break as one might
hope) is really uncalled-for.

 -Milo
'86 951

Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 08:48:42 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: re: MB 500SL vs Porsche

Rich:

The two cars have entirely different characters outside of build quality and
hardware.  The 500SL is a great car with excellent structural rigidity but it
feels like a "tank" compared to the lightweight and responsive nature of a
911.  We just about bought a low-mileage 300SL 24 valve 5-speed last year but
after driving the car (and as a Mercedes owner), I felt it was "just like a S
series Sedan" compared to the unique (engine noise, responsiveness, small,
etc) nature of our 88 911.  A moderately well-driven 500 SL will "eat" most
Porsches (up through stock Carrera 2/4) on tracks with long straights at most
non-competitive "club type" driver education events.

The body, paint quality, and switchware of the new 84 944 I had and others
I've looked at including the last Turbo, S2, and 968, was mediocre by
comparison to Mercedes (latter also true for many BMWs).  SLs hold resale
value even better than a 911.   But if someone (maybe Bart??) suggested
driving into a brickwall at 50 mph, I'd choose the MB anytime over a Porsche
or the new M-3 we have.  But is that what you're buying it for ????

Perry

Date: Sun, 7 May 95 07:10:16 MDT
From: kimknapp@vail.net (Kim Knapp)
Subject: Re: Porsche Quality--Low

>grand, one must look for the quality that lies in the details. I looked 
>at both a 993 cabrio and an SL500 in the same day, and the M-B is simply 
>the better car. Now, for those of you who say you can't toss an SL around 
>the track like a 993, I wouldn't do that to any of my personal cars. The 
>993 is $75000, the M-B is $83000: with the SL, you're getting the best 
>resale value of any car, the best made car in the world, the safest car, 
>and a car that reeks of quality, from the carpets to the switchgear to 
>the engine to the gauges. Hate to admit this, but owning a Porsche has 
>made an M-B man out of me. Anyone else out there with an unbiased view? 
>By that I mean, someone who has owned both an M-B and a Porsche?

>RickSH


Rick,
        You are comparing apples and oranges. As others have said on this
list, ou have to buy what you like. My mother-in-law owned the 300SL for
about a year and couldn't live with it. She ended up with another MB, which
she likes better, but she could EASILY be swayed by another car. The SL
drives like a big heavy car and just is not the same type of car as a 993.
OTOH, I have a 993 that I wouldn't give up for anything. It is not just
enjoyable to drive everyday, it is downright fun. To illustrate this
further, when I bought my '91 911 C2 (which I traded for the 993) my wife
thought that it was not for her, for many of the same reasons you don't care
for the 911's. So, she got a 928, which was a heavier more "solid" feeling
car, which felt like it had more "quality". Both cars have been rock solid
reliable, but after about 2 years my wife stopped caring to drive drive the
928 and much prefers the 911. The only reason I traded the C2 for a 993 was
so that we could get a color that she felt we could share more (she didn't
like the silver :->), although I am glad we traded because the 993 is even
better yet. By the way, the C2 never had a problem in 4 years, not bad
reliability. And the 993, after 6 months hasn't seen the dealer since I
bought it, which speaks for initial quality - no adjustments, etc. I can't
say the same for the 300SL that my mother-in-law owns (or the 600SLC that my
father-in-law owns, although he loves it).
        Not all of us are biased and have owned Porsches all their lives. I
didn't buy my first one until I was about 40. I swore that the Porsches were
over priced especially compared to my previous favorite brand, Mazda, of
which I have owned several. I have also owned 2 "7" series BMWs, a brand I
prefer over MB for a sedan because of its great handling. Unfortunately, I
had many quality problems with the BMWs and it might be a while before I go
back to them.
        The point is, if you like the MB, go for it. Personally, and that is
what buying a car is all about, I wouldn't drive one unless I had to.
Driving my Land Cruiser is more fun than driving those numb handling
trucks///cars. My German friends tell me that the Germans think the MBs are
oversized boats, which could have something to do with why sales died when
they first came out with the new S class cars.
        Get the SL500 and come back in about a year and tell us how much you
like living with it, if you aren't too embarrassed :-).
                        Kim
ps Anyone want to buy a '91 928?
