Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 09:20:35 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 Valve Adjusting Blues

>I just got done adjusting the valves on my 911 for the first time (I've
>adjusted them on other cars before).  When I got done, the clicking of the
>valves (one in particular) seems to be alot worse.  I mean it is damn
>annoying and somewhat worrysome.  I didn't used to be able to really notice
>the clicking that bad.  I've been around other 911's before and they were
not
>nearly this bad either.

Corbett,

I have had this same experience.  You may be right - your valves may be
making more noise than they were before you adjusted them.  On the other
hand, I think one of Murphy's Laws deals with this phenomena - "Anytime
you make an adjustment to something to make it quieter, it's going to
sound louder whether it is or not".  OK, I'm making all of this up, but now
that you've adjusted them, you are much more conscious of how loud they
are.  

As long as you feel comfortable with the adjustments you made (what you
did sounds fine), I wouldn't worry a whole lot about it.

I was told by a well-respected mechanic that, if anything, the valves should
be adjusted a little on the loose side.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 10:59:13 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Which end locks first?

Gosh, just when P'philes was getting dull, we get another flame war! All
right!!!  Larry Herman wants us to believe his cauterization of Tracy Nelson
was an accident. And Frank Kerfoot basically got it "right" (in the Political
Correctness sense of being right). And like Frank I agree that if wheels
lock, it should be the fronts. But...

One of the standard textbooks on brake systems is "Braking of Road Vehicles"
by Newcomb and Spurr. copyrighted 1967. p. 20, under "Directional Stability",
says:

"When a wheel is locked the direction of the frictional force is independent
of the orientation of the wheel and so cannot be used to control the
direction of the vehicle." (OK, we're with you so far...)

"Consider first that the rear wheels are locked and that the vehicle is
moving in a straight line. The centre of gravity of the vehicle will continue
to move in the original direction, but if for some reason a small couple
operates about a vertical line through the CG, caused for example, by uneven
braking on the two sides of the vehicle, or by the road camber, the vehicle
acquires an angular velocity about an instantaneous centre...  (you mean it
spins, Doc?)

[Newcomb goes on to describe the actual trajectory of the car; car whill spin
faster to conserve angular momentum]....until the axis of the car is
perpendicular to the direction of motion, then begins to diminish until
eventually it becomes zero and the vehicle proceeds stably with the rear
wheels leading... (Ever wonder why many spins wind up with the car going
backwards in a straight line? Because it's stable that way).

"Conversely, if the front wheels lock the front of the car tends to slide
forward in a straight line, the vehicle as a whole being restrained by the
rear wheels. There is a caster action and the vehicle is highly stable and
will not respond to the steering wheel."

"If all four wheels lock simultaneously, the vehicle will slide down the
camber out of control. If the rear wheels lock less than 0.5 sec before the
front wheels the vehicle continues to move ahead in a straight line, and if
one rear wheel locks before the other no deviation occurs until both lock."

"There is some controversy whether front or rear skids are more dangerous;
indeed the argument goes back to the time four wheel brakes were first
introduced. A good driver with a fast response time can correct a rear wheel
skid by driving out of it, but once the car has deviated 20 degrees or so
even a skilled driver can no longer regain control if the vehicle is moving
at any speed; and at high speeds a skid can build up too rapidly for the
driver to recover from it. Once the car is out of control it is a danger to
other traffic.

"A front wheel skid gives the driver a feeling of utter helplessness as he is
powerless to steer the car. He can regain control if he releases the brake,
but then might risk a collision with the object ahead. He also feels more
vulnerable in the event of a collision, for with a rear wheel skid the rear
end of the vehicle is more likely to take the impact. Front wheel skids are
much rarer than rear wheel skids. The consensus of opinion in Europe appears
to be that rear wheel skids are more dangerous, in America opinion is more div
ided. All skids are of course dangerous; the controversy probably reduces to
whether the driver prefers to leave the road head first or tail first."

Thus endeth the scripture lesson.

Does all this mean that people who think the fronts should lock up first are
Nazi Sheep [(c), TM, marca registrada, all rights reserved by Porschephiles-Na
zi Sheep Pty. Ltd. etc.) and those who think the rears should lock up are the
Uebermenschen (Supermen to those of you who aren't into Nietsche, but then,
who is...) who can recover from a skid after the tail has come around 90
degrees?

Pete

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 07 May 1995 08:24:08 -0700
From: kemoto@nas.com (K E Motographics)
Subject: 911 stalling

I have an '85 911 coupe.  I've had it for 4 years, been very happly with it,
with no mechanical maladies other then changing the alternator at 50,000
miles.  I've also had a 356 and a 912.

About 6 months ago, it started losing power for about a second, then back to
normal.  It didn't seem like a fuel starvation thing where an engine starves
and loses rev's gradually - this is complete off and back on.
It will go weeks at a time and then repeat this, recently dying completely,
only to easily restart on the shoulder of the road, then fine.

Just to rule out fuel as the culprit, I've changed the filter twice and
found no debris, water, etc.  The shop that I take it to says the Motoronic
doesn't have diagnostics that help, which is reasonable since all the vital
signs are fine except for when it cuts out.

Both the shop and I have checked and re-seated every wire and connection
accessable, as this seems like a wire that sometimes loses contact.

Anyone experience this sort of thing?  I'm at the point of hoping for a
complete failure so that it can be diagnosed and fixed.

            
Ken Ehlers
kemoto@nas.com

Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 12:39:56 -0400 (EDT)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Thanks for 'Quality' Replies

Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 12:53:59 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: New Shoes for Katarina


Well, I took the plunge yesterday (after an excellent pre-tech of the car 
confirmed that the rear Dunlops had finally worn out - not to mention the 
right rear having developed a mysterious groove on the very inside edge 
of the tire that did not BTW go all the way around the tire; and finding 
a nail in the other).  The debate raged in my head:  Yoko A008RS's or 
Comp T/A's.  I decided (flame retardant procedures in place!) to go with 
the Comp T/A's because I'll only do about 10 days on the track this 
summer and LOTS more on the street.  I got a little nervous when I saw 
the tread (or lack of tread) pattern on the RS's.  So, call me a whimp, 
but the Comp T/A's have got to be better than my old Dunlop D40's come 
the first track event on Thursday.  BTW, net wisdom was very useful in 
this decision.  Thanks to all.

Jerry Mac
84 911 Targa (rauschquarzmettalick)
Motor-stadt Resion PCA
"Baby's got some brand new shoes!"

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 07 May 1995 11:15 -0600 (MDT)
From: Hunter Heath <HEATH@ENDO.MED.UTAH.EDU>
Subject: Build quality

My 1983 944 is "almost new," still w/ less than 20,000 mi on its untampered
odometer.  I've crawled all over/under it, and think its build quality is
very good.  However, 13 years have elapsed since it was built, a millenium in
auto industry terms, and the standard of quality has risen tremendously since
then.  I am amazed by the quality of construction, design, and fabrication in
such modest cars as Tercels, Civics, and Neons, which bests that of very
expensive cars of 15-20 years ago.

I agree that the 951/968 lines are not built to the standards of M-B, but
then few cars are, and the price difference is, um, *noticeable.*  It seems
to me a bit of apples/oranges comparison.  If I had the bread, I'd have
driven to work today in a new 993... or better yet, the new turbo.  Whoosh!
As it is, I tossed the ole '944 around a few curves and felt quite well
entertained.

After having had the 944 for two years, I must say that owning what is almost
a custom built car almost new for under $10K is very satisfying.  If the 944
body were introduced de novo today, it would look timely and sexy.  I'm a
happy buyer who would cheerfully buy a new 968 if circumstances permitted.

Hunter Heath
Utah "1983-944"

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 07 May 95 13:23:34 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Porsche Quality--Low


> Hate to admit this, but owning a Porsche has 
> made an M-B man out of me. Anyone else out there with an unbiased view? 
> By that I mean, someone who has owned both an M-B and a Porsche?
> 

I have to admit to having owned both.

My Mercedes was a solid car, to the point of being a tank. No one will ever
accuse Daimler Benz of not building a sturdy vehicle.  

Unfortunately, when they add all of that weight, they diminish the
sportiness of the vehicle. Face it, the 500SL (like the BMW 850i) is an
autobahn cruiser, not a sports car.

Porsche makes sports cars, for the most part, and that's why I own them.

Mercedes makes Sedans, and very well, but, that's not what I want.

(Of course, with 2 Audis and 3 Porsches, I always have something to do...)
- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 13:53:00 -0400
From: PersonalT@aol.com
Subject: Re: Speaker Box


If I got the drift:
The is nothing wrong with using the sheet metal for one or more sides of the
enclosure.  I have dont this many times also at my shop.  Make sure you use a
material that seals the wood to the metal well.  And use MDf like you said
not particle board.  With 8 inch speakers it probablly will not make much diff
erance but MDF is what you use for bigger speakers so why take the chance of
the wood vibrating.  I guess one side of the box sheet metal has the access
panel for the rear lights.  8 inch speakers will not build up enough pressure
to blow out the lights or anything like  that.   I don't know if you are
going to port the speaker box but if you do that the air pressure is reduced
even further.  I am not sure what the drain tubes go through the metal their.
 I assume that it comes in through one peice of sheet metal and out the
other.  You could put  a silicon sealer on it.  That would be more then fine.
 Just make sure you still have access to your tail lights.   Even if you have
to take the speaker out of the box to get to it..  If you have any other
questions let me know I would be glad to answer.  BTW I run a custom car
stereo business so anyone with car audio or security questions can direct
them to me..

PersonalT@aol.com
Personal Touch Audio
===================

Since car audio seems to be a current topic...

I've been planning to mount some 8" JL subs in my 944.  They've been in the 
car for a while now, in a temporary box in the back.  But the plan is to
mount
them in the spaces behind the rear wheel wells.  At first I tried building
boxes that would fit in these spaces and be just big enough.  Worked
perfectly except that my calculations were off and I couldn't quite get the
boxes in place (luckily the prototype only took an hour to build...) A friend
who does installs for a living suggests I should use the existing sheet
metal for the enclosure walls, with an MDF top-surface (where the sub mounts)
cut to shape and bonded in place with fiberglas-type body filler.  He says
they
do this a lot and it works well.

Has anyone done such a thing?  I'm a little leery, because of (a) the rear
side
signal lights which could leak out air or have their gaskets "blown out" by th
e air
pressure, and (b) the several drain tubes which go through those spaces and
out through
rubber grommets (this would all have to be sealed better).

I'm more inclined to spend a lot more time and create a fiberglas "shell"
inside
each cavity, shaped so that it could be removed.  The thought was that I
would line
the surfaces with foam or some other filler, then lay in the fiberglas and
keep
layering it...

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 16:40:13 -0400
From: NPIBob@aol.com
Subject: Painting Advise (long)

This is in response the an E-mail I received from fellow 
P-filer H. Wilson Busby on questions regarding my 
experiences in restoring my two 911SC's.  Thought that 
this may be of some value to anyone else taking on this 
task.

I am by no means an expert, but I am very willing to 
share my experiences (or, lack thereof <g>)  These are 
opinions only and not based on scientific fact.

First and foremost - 
==============
Examine the quality of craftmanship on work that the 
shop has done and work that is in progress.  Some 
of the keys for me were:

* Level/extent of disassembly (take it all off!!!)
* Looking at how the painter lays down metallics is a
  good indicator of his talent.  Perfectly even, no 
  variance at all!  This is not a factor on solids, but it
  does give you an idea of someone's talent with a gun.
* Hand Color Sanding vs. using a DA (Dual-Action
  Sander)  Done both, and am convinced that Hand 
  Blocking gives a ''flatter'' more uniform gloss to the 
  finished product.

Second and nearly equally important
===========================
Issue a ''work-order'' for the project.  Detail exactly and 
specifically what is to be done.  **Do not leave anything 
out**  Get it all in writing.  I did this on my second car, 
and it save money and kept confusion to an absolute
minimum.  If you expect your car to be returned in 
a condition that is ''perfect'' state it!!  No runs, No sand
through, No over-spray, hand color sanded, paint cut and
polished to a high gloss.  Door jambs painted??? etc.

(Obvoiusly - don't leave out the $$$$)

Take it off yourself!!!
===============
The money savings are obvious here but even more 
important to me was that the level of disassembly was
guaranteed.  You should arrange with a reputable glass 
shop to remove, store and re-install the glass.

I delivered my second car as a rolling shell, no glass, 
with only the doors and trunk lid attached (and the 
shop removed them)  

The disassembly and re-assembly was done without a
manual (and no, I did not have parts left over <G>)  The 
German engineers were very logical for the most part and
this made things fairly easy to ''figure out''.

Be an active participant/inspector
========================
I visited the shop on a regular and friendly basis.  You 
can monitor progress better and if they know you're 
coming by....they seem to take better care.

Supply the parts Yourself
===================
Money Savings in a big way!  Fellow P-filers were a HUGE
help to me here!!!!  All fresh OEM rubber any place a good
seal is important.

Paint Recommendation
=================
I have used PPG and Sikkens Urethane color coats with 
clear coats over.  It is my perception that the Sikkens is 
the better product.  However, I have been told that the
PPG is more flexible and will better resist rock chips.

I have also heard good things 'bout Glasurit, but have
no experience with it.

$$$$$$$$$
========
My ''baby'' cost me 'round $8500 to re-do.  (Prep/Paint/
Parts/Everything)

The shop did most of the work and I was not very satisfied 
with the work. She took first place in class at the Portland 
Rainbonnet concours, but I can still see lots-o-things that 
'bug'' me in the paint.

I did a lot more work on the second car, and It cost me
about $4500 (for all) and the quaility of the job is 
noticably better (to me) than the show car!!!!

One last comment.... It will cost more than you have
budgeted, and It will take twice as long as originally 
anticipated.  Face this on the front end and don't be upset
on the back end.  The best paint guys are true artists, and
as such...they tend to walk to that different ''beat''...They
have also been ''sniffing'' Laquers, Enamels and 
Urethanes for years.  Ya just gotta face that fact.

Hope that this is of some value to Y'all!

Bob Dubay / NPIBob@aol./com
1980 911SC Triple Black

>I have an '85 911 coupe.  I've had it for 4 years, been very happly with it,
>with no mechanical maladies other then changing the alternator at 50,000
>miles.  I've also had a 356 and a 912.
>
>About 6 months ago, it started losing power for about a second, then back to
>normal.  It didn't seem like a fuel starvation thing where an engine starves
>and loses rev's gradually - this is complete off and back on.
>It will go weeks at a time and then repeat this, recently dying completely,
>only to easily restart on the shoulder of the road, then fine.

I have the same problem on my 87 911 Carrera. I have had no luck in 
diagnosing either. Mine has not cut out yet but only happens when the engine 
is warm. The power goes out ( revs fall ) and scares the hell out of me. 
Then the power comes back and I'm away agin.

This list is great and I know somebody will help both of ou out !

Date: 07 May 95 19:26:06 EDT
From: "Eric S. Shea" <73633.1772@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: Early 911 Tires

Hi Paul:

I just went through the Early 911 Tire thing myself.

The 6x15's work well and it is my opinion that 6x16's would be no problem given
they have the same offset.  What you want is the same total height as stock (or
close) so your speedo reads right.

I found that the 205/60x15 V rated tires are only about 3mm shy of the original
specs for that car.  They seem to tuck up in there without any problems.

Good Luck!

Eric Shea

Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 20:17:52 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re: Tires for 911SC

Wayne joerd@wsunix.wsu.edu asked about his '80 911SC :

>Rolling the fender lip sounds like a "nasty permanent" change so >could you
tell me a little about what is involved?
>Should I be very careful about who I had do this operation?  Cost?

I'm not an expert on this modification, but it involves using a
baseball bat or something to crush the little lip on your fender,
or push the fender out a bit (or both). I would be very careful
about who did it. Ask someone in your local PCA club if there
is a Porsche body or race shop that does it. Anybody care
to respond to this? I used a jack handle on my first Porsche 914
(ouch).

>What do you think of the 924 vs 914 vs 911 for autoX?  I wish there was a 
>FAQ on this question, maybe I should get busy and collect answers and 
>submit it to general.faq.

Actually I have a very long article about autocrossing every model of
Porsches, I should post it to the faq. It ran in several CVR PCA
magazines, and some other newsletters picked it up. It is
geared to stock class autocrossing. But I need to update it for
1995. I'll send it to you if you want, and try to post it soon.

Anyway, the 924 has not proven very good, but the later 924S 
is quite good, it's a 944 in 924 clothing. The '73 914 (either 1.7 
or 2.0) and '74 2.0 are great autocrossers. I have a '73 2.0 in 
CT that I am thinking of selling... Your 911 should be very fun,
and competitive in PCA. In SCCA it could be tough.

Mike Piera '72 911S  '73 914/2.0 (?)

Date: Sun, 07 May 1995 22:23:53 -0400 (EDT)
From: DNEL@delphi.com
Subject: Cronar Paint

Eight or ten years ago, I had my bought-new '73 911-T restored - a very 
nice job they made of it, too.  I had them paint it guards red, using, at 
the suggestion of the shop, DuPont Cronar.
 
I haven't heard of anyone else using Cronar in all these years.  It's been 
wonderful for me - I wash it occasionally with cold water only, and that's 
all it needs.  The color is still eye-popping.  The car lives in the 
garage, so it hasn't been exposed to UV or extremes of heat or cold.
 
Is anyone familiar with Cronar?  How does it stand up to other paints?  
Have I just been lucky, or is it as good as it seems?
 
Thanks for comments.
 
Doug Nelson
Tennessee
'73 911-T 56k miles


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 23:10:11 -0400
From: RonS993@aol.com

Date: Sun, 7 May 1995 23:31:01 -0400 (EDT)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: Porsche quality

Now, let me qualify my statements by saying that I have had little
experience with the 944 series and not really that much with other
Porsches simply because I don't own one right now. :(

However, I never personally thought that the 911s seemed like they were 
of poor quality. Maybe I never paid much attention to these things, I was
too busy absorbing the driving experience of the car. The thing that 
struck me the most about a 911 was that the pedals stuck out of the floor,
the windshield seemed rather upright, and the engine made the most unique,
interesting sound I've ever heard- maybe. Whenever I've driven a 911, I am
always reminded of a hopped-up VW Beetle, for some reason. I guess that's 
coming from my childhood, when my Dad drove to work in a Beetle. What a car.
You could always tell when he was coming home, 'cos you could hear him
from a block away. :-) I loved that Beetle. I guess from that time on,
I've had an innate attraction for air-cooled, flat engines in a car 
designed by a German engineer named Porsche. I hope that the 996 will retain
some of that unique engine note and character that sets the 911 apart from
other sports cars.

I've only ridden in a Mercedes, never driven one. But I think a friend's
father put it best: "I feel like an old man driving the Mercedes (it was 
a 560 SL). Especially with the automatic transmission."

If you ask me, a Mercedes is not a car for a driving enthusiast. At least 
not in the US, where you can't get a Benz with a manual transmission. For 
the most part. (I think) If I wanted a sedan, BMW is my choice. I wish I 
could get an M5, that was the sweetest driving experience I've ever had, 
except for the Porsche, which was a religious experience. :-)

Also, you shouldn't be worried about resale value with either a Porsche 
or a Mercedes. These are cars that are meant to be bought, and driven for 
the life of the car. I couldn't imagine selling a Porsche, if I bought it 
new. It's like having another child in the family.

- -- 
Taka Mizutani                                     University of Pennsylvania
takaharu@mail.sas.upenn.edu                            Philadelphia, PA, USA
Land line: (215) 243-1247                             Mobile: (215) 960-0592

Date: Sun, 07 May 1995 20:45:15 -0700
From: cbarbosa@Direct.CA (Charlo Barbosa)
Subject: Planning to purchase '77 911S

I'm planning to purchase a '77 911s, but when I had the vehicle inspected,
the mechanic (Eurosport - pretty reputable Porsche service center in
Vancouver) said that the engine needs to be completely overhauled.  He said
that there is power loss from the engine because the head gaskets leak on #4
and #5.


Here was the compression check:

          1) 125    2) 125    3) 130    4) 110    5) 115    6) 125

Here was the leakdown test:

          1) 10%    2) 16%    3) 12%    4) 70%    5) 40%    6) 8%


There are 155,000 miles on the engine.  I read in the 911 FAQ, that the 2.7
litre engine has an average of a 50,000 mile life-span.  Eurosport said that
it will cost me around $5,000 (Cdn), or $3,500 (US) to rebuild.  Would it be
better to rebuild this engine or find a good used 3.0 litre engine?  What
would be more expensive?

Another problem was that the rotors all had to be replaced.  The car hasn't
been in any accidents, the paint is still original and beautiful, there is
no rust and basically everything else checks out.  

I was wondering if an offer price of $10,500 (Cdn) or $7,350 (US) is
reasonable for this car. 


Charlo Barbosa
cbarbosa@direct.ca

Date: Mon, 08 May 1995 01:03:56 +0600
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: Fiberglas & Subwoofers -- 944

Hello Richard,

Your idea is not a bad one in theory.  It must, however, be properly carried 
out.  There is nothing fundamentally wrong with using the "metal" of the car 
as part of the enclosure as long as it is structurally solid.  It is 
imperative, however, that the resulting enclosure is *completely* air tight 
for maximum efficiency.  There must be no leaks or gaps anywhere in the box 
that can allow air to escape (regardless of whether you intend to build an 
acoustic-suspension or a bass-reflex enclosure).  I suspect that this goal 
might be difficult to achieve with respect to the lenses and drain tubes 
present in that area of the car.  With that in mind I would recommend the 
fiberglass enclosure or "shell" route you suggested to build a custom formed 
enclosure to specifically conform to that mounting location.  You must 
design it so as not to prevent access to the rear light bulbs in the event 
that they may need replacing.  It sounds as though you are well on your way 
to improved bass, and some basic fiberglass work should bring your project 
to proper completion.  Fiberglass is not the *only* option, but it is 
usually the easiest medium to use when dealing with many complex curves, 
shapes, etc.  Follow the instructions very carefully on the fiberglass 
products you use.  To avoid a very lengthy discussion of fiberglass working 
I will recommend that you check out a book about fiberglass boat repair at 
your library for some of the basic info regarding fiberglass work.  

In case you don't have the necessary information, here are the enclosure 
volumes recommended by JL Audio for their 8" subs. 
                                                                             
Sealed Enclosure Volume:      8W1-4or8   0.25 - 0.375 cubic feet
                                             8W6          0.25 - 0.5    
cubic feet

Ported Enclosure Volume       8W1-4or8    0.375 -0.875 cubic feet
                                            8W6           0.5 - 0.875    
cubic feet

Good Luck!  Hope this helps.  Let me know if you have more questions.

Andy 
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)
                                                                              



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 08 May 1995 01:04:02 +0600
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: Radio Help!

Jonathan, 

The fact that your speakers "click" at power up most likely indicates that 
your problem lies within the head unit (assuming that there is no type of 
external amplifier powering the speakers).  Obvioulsy, the unit is getting 
proper power if all other functions work properly.  If it were a problem 
with the head-to-speaker wiring then you would not hear that power-on 
clicking.  If you want to check for yourself, disconnect the speaker clip 
and turn the unit on and off listening for the clicking.  There should be no 
sounds what-so-ever.  If the unit has a "knob" style volume control then 
that *may* be your culprit as the wire-wound potentiometers often wear and 
become dirty (although that doesn't necessarily explain the total lack of 
sound).  I recommend that you take the unit in to a repair shop to diagnose 
and repair the problem.  If the cost is excessive I strongly recommend that 
you do *not* have it repaired.  New units are not that expensive, and now 
may be a good time to upgrade to CD if you wish.

Hope this helps.  More questions?

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 08 May 1995 01:03:23 +0600
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: Stereo for 73 911 targa (long)

>In order to appease the girlfriend, I am installing a stereo in the 911 so 
>as to make the trip to Parade more enjoyable.  Sigh.

Who knows, maybe you will  like some extra tunes once in a while as well.  I 
know the sound of a 911 engine is music to a P-philes ears,  but a little 
tune-age on the long trips is nice sometimes.

>I'm doing a consulting trade with a friend who owns a stereo store (which 
>means no cash out, a big plus) and have tentatively decided on an Alpine 
>7822 CD unit.  I may or may not put an additional amp in depending on how it 
>sounds.

IMO, the Alpine is a very good, high-performance unit.  You should be very 
pleased with your choice.  You will want to add a basic small to mid-sized 
amplifier if you experience problems with excessive road noise and/or 
top-off listening.  An external amp will allow your system to play louder 
and *cleaner* with far less distortion at medium to high listening levels 
than the head-supplied power.  If you find it unbearable to listen due to 
road/engine/wind noise, then go for an external amp.  An amp not only makes 
a system potentially louder, but it *also* will improve the overall sound 
quality and dynamic range in most cases.

>So the early 911s have the pocket that interferes with speaker installation 
>in the door.  My pockets aren't perfect anyway, and I've been thinking about 
>updating the door panels, and installing separates (mid-woof and tweeter).
>
>1. Do the doors have a cut-out provision for speakers?  What year panels 
>should I be considering?  Or aftermarket?  Custom?

I can't tell you what lies behind the stock door panels of your '73, as I 
have never personally opened them up.  Perhaps somebody else on the list can 
help you there, or just pull the panels and check it out for yourself.  If 
you want to go to the expense of aftermarket specialty door pods that will 
handle separates, then take a look at the SOUND QUEST "Audioforms" line of 
equipment.  They are specially designed speaker pods created for a 
particular model of car, and are designed to blend and flow with the lines 
of the interior as much as possible.  They are *not* cheap, but they do 
usually turn out well.  Also, USD Audio by Speaker Works sells 
raw-fiberglass kick-panel enclosures for the 911 that will accomodate 
separates.  Using kick panel enclosures you elimiate the need to do any work 
with the door panels.   Alternatively, a good installer (or a highly 
competent DIY'er) should have no problem custom fabricating new door panels 
or speaker pods of your preference.  The experienced professional will use 
various materials (MDF, fiberglass, bondo, etc.) to custom build any style 
of door panel/pods that your tastes desire suited to accomodate any size 
driver you wish.  Obvioulsy this service is, likewise,  *not* inexpensive, 
but it can yield some of the most attractive aftermarket looks possible.

Addresses:       Recoton (Sound Quest)(Z-Box) 
                        2950 Lake Emma Rd.
                        Lake Mary, FL 32746
                        Phone (407)333-8900
                        Fax (407)333-8903

                        USD Audio
                        1030 N. Main
                        Suite A
                        Orange, CA 92668
                        Phone (714)997-9880
                        Fax (714)997-7360

>2. Will 6.5" speakers fit or am I limited to 5.25"?

Once again, that depends upon whether you want to maintain the factory look 
or opt for a custom installation.  If you prefer to mount directly to the 
factory door panel, you will be limited by the maximum cut-out diameter in 
the door, as well as the max mounting depth available in the door.  If you 
go custom, on the other hand, you will be able to accomodate nearly any size 
driver(s) you want.

>3. I'll probably use Alpine separates in the doors, but my dealer friend has 
>  recommended Boston c700 plates for the rear shelf.  Comments?

I have privately commented several times to others on the list regarding 
rear speakers.  Without going into excessive detail, basically, some people 
like a bit of "rear-fill" to add ambience and "realism" to the sound while 
others prefer no rear speakers at all.  I myself do not prefer any rear-fill 
based around the idea that stereo reproduction demands *two* channels, but 
the debate is highly controversial.  The choice to add rear speakers is 
yours.  I *do not* recommend that you spend excessive amounts of money on 
very hi-fi rear speakers, as it is simply unnecessary and over-kill.  A good 
plan is to add the fronts, listen, and then decide if you want to add the 
rears based on your *own* preferences.  If you do opt to add rears the 
plates should give you good results, and if the Boston's sound good to *you* 
then go for 'em.

>4. I really like a fair amount of bass (I was going to say bottom end, but 
>didn't want to excite Bart) but I have kids that fit nicely in the rear 
>seats so I need to keep the rear seats and foot wells.  Any ideas about 
>subwoofer placement?  I put Recaros in a year ago so I do have some room 
>under the seats...

If you want good bass, you need a sub(s) and a corresponding amp to drive 
them.  Sub placement is not easy in a 911.  As before, most options involve 
some degree of custom work.  Determine what you want, what you are willing 
to spend, and then consult your local installer.  Recoton also makes a line 
of pre-fab enclosures under the name of "Z-Box" designed for different cars. 
 One model is designed to fit the area below the rear seat of a 911, and 
another is designed to fit the "rear-deck" area above the back of the rear 
seat.  They are not inexpensive, but are a good alternative.  A good 
installer should be able to design small enclosures for under the front 
seats, space permitting.  Lastly, a pro could do a custom installation 
involving a front-trunk mounted enclosure.

>5. This will require doing something on the order of an antenna, obviously, 
>and although I've considered doing the in-the-windshield  version with 
>preamp ( I'm replacing the original windshield this summer when I repaint) 
>cost makes me lean towards an electric antenna in the stock position in the 
>rear of the RF fender.  I recall some posts about this a few months ago, but 
>can't find them.  Any quality antennaes that will fit there?

Contact Hirschmann in regard to aftermarket antennas suitable for your 
application.
                    P.O. Box 229
                    Riverdale, NJ 07457
                    Phone (201)945-8880
                    Fax (201)945-1218

>Thanks in advance for any comments/advice.  Andy?  Other stereo pros?
>
>Bob Brewer
>rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Hope this helps!  Let me know if you need any further advice.

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)

Porschephiles #1383                         Mon May 8 11:53:06 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 06:30:43 -0400
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: are we going backwards?


Hi, gang,

  Yesterday, Peter Albrecht came out of the library, blew the dust off his
tome, and spake:

>One of the standard textbooks on brake systems is "Braking of Road Vehicles"
>by Newcomb and Spurr. copyrighted 1967. p. 20, under "Directional Stability",
>says:

>"When a wheel is locked the direction of the frictional force is independent
>of the orientation of the wheel and so cannot be used to control the
>direction of the vehicle." (OK, we're with you so far...)        

(most of excellent technical description of the emoticon =:-o deleted) 

>[Newcomb goes on to describe the actual trajectory of the car; car whill spin
>faster to conserve angular momentum]....until the axis of the car is
>perpendicular to the direction of motion, then begins to diminish until
>eventually it becomes zero and the vehicle proceeds stably with the rear
>wheels leading... (Ever wonder why many spins wind up with the car going
>backwards in a straight line? Because it's stable that way).

   Ummm, I have a slight quibble with your paraphrashing.  Now, I must admit,
I have never read this Newcomb fellow, but I have read some other guy with
a very similar name... gosh what was it? ... Ahh, Newton!  That's it, Newton.
Angular momentum is not conserved in this situation (obviously!).  We are not
talking about an ice skater pulling her arms in while spinning.  The car
spins faster as the axis of the car nears the direction perpindicular to the 
direction of travel because that is where the torque on the car is greatest.
The force is applied to the car by the road through the front tires.  The
(projected) distance of the tires to the CG (i.e., the lever arm) goes as 
the sine of the angle of rotation, hence, maximum at 90 deg.

  Just clarifying the obvious!

Paul Lyman
Nazi-Sheep to the Laws of Motion

P.S., Yo, Pete, I just re-read this before sending it out.  My message *could*
be read with a slightly negative cast to it.  Not my intention.  YOU might
want to see more fireballs around here, but I don't want to be on the other
end of the flamer-of-the-month's blowtorch!

> I have an 84 944. It runs and dies. I think I have a loose wire in the back
> of the fuse box but I can't drop the box because I the relay that controls

Yep, you can get it out...

1) Disconnect the battery.
2) Remove that relay that is keeping it from pivoting.
3) You may have to use a bit of force (prybar) to move the fusebox, there's
   just too much wiring attached for it to move easily...

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 08:50:47 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Brake Bias


>I read the recent thread on front/rear brake bias with interest.  Assuming
>street cars are set up to lock up the front first for safety reasons, is
this
>something worth changing on a road car that is used for about 6 to 8 track
>events per year?  If so, how does one do this?
>
>Joe <OneGRed930@aol.com>


Joe:

IMHO, I have found that the bias in most 911/930s to be acceptable for the
track.  My car (911 Carrera) wears out rear pads 1/2 as fast as the fronts,
and I can definately feel a difference (poorer braking) when the rear pads
have worn out.  Unless you are RACING and looking for a couple of tenths of a
second per lap, don't worry about trying to add more rear bias on your 930.
 Just make sure that everything is working properly.

However, as a point of information, there are three typical ways to do so.
 If the rules allow, the best way is a dual master cylinder setup (one
cylinder for the front, and one for the rear), with an adjustable balance
bar.  This will allow you to "balance" the pressure to the fronts and rears,
and it will keep that balance all the way through the braking range.  The
more typical way is to install an adjustable proportioning valve; replacing
the existing fixed one.  This will set an upper limit to the pressure that
the rear brakes will see, and will prevent them from getting enough pressure
to lock.  I am not an expert on exactly how these valves work, so that is a
question best left to others.  The final way to adjust brake bias is through
brake pad selection.  This is what most racers have to do if the rules
prohibit any of the above modifications.  By selecting rear pads that produce
more braking effect (at the same pedal pressure) than the fronts, you will
have effectively added more rear brake bias.  This is also an easy way to
"tune" your car for the track, and then set back for the street.  It's best
to discuss this with some of the brake pad reps, and stay with the same brand
of pad, for uniformity.  Some of the more knowlegeable ones should know
exactly what you want to do.


Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 08:58:22 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Porsche Quality--Low


~e

> > I've had a Porsche 951 for 8 years now and I also had a Mercedes SL. I'm 
> > going to sell the 951 very, very soon as I want a new car. Though my 951 
> > is in amazingly excellent shape and has been meticulously maintained at 
> > some of the top Porsche dealers in the country and all service records 
> > have been kept and the car gets a coat of Klasse every month religiously, 
> > I'm not going to buy a new Porsche. Simply put, the quality of the car's 
> > components is awful, when compared to any M-B. The switchgear is almost 
> > dime-store next to that of a M-B's and the resale value is laughable. I 
> > think Porsches are almost the ideal car, owing to their performance and 
> > "okay" reliability, but in a day where a great new car starts at over 60 
> > grand, one must look for the quality that lies in the details. I looked 
> > at both a 993 cabrio and an SL500 in the same day, and the M-B is simply 
> > the better car. Now, for those of you who say you can't toss an SL around 
> > the track like a 993, I wouldn't do that to any of my personal cars. The 
> > 993 is $75000, the M-B is $83000: with the SL, you're getting the best 
> > resale value of any car, the best made car in the world, the safest car, 
> > and a car that reeks of quality, from the carpets to the switchgear to 
> > the engine to the gauges. Hate to admit this, but owning a Porsche has 
> > made an M-B man out of me. Anyone else out there with an unbiased view? 
> > By that I mean, someone who has owned both an M-B and a Porsche?
> > 
> > RickSH
> > ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

I agree with you, but I also question the reliability.  I own an "87" 944
and personally have had very good luck with the car.  I have put 55,000 miles
on the car, it has 63,000 total miles, and have never been stranded, but I
drive the car in anticipation of something breaking.  What will it be?  The 
water pump, the heater control valve, the ring and pinion, a motor mount,  the
cruise control, a C-V joint,  oil in the antifreeze, ball joints,
 and on and on.  The main quality 
thing that bothers me is the laughable chip guard.  Why did they even bother?
I drove the car in the snow twice and it looks like somebody sandblasted the 
rocker panels and the tuner on the Blaupunkt Reno is the worst I have ever had
the displeasure of listening to.

The funny thing is when I consider what else I would own for what the car
cost me, I go right back to the 944.  The low resale value is to my advantage
because I'll never be able to buy a new one.  In 91 I paid $14,700 for the 
car that was about $30,000 new in "87".  You can't even buy a Honda Accord
for that amount of money.  Maybe a Dodge Neon, but consider that you'll then
be driving a Dodge Neon and I'll take the 944 everytime.  The closest thing
in terms of performance is an Integra VTEC or a Probe GT.  The Integra has
a terrific engine that is not much faster than the 944,  but the handling or
brakes aren't even in the same league.  The Probe rides like a truck has
a better engine and no appeal.  Both are over $20,000, the extra $5000 would
go a long way towards maintaining the 944.
In light of the choices, I'd take the questionable reliability 
and quality everytime.

Jeff
jpuzas@astro.ge.com

Re: 993 bra. I use a *MagBra* $99 US, 410-633-6336, Baltimore, MD on my
Riviera Blue (solid color) 993. Stays on at 125MPH at LRP. Obviously magnetic
material does not cover resilient plastic nose area, but chipping is not as
big a problem there either. Also Botho v. Bose in Ottawa has a *Stongard*
clear film bra made by *Those Guys* 206-646-0670 or 800-350-4897 in Bellevue,
WA, on his Silver 993. 
Re: Paint Care. I use Zymol Carbon on metal areas and Zymol Detail on plastic
(resilient) areas. Works great so far, 5 months.

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 09:36:25 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Porsche Quality--Low

>By that I mean, someone who has owned both an M-B and a Porsche?
>
>
>RickSH
>ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Between my father and I, we owned a 76 300D for 17 years. It leaked water
into the interior, and the floor boards rusted out. It made 76 HP. The
fenders around the headlights rusted out. The rubber seal around the trunk
disintegrated. The vaccum pump that supplied the power assist to the brakes
died regularly. the pnuematic plumbing leaked, requiring the car to be shut
off manually with a switch under the hood. The A/C pump siezed, and since
the entire system had been added after the car was designed, it required
$700 in labor to remove. The stuffing fell out of the drivers seat. The
clock died. the blower fan siezed. The cruise fried. The lectric antenna
froze. The MANUAL pump for the windshield washer died.

The porsche had a bad clutch from day 1, that eventually failed after 30K
mi, and even though the problem had been reported in writing during the
warranty period (no fault found, duh). I only managed to get "good will"
donation of parts, $900 in labor. The header cracked because some fool
engineer didn't realize that a stainless steel piece bolted to an aluminum
alloy piece would experience differential thermal contraction abd expansion
on every heat cycle and fail. (ok, so it WAS covered)

It seems to me that these cars depreciate enough to buy a new honda
everytime the old one breaks. Of course, if you don't WANT a Honda, you
should shut up and drive. If you're not still smiling when you get there,
you got the wrong car.

Flame off.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 95 09:44:08 EDT
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: Which end locks first?

>Gosh, just when P'philes was getting dull, we get another flame war! All
>right!!!  Larry Herman wants us to believe his cauterization of Tracy Nelson
>was an accident. And Frank Kerfoot basically got it "right" (in the Political
>Correctness sense of being right). And like Frank I agree that if wheels
>lock, it should be the fronts. But...
>.....
>
>"Consider first that the rear wheels are locked and that the vehicle is
>moving in a straight line. The centre of gravity of the vehicle will continue
>to move in the original direction, but if for some reason a small couple
>operates about a vertical line through the CG, caused for example, by uneven
>braking on the two sides of the vehicle, or by the road camber, the vehicle
>acquires an angular velocity about an instantaneous centre...  (you mean it
>spins, Doc?)

Tracy and I discussed this a bit more by email. BTW, dispite Tracy's
attempts at a "T*d of the month" award, he seems like a reasonable guy
by email, and I would expect him to be a bit more circumspect in the way
he offers opinions to the group in the future.

In any case, I think that a very relevant point in the "rear locks first"
scenario under maximum braking conditions is that with something on the
order of a large fraction of 1G applied at the front wheels, several
feet in front of the CG, very substantial torques about the
CG are generated for small angular errors (i.e. if the CG isn't directly
behind the point where the braking force is applied). As the car starts
to rotate, the torque generated by the braking force continues to
increase rapidly as the angle between the force on the CG from braking
and the line to the point where the force is applied increases. In
effect you can transfer a large part of the braking force into rotational
force. Thus you get a VERY fast spin, until the car reaches the stable
position with the CG in front of the wheels applying the braking (i.e
the car is going straight backward).  While stable, this is usually not
what the driver had in mind.

Tracy suggested he doesn't find this to be the case on ice, which is
true, because you can't generate enough braking force on ice to create a
very strong rotational force. It is also different than the trail
braking disucssions, with partial braking and simultaneous turning.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 10:10:31 -0400
From: SBrao@aol.com
Subject: Re: www/912

Wade writes, 
I believe, but am not positive, that Porsche partially galvanized all
of its cars in 1975 and completely galvanized all its cars (including
the 912) starting 1976.

Can anyone confirm or deny this?

During my long and seemingly unending search for the 912 of my dreams, I have
seen a specimen 76 model year with typical pre 76' symptoms of rust ( floor
pan, battery box ). Although its true that many of the bodies were
galvanized, I believe that the earliest 912's were "left over" non galvanized
911 bodies from the 75' model year. I have seen no examples of 911 non
galvanized bodies from 76 or later, supporting my theory that the 912's were
given "leftovers". It's not that difficult to check either way.
Happy hunting!

Steve Brao

Date: Mon, 8 May 95 11:53 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Rear Mirror Attachment

    Any suggestions on an adhesive to attached my rearview mirror to the 
    windshield?  (And where I can get it if not readily available at a 
    hardware store etc.)  TIA!

I just replaced mine with some stuff called, appropriately enough, "rear-view
mirror adhesive".  I got it at Pep Boys, it was about $2.  Just make sure to
make a mark on the outside of the windshield where the residue is, scrape the
old stuff off with a razor blade, then follow the directions on the package.
Mine (on my 944) was easy, there was a small bracket that had to be mounted,
then the mirror just snapped onto that.  That way, I didn't have to sit there
holding the mirror against the glass until the adhesive dried.

Good luck!
- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)

Date: Mon, 08 May 1995 12:34:42 +0600
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: Tree sap on my paint! Best way to remove?

Hey Marc,

I'm sure you'll get a great explanation from Larry at Car Care Specialties, 
but here's a little primer until then.  Your only salvation here is the fact 
that the cars are well waxed.  As long as the sap hasn't become rock hard 
and solidified from heat/age on the car then you shouldn't have too much 
difficulty getting it off.  Some careful scrubbing (to avoid scratching) 
with a good amount of dish detergent (Ivory, Dawn, Palmolive, etc.) should 
do the job.  Like Larry says, these are designed to remove amimal fat and 
vegetable oils from dishes, but they should do similar duty to tree sap on 
sheet metal.  The catch is, however, that you *must* re-wax (at least the 
washed area) the car after using such a soap because it will strip the wax 
along with the sap.

If the sap is too stubborn to come off with hefty dish soap, step up to an 
automotive bug and tar remover.  I have also used a 3M product available at 
body shop suppliers called "General Purpose Adhesive Cleaner" with good 
rusults.  This is a rather powerful cleaner that should remove most any 
tar/sap/adhesive/bug deposits from your cars.  Just for extra precaution I 
recommend that you test it with a soft rag on a hidden portion of paint on 
each car to be sure that it is compatible.  Once again, any bug/tar remover 
product will strip wax along with the contaminant.  I recommend that you 
wash the area where the cleaner was used with car-wash solution or dish-soap 
and immediately re-wax the area(s). 

The moral of the story is *don't* park your car(s) under tree sap.  It just 
isn't good for the finish to have the above cycles constantly repeated (not 
to mention a lot of work).

I hope this helps.  Good luck.

Andy
(General Stereo Guy & Auto Detailer)



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 95 12:40:59 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Laws of motion repealed... nah!

Paul writes:
> 
> >[Newcomb goes on to describe the actual trajectory of the car; car whill spin
> >faster to conserve angular momentum]....until the axis of the car is
> >perpendicular to the direction of motion, then begins to diminish until
> >eventually it becomes zero and the vehicle proceeds stably with the rear
> >wheels leading... (Ever wonder why many spins wind up with the car going
> >backwards in a straight line? Because it's stable that way).
> 
>    Ummm, I have a slight quibble with your paraphrashing.  Now, I must admit,
> I have never read this Newcomb fellow, but I have read some other guy with
> a very similar name... gosh what was it? ... Ahh, Newton!  That's it, Newton.
> Angular momentum is not conserved in this situation (obviously!). 

Beg to quibble - you can't switch off conservation of momentum.
Angular momentum undeniably IS conserved, like it or not. The
change in angular momentum of the vehicle is equal to the
angular impulse applied (couple integrated over time), which
of course is also applied inversely to the surface the vehicle
is on. So as the car spins up, the earth (or whatever body your
vehicle happens to be spinning on) will spin (much more slowly)
in the opposite direction...

However, this has, as I think you were trying to point out,
nothing whatever to do with the way that the applied couple
on the vehicle varies with angular displacement.


> We are not
> talking about an ice skater pulling her arms in while spinning.  The car
> spins faster as the axis of the car nears the direction perpindicular to the 
> direction of travel because that is where the torque on the car is greatest.
> The force is applied to the car by the road through the front tires.  The
> (projected) distance of the tires to the CG (i.e., the lever arm) goes as 
> the sine of the angle of rotation, hence, maximum at 90 deg.
>   Just clarifying the obvious!

This part is quite correct, although it is possible that the
monent of inertia of the driver is reduced a bit as every sphincter
muscle available get clinched up really hard, this won't have a noticeable
effect on the trajectory.
And to elaborate a bit more, although the bass-ackwards position is
stable when the rears are locked and the fronts are not, it isn't
as if the vehicle will suddenly stop spinning once it gets backwards.
Although the couple between the front wheels and the CG will have
gone to zero, it will have been positive throughout the spin except
at the 90 degree point, where the front wheels operate in 100% slide.
This assumes that the driver has kept the fronts pointed straight ahead,
since your analysis also seems to have so assumed. So as the vehicle
approaches 90 degrees, the couple goes to zero, the rises again
and goes to zero again at 180 degrees. This effect explains why many spins
only go 90 degrees, and many only go 180 degrees. The thing is, though,
that if you make it as far as 180 degrees, you are very likely to
keep going - there was a positive couple applied to the car except for
an instant at 90 degrees, and another instant at 180 degrees. The spin
will only stop at the 90 degree point or the 180 degree point if the
damping in the system dissipates the rotational energy as the stability
point is reached. With big sticky tires, this happens a lot. And if the
driver takes corrective (or defensive) action, it becomes more likely:
once you start spinning in an uncontrolled manner, lock 'em up!
Then you don't get this see-saw rising and falling applied couple, 
and the effect is primarily dissipative.

By the way, it's the conservation of rotational momentum that leads
to the classic "button hook" spin as well - the vehicle begins to
rotate, the driver corrects (accurately, inaccurately, it hardly
matters) and the vehicle comes back into line, and keeps right on
going, resulting in a spin in the other direction. This is because
the driver did not "recover" correctly. The correction stops the
spin and starts the vehicle back towards the proper orientation,
the recovery makes the vehicle stop rotating as it reaches the
proper orientation.

> Nazi-Sheep to the Laws of Motion

Ubershaff hier, und du ist nicht gut gesprecht.
Like I know german! really, I'm much better with a wrench...
no blowtorch here either...


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 08 May 95 12:49:27 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Rear Mirror lose

> 
> Readers, I have a 85.5 944 with a lose rear view mirror, I looked it over
> and can't seem to find a set screw, also would like to remove it to 
> remove a 'sticker" on the back of the mirror.
> TIA
> 

Hi, David,

The arm that holds the mirror has a bracket that slides into the support on
the windshield from above.

The support on the windshield has a couple of prongs that keep the mirror
arm under tension, thus keeping it from wobbling.  Those tend to get bent out
and let the mirror wobble.

To remove the mirror, rock the arm gently, with a twisting motion and a
slight amount of force to lift it up.  The operative word is gently, because,
if you put too much pressure on it, you will break the windshield.

After you remove the mirror, you can see the prongs I'm talking about. You
can then, very gently, with a pair of needlenose pliers, move the prongs
slightly to the front of the car (about .005 inches) to restore the tension 
and tighten your mirror.

If you break the windshield, don't blame me, but it can be done.  You may
want to take a copy of these instructions to your local glass installer and
ask him to do it for you...
- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (needs work)
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1384                         Mon May 8 16:12:44 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 8 May 95 09:53:55 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Locking Brakes


As the owner of a 944 and a couple of 924s, I can tell you that these
4 wheel disc brake cars are quite capable of locking ALL four wheels
at once. Especially when being autocrossed or track driven. I have a 
stack of flat spotted Yokohamas to prove this point. 

The problem, as Pete Albrecht touched on, is that locking is an uneven
process. That is, road surface, tire inflation, wheel bearings, tread 
condition, etc. all contribute to the equation. 

Front locking is correctable. Rear locking, especially when the left 
rear locks before the right (the most normal situation) turns the car
with no appeciable method of correction: when it occurs, you are toast,
locked into the direction unless you correct the situation.

This is more critical on the race track, if the unloaded inside tire 
tends to lock, you either slow or risk losing control. Larry Wilson
stated that you brake to the point of minimal lockup. This is true
when racing. You have to understand what the car does. If it locks the 
front brakes, you can predict how deep into a corner you go. If the 
rears lock, then you don't have any confidence in where you're going, 
hence, go slower. On my Shelby GT-350, I set the adjustment on the rear 
brakes to allow the fronts to lock: this was worth 2 seconds at Laguna 
Seca because the car became a more stable platform under braking, I 
could carry more speed in and exit faster as I could take a more 
aggresive line.

The reason we are seeing more ABS is because it tends to correct some of 
the braking problems that occur because of the excessive front weight 
bias of the modern front-wheel drive sedans. It also covers up the use
 of sh*t brake pad material that is being used in place of asbestos
materials. Considering the poor road surfacing in this country and the
poor quality of driver training, ABS is a good thing.

There is a fact to be considered here; most people drive in the same
manner they have sex. They will never approach the limits that will
thrill them driving. I'm glad I don't see them having sex.

If you want a car that locks the rear brakes, buy a 1980 Chevy Citation.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 08 May 95 12:55:32 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Tree sap on my paint! Best way to remove?

> Hi Porschephiles!
> 
>     I need a little advice on cleaning my car, Recently I moved to a new 
> house and now have to park my Black 944, Black GTI 16v & Black S-10 
> Blazer under some trees.
>     Here is athe problem, I have noticed little drops of sap appearing 
> all over the cars, The Porsche is usually covered but from just being 
> parked uncovered for a little while also picked up the sap.
> All the cars have good coats of wax on them. Whats is the best way yo 
> remove this sap?
> Thanks in advance for the excellant advice this list usually produces.
> Marc
> 
Sounds like you would be a good candidate for the quantity discount on 
Car Covers...

First, don't let the sap sit for any length of time. It will eventually get
so hard that it will remove the paint when you try to remove it...

You can use kerosene, or a bit of gasoline on a soft rag to soften the tar 
and it will come off with a bit of rubbing. Rewax that area immediately 
and find another place to park it...
- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

noticeable texturing, but the LR & RR fender lips (which are much thinner 
than the width of front fender lips) have hardly any texturing.

than obvious texturing on the rear fender lips than on the front fender lips? 
Or does this car probably have replacement fenders? Its a really clean car 
(inside and out) with low mileage, incomplete documentation, and only one
owner.

the car insured, couldn't he have his insurance company replace the windshield

Date: Mon, 08 May 95 10:17:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: 914 rear bumper swap


>How about just replacing the heavy
>back bumper with the earlier kind, are they easily interchangeable and
>will it help the front/rear balance?

I theory, all you'd have to do is drill 2 holes on each side of the rear
part of the car in order to bolt up the early bumper.....BUT....

the '75 and '76 have a slightly modified rear trunk floor to accomodate
the bumper shocks.  This new raised area is directly in line with the top
hole you'd have to drill.

I'm going to do this swap anyway, since my car is sitting 3" off the
ground and I don't need any more weight back there.  So I'm going to
weld a stud to my car where the top hole should be drilled and
remove the welded nuts from the top holes on the bumper.  These
welded nuts can be easily removed with a center punch.

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
'75 914-6  3.0 SC

i have the following that i need to get rid of:

this unit is one piece, i simply had the pieces joined when the flange
at the rear of the cat broke. also, the cat has been cut open and
emptied. (by PO).

most of the 15hp that the early 928's lost when crossing the atlantic. 
i removed
them, and went back to stock, because i wanted the more civilized sound of
the stock exhaust.

i'd like to get $50 for the whole mess, plus shipping. shipping the muffler
won't be too bad, but the other piece will be a hassle/expensive, as it is
one piece, about 9 feet long.

anybody interested?

Date: Mon,  8 May 95 11:34:54 PDT
From: gschoepp@onramp.net
Subject: Anecdotal P-Car Stuff


Well, since the most technical info I can provide to the list 
involves the topping off of windshield wiper fluid in a 928, I 
thought the following non-technical anecdotal info would be of 
some value to the list...

This past week, I was finally able to find two days to let the stereo 
installers drop the stock system out of the 928 and put in a good 
one :-).

When I picked the car up, the manager informed me, to my 
surprise, that they had not changed out the front door speakers. 
He indicated that he simply didn't have a better speaker to sell me 
to put in either location. He muttered something about "soft dome 
tweeters" etc, and told me that all they did with the front speakers 
was to assure that they were properly crossed over.

The speakers to the rear of the front seats were replaced with 6.5" 
Canton component speakers; 6.5" woofer and 1" high dome 
tweeter. The 4" speakers in the rear were replaced with Infinity 
RS's. Head unit was replaced with a removeable-faced Sony 
XR-C210, controlling a Sony CDx-51 10 disc changer which is 
mounted in the passenger side rear footwell. All of the speakers 
are being driven from a Mosfet powered, 4 channel  Sony 
XM-2545 amplifier mounted in the stock location (under the 
passenger seat). 

I emphasized fidelity over volume when asking for the system, 
and got it. The system will get loud, no doubt, but is crisp and 
clear. The newly crossed over front speakers sound incredible! I 
had thought that at least one of those front tweeters was trashed; 
indeed it was not, just being muddied up with all the nonessential 
lower frequencies.

The sound is fantastic, the install quality superb, stock finish and 
look totally preserved. Mozart, Clapton, INXS, Stones, etc. have 
all gained new life in my car. Now, if there was room to have sex 
in the car, I could live there.... :-)

I still have the original amp and head unit from the stock system. 
Anyone in need of these? I'm not attached to them and would let 
them go to a fellow enthusiast for shipping plus a beer.

Onward! Now to plan some nice long trips to enjoy the sound 
*and* the car!

Gene Schoepp
gschoepp@onramp.net
'86 928S Marine Blue Metallic

>is, I know you're on a budget!  Seriously, I'd look for a good 28.8 modem in
>_Computer Shopper_.  If you're willing to do without FAX features you should be
>able to pick one up for under $300.  Yeah, it's more than the USR Sportster
>(which is a good modem, BTW), but it's twice as fast, which means your connect
>time (and fees) drops in half also.  You might also want to ask your 
prospective
>service provider what they recommend -- it won't do any good to get a 28.8
>modem if AOL (or whoever) only provides 14.4 service...

assumption?  BTW, I'm a little behind on my computer acronyms, so what is an

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 11:02:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: Wayne Joerding - Economics <joerd@wsunix.wsu.edu>
Subject: MagBra

DH993@aol.com recommends the MagBra and I heartily agree with this 
recommendation, with one caveat.  I have a black magbra on a black car 
and on two occasions it has clouded the paint.  The two occasions were 
during extended driving on a very hot day, 95F+.  At least that's my 
theory.  After removing the magbra i noticed that the paint was cloudy.  
It turned out to not be the wax and required extensive buffing out with 
a very light polishing compound.

Otherwise, I am very pleased with my magbra.  It goes on and off very 
easily so one isn't tempted to just leave it on; and I never get any 
abrasion from flapping as sometimes happens with cloth bras.

Is it the paint on my car?  I dunno, but the car was repainted by 
previous owner and maybe a poor quality paint was used.  Maybe somebody 
else can explain, I went to a couple of body shops and asked them about 
the phenomena and didnt' get any reliable information.  Can I solve the 
problem by painting the MagBra silver or white?  I don't know but plan to 
try before the hot weather arrives this summer.  Too bad, because the 
black color matches fairly well with my car and so the bra is not so 
noticeable.

Note: the MagBra vendor warns owners that using the MagBra after a rain 
can cause clouding of the wax, but I don't think that was my problem 
since corrections required extensive buffing.

Maybe I'm reading more into this than I should, but it sounds to me like
two bad things here:

wrong, but if I'm right, I'd advise doing that at once.  The report, with a 
cost of the necessary repairs, becomes a negotiating tool.

2)  This car hasn't received the kind of care you want the previous owner of
a 911 to exercise.

and if you think you're getting this car at a price that's too good to be
true, it probably is...

     was previously.  It's one of those psycho-acoustic things.  It has 
     driven me to distraction too!

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 12:32:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Rolling fender lips

I replied to AnalogMike privately, and he thought I should share this
item, so here goes:

Rolling the rim of the fender, to prevent the inside edge from
catching on the tire, is recommended if your car has been lowered
and/or if you're using wider than stock tires (as most people with
older cars are now doing).  It's a touchy process, but a good shop can
do it without requiring repaint.  I had it done to my '75 in '88
(paint was original) with no problem.  They sealed it with clearcoat
just to make sure.

IMO, it's worth it to seek out a shop that has experience doing this,
and I'd definitely not try it at home.  A suspension shop with Porsche
experience probably has a regular place where they send their cars.
When Dwight Mitchell was in Sacramento he used Fabrication
Specialties, and that's who did mine.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 12:45:53 -0700
From: peterg@airdata.com (Peter Gregory)
Subject: 912 broken crank?

Just as I was getting my 912 running strong again... on the way home last
Friday night (~45 mph, 3rd gear, light throttle), I heard/felt a loud knock.
Then, the gearshift popped into neutral and the engine stopped.  Hmmm.

I coasted to the side of the road, rolled to a stop, and assessed the matter.
I got out and looked underneath, and noticed a few ounces of oil on the
ground from around the bell housing.  Hmmm.

With the clutch pedal depressed (gee, less resistance than usual), I turned 
the starter... it engaged the flywheel and _sounded_ like it was turning
the flywheel, but it was NOT turning the engine.  Hmmm.

My neighbor tow-roped me home (1/2 mi).  The car rolled free, and I could
still work through the gears (tranny okay?).  Hmmm.

I put a big wrench on the crank pulley and tried to turn it.  Crank frozen
solid.  Hmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.

With the gearshift in 1st and clutch pedal OUT, starter tries to roll the
car along.  Driveline seems okay.

My trusted mechanic replaced the clutch disc a few months ago.

Ideas?

My first thought was that the flywheel is sheared from the crankshaft.  Yuck.

I stopped in to see my mechanic this morning, and he thinks the crankshaft is
broken.  "$5k-6k" to put it back together (I need new P+B's, too).

I called another trusted mechanic (Denny Akers, Seattle).  He thinks my
mechanic didn't tighten the gland nut and that it came out and caused this
all to occur.  (???)  He further said that the crank can probably be machined 
(where the dowel pins go?).  Sounds like my mechanic would be liable for 
this?  Yes, no, and why?

If this is NOT warranty work, I'm looking at having to sell the car as is
and trade up to a late 70s/early 80s 911SC.

Thanks for your help.

Peter Gregory

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 15:48:52 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 951 Wheel Bearings

Had the same problem. I went to sears, and bought this really evil looking
tool. One end is long and pointy and belongs in the hands of someone who
wears a hockey mask on a date. Don't use that end. The other end has a hook
that's maybe 3/8" wide. If you put the hook on the dust cap, you should be
able to work it loose by tapping and working around the circumference.
Note-while this works, I did mar the aluminum hub a touch, nothing serious
though. I don't know if a pro could have done better. 

good luck.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: 8 May 1995 11:48:52 U

Subject: 73.5 911T coupe

                      Subject:                              Time:  11:23 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         73.5 911T coupe                       Date:  5/8/95

I'm very closing to buying a 73.5 911T coupe and I have a few
questions.  Sorry if these have been covered recently.

1) What can be done to quiet the common creaks and groans due to
the hard (silicone?) bushings?  The car is very tight and free of
strange noises except for this.  E.g., are grease fittings possible?

2) Window cranks are a pretty stiff.  Anyone had good success
with this?

3) Rubber recommendations and sizes?  The car has the original
Fuchs and new Riken 185/70-15's (OEM tire).  Front lips have
been rolled.

4) How hot is hot?  (I've forgotten Bruce's rule and I gave my
Performance Handbook to my brother.)  I saw 200 on a 70 degree
day with some hard driving.  No front fender oil cooler.  What's
the advisable upgrade?  Cost?

For those interested, I'm considering paying more than the going
price given it's condition.  The owner has spent $20k over the last
three years, rebuilding the tranny and engine (a 2.7 upgrade with
the right rebuild including proper studs, inserts, chain tensioners,
etc.), replacing the clutch, restoring the interior and all seals and
rubber, and striping and repainting.  No thermal reactor (it passes
smog for a '73 w/o it).  No A/C.  The inspection went well, only 8%
leakdown on all cylinders, very minimal oil seepage, no signs at
all of rust or body damage, and some really nice improvements
like stainless steel SSI heat exchangers, adjustable Weltmeister
suspension, new shocks, front pan, torsion bars, sealed battery,
and straight original Fuchs with new tires.

Is $11k too much?  My instincts tell me I could get there fast with
a lesser car for $8k or so.

Thanks for any input.

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 16:44:40 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : '73 911T sluggish performan

Jim Meyer, M451@aol.com asked :

> '73 T ( Mechanical FI) with 77K miles... seemed sluggish but did not smoke.
> I did notice a leak in the heat exchangers on one
> side.  Could this cause a backpressure problem on the mechanical FI unit. 

Yes, an EXHAUST leak in a heat exchanger can cause a huge power loss
in an early MFI 911. It can also cause a huge loss of life if you breathe the
fumes through your heater. 

Try hard to get it repaired BEFORE you buy it or it could be a huge 
headache. It's easy to brake exhaust studs/bolts, or the lack
of power may not go away due to other problems. A '73 T should not 
be sluggish.

>Any ideas on probable cause?

You noticed the exhaust leak in sound only, or visually? Probably rust.

>Also: what should compression be? 

Probably 120 or so, within 10 pounds cylinder to cylinder would be OK.

Regards, Mike Piera, '72 911S


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 13:48:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@MCC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: 914 bushing removal -done!

Hi all,

	Well, I finally accomplished the threatening task of removing my
trailing arm bushings. I couldn't find all the parts I needed to make my
nifty puller, so I wound up dragging my trailing arms over to a machine
shop and used their press to remove the shafts. EASY! And clean too, the
bushings came right out with the arms. Definately worth the hassle of
loading them into the stand-by car and spending the paltry $30 for the shop
time.

	I havn't installed the new bushings yet, so I can't say it's all
been fun and games so far. 

	On an unrelated note. While I have the engine out to replace my
flywheel seal and epoxy my galley plugs, I've decided to upgrade my oil
pump and relief pistons. For those of you who are thinking of doing this
and have only the haynes manual to guide you, IT LIES! The book says that
the second releif piston is located on the driver side just under the oil
breather. WRONG! It's actually located inbetween the pushrod tubes near the
back of the engine. It's also a huge 12pt socket head bolt. As it turns out
, it's a 3/8" triple square, and a 3/8" extension fits very nicely :).

 -Josh "hoping to have it running by saturday"

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CSP
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Everything expresed here is the opinion of the idiot that wrote it, 
namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...

Porschephiles #1385                         Tue May 9 02:00:23 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 08 May 95 17:19:49 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: How to identify if oil cooler update had been done?

>  Is there an easy way of telling if oil cooler housing has been changed? I ha
ve oil seeping from under the cooler. No oil in water.
> What is recommended approach? Can cooler be changed from under car with out r
emoving exhaust manifold or frame members? Should I just replace cover gasket? 

> 

Hmmm...what year is the subject car? (Assuming it is a 944...)

Anyhow, there is no oil cooler update per se.

If you are wondering whether or not your car is susceptible to oil cooler
seal failures, if the car is a 1987 or newer 944, then you might have the
problem...

If there is no oil in the water, and no water in the oil, then you don't
have the problem.

If you just have an oil leak near the oil cooler housing, then it is
probably some other source (e.g. cam tower, oil pressure gauge sender, head
gasket, etc.)

Clean the area around the oil leaks and see if you can isolate the problem.

Of course, I could be totally wrong...
- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (needs work)
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 17:25:30 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Antiroll bars or stiffer springs?

>Can anyone explain what the trade-offs are between stiffer springs and stiffer
>antiroll bars?  Seems to me one would want the stiffest antiroll bars you can
>fit while having the springs and dampers the softest with which you can
>get away.  
>
>Jeff
>jpuzas@astro.ge.com

You want the car to corner flat enough to maintain optimal tire position
through the turn. I thought I could just get monster sway bars too. I got
the 30/24mm bars from Andial. With the big tires, I still rubbed on the
inside (rear) fenderwell, i.e. too much body roll. Now I'm getting the
turbo cup suspension, which has 80 # rear springs, where the original was
just torsion bars (no springs). I'm afraid the conclusion is that stiff
sway bars are not enough. Bummer, man.

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
Groucho the cat

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 18:23:58 -0400
From: NPIBob@aol.com
Subject: Re: MagBra (Too!)

I also use a mag bra on  a black car and agree that it is ''by
far'' the best possible option.

It goes on and off easily.

It stays on down the front straight (120MPH) at PIR.

And, it has clouded the wax when left on after a rain and then 
sitting in the hot (Oregon? Hot?) sun.  The ''cloudiness'' came
off with an application of Meguires ''Final Inspection'', but I 
would not recommend leaving any bra on with moisture  
present.  

Bob Dubay  /  NPIBob@aol.com
