------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 19:01:29 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Re:Which end locks up

Paul Lyman replied to my quote re spinning cars with rear tires locked.

(ATTENTION CITIZENS: This is not a flame job. Had this been an actual flame
job, you would have been directed to tune in a radio station in your area.
Once again, this is not a flame job. We now return to your regularly
scheduled programming.)

I was pretty amazed by the stuff in Newcomb's book too. But it makes sense.
You have to consider the instantaneous center of rotation, something I
haven't done since I passed the final exam in the freshman statics and
dynamics course. 

The instantanous center of rotation is located way off in the weeds
somewhere, maybe many yards from the car itself. A car going straight down
the road with no rotating force has its instantaneous center at infinity.
Once it sets up a yaw angle (either spinning or cornering normally, you have
a yaw angle) the center moves inward. The instantaneous center in this case
is determined by the intersection of the perpendicular to the car's path and
a line through the front axle. Newcomb says angular momentum is conserved
around this center, not the CG of the car. The couple operates around the CG,
but momentum is conserved around the instantaneious center, As the car comes
to 90 degrees, that center moves in and the car has to spin faster to
conserve momentum. 

Or so he says. 

I tend to believe him because he has written many papers on brake system
design. Anytime anybody uses armloads of differential equations to describe
anything two things happen: 1) I tend to believe them and 2) I leave the room
and look for a simpler solution in a handbook somewhere. His credentials are
(were) D. Sc, F. Inst. P., C. Eng., A.M.I. Mech. E., principal research
officer, Ferodo Ltd.

He says the locus of the center of rotation describes "approximately a cusped
tractrix." (No, I don't know either. I thought tractrix was someting like
Danny Sullivan doing two of these in succession and going on to win Indy.)
Looks like a parabola to me.

My scanner is not scanning or I would scan the nifty diagram in the book and
upload it. I could fax it to you.

BTW I have never accepted money for flame jobs. I do this on my own time. I
hope this becomes an olympic event, so I have to maintain my amateur standing
until that's over, THEN go pro. I will however accept money for flame jobs on
356s. Like starting on the front where there is no engine, etc. That way I
can learn as I go in case I ever want to do this to one of mine.

Pete

summer. They are only 195/65 VR14... but my car was built with 14" wheels and
I like to keep it origonal .  The car handles and brakes well. The ride is a
bit firm but the perofrmance compared to older tires (Michelins circa 1986)
was quite noticable.  Perhaps the 15" versions would work nicely for you as
well.

Date: Mon, 8 May 95 17:18:26 PDT

> HATE the brake light switch off the m.cylinder which I forgot to tighten

> where all the damn air bubbles were originating from......

Not familiar with your set-up, but it seems to me that with an EZBleed
your quart of brake fluid might now be resting in your trunk or
footwell...  I too have some frustrations with the mity-vac (see
post last month), but I've decided that any method that makes every air
bubble in the system swell to 5 times its normal size, thus rendering it
that much more likely to be bled out of the system, is the method that I
want to use.  I realize this viewpoint is not shared by knowledgeable
pros... but hey, that's why I'm an amateur at this!

Date: Mon, 8 May 95 17:47:44 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Tree Sap

> > 
> >     Here is athe problem, I have noticed little drops of sap appearing 
> > all over the cars, The Porsche is usually covered but from just being 
> > parked uncovered for a little while also picked up the sap.
> > Marc
> > 

Hmmmm, the bad news is, that's not tree sap, it's aphid pee!  At least
in my experience with your basic broadleaf deciduous tree in warm
weather.  You'll probably prefer to keep thinking of it as tree sap :-).
The good news is, it is about as water soluble as maple syrup, i.e.
very.  Try lukewarm water before you try any of the more agressive
solvents already suggested.   Used to work like a charm on my '64
Fairlane when I had to park under the ol' tuliptree.

Now if you're parked under a pine or other conifer and you've got big
globs of pine resin coming down, well then, NOW you've got trouble.  An
equal mix of turpentine and elbow grease WILL take it off... but your
paint will look so bad you'll wish it hadn't.  Time for a car cover! 

 -Ed



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 21:42:44 -0400
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: 914 Rear Springs - Revisited

Thanks to all who responded re the direction of installation of 914 rear
springs (I foolishly took mine off without noticing direction).  It looked as
though there could be no UP or DOWN to them, but my paranoia always gets the
best of me.  My VERY lucky experience with spring compressors will not happen
again, since my good friend Jon Lowe reminded me that a spare tire/wheel does
a much safer job, and works just as well.

One item should be brought to the attention of other 914 owners.  I was
changing from Konis to Boge.  The front was complete, and the shocks were a
gift 2 years ago, so I don;t remember where they came from(i.e - couldn't
send them back).  Guess what?  You can't fit Boges without having a BOGE
lower spring retainer ring - the Koni ring is way too big!  OK, some may say
 - Why change to Boge from Koni?  Easy, I'm tired of having my kidneys turned
to puree after a 150 mile trip!  This is a concours car, not an autocrosser.

I checked several sources for the Boge retainers - all said they did not
stock, and would have to get them from Reno.  BEST price was $95 - EACH!
 Well, I got lucky, and found some used ones nearby, refinished them, and
saved myself $175!  Shop around, shop around, sho.....

Anyway, thanks again to all who helped.  Hope I can do the same someday.
Anyone need some beautifully refinished Koni/Bilstein lower spring retainers?

Pat Garvey

Date: Mon, 8 May 95 19:21:30 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Temp Sender Resistance


Bob-

When hot, i.e., 180 degrees, the sender measures
65 ohms to ground with the wire to the gauge connected,
and 140 ohms to ground with the wire disconnected.

I'm curious to know what your readings are.

Date: Mon, 8 May 95 21:51 CDT
From: jimf42@mcs.com
Subject: dying 911s and locking brakes

I had a dying problem on my old SC...turned out to be a loose fuel pump relay. 
 Pushing it in firmly solved the problem. (just an idea)

RE: brake locking.  You definitely want the fronts to lock first!  When I had 
my 914-6, I adjusted the brake bias (garretson adjustable) until the fronts 
locked before the rears.  Never had a problem on the street or track. (Guy 
Allen now has the car. I think it has been fine for him too.)

If the rears lock first, you will spin unless you are on dead level ground and 
perfectly straight and the car is real well balanced.  

Jim Fuerstenberg

"It has been said that motor racing shares in common with sex the
distinction of being one of the most popular, most maligned and least
understood of human activities."  Charles Beaumont and Phillip F.
Nolan (Omnibus of Speed, 1958)

the motor in the past.  Is there a way of repairing the motor?  Or do I have
to pay the big bucks & buy a new motor for the inside blower.  Any info
would be appreciated.

Symptoms:
 sometimes a/c doesn't blow on low.  High pitch sound when I apply the
brakes,  this causes the fan to push foward (sounds like bearing or bushing
in motor).   Motor blows fast & then slows down intermittently.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 8 May 1995 23:14:27 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: PCA Club race at Mid-Ohio

Well, the Club race at Mid-Ohio is history.  Two great days with great
weather, with EXCELLENT racing.   Amazing how the series has matured over the
past three years.

Fastest car in the field was Dave Finch's 944S GT-2 SCCA car.  It currently
holds the lap record at Mid-Ohio for SCCA in GT-2, and he was running at
record pace.  He was in Class C1 with a normally aspirated car, but he was
faster than ANY of the B or A class cars, including John Paul Jrs. old 935!
He turned a 1:33.9 in qualifying and 1:35's in the race. 

For those of you wondering how the 13/13 rule is working out:  It works well.
Most of the weekends incidents were from cars dropping oil either through
leaking oil coolers or blown engines, not from car to car hits.  People who
hit someone else (two that I know of) and were at fault were sent packing for
the weekend.

Several cars, already prepped, were for sale; if you are thinking about
racing, go to a race and see what is available for reasonable prices.

Apparently, PCA had a great idea, as BMW CCA and the Ferrari Club are both
emulating what PCA has done. SCCA missed a LARGE untapped market in this
case.

Got to get busy and get that trailer and tow vehicle so Nancy and I can
race...

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

Subject: Zone 8 Concours - May 14th

OK So-Cal P-Philiers. 

Give your favorite P-Car a bath and show it off! 

PCA/Orange Coast Region, is hosting the Zone 8 Concours d' Elegance, on the
cobble stone streets of Old World Village in Huntington Beach. 

First time? Got Concours gitters? Then put your car on display! You will have
soooo much fun talking to people about your P-Car, you'll wonder why you
haven't done this before.

Now, before some of you guys start flaming me about "Concours people", it is
fun! We have a great group of people, who enjoy going from one show to
another, doing PR work for PCA. 

This year, we will be featuring the Porsche 904. 

So, get out those wash mitts, dust off the dash and bring your car down to:

           $15 per car - Display ( Park 'n Party)

Date: Mon, 08 May 1995 21:26:03 -0600
From: qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: 1959 356A

I was at my local VW AUDI dealer today to pick up some parts and couldn't 
help noticing a very shiny black 356A on the showroom floor.  I asked the 
dealer about the car and was told the following:  (I am not an expert on 
356's so bear with me if the information appears to be incorrect)

The VIN is 106817 
The car is black with red interior.
The car has coachwork by Reutter and is in very good condition.  It was 
originally purchased locally by a local doctor (Edmonton, Alberta) and 
serviced by the dealer with full records until sold to a second owner.  It 
was repainted about 20 years ago and was never driven in winter.  Aside from 
some minor imperfections it does not show it's age.  The chrome work is in 
excellent shape including the hubcaps (not a ding or scratch).  The interior 
is in similar (good) shape.  The engine compartment looks extremely clean. 
The asking price is $32000 CDN ($22400 US).  Mileage is 80000+ miles.  I am 
posting this for the information of the list and have no idea if the price 
asked is reasonable or outrageous.  Those of you who may be interested in 
the car can Email me directly and I will put you in touch with the dealer. 
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S
qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca

Date: 8 May 1995 11:48:52 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: 73.5 911T coupe

                      Subject:                              Time:  11:23 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         73.5 911T coupe                       Date:  5/8/95

I'm very closing to buying a 73.5 911T coupe and I have a few
questions.  Sorry if these have been covered recently.

1) What can be done to quiet the common creaks and groans due to
the hard (silicone?) bushings?  The car is very tight and free of
strange noises except for this.  E.g., are grease fittings possible?

2) Window cranks are a pretty stiff.  Anyone had good success
with this?

3) Rubber recommendations and sizes?  The car has the original
Fuchs and new Riken 185/70-15's (OEM tire).  Front lips have
been rolled.

4) How hot is hot?  (I've forgotten Bruce's rule and I gave my
Performance Handbook to my brother.)  I saw 200 on a 70 degree
day with some hard driving.  No front fender oil cooler.  What's
the advisable upgrade?  Cost?

For those interested, I'm considering paying more than the going
price given it's condition.  The owner has spent $20k over the last
three years, rebuilding the tranny and engine (a 2.7 upgrade with
the right rebuild including proper studs, inserts, chain tensioners,
etc.), replacing the clutch, restoring the interior and all seals and
rubber, and striping and repainting.  No thermal reactor (it passes
smog for a '73 w/o it).  No A/C.  The inspection went well, only 8%
leakdown on all cylinders, very minimal oil seepage, no signs at
all of rust or body damage, and some really nice improvements
like stainless steel SSI heat exchangers, adjustable Weltmeister
suspension, new shocks, front pan, torsion bars, sealed battery,
and straight original Fuchs with new tires.

Is $11k too much?  My instincts tell me I could get there fast with
a lesser car for $8k or so.

Thanks for any input.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
95 993 coupe, guards red
73 1/2 911T coupe (almost)
85 535i, everyday grey

Date: Tue, 09 May 1995 00:10:29 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Cronar Paint

Yepper, Cronar is great stuff.  It is currently available as a DuPont product
called Chromabase.  Slightly reformulated to reduce the VOC's.  Color match
is exceptional and metallic striping is almost non-existant.  I like to use it
over the DuPont Uro primer.  The build is excellent and it sticks so hard that
your hands won't be clean for a week.  If you have any corrosion at all,
consider DuPont's Variprime as a first coat.  

I shoot everything out of my old DeVilbiss JGA-502 with an 80 head except
for the clearcoat.  I use a 30 head for that since the stuff seems to squirt
like water.  I'll often shoot it a little below recommended pressure to help
save paint (this suff is expensive!).  Of course, if I had an HVLP gun it 
wouldn't even be an issue (saving).

Hope this doesn't sound like a DuPont ad.  I don't have any interest with
them except for using products that work (and believe me, I've tried them
all).

I know all the folks in California are green with envy 'cause here in Missouri
we can still shoot our own paint.  (Big ol <G>).


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 10:54:32 +0100
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Porsche Quality--Low


On the subject of the Porsche 993 vs MB SL. This is a real
chalk and cheese debate. It would be better to compare the
SL with other contenders in the same bracket, like Aston, 
Bentley or similar marques because they have a common configuration 
and mission ie huge, heavy, powerful, luxury trucks!

I don't want to get Lucinda, her `cello, two sets of golf clubs, 
and a weeks worth of luggage in my car, and out cool the other 
people on the `bahn to boot, for me the thrill factor in this
scenario is rather low.

No, I want to go and scratch down empty country roads,
spattering bugs, snapping the back out on the bends and locking it 
down with the power, playing tunes on the flat six. I want the 
excellent roaring music of an air-cooled boxer, as it cycles up to
maximum torque, I want to hear the hot tires chattering as I fight
for maximum deceleration, I want the smell of hot metal and oil,
I want the heavy thump, thump as my low 911 surfs over the irreglarities
with all the forgiving and comfortable ride of a skateboard, I want
the quite "tick, tick" sound of the hot exhaust and metal contracting
after power off. 

People who don't want these should purchase an MB, or a Lexus or
and Aston or a similar fine motor car. Low thrill factor, high
component of luxury, fast on the autobahn, high status, and not
for me.

For the airheads out there, I saw the Bf109 "Black Six" flying at
Duxford yesterday. "Black Six" is the only original German manufactured
Bf109 I understand. It is complete with the supercharged Damiler-Benz 
engine and it took twenty years to get it flying again, and I feel very 
lucky to have seen it. Yesterday they had it flying formation with "Black 
Two", a Spanish license built Bf 109 and also the P51 and Spitfire IX from 
The Fighter Collection, magic stuff. The sight and sound were truly 
sensational.



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 07:41:49 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Wheel Bearings


I use a cold chisel for this purpose.  If you use the chisel as a wedge and
tap it down into the crease it will separate the dust cap from the hub.  Then
I use a large screw driver in the gap.  If you turn the screwdriver while
in the gap it works real well.
 
Jeff
Jpuzas@astro.ge.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 08:01:41 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Re: Antiroll bars or stiffer springs?


Jeff wrote:

> Can anyone explain what the trade-offs are between stiffer springs and stiffer
> antiroll bars?  Seems to me one would want the stiffest antiroll bars you can
> fit while having the springs and dampers the softest with which you can
> get away.  
> 
> Jeff
> jpuzas@astro.ge.com
> 

Bruce wrote:

> Hi Jeff,
> 
> The problem with the really stiff sway bar is that if one wheel hits a pot
> hole of a bump it will beat you to death because it will effect the whole
> suspension on that end. Whereas a stiffer spring will probably only effect
> the one wheel and reduce the shock some. 
> 
> Bruce Anderson 
> 

So the trade-off is that the stiffer the anti-roll bar the more you are
moving away from an independent suspension.  From this I would have to say
the proper compromise would be track dependent?  Stiffer springs for bumpy
tracks and stiffer roll bars for smooth tracks?

------------------------------

Date: 9 May 95 05:47:50 -0700
From: Lee Butler <leebu@microsoft.com>
Subject: 911S Targa Side Window

I've been reading this list for a couple of weeks and it sure looks
like there is alot of experience here as well as a ALOT of traffic!

I've got a problem to add to the bandwidth maybe somebody out there
has solved before...

I'm trying to get the right side window on a '76 911S Targa to seal
completely.  I've done all the adjusting and the window angle now
matches the rear side seal very nicely.  The problem is that the
window is sitting about 1/4 inch too far forward in the door.  The
door is already adjusted perfectly, the window must have been replaced
at some time in the past and not set properly.

Has anyone moved the side window position?  I'm hoping the thing isn't
glued in place...  I wanted to ask for tips and tricks before I tackle this.

Thanks for any help!

Lee Butler
76 911S Targa

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 06:54:37 -0600
From: mhatch@alphabusiness.com (Mark Hatch)
Subject: Cheap rubbers, the sequel...

Hi all,

Since I am about to pop for a complete set of rubber for my 73'911 Targa
($$$$), I was very interested in the latest thread on rubbers.

Currently, I am considering buying the rubbers from International
Mercantile of Del Mar, CA. They have been a long advertiser in Pano and
Excellence so I am not too concerned with their request for cash up
front... (no credit cards)

They sell OEM rubbers and reproductions made out of DuPont E.P.D.M.
(Nordel) or DuPont neoprene.

Their price was reasonable (cheap?) being below Tweeks. But I am worried
that in the recent thread, nobody mentioned them as an option?

Is this because of a lack of knowledge or problems in the past????

Any comments appreciated.

Mark

Date: Tue, 09 May 95 09:05:45 US/Eastern

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 09:30:43 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 944 clock adjustment?

If its the digital one with three buttons, hold down the left two until the
display cycles to the set mode. Then (I think) use the center button to
change the settings. The right button returns you to clock mode.

good luck.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 08:35:48 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: 911-Front Strut Replacement Question


>Also, BTW, I am replacing my Boges with Konis (red) - you
>folks would have gotten a kick out of seeing me trying to
>compress the rear ones with one hand and getting the bottom
>bolt started with the other (while laying on my side under
>the car).  My wife had to keep reminding me that there were 
>young children around...
>
>Man, this is fun!!
>
Mike,
   I did the same on my 66. Here's a quick tip. After you are ready to turn
the nut with the channel locks (I used a pipe wrench!) place the top of the
strut insert back into the top of the fender and secure it with the old nut.
This assumes that you have removed the dust cover. I have found this to be 
the best way to secure the strut assembly and put torque on the nut. BTW if
you go with Bilsteins most I have done come with the proper wrench. I am
satisfied with my Konis.


Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 9 May 95 09:44 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: 911-Front Strut Replacement Question

From: MLBDayton@aol.com
    I'm in the middle of replacing the 19-year old Boges on
    the front of my 911.  Fellow pfile John Goodman suggested
    I get a big set of Channel-Locks to get the nut that holds
    the insert into the housing loose.  Of course I decided to
    try it anyway (without the Channel-Locks).  Before I go
    buy them, does anyone have a neat trick for getting this
    nut loose?  BTW, I'm doing this with the strut in the car,
    so please, no advice that begins "put the strut in your 
    vise...".  :>)

The last time I replaced strut inserts I just used a big pipe wrench (I had
one, and didn't have a pair of Channel-locks big enough).  One thing to try
is wrapping a piece of inner tube or an old rubber glove or something around
the nut.  Mine were pretty badly crusted, so I really had a time getting them
off, and I really scratched them both up.  A rubber glove or something in there
can save your finish and give you a better grip.

Good luck!
- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 10:04:51 -0400 (EDT)
From: Rick Shimkets <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: Drive carefully the Porsche Japan in

Clearly this group has if nothing else the distinction of some cleverly
humorous members whose commentaries I've enjoyed reading.  I thought
perhaps I would provide a little light passage myself, excerpted from an
official Japanese guide for English-speaking drivers from 1936.  No racial
or cultural insult is intended here.  And those of you who like to
accelerate around the corners, pay extra close attention to number 5! 

1.  At the rise of the hand of the policeman, stop rapidly.  Do not pass 
him or otherwise disrespect him.
2.  If a pedestrian obstacle your path, tootle horn melodiously.  If he 
continue to obstacle, tootle horn vigorously and utter vocal woraning 
such as "Hi, Hi."
3.  If wandering horse by roadside obstacle you path, beware that he not 
take fright as you pass him.  Go soothingly by, or stop by roadside till 
he pass away.
4.  If road mope obstacle your path, refrain from pass on hill or round 
curve.  Follow patiently till road arrive at straight level stretch.  
Then tootle horn melodiously and step on, passing at left and waving hand 
courteously to honorable road mope in passing. 
5.  Beware of greasy corner where lurk skid demon.  Cease step on, 
approach slowly, round cautiously, resume step on gradually.
			Happy driving!  -Rick

Date: Tue,  9 May 95 09:07:01 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Painting in the garage (was Cronar paint)

 re; Cronar and painting in the garage

>Yepper, Cronar is great stuff.  It is currently available as a DuPont product
>called Chromabase.  Slightly reformulated to reduce the VOC's....
> ....... If you have any corrosion at all, consider DuPont's Variprime as a
>  first coat.

    My own preference is PPG's DP-90 epoxy primer. Variprime will stick to
 anything but it won't hold back moisture. DP-90 is excellent as both a
 base primer and a sealer. Maybe the best stuff on the market.

>I know all the folks in California are green with envy 'cause here in  
> Missouri we can still shoot our own paint.  (Big ol <G>).

>Mark W Kuefel

    Is this true (about California ?) Is it impractical/illegal for anyone to
 spray in their garage ? I didn't realize that the VOCs are such a big issue,
 til I tried to buy Deltron yesterday and was told its been discontinued 
 because of this.  The red Concept urethane I got instead will cost $80 a  
 quart once catalyzed ! Even more expensive than Glasurit !

    Not to say that I -should- have a right to fog up the neighborhood with
 isocyanates...but if Water-based paints are the future (which dry slowly and
 require a class 100 clean room...) then it looks like the days of painting
 at home are certainly numbered...

    -Lee A.  3qts code FM9 on a '90 chrysler this weekend....

------------------------------

Date:  9 May 95  8:06:15 EDT
From: Mark Forrester <Mark_Forrester.LOTUS@crd.lotus.com>
Subject: 911SC's and CB's and Windshield Wipers

Folks,

I remember way back that a few individuals had the same problem that I had.  
You owned a 911SC, had a CB radio that was powered through the cigarette 
lighter, and your windshield wipers went on every time you keyed the mic.  
Finally tired of those annoying wipers and REAL tired of getting little 
scratches in the glass (from dry wiper action) I decided to solve this.

First, you may be aware that in a 911SC the cigarette lighter is on the same 
fuse circuit as the windshield wipers.  So my first guess was that this was 
somehow related to the problem.  So, I rewired the CB through the radio power 
circuit and voila!  No more wipers.  Not sure of the actual reason why the 
wiper relay was getting tripped.  Actually don't really care anymore.

If you're still interested in having a removable radio and don't want to 
"hardwire" your to the car do what I did.  Pick up a set of "banana" connectors 
at your local electrical supply.  Solder a pair (I chose the male ones for the 
CB side) to the CB wires and solder the receiving pair to the other half of the 
connection.  This gives you a quick disconnect / reconnect.

Regards,
Mark
mrf@lotus.com

------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 10:49:59 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Re: Cronar paint

Mark Kuefel writes:

>I know all the folks in California are green with envy 'cause here in
>Missouri
>we can still shoot our own paint.  (Big ol <G>).
>


We can shoot our own here in California too. All the usual brands are
available -- PPG, DuPont, Sikkens, Glasso, you name it. There are about half
a dozen paint suppliers who specialize in restorers and the hot rod industry
within a half hour of my house. 

I can do anythinng I want in my driveway or garage, and until now there
hasn't been any problem getting the stuff.

What you can't do (easily) is open up a commercial repaint facility. Then the
Air Nazis come in and make you do all sorts of stupid shop tricks. I think
there would be a great market possibility for opening a shop in San Diego
that just takes in laundry, as it were, loads it on a flatbed and trucks it
across the border to Tijuana where you can do anything you want to it. (Oh,
oh, here come the AirNetNazis, telling me that if it's bad for the air in
California, it is just as bad in Tijuana and what if the winds are from the
south... go stick it.)

I know of too many firms that have just given up on California's
anti-industry attitude and gone away. Just last week I was shopping for quotes
 for some aluminum forging. One shop in squeaky-clean Irvine said they don't
do Al anymore because the process develops lots of smoke, and the city would
want them to install treatment. So they just do titanium which doesn't
produce smoke. Another firm I know of turned out automatic screw machine
products. The machines (basically automatic lathes) inevitably had some small
oil leaks (not spills, just the sort of thing you find under your 911). The
Dirt Nazis wanted the shop to dig up all of the floor of the plant and haul
it off to a dump. The shop said "stick it" (it was leased space) and
relocated to Colorado.

Pete

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 07:55:14 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Re: 73.5 911T coupe

> 2) Window cranks are a pretty stiff.  Anyone had good success
> with this?

Depends on what you mean.  My drivers side window winder used to sort
of bind halfway up.  I think they tend to get bent over time,
especially if you crank it hard against the stop.  I got in, took the
hardware out, and bent it back straight, and it's been OK since.  You 
can also lube it some while you're there...

- --Walt Thode

Date:         Tue, 9 May 1995 11:30:42 EDT
From: AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd.edu
Subject:      Finally bought a porsche

Hi all,

Well a couple of months ago I was about to buy a 1974 porsche 
911 with a sportomatic transmission or a 1971 911T .  Thanks to this 
list I reevaluated my choices and yesterday bought a 1981 911SC 
Targa with 123,000 miles on it for $7,600.  I had the car, as advised on 
this list, checked out by a respected Porsche mechanic for -yep as the 
you all suggested $100.  The mechanic -Ralph of Ralph's in 
Reisterstown MD, spent two hours going over the car.  Leak down test, 
compression test, rust inspection etc passed within better than usual 
limits.

I was debating between a 928S and a 911, but after driving both cars 
and listening to advice from this list I decided I really wanted the 911.

Anyway the car I purchased does have a few problems:

* The paint is really stone chipped on the hood and front fenders and is 
scratched and has two minor dents

* The leather seats and dash are really scuffed up, and the drivers side 
seat is ripping at one corner and on the left edge.  The leather steering 
wheel is rather scuffed.

* The radio barely works.

* The oil return tubes are leaking and it's going to cost $600 to replace 
them.  Is this a job to be done at home?

* The oil pressure swith is leakin oil 

* There is some sort of leak from the pipes (rer end of car) going to the 
oil cooler

* The car does not leave any oil on the ground but it is visible all 
around the bottom of the engine. 

* Needs smile

* Speedo only goes to 85mph -yuk!

The owner didn't even bother to clean the car so it looks really scruffy 
especially with the dark blue interior and metallic pacific blue exterior.  
Is this color paint available at porsche dealer for touch up?

All records are there -The clutch has been replaced twice.  Last at 
97,000mi with new throwout bearings.  The blower box blew at 28,000 
and a new one with a popper valve was installed.  There has been 
some body work on the right door and left rear fender all done by 
porsche dealers.  Both heat exchangers have been replaced.  


The chain tensioner has not been updated and the mechanic didn't 
think I should change it.  Should I?


Did I get a good deal?  The owner was asking $9700 initially when he 
first advertised and then $8700.




**********************************************************************
Asad Husain, Director Technical Services     Phone: (410)706-3971
School of Medicine                           Fax  : (410)706-2043
University of Maryland at Baltimore
655 W. Baltimore Street 
Baltimore, MD 21201

I used PPG DP-90 last fall when reconditioning my chassis.  I agree that it

sealant properties, I was told you could slap a coat on a car and leave it
in the rain without worry.  Really easy to work with.

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 10:39:28 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: Re: 911-Front Strut Replacement Q's


Dave writes...

>I'm in the middle of replacing the 19-year old Boges on
>the front of my 911.  Fellow pfile John Goodman suggested
>I get a big set of Channel-Locks to get the nut that holds
>the insert into the housing loose.  Of course I decided to
>try it anyway (without the Channel-Locks).  Before I go
>buy them, does anyone have a neat trick for getting this
>nut loose?  BTW, I'm doing this with the strut in the car,
>so please, no advice that begins "put the strut in your 
>vise...".  :>)

I asked the same question a month or so ago, no problem.  I
used a large pipewrench and it worked just fine.  Just use
some penetrant (Liquid Wrench or ??) to make sure they'll
come loose and "Just Do It."  It helps to have a friend
holding the bottom of the housing steady - but, otherwise the
steering stuff will eventually stop the rotating.

>Also, BTW, I am replacing my Boges with Konis (red) - you
>folks would have gotten a kick out of seeing me trying to
>compress the rear ones with one hand and getting the bottom
>bolt started with the other (while laying on my side under
>the car).  My wife had to keep reminding me that there were 
>young children around...
>
>Man, this is fun!!

I used my floor jack to compress the new shocks in the rear whilst
I got the bolt/nut started - a little easier.  My claim to fame
came when I applied 120 ft lbs to a brake caliper to get a piston
out and now have a significant hole in the garage's drywall - those suckers
can really fly!  Now I clamp 'em to a piece of 2x4 so they dont
go very far.

Ron  rondl@uscbu.att.com

Date: 9 May 1995 08:49:25 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: Inspection shops in the Bay

                      Subject:                              Time:  8:27 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Inspection shops in the Bay Area      Date:  5/9/95


Trond,
I've been to most of the better garages out here, including all the
dealers, Garretson's (when it was around), Carrera Tech, T&D
Performance, and Ken's SportTech, all in Campbell.  I think any of
the above will do a decent job, including Tom Heyer's shop (Heyer
Performance?) in Mtn View (whom Stan likes).  But when I am the
one paying for the inspection (instead of the other way around)
there's only one shop I trust: RMG Enterprises.  This is a one man
operation, run by Bob Grigsby.  Bob has been working on air-cooled
Porsches for over twenty years and is clearly one of the best in
California.  Every shop I've been to knows him, many consult with
him regularly, and everyone has great things to say about him.  He
spent several years with dealers and Garretson's, but has been on
his own for 10 years or so.  I've taken all my cars to him for the
last seven years and I've never been disappointed.  The only
negative I can imagine is that he's a bit more expensive than most
places.  But then Bob does *all* the work himself.  No grunts ever
touch your car.

Bob can be reached at (408)-738-2060.  He's off El Camino Real
and Mary in Sunnyvale.  He'll charge about $100 for a thorough
checkout, including the leakdown.

Incidentally, Bob's wife, Linda Grigsby (aka, Linda Piccone) is
some sort of Porsche parts celebrity.  She works at Carlsens, a
Porsche dealer in Palo Alto, and is well known as one of the best
parts experts around.

And if you or anyone else is looking for a great 63 Super 90 ask
him about the one he just finished restoring.  Looks brand new
everywhere.  Upgraded to 4 wheel discs, 12 v., and intermittent
wipers (so no concours but a great street car).  Cream lacquer.
3000 hours.  Awesome car.  $22k.

Regards,
Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
95 993 coupe, guards red
73 1/2 911T coupe (almost)
85 535i, everyday grey

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 09:39:21 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 questions


Lance,

> 2) Window cranks are a pretty stiff.  Anyone had good success
> with this?

I had a pin shear in mine, had to take the window and regulator out
to replace it. You might be able to free things up by spraying the
window felt tracks with silicone spray. If that doesn't work, remove
the door panels and lube the horizontal metal track with WD-40
or something similar. There is a nylon slipper foot that rides in
it and mine was clogged with old hardened grease.

11K sounds a bit steep considering what I've seen in the paper,
but you are right, you would easily spend that much trying to
get a lesser car into shape.

 -Mitch

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 09:49:03 -0700

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Drive carefully the Porsche Japan in
Author:  Rick Shimkets <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu> at SMTP
Date:    5/9/95 10:04 AM


Clearly this group has if nothing else the distinction of some cleverly 
humorous members whose commentaries I've enjoyed reading.  I thought 
perhaps I would provide a little light passage myself, excerpted from an 
official Japanese guide for English-speaking drivers from 1936.  No racial 
or cultural insult is intended here.  And those of you who like to 
accelerate around the corners, pay extra close attention to number 5! 
     
1.  At the rise of the hand of the policeman, stop rapidly.  Do not pass 
him or otherwise disrespect him.
2.  If a pedestrian obstacle your path, tootle horn melodiously.  If he 
continue to obstacle, tootle horn vigorously and utter vocal woraning 
such as "Hi, Hi."
3.  If wandering horse by roadside obstacle you path, beware that he not 
take fright as you pass him.  Go soothingly by, or stop by roadside till 
he pass away.
4.  If road mope obstacle your path, refrain from pass on hill or round 
curve.  Follow patiently till road arrive at straight level stretch.  
Then tootle horn melodiously and step on, passing at left and waving hand 
courteously to honorable road mope in passing. 
5.  Beware of greasy corner where lurk skid demon.  Cease step on, 
approach slowly, round cautiously, resume step on gradually. 
			Happy driving!  -Rick

Date: Tue, 09 May 95 13:25:28 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 hatch adjustment

> Dear P-philes;
> 
> What is the proper procedure to 
> adjust the pins that latch down 
> the rear hatch?
> 
> Pat

Assuming you have allowed the pin and lock nut to soak in penetrating oil,
without ruining the rubber around it...

1) Holding the pin with either a screwdriver (if you have a slot) or a
vise-grips (like the one that Ken Schrader used as a shift knob at Sears
Point last Sunday), loosen the lock nut.

2) Adjust the pin length by turning it.

3) Tighten the locknut somewhat.

4) Check the adjustment.

5) Repeat steps 2,3, and 4 until the hatch closes easily and has no looseness
when closed.

6) Tighten the locknut.


- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (needs work)
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: 9 May 95 12:31:00 -0500
From: bill.brown@pscmail.ps.net
Subject: Sled Diagnostics

     
Posting for a friend, who has an '83 911SC.
     
  My sled has recently developed a rather irritating tendency to stall out 
at idle.  Here are the symptoms.  Cold start is fine, idle is fine when 
engine is cold.  As soon as engine reaches a certain temp (something less 
than normal operating temp, oil temp gauge just starting to rise) the idle 
begins to fluctuate wildly between 0 and 2000 rpm.  Eventually it will fail 
to "pull out" of one of its rpm-valleys and stall.  Runs fine at speed, but 
even when up to normal operating temp, the idle problem persists.

bill.brown@ps.net

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 13:35:48 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@use.usit.net>
Subject: Re: 944 hatch adjustment

This is fresh in my mind as I just did it to get rid of some
squeeks that came with the warmer weather. There are actually
two parts to this: (1) the latches and (2) the lock and remote
release mechanism.

First off, clean and lube the latches. There are plastic "keepers"
on the rods running from the lock mechanism to the latches. Do not
lubricate these or they will bind and you'll have a fun time
taking the whole thing out and cleaning it off. If the car hasn't
been in an accident there should be no reason to remove / adjust
either the female or male components (we haven't gotten PC yet here
in TN). If the backlight latches but is loose, you'll want to loosen
the lock nut on the male component and turn the latch post in,
maybe a full turn at a time. Try closing the backlight. It should
latch with firm steady pressure but should not require a "slam"
like the doors on Dad's LTD. Iterate this process until one or
both of the latches fails to catch. When this happens loosen the
failing latch post about 1/4 to 1/2 turn. The latch should then
catch. While you're looking at the latches make sure that the
drain tubes are clear.

Lubricate the bellcrank assembly behind the lock. Again, keep the
lubricant off of the plastic component there. Lubricate the cable
assembly from the remote release motor.

When you're done the latch should release easily with either the key
or the remote release and should shut easily and consistently and
should not rattle.

Note that if the latches are not lubricated once in a while the effort
on the key to unlock the latches will increase to the point where the
bellcrank mechanism will become very loose. In this case you'll have
to disassemble that and tighten it up. But that is a differnt thing.

Good Luck!

Doug Donsbach - dld@symtec.com - Knoxville, TN
'88 951 - '88 735i

turbo bullsh*t. Had left the road backwards at 140 mph on a "private" road.

Date: Tue, 9 May 95 11:11:27 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 951 M474 Suspension kits


To 951/944 owners:

I was visiting Kahlers in Dublin, California this morning. Denny Kahler
has a package deal on the M474 Koni shocks, with springs, spring mounts 
and shock boots.

Here's what you get for $399.00:

	2 Koni Adjustable gas front struts (not inserts)
	2 Koni Adjustable gas rear shocks
	2 Eibach 250 lb coil springs (fit the new struts)
	2 Upper spring mounts
	2 Front shock boots.

This will fit all 85.5 and later 944, 924S, 951 and 968 with no 
modifications. 

If you have an earlier 924, 924 turbo (four wheel disc brake only) or 
944, the front struts can be modified. Rear shocks for the steel rear 
trailing arms require the rubber center from your present shock to be 
pressed in.

Call Denny Kahler at (510) 829-2050 for info and details.

Jim Pasha

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 15:01:34 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: :What is the original color?

The color code should be located on the door jamb along with several other
numbers.  Lacking that, you will have to write PCNA with a check for $20 and
request the so-called "cardex" production information.  The response to your
request can take up to 2 months. So, if you are in a hurry, seach out the
color code or other clues on the chassis.

 -Allen Henderson

------------------------------

Date: 09 May 95 17:06:32 EDT
From: ED SCRIPPS <73200.2362@compuserve.com>
Subject: Battery woes

Hi group,

I'm having a battery problem and looking for some advise. 

I jumped in the C2 this morning and...nothing, well enough for the idiot lights
but not much more just a couple of clicks from the starter solenoid.

I couldn't find anything left on so I jump started the car and drove for about a
1/2 hour. Stopped for 5 minutes then started the car again. Enough to get it
started but sounds very weak. Stopped again for 20 minutes. That's it, not
enough juice to start up again.

When I got home I put my VOA meter in line to test the amp draw. I get a reading
of -.09. I then started pulling fuses to isolate the culprit. No luck, still a
steady -.09 after pulling all fuses and relays in the fuse box. (I did remove
the interior light fuse so the open boot light wouldn't be a factor.)

Is the -.09 normal? It sounds excessive.

Is there anyway to tell if I just plain have a bad battery? Or is it time for a
visit to Sears?

Thanks,
 -Ed-

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 16:27:30 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: Paint Color


     Color codes on Bob's car....
  
>I tried to buy or order Johnson's Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
>from my local (huge) Barnes and Noble, and was told it was out of
>print.  I'm trying to learn what the original color of my new
>project was.  It's a '72 911T Coupe, and the color plate on the
>driver's forward doorjamb says 325-9H or 325-94.  I can't see
>the last letter/digit very well.  The car is dark blue now.

Color code 325 is Albert Blue and is marked as a color only available
for the US market. From what I can tell 9 is the coach builder and the
last number is the paint supplier. There are no codes available for
numeric paint suppliers but on the earlier cars H=Herbol, G=Glasurit
and L=Lechler. Hope that helps.
Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)

from Automotion, Performance Products and BHMA. I had it sent UPS Blue ($20)
and it was here in 4 days (takes 2 days to make and 2 days to ship).

Autoxtra 800-221-9872

Randy Kirby

> >Can I get only 914 info in the mail?

to which our beloved and esteemed leader succinctly replied,

> NO! This is covered pretty hard in the FAQ.
> 
> Drink from the fire hose, or go thirsty and be damned!

before considering either option, one of us, Chuck Campbell to be
exact, suggested (7 Apr 95) setting up mail filter to select those 
you wish to keep and read later, keep and read now or delete.  It 
revolves around the type of system you are on and the mailer it uses 
how successful you can be at this. It may pay to research your system 
to see if you wish to go this route.

Herb Myers

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 17:53:11 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 Thermostat Flaps

        I got to thinking about the "accordion" thermostat and the
flaps in the fan shroud/engine tin that it controls.  How do they
work?
        The flaps are controlled by a rod that is twisted against
the pressure of a spring.  When you let the spring relax, the flap
over the oil cooler closes, and the flap above the LHS cylinder bank
opens up.  When you twist the rod against the spring tension, the
flap over the oil cooler opens and the other flap closes off the fan
shroud from the LHS cylinder bank.
        (Am I backwards here?)
        The thermostat is a given length when cold.  When warm, it
expands.  (Am I backwards here, too?)  It is held at one end, and
has a wire attached to the free end.  The wire goes under a pulley,
and comes up through a hole in the engine tin to connect to the rod
near the spring.  If the wire pulls, the rod twists against the
spring tension.  If the wire relaxes, it lets the spring relax.
        Therefore, a warm thermostat is longer, so it relaxes the
pull on the wire, which relaxes the spring pressure which closes off
the oil cooler!?!?  This seems backwards!
        Please help me to understand--I'll have to put this all back
together in the (not-so distant?) future!  And no, I don't want to
leave it disconnected.  I believe that it serves a purpose, even in
California where it dosen't get that cold.
        TIA!

- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 18:13:57 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 944 Supercharger?????

Hoo boy, here we go again...

>      Is it POSSIBLE to add a supercharger to an otherwise stock 944 8 valve
> engine?  

Yes.

> Could it be done without making other major mods?  

Yes. 

But what you *DIDN'T* ask is "would it work very well for very long?"

No. 

Most of that is covered below.

> If possible, what
> kind of gains could be expected?  Would software etc have to be recalibrated,
> or would the engine's management system automatically adjust to the increased
> flow of air?  

Turbocharging and supercharging are both ways to beat the volumetric
efficiency problems of the Otto Cycle engine in other than it's peak
band of operating efficiency. You want the static pressure in the cylinder
at BDC on the intake stroke to be low enough that the compression effect
will leave you below 180 psi at full compression unless this is a full
race engine that you are seeking to blow up in search of more power.
That means that you can diddle two items: 1) static compression ratio,
(2) base boost pressure. Do the math here, and you see that if you're
looking at say a 930 where the static compression is 7:1, that you can
run up to a 1.75-1.8 bar boost OK. If on the other hand you're running
say a 9.5:1 engine (just guessing, all my waterpumper stuff is in storage
since I never really use it) then you only get a 1.3 bar boost, and 
since we're already at 1 bar static, that's a .3 bar boost or about
4 psi on a 1.5 liter steady state push. You'd do better hooking a big
hose and having your passenger blow hard when you punch the gas.

You also have to *COMPLETELY* re-do the engine management software. On a
dyno. With a four-gas analyser.You will also almost certainly need larger 
injectors, and possibly a higher capacity fuel system. All that can be 
calculated from the additional air flow, and is reasonably well understood.

And of course if you want to do this at HIGHER RPM, there are more things
you gotta consider...

There is no cheap answer in the search for power, just cheap ways
to blow your engine up.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 09 May 95 19:30:32 EDT
From: "Eric S. Shea" <73633.1772@compuserve.com>
Subject: Early 911 Drivers Side Door Pull

Hi Gang:

I spoke with Howard Adams today regarding our RHD door pulls and a possible part
number.  Here's the answer from PCNA:

They do not exist.

Howard has done some research on these as late as 1990.  The total (T, E and S)
number of RHD 911's (early models) is under 1000.  All of the parts have been
salvaged... period.  The only alternative would be to fly to the UK, search out
a pre 73 owner, slam into him at high velocity with your rental car and,
profusely apologizing, offer to purchase his door pull from his now totalled RHD
911... just a thought.  (The previous thought is in no way sanctioned by PCNA,
nor was it part of their illustrious advice)

There is light at the end of the tunnel:

There is someone rumored to be working on a aftermarket piece.  I spoke with him
today but... but he's not quite ready so he didn't want me giving out his name.
(Don't you hate this secret stuff??)  I told him that I'd take a head count and
get back with him.  He has the last original OEM NOS piece from Porsche.  They
(Porsche) do not have any more of these pieces and they WILL NOT sell them in
the US because it would be illegal.  These parts are not originally manufactured
for American cars.  They do bolt right in however.  The door is machined to
accept this part.

So... here's the head count part.  Let me know if you're interested in a real
drivers door pull for a 68-73 911.

TTYL (Talk to you later)*

Eric

*You wouldn't believe how many people ask...

Date: Tue, 09 May 95 17:59:00 PDT
From: Thomas Pindelski <ThomasP@nacm.com>
Subject: Eezibleed


In response to Ronald Jay de Lange's request for the # of the Eezibleed 
importer - I believe it's an English product - contact Auto Experts Products 
Co at 800-795-6958,fax 407-483-7825.

I bought mine in 4/94 for $33, incl. P&P.

I have used it successfully on my 1983 Mercedes 300SD, my mother's 1983 
Volvo 245DL wagon and my 1990 Porsche 928S 4 - the cap fits all three 
systems interchangeably.  After using the horrible MityVac  - how many times 
have I had to rush to clean brake fluid off of bodywork? - there is no 
alternative.  I use a spare tire as a source of air pressure, albeit 
deflated to 20psi so as not to blow anything, as per the instructions.

The wonder of it is that you do not need a helper, and even the dual cicuit 
brakes on the 928 - eight bleed screws - can be properly bled in a few 
minutes.  Also, the container holds a large quantity of fluid, so you're not 
about to pump air in if you fill it up before a session.

I use NAPA heavy duty DOT4 brake fluid which references 'QSC Corporation' as 
the manufacturer - presumably Quaker State. Results over the last two years 
have been just fine.  Is there any benefit to the exotic fluids now being 
touted? (DOT4, that is; I am aware of the horror potential of the 
non-hygroscopic, silicone-based DOT5)

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 22:50:11 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 Supercharger?????

Hello FiewVinder (could you add your real name to the post?)

Of course it could be possible to add a supercharger to an 8v 944. I have
heard of 305ci small block Chevy powered 944s! Anything is possible, but why
one would do such a thing is beyond me. Why not just buy a 944 Turbo? This
way you have a car that is designed to handle the additional power. 

Since the supercharger just forces more fuel-air mixture into the cylinder,
the engine management computer should be able to adjust enough to make the
car run ok. I have doubts about how long the engine would stay together. The
944 Turbo has a much lower compression ratio then the non turbo. A
supercharger could easily blow the head. I think that at low enough boost
levels to allow the engine to not blow up would probably give less than 50hp
gain. The Turbo has 217hp vs 147 from the non-turbo for a HP gain of 70HP,
and this was optimized by Porsche. Any aftermarket supercharger would yield
less than this.

Or I could be completely wrong on everything!

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 23:23:12 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Re: Welding

Jerry Brady asked about somebody taking a day to show him how to weld. 

You can't learn it in a day. You can do some things after a day of futzing
around with a torch and gas bottles, but if you attack your car with that
level of knowledge you'll cause more damage than you can repair. Not to scare
you about welding, but it takes a little while to learn, to pick up some
tricks, to learn how to think about what the heat is doing, and most of all
it takes practice. Good welders do this every day. If you knock off for a few
weeks you have to get back in practice. I learned how to do my own welding.
It takes me so long to do the quality of work I want on my own cars that I
know I could never make a living at it. I just got done welding a tail clip
to a freind's '58 coupe and it is better than all but the most professional
top-dollar resto jobs I've seen. I'm now touching up the lead on one side to
get the engine lid gap absolutely perfect.

Perhaps a better way for you to learn, better than asking somebody to show
you more tricks than you can absorb in one day, is to take a course at the
local community college, if such are offered. That's what I did. Eventually I
got so frustrated with half-wrecked school equipment that I bought my own
tanks, a Henrob torch, and a Lincoln SP-100 MIG and now I do it all at home.

If you have a torch and a set of tanks, get some CLEAN scrap sheet metal, 22
gauge, cut it into little squares about 3 inches on a side, and after you can
draw a bead without welding rod, and make lap welds, practice making butt weld
s. You will probably blow a lot of holes in the material at first. Now think
of blowing these into the car you want to fix. Figure on at least a week of
this practice, an hour or two a day, before you can trust yourself on a car. 

If you have a MIG welder, it's a bit easier but you still need to be careful
not to blow holes. MIG has many advantages, including less heat buildup, but
it can't do everything and the best setup is still to have both MIG and
oxy-acetylene.

You need to learn tricks like cutting out rotted sections, making a GOOD
patch (fits tightly, not with big gaps; a gap as wide as the metal is thick
is about the most you want), clamping patches, using special clamping methods
to position the patches, using products and techniques to minimize heat
buildup (anything from wet rags to "heat fence" clay around the area, as
needed). The keys to good patches are precise fitting patches, precise
location and unhurried, carefully considered welding. 

Pete

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 23:23:33 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Re: Paint color

Bob Spindel writes

Naah, isn't neither. Call Brett Johnson's ordertaker at 1-800-553-5319. The
first volume covers all 911/912 through 1973, the second volume has just come
out and covers 74-present. Both are $19.95 plus $3 per item shipping. 

If enough people on the list want either of these, the 400-page 356
Restoration Handbook, the 356 Restorer's Guide, the VW Beetle Restorer's
Guide, the 914 Restorer's Guide, the Conradt hardcover 356 history or the
upcoming 400 page hardbound 911 history, let me know and I'll get a big order
together and order another box of books from Johnson. I can cut a slightly
lower price on each, shipping is same or lower. I don't have any more Johnson
books in stock at the moment (frankly glad I don't have any more to get rid
of).


Craig_Zaplatynsky writes

>I had a similar situation in the Chicago area trying to get his book
>(Johnson's 
>Restorer's Guide to Authenticity).  Barnes and Noble does not >and cannot
order 
>that book due to distributor contracts.  Try Boarders or any other >large
book 
>store.  You can also get it mail order throught the variety of >Porsche parts
 
>houses.

Yup, basic problem. Just about all the bookstores and libraries in the
country buy from two big distributors, Baker & Taylor and Ingram. They don't
carry any of Johnson's books. They are most definitely still in print. For
automotive books, a lot of bookstores use Motorbooks in Wisconsin as their
single-source distributor as B&T and Ingram don't carry a comprehensive line
of car books. 

I have seen Johnson books at Borders. Rizzoli has been known to carry the
Conradt 356 book, depending on the store and the store's buyer. Rizzoli buys
from Motorbooks.

Pete

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 23:23:46 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Re: Painting in California, Variprime, and NaziAirSheep

Lee Atkinson writes  re; Cronar and painting in the garage

>    My own preference is PPG's DP-90 epoxy primer. Variprime will
>stick to
> anything but it won't hold back moisture. DP-90 is excellent as both
>a
> base primer and a sealer. Maybe the best stuff on the market.

Absolutely. Variprime is not supposed to be used without a top coat to hold
water away.
Otherwise, little brown spots appear right through the primer. I think Varipri
me is or at
least was a high-zinc primer, they may have reformulated it.

Another good primer is zinc chromate, available in two colors from Aircraft
Spruce
and Specialty in Fullerton, CA (or try 800 directory). Wear really good
breathing gear.

>    Is this true (about California ?) Is it impractical/illegal for
>anyone to
> spray in their garage ? I didn't realize that the VOCs are such a
>big issue,
> til I tried to buy Deltron yesterday

I don't know about Deltron. But as I said in another message, I can do
anything I want
in my driveway. Whether it's legal or not (and as far as I know it is legal)
it is virtually
impossible for the Air Nazis (flying Nazi sheep? baaaaa... THUMP!) to do
anything in the way
of enforcement. It's not like they cruise residential neighborhoods looking
for illegal
barbecues (don't ask; no, it's not illegal) and hobby painters.

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 21:29:18 -0700
From: paulm@kestrel.engr.sgi.com (Paul Mielke)
Subject: Re: What is the original color?

Hi, April.

If you send your VIN and $20 to PCNA, they'll send you a
Certificate of Authenticity for your car that will include
the original color code and the list of options on it at
time of purchase.  The name and address of the person to
send the request to is in the Porschephiles FAQ.  If you
don't have access to that and are interested, let me know
and I'll dig it out for you.

The downside is that you can't necessarily trust the info they give
you.  They copy it by hand from a 3x5 card or something
of the sort.  I got a Certificate for my car and the color
code is only one of several things that don't match the
car.  And I'm pretty sure that they are wrong, versus the
car having been repainted.  I have a container
of touchup paint from the factory that has the same color code
as the 'Kunstharzlack' badge and it matches the color of the car.

FWIW ...

Cheers,



Paul Mielke (paulm@sgi.com)
Silicon Graphics, Inc.

Hi,

Last week I bought a set of sun visors for my '73 targa. They are from a '92
911 and although they do not match the shape of the originals, they are
really nice to have. I can't believe I drove 9 months without them. Anyway, I

would pass on some info to the list. I got the set for $100 for the set when
they cost $270 from the dealer.  Seems like a good deal to me. So if you need
parts for you C2 you should give them a call, there selection might not be
great but their prices seem reasonable.  #305 327-8115

Standard disclaimer: I'm not connected to them in any way other than being a
happy customer

Neil Kumpers

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 00:08:27 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Heater?

> I just bought a 914 two weeks ago and it does not have heat.  Is this the way
> all of the 914s are?  

Absolutely not. You can usually cook meat in the cabin of a 914 with a
correctly working heater. You may need anything from just a simple adjustment
of some cables to a whole pile of niddly little parts under the car. Consult
a shop that understands this stuff for an evaluation of what you need, or
better, a nearby list member that understands this stuff and has a 914 
you can look at...

> Also what is the small pull lever near the shifter?.  I have a feeling this
> has something to do with the heater but not sure.  I saw a referance to it in
> another book.

Don't pull it with the top on!!! Just kidding -- it's the heater control
lever.

P.S. Please go buy an owner's manual. You'll be a lot happier if you actually
understand your car...

Stan

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 23:28:55 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Re: What is original color

April Lambert asked about original color of her 912. 

Try sanding through the color in a small spot in the trunk. It's unlikely
anybody stripped that to bare metal (that would be a really thorough
repaint). 

Somewhere there should be a sticker or plate with option codes and color
codes. Look inside the front trunk and under the lid. Somebody else said
inside the driver's door. Given those codes, you should be able to look up
the color. I don't have Brett Johnson's book covering the early 911s but in
1974, for example, silver coupes had a color code Z2 Z2, while silver Targas
were Z2 V9. 

Pete

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 09 May 1995 21:32:24 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Antiroll bars or stiffer springs?

At 03:15 PM 5/8/95 -0400, Jeffrey Puzas wrote:
>
>Can anyone explain what the trade-offs are between stiffer springs and stiffer
>antiroll bars?  Seems to me one would want the stiffest antiroll bars you can
>fit while having the springs and dampers the softest with which you can
>get away.  
>
>Jeff
>jpuzas@astro.ge.com

Jeff,

Simple question, but the answer is a little more difficult to form.  A sway
bar gives you springing only in side-to-side, while coil or torsion bar
springs give independent springing at each corner.  So, for example, a
sway bar does absolutely nothing for anti-dive.

The received wisdom is that it is best to set basic springing in a car
with coil and torsion springs, then to use sway bars to tune.

With 944-series cars, most people update sway bars because it is real
easy to do.  Changing the torsion bars is a pain, like six hours of
shop time not counting corner weighting and alignment.  I just did mine,
and while the results are terrific, it was truly a pain in the rump.
911's have a hole in their rockers; a certain 944 may get a pair next
time its owner feels like re-springing it!

People on the list and at the track often speak of updating their
suspensions to Escort or Passport spec.  Ditto for Carrera Cup 911's.
I would caution that those suspensions are often laid out by Porsche
because of series rules and not because they are necessarily the best
clean-sheet-of-paper solution.  For example, the Firehawk 944's ran
rear coil-overs because series rules did not permit torsion bar
changes (this according to a friend who drove in the series).

Soft shocks are not the answer, but setting them is very difficult
and is something that the Indy and F1 mechanics, for example, spend
quite a bit of time trying to get right at each circuit.  For one
thing, a shock acts as a transient spring during weight transfer,
eg, during turn-in.  As such, the wrong setting can induce turn-in
understeer or oversteer.

Kevin Gross

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 07:55:11 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: 944 Supercharger?????

> A theoretical question to ponder:
>      Is it POSSIBLE to add a supercharger to an otherwise stock 944 8 valve
> engine? 

Yes, but the other drive train components would fail prematurely due to the
increased loads.

> Could it be done without making other major mods? 

Depends what you consider major.  One thing that might be a pain is the drive
belt.  Off of what pully would you take power to drive the supercharger.

> If possible, what
> kind of gains could be expected?

Lots more horsepower that depends on how much more air and fuel you stuff
into the combustion chamber, i.e., how big the supercharger is. 

> Would software etc have to be recalibrated,
> or would the engine's management system automatically adjust to the increased
> flow of air?  Thanks in advance,

Depends on whether the supercharger is up or downstream of the air flow 
meter.  In either case some new software would probably be necessary.

Jeff
jpuzas@astro.ge.com

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 08:42:06 -0400
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: which end locks first,


(Sorry this is moldy, I have been "away" for a day or two)

Pete Albrecht benignly replies:

> I was pretty amazed by the stuff in Newcomb's book too. But it makes sense.
>You have to consider the instantaneous center of rotation, something I
>haven't done since I passed the final exam in the freshman statics and
>dynamics course.

  Yup, me too.  Well, actually I guess it was grad school, but that seems 
like a long time ago, too! 

>The instantanous center of rotation is located way off in the weeds
>somewhere, maybe many yards from the car itself. A car going straight down
>the road with no rotating force has its instantaneous center at infinity.
>Once it sets up a yaw angle (either spinning or cornering normally, you have
>a yaw angle) the center moves inward. The instantaneous center in this case
>is determined by the intersection of the perpendicular to the car's path and
>a line through the front axle. Newcomb says angular momentum is conserved
>around this center, not the CG of the car. The couple operates around the CG,
>but momentum is conserved around the instantaneious center, As the car comes
>to 90 degrees, that center moves in and the car has to spin faster to
>conserve momentum.                                                             

   True, but this sort of just semantics.  Angular momentum is conserved about
ANY axis for which there are no forces acting at a distance from, or, more
generally, any axis about which there is no net torque applied.  The center 
of the front axle qualifies in this case because the forces applied by 
the front tires result in equal and opposite torques with respect to the 
center of the axle.  So, yes, the angular momentum about *this* axis must be
conserved.  Newcomb chose this point as the origin of his reference frame, 
I suppose it was easier to keep track of stuff about this axis.

   It is equally valid, (and easier for *me* to visualize) to consider the
CG as the origin, and then the forces applied by the tires DO result in a net
torque with respect to the axis running through the CG.  Angular momentum is
not conserved about this axis, as a torque changes the angular momentum 
(by definition, I guess).  This reference frame is generally the one I care
about, as in "Oh my god, my car is spinning!"

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa (that generally follows its nose!)


P.S., I sent in a reply to John Lupien the other day, graciously handing over
GOTW (Geek of the Week) honors for his pointing out that angular momentum
is conserved in the earth-sun-moon-porsche four-body system!  This didn't 
appear in my digests......

Education, I'm back to soft brakes ) again that allow my foot to slowly move
almost all the way to the floor (a quick pump of the brakes increases
preasure (I'm replacing the front rotors installing cool carbon pads, and
will bleed them again with high temp fluid once I'm done). 

After only two weeks with the new fluid, the fluid in the resevior tank is
already nearly black.  The sensor on the tank cap has broken free, and air
can get in (ordered a new cap already) so I know I'm picking up some moisture
here.

already?  I have heard that sometimes the "rubber portions" of the brake
system break down and cause this problem, if so what is a possible cause?  (I
am running with stock brake lines)

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 10:46:56 EDT
From: kresh@cvi.hahnemann.edu
Subject: Re: 911 (ant-) sway bar and mounts 

I was surprised to find that one (right side) of the (anti-) sway bar mounts
on my 88' 911 was severed. The only "extreme" maneuver that I performed was a
quick and decisive head-on collision avoidance (tell the war story another
time). Last night I dismantled the sharp-edged bracket (from the stabilizer bar) 
to avoid possible perforation of the AC-line -near-by. It is made from a very
flimsy (thin) material. 

I now remember that many of the 1987 Carrera's that I looked at had one
or both mounts sheared-off. Is this a bad engineering design or is the 
rear made to "stiff" with the 21mm stabilizer bar. It was increased from 
18 mm to 21 mm in 1886 (?). Is this "stiff" rear-end telling the suspension 
dynamics that it wants to be released (aka: self-regulating system wisdom ?) 

Now to the fix:  Should I release the other side -to make the car more 
"neutral" (symmetric) until the welding can be done? 

Is this a common problem among the post 86' 911? Did Porsche modify this
bracket design? I assume that it should be MIG welded by a Pro: protecting
the near-by components..

TIA for the help!

regards, Jascha

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~|~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 11:26:20 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Painting in the garage, birthing, and telescopes

Mark Kuefel wrote

>I'm an EF! member and active environmentalist but the
>problem isn't PRODUCTS it's PEOPLE (or, more specifically,
>the numbers of).

Amen to that. What nobody has figured out yet is that if you double the
number of people on the planet (and all of them want to live like Americans,
specifically the Americans they see on TV, i.e. Californians) and you make a
big effort to reduce pollution by 10 or 20 percent or whatever, you still
find yourself slipping downhill. 

Absolutely nobody except the Red Chinese have addressed the problem of too
much birthing going on. There is no tax disincentive to make more than 2
babies; if anything there is an incentive (deductions). And that's not even
getting into the welfare thing, where more babies = more $$$.

It's all just basic thermodynamics, First Law of. You have basically a closed
system (the whole planet), nobody is making a serious effort to get off the
planet, and everybody on the planet wants to consume more  (and by implication
 pollute more). I'm as guilty as anybody else and freely admit to being a
hypocrite on this.

Somebody once pointed out to me that anybody who has studied astronomy
(including self) thinks there are too many people on the planet. Probably has
something to do with light pollution. I'm told that on a clear day, from the
catwalk around the 200 inch telescope dome on Mt. Palomar, you can see the
brake lights of evening rush hour traffic on California 60 in Corona, 90
miles away.

Pete

Date: Wed, 10 May 95 09:36:25 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Gastester(schon wieder!)


Jerry-

I've had pretty good luch using a O-2 sensor (lambda sensor,
if you like) in the tailpipe to check air/fuel ratio.  I've
psoted a few info-pieces about it in the past several months.

It's cheap. and accurate, and it is, after all, the device
that is used in most (maybe all, but it's dangerous to be
so definitive on this list because someone out there will
be sure to point out the exception) engine control systems
to sense optimum fuel/air ratio.

 -Bob Spindel

In my original ID of MagBra I included Phone NBR. Here is rest of info.
MagBra, Ltd. 101 South Kane St. Baltimore, MD 21224.
410-633-6336 FAX 410-633-3666. Cost is $95 pre-993 911's and $99 for 993.
Note: For special applications the material can also be white, inquire!
 White is a different texture that allows for easier painting as well. I have
no affiliation with company just very satisfied with product having struggled
with various one and two-piece conventional bras on 914's, 911's, and 356's
for over 24 years. I concur with caveats that any wet bras left to dry on
metallic/clearcoated paint can create problems, more than on my car's solid
one-step paint. Over four days in April at Lime Rock mine got soaked and
dried three times without a chance to dry it or clean car. No problems.

Date: Wed, 10 May 95 13:13:08 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Subject: which end locks first,

>    True, but this sort of just semantics.

Although Paul is quite right about this statement, this kind of semantic
reduction can often greatly simplify the dynamic analysis.

> The center 
> of the front axle qualifies in this case because the forces applied by 
> the front tires result in equal and opposite torques with respect to the 
> center of the axle.  So, yes, the angular momentum about *this* axis must be
> conserved.

Well, it would be, except that it won't happen that way in practice.
Suppose you happen to be sliding downtrack at a 45 degree inclination
to the direction of motion (kids, these are trained drivers, don't
try it at home, etc.). The friction from the slide will effect a
weight transfer to the downtrack direction, so the downtrack front
will have more normal force and hence more traction than the uptrack front.
More normal force implies more traction than the uptrack front wheel,
which implies an unbalanced couple about the center of the front axle.
This is why the center of rotation follows a strange path during the spin.

>    It is equally valid, (and easier for *me* to visualize) to consider the
> CG as the origin, and then the forces applied by the tires DO result in a net
> torque with respect to the axis running through the CG.  

And visualization isn't all there is to it, either. The motion of the CG is 
what you are usually focussed on in terms of car control. Trying to
pick a desired center of rotation and effect control changes on that basis
is hopelessly complex. I have great difficulty doing offset-polar-to-cartesian
coordinate transforms while sitting in a stationary armchair - the driver's
seat of a spinning car is much less conducive to such cogitations.

> P.S., I sent in a reply to John Lupien the other day, graciously handing over
> GOTW (Geek of the Week) honors for his pointing out that angular momentum
> is conserved in the earth-sun-moon-porsche four-body system!  This didn't 
> appear in my digests...... 

I thank you for your confidence in my geekishness. To be fair, though,
I only mentioned the earth-porsche part of the system, and I am of the
opinion that any non-terrestrial bodies have no impact on the condition.
However, on further consideration of my statement regarding the effect on
the Earth's rotation of spinning a car, the only time it is as direct as
"Earth spins slowly the other way" is if you spin your car while passing
directly over the north or south pole. In any other location, there will
instead be a gyroscopic precession effect.

What's the prize for GOTW? Any way I can avoid winning it at this point?

- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Dear Mike,

I think you would know as well as 'most anybody about these matters,
but here's my two cents:

Rust spots, typically:  bottoms of door skins.  I'd check the trunk
for acid damage.  

A/C units are readily available.  Don't know if it was a factory
option, but International Conditioning Enterprises (ad in Pano and
I've dealt with them) advertises parts and complete systems.  The
earliest 911 I saw with factory air was in '72, a Targa with a sticker
of slightly over $10K, a price that astonished me at the time.  It
could well have been an option earlier.

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 13:34:51 -0400 (EDT)
From: gp310ad@prism.gatech.edu (ROBERT DUCKWORTH)
Subject: Re: 86 928S 67k miles $10k. Good buy?

If it sounds to good to be true it probably is.

The 86 928 was red, not burgandy.
Mechanically it looked good. 
No leaks, strong, auto transmission shifted as it should.

It had mismatched tires.
Minimal tread.
The front clip had been replaced. 
The crossmember over the engine hadn't because the frame was too 
crooked to get it back on. Instead the bent one was left there :-(

It drove nice and straight and cornered evenly and felt tight so I
guess the suspension was reasonable straight.

The brakes worked great.  The owner? (I'll get back to this)  didn't
have his seat belt on ;)
110 to 0 in very few feet.

Well we got down to business.

I asked to see the title. It was new and the mileage on the title
of 103k didn't match the odometer 69k.

I copied down the VIN number, the title number and the
previous title number and asked him to meet me at the mechanics
the following day.
I called Ga DMV. No record of the title.
I called SC DMV. No record of the previous title and no record of
the VIN.

Needless to say, the seller didn't keep his appointment and is now
nowhere to be found.
A
A
