Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 13:54:32 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: More 911 targa top sealing question + a HINT #2

Oops, forgot to offer a hint on targa top sealing in my original post.
Actually my hint is on stopping leaks which plague some targas. I was getting
some water on the floor behind the front seats which I traced it to a leak in
the rear window seal. When I went to seal it with silicon, I noticed a lot of
dirt coming up when I shoved the silicon applicator between the window and
the seal. I then got a small flathead screwdriver and cleaned up as much dirt
as possible, it was a surpising amount. I then continued resealing with
silicon.  Hopefully it will work. Just did it last night.

So in short, before you try using silicon to seal the  wondows, make sure
that there is no dirt between the seal and the glass. It might be obvious to
the rest of you, but I was really surprized at the amount of dirt that came
out. 

neil
'73 911S targa
NeilK356@aol.com

Date: Wed, 10 May 95 13:31:37 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; supercharging and 924s...

From: "Dave J. Andruczyk" <ANDRUC00@SNYBUFAA.CS.SNYBUF.EDU>

>Speaking of superchargers, I've been toying around with that idea for my 924
>..   My car is a '79 924 with the newer series 5 speed. ( not the audi 4 spd)
>but I'm not sure if the engine is original.... I though on most engines that
>the pistons come up to zero deck, meaning all the way up to the top of the
>block?  Mine don't that get up to about 1/8th of an inch away at TDC.  Is
> this a turbo motor?? or stock??  If its a turbo, it seems to me to be a
> prime canidate for supercharging due to the low compression ratio (7.5:1)
> If anyone whos of info, pleas reply....

>Dave..
>'79 924 in restoration...
            
    I forget how to identify these, but I thought the turbo motor used 
 a true Porsche head with the intake on the passenger side. I'm probably wrong
 there. I also forget what you call the 924 type of head (where there is no
 volume in the head for the combustion chamber, but instead dish). Starts
 with an "H"....(give me a letter...).

    The rule of thumb that I've heard is that 3.8pounds of boost is equal
 to a point in static compression. The 924 was a low compression motor,
 theoretically you could go from 8.5:1 to 10.5:1 at about 7 pounds boost
 which should (more thumbs; 15psi=double horsepower) give you around
 150 hp.
     Or, you could just get a stock 944 and probably you'll be happier...
 Or a 928 and have a blast... :)  That poor little 2 liter motor just
 doesn't want to give up "real power," but in stock, well-running form
 I think its a dandy car...

       -Lee A.

Date:          Wed, 10 May 1995 11:31:51 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Geek of the Century

Professor Lupien continues the abstruse discourse on four wheel spins 
thusly:

> ...More normal force implies more traction than the uptrack front wheel,
> which implies an unbalanced couple about the center of the front axle.
> This is why the center of rotation follows a strange path...
> ...offset-polar-to-cartesian coordinate transforms...
> ...However, on further consideration of my statement regarding the effect on
> the Earth's rotation of spinning a car, the only time it is as direct as
> "Earth spins slowly the other way" is if you spin your car while passing
> directly over the north or south pole. In any other location, there will
> instead be a gyroscopic precession effect.

And then has the nerve to ask:
 
> What's the prize for GOTW? Any way I can avoid winning it at this point?

Buddy, you're way out in front for Geek Of The Year.  Normal forces 
and spin couples, coordinate transforms (it'd take me a week to 
remember polar to cartesian...), and fergodsake the gyroscopic 
precession effect in the car/earth action/reaction system.

Let's stick to a frame of reference that keeps the calculations down 
to the merely unmanageable, as opposed to the totally unnecessary.

I think we need to add to our pile of P-philes memorabilia the GOTW
trophy.  I suggest a carbon fiber beanie with a servocontrolled gear
driven propeller. 

John, you're GOTW, strap on that beanie and FLY!

Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911S, Brick Shithouse Red (and when I spin it, you better believe 
the earth moves for me!)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 12:52:07 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 914 Thermostat Flaps

In response to text from In2914s@aol.com:
>
>One more 914 thermostat flap question:
>If my flaps are installed correctly, and the thermostat cable breaks do they
>fail safe or will they cook the engine.   My cable is disconnected and I run
>a constant 350 degree head temp, regardless of oil temp and highway or
>speedway driving.   Heads reach 350 within 10 minutes.  
>

During my recent rebuild I learned the following.  First, the flaps when
installed correctly will be spring loaded to stay open(on both sides).  

The termostat cable holds them fully closed with the engine cold.  As the
engine warms, the termostat coil expands, thus permitting more air to 
enter the engine shrouds.  If your thermostat breaks or is streched, you
should not worry about cooking the engine, but you may have a hard time
reaching operating temperatures in cold weather.

My .02

- --

 - Open Networks Engineering    fax:313 996 9908             abaris@msen.com -

 - '76 914 1.9                                                               -
 - '70 914 roller (soon to be recylced)                                      -

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 14:57:56 -0400
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Antiroll bars or stiffer ...

Antiroll bars and springs perform different though seemingly similar
functions.

Springs, along with shocks, keep the wheels on the ground to provide  maximum
traction and grip. They also help to limit roll and they affect the RATE of
weight transfer. If you change your springs you may have to change shocks to
match them.

Antiroll bars control roll couple distribution, ie the relationship between
the tendency of the two end of the vehicle to roll ( they may do so at
different rates). This means you can adjust oversteer/understeer
characteristics with antiroll bars.

It is not that simple to just "stiffen the bars" or "stiffen the springs"
beacause all these things interact on each other.

I am not qualified to give you advice on your car setup but I would recommend
that you read Carroll Smith's "Tune to Win". It is very readable, has great
diagrams and explanations and will most likely teach you enough to figure it
out for yourself.

I think we all should get off Rick's back. People are responding to his

doesn't like Porsches go drive something else!

All he said is that some of the parts on a 951 are not good quality -he's
right, if it is anything like my 944.

 Many of the electrical components (switches etc) are VW parts and are of
average quality and were designed for (cheap) mass production and not for use
in a high dollar sports car.

That doesn't mean he (or I ) don't like our cars or don't love to drive them.


Give the guy a break, Porsches may be the best cars there are but they are
not perfect or we wouldn't all be on this forum asking each other questions
about how to fix them!

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 12:27:36 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@MCC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: Re: 914 Thermostat Flaps

>From: In2914s@aol.com
>Subject: Re: 914 Thermostat Flaps
>
>One more 914 thermostat flap question:
>If my flaps are installed correctly, and the thermostat cable breaks do
>theyfail safe or will they cook the engine.   My cable is disconnected and
>I run
>a constant 350 degree head temp, regardless of oil temp and highway or
>speedway driving.   Heads reach 350 within 10 minutes.

If the cable breaks, which they do, the flaps fail safe. If your engine is
getting that hot there are a few possible culprits. One, you have many
broken fan blades and/or holes in your fan shroud. Two, you have a large
obstruction of air flow inside the engine cowling. Three your temp readback
is busted. In cases one and two, fix it now. The longer you run it like
this, the more damage you can do. To repair the fan? Replace it. To clear
out the air passages? Drop the engine and pull off the sheet metal and
clean the sucker out. This is a time consuming and potentially costly
venture. I say costly because you never know what you might notice needs
replacing or fixing once you get in there. When I did this to my very hot
running 914, I discovered both one and two. I had -NINE- misssing blades on
the fan and tons of glop and stuff blocking airflow thru the cylinders.

Good luck in any case.

You might be able to check out your fan with an inspection mirror and a
double jointed elbow :).

 -Josh

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CSP
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Everything expresed here is the opinion of the idiot that wrote it, 
namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 12:42:10 -0700 (MDT)
From: Wade Guthrie <wade@realm2.realm.net>
Subject: Re: Porsche 911E

Mike,

> Someone recently asked me some questions on a 911E that I thought all of 
> you in your collective wisdom could answer better than me. So here goes:

> By any chance do you know what the fair value for a 69 911E is,

I believe that the value should be somewhat less than $10K, maybe
as low as $5K or $6K for a streetable car.

> Also, did Porsche offer A/C in 69 for the 911 

I believe so.  Check out "The 911 and 912 Porsche, a Restorer's Guide 
to Authenticity", by Dr. Brett Johnson, published by Beeman Jorgensen, 
Inc., 1988, 1991.  You can get it from Motorbooks International.

> and is it still available to be added to a non A/C
> 911? If they did not, is there an after-market a/c unit that can
> be added to a non A/C 911?

Yeah, you can get aftermarket stuff in the neighborhood of $1.5K (I
think -- my price may be way off).

> The next question is somewhat easier to answer but have at it also:

> What kind of stuff like rust, etc. should a potential buyer be
> looking for? Where are the common places to look for rust?

Check out the 911 FAQ -- a lot of this stuff is mentioned there.  Also,
check out "Guide to Purchase & DIY Restoration of the Porsche 911", 
by Porter and Morgan, Haynes Publishing, 1988 or "Porsche 911 
Performance Handbook", Bruce Anderson, Motorbooks International, 1987

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 12:55:54 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: EDITORS - Porsche Supercup

Porsche Supercup Returns to U.S. Television in 1995

RENO, NEVADA, May 10, 1995 --- Porsche Cars North America today announced
the 1995 Porsche Supercup Championship will be televised in the U.S. over
the ESPN cable sports television network. It marks the second-straight year
ESPN has telecast the Porsche Supercup to U.S. households.

Lingner Group Productions of Indianapolis will again produce each of the
nine race broadcasts plus a season wrap-up program. All of these half-hour
telecasts will be seen once on ESPN and at least twice on ESPN 2. Veteran
motor sports announcer Marty Reid returns as the Championship host.

Now in its third year, the Porsche Supercup Championship is run in
conjunction with nine European World Championship Formula One Grand Prixs
- -- San Marino, Spain, Monaco, France, Great Britain, Germany, Hungary,
Belgium and Europe (Nurburgring). Drivers from seven European countries
will contest the entire 1995 series in cars fielded by some of that
continent's top sports car racing teams. In addition, several well-known
North American drivers are expected to compete in individual races at the
controls of Porsche factory "guest" cars.

All cars entered in the Supercup Championship are identically equipped and
based on the highly popular 1995 Porsche 911 Carrera. Changes in the
race-prepared Carreras for the 1995 Championship include the addition of a
huge fixed rear wing and new front spoiler, enhanced suspension and a
shortened sixth gear for added performance at very high speeds. These
modifications have resulted in a car that is faster yet easier to drive
than last year's version.

1995 Porsche Supercup  U.S. Television Schedule

San Marino
ESPN - Sun., May 28, 3: 30 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Sat., July 1, 3: 00 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Thurs., Oct. 5, 4:30 pm EDT

Spain
ESPN - Sat., June 10, 3:00 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Sat., July 8, 12: 30 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Thurs., Oct. 12, 4:30 pm EDT

Monaco
ESPN - Tues., July 11, 12:30 am EDT
ESPN 2 - Sat., July 15, 5: 00 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Thurs., Oct. 19, 4:30 pm EDT

France
ESPN - Sun., July 30, 6:30 pm EDT

ESPN 2 - Thurs., Oct. 26, 4:30 pm EDT

Great Britain
ESPN - Tues., Aug 29, 1:00 am EDT
ESPN 2 - Sat., July 29, 1:00 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Thurs., Nov. 2, 4:30 pm EST

Germany
ESPN - Sat., Sept. 2, 6:00 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Sun., Aug. 13, 12:00 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Thurs., Nov. 9, 4:30 pm EST

Hungary
ESPN - Fr i ., Sept. 22, 1:00 am EDT
ESPN 2 - Sun., Sept. 10, 6:30 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Thurs., Nov. 16, 4:30 pm EST

Belgium

Date: Wed, 10 May 95 15:07:32 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: RE: Temp Sender Resistance

Bob-

Here are the temp sender's hot and cold measurements

                                   Cold          Hot
Wire to gauge connected            116           65
Wire to gauge disconnected        1100          140

Not a very linear device, is it.  Let me know what you
find when you measure yours.

(Remember, mine reads a pretty steady 180 when hot, so
I believe the sender is OK.)

 -Bob Spindel

Date: Wed, 10 May 95 15:39:09 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Nationwide Insurance


A point on the curve of a recent thread.  I received in the
mail an invitation to have Nationwide provide me with
an auto insurance quote, saying that as a State employee
(I work for the Univ. of Washington.) I was eligible for certain
discounts, etc.  I called them, spent about 10 minutes
giving them information, like my wife's name, because they
just couldn't give me a quote without it, and when we got
down to the kind of cars I had, and I mentioned my Porsche's,
they informed me they do not insure Porsche's.

Aren't insurance companies regulated in some way?  Aren't they
given the right to provide insurance in a given state by a
state commission of some sort?  Don't they have to provide
roughly equal services?  What's the point of the regulatory
business if it doesn't regulate?  Aw...forget it.  It's too
complicated, I'm sure, and too depressing.  I'm pretty sure
I'd rather not know the answers to any of those questions.  I'd
just get more upset.

 -Bob Spindel

P.S.  Thanks for listening guys.

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 15:36:11 -0700
From: pyshih@csupomona.edu
Subject: Re:re; superchargin and 924

From: "Dave J. Andruczyk" <ANDRUC00@SNYBUFAA.CS.SNYBUF.EDU>

>Speaking of superchargers, I've been toying around with that idea for my 924
>..   My car is a '79 924 with the newer series 5 speed. ( not the audi 4 spd)
>but I'm not sure if the engine is original.... I though on most engines that
>the pistons come up to zero deck, meaning all the way up to the top of the
>block?  Mine don't that get up to about 1/8th of an inch away at TDC.  Is
> this a turbo motor?? or stock??  If its a turbo, it seems to me to be a
> prime canidate for supercharging due to the low compression ratio (7.5:1)
> If anyone whos of info, pleas reply....

>Dave..
>'79 924 in restoration...
	    
To my knowledge the all N/A 924 engines have valve/piston clearance even   
though (some) has higher compression ratio than turbo. 924 Turbo engines
have no clearance. Just wondering, how do you plan to turbocharge your
7.5:1 N/A engine? Doesn't seem easy to me. Although the 80' 931 (924 T) 
have that 7.5:1 C-Ratio. Do you have the Audi 5 spd? (thats the one on early
944's) or the Porsche 5spd? (the one that grinds) Supercharge it? not worth
it. cuz the low rev torque needed to spin up that supercharger itsn't there
for the stock motor. BTW: I doubt its a turbo motor. 

>    The rule of thumb that I've heard is that 3.8pounds of boost is equal
> to a point in static compression. The 924 was a low compression motor,
> theoretically you could go from 8.5:1 to 10.5:1 at about 7 pounds boost
> which should (more thumbs; 15psi=double horsepower) give you around
>150hp.
     
I wouldn't call a stock 10.5:1 ratio low compression! I think the 80'-83' 
924s had that. 81'-82' 931s had 8.0:1 C-ratio. That's probably optimum for 
street use and pump gas. 

>     Or, you could just get a stock 944 and probably you'll be happier...
> Or a 928 and have a blast... :)  That poor little 2 liter motor just
> doesn't want to give up "real power," but in stock, well-running form
> I think its a dandy car...

>       -Lee A.

Or, get a 80' 931 motor and just slap it in your 79'! (there over 10,000
units around vs under 5500 for 81'-83') "Poor little 2 liter"?!
hardly! What was the hp output of the 1980 and 1981 LeMann's 924? 600 hps
I think. Ok for pratical street purpose, my stock 81' 924 turbo (931) puts 
out an easy 150-160 ponies (and I have a Calif. model!) With a little tweekin
(turbo and intercooler, good gas)...well Euro specs. are above 220 hp. Thats
almost 1.9hp per c.i.! 

- ------------------------------------------------Phil------------------------- 
   Had several P-cars... 
   (2)72' 914, (1)84' 944,(1)84' 930 and (1)81' 931. I still think my 
   931 is engineered the best.
- ---------------------------------------------PYSHIH@CSUPomona.edu------------

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 19:47:45 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: 914  Ignition

Afetr much consideration and reflection, I have think I have determined my 
new plan for ignition and would like to hear any comments anybody may have.

After geting feed back from P-Philes, I spoke with a tech guy at MSD and 
asked about the MSD distributor. "Yes,"he said, "it fits a 914, yuh just 
gotta bang out the sheet metal a bit.." "Cool", thought I,"but is it worth 
it?" I asked if the MSD distributor was any better than, say a 050 or an 009 
. "Well", he answered, "I guess it depends on which you prefer.." "But", 
said I,"your's is four times the money...and I'll get it if it's better..." 
"Well," he said, "I dunno if it's better, it's different..." 

It seems that if you use an MSD-6 with the crankfire option, the distributor 
really does sweet FA, so you can use anything virtually, such as an 009, but 
you may wish to allow some retard (it's a street engine after all) so you 
just buy the 8981 programmable timing computer (only computer I ever saw in 
a 3 inch square box..oh, well, guess it's a euphemism)and you're off to the 
races (metaphorically).

The question I have is will this actually work? and if so, has anyone got a 
good idea as to where the crank trigger should go? Does it restrict the 
airflow unduly if it's on the fan? 

TIA, Chris Paine

__________________________________________________________________________
Christopher Paine 
cpaine@fox.nstn.ca                        "Technology is like a steamroller,
Metropolis Pictures, Director              if you're not on it, you become
Editor,Der Auspuff,Rennsport Region PCA    part of the road"


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 10 May 95 15:52:13 PDT
From: Mark Blaskovich <blaskovi@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: Porsche 911E

Comments from the '69 911E value/questions.  Comments to the
effect of $5K to $6K for a streetable car seem low, depends of
what streetable is.  I believe that real nice examples should
and could bring $10K or more.  

People seem to buy the earlier 911's for two reasons.  Some like
the style, pureness, whatever of the early cars (same for 912's,
too).  Won't be too much longer before a '69-73 911 is near the
same value as an '78-83.

Some people can't believe that you can buy a Porsche 911 for less
than $10K!  You get a lot of the looks of the later cars at a
fraction of the cost.  Some people buy $2500 911's as project cars
and know what it will cost to ultimately get the car "right".
Others buy them and the dissapointment begins on the drive
home, reality sets in the first time they're in the shop.  I'd
personally be careful of any car under $7K unless the price is
discounted and agreed on  because of known problems.

I also believe that if folks ultimate goal is to have a very 
nice/mechanically sound early 911, that the more money they 
spend up front will save money in the future.  If your goal is 
just to get into a 911 without spending a bunch of money, my 
guess is that you'll start spending money or get rid of the
car (then maybe some dummy like me who should know better
will buy it.....).

I'm a happy driver in my '70T, and close to getting the car the
way I want it (you'll know you've reached that point when you
quit apologizing for the car...."I'm going to_________someday,
just haven't gotten around to it".  Insert repaint, fix upholstry,
rebuild motor, fix rust, etc, etc).  And I'm certain that if I
ever decide to sell and replace my current car, the next one like
it will cost over $10K and likely more.  You just can't beat the
value of a properly restored or excellent original car.

Oh, on early AC.  I looked at a '68 911L (yes, it really was
an L) that had a/c-non functioning of course.  This was a funny
car.  It was an L so I expected good options.  It had a/c, but
the simple 3 gauge dash, and painted steel wheels.  Complete,
older rebuild, sound body and mechanicals, needed paint and
interior work for my tastes for $4k obo.  I think $3k could
have had it, anyone want me to see if it's still around?  Anyone
still reading this?!

sorry for the rambling (shouldn't drink decaff)
Mark

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 19:12:00 -0400
From: BeaulieuB@aol.com
Subject: Re: Battery Problems.

I've experienced similar problems with my 928.  I bought a battery
quick-disconnect from Automotion.  It connects at the negative terminal of
the battery, and only requires turning a screw to disconnect/connect.  I broug
ht my car to an electrical shop to find/fix the battery drain, it turned out
to be my alarm system wasn't wired correctly!  Another PCA member I know had
a stereo system wired incorrectly which caused similar problems. Let me know
what you find out. Bryson Beaulieu

Date: Wed, 10 May 95 16:31:19 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: 911 Engine Air Thermostat - NOT

Hi Folks - 

The recent thread on 914 engine air thermostat flaps prompts me to ask:
why doesn't my 911 have one of these clever devices?

When I got my first 911 and was poking around I was pretty suprised to
find that there's no thermostatic control of the cooling air flow.  This
seems either pretty crude (can you say Briggs & Stratton), or else
really advanced (look Ma! matching expansion coefficients!  no
thermostat!).  Regardless, the valves and pistons must
operate over a pretty wide temperature range.

So, does anyone know why the 911 doesn't have this, uh, feature?   (all
you 914, 356, 944, 928 etc folks, let's keep the smirking to a dull roar, at
least till we figure this one out...)

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Date: Wed, 10 May 95 17:06:33 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Windshield Polishing

> 
> From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
> 
>     Well, there is a kit, I believe that Eastwood sells it, to polish
> your windshield at home... I think it was absically designed to fix
> windshields on really old cars (like my Chevy) that can no longer be
> replaced, but I see no reason why you couldn't give it a try on a
> "well-loved" p-car..
>

I tried the Eastwood kit.  Comes with some special abrasive (zirconium
oxide?) and a felt wheel you chuck in your hand drill to do the
polishing.  The instructions featured photos of the felt wheel
splattering abrasive all over the front half of the car.  Desiring to 
avoid this, I tried a test patch by hand.  Couldn't see *any*
difference in the area I did, no matter how hard or long I rubbed... so I
put the kit away "for another day" and haven't touched it since.

Don't take this as a slam of the kit, after all I *did not* follow
directions... but I offer it as a point on the curve.  

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 17:47:49 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Matthew A. Dilligan" <diligan@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: Re: DOT5

On Wed, 10 May 1995 wayne@aprf.arl.mil wrote:

> Thre was a recent reference to problems with DOT5 - anybody care to comment.
> I have used it for 25 years now in a mix of brake systems from 
> all drum to drum/disc with and without a hydrovac style booster to all disc
> with and without hydrovac style booster and have found no problems!!

DOT5 does not absorb moisture unlike the other grades (as it is silicone 
based instead of whatever-else-based), so any water in your brake lines 
will collect at the lowest point and rust it out quicker than if it had 
been absorbed. So it's good if you regularly flush your brake fluid or if 
you can keep water out of your lines. At least this is what I've picked 
up when this issue is rehashed on the motorcycle list every month.

Matt

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 22:16:58 -0400
From: dsnover@ns.fast.net (Darryl Snover)
Subject: Dave J Andruczyk 924 Supercharged

Dave,
 As the mostly proud owner of a 1980 931 (924 Turbo), I can tell you
factually that the turbo pistons have a deep dish in them for lower
compression, and that they do indeed come up flush with the block.  I don't
believe that Porsche mad a 931 in 79, although the oddball 5 speed was
installed in some 79 standard, and all 80 turbo's (I think its a 016Z
trans).  This trans ROTS to buy parts for, cause they only produced the
thing 1 year or so.  Not that they aren't available, but that they are
terrible expensive (like 1500.00 for second gear).  However, I love the
shift pattern (like a 914, as I recall).  From what I can gather, the
standard 924 only has a CR of about 8.0 or 8.5 to 1, so LOW boost could
probably be tolorated well.  The bottom end of these audi motors is strong,
pretty much a hot-rodders delight.  The weak link is the cylinder head,
which if overheated, will warp.  Raceware makes an excellent stud kit for
the head, which helps hold things together better than the stock bolts. 
Since you have to replace the bolts upon removal anyway, it only makes
sense to replace with a superior fastener.

Hope this info is useful to you.

Darryl Snover  1980 931  (Almost back together :-)



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 19:22:51 -0700
From: "Volney Spalding" <vol@espresso.corp.sgi.com>
Subject: RE: 69E


>Rust spots, typically:  bottoms of door skins.  I'd check the trunk
>for acid damage.

Since I have an old car I tend to look closely at the old ones I see. The most
visible and common rust spots are in the outer door skins.  Next is around the
nose area. Rock chips mostly.  Third is the rear part of the front fenders
between the wheel arch and the door, down low. You can see rust bubbles there.
Definately bad news.

Also, the whole front suspension pan is a typical spot for rust. If it's
really bad you can see it from below the car.  Check jacking points. And,
for laughs you may want to remove a headlight ring to inspect for rust in the
headlight buckets.

Good Luck,

Vol





- --

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 20:22:56 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: the rear view  adhesive thread

Is there an adhesive patch for the later-style mirrors?  There was a
change phased in with the introduction of the 928 that eventually went
to the whole Porsche line, of an American-style round bracket mounted
with metal-to-glass (like Loctite) adhesive, with an easily detachable
mirror.  Earlier cars had a black adhesive patch set in a rectangular
base that was hard to detach (I never was able to do it).  Many cars
with replacement windshields and/or mirrors have the bases of these
mirrors sanded down and mounted with the Loctite adhesive.  I know,
because that is what a glass shop did with mine.  To be correct, I
have a spare mirror and patch just in case the mirror comes off again
and/or I need a new windshield (wouldn't hurt, but it's just pitted,
not cracked).

In short, I think the adhesive patch is for the older-type mirrors.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

P.S.  Actually, the old-style mirror base is a trapezoid, not a
rectangle:-).

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 23:29:13 -0400
From: finline@crocker.com
Subject: Re: How do you ship a Porsche???

Intercity Lines out of Warren Massachusetts.  They haul backloads to east 
coast on standby basis for $999.00 per vehicle.  You'll have your car in about 
three weeks.  Enclosed trailers and five star service.  They have 18 rigs on 
the road and exclusively haul new Porsches from Charleton SC to dealerships 
nationwide. Ask for Dave Wilson, the owner.  He has been doing it right for 
years. Tell him Greg Olchowski referred you to him.

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 20:34:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Two birds with one stone

Hope you don't mind the enigmatic subject.  The two birds:

1.  A low price for a carbureted 914 in California (but $400?!?) is
understandable, since putting the fuel injection back in is, so I'm
told, very expensive, and it won't pass smog with carbs.  But for a
track car, that's another story.

2.  I'm not asking what I should charge, necessarily, but I have 20+
years of PANORAMA including some multiple copies from when I was a
region president, and would not be averse to parting with all or some
of them.  If anyone has any interest, any knowledge of what traffic
will bear, or a particular issue in mind, please let me know.  I'm
only missing one month, due to an unfortunate but ultimately
beneficial episode in my private life (i.e., they always take
reminders even if nothing at first appears to be missing--especially
if she's a sociopath like mine was).

Thanks for listening.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 21:03:18 -0700
From: dem@best.com (Dennis Mitsch)
Subject: 914 cold start/shifting action/backfires (unrelated)


Hi folks.

Nothing has broken in a few weeks on either p-cars. :)

A few quirks on the 914, nothing major, but in the "just wondering"
category.

Cold starts.  It dies.  Usually once or twice.  On the second or
third time, I can modulate the pedal (aka frantically pumping the
peddle random amounts in and out) and keep it going.  Once I drive
a block or so (hardly any significant distance) it idles fine.  Starting
a few hours later is no problem.  Starting 8 hours later it will repeat
it's cold start symptoms.

I also notice small backfires occasionally on deceleration.  Nothing
major, just a little putting.  I'm assuming this is normal?  I've heard
it on every 914 I've driven (not exactly a whole lot.  3 or 4).

Now for a quirky one (to me).  The shift action on the whole, is good
(for a 914).  I can downshift from any gear while moving with no problems
(with no double clutching, which I haven't mastered in the 914 yet anyways).
Including first.  No grinding, etc.  However, from a complete stop,
it is nearly impossible to get the car to go into gear.  If I don't go into
first *before* I completely stop, I'm stuck frantically doing the 
5-4-3-2-1 3-4-2-5-1 random shifting in an attempt to get into gear 
before the honking begins.  If I let the car roll a bit with the clutch 
out, and then try again, it'll grind if I go straight for first, but if 
I go to 2nd or 3rd first (which it now goes into with little difficulty) 
and then first, I'm fine.

Confused?  I am.  I have no problem leaving it in 1st with the clutch
in at a light, it just seems so Wrong. :)

Thanks for any information.


Dennis Mitsch
'88 944S
'74 914 2.0 Special Edition

Subject: Stolen 2.2 911 E motor

My rebuilt 911 E 2.2 motor and all my tools were stolen Sunday night 
or Monday, May 7-8 from a locked garage in a public storage facility 
in Dublin, Ca.

Description of the motor:

Serial number: 6210165  (stamped on engine case near alternator stand)
Just rebuilt, never run
New Ps&Cs
Air deflector plates that fit around cylinders are painted grey
4 new time serts in top of RH timing chain housing.

May be missing the following parts:
upper pair of valve covers, timing chain housing covers,
timing chain tensioners, 10 valve rockers, induction system (fuel 
injection pump, injectors, throttle bodies, intake manifolds), 

If you happen to hear of or see a motor matching this description,
please contact Mitchell Craig (510) 842-0809 (work) or
(510) 833-0809 (home). San Francisco Bay area.

Date: Thu, 11 May 95 07:19:20 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Zone 1 Concours and Swap Meet

Hi, Triet,

Well, sounds like you have some good merchandise to sell..

First of all, spend the $25 and buy a space.  The proceeds go to charity and
you'll get 10 times the traffic that you would otherwise.  In addition, if
you don't, I'll have Unka Bart make you wear that hair shirt he has
available for such events...

Swap meet prices are kind of interesting.  They tend to be low at the
beginning, due to the desire of sellers to get off to a good start, then
they flatten out, while sellers strive to maximize their return, then,
towards the end of the day, they dive again, in a flurry of panic selling.

(Strangely enough, the swap meet works by the same economic rules that
govern Wall Street or your local singles bar - fear and greed...)

So, mark your prices on the wheels, display them, and be prepared to deal...

(P.S. I'll be there to swap on Saturday and score the concours on
Sunday...Look me up, if you have a chance...John and Donna should know where
I am...)
- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (needs work)
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 10:58:09 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Supercharging and 924s

        
>>     I forget how to identify these, but I thought the turbo motor
>used 
>>  a true Porsche head with the intake on the passenger side. I'm
>probably wrong
>>  there. I also forget what you call the 924 type of head (where
>there is no
>>  volume in the head for the combustion chamber, but instead dish).
>Starts
>>  with an "H"....(give me a letter...).
>
>
>Hmmm... Would that be a 'Herron' head?
>
>Do I win anything? (or did I screw up?) ;^)
>
>Ross
>- --
>Ross Parker 


Close enough. Heron head (one R). Used on Audi, Alfasud, British designs
including Kent 4-cylinder (Cortina, Pinto, therefore Formula Ford). High
resistance to knock, little tendency to build up combustion deposits and
therefore octane requirement tends not to increase as much during the life of
the engine. Disadvantage: higher exhaust emissions. 

This may be named, but I'm not sure, for one S.D. Heron, also credited with
inventing the internally-cooled valve, filled with sodium.

Pete


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 11:09:09 +0059 (EDT)
From: robin hansen <rhansen@world.std.com>
Subject: Back on line

Please put me back on Porschephiles. I went off line eight months ago 
when my wife and I took off for Mexico and Central America via Aerostar 
Van with two dogs. Went across Canada and down the West Coast to the tip of 
Baja where we stayed for two months. Then off via car ferry to Mazatlan and 
down the West Coast of Mexico to Tapachula, crossed the border into 
Guatemala, then, El Salvador, Honduras, and Nicaragua to Costa Rica where 
we stayed for two months in San Jose and then back via Tikal in 
Guatemala, Belize, Mexico and home. 23,800 miles in all. Roads varied 
from unlimited speed to a stretch of 100 miles that took seven hours on 
the way to Tikal in Guatemala. Driving in all these countries would 
delight any Porsche driver. I suspect that either a 911 or a 356 would 
make the journey except for the Tikal stretch which the 356 might make. No 
one pays attention to speed limits and double lines and police ignore traffic 
violations. If you didn't ignore double lines in the mountains, you would 
not be able to get by the heavy truck traffic that is nose to tail with 
no room to squeeze between. It is all or nothing. Mexico is the land of 
the Vdub beetle. They still manufacture them. There are interesting 
variations that are developed in Baja California. The top is chopped off 
to the back of the rear seats with a section left just aft of the driver 
and passenger compartment. Rear seats are left open to the sun, but the 
driver/passenger have the option of buttoning on a cloth top as a sun 
shade. Not a car for New England. Saw only one Porsche after we crossed 
out of the States. That was a 911 Carrera in Costa Rica. It was a 94 or 
95 and must have cost around $200,000. They have a 100% duty on new cars.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 11:16:53 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: 73 911 2.4 S converted into 2.7 RS lightweight

Michael,

A real RS lightweight is a very special car and it would take several pages
to describe the differences between it and a 2.4S.

A 2.4S engine can easily be converted to a 2.7 911.83 engine that the RS's
had and properly done is a great engine.  If the engine has been completely
gone through correctly and with detail you are looking at $10,000 for the
coversion of the engine alone.

As for the chassis, it would be virtually impossible to convert the chassis
to a "real" lightweight as the lightweight was made of special, thinner steel
and used lightweight glass.
It could be made to look like a lightweight.

As to the value of such a car, that is hard to estimate without actually
seeing the car.  Improperly done, it is a 2.4S conversion worth less than a
proper example-this is only my opinion but try and sell such a car and you
will see the problems.

Properly done (a rare find), it is probably worth somewhat more, maybe a
little more, than a 2.4S. $24,000 US might be in the ball park for a really
nice conversion.

If you are really interested in this car I would:1. Buy "The RS 
Book" and learn about RS's.  It is advertised in most Porsche magazines but
is expensive, around $250 US and 2. have the car inspected by a reputable
Porche shop.

 -Allen Henderson-
'72S coupe, '59A coupe 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 08:22:01 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: Re-Nationwide Insurance

My Porsches are insured with Nationwide. In fact my 914 has been with 
them since I bought it new.

The carrera was put on the policy when I got the car a few years back 
with no problem. Their rates are by far the best I have access to for 
the porsches. 

I have now moved the Carrera over the Porsche Club insurance with 
Leland West. They adv in pano. 

There are many restrictions with this policy and it is not for the 
"daily driver". But if you do not use your Porsche for other than 
pleasure and have other cars for daily drivers you can save a bunch of 
money with this insurance. The Carrera costs $250.00 for the year with 
stated value-this is a true stated value backed up by an appraisal. All 
drivers must be over 25 and have clean driving record. They do ck BTW.

For the record insurance is in Calif and I am definately over 31.

mike
- -- 
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	Well we worked out the deal on the 2.0, $4900 of which I loaned 
him $1000 so I guess that makes me part owner of yet another P-car :^)
About the exhaust system, Has Bursch header and muffler which was 
installed at engine rebuild and stainless steel heat exchangers that are 
eight years old and put out good heat.  All emission controls were removed 
very near new (my 924 was like this) as NC has VERY liberal inspections.  
The owner made the "always garaged, never in rain" claim which usually 
I would be suspicious.  But this car looks the part, has a 3 car garage 
and I looked HARD for rust and could find NONE.  I even went so far as  
to take up a lot of the carpet, even behind the seats on our test drive  
(didn't want the owner to sh*t his pants :^)
	My brother is SO happy to have found such a great car.  We pick 
it up tomorrow, can't wait to see how a stock 914's handling compares to 
my 924 and my Corvair/914.  He likes the '76 bumpers, he thinks they 
blend better with the lines of the fender, kind of extending the line on 
the end of the fenders at the parking lamps.  I'll agree with him on 
that, though I would like the integrated fog lamps and lesser weight the 
early bumpers offer.  Question, any good way of removing the "innards" of 
these bumpers to lighten them up?  How about just replacing the heavy 
back bumper with the earlier kind, are they easily interchangeable and 
will it help the front/rear balance?  
Thanks for any ideas.

Jay Karolyi
'75 fly yellow Corvair/914 "The Bastard"
'76 silver 914 2.0 (well at least its PART mine :^)
'77 mist green 924 w/NC plate "NOSBST2T"
'80 mustard yellow Toy 'rolla  (just rolla'd over 320,000 miles!)

Date: Thu, 11 May 95 09:59:50 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924 Compression and Superchargers


Okay folks, here's the hot info you've been waiting for. No yawns,
please. The Compression ratios for the 924 are:

Normal:
	Euro, ROW: 9.3:1, all years 1976-84 or so

	USA, Canada, Japan: 8.1:1, 1976-77.5
                            8.5:1, 1977.5-80.5
			    9.1:1, 1980.5-82

Turbo:  Euro, ROW: 8.5:1, All years
	
	USA, Canada, Japan: 8.0:1, 1979-80
			    8.5:1, 1981-82


The head is different between the normal and turbo. The pistons will
hit on a turbo, but not on a normal.

John Butera, of hot rod fame as a manufacturer of billet accessories for
Chevy and Ford hot rods, had a 924 which he installed a small vane-type
supercharger. He used a small 4-barrel carb to feed it. It ran pretty
well, but the turbo 924 happened along and it was much neater.

The head design is different between the two, they are not interchange-
able for use. True, the roadracers use the turbo head because it flows 
better, but that use requires special pistons because of the combustion 
chamber design to get any sort of decent compression.

There are three different heads for the normal, 1976-77.5, 1977.5 -80.5
and 1980.5-84. All work well, the latter two being the best (Larger 
valves, improved ports).

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 10:00:01 -0700
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re: 911 Engine Air Thermostat - NOT

     Ed said


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
>Subject: 911 Engine Air Thermostat - NOT
>Author:  Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org> at SMTP
>Date:    5/10/95 4:31 PM 
>
>
>i Folks -  
     
>he recent thread on 914 engine air thermostat flaps prompts me to ask: 
>hy doesn't my 911 have one of these clever devices?
     
>hen I got my first 911 and was poking around I was pretty suprised to 
>ind that there's no thermostatic control of the cooling air flow.  This 
>eems either pretty crude (can you say Briggs & Stratton), or else really 
>dvanced (look Ma! matching expansion coefficients!  no thermostat!).  
>egardless, the valves and pistons must
>perate over a pretty wide temperature range.
     
>o, does anyone know why the 911 doesn't have this, uh, feature?   (all
>ou 914, 356, 944, 928 etc folks, let's keep the smirking to a dull roar, at 
>east till we figure this one out...)
     
>Ed Mellinger
>eed@mbari.org
>83 911SC
     
     The 911 motors have an oil thermostat, which the 914s don't.  I think 
     that a flap scheme like the 914 or for that matter VW type 1 motors 
     would not work with the 911 fan/shroud setup.  I think the oil 
     thermosat accomplishes a similar purpose.  Remember that any flap 
     scheme when fully open still adds restrictions which reduces air flow. 
     The 911 motor was originally designed for a race car environment and 
     the cooling requirements at full load/temperature where more 
     important.
     
     Dan 
     
     70 914/6

------------------------------

     California or Arizona (or anywhere without snow) car is preferred due 
to
     the salt making the vehicle rust.  Is this still a concern for the 
modern
     galvanized cars. If so what part of them suffers from the salt?

     Does anyone know the number of 1989 911 cabriolets that were built?
     And what colors were they available in. I personally would like a color 
other
     than red, white or black, but it seems that is the most common
     color from the ads that I have seen. Is this info in Brett's new book?

     The car I'm looking for would be totally stock, low mileage, preferable 
blue
     or grey. If you've seen (or have) this car for sale let me know.

     the best (west) coast, as I live in Vancouver, B.C. Canada.

Date: Thu, 11 May 95 12:10:55 EDT

Subject: Re: Alternator needed

>Subject: Alternator needed!
>
>Hi all-
>I was wondering if any of you 911SC guys can point me in the best 
>direction for alternator replacement?  Mine's about to go and I'll do the 
>work myself- and I hear a rebuild is a good deal-

I had my Paris Rhone rebuilt at a local alternator and starter shop, cost
was $165cdn,(about $120US), and I had it back in two days. It may have
helped that the shop owner has a 944 turbo but this is considerably cheaper
and quicker than anything I've seen advertised in Excellence and gave
business to a fellow enthusiast.

(feet, that is) plaque with the following words of wisdom, suitable for
prominent display over the computer.  It should be priced reasonably so that
we all can afford one.

He that knows not and knows not that he knows not is a fool.  Shun him.
He that knows not and knows that he knows not is ignorant.  Teach him.
He that knows and knows not that he knows is asleep.  Awaken him.
He that knows and knows that he knows is a wise man.  Follow him.

(With thanks to Alan Bramley, Partridge of Redditch.)

Bob Joyce
Knoxville, Tennessee

Date: Thu, 11 May 95 13:47 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Supercharging a 944

pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net types:
    I read in the new European Car that the latest Audi T4 has a 9.5:1
    compression ratio and a turbo. According to Stans calculations, either it
    runs 0.0001 bar or it won't last last five minutes because it's not a race
    engine! Maybe it's only Porsches that can't run high compression ratios and
    turbos.

On a tangental note, has anyone heard of a supercharger running a variable-
ratio drive, something like that used in continuously-variable transmissions?
This would permit the supercharger to be driven more slowly (and therefore
creating less drag on the engine) at low RPMs, then smoothly (?) brought up to
speed in proportion to engine speed.  This would also permit the amount of
boost to be backed off at high RPMs (we don't need no steenking wastegates!).
Or would this be too inefficient to be practical?  

Junk food for thought!

Genuine Porsche Content: Does anyone know why Porsche never {turbo|super}charged
a variant of the 16-valve 944 motor?  Or are there really nasty cooling
problems with that particular valvetrain arrangement?  I notice that even the
new 993 turbo still has only 2 valves/cylinder.

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)

Date: Thu, 11 May 95 15:00:00 PDT
From: "Gaskill, Gregory (ASC/LN)" <GASKILL@rerw.wpafb.af.mil>
Subject: Microfiche Workshop Manuals


Took the plunge and purchased the fiche for my 924.  $18 was the price which 
is reasonable, but boy, the quality left a lot to be desired.  Most of the 
photos are "washed" out and almost impossible to see.  Most of the text is 
legible with much focusing.  Has this been anyone else's experience or did I 
get a bad set?  These were "genuine" Porsche fiche (made in USA by Bell and 
Howell I'm told), so I don't know of a better set.  Would there be one? 
 Mine came through a dealer.  It's not my reader that's bad, .

By the way, for those of you wondering where to find a fiche reader, try 
what I did.  Like everyone else the government is starting to put data on 
CD-ROM and is getting rid of fiche readers.  I got a printing fiche reader, 
that works, for $5.  They routinely try to dispose of equipment like this 
through open sales or auctions.  You may have to hunt to find even a decent 
one, but the payoff might be worth it.

Greg
gaskill@rerw.wpafb.af.mil

he patiently outlined the applicable numbers in response to a (naive
IMO) question about bolting a supercharger to a 20 year old engine
design.  Modern engine management electronics, modern combustion chamber
design, bottom end designed for boost, sure you can do better.  
That wasn't the question.  Give the man credit for answering something
most people just rolled their eyes at.

that works, for $5.  They routinely try to dispose of equipment like this 
through open sales or auctions.  You may have to hunt to find even a decent 
one, but the payoff might be worth it.

Greg
gaskill@rerw.wpafb.af.mil

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 15:00:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: Supercharging a 944

>Genuine Porsche Content: Does anyone know why Porsche never {turbo|super}charged
>a variant of the 16-valve 944 motor?  Or are there really nasty cooling
>problems with that particular valvetrain arrangement?  I notice that even the
>new 993 turbo still has only 2 valves/cylinder.

I believe that a factory race version of the 944 turbo engine 
had 16 valves and produced 450 hp.  My understanding is that 
the performance gains for going with 4 valves/cylinder on a turbo
engine are minimal.  Both items are trying to accomplish the 
same thing - flow more air.  This little bit of power gain can
be crucial in a race engine.  When traded off with the added 
complexity and maintenance the factory apparently didn't feel
like it was worth it for a street engine.

The reason for seeing no 4 valve/cylinder 911 engines is different.
The heads can't be kept cool enough in the air cooled engine to use
4 valves/cylinder.  As far as I know, all of the 911 based race 
engines that used 4 valves/cylinder had water cooled heads.

Ross Stites
'87 951

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 13:10:59 -0700
From: "William Dunham" <dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: Adhesive questions

I wound up trying the 3M spray "super" adhesive to reattach the coverings
on the door panels for my 911.  It took a little practice to get the
coverage right since it comes squirting out of the can pretty hard.  It
gives just about the right amout of time to get things positioned and
taught before setting up, and seems to hold well once cured (so far).
Thanks to those who sent suggestions and recommendations.

Bill
'72 911T Targa (now a cabrio) with newly restored door pockets.

- -- 
William J. Dunham
Silicon Graphics
dunham@esd.sgi.com
(415)390-2129

The 1979 Lemans car was a turbo/4-valve. The boys at andial tell me they
have two conversions running around with 2.8 l-4 valve turbos. Porsche must
figure the street cars aren't worth the longevity risk. Of course they felt
fine about the clutch lasting 30 k mi.

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 16:52:23 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Re: #More on speed limit law

I have been unable to get the complete text of Senate 440, but here's what
I've been able to find out. Repeal of the national speed limit has been
attached to the bill as an amendment, is not in the original bill. If/when
you contact your senator, it's important to emphasize that you are in favor
of this part of the bill. Otherwise they may cross it off, thinking you
approve of whatever else is in there and don't care about the speed limit.

The bill was introduced by John Warner, Republican, of Virginia, in February.
I know California's Democratic senator Barbara Boxer voted yes in committe.
Some info I got says it has 17 Democratic and 13 Republican cosponsors so
far, but that can't be entirely right, because one of the cosponsors listed
is Lautenberg, who is against repeal of the limit. Maybe he was in favor
until that amendment was added.

Sen. Boxer's office promised to send me a copy of the bill as it left
committee.

Again, we need to take action NOW to tell our senators that we favor repeal
of the national speed limit.

Pete

Text item: Re: Nationwide Insurance



  Regarding the Nationwide Insurance thread going on...

  I previously had a Saab 900 SPG insured with Nationwide.  When I bought
  my 911 a few years ago, I added it to the policy as a second car.
  Nationwide said that as an existing policy holder, they have no problem
  insuring a Porsche.  They would not have insured it had I not had a
  policy with them.  Not sure if it had to deal with my age (23 at the
  time) or the location (Portland, OR - home of the 1995 Porsche Parade :-)

Date: 11 May 1995 14:43:53 -0800
From: "Stephen Kurtzman" <stephen_kurtzman@taligent.com>
Subject: Re: A Quick CARB (CA. emissi

        Reply to:   RE>A Quick CARB (CA. emissions) Question

>Does anyone know how (/if) California emissions testing differentiates
>between 49-state cars and California-certified cars? Are the ppm's and %'s
>any different?

I wouldn't be surprised if there were no difference in emission standards. A
well tuned 49-state car will be well under Ca emission standards. I've heard
that the distinguishing factor between 49-state and Ca cars is whether or not
the smog tax has been paid to the state. I brought a '92 Sable into Ca from
out of state and it was significantly below all standards. That didn't free me
from paying the extra smog tax on the car.

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 12:28:29 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 914 Body Kits

In response to text from PersonalT@aol.com:
>
>Has anyone bought any of the 914 body kits other then the 916 flares.  I am
>going to have to do a little body work on this car and repaint it so I
>thought about getting a body kit for it.  I saw a couple of OK ones but none
>that really screamed buy me.  Any suggestions on ones to buy and ones to stay
>away from?  Also the front bumper is welded on right?  

I have a full set of 916 glass that I'll get to one of these years.  First
and foremost, I want to get my 914 on the road.  I've seen many different
914 kits(including, IMHO, the ridiculous 9014 kit from AA).  

Most, if not all, require professional installation, and significant outlay
of money.  I feel that the only flattering things to be done to a 914 are
the GT/916 flares(steel over fiberglass) and the 916 bumpers.

Neither of the bumpers of any 914 I know of are welded on.  You can drop them
off the car in 10 minutes.   Personally, I would avoid any body kit that
requires major panel replacement.

There's an interesting Chalon kit in one of the aftermarket catelogs.  Sort
of a slant-nose, make the rear more like a 911-type job.  Thanks but no
thanks.

I like the 914 the way it is:  Sure they're boxy, but the engines in the 
middle.

Date: 11 May 1995 14:51:47 -0800
From: "Rodger Keesee" <Rodger.Keesee@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re: DOT5

Wayne,
The negative words I have heard about DOT5 came from drivers with ABS.  The
belief is that the DOT5 interferes with the micro valves used to control
brakefliud flow in the ABS passages.   I don't remember what the symptoms are,
but i'm sure it's in an archive somewhere.
Rodger
keesee1@llnl.gov
'80 911SC shaped parking space

- --------------------------------------
Date: 5/10/95 3:04 PM
To: Rodger Keesee
From: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
Thre was a recent reference to problems with DOT5 - anybody care to comment.
I have used it for 25 years now in a mix of brake systems from 
all drum to drum/disc with and without a hydrovac style booster to all disc
with and without hydrovac style booster and have found no problems!!

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 09:49:32 -0700
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: Re: 2.7 RS lightweight

Michael Hecken asks:
>Is the metal or the body of a 73 2.7 RS really made out of thinner steel
>than a normal 911???

Up to serial number 1028 (if my memory serves correctly) the body and 
glass are thinner.  Afer that production metal and glass were used, 
although some remaining light stuff was thrown on as supplies were used 
up.  The switch to normal metal and glass happened after 1000 units were 
made, allowing Porsche to homologate in I believe Group B.

Jeff Jensen
jcjensen@raychem.com
nearly restored 73 RS (after 1028)

Just a little newsy-news in case you're into Indy Cars:

Thursday, May 11, 1995 -- Valvoline announced the opening of a new website
at www.valvoline.com in conjunction with Apple Computer. The website opened
at 7AM CST and recieved over 2000 hits in it's first hour.

This website is based at the track in Indianapolis just outside the garage
area. The site features new photos every two hours and will have Quicktime
movies each day. In addition, all practice times and speeds are updated on
a continual basis.

Try it -- it's really trick!

Date: 11 May 95 20:13:01 EDT
From: Dennis Winter <71334.2372@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE:Help with hot heater

>>> my heater is stuck on hot

Keith,

This happened to my 86 Turbo. The solution was *lots* of pennies to buy and
install a new motor. The center console has to be removed.

On the other hand, it happened again a few years later, and the solution was to
re-attach a vacuum hose that you can't get to from here, its between the back of
the engine and the firewall. My mechanic did it and spend some time explaining
to me what a pain in the a** it was.

	D.	10-May-95 at 06:45:01 PT

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 18:13:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: 1969 912 Targa soft-back


Someone could have gone to the trouble, I suppose, to install a soft
rear window that looks factory, but it's IMO unlikely.  Virtually any
combination of existing options could be ordered.  For example, I knew
someone who had a '69 912 ordered with 911S instruments.  Why?
Because it looked nice.  The 912, so I understand, sold much better in
the US, where most of the time one can only fantasize about going
fast.  In Chermany they hated it--it blew up on the Autobahn.

Sounds like a nice collector car if everything else is nice.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

P.S.  That "perfect" '71 914 sounds overpriced to me.  If it were in
*original* unrestored condition, maybe--but a repaint, no (IMHO).  But
if the buyer knows 914's and really likes it, who are any of us to
say?

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 21:53:34 EDT
From: BWSH00A@prodigy.com (MR GEORGE M MCROBERTS)
Subject: 914 cold starting

I have the same cold start problem with my '70 914.I solved 
the problem by putting a variable resistor in the wire from 
the head temperature sensor. I used a 0 to 1000 ohm unit. By 
adding resistance the brain thinks it is colder than it
really is and makes the injection pulses longer. Can anyone 
tell me what changed in the brain to make this added
resistance necessary? It seems obvious that with the added
resistance the engine is going to be running too rich when
it gets hot, but it seems to be O.K. 



------------------------------

What kind of difference can I expect when comparing this car to one that 
was built for distrubution in America?  For example, would I still be 
able to use an aftermarket chip or are these only programed for the 
"americanized" 911? 

Does anyone know what the factory specs are for 0-60, 1/4 mile 
and HP ratings? 

Everything I've read seems to conflict and I'm not sure if being a Euro
motor makes any difference... (The manual that the dealer supplied was 
for an 87-anyone wanna trade?)

Also what is the going rate for this car?  I traded two other porsches in 
for this one (and 87 924s C- and a 82 911SC B-) so I it hard to say what 
I acutally paid for this, probably about 19K, it is in A-/B+ condition, 
has 70Kmiles and 17" RUF Wheels.  Also has the Carrera tail, but I am 
assuming that this was standard as the leather interior is...

I did just have the 60K service done and the car has a pretty clean bill 
of health, except a syncro gear (1st) is starting to go, but the extended 
warranty is goning to pick that up....

Thanks for any information provided!

Armand



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 13:07:02 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Supercharging a 944

>Genuine Porsche Content: Does anyone know why Porsche never
>{turbo|super}charged
>a variant of the 16-valve 944 motor?  Or are there really nasty cooling
>problems with that particular valvetrain arrangement?  I notice that even the
>new 993 turbo still has only 2 valves/cylinder.

        Several schools of thought on this:
On the 993 Turbo--Porsche has never figured out a way to four-valve an
air-cooled motor with a reasonable lifetime.  Some of the motorcycle
companies have, but they're working under a different set of constraints.
My guess is that it's (at least partly) a heat problem--and a boosted
engine (turbo- or super-charged) would aggravate that.
        On why they never made a 4-valve 951--speculation is that they
didn't want to blow the doors off their "flagship", the 930...  If you
look at the 924 GTP/GTS/GTR (whichever was the right one), you see what
can be done when you do the 4-valve turbo properly...  Ether that or
there is some technical reason why--maybe engine lifespan, again; or
possibly expense...

        That'll be $00.02, please!
- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 15:00:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: Supercharging a 944

>Genuine Porsche Content: Does anyone know why Porsche never {turbo|super}charged
>a variant of the 16-valve 944 motor?  Or are there really nasty cooling
>problems with that particular valvetrain arrangement?  I notice that even the
>new 993 turbo still has only 2 valves/cylinder.

I believe that a factory race version of the 944 turbo engine 
had 16 valves and produced 450 hp.  My understanding is that 
the performance gains for going with 4 valves/cylinder on a turbo
engine are minimal.  Both items are trying to accomplish the 
same thing - flow more air.  This little bit of power gain can
be crucial in a race engine.  When traded off with the added 
complexity and maintenance the factory apparently didn't feel
like it was worth it for a street engine.

The reason for seeing no 4 valve/cylinder 911 engines is different.
The heads can't be kept cool enough in the air cooled engine to use
4 valves/cylinder.  As far as I know, all of the 911 based race 
engines that used 4 valves/cylinder had water cooled heads.

Ross Stites
'87 951

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 13:10:59 -0700
From: "William Dunham" <dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: Adhesive questions

I wound up trying the 3M spray "super" adhesive to reattach the coverings
on the door panels for my 911.  It took a little practice to get the
coverage right since it comes squirting out of the can pretty hard.  It
gives just about the right amout of time to get things positioned and
taught before setting up, and seems to hold well once cured (so far).
Thanks to those who sent suggestions and recommendations.

Bill
'72 911T Targa (now a cabrio) with newly restored door pockets.

- -- 
William J. Dunham
Silicon Graphics
dunham@esd.sgi.com
(415)390-2129

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 16:52:23 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Re: #More on speed limit law

I have been unable to get the complete text of Senate 440, but here's what
I've been able to find out. Repeal of the national speed limit has been
attached to the bill as an amendment, is not in the original bill. If/when
you contact your senator, it's important to emphasize that you are in favor
of this part of the bill. Otherwise they may cross it off, thinking you
approve of whatever else is in there and don't care about the speed limit.

The bill was introduced by John Warner, Republican, of Virginia, in February.
I know California's Democratic senator Barbara Boxer voted yes in committe.
Some info I got says it has 17 Democratic and 13 Republican cosponsors so
far, but that can't be entirely right, because one of the cosponsors listed
is Lautenberg, who is against repeal of the limit. Maybe he was in favor
until that amendment was added.

Sen. Boxer's office promised to send me a copy of the bill as it left
committee.

Again, we need to take action NOW to tell our senators that we favor repeal
of the national speed limit.

Pete

  Regarding the Nationwide Insurance thread going on...

  I previously had a Saab 900 SPG insured with Nationwide.  When I bought
  my 911 a few years ago, I added it to the policy as a second car.
  Nationwide said that as an existing policy holder, they have no problem
  insuring a Porsche.  They would not have insured it had I not had a
  policy with them.  Not sure if it had to deal with my age (23 at the
  time) or the location (Portland, OR - home of the 1995 Porsche Parade :-)

Date: 11 May 1995 14:43:53 -0800
From: "Stephen Kurtzman" <stephen_kurtzman@taligent.com>
Subject: Re: A Quick CARB (CA. emissi

        Reply to:   RE>A Quick CARB (CA. emissions) Question

>Does anyone know how (/if) California emissions testing differentiates
>between 49-state cars and California-certified cars? Are the ppm's and %'s
>any different?

I wouldn't be surprised if there were no difference in emission standards. A
well tuned 49-state car will be well under Ca emission standards. I've heard
that the distinguishing factor between 49-state and Ca cars is whether or not
the smog tax has been paid to the state. I brought a '92 Sable into Ca from
out of state and it was significantly below all standards. That didn't free me
from paying the extra smog tax on the car.

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 12:28:29 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 914 Body Kits

In response to text from PersonalT@aol.com:
>
>Has anyone bought any of the 914 body kits other then the 916 flares.  I am
>going to have to do a little body work on this car and repaint it so I
>thought about getting a body kit for it.  I saw a couple of OK ones but none
>that really screamed buy me.  Any suggestions on ones to buy and ones to stay
>away from?  Also the front bumper is welded on right?  

I have a full set of 916 glass that I'll get to one of these years.  First
and foremost, I want to get my 914 on the road.  I've seen many different
914 kits(including, IMHO, the ridiculous 9014 kit from AA).  

Most, if not all, require professional installation, and significant outlay
of money.  I feel that the only flattering things to be done to a 914 are
the GT/916 flares(steel over fiberglass) and the 916 bumpers.

Neither of the bumpers of any 914 I know of are welded on.  You can drop them
off the car in 10 minutes.   Personally, I would avoid any body kit that
requires major panel replacement.

There's an interesting Chalon kit in one of the aftermarket catelogs.  Sort
of a slant-nose, make the rear more like a 911-type job.  Thanks but no
thanks.

I like the 914 the way it is:  Sure they're boxy, but the engines in the 
middle.

Date: 11 May 1995 14:51:47 -0800
From: "Rodger Keesee" <Rodger.Keesee@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re: DOT5

Wayne,
The negative words I have heard about DOT5 came from drivers with ABS.  The
belief is that the DOT5 interferes with the micro valves used to control
brakefliud flow in the ABS passages.   I don't remember what the symptoms are,
but i'm sure it's in an archive somewhere.
Rodger
keesee1@llnl.gov
'80 911SC shaped parking space

- --------------------------------------
Date: 5/10/95 3:04 PM
To: Rodger Keesee
From: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
Thre was a recent reference to problems with DOT5 - anybody care to comment.
I have used it for 25 years now in a mix of brake systems from 
all drum to drum/disc with and without a hydrovac style booster to all disc
with and without hydrovac style booster and have found no problems!!

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 09:49:32 -0700
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: Re: 2.7 RS lightweight

Michael Hecken asks:
>Is the metal or the body of a 73 2.7 RS really made out of thinner steel
>than a normal 911???

Up to serial number 1028 (if my memory serves correctly) the body and 
glass are thinner.  Afer that production metal and glass were used, 
although some remaining light stuff was thrown on as supplies were used 
up.  The switch to normal metal and glass happened after 1000 units were 
made, allowing Porsche to homologate in I believe Group B.

Jeff Jensen
jcjensen@raychem.com
nearly restored 73 RS (after 1028)

Just a little newsy-news in case you're into Indy Cars:

Thursday, May 11, 1995 -- Valvoline announced the opening of a new website
at www.valvoline.com in conjunction with Apple Computer. The website opened
at 7AM CST and recieved over 2000 hits in it's first hour.

This website is based at the track in Indianapolis just outside the garage
area. The site features new photos every two hours and will have Quicktime
movies each day. In addition, all practice times and speeds are updated on
a continual basis.

Try it -- it's really trick!

Date: 11 May 95 20:13:01 EDT
From: Dennis Winter <71334.2372@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE:Help with hot heater

>>> my heater is stuck on hot

Keith,

This happened to my 86 Turbo. The solution was *lots* of pennies to buy and
install a new motor. The center console has to be removed.

On the other hand, it happened again a few years later, and the solution was to
re-attach a vacuum hose that you can't get to from here, its between the back of
the engine and the firewall. My mechanic did it and spend some time explaining
to me what a pain in the a** it was.

	D.	10-May-95 at 06:45:01 PT

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 18:13:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: 1969 912 Targa soft-back


Someone could have gone to the trouble, I suppose, to install a soft
rear window that looks factory, but it's IMO unlikely.  Virtually any
combination of existing options could be ordered.  For example, I knew
someone who had a '69 912 ordered with 911S instruments.  Why?
Because it looked nice.  The 912, so I understand, sold much better in
the US, where most of the time one can only fantasize about going
fast.  In Chermany they hated it--it blew up on the Autobahn.

Sounds like a nice collector car if everything else is nice.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

P.S.  That "perfect" '71 914 sounds overpriced to me.  If it were in
*original* unrestored condition, maybe--but a repaint, no (IMHO).  But
if the buyer knows 914's and really likes it, who are any of us to
say?

anythig like that.  A color that I really like is the BMW Iguana Green and

    Is metalic pants or any one type of paint harder for the do it
yourselfer?  More importantly is one type of paint easier then any other.  

I bought a couple of books on painting so I have a lot of reading but I
always like to hear real  peoples input.

Richard-Personal Touch Audio

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 21:53:34 EDT
From: BWSH00A@prodigy.com (MR GEORGE M MCROBERTS)
Subject: 914 cold starting

I have the same cold start problem with my '70 914.I solved 
the problem by putting a variable resistor in the wire from 
the head temperature sensor. I used a 0 to 1000 ohm unit. By 
adding resistance the brain thinks it is colder than it
really is and makes the injection pulses longer. Can anyone 
tell me what changed in the brain to make this added
resistance necessary? It seems obvious that with the added
resistance the engine is going to be running too rich when
it gets hot, but it seems to be O.K.

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 13:07:02 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Supercharging a 944

>Genuine Porsche Content: Does anyone know why Porsche never
>{turbo|super}charged
>a variant of the 16-valve 944 motor?  Or are there really nasty cooling
>problems with that particular valvetrain arrangement?  I notice that even the
>new 993 turbo still has only 2 valves/cylinder.

        Several schools of thought on this:
On the 993 Turbo--Porsche has never figured out a way to four-valve an
air-cooled motor with a reasonable lifetime.  Some of the motorcycle
companies have, but they're working under a different set of constraints.
My guess is that it's (at least partly) a heat problem--and a boosted
engine (turbo- or super-charged) would aggravate that.
        On why they never made a 4-valve 951--speculation is that they
didn't want to blow the doors off their "flagship", the 930...  If you
look at the 924 GTP/GTS/GTR (whichever was the right one), you see what
can be done when you do the 4-valve turbo properly...  Ether that or
there is some technical reason why--maybe engine lifespan, again; or
possibly expense...

        That'll be $00.02, please!
- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 05:02:26 +0000 (GMT)
From: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
Subject: Re: Variable ratio supercharger drives

It is my recollection that McCullough (aka Paxton) used a variable ratio pulley
on their drive.  These were a factory option on Fords and Studes back in the
50's.  By the '60's Stude used a fixed pulley - compression was 9.75:1.
It has been so long since I have seen photos of the sedans that Porsche 
designed and built for Stude that I do not recall if the McCullough 
supercharger was used on them.  Maybe folks better versed on mid 50's
Porsche's remember.
- -- 
Wayne Flowers                 Voice:  505-678-8303
Senior Scientist              Fax:    505-678-6049
Science & Technology Corp.    E-mail: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
White Sands, New Mexico       URL:    http://aprf.arl.mil/

Subject: Porsche crest - not what you think...


Is it true that the design for the Porsche crest does not share the same 
heritage as the car itself since it was really designed by an early US 
Porsche distributor who drew it on a restaurant napkin to demonstrate to 
Dr. Porsche that the company really needed an emblem to identify the marque?
Prior to that point, the logo only consisted of the 'Porsche' script.
 
BTW, I notice that 'Porsche' on the crest is now in black whereas before, 
it was only embossed. I painted mine black and it really looks much nicer.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 05:22:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: Remove: 944 Stone Guards

Tim,
I have removed them from an 83 and an 86 944.  We removed them because 
the plastic was cracked and looked worse than what I thought it would 
look like after I removed them.  In both cases - I was right.

I used a heat gun to heat the plastic - but you could probably use a hot 
hair dryer.  You'll visibly see the plastic change when it gets hot.  
Then I used a plastic Bondo spatula to scrap off as much plastic as I 
could.  You can use your hand to find those areas that still have a lot 
of plastic.  You want to remove as much plastic as you can, b/c step 2 is 
harder and the less you have left to remove - the better.

After the majority of the plastic is off - you'll want to use an adhesive 
remover to remove the remaining stuff.  I would try 3M's Adhesive 
Remover.  But when I did the two cars - I wasn't aware of that product 
and I used Gumout.  I would spray it on - wait about a minute and scrap.  
I would repeat this until the surface was just paint - no adhesive.

I then would clean the painted area and apply wax.

It took me about 45min to 1hr per rear stone guard.  I have never removed 
the front guards.

The results look great.  It looks so much better without them.

Scott
(scokelly@netcom.com)



> 
> Does anyone have any experience removing the clear plastic stone guards from a
> 944? I have been advised that it is extremely difficult, to the point where you
> must heat them up and possibly char the paint on the quarter panel.
> 
> Best Regards,
> Tim Pinckney
> Rochester, N.Y.
> 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 08:53:37 EDT
From: RON OLSON  12-May-1995 0851 <olson_r@cho000.dnet.ge.com>
Subject: RE: Replacing 944 Stone guards

 > Tim Pinckney writes:
 > Does anyone have any experience removing the clear plastic
 > stone guards from a 944? I have been advised that it is
 > extremely difficult, to the point where you must heat
 > them up and possibly char the paint on the quarter panel.

Tim,
  I just happened to have replaced my stone guards this weekend
  (actually my kids did most of it).  The yellowed guards, with the dirt
  that traps around the edges, were the worst looking part of the car,
  and replacing them helped greatly.  The job was fairly easy - I don't
  know about others' reports of it being difficult, but maybe factors
  such as film type or age complicates matters.

  We didn't have much trouble getting the old guards off.
  The guards themselves all peeled right off within a few minutes,
  without using any heat.  We used alcohol and gasoline to remove
  the adhesive, because that's what was handy, and spent a few minutes
  cleaning the car after removing each guard.  It got the job done,
  but I suppose a real adhesive remover would've worked better.

  For the new guards, I bought a 6' x 1' (or so) roll of the
  3M Scotchcal film (product 051141-84911) at the body shop supplier,
  for $40.  I was a walk-in, so better pricing must be available
  with some effort or with connections.  This stuff is non-yellowing,
  and hopefully better than the original.  I used about half of the roll,
  so if you can split a roll with someone, that gets it down to $20
  for one car.  Just make sure you cut the patterns sensibly from the roll,
  to avoid waste.  Sure, the pre-cut guards I've seen for about
  $90-$200 a set would have made life easier, but not enough
  to get my money.  Some of the pre-cuts apparently use the same 3M film.

  Having to cut the guards was a slight disadvantage, but my daughter
  is good at that kind of thing and it wasn't a big deal.  For a pattern,
  we used the removed guard.  Keep in mind that the guard may stretch
  somewhat when removing.  Alternatively, you could make a pattern
  by holding paper over the existing guard before removing, and running
  a piece of chalk flat-wise over the guard edges.
  
  The 3M film simply requires wetting down the film back and the car
  with an alcohol solution, and then squeegeeing the film onto the car.
  This was trivial for the 4 thin guards, and a little more difficult
  for the 2 middle wide ones.  But, with a little patience
  it's completely manageable.

  The final result was well worth it.  It's a relatively easy
  and inexpensive do-it-yourself project, and one where my kids
  were able (yes - willingly) to contribute.

Ron Olson  (olson_r@cho.ge.com)
