------------------------------

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 09:33:18 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re;painting your Porsche


>from: PersonalT@aol.com

>I am interested in finding out what it takes to paint a  car.  I have done
>body work on about 5 cars but I always had a shop do the painting....

I have a few questions.
>      What kind of costs are invloved for the equipment.  I have access to a
>compressor and I can most likely borrow a spray gun.  But what else do I need
>as far as equipment(other then the stuff needed to do bodywork)

    To paint, a minimum 2hp compressor is needed. I believe you can paint
 with a cheap paint gun -if- you are experienced enough to set it up right,
 but I've used a Binks Model 7 for about 15 years (they are over $200 now).
 Lastly, you will need a water trap and regulator located by the gun (another
 $40).  Other than that, just good lighting and an open bench to mix paint on.
   Oh, don't forget the safety aspect. Always wear gloves, I wear disposable
 latex with urethanes and heavy rubber gloves when using lacquer thinner. And
 you'll need a good air mask, NOT A DUST MASK, for about $40.

>   What kind of costs are involved in the paint...

   Say $30 a gallon for cheaper acrylic enamel up to $75 a quart for better
urethanes. I would only use the cheaper acrylic enamel on a cheap car as
practice anymore... the urethanes are expensive but worth it.
    As far as color, red pigments are the most expensive.
 The last car I just did, I spent about $120 on primers alone and about
$260 on the color/clear hardener. Good paint is expensive. Using cheap paint 
in the long run is very expensive....

>   Is metalic pants or any one type of paint harder for the do it
>   yourselfer? More importantly is one type of paint easier than another...

   Metallics are -evil-, just hard as dickens to spray well. I keep a clean
 pair of bolts in the can (constantly shake the can, the bolts help stir (i
 suppose). Use thin coats at every angle. Going too heavy will kill you
 ("mottling") making the car look splotchy.
   Lacquers are famous for being easy to work, easy to repair. But they have
 just don't last and a 5-year old laquer job will crack right off the car...
 The urethanes can be buffed quite nicely, which is critical because of the
 dust issues in the garage and the orange peel amateur painters just get....

     A good paint job relies on several things;
  1. Great preparation thru the primer. This is where all the time goes.
      Strip the car completely of every piece of trim--try not to use any
      masking tape when you paint.  You'll be sick and tired of your car after
      you've done this right...
  2. A good paint booth; I've gone to a lot of work installing filters,
     plastic sheathing, etc. I line about 8 box fans under the garage door
     when I paint; it evacuates both dust and fumes. I hang the hood and
     trunk deck vertically for lower dust. All this helps, but it is nowhere
     near a real paint booth.
       Bob Spindel has told me about a DXF-7 "supercharger" that quickens dry
     time of the PPG urethanes, getting a quicker time "out of dust" when
     painting in the garage.  And his '72E is a beauty...
  3. Practice, practice, practice....you'll paint a lot of ugly cars before
     you paint a beauty. There are so many things to watch out for, and your
     friends are not going to be impressed with the first car you paint.
     "Spray day" is the most intense hour that you'll spend, when you get
     there you really have to know what you are doing and GO !

    Keep in mind, the best you can be is a good amateur. Treat the paints and
  solvents as the toxic chemicals they are and go have fun....

             -Lee A, high on DT reducer

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 11:23:45 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Nate's driveway paint jobs

References: 
 

    I saw another happy p-filer asking about cheap DIY paint jobs, which
happens to be right up my alley...

    First of all, don't skimp on bodywork.  If there is any rust, cut it
out and weld in a patch.  If you don't, you will be sorry.  I like to
use an electric 4" grinder, with a grinding wheel for removing surface
rust and a cutoff wheel for removing rotted areas.  I suppose a die
grinder would work better if you had the money to invest in two tools.
    Don't be afraid of body filler... it's OK if used PROPERLY. Don't
use it to fill holes (you can get away with bondo and fiberglass screen,
but why take chances when you're spending all that $ for paint?)  Never
use it to fill dents, if you have dents, pop them back out and then use
the bondo for a skim coat to level the surface.  Don't be afraid to
cover a whole panel in bondo and then sand most of it back off... that's
how you get a smooth finish.
    Sanding... don't get too fancy here.  ALWAYS use some kind of block,
but other than that all you need some kind of elbow grease.  I like a
long 2x4, with some of those sheets designed for an air sander stapled
to it (80 grit) and also a 2x6, shorter, with regular 80-grit stapled to
it.  Run the sandpaper over the edge of a door to flex the backing,
it'll last longer.  I have one of those straight-line air sanders, but
frankly, I prefer a piece of wood.  After this, you need to go to finer
paper, I use wet-or-dry 120, wet, followed by 320 wet (the recommended
surface finish for most paints.)  If you get bare metal at any step,
spray primer over a large area around the spot before continuing.  At
this point, the car should look and feel perfectly sommth with a nice
matte finish.  Use your hands... run them over the whole car to detect
any irregularities.
    On the wet-or-dry papers, I use a hard rubber block, like the ones
3M sells at Kmart, etc.  Over areas that I have repaired and sanded with
80-grit, I often use a skim coat of glazing putty to fill in the sanding
scratches before using the wet-or-dry.  Saves a lot of time, and if I am
having a good day, I can go straight from 80-grit to 320.  This also
lessens your chance of sanding throught to bare metal, which actually
would be a good thing, were it not for the fact that your underlying
sheetmetal is probably not perfectly straight (if it IS, then go ahead
and take it down.... but make sure before you start, or you're going to
have to use about 20 coats of sanding primer to get it flat again!) I
cannot say enough about the importance of using a block... old paint,
bondo, and glazing putty all have different resistances to being sanded
away... if you don't use a block, it will show.  Every repair you have
done to your car will be painfully obvious.
    If you have any body filler on areas where the filler is exposed on
the backside, you MUST paint it.  I use rust-oleum rusty metal primer
coated with rust-oleum semigloss black on any exposed filler that does
not get painted when I spray the car.  If you don't do this, the filler
WILL get soaked with water and it WILL rust, and you'll have to go back
and do it all over again.  You may want to spend the extra money and get
special water-resistant filler, I would still paint it anyway.  Paint
the backside of all your welded patches, too.
    Next... priming and painting.  Always use a water trap on your
compressor... I use a big permanent one at the compressor, with one of
those little disposable ones right before the spray gun.  I go through
about 2 disposable ones for every paint job.  Most people will recommend
that you prime the whole car before going any farther, and I would agree
that that is a good idea.  However, the last car I painted was a '78
Impala, and we just sprayed the paint right over the old stuff.  It
still looks good 2 yrs. later, no flaking anywhere.  That's what happens
when you sand the whole car properly!  If you do prime, use a lot, and
then sand the whole car again.  It's the only way.
    When you spray the car, make sure your gun is adjusted for a proper
pattern.  Make nice, even strokes.  I'ts prob. a good idea to practice
on some scrap beforehand.  Metallics are evil, the Impala I did was
metallic blue and it has a very faint orange peel finish because if I
laid the paint on thick enough to get a smooth surface, the metallic
would "run" inside the paint.  Very bad.   Also make sure that you use
the correct reducer for the temperature conditions, and if you paint in
your driveway, do it in the morning as soon as the fog has lifted.  A
cloudy but warm day would be ideal, as you don't want to be painting in
the direct sun.
    For paint, I would recommend a urethane enamel, with hardener.  It
will look much better than any other paint, and using PPG stuff on the
Impala still cost us under $200 for everything.  I'm sure others on the
list can point you to the higher end stuff they recommend, I have heard
good things about Sikkens, for example.
    So there it is... a job a hell of a lot better than Maaco and a lot
cheaper, too.  If anyone has any questions and/or comments, fell free...
and if you are shocked that I would attempt to do a car so cheaply, all
I have to say is, it was a cheap car, and I think I have probably
doubled its value.  (Well, the back of the frame rotted away about 1
month after I painted it, and had to be welded... then a big rock fell
on the hood - very scary - but I digress...)  If you think I skimped,
you're right... and you can bet I will spend a whole lot more when I do
my p-car!

later,

Nate

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 11:28:52 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Painting you Porsche

Excerpts from mail: 12-May-95 Re: Painting you Porsche by PersonalT@aol.com 
> I am really interested in learning more.  I am just finishing up the body
> work on this chevy.. I have access to a spray gun and a compressor.  I have
> basic body tools but nothing really for painting.  I have all the body
> working tools.  With the chevy the mission is to get the car as straight as
> possible then paint it.   The 914s mission is to clean up the two rust spots
> and paint this car as nice as possible.  I have a empty two car garage to
> use.  
> 
> Please tell me what ever you can about what it takes to paint.
> 
> I am interested in finding out the costs of paints and supplies needed.
> 
> What kind of paints are recommended to the beginner?  

    I think I got most of the stuff covered in the thing I posted to the
list... one thing I did forget is ALWAYS USE A TACK RAG before you spray
on any color coats.  Also, if you use either lacquer or urethane enamel,
you can color-sand and buff the car to a perfectly mirror-like gloss,
which looks pretty cool.  You have the important stuff, just use a water
trap and you're set.  If you want to paint your car inside, I would
recommend covering the inside of your garage with plastic and hosing the
whole thing down, including the floor.  Dust can be a real problem
indoors.  Also, make sure you have some kind of ventilation, and
especially if you are working inside, invest in some kind of breathing
protection.  If you can think of anything I didn't cover, feel free to
drop me a line...

later,

Nate

PS - I seem to remember that you wanted to change the color of your
914.... I would almost say that's a bda idea, as you would have to
disassemble the whole car to get it right.  Instead why don't you trade
me your black one for my red one ;)
>

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 08:19:13 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: 1969 912 Targa soft-back


- --Boundary-8863412-0-0

There's an excellent chance that you are looking at a factory 69 softback.  I 
have a 68 and for some time was under the impression that 68 was the last year 
for the softback. 68's were availabe from the factory with glass beginning 
abut halfway thru the production run. 69's are rare but apparently they could 
be ordered.  I've seen one or two.  Many softbacks were converted to glass 
windows. This was a much better and cheaper fix than replacing the vinyl in 
the 70's.  For convenience sake, the glass is better but IMHO lacks the 
character of the top down roll bar look.  Commonly, when it was time to 
repaint the car, the owner would buy the glass and have the fastener holes 
brazed up or filled and pop it in.  The vinyl back has it drawbacks.  Unless 
it's really warm outside the  window is a bear to zip and unzip, they will 
crack in very cold temps, and they wear out faster than the glass.  A new 
factory back will cost you up to $2K.  After market ones can be had for $500 
but the materials can't compare.  Check for release handles under the targa 
bar.  They should be there.  I saw one 69 with a softback and no release 
mechanism, probably not factory. Also check that there is a boot for the 
window when down.  I don't think these are available from the aftermarket.  If 
there is one try to gage whether it is original, pull up German snap 
fasteners, etc.  It's more likely that a Targa would have been a softback, and 
converted to glass than the other way around. 
Hope this helps. 
 
Ted Smith 
 
63 B Cab (for sale) 
64 C Cpe 
68 912 Softback 
83 SC Cab 
one half dead cat (Miss BooBoo) 



- --Boundary-8863412-0-0

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 08:46:19 PDT
From: bezzant@corp.cirrus.com (Dan Bezzant)
Subject: Tire Sizes

I have a 1968 912 with 6" Fuchs, and went down to the tire shop
to look for new rubber.

Decided I don't want the stock 165/70R15's and wanted to do something
wider but with a high enough profile where the speedo is still accurate
and I can cruise along with my 4-speed box without winding out the engine.

So I saw some nice 205/65x15's that have about the same height profile but
I don't think there's any way those will fit on a '68 as the fenders aren't
flared on a 912 until '69.  Next best guess: 195/70x15, but I would have to
special order them.  Anybody know what I can fit without scraping on the
struts/fenders but still keep the right profile?

I think scraping on turns is something you can prevent with adjusting a turning
stop somewhere up front.  Anyone know about that?

Dan

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 09:26:39 PDT
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: Drawing for 69 912.

Hello Everyone,
I am sure this will either generate interest or flames.

I am in pursuit of getting a 911...
In lieu of this, I need to capitalize on my 912.
I am going to hold a drawing to give away my 69 912. The car is not
absoulutly perfect but is in very good to excellent condition. 120k
miles. There is one small rust bubble on the lower left front fender.
The battery area is missing some paint but there is still plenty of
steel there and is very solid. It was looked over at D&M in Palo Alto, CA
and was given a clean bill of health.."best I've seen in a while".
Grey w/black interior, CA original car and here ever since. The
engine was rebuilt by the previous owner's mechanic about 20k ago and is
very strong. I have some recent compression #'s but not right in front
of me. It has been repainted (original color), The interior is excellent
except for the typical crack in the dash near the speaker. It has: Flofit
sport seats,weber carbs(w/velocity stacks & K&N air cleaners), 050 
distributor w/Perlux ignitor, Bursch exhaust, cookie cutters(15x6) w/new
BFG tires, recent alignment, bronze phosphor pedal bushings, euro tail
lenses, retractable seat belts, new ball joints, new trans mounts, rear 
"amco" bar, etc.. It has an A/C system partially installed, blower motor,
interior ducting. The compressor, condensor, and hoses from the rear are not
installed and I think I have all those parts. It is turn key and ready to 
be driven away by the winner.

I want to sell 200 entries at $50 US each for a total of $10,000. $1000
of which will be given to the Porschephiles Fund. All entries MUST(sorry)
be sold by the closing date or all monies will be refunded and the car and 
donation will NOT be given away. All rules, terms, conditions will be 
stated on the entry form. If you are interested, please e-mail me directly
and I will e-mail you an entry form. sean@scifi.ucsf.edu. This will give
me an early idea if there is an interest.

Dates: All entries to be sold by August 1, 1995. The drawing (pending the
sale of all entries) will be on August 11, 1995. This will allow all checks
moneyorders to be cleared prior to the drawing.

Hope to hear from you.

Sean
69 912 (could be yours for $50 and a little luck!)

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 10:40:47 -0600 (MDT)
From: mark r gillis <mgillis@unm.edu>
Subject: 914 engine update

Hi P-philes,
I've lurked on this list long enough, I've been dying to ask this question.
I have a 72 914 which has a blown engine. I think a valve guide went bad 
and got swallowed. From my VW's which I overhauled, I think I want to put 
Hydralics with associated cam and lifters, and convert it to electronic 
spark. It has 81k on the engine, so I probably need to put in new 
bearings and oil pump. Would you guys do anything else? How would you 
update a 1.7 engine. Lots of power in unecessary, reliablity is important.
Mark Gillis, Albuquerque New Mexico

Date:          Fri, 12 May 1995 10:04:52 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Re: Drawing for 69 912.

> I am sure this will either generate interest or flames.
> I am going to hold a drawing to give away my 69 912.
> I want to sell 200 entries at $50 US each for a total of $10,000. $1000
> of which will be given to the Porschephiles Fund.

I'm interested, provided you do some research.  Specifically, what 
will it cost me if I win: registration, title transfer, TAXES, 
obscure fees levied by the state, smog, all of that?  How much of 
this BS are you going to pay out of the take, and how much will the 
winner be responsible for? How are you going to guarantee this 
shtick--lawyer, escrow, whatever, who holds the money, how do you 
avoid losing yer shirt, how do we know you won't skip off to mexico 
in your 912 with $10K in a briefcase?

If you can demonstrate that you've really thought this through and
made the correct preparations, and will absorb some/most of the
hidden costs for the winner, I think it'll be great fun.

You will probably end up with about $8K when all is said and done,
for a great deal more trouble than you would have had selling the
car (though I don't know what you could get for it on the market).

The car sounds nice, and I sure wouldn't mind a 912 to play with 
(though I'd probably sell it after a few months to support my 911 
habit).  Count me in (provisionally).

Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911S

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 18:25:57 GMT
From: kam@sandwell.demon.co.uk (Keith A Matthews)
Subject: 944 clutch woe?

My recently arrived  86 944 is turning out to be a problem car.
Latest worry is the clutch, and I am hoping for a diagnosis. When
the car is cold it is very difficult to select a gear and it
has to crunch to go in to either first or reverse. The first few
changes are rather notchy, and after that a trace of notchiness
remains on some changes. This problem seems to have gotten worse
in the week that the car has been on the road, the first 10 days
of my ownership having been spent at the workshop!

Does this sound like a hydraulic problem or of a more mechanical
and presumably therefore more expensive nature.

TIA (again!)

- -- 
Keith A Matthews
86 944 (Great White Tadpole)

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 11:12:43 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Tire Sizes

I think there's a typo here:  stock on older Porsches was 165x15, then
185/70x15.  205/65 is too big; 195/65 is the closest, then comes
205/60.  If the car has been lowered, I'd have the fender lips tucked
under (an experienced person can do this usu. without cracking the
paint, but don't trust it to anyone).

Hope this helps.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 11:19:19 PDT
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: Re: Tire Sizes

Dan Bezzant says:
> 
> I have a 1968 912 with 6" Fuchs, and went down to the tire shop
> to look for new rubber.
> 
> Decided I don't want the stock 165/70R15's and wanted to do something
> wider but with a high enough profile where the speedo is still accurate
> and I can cruise along with my 4-speed box without winding out the engine.

Look at a comparison:

Specification  Sidewall  Radius  Diameter  Circumference Revs/Mile Difference
165/70-15         4.5in  12.0in    24.1in         75.7in       837     0.0%
195/60-15         4.6in  12.1in    24.2in         76.1in       833     0.5%
185/60-15         4.4in  11.9in    23.7in         74.6in       850    -1.5%
205/60-15         4.8in  12.3in    24.7in         77.6in       817     2.5%
205/65-15         5.2in  12.7in    25.5in         80.1in       791     5.8%
195/70-15         5.4in  12.9in    25.7in         80.9in       783     6.9%

I would go with the 195/60-15 size tires.  A 6" rim will be perfect for
those.

You should have no trouble finding a decent tire in that size.

- -- 
Miq Millman   mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com	  503 642 6139   (Aloha site)
AL4-55  Intel, 5200 NE Elam Young Parkway, Hillsboro, OR 97124-6497
See also miq@teleport.com

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 20:24:00 PDT
From: "Thiger Jonas, Netsupport" <jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se>
Subject: Re: Supercharging a 944

Just a few words on the Turbo/16V discussion:

The 924 Carrera GT, had an 8 valve head, and intercooler (ol' reptile brain 
tells me 220 hp DIN). I don't think any of the GTS/GTR had 16-v since the GT 
was the homologation model. Did the GTP have it?
What I do know, is that the factory produced a 968 Turbo (limited edition).

BTW, Porsche dealers is now selling a toy model on the Boxter, here in 
Sweden. I assume it's approved by Porsche AG.

Jonas Thiger
Lulea, Sweden ('87 
944)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 12:34:27 -0700
From: cbardeen@csn.net (Charles Bardeen)
Subject: 944 : Helmets, Seat Height, Foot Rest Position

I ran in my first autocross a couple of weeks ago. I had a great time, but
was surprised to find that I could fit in my car ('89 944 S2) with a helmet
on. It seemed like I was an inch or so short of fitting.

I have the full power seats on the driver's side. One suggestion was to
remove the padding (don't like the idea of mangling the seat). Another
suggestion was to get a replacement seat. I called Recaro, and they said
that their seats would not provide any additional head room. Are there
other brands that might?

Another question is whether all helmets add the same dimension to the top
of your head. I assume they do.

To run, I removed the sunroof. This is OK, but it means I can't race on
rainy days. Could a thinner replacement panel be made that I could install
for the race (e.g. remove the inner linner)?

One other question - The foot rest for the left foot seems too low to me.
It is about where the clutch is when pushed in. I would think it would be
better placed to be even with the clutch when the clutch is let out. This
would make for less leg movement when going to engage the clutch. It seems
like they put the rest to be even with the accelerator (which is even with
the brake (when pushed in) for heel-toe). The clutch and the brake are even
when let out. Is this the best arrangement? Can/Should the clutch pedal be
adjusted? Can/Should the foot rest be built up.

                                                Thanks for any suggestions!

                                                                Chuck



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 11:39:57 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  944 : Helmets, Seat Height, Foot Rest Position

Interesting problem.  I've run into this fit problem on my (or should
that be in my) 944.  I move the seat a notch closer to reach the wheel,
and then adjust the rake of the seat so that I fit in with the sunroof
inplace, but "tilted".  There was some problem at the '91 Parade in 
Boston, because they insisted at the autocross that the roof must be
closed.  So, I drove with my head tilted sideways.  For the '92 Parade
here in San Diego, I did some research and got a ruling before the
Parade.  According to the litterature from the factory, the 944 has
a "removable roof pannel" similar to that of a targa.  So, according 
to the PCRs, the removable roof pannel must be in place and attached,
and even with the rear tilted, it was.  So, I got to look at the track
a little nicer in '92.  8-) 

As for a solution that will allow closing the roof, I've been told that
the earlier, non-power seats, sit about 1" lower than the power seats.

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 14:40:21 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: 16 valve Turbo engine

>Genuine Porsche Content: Does anyone know why Porsche never?
>{turbo|super}charged a variant of the 16-valve 944 motor?  Or are there
>really nasty cooling problems with that particular valvetrain >rrangement?
 I notice that even the new 993 turbo still has only 2 >valves/cylinder.

This reminded me to ask a question that I had been wondering about. At the
endurance races (Daytona, Sebring, etc.) where the GT cars race I saw a few
968's running in GT2 (I think). When I checked the standings, I saw that they
were identified as "968 Turbo RS" models. What is this? I imagine that they
produce plenty of HP since the street version of the 968 (3.0l DOHC 16valve 4
cylinder) has 236HP. Is this a car the Porsche sells in Europe or something?
I have never heard of a Turbo RS before. Any answers? If anyone does know
about them, what are the performance specs?

Barry Lenoble

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 14:52 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: 944 : Helmets, Seat Height, Foot Rest Position

cbardeen@csn.net (Charles Bardeen) writes:
    I ran in my first autocross a couple of weeks ago. I had a great time, but
    was surprised to find that I could fit in my car ('89 944 S2) with a helmet
    on. It seemed like I was an inch or so short of fitting.
    
    I have the full power seats on the driver's side. One suggestion was to
    remove the padding (don't like the idea of mangling the seat). Another
    suggestion was to get a replacement seat. I called Recaro, and they said
    that their seats would not provide any additional head room. Are there
    other brands that might?

Be careful here -- I know that in some organizations, replacing the seat will
move you up into a more advanced class.
    
    Another question is whether all helmets add the same dimension to the top
    of your head. I assume they do.
    
    To run, I removed the sunroof. This is OK, but it means I can't race on
    rainy days. Could a thinner replacement panel be made that I could install
    for the race (e.g. remove the inner linner)?

Yes, I inquired about this a month or so ago.  Apparently a fairly common
solution is to acquire a used sunroof and just remove the inner liner entirely.
I haven't actually done this yet, so I don't know how much headroom can actually
be gained.

Subject: Subject: Porsche was Austrian


Phellow Philes,

   Next week I am going to visit my SO, who is in the middle of a looong 
stint in der Vaterland (in Berlin).  We are going to spend most of
the trip in Austria, with a brief stop on the way back in Stuttgart :-) 
While I got her to concede me the visit to the Porsche factory/museum, she
doesn't know about the Austrian Porsche sights yet!

    As I understand it, there is a Porsche museum in Gmund (Gmu:nd for the 
purists :-), not too far from Vienna (where we will be for a few days).  
Furthermore, the Porsche family home is in Zell am See, near Salzburg, and 
is apparently open to visitors.  Has anyone visited either of these sights, 
and could advise me if either one warrants a pilgrimage?  (At possible 
risk of domestic bliss?)

  In return, since questions arise this time of year about the Stuttgart 
sights, I will post the PCNA contact: call Karen at 702-348-3244 a few 
weeks in advance to arrange a tour.  (Although, as has been discussed 
here prevously, the factory will be closed to visitors for some time 
this summer for retooling for the Boxster production.)

TIA

> will it cost me if I win: registration, title transfer, TAXES,

Never mind obscure fees, this is a lottery and the state will likely
get all upset about it. CA is one of the more enlightened states in that
they allow actual gambling, under highly regulated conditions, but
the idea of a private citizen operating a lottery is not likely to
go down well without greasing the right palms and paying the usual
vig. to the crooks in charge.

You would probably do much better to carry out the business in Nevada.

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 12:08:40 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924 GTR


Kevin,

You are correct on th e924 Carrera and 924 GTS having 2 valves/cylinder.
The 924 GTR also had 2 valves per cylinder except for the prototypes 
using the 944 experimental engine.

The Paul Miller car was a spec car that was hindered by a looseleaf rule
book that penalized it each time it wen5t faster than the junk it had 
to race against. It was up to 2.3l toward the end, perhaps harger. Still
a 2 valve head.

Nice to hear you on the net again.

Jim Pasha

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 21:16:57 +0100 (METDST)
From: Morten Christian Holmgreen <joker@diku.dk>
Subject: Re: Supercharging a 944

>  > What I do know, is that the factory produced a 968 Turbo (limited 
> edition).
> 
> Jonas, was the 968 Turbo ever sold to the public, and how many were 
> produced?
> 

According to Christophorus 3/93 (english version), there was a 968 Turbo S,
producing 305hp on a 2-valve 3.0 engine. (Torque: 500 newtons @3000 rpm).

0-100 kph (62mph) 5.0 secs topspeed 280kph (~175mph).
The article said they would build a max. of 100 for GT-racing. I suppose
anybody with enough $ could buy one (the price was not quoted).

This is the kind of power the 968 needs. In my opinion, the 968CS needs
more power - the engine just doesn't feel up to the body... (_NOW_ I'm
gonna get flamed :-) ). My guess is, that the Turbo S would be too much of a 
threat to the 911 Carrera to be put on the street as a normal production
model. (The car in the pictures _does_ have plates)

Christian

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 15:42:20 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE:  944 Clock adjustment

While I haven't had any experience with the ones in the P-cars, most electric
clocks respond well to cleaning (probably with a process similar to Casey's
Tri-Flow treatment, but using something a bit more benign...say mineral
spirits).  Ask a local watchmaker.

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 16:12:50 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@use.usit.net>
Subject: A Question About Shocks

Hi Again,

Since most of us are apparently driving cars that we bought used,
and may have never even driven a new example of the cars we drive,
what is the best way to determine if the shocks need to be replaced?

Obviously, if they're leaking or the car is floating on rough surfaces,
they needed to be replaced yesterday. And I'm sure that if I buy a new
set today and sweat to put them on, they'll sure feel better to me,
even if they aren't.

Any comments?

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 17:46:36 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: Scantily Clad Females and 914 Ignition

I posted this earlier in the week and got -0- response, so I thought maybe 
I'd try it again with more primal appeal. Sorry for the use of bandwidth, 
but I really want to figure this out by next week or so... Hey, I'm 
beginning to sound desperate...I guess that's what happens when you're neat 
car's been apart since September and the other car is painfully utilitarian..

>After much consideration and reflection, I have think I have determined my 
new plan for ignition and would like to hear any comments anybody may have.
>
>After geting feed back from P-Philes, I spoke with a tech guy at MSD and 
asked about the MSD distributor. "Yes,"he said, "it fits a 914, yuh just 
gotta bang out the sheet metal a bit.." "Cool", thought I,"but is it worth 
it?" I asked if the MSD distributor was any better than, say a 050 or an 009 
. "Well", he answered, "I guess it depends on which you prefer.." "But", 
said I,"your's is four times the money...and I'll get it if it's better..." 
"Well," he said, "I dunno if it's better, it's different..." 
>
>It seems that if you use an MSD-6 with the crankfire option, the 
distributor really does sweet FA, so you can use anything virtually, such as 
an 009, but you may wish to allow some retard (it's a street engine after 
all) so you just buy the 8981 programmable timing computer (only computer I 
ever saw in a 3 inch square box..oh, well, guess it's a euphemism)and you're 
off to the races (metaphorically).
>
>The question I have is will this actually work? and if so, has anyone got a 
good idea as to where the crank trigger should go? Does it restrict the 
airflow unduly if it's on the fan? 
>
>TIA, Chris Paine
>

__________________________________________________________________________
Christopher Paine 
cpaine@fox.nstn.ca                        "Technology is like a steamroller,
Metropolis Pictures, Director              if you're not on it, you become
Editor,Der Auspuff,Rennsport Region PCA    part of the road"

Porschephiles #1397                         Sat May 13 02:00:10 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 13:54:30 -0700
From: cherie@corp.cirrus.com (Cherie Woodward)

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 18:05:07 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Scantily Clad Females and 914 Ignition

I put this aside to respond to, and apparently lined the virtual bird cage
with it instead...

> >After geting feed back from P-Philes, I spoke with a tech guy at MSD and 
> asked about the MSD distributor. "Yes,"he said, "it fits a 914, yuh just 
> gotta bang out the sheet metal a bit.." "Cool", thought I,"but is it worth 
> it?" I asked if the MSD distributor was any better than, say a 050 or an 009 
> . "Well", he answered, "I guess it depends on which you prefer.." "But", 
> said I,"your's is four times the money...and I'll get it if it's better..." 
> "Well," he said, "I dunno if it's better, it's different..." 

At least he was honest about it...

> >It seems that if you use an MSD-6 with the crankfire option, the 
> distributor really does sweet FA, so you can use anything virtually, such as 
> an 009, but you may wish to allow some retard (it's a street engine after 
> all) so you just buy the 8981 programmable timing computer (only computer I 
> ever saw in a 3 inch square box..oh, well, guess it's a euphemism)and you're 
> off to the races (metaphorically).

Any crankfire ignition can obviate the need for a distributor. That's part
of what it does. A distributorless ignition setup like the Compu-Fire DIS IX 
(about $150 at most of the popular VW parts places) or the Electomotive 
system (used a lot of them on 911s over the years) is required. Once you do
that, though, you really don't need the MSD setup. See below on "how the
MSD works".

Which is why, of course, MSD sells their own version. About which, as it
turns out, I know nothing.

> >The question I have is will this actually work? and if so, has anyone got a 
> good idea as to where the crank trigger should go? Does it restrict the 
> airflow unduly if it's on the fan? 

I've mounted triggers as separate notched disks bolted to the front crank
pully on 911s and VW Type Is, and embedded them in the rim of the fly
wheel on 911, but have never installed such a system on a 914. The rules
under which I have competed just wouldn't allow use of such systems.

Things to watch for:

1) balance. don't upset the balance of the  thing you're mounting on. ALWAYS
   have it rebalanced as part of the process

2) getting flung off. It's best not to stick a sensor *on* a rotating part
   lest they part company at high velocity. 

3) access. You'll need to get to it, so take that into account when deciding
   where that it should go.

BTW, one final word here: let's answer the "what is MSD good for" question.
IF you have an engine with high compression and that is cam'ed for high
RPM operation and has the FI tweaked to match, complete with fairly cold
plugs to keep the heat down under load, odds are that you'll foul
your plugs at putting-around-town engine speeds and when you really
stand on it, nothing pleasant will happen.

MSD fixes that by sending multiple spark discharges (wanna guess where
the acronym came from?) per "firing signal" at low-medium RPM operation.
In other words, when the plug would *normally* get the signal to fire at
say 1200 RPM, it'll get one, then as soon as the CD unit recharges, another
and another and another. This helps keep the plugs clean. At anything over
about 3000 RPM, it shuts off since then in theory you have a decreased 
relaxation time between the originating signals and also you should be at
operating temp for the plugs so they won't foul.

What makes it work is two things: 1) it gets that "firing signal" from the
points or whatever passes for points on your car, so having the right
"programming" on the distributor or the crank fire computer or whatever
is VITAL. 2) distributor and coil. This setup won't work without it. They
(MSD) may have a distributorless version, or be able to recommend one that
is compatible. Believe them and use whatever they say to use.

Final note: I have a spare 6AL sitting around. It has zero hours on a factory
refurbishing job. Included are "programming pack" resistors for rev limting
in the 7-8k range, documentation, wiring harness, etc. $150 gets it.

Stan

Good luck.

Stan


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 18:09:24 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine update

> I've lurked on this list long enough, I've been dying to ask this question.
> I have a 72 914 which has a blown engine. I think a valve guide went bad 
> and got swallowed. From my VW's which I overhauled, I think I want to put 
> Hydralics with associated cam and lifters, and convert it to electronic 
> spark. It has 81k on the engine, so I probably need to put in new 
> bearings and oil pump. Would you guys do anything else? How would you 
> update a 1.7 engine. Lots of power in unecessary, reliablity is important.

This does get covered a lot. Hydraulic lifters are evil. Plan on new
pistons and cylinders, and for that matter clutch. Odds are good you 
need full valve jobs and maybe some head work. Replace the oil cooler as
it's full of blown engine bits.

For max reliability, use a high-grade counterweighted balanced crank and
BALANCE EVERYTHING. Make sure everything is *SUPER* clean going back
together. Consider using PolyDyne coating on the bearings.

Good luck.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 12 May 1995 18:55:06 -0700
From: cjk50g@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Woodward)
Subject: RE: 944 clutch woe

>Latest worry is the clutch, and I am hoping for a diagnosis. When
>the car is cold it is very difficult to select a gear and it
>has to crunch to go in to either first or reverse. The first few
>changes are rather notchy, and after that a trace of notchiness
>remains on some changes. 
>
>Does this sound like a hydraulic problem or of a more mechanical
>and presumably therefore more expensive nature.

Keith,

This may indeed be only a hydraulic problem.  Have your clutch
thouroughly bled and have the travel of the slave cylinder piston
checked at the clutch bell housing.  The engage/disengage travel
should be not less than .5 inches nor greater than .75 inches.  Too
short a distance indicates a lack of disengagement and would result
in the type of problems you are having.

I've never heard of this happenning, but perhaps the tongs of the 
pressure plate have grown weak, allowing for travel w/o disengagement.
Anyone heard of this?

Chris Woodward
944S

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 00:19:34 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: A Question About Shocks

At 04:12 PM 5/12/95 -0400, Doug Donsbach wrote:
>Hi Again,
>
>Since most of us are apparently driving cars that we bought used,
>and may have never even driven a new example of the cars we drive,
>what is the best way to determine if the shocks need to be replaced?

Doug,

I don't have a definitive answer, absent an available shock dyno near
to you.  To my experience, the failure or deterioration mode is generally
a loosening of the piston.  It could be that damping changes over time
too, but it's hard to tell.

When the piston loosens up, you can feel it by rocking the wheel, like
you are checking wheel bearing play.  In fact, a lot of people mistake
a loose strut for misadjusted wheel bearings.  If you pull off the wheel
and place one hand on the shock body, while you shake the rotor with
the other, you can then tell whether the looseness is in the strut vs.
wheel bearings.

The practical effect of this loosening is significant and unwelcome 
camber changes.  The strut has to be replaced -- there is not a separate
insert which can be swapped out.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 00:24:08 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Brake Piston Seals

Bill,

No, there is no source for just the seals, which sucks.  The US Brembo
distributor is no help, according to several sources.

You may not need to replace all four pistons and seal sets.  I would
disassemble, clean up, and reassemble the calliper with the existing
seals if they look OK.  It may be that you have a single seal or piston
which is bad and can get away with replacing just that piston and its
seals.


Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 00:31:15 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Oil pressure light stays on? 86 944

Mark,

If you have a number of the lamps on, and they all started coming on
together, you may have an electrical gremlin.  Start by going over
(locating, cleaning, snugging) all your ground points.  Make sure the sensor
connectors are clean and snug.

Slow oil pressure build-up in a 944 is usually a problem with the oil
pressure relief valve.  Solution is to remove and clean it, replace the
o-ring at its end, and reinstall with a fresh seal ring.  If that doesn't
solve the problem, the factory recommends removing and resealing the oil pump.

And if that doesn't help, drop the oil pan and check the oil pick-up for
overall health and esp. its seal to the bottom of the block.  The pick-up in
944's has been known to suffer if the car is run a long time with bad engine
mounts.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 00:33:06 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 hood latches and dents

I have been taught not to push a hood closed.  Instead, you grab it with
your fingers under the front lip, yank it down sharply, and let its inertia
do the job of engaging the latch fully.

Kevin Gross

Porschephiles #1398                         Sat May 13 22:41:03 CDT 1995
Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 09:06:01 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Worn struts/misadjusted bearings

Kevin Gross wrote :

>When the piston loosens up, you can feel it by rocking the wheel, like
>you are checking wheel bearing play.  In fact, a lot of people mistake
>a loose strut for misadjusted wheel bearings.  If you pull off the wheel
>and place one hand on the shock body, while you shake the rotor with
>the other, you can then tell whether the looseness is in the strut vs.
>wheel bearings.

Absolutely!  I thought my front wheel bearings were a little loose on the
passenger's side of the car until, when pulling my worn Boge inserts
out of the housing, I noticed some play in the piston/cylinder interface.
When I put my new Konis in, I made a point to check to see if the same
slight movement was present (grabbing the top and bottom of the tire) -
GONE! 

I had checked the adjustment of my bearings when I first found this
play in the front suspension.  When I found the adjustment to be OK,
I was a little concerned that the problem was something bigger$$.

What a pleasant surprise - new shocks and my "looseness" went
away!!

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 10:34:12 -0400

Give out "numbers" from 001 to 200. These can be posted
on PFILES before the drawing. Take the last three (or 4 if 
000) digits of the Dow Jones industrial average (001 to 1000)
from the Wall Street Journal (or some other nationally
published random number) and divide by 5. Round it UP if 
not an exact multiple of 5. The winner has this number.

This may not be exactly correct (it's late) but you get the idea.
People can even choose their numbers if you want to let them,
by "First come first served".

If you do something like this to ensure fairness, then I'm in,
even though I'm in Connecticut.

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S, '73 914/2.0 (?)  
'73 911E (??) '69 912 (???)

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 09:40:17 -0500
From: cowan@sccsi.com (Ken Rentiers)

>human population was evenly distributed across the earth's
>land mass, that there would be ONE person per FOUR city blocks.

>Seeing how this includes alot of desert and tundra, that's
>ALOT of people.  On top of that, the population is growing

Enough!

The world's most densely populated country, Bangladesh, has 2130 people per
square mile. Fremont, CA has a population density of 2.250 people per
square mile. And lots of Porsches.

There are about 5.3 billion peole out there, roughly 101 per square mile if
we exclude Antarctica. There are 118 people per square mile in Tennessee,
home of that renowned pessimist, Wooden Al. And many Porsches.

If all the population of the earth lived as densely as the folks of
sprawling Fremont, California we would use up all of western Europe (gasp).
At the density of San Francisco (still plenty of room for Porsches) all 5.3
billion could fit in Texas and Oklahoma. IF we lived as densely as folks do
in Manhattan, everyone can live in Yugoslavia! Weissach, Nurburgring and Le
Mans would be deep country.

(thanks to P. J. O'Rourke)

 -ken-

Date: Sat, 13 May 95 11:47:39 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: 944 Seats and Sunroofs

Hi, Charles...

First about the seats...you may have a bit of a problem about using early
style seats with the later style chassis.  You may have already noticed that
the later style seats have the seat belt receiver attached to the seat, not
to the chassis.  In the early style cars, the seat belt attaches to the
chassis. Were you to put early seats in a later car, you would have to come
up with some method of using seat belts.  Probably 5 point harness, etc.,
which may not be suitable for street driving...

I would not recommend pursuing it for that reason.

As far as replacement sunroofs go, yes, there are used sunroofs available (I
know of several that I could put my hands on in short order... I might even
have one in red... )  It is not too hard to remove the paneling, after which
you are left with about an extra inch of headroom, but, for most people,
this is a one-way road.

I have sold several sunroofs to trackies who want/need the extra room, and
have done just what you are proposing...

As far as the Saratoga roofs go, bottom line, I don't like them.  1) They
are glass, not plastic; 2) The glare from above is irritating and fatiguing;
3) They are not currently being manufactured and are difficult to locate.

Good luck, and let me know if I can be of any help to you...
- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (needs work)
1980 GMC Pickup (tow vehicle), 1986 Audi 5000 Wagon
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Previously Owned Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 11:58:07 -0400

Subject: Porsche Pilgrimage Places


Subject: Re: Porsche was Austrian


Paul F. Lyman & Phellow Philes,

   Been there, done that last October. The Porsche Museum in Gmund is worth
about 30-45 minutes visit. If you take the old route south through the
Kartschberg Pass *Rte. 99* it makes the trip more worthwhile than going thru
the tunnels (captive smog) and the long bridges on the A10 Toll Road. I do
hope you realize that there are two Gmunds in Austria! Do not go to the one
closest to Vienna in Niederosterrich Province, The correct Gmund is in
Karnten Province (Corinthia) near the border with Slovenia.
My visit to Zell am See was aborted when I tried to go over the Grossglockner
pass in my rental car and was turned back because I didn't have chains, too
much snow in October! So I can't help much there.
Doug Hendrickson
95 993 (picked up at factory in Oct 95)

wondering about what you had said about a microfiche printer; I didn't know
such things existed!

investment, it lists the Porsche part number for every important part on my
car, including the nuts and bolts!

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 12:32:02 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Car Waxing

Hey,

A couple of weeks ago Larry Reynolds posted something about
using your *fingers* to apply wax to one's car.  I basically rolled
my eyes at the time  (I rarely wax my car, let alone put alot of effort
into it).  This morning, though, I had some time to kill after changing
the oil in the wife's car and decided to give it a shot - after all, no one
was watching :>).

I couldn't believe it!!  I have *never* seen my paint look as good as it
does using my fingers to apply the wax.  It is very time consuming (I
only did the roof and it took over an hour), but the results are amazing.

I guess you get out of it what you put into it.

Thanks Larry,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911 - with 19 year-old paint that loks almost like new now...

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 12:37:58 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Re:73 911 2.4 S converted into 2.7 RS lightweight

Michael Hecken had some specific questions on the 2.7 liter Carrera RS.

The history of the RS is thoroughly covered in a very well produced (but
hyper-expensive) book entitled "Carrera RS" by Drs. Thomas Gruber and Georg
Konradsheim. The English language version is ISBN 3-9500179-1-7. This book
gives all the details, and has a listing at the end of EVERY genuine RS, with
its color, engine number, and options. 

The English language edition was translated by a friend of mine who works at
Porsche. If you are German, though, you will probably want to get it in the
original language. I don't have the German ISBN number handy but you could
contact T.A.G. Verlag GmbH, Cottagegasse 94, A-1190 Wien.

On p. 78 it says that the RS used 0.8 mm sheet metal instead of 0.88 mm sheet
for the exterior roof and door skins, front lid skin, trunk floor, door
sills, rear seat panel, upper and lower dashboard sections, front fenders and
rear side panels (fenders). 

It says the thinner metal was only necessary until the 1000 units required
for Group 3 homologation were built, after which normal production sheet metal
 was used throughout. As you might guess, there was no definite chassis
number at which the change occurred. "The last supplies of special materials
were then used up, and series-production parts used instead. The vehicles
from this transitional phase could sometimes be a strange mixture of thin and
normal sheet metal. But even before, holdups in parts deliveries sometimes
made it necessary to use series parts -- especially rear fenders -- in a few
cars. For organizational reasons, spare parts of thin sheet metal could not
be reordered."

Sheet aluminum was used only for the engine lid. There were 2 variations:
without rear spoiler, the entire rear lid was aluminum. WIth rear spoiler,
the engine lid frame was aluminum, carrying the fiberglass skin and spoiler.
"Once the homologation series was complete, the aluminum frame was replaced
by a steel one."

Also in your listing (which I haven't gone through all that carefully) I
noticed that you say front double wishbones. No, the street 911 did not have
double wishbones. Just struts, torsion bars, and a lower A-shaped arm for
location. Recently, they got away from the torsion bars and installed true
struts ("Federbeine" for you), with coil springs over the shocks, but still
use a lower A-arm.

For me, as a former Bosch (and later Porsche) engineer, the key element of
the RS is the injection pump. A true RS has a Bosch assembly number reading 0
408 126 019. Major difference is the space cam.

For those who are interested, here are the other applications:
0 408 126 001     1969 911 S 2.0 liter
                002     1969 911 E 2.0 liter
                005      1969 911 S 2.0 liter
                006      1969 911 E 2.0 liter
                009      1970-71 911 S 2.2 liter
                010      1970-71 911 E 2.2 liter
                013      1972 911 S 2.4 liter (Europe)
                014       1972 911 E 2.4 liter
                015      1972 911 T 2.4 liter
                019       1973 911 Carrera
                021       1972 911 S 2.4 liter (USA)

Pete

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 12:54:43 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Painting you Porsche

Excerpts from mail: 12-May-95 Re: Painting you Porsche by "Asad
Husain"@schmed01.a 
> The info you gave on painting was very useful.  Can you expand a bit 
> more on the color sanding and polishing.  i.e what grit sandpaper, 
> polishes/rubbing compounds to use, type of buffer/revs speed, type of 
> material used on the buffer etc.
> 

    In short... not really.  The only time i have ever done this I do
remember that I used 3M products, but without access to my garage I
can't really tell you what they were.  I also did the buffing by hand...
kind of a tradeoff, as my arms hurt for quite a while afterward, but I
didn't have to worry about burning or rubbing through the finish.... 
Several different people warned me to be careful using a power buffer to
rub out the paint, I guess you have to have the right touch... (how you
get it is a mystery to me still.)
    If you want a show quality finish, though, there is no substitute
for a color sanded/buffed finish.  Even the steadiest hand at the spray
gun cannot produce such a beautiful, perfectly flat finish.  One caveat:
 here's another place where metallics are a pain in the butt.  (i.e.
weird patterns surfacing once you sand off the top layer of paint,
etc...)  Don't get me wrong, though, the better you are at spraying, the
less paint you'll have to sand back off again.
    Can anyone help this guy?  I'd be interested in responses from
anyone who has done this, as well.

    One last thing... I realized that I forgot one of the most important
steps in my summary of my "cheap driveway paint job..."
    Please, please, whatever you do, right after finishing the bodywork
and before using athe tack rag (before spraying anything - paint or
primer) PLEASE wipe down the surface with reducer or lacquer thinner. 
Don't skimp, and don't be alarmed if it dissolves your primer a little. 
A clean surface is absolutely essential for proper paint adhesion.  In
fact, lacquer thinner is handy stuff to clean things at almost any stage
of paint prep. How could I forget something so basic... sheesh...  Um,
Bart, what do you have for me (cringing...)
    I apologize profusely if anyone ran out and followed my instructions
and got a really crappy paint job....  I really should start putting
disclaimers at the end of my posts...

later,

Nate

Disclaimer:  Just because I shoot my mouth off a lot and sound like I
know what I'm talking about does not mean that I actually do.  Please
think carefully about everything I say as I am not responsible for
anything unpleasant that might happen to you as a result of being dumb
enough to listen to me.

Date: Sat, 13 May 95 10:18:18 PDT
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE:  Turbo 16V


My understanding is that there is no point to using a 16V head with
a turbo system.  They (turbo & 16V) are different ways of getting
more "stuff" into the combustion chamber.

So rather than add all of the moving parts for the extra valves,
just up the boost a tad.

(Is my understanding wrong?)

Gary.

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 12:20:00 -0600 (CST)
From: JMB@wuchem.wustl.edu
Subject: Laser jammers

	A couple months ago Car & Driver did a test of laser detectors
and the various ways to overcome them. I can't remember the exact specifics
or when it came out But I do remember the following:
1.Laser detectors are not very useful since by the time they pick the
stuff up you are dead.
2.The diffuser licence plate covers do give you more time before the gun
will lock on thereby giving you a chance if you have a laser detector and
the guy actually hits your plate.
3.The best thing to use is very powerful halogen lamps on the front and
rear (if your dedicatet) which throw out enougH IR energy to confuse the
gun once again so your detector has a chance. There is a company which
sells lenses for the lights so that only the IR and not the visible
wavelengths pass so you don't have 150Watt halogen lamps "on" throughout
the day since if you also use them on the rear your are breaking the law,etc.
5.I have not personally tried any of this since where I live the lasers
aren't in use.
6.I haven't investigated this further but there are sources of IR energy
which are much more efficient than off-road halogen lamps and should prove
more effective if one is dedicated and $$$$.
7.The radar jammers are illegal if you don't have an FCC licence and are
probably still ellegal if you use them against police radar. I once got 
some plans to build one but the money involved in buying the klystrom was
prohibitive.
8.There is presently no law against sources of IR transmission and therefore
these people are open for countermeasures such as described above.
9.My memory is a little fuzzy about the details of the above post so don't 
flame me over the details. Get the C&D article to begin your quest for
countermeasures.

Incidentally got a ticket last week from good old fashioned radar, detector
broken, anybody have any experience at beating these things in court?

Good Luck and happy research. Jonathan

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 14:42:19 -0700 (PDT)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: Re: Car Waxing with Bare Hand

Mike,
Larry's suggestion of using your bare hand was a good one.

After doing my roof with my finger tips (and wearing out my knuckle 
joints) I found that I should use the palm of the hand instead of the 
fingers.  It allows you to use the shoulder and elbow to move the hand 
instead of using the wrist when you just use the finger tips.

I ran this by Larry and that is what he does too.  He also remarked that 
using your finger tips causes finger tip lines - where using your palm 
gives a much more consistent coverage.

For those of you who still haven't tried this - DO!.  You'll have a lot 
more control than using a rag or powered buffer; you'll feel any grit 
that may be between your hand and the paint surface so you can STOP and 
not scratch it; it doesn't take that long - you get faster at it; and it 
gives you the feeling that you are massaging your P-car - ooohh!!!

By the way - using pure Carnuba doesn't seem to cause your skin to get 
raw or dishpanish (?).

Scott
(scokelly@netcom.com)

Mike original follows:
> 
> Hey,
> 
> A couple of weeks ago Larry Reynolds posted something about
> using your *fingers* to apply wax to one's car.  I basically rolled
> my eyes at the time  (I rarely wax my car, let alone put alot of effort
> into it).  This morning, though, I had some time to kill after changing
> the oil in the wife's car and decided to give it a shot - after all, no one
> was watching :>).
> 
> I couldn't believe it!!  I have *never* seen my paint look as good as it
> does using my fingers to apply the wax.  It is very time consuming (I
> only did the roof and it took over an hour), but the results are amazing.
> 
> I guess you get out of it what you put into it.
> 
> Thanks Larry,
> 
> Mike Dayton
> '76 Euro 911 - with 19 year-old paint that loks almost like new now... 
>

Date: Sat, 13 May 95 17:05:08 cst
From: lcrisler@mail.millikin.edu
Subject: 911 elec. gremlins

          Help!

               While cruising at super-highway speed to a "Free
          Service Clinic" at a nearby P-Car dealer my '84 911 simply
          started dropping revs and power.  Finally, it died at the
          side of the Interstate (very embarrassing to have to wave at
          those cars I had passed earlier as I walked to the exit!)

               Seemed like an electrical problem so I replaced the
          battery of unknown vintage (probably '89) and everything
          seems fine.  This happened a couple of months ago after
          parking with the power antenna stuck halfway up.  Next time
          tried to start no juice, dead as a doornail.  Charged the
          battery and snipped leads to "formerly" power antenna.  No
          problems until today.

               When home, checked old battery with meter--11.85 v (3
          hours later 12.39).  New battery 12.51 (installed in car).
          Voltage stays at 12.24 when at idle, 2k, 3k, and 4k.  I am
          familiar with 6v systems from my 356 days, but don't feel
          confident testing around Motronic, etc.

               What tests can I perform to isolate any remaining
          problem--alternator, voltage regulator, etc.?  I have a
          Fluke multi-meter, but only enough knowledge of electrons to
          be dangerous.

               If this is addressed in the FAQ's I apologize, but if
          not, I seek the inestimible wisdom of my Phellow Philers.

          Larry J. Crisler
          Department of Behavioral Sciences
          Millikin University               phone:  (217) 424-6399
          Decatur, IL 62522                   fax:  (217) 424-3993

          '84 Black Targa
          '62 Roadster (mistakenly sold after 17 beautiful years!)

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 21:52:33 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: Turbo 16V

Gary Writes:

>My understanding is that there is no point to using a 16V head with
>a turbo system.  They (turbo & 16V) are different ways of getting
>more "stuff" into the combustion chamber.

>So rather than add all of the moving parts for the extra valves,
>just up the boost a tad.

>(Is my understanding wrong?)

>Gary.

Gary,

I think you are wrong. The Japanese cars commonly use 16v and Turbochargers
to achieve high horsepower engines. The Nisson 300ZX Twin Turbo, Mitsubishi
Eclipse GS Turbo and 3000 GT, and the Toyota Supra Turbo are all 4V engines
with turbochargers. They all get around 300Hp from 3 litres engines. I'm sure
Porsche could if they wanted too, but I think that they don't want too. I
agree with some earlier postings who mentioned that Porsche probably didn't
want to embarrass the flagship 911 by producing a "lesser" car with more
performance. 

I think that's why the 944 Turbo was discontinued. It easily surpassed the
performance of the 911 for the same amount of money. However, the 944 Turbo
(88 Turbo S and 89 Turbo) is now selling for about 16-20K and the 911 (88-89)
is selling for 25K, so what do I know?

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

Porschephiles #1399                         Sun May 14 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Sat, 13 May 95 23:44:41 EDT
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: females and ignition

This subject reminds me of an experience perhaps 35 years ago when
my sports car was a Berkeley.  Returning a young lady to her campus
home after a date, there was smoke from under the dashboard, the
lights went dim and the car stopped.  I got the battery lead off,
but the wiring was fried. A ignition coil (one of three) had rotated
and the hot lead grounded against the nearby sheet metal.

It took four long nights to totally rewire the car from the dashboard
forward and much longer than that to live down the reputation for
having her feet get entangled in the wiring  :-)

I've still got the Berkeley, but it's been a while since it ran.  It
was a sufficiently unusual sports car that it held off my Porsche
needs for over 25 years.  (see Porsche content !)

Rick

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 00:29:15 -0400
From: JWilli911@aol.com
Subject: Re: Gastester(schon wieder!)

Hi,

relative to the comment about using the O2 tester in the tail pipe, it's
important to point out that this will give valid results in the tail pipe if
there is no catalytic convertor ahead of the sensor.  If the engine has a
catalytic convertor, the O2 sensor should be installed ahead of the catalytic
convertor in the exhaust stream.

Just an observation.

Jim Williams
JWilli 911@aol.com

Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 21:46:19 -0700
From: dem@best.com (Dennis Mitsch)
Subject: 914 short shifter/driver's side door pockets/carpet kits


I read quite a bit about 911 short shifters in the 1994 archives.  The 
consensous
seemed to be that the factory kit was best, and that reports of "missed shifts"
were more than likely caused by track usage more than the short shifters
themselves.  The major trade off was one of increased lever pressure.

So, what about for 914's?  As I'm slowly mastering stirring the 914 and
driving reasonably quickly, I notice two things.  When going from 2nd to
1st and cornering fairly hard, my knee gets in the way of the shifter (no
harness to hold me down so I prop my leg against the center console) and 
when going from 3rd to 4th, my arm is at nearly full extension (aka the 
bus driver effect).

So, will a short shift kit help either of these?  I understand it will
not alleviate the vagueness or make the shifting more crisp.  I also have
a problem with my knee getting in the way of my knuckles on the steering wheel,
but that's fairly easy to fix with a smaller wheel.

What about the general "feel" of a short shift on a side shifter 914?
Liked it? didn't like it?  am I going to be posting a "914 short
shifter for sale, hardly used" message in a month if I buy one?

Is there a factory kit available for the 914?  Or a favorite after
market kit?

As for door pockets:

My driver's side door pocket is pretty nasty.  It's been recovered
once in the past, and it's pretty warped.  I just pulled the thing
off entirely for now.

Ideally I'd like a factory style replacement for a semi-reasonable
price ($200ish at the most).  The used pockets I saw at the
automotion swap meet didn't impress me, so whatever replacement
I choose will probably have to be new or refurbished.

However, I don't really like the driver's side pocket (too large,
makes me feel claustrophobic).  So, if there is no reasonable
factory style replacement, I wouldn't mind going with something
else.

First choice would be an arm rest like the passenger side, except
it would have to be for the driver's door.  I don't suppose the passenger
side arm rest is out of some VW and there is a driver's side available?

Other than that, I have no ideas.  The only thing to keep in mind is
that I do have 6 1/2" speakers in the door panels.  Any other
pocket alternatives?  Hell, even a pull handle that looked semi
decent would be ok.

Carpet kits:

Anyone dealt with "Original Fit"?  They advertise in Pano.  Their
914 carpet kit is significantly cheaper than Automotion/Performance
Products ($125 vs $250ish).  Just wondering if there is a major
difference among domestic knock off carpet kits.

The driver's door pocket & the carpet are the only really ratty interior 
bits I want to take care of.

Thanks much.

Dennis Mitsch (dem@best.com)
'88 944S (dirty because it keeps raining every weekend for the past month)
'74 914 Special Edition (dirty, and a primered duck pond in the trunk)

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 01:26:37 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Brake Bias

Larry,

>However, as a point of information, there are three typical ways to do so.
> If the rules allow, the best way is a dual master cylinder setup (one
>cylinder for the front, and one for the rear), with an adjustable balance
>bar.  This will allow you to "balance" the pressure to the fronts and rears,
>and it will keep that balance all the way through the braking range.

I've never quite understood this.  If you read Puhn's book on brakes, he
shows how a proportioning valve with a cut-over pressure effects an
approximation to an ideal front/rear curve with two straight lines.  A
balance-bar system gives you just one line, no?  So how come it's better
than a proportioning valve with cut-over?

Kevin

Kevin Gross

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 00:20:03 -0600
From: qmoolla@gpu3.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: 1987 944S Lack of power

I  posted a recent request for help on the same subject and received some 
very good responses from the list, for which I would like to thank you.  The 
marjority of the responses attributed the "lack of power to a slipping 
clutch", which even my mechanic thought was the cause given the observed 
symptoms.  I decided however to take the car to another Porsche mechanic for 
a second opinion before I embarked on the major and expensive work of 
replacing the clutch.  I will reiterate the symptoms and also the new 
diagnosis by the second mechanic.
(1) Car seems to run out of steam at approx 3750-4000 rpm.
(2) Especially noticeable in 1st and 2nd gears.
(3) At higher rpm's in the lower gears there is no corresponding forward 
motion (thus the slipping clutch diagnosis).

The latest checks confirm the following systems to be OK:
ignition, camshaft and cam timing, vacuum leaks, exhaust system and clutch.

The mechanic found the following exceptions:
The CO fluctuates (cycles) through the entire range, from 0.2 to 1.3.  He 
says it should be within a narrower range.  The hydrocarbons are fairly 
steady at 350-430 ppm.

The burn times on cylinders 3 and 4 are longer than the rest, 2.2 
milliseconds as compared to 1 and 2 which are at 1.7 to 1.8 milliseconds. 
(checked by spark plug voltage fluctuation)

He believes that the DME is at fault because everything else checks out.

I am hoping that the engine management gurus on the list can pinpoint the 
specific area of the DME that is acting up, or suggest further tests to 
determine where the problem might be. If the DME is in fact at fault can an 
aftermarket chip be substituted to confirm the diagnosis before the whole 
DME is replaced?  I am a firm believer in keeping everything stock but may 
be forced to use an aftermarket chip until a suitable donor DME becomes 
available.
Thanks for the bandwidth.
   
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S
qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca

Date: Sun, 14 May 95 06:15:15 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Drive Axle Bolt Removal ???

Hello, Afsar,

> What I want to know is how does one loosen the driveaxle 
> bolts. I bought this Craftsman T-40 TORX Bit socket to help me
> with this efforts but so far I have had no success. The process
> I have followed is to clean the bolt head and carefully tap the
> bit into the bolt head (for a good snug) then use the ratchet to
> turn the socket. I have tried this on three different bolts but
> every time, I apply the force to loosen the bolt I end up slipping
> the bit. 
> 
> Now, before I go and try something radical (like using a
> Vise-grip), can someone with experience, please tell me the
> correct way to accomplish this task. Haynes manual does not
> really mention any special tools.
> 

The axle bolts are not Torx bolts.  They are standard metric 12 point,
triple-square bolts.  I believe the size is 6 or 8 mm.  

May I suggest that you use your vise grips to remove one of the bolts and
take it to your local auto parts store and use it to determine which of the
sockets is the right size.


- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

Date: Fri, 12 May 95 14:22:01 -0400
From: "THOMAS R BRITTON" <britton@a1.esvax.umc.dupont.com>
Subject: RE: 951 Question


Doug,

	I'll give you a snap shot of the mechanical differences.
First, the Turbo S is based on the Turbo engine M44/51 (217hp). The 
Turbo S (M44/52) is equipped with a modified turbo, the vanes were redesigned, 
but the turbo is not "bigger". The DME control unit has different 
look-up tables for fuel and ignition maps. The knock and charge pressure 
were also modified. The Turbo S will give higher full boost over the 
entire rev range, where as the turbo's boost is slightly lower and 
reduces even more above 3,500 rpm. Turbo S exhaust valves were 
increased in diameter by 1/100th mm in the area of the valve guide for 
better running behavior at full load. Water hose/pipe and mounts were 
changed including turbo charger water pump due to reinforcements of 
the front end.
	Other than engine: Clutch 240 WTD changes in springs and 
friction liner is cemented and riveted. Front and rear shocks are 
adjustable and stiffer. The brakes are of 928-S4 type, 
larger stabilizer and torsion bars. Transmission is limited slip w/oil 
cooling and 1st and 2nd gears are hardness blasted for increased 
strength. "S" coil springs are harder and tampered for wheel 
clearance. Larger wheels 225/50 ZR16 frt, 245/45 ZR16 rear, Club Sport 
wheel rims. Also harder rubber suspension bushings.
 

Hope that's what you were looking for.

Tom Britton
88 Turbo S

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 09:52:40 -0700
From: cjk50g@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Woodward)
Subject: RE: Brake bias, long

Kevin et al,
   
>>However, as a point of information, there are three typical  ways to 
>>do so.  If the rules allow, the best way is a dual master cylinder 
>>setup (one cylinder for the front, and one for the rear), with an 
>>adjustable balance bar.  This will allow you to "balance" the 
>>pressure to the fronts and rears, and it will keep that balance all 
>>the way through the braking range.
>
>I've never quite understood this.  If you read Puhn's book on brakes, 
>he shows how a proportioning valve with a cut-over pressure effects an
>approximation to an ideal front/rear curve with two straight lines.  A
>balance-bar system gives you just one line, no?  So how come it's 
>better than a proportioning valve with cut-over?

Going out on a limb, I'd bet race cars generally don't use 
proportioning valve systems because they are inherently difficult to
manage from the driver's seat.  If there is an ideal ratio where near 
simultaneous front/rear lock-up occurs, and this is the objective, a 
driver would want to keep it once it has been found with his adjustable 
balancer.  A proportioning valve, which he has no control over, ends up
continually adjusting bias making it closer to a box of chocolates.  
This is because the bias becomes dependant upon what the proportioning 
valve does when it sees different breaking pressures (above the 
cut-over) from corner to corner. 

Jerry, who owns a 951, just did the popular proportioning valve swap
and we went over what they do.  I'm reposting the math below: 


I think numbers say it best, but basicly with either the 5/33 
or the 5/18 you have a device that maintains your existing brake
bias only to a certain point.  So, at intersections, in street
driving etc. you get a well balanced braking situation.  On the 
track, or during emergency stops however, things begin to change.
If the pressure in your brake system reaches the designated
points 18 or 33 barr as the case may be, for what some, including
myself think are litigeous reasons, Porsche doesn't want any 
consequential rear lock-up and what usually follows.  So, brake
pressure starts biasing foward as a result of these regulators.

The numbers:
	-5 is a lame way of describing the number .46 (as per the 
	 factory manual).  I guess it could be seen as a reciprocal
	 in their eyes, whatever.
	-18 or 33 are numbers describing the magnitude of pressure
	 (in barr) where the regulator begins to function.
	 
	I don't know what the exact bias on our '44s is but lets say
	for example we have 70 percent front and 30 percent rear.
	At a normal slow down which never sees a barr pressure above
	18 or 33 everything is peaches and stays 70/30.  But say your
	on a track and braking for a turn where you send 50 barr to
	your brake master cylinder before turn-in, hopefully:)......

	using the 5/18:
	Barr to the front is  50(.7)=35
	Barr to the rear is 18(.3) + *32(.3)(.46)=5.4 + 4.416=9.816
	bias ratio = 35/9.816 or 78%/22%
	
	using the 5/33:
	Barr to the front is 50(.7)=35
	Barr to the rear is 33(.3) + *17(.3)(.46)=9.9 + 2.346=12.246
	bias ratio = 35/12.246 or 74%/26%
	
	* 32=50-18			* 17=50-33


You can see from these equations how a proportioning system operates
to affect bias and how the 5/33 is a little better than the 5/18.  
Using different barr pressures in the equations will illustrate how
front bias goes up with brake pressure when we brake hard enough to
activate these valves. I don't know what barr we reach at the track, 
but I'd be curious to find out.

Hope this helps,
PS Jerry, what difference did the 5/33 make at Pocono?

Chris Woodward
944S

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 14:20:43 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Rejected postings

It seems that there's someone out there with a prudish on-line service
that censors messages by subject line.  My reply to the post "Porsches
and Sex" was marked as REJECTED by one such server.  It must have been
on the basis of the subject line, since neither the message nor my
reply had any prurient content.  "Porsches and Marriage" might
have been a better label and more to the point.

So if you get this and haven't gotten the aforementioned posts, you
might want to change companies.  And a warning to the rest of us about
provocative subject lines.  I *have* heard that Prodigy censors
postings; don't know about the others, and didn't keep the rejected
post with its trajectory.

OR... Do we have to resort to "Porsches and S*x"?  ;-)

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu
