Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 17:15:24 -0500
From: sperera@infohwy.com (Saman P Perera)
Subject: Flat nose

My heart has always been to own a flat nose 911. Unfortunately, I cannot 
afford one off the factory. Next best thing is to put one on my 87 911 Carrera.

Can anyone give me any ideas as to which ones are the best, i.e., 
manufacturer, steel over fibreglass, cost, good shops experienced in putting 
these on etc. Houston is where I live.

I'm sure that somebody on this list can help me out.

The ultimate question is , is it worth doing ?

Sam


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 19:11:04 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Flat nose

> My heart has always been to own a flat nose 911. Unfortunately, I cannot 
> afford one off the factory. Next best thing is to put one on my 87 911 Carrera.

> The ultimate question is , is it worth doing ?

Well, measured in terms of "will it get me what I've always wanted"
the answer is "maybe". If measured in pure dollars and sense, the
answer is *CLEARLY* "no".

To do this right involves using steel parts, a moderate amount of cutting
welding and fitting, then a complete ground up repaint. In Houston, there
are about three shops I'd trust this to, none can just "do it" -- it'll
take about 3-5 months, and I'd expect the end result to cost at least
$12-15k if a halfway decent job were done. Plus another $2-3k for the
wheels and tires to fill out those wider flares that you'll add as part
of the job, assuming that you really go for the 930S look.

There is no measureable increase in resale value; to get anything more than
what you'd get for a vanilla '87 911, the car would have to be essentially
*PERFECT*, low miles, and you'd have to find someone that really wanted what
you have.

If you're interested, shoot me a note and I'll pass the contact info for the
shops along. Note that with some looking you can actually find a 930S for
something in the mid-40s, and that if you take the value of your car plus
the $15-20K you'd be into it with a conversion, you *MIGHT* want to re-think
whether or not you might not want to own the real thing.

Stan

------------------------------

Picked up my latest project - a restorable '73E Targa.

but going to start fixing it up. First thing : the oil tank
leaks, mostly (hopefully all) from the bottom seam, only
when oil is hot.

Is there some way I can weld/braze/etc  the seam, or
any good sealer to use? I have a friend who is a pro welder
with all the good stuff. 

Alternatively, anyone have a '73 and up oil tank for cheap?
(Robert Z?)

Funny thing happened on the test drive : owner filled oil to
full with a cold engine. Brakes drag, warming the engine
nicely. Guess where 2 quarts of oil leaked onto? SSI
heat exchangers don't need to be oiled...

Regards, Mike Piera  '72 911S & '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 21:38:51 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 Drive Axle Bolt Removal ???

>The axle bolts are not Torx bolts.  They are standard metric 12 point,
>triple-square bolts.  I believe the size is 6 or 8 mm.  

They're 8 mm., and that's this size spec of the triple-square socket
you need.

Kevin Gross

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 23:03:58 -0400

Peter,
I did a whole lot of research trying to get individual brake parts for the
944 T/S that I race. I wanted to get new dust covers for the individual
pistons because the old ones were dry and falling apart from heat.
I had no leaks and since the pistons are stainless steel I wanted to just
replace the dust covers.
It seems ridiculous to buy 16 rebuild kits (at a horrendous expense) to just
get dust shields but this is apparently what must be done. I could get no
help from Brembo. They told me that Porsche owns the rights to the calipers
involved and therefore they couldn't sell anything to me. They can only sell
the complete kits to a Porsche dealer. End of story.
Seems like Porsche does this once in a while. Pistons and cylinders come to
mind. 
If you could be any help in this situation I am sure many of us would be very
gratefull.
Interestingly enough the dust covers have part numbers on them so it seems to
me that they should be cross referenced with other Brembo calipers. 
I have pursued this with a number of people and have gotten nowhere.

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 22:11:03 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: It's electricity, but is it snake oil?



On Sat, 13 May 1995, Scott S wrote:

> 
> Any one know anything about those gizmos that run a slight electrical charge
> throughout the body of your car in order to slow/halt the formation of rust?
> 
While this sounds suspicious, the use of anodes, or dc voltages to
minimize corosion in industry is tried and true. All you have to do
is induce a small voltage that is high enough to overcome the
galvanic reaction that forms rust. While this sounds easy, there
are corosion engineers who make a living out of it, so it also
suggests that it's not as easy as it seems.
Dave Christiano, Springfield, Missouri
1974 914/6 3.0 liter
1976 911S (for sale)
1986 930

Date: Mon, 15 May 95 01:18:08 EDT
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: Re: Gastester(schon wieder!)

I whiled away 1.5 afternoons this weekend doing the O2-sensor-as-mixture-
tester trick.  Paid $45 for generic three-wire O2 sensor, $25 for cheapest
Radio Shack DVM.  Wired so I could power the heater leads from the cigarette
lighter, and see the voltage display as I drove.

As I had read posts about the idea, I had pictured sticking the sensor into
the tailpipe (eg on a copper pipe to protect the wiring) but with sensor in
hand I realized this won't work:  pigtail end of sensor must be in outside
air for it to work.  I tapped the sensor into a pipe that is a press fit
into my tailpipe.  

Very educational to watch the display.  "Sweet spot" setting of mixture
(on 77 CIS engine) is very narrow and has nothing to do with best (ie
stoichiometric) setting at idle.  I can't imagine pulling the plugs often
enough to get it right without a tester that can go on the road.  Does this
match the experience of others -- that CIS system is rich at idle in order
to be neither rich nor lean at speed?  Or do I need to install clean plugs
and try again?

B.

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 00:05:07 -0600
From: tabel@cyberport.net (Tom Abel)
Subject: Re: painting your Porsche

This is in response to the question about rubbing out paint and is from 
experience gained while managing a Chevy garage detailing department and  
from painting my own cars.  This works well on non-metalic paints.  Metalic 
paints are a pain in the ass and is best to have 2 or 3 coats of clear over 
the metalic so you are not
sanding into metalic layer.  You had better not get drips with metalic, 
because they are a
bitch to remove, not impossible, but a bitch.

For rubbing out paint have the following materials:
3M wet or dry sandpaper 300, 400, 600 grits.
Rubbing compound
water
squeeze bottle (kechup) 
lambs wool buffing wheel
grinder or drill motor
clean rags (old t-shirts or diapers are best)
water proof sanding block  (3M makes a good one)
HAND RUBBING:  Use the compound directly out of the tin on a wet rag.  Rub in a
circular motion until the paste dries out.  Continue rubbing until a shine 
appears.  Don't
rub too long or too hard when the paste is dry, because this is when you 
tend to rub
through. If it is a new paint job and there is enough paint, you will hardly 
ever rub
through.  Older, oxidized paint jobs are much thinner and you can rub 
through them
easily.  If you do, that means you probably need a new paint job anyway.

MACHINE RUBBING:  Mix a slurry of 1/2 tsp. rubbing compound per 2 to 4 cups of
water.  The more experience you have at buffing the less water you can use.  
Be sure the
paint job is really clean and has no grit that will put scratches into it.  
Apply some of the
slurry to the paint and squirt some on the buffing wheel.  Start the wheel 
going and cut
the power.  While the wheel is still spinning (no power) touch it to the 
rubbing compound
puddle on the painted surface.  The wheel will start cutting the paint and 
form a paste. 
You can keep the power on, but it will spray all over the place until the 
paste is formed. 
When the paste forms, turn the power on and continue buffing until the paste 
starts to dry
out.  Keep it wet with the squeeze bottle.  You will see the shine appear.  
After repeating
this procedure to your satisafaction, wash the area with clean water, and 
wax it well.    If
you are really anal retentive about your paint job, there is a product made 
by 3M called
Mirror Glaze that comes in a squeeze bottle and is pink in color.  This can 
be applied
after the rubbing compound and before the wax to remove fine swirl marks 
from the
rubbing compound.  Use the wheel just like you did with the rubbing 
compound, but use
a different wheel or thoroughly clean the rubbing compound wheel.

Orange peel has to be sanded first with either 400, or 600 wet or dry paper 
depending
how bad the orange peel is.  Always finish with the 600 paper.  Holding the 
paper in a
3M rubber sanding block, sand lightly using plenty of clean water until the 
orange peel is
gone.  For compound curves, the heel of your hand is best.  Avoid using 
fingertips.   Then
proceed with the rubbing compound.

Drips can be sanded out with a block and 220 or 300 paper.  Keep the block 
parallel to
the paint surface.  When the drip is almost gone, start switching to finer 
grits.  By the
time the drip is gone, you should be using 600 grit paper.  Follow with the 
rubbing
compound.

I hope this helps.  While I don't claim to be an expert,  I do have a hand 
rubbed model A
Ford that gets plenty of compliments at meets.  I know what to do and would 
be happy to
help anyone if there are more questions.  

Tom 
Tom Abel
Abel Engineering
212 Segiah Way
Kalispell, Mt. 59901   (406) 752-7665


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1401                         Mon May 15 10:53:38 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 07:23:58 -0400
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: What's it all about, Bartie...? (fwd)

Our gratitude to Robin Hanson, for the perfect opening...

> What is this about? I have been off-line for some months, Thanx
> robin

Thanks Robin,, for this opportunity!  Below, I shall reveal all (read this to
the tune of "Alfie", "What's it all about, Bartie...?"):

You 141 payed-up Patrons and Members can delete this...

To you Old and New Porschephile-members (who are wondering
what all this talk of money for a *free* list is all about...)
Greetings!

Porschephiles has steadily grown to a membership of *OVER* 1200 members,
generating traffic of more than 68,000 messages per *day*, which is more
traffic than MCI handles!

This volume of traffic is eating a significant chunk of Stan's T-1
service.  In addition, it now requires that a machine be dedicated to
handle this traffic.  This machine is old, nearing the end of its service
life, and should be replaced.

Not to put too fine a point of this, this eats into the Listmeister's
livelihood, and, amigos, that ain't right.  We owe Stan an inestimable
debt of gratitude for freely providing this service at no cost for the
past 5.5 years.  The very least we can do to show our gratitude is to
take as much of the capital burden upon ourselves as possible.

We have established a Not-for-profit bank account with my bank in
Crofton, Maryland, to accumulate the funds, and are asking that each
member who is concerned for the survival of Porschephiles, to contribute
what they can.  I have suggest appropriate donations would be $15 for
Students, $50 for Employed people, and $100 for those who wish to be
considered Patrons.

*Nobody* has to contribute anything.  We are trying to acquire the funds
to build the infastructure to ensure the survival of Porschephiles
independent of any member.

I don't have firm figures for the costs we are facing, and that doesn't
bother me a bit. I do know that Stan has made the service available to
the group, using the capital resources that he depends upon to earn his
daily bread, and is begining to feel the strain.

So where do the suggested contribution numbers come from?  Can you say
"Rectal Data?"  It is my sense that a Student should be able to afford
$15.  If a poor starving Stoont can cough up $15, it isn't far out of
line for a Working person, who can afford both a love of Porsches and
access to the 'net, to be able to pony up $50.  If you want to do more,
then $100 seemed like a nice, tidy round number.

I don't think it's anal-retentive to recognize those who dig deeper.  I
have assured all that no one's name or contribution level will be
published *unless* they instruct me to do so.  NOBODY *HAS* TO CONTRIBUTE
ANYTHING!

I also know (I've been investigating the costs of becoming a Service
provider on the 'net, and) it's not cheap.  Last week's InfoWorld has a
comparison of two package servers, one from BBN, and the other a Sun
Netra.  We're looking at $7-10K just for the box and software.  I don't
believe that Mailing list Software was in those figures, but I do know
that they do *not* include T-1 service.  As we determine what the blivid
(5 lbs in a 3 lb bag) of stuff totals out to be, you will be advised.

So what If you don't send anything?  You're *still* a Porschephile, with
all the privilidges and rights pertaining thereto.  As long as the
service survives...

If you want to ensure the survival of this organization, and I sure as
hell do, then send what you can.  Many folks have asked what would be
appropriate to send, and I've tried to offer guidelines.

So What do you get out of this?  How about a nice shiny *Number*,
reflecting the order in which I receive your check?  Whatever
organization we form to shelter the funding under, this number will be
your membership number.  You get to be a *charter* member of whatever it
becomes.  Impress your Friends!  Be *attractive* to Members of your
favorite Gender!  Be known as a *True* Porschephile...

And, how about *Satisfaction* that you've been part of one of the *great*
happenings on the 'net?

Finally, the "membership" issue.  By 3/18/95, we must apply to the IRS
for Non-Profit Organization status. (tick...tick...tick) I'm the guy in
the barrel here.  We need to decide what kind of an organiztion we will
be.  Here, again, you can be a PORSCHEPHILE and not join any more
organizations.  Many of us would like to be the Electronic Frontier
Region of PCA, but this is not universal. Most of the Non-US folks are
not interested in affiliating with PCA, and that's no problem either.

Everyone *Can* send a donation; *NOBODY* has to!  Everybody can Join
(whatever orgainzation we decide); again, *NOBODY* has to...there is
enough interest in the EFR business that we *can* go that route if
required to keep my butt out of the [deleted] grasp of the IRS.

Finally, for you good souls who want to contribute:  The bank folks would
rather that you send the checks to me, made out to

for deposit to "Porschephiles" Acct #3933150532

My address is:

Custodian "Porschephiles" 
c/o Bart Chambers 
1270 Lavall Drive
Davidsonville, MD  21035 
(410) 721-2989

If you wish to call me, please do so prior 8:30 PM EST.

***Please send me an Email with your address, ck number and amt.*** This
will be private unless you wish to send it to 'philes yourself:

Here is the name, address and Phone number of the bank officer so anyone 
who whishes, may verify that this is on the up-and-up.

     Cathy Laster,
         re:  Porschephiles acct.# 3933150532
     NationsBank, Crofton Office
     2227 Defense Highway
     Crofton, MD  21114
     (410) 793-0770

We are, as always, grateful any and all donations.

Cheers

(yer kindly ol' Unka) Bart

Frau, Feline Varmint, '86 Indischrot Carrera Cabriolet, etc.
Custodian, Porschephiles Phund

apparent finish. Is what's coming off yours a coat of something clear?

thing to do would be to just remove the rest of what's coming off and
stick with the aluminum. That expanse of chrome would be pretty much
of an eyesore, anyway.

Subject: TechTips Opens!

As part of the second update of the Porschephiles World Wide Web Site 
(address http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html), I have included the 
following:
* Slightly updated main page design (now includes rainbow gradient on the 
clickable balls)
* New TechTips Center! Replaces the old FAQ page... This will grow as 
topics become available (the Air Conditioning one will be done tonight 
and hopefully put on-line later this week)
* New addition at the bottom of the updated pages. Send comments 
questions and such to webmaster@tta.com, and title it something 
appropriate like: HTML pages, or WWW Site, so that it doesn't get lost in 
the flurry of other mail...

Oh, BTW, I personally don't like the TechTips logo (I made it as a 
placeholder) if anyone has any good ideas (maybe a wrench forming the C 
or something) tell me about them, and we'll work something out...
 -Derek Cahill

Date: 15 May 1995 09:27:01 -0500
From: "Elliot Entin" <elliot.entin@alphatech.com>
Subject: Helmets

                       Subject:                               Time:12:32 AM
  OFFICE MEMO          Helmets                                Date:5/14/95

This is for list members in the Greater Boston area.

I am looking to borrow a helmet for the Drivers Ed. at Watkins Glen, 1-2
July'95.  If you have one I can borrow please E-mail me direct with the
particulars.

I may also be looking to purchase a helmet, where is a good place to shop? 
Again, in the Greater Boston area.

TIA
Elliot.

------------------------------

Date:          Mon, 15 May 1995 09:58:25 EDT
From: "Asad Husain" <AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd.edu>
Subject:       Re: Interested in 928 (s)

Leonard,

I went through this same dilemma just a few weeks a go.  I looked at a 
porsche 928s, 1985 which was a really fast and nice car.  I then went 
asking on this list for advice and it was suggested that I try out 
some 928's and 911's.  Both are excellent race cars and both have 
there advantages and disadvantages.  I ended up buying a 911 that was 
both older and had more miles on it.  My reasons were:

The 911 shape is so distinctive and beautiful to me that I wasn't 
going to give that up for anything.  The 928 is nice but other cars 
such as the Nissan 300ZX turbo are just as good in many respects and 
the shape is just not like a 911 -timeless and unique.

It seems that parts are more readily available for the 911, 
especially used 911 parts.

The 911 is more of a sports car than a 928 in the sense that it is 
lighter and has less comfort creatures.

I really wanted the Targa or convertible and ended up with a Targa.  
This was also a very important criteria for me.

I think I got a good deal on my 911 and I think that it will hold it's 
value or even go up.  928's in my area don't seem to hold their 
value, not because they are not good cars, but because people around 
here just don't recognize them.  

The drug dealers in Baltimore prefer luxury sedans or luxury sports 
cars with all the amenities. As such the thieves who want to mimic 
the 'dealers' tend not to bother with 911's.  A 928 would be a better 
target for them.  I'd worry about my 911 in NY, but in Baltimore, I 
feel its safer -much safer than a Mazda 323.

 
Go drive a few cars.  I did and it was worth it.

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 09:10:31 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: It's electricity, but is it snake oil?

> While this sounds suspicious, the use of anodes, or dc voltages to
> minimize corosion in industry is tried and true. 

So far, so good. The trick is this: can you do this in a CAR, which affords
a very poor true ground path? If so, why are there no studies saying so?
If not, can something be done to improve the process?

I'm saying this is an open question, not a clear case of something being
snake oil. If there's more info out there, I'd like to see it. Otherwise,
my natural skepticism rises to the surface...

BTW, most natural gas pipelines employ something similar, though the
intent is differenc (maintain potential difference low enough not to 
blow it up, basicly). So do the larger old-style copper telephone plants.
You can see the signs that say "cathodic protection point" if you look close,
particularly close to rail road crossings. Of course, the first time she 
noticed this, my wife read these as "Catholic protection point" and proceeded 
to get real excited about things... 8{)

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 15 May 95 10:19:33 EDT
From: "Jay S. Karolyi" <102062.710@compuserve.com>
Subject: '80 924 purchasing advice given

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	Nice to see more interest in 924s lately on the list, and "dabredum"
(forgot his real name) askes about what to look for on an '80 924.  There is a
bit of difference in '80 and '80.5 924s.  The later model has a better FI system
and, according to Jim Pasha who has done dyno work on them, 14 more real HP at
the rear wheels.  Look and see if it has an early or late build date (shown on
driver's door jamb).  A better way to tell, again according to Jim Pasha, is the
presence of steel tubes to the injectors, instead of the earlier more flexible
ones.  Maybe you should post a note for him to go into more detail for you.  An
early '80 would be a fine car, but like I said will have less power.
	Things to look for?  Rust wasn't really a problem on 924s, the only place
on my '77 is in the battery box located above the passenger's footwell.  It
loves to pee on people's legs on rainy days.  Brakes, especially on mine, aren't
that great.  Otherwise they (at least mine) don't seem to have many problems.
Check the FAQ also, it has a lot of info.  Prices?  Around here (Charlotte, NC)
924s go anywhere from $2000 for ratty ones up to $4000 for nice, later models.
I paid $3700 for my '77 five years ago, but its one of the nicest, well kept
924s I came across, and IMHO its better to "overpay" for a nice car than to
spend the same or more fixing up an abused one.  
	924s are really under-appreciated, mine is extremely reliable and I've
had no problems in the past two years.  I have a 914 too, and the 924 makes an
excellent companion.  Hope this helps :^)
	Jay Karolyi
'75 Corvair/914 "The Bastard"
'76 914 2.0 (part owner with brother)
'77 924 w/ NC plate "NOSBST2T"
'80 Toy 'rolla

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 09:30:51 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: R134a A/C retro/restoring leather interior

> 1.What is involved in retrofitting my A/C with the R134a substance.
> Is it expensive to do this?

The nice folks at I.C.E. (see their ads in most of the Usual Places)
have update kits for most P-cars. You gotta replace just about everything.
Different operating pressure, different thermal rate of expansion, and
best of all, it leaks through conventional old-style rubber A/C hose!

Plan on at least a kilobuck in parts unless you have a car from the
very last few years where they actually started using R134A compatible
hoses...

> 2.  My leather dash and some other parts of the interior are scuffed 
> in many places, although the dash is the worst.  Luckily it's right 
> behind the steering wheel, so it is not really visible.  The color is 
> a medium/dark blue.  Are there any kits available to 'repaint' or 
> restore small patches of leather.  

Probably, but you'll be a lot happier if you have someone that knows what
they're doing do it for you. Most high-end automotive upholstery shops
can do this in a day, for cheap.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 14 May 95 13:53:28 EDT
From: myers_h@mdso.vf.ge.com
Subject: Re: 944 durabilty issues

Hi Casey,

You asked, thusly,

> Also, I was wondering what some other 944 owners had experienced as far
> as durability.  Should I realistically expect more than 100,00 miles on the
> drivetrain?  Any interesting stories to relate.....

And since you did ask...
I got mine in Aug 1991 with 77k on it and in excellent shape. Buying it was 
sheer, blind luck.  I knew next to nothing about the car. I saw it, drove it 
once and bought it.  It has turned out to be as excellent a car as I could
have wanted. I now have 122K on it and still smile whenever I drive it! 

As with any "commitment" there are trials. I have replaced the battery (normal),
the water pump (it's second according to the original owner), the clutch, the
radiator and hoses. The radiator went one day after getting it back after
having the oil cooler replaced. Yes, replaced. Usually it's the o-rings that
go and allow water and oil to mix. Not mine. No, mine had to develop a pin-sized
hole that allowed the oil to blow out into the water and go through two quarts
in fifty miles. No harm to the bearings because no water got into the oil. Mucho 
harm to my wallet though.  The original owner said he had had the motor mounts
replaced eary on along with the water pump.

The car is my daily driver, and I confess there are times I wish it didn't have to be.
But, even though it was blessed with minimum power accessories (just pwr windows,
mirrors, and A/C) and it's a "puny" 8 valver I can't wait to get back in it every
time I drive some other brand.  Is it the best car in the world, no, but it's very
pleasing to me.

Herb Myers
83 944
Dark Red Metallic

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 10:41:51 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: It's electricity, but is it snake oil?

I picked this up late, but the problem with differential metal corrosion is
the local potential. The voltage is defined locally, say between the
exposed steel and the surrounding zinc, resulting in zinc plating onto the
exposed steel through the water on the surface. 
Applying a voltage to a steel structure (car) relative to ground, where the
process is actually oxidation sounds like bad medicine. If you immerse the
car into a plating bath, and use a yugo as an electrode...

Note that even the zinc plating trick only works on small "wounds" where
the zinc can get at the steel. I've seen badly worn porsche front ends
where the zinc couldn't save the underlyng steel. This, even though the
holes were only ~1/2".

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 09:51:56 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 wheels/suspension

> When is it necessary to replace the struts *and* the shocks, or can I get 
> away with just new shocks?  Recommendations on possible replacements?  If
> I get bilsteins for the front, will they fit in the boge struts?

The fronts have inserts which can be replaced by themselves unless the
strut housing is bent or something. I'd go with Bilsteins to match the
back. RD Enterprises has the lowest prices in the known universe. They
advertise (very small ads, BTW) in all the Usual Places. Paragon Products
in Corpus Christi is also a good source, mainly on principle. They race
914s in several differenct autox and road racing classes, and have a ton
of 914-specific parts and info available.

> Second, I am in the market for some nice looking aftermarket alloys.  What
> are your opinions on what looks nice?  I am also curious as to how much 
> tire I can stuff under the fenders with 5.5" rims.  What about the possibility
> of 6" rims?

You can run up to 8" rims. But you can't run wider than 205 series tires.
In my opinion, the absolute best setup is 15x7s, with 205/50s. Lots of
places have rims that fit, but one of the sharpest setups is the "true"
Minilites which are now available again through Brett Johnson's TPR
outfit. I have no idea how much, but I'd bet "a lot". You can get
ATS or similar for about $180 a wheel in that size several places.

> Thanks in advance. (I'd also ask about engine break-in procedures but don't
> want to get carried away!)

Make *SURE* that everything is installed correctly. Check and double check.
Fill with SAE-40 oil, pre-fill the oil filter, disconnect the coil wire,
crank for about a minute after the oil pressure light has gone out. Re-connect 
coil and start it up (you may have to screw around with lots of things at
this point 8{) ), bring it up to about 2500 RPM and let it run there for about 
half an hour. Bring idle down to about 800 RPM, adjust timing. Stop engine.
Let sit overnight. Change oil and filter (still SAE 40). Adjust valves. Check 
torque on the exposed fasteners (including head studs). Drive car for
about 30 miles, running through a wide range of RPM (accelerate from say 20 
to say 70, back all the way off the throttle, repeat, etc). DRIVE NORMALLY
otherwise. Return to home base, change oil and filter. Drive normal for 300 
miles (another 270), again being sure to run through a wide range of RPM
(please stay under 5000). Let sit overnight, change oil and filter, adjust
valves and check fastener torque. Next oil change/valve adjust is 3000
miles, then oil every 3000 and valves every 6000 after that.

And stick with SAE-40 oil. I like Valvoline, even though I no longer
have a sponsorship deal with them... *AND* do *NOT* use Fram or AC or K-Mart
or any oil filter other than the OEM filters. Mann. Mahle. Nothing else.
You can get these  at good prices from Zims, etc.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 08:06:59 -0700
From: "jim gregory" <jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: '86 944; Need some advise

Remove the tank- find some fiberglass resin and mix it up. Paint the area of
the crack with the resin, let it harden and reinstall. Worked fine on another
car I had with the same problem. Cost: $5-10.

cheers-

jim

Subject: 914 Engine Rebuild Questions

 give me advice....
 
 Details:
 Rebuilding 1975 2.0 L motor
 Installing into 1974 (used to be 1.8 L)
 
 Current Status: Engine is out, heads off, cylinders in trash, will take to FAT 
 performance for machining, hopefully this week.
 
 Questions:  What sort of machine work is suggested for this motor? Stuff I had 
 planned on was--
 
 -Machine cylinder deck on case  ($35)
 -Drill and tap oil galleys ($50)
 -crackcheck crank ($12)
 -polish crank ($20)
 -Balance crank ($20)
 -Rebuild rods ($40)
 -Balance Rods ($20)
 -Surface flywheel ($25)
 -Balance Flywheel ($15)
 -Surface Heads ($35)
 -Repair spark plug hole- one ($15)
 -Balance pistons ($25)
 -Install valve guides ($32)
 -Competition valve grind ($70)
 
 Is this sufficient / not excessive?  In the VW type I motors I pretty much 
 Align Bored every motor, but I heard this isn't usually needed in the Type IV. 
 Also, I assume I'll have to wait to see if I need a crank regrind....
 
 After looking at the engine and the previous records, I think this is the first 
 rebuild -- can I reuse the sodium-filled exhaust valves like some of the books 
 say? (If so I can save $300!)
 
 Almost done -- Stan mentioned it is good to replace the oil cooler.... Is there 
 a way to inspect the ones I have (from various cars) to find ones clean of 
 engine metal? Perhaps have them cleaned? 
 I was told that counterweighted cranks are not needed, but Stan just suggested 
 to use one -- what am I trading off with $$$ if I get a counter weighted crank?
 Finally, Stan... what is this bearing coating you mentioned a few digests ago?
 
 Many thanks to all...
 
 (BTW, engine will use FAT 440HP cam (mild FI capable cam), solid lifters and 
 euro 2.0 L pistons.)

Subject: SPEED TRAPS

Planning a trip to the Porsche Parade? Here's a site that'll warn you of
those nasty speed traps and possibly spare you a night in jail. The Speed
Trap Registry allows visitors to discover and post locations of habitual
speed traps in each state.

You might also want to check out the link to Vagabond Jim's Cop Car
Registry to learn which car profile to look out for in your rear-view
mirror. <URL:http://www.nashville.net/speedtrap/>

Date: 15 May 1995 16:24:08 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.com (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: 911 Seats

I took the plunge this weekend and bought my seventh 911
(actually one was a 912).  The 73.5 911T is just like the old
911's I remember and it really is a blast to drive.  But I digress...

The 77 seats that the prior owner installed really suck.
There's no thigh support at all, the edge of the seat sits very
low (barely rises at all), and the slippery leather keeps
sliding me forward.

I'd like to replace these.  I'm looking for pointers on where to
pick up a pair of black high-back seats, new or used, cloth,
velour, leather, vinyl, whatever.  It would be nice if they had a
little more length to the seat portion (I'm 6'2") and lateral
support is obviously a must.  I'd prefer a manual seat with an
adjustable rake (for the back portion).  Other features are not
critical.  The mounting brackets for later-911's are obviously
installed.  I don't want to spend more than $1k.

Any ideas?  I've checked the "for sale" listings in Excellence
and Pano.  No match.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 11:37:14 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 944 Drive Axle Bolt Removal ???

>The axle bolts are not Torx bolts.  They are standard metric 12 point,
>triple-square bolts.  I believe the size is 6 or 8 mm.

        *IF* they are the same as 914s and 911s, they're 8mm.  Any VW-
specialized shop should have them.  Locally, (Sunnyvale CA) Bugformance
has Snap-on ones for $20.  Same price as AutoMashin's, but higher quality.

- --DD

British Racing Green paint.

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 12:28:21 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: Re: '86 944; Need some advise

Joe Brown writes:

>As the subject line reflects I need some advise on my 1986 944.
>The windshield washer reservoir has developed a leak (I think it is
>on a seam near the bottom).  I'm not a mechanical person - though
>I try hard to be at times.  Is there a way to fix the crack without
>removing the old reservoir and inserting a new one?

As a boater, I had to fix a significant crack in my foul-water
holding tank (a.k.a. sewer tank) rather quickly and could not drain
it first - without getting significantly fined.  I used MarineTex,
its a two part epoxy and works GREAT!  You do not need to drain
anything, will even dry under water.  Just wipe the surface as
clean as you can (if you can, sand a little to get a good surface),
mix the stuff up, one last wipe and apply it.

Will dry almost instantly and after several years of use on
my 32' Bayliner, it never cracked/leaked.  Its amazing stuff, all
experienced boaters carry it on board.  Any decent local marina should
have it.  I think its $5.00US and well spent.

Dont know about taking the reservoir out/apart since I dont
have a 944 (maybe someday).  Good Luck,

Ron De Lange  '66 912
rondl@uscbu.att.com

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 10:23:31 -0700
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: Re: SPEED TRAPS and penalties

Having run the gauntlet of I-5 through Oregon for the last
26 years, I can attest to the "proactive" attitude of the
Oregon Highway Patrol. Especially around a place called
Cottage Grove. They will use an airplane and about 8-10
cars in their revenue collecting efforts. They line up
on the on ramp like taxis at an airport. It's really
quite a sight!

As for cost, a 1981 ticket for 125mph cost $230. A 1992
ticket for 65mph cost $80. 

If anyone is looking for an alternative for I-5, I HIGHLY
recommend Hiway 395 north out of Reno all the way to the
Columbia River, then west on the freeway. It's quite
incredible, especially through southern Oregon where
it's basically a desert. Or, go north on 395 from Reno,
and cut over towards Mt. Shasta. Another incredible journey.

Jim Bauman
'86 Carrera Cab
GETA911

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 95 13:47:55 EDT
From: scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com (Scott Humphreys)
Subject: RE: 944 Rattle


Todd- 

My 87 944 had the same problem (rattle under front belt shroud that
goes away after engine warms up).  It turned out to be the timing/cam 
belt slapping the shroud just below the cam sprocket(!).  The timing belt 
had been replaced about five months earlier, and it apparently 
"slackened" up.  If you take the front shroud off, you'll probably 
see a smooth dust-free spot on the inside of the shroud where the 
belt was hitting.  It didn't appear to damage the belt.

After re-tensioning the belt (the 87 has the "self-tensioner")
the problem went away.

 -Scott H.
scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com
87 944

I have to say that I am truly disgusted by the overtly sexist attitudes 
pervading this thread.  Think now:

1) Which is truly more reliable, your Porsche or your devoted S.O.? (OK, 
I'll give you this one, but only because it is a superior design)

2) From which do you consistantly derive more pleasure? (Damn, that's 
two...)

3) Which do we tend to have longer relationships with? (Uh oh.)

4) Which causes you the least grief? (Shit.  This isn't working, is it)

5) Which tends to be there when you really need it? (Well, I guess you just 
turn the key...)

6) Forget it.  I'm afraid I have to fall on the sword on this whole 
thing....

Seriously, though, isn't it rather odd that we compare the two?  My ex-wife 
had a REAL problem with my Porsche.  NEVER understood.  But she was one of 
those who just considers cars a mode of transport, you know.  My present 
S.O. on the other hand, likes P-cars, can DRIVE, and is going to Parade with 
me.  My daughter LOVES Porsches.  Pity the poor young suitor who pronounces 
the holy word as one syllable.  She will surely emasculate him on the spot.

I'd feel better of some of the female Porschephiles would relate some 
similar stories.  That way this wouldn't appear to be a Y chromosome thing. 
 You know, the KAR gene.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Mon, 15 May 95 10:38:00 PDT

Mike,

I had (sniff) an 86.5 928S with the same wheels...chromed.  They are 
absolutely gorgeous and make a BIG difference.  Caveat:  Tire mounter types 
have to be somewhat careful mounting rubber.

After 9 years, the chrome still looks great with only minor flaking where 
the tire guys biffed it.  $500 is probably an OK price.  Prepping the wheels 
is pretty important.

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 12:03:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: RE: Brake bias, long

>Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 09:52:40 -0700
>From: cjk50g@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Woodward)
>Subject: RE: Brake bias, long
>>I've never quite understood this.  If you read Puhn's book on brakes, 
>>he shows how a proportioning valve with a cut-over pressure effects an
>>approximation to an ideal front/rear curve with two straight lines.  A
>>balance-bar system gives you just one line, no?  So how come it's 
>>better than a proportioning valve with cut-over?
>
>Going out on a limb, I'd bet race cars generally don't use 
>proportioning valve systems because they are inherently difficult to
>manage from the driver's seat.  If there is an ideal ratio where near 
>simultaneous front/rear lock-up occurs, and this is the objective, a 
>driver would want to keep it once it has been found with his adjustable 
>balancer.  A proportioning valve, which he has no control over, ends up
>continually adjusting bias making it closer to a box of chocolates.  
>This is because the bias becomes dependant upon what the proportioning 
>valve does when it sees different breaking pressures (above the 
>cut-over) from corner to corner. 

Chris,

	There is a two fold purpose to having an adjustable proportioning
valve. First, to set up the car cold with an ideal balance between front
and rear brake bias. This can change on a day-to-day or track-to-track
basis. Depending on surface, tire choice, temperature etc. Secondly, is
the desire to have an easilly adjustable valve for the driver. As the car
is driven harder and the longer a race continues, the front brakes, which
are doing the majority of the work, begin to fade. As the fronts begin to
fade, the rears will have more braking authority, if the brakes have been
finely balanced, the rears will start to lock first. This, we can all agree
(I hope), is bad. So as the fronts start to fade the driver needs to re-
adjust the brake bias so as to not swap ends when they get to the braking
zone.

	For a street car, there is no need to have a driver adjustable
valve. But for a track car, that can see very hot teps on the brakes, this
can be a very handy item indeed.

	If you ever get a chance, take a look inside the cockpit of a
formula atlantic/Indy etc. There are adjustable everythings. Sway bars
front and rear can be adjusted from the cockpit, as can the brake bias.


 -Josh

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CSP
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Everything expresed here is the opinion of the idiot that wrote it, 
namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 15:21:00 -0500 (CDT)

Subject: Re: an idea...

>     I just thought of something...  everyone on this list seems to
> bemoan the exorbitant cost of the factory manuals...  why not take some
> of that money that Bart has so diligently collected and buy some manuals
> for the more popular cars on the list (914, 944, 911, for starters.) 
> THen if anyone needs specific info they pay the holder of those manuals
> to copy the appropriate pages and send them off

There's this matter Fair Use under the various copyright laws. It's not
legal, most simply put.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 15:35:55 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Big Bore Throttle Bodies

> Anyone have any information on big bore throttle bodies for the 964 engine.  
> I've seen these advertised by both Performance Products and ELP Motorsports.  
> Are there substantial gains from increasing flow in this way??  Thanks in 
> advance for any feedback.

You gotta do something *FIRST* that makes it *NEED* more air. Otherwise,
you slow down the air velocity and low-speed performance just sucks...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 15:47:18 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Engine Rebuild Questions

>  Current Status: Engine is out, heads off, cylinders in trash, will take to FAT 
>  performance for machining, hopefully this week.

Good choice. FAT actually understands this stuff.

>  -Machine cylinder deck on case  ($35)
>  -Drill and tap oil galleys ($50)
>  -crackcheck crank ($12)
>  -polish crank ($20)
>  -Balance crank ($20)

All of the "balance" stuff should be together. You balance *ALL* of the 
rotating parts, including the clutch pressure plate. Some you also balance
staticly, like the rods, pistons, wrist pins, etc.

>  -Rebuild rods ($40)

Be *DAMN* careful on this -- do NOT let them "resize" the big ends. If the
big end is out of round, then find another good used rod instead. Re-bushing
the little end is fine, though.

>  -Balance Rods ($20)
>  -Surface flywheel ($25)
>  -Balance Flywheel ($15)
>  -Surface Heads ($35)

I'd also add CC heads, and ...

>  -Repair spark plug hole- one ($15)

Actually, I'd send that to H.G. Bieker. Doing it right is more expensive that
$15, particularly if it's cracked. Rush service for fixing three cracks, 
surfacing the sealing surface and lower flat surface, and cc'ing the heads
was about $150.

>  -Balance pistons ($25)
>  -Install valve guides ($32)
>  -Competition valve grind ($70)

Have Bieker do this, and NOT a competition valve grind, but a "venturi
valve job". He'll know what it is.

>  Is this sufficient / not excessive?  In the VW type I motors I pretty much 
>  Align Bored every motor, but I heard this isn't usually needed in the Type IV. 
>  Also, I assume I'll have to wait to see if I need a crank regrind....

You should NEVER bore a Type IV. If its' that bad, toss it. You *CAN* find
0.020 over bearings, rarely, but it's hard.

And yes on the crank. It should be checked for straightness and cracks. Either
being a problem and it's toast. There's a guy in Houston that can grind new
2.0 cranks from 1.7/1.8 cranks, and counterweight,and balance them, all for
under $200 should it come to that.

>  After looking at the engine and the previous records, I think this is the first 
>  rebuild -- can I reuse the sodium-filled exhaust valves like some of the books 
>  say? (If so I can save $300!)

MAYBE. In the Spec Book there is a tolerance for neck wear. I personally
would not bet my new engine on being able to re-use the valves. I just about
always replace the valves if I'm pretty sure that they're original.

>  Almost done -- Stan mentioned it is good to replace the oil cooler.... Is there 
>  a way to inspect the ones I have (from various cars) to find ones clean of 
>  engine metal? Perhaps have them cleaned? 

I guess you could use an endoscope if you can find someone what wants to
do that.... You can hook it up to something that pushes a high grade of
solvent through it under 60 PSI or so for a couple of hours. I mean, there
are all sorts of things you *COULD* do, but none are as cost effective as
just replacing it.

>  I was told that counterweighted cranks are not needed, but Stan just suggested 
>  to use one -- what am I trading off with $$$ if I get a counter weighted crank?
>  Finally, Stan... what is this bearing coating you mentioned a few digests ago?

Counterweighted cranks put less stress on the case at higher RPMs. They're
NOT really needed. But they do help if you flog the engine pretty hard.
The coating is PolyDyne, and it's from Polymer Dynamics in Houston, TX.
A full set of main bearings is like $40 to coat, mains, rods and cams is
like $75. It's a high-pressure Teflon coating, applied properly AT THE
RIGHT TEMP, so you do actually get some benefit from it, unlike say Slick50...

Stan

Date: 15 May 1995 14:55:32 -0800
From: Steve Poole <stevep@wrq.com>
Subject: Re(2): SPEED TRAPS and penalties

>As for cost, a 1981 ticket for 125mph cost $230. A 1992
>ticket for 65mph cost $80. 

These figures are wildly out of date -- even the 1992. I drive between
Seattle and Newberg (south of Portland) fairly often and am now pretty
careful in Oregon because they recently DOUBLED the price of tickets! I
haven't had one, so can't say what the exact amounts are, but I believe that
20 or 30 mph over the I-5 limit can now cost you several hundred dollars.

I-205 around Portland seems to be pretty heavily patrolled, and there are
numerous sweet spots for speed traps, especially for those of us who like
high speed sweeping curves. I've been nailed in that situation.

Washington ticket prices are doubled if the ticket is issued in a work zone.
Oregon does something similar, but I don't know if it's 2x exactly.

Just returned yesterday from my first Seattle->Newberg->Seattle run in the
911. Great weather both ways, and it was a blast! My favorite moment was
being passed on a slight downhill by some rattly Honda boltbucket. I was
doing about 90 when this thing came roaring past on my left. About 7 seconds
later the BEL shrieked twice and I hit the brakes hard to drop to about 65.
At almost exactly the same time, a Washington patrol car came smoking off the
left shoulder just ahead of me, where it had been hiding behind some bridge
struts. I thought he was going to nab me, but he accelerated like a bat out
of hell and the next time I saw him was on the right shoulder where he was
looking with extreme displeasure at a certain Honda driver. Wahoo!

Steve
1979 911SC

Well, a couple of hours ago another 914 bit the dust (not mine,
thankfully!!!).  Last I heard, the engine was on fire and it was
spreading to the passenger compartment and the fire dept was on
the way.  The culprit was probably old fuel lines.

If you don't know when your fuel lines were changed last, change
them NOW!!!

Please don't wait....

Allan

Date: Mon, 15 May 95 16:11:39 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Gauge question

Ok, I need a sanity check.  First, you can't put a traditional fuel pressure
gauge in the cockpit because there is fuel going to it.  So, you need to isolate
the gauge from the fuel with use of a sender.  

Now here's the question:  Is it acceptable to use an oil pressure gauge and 
sender (with the proper fittings, of course) for a fuel pressure gauge that
is isolated from the fuel?  I've got a spare guage (oil pressure gauges cover
the correct pressure for the injected cars) but I hesitate to actually use
this arrangement.

Any comments?

Thanks,
Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com

Austria.

If memory serves, the Porsche Family Estate is in Zell Am Se in Austria not
far from Salzberg.  Also in Zell Am Se or very near by are, I believe, one or
two hotels, owned by the Porsche family.  These were covered in Excellence
magazine a couple of years ago but I don't recall the exact date(s) of
publication; maybe some pphiles out there know.

In Gemund (check the map carefully as there are several Gemunds-this one is
near Spittal, in Austria), I believe there is a landmark marking the orginal
site of the first cars manufactured under the Porsche name.

Also in Austria, I think I remember, is a small musuem owned by Otto Mathe
where one can see the famous Rome-Berlin VW and a couple other early Gemund
coupes.  I can't remember where this is, however.

The above details are not exactly right and fine tuning is requested.

Date: Mon, 15 May 95 17:09:53 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: 911 Hot Brakes

Hi Folks -

I just completed a track weekend at Laguna Seca and for the first time
ever was troubled by overheating brakes on my 911SC.  This was 
disappointing, since I overhauled the brakes a month ago in preparation
for this event.  The overhaul included new pads (Textar asbestos free),
rotors (Zimmermann), caliper seals (ATE), fluid (Castrol LMA), and
a bed-in period (several hundred miles).  Things were initially fine at
the track but about halfway thru each half-hour run I'd begin to get
pedal pulsations and steering wheel shimmy under braking, which would
steadily worsen until the end of the session.  After each cooldown lap,
and today on the way to work, the pulsations were gone and the brakes
were back to normal.  As far as I could tell I didn't have any brake
fade at any time, and only very minor pedal mushiness after the car was
parked between sessions.  

Seems to me like my rotors are warping when hot.  No big suprise... but
most 911 people I've talked to have had their brakes go mushy or fade
before their rotors have warped.  I'm curious what experience other 911
track junkies here have had.  How do YOU know when your brakes are cooking?
What have you done about it?  Some of you may remember my post last
month asking about the aftermarket Zimmermann rotors; I guess you can
consider this post to be a partial answer to those questions.  Or in
other words, I kind of wish I'd paid the 20% more the dealer was asking
for rotors with the little Porsche sticker over the "Zimmermann"...

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC
 

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 19:33:13 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Full-Flow Oil Filter on 914

        One of the mods I am considering making to my 914 motor (now
in the shop) is installing a full-flow oil filter.  To those of you
who have done that:
        How did you put it on the car?  Did you use the spin-on one
or the remote one?  Where on the car did it go?  Where did you put
the intake and outlet in the oil circuit?
        I am considering using a spin-on unit in the stock location.
This will require disabling the pressure relief piston inside the
filter-mounting flange.  IS THIS A BAD IDEA?  The filter is supposed
to be able to handle the pressure of cold oil--can the seal between
the filter and the flange?  Can the flange itself?
        Another option would be tapping the inlet and outlet holes in
the case (where the flange mounts to) and intalling AN-whatever fit-
tings to use a remote filter.  On an engine without external cooler,
does anyone have suggestions as to where to put the filter?  "Up front"
is not a good idea at the moment--I don't want to run the lines that
far until I've got a cooler.  And that won't be for a while.

- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov




------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 19:40:12 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: one last question...

>   I was planning on replacing all the vacuum hoses for my 914 ('71
>1.7)  [...]
>  I have a nasty suspicion that the decel. valve on my car has been
>removed, but I would still like to run the hoses to it in the proper
>locations, so if I can find on I can reinstall it.

        I don't know if the 71's had them.  If it's there, it should
be located down by the manifold pressure sensor below the battery.
Two hoses (one large, one small) would run from the plenum (where the
throttle goes into) and one would run from the air cleaner.

>  Also, who's the cheapest source for vacuum hoses?  I'm not
>looking for pre-cut anythihng or anything fancy here, just something to
>get the job done...

        Astoundingly enough, Auto Atlanta seems to have decent deals, even
on their pre-cut stuff.  Plus, you get a diagram of where which goes...  I
tried buying by-the-foot from two local suppliers (Economy Imports and
Kohlweiss--they've got more-or-less the right hoses) and wound up with about
$50 of hoses that way, too...

>    Finally, the manual shows a lot of connections on the air cleaner
>that just aren't there.  What's the deal?  Could some PO have switched
>the air cleaner for a bug unit?

        They swiped the diagram from the VW 411 manual.  The key of the
diagram probably has notations like: "(not used)"...  At least, the factory
one does, and most of Haynes seems to be a photocopy of the factory book.

- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov




------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 17:48:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: Mujahid Mahmood <mmmahmood@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: 944 temp 


hi there,

	i just had my water pump, thermostat, timing belt, etc done by an 
independent shop that i've been quite happy with.  my problem is that my 
temp gauge now climbs to the middle line (83 944) and stays there during 
normal highway driving.  in stop and go traffic it will rise to the 3/4 
mark, fans turn on, drops to 1/2, fans turn off.  before the water pump 
replacement, the guage would only climb to the 1/4 mark (or lower) during 
highway driving.  i just asked the mechanic about this and he said that 
the 944 engines like to run at the 1/2 mark and that my previous thermostat 
was probably opening too soon or was just staying open.  any advice?

thanks in advance,

mujahid mahmood

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 21:02:24 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Gauge question

> Now here's the question:  Is it acceptable to use an oil pressure gauge and 
> sender (with the proper fittings, of course) for a fuel pressure gauge that
> is isolated from the fuel?  I've got a spare guage (oil pressure gauges cover
> the correct pressure for the injected cars) but I hesitate to actually use
> this arrangement.

I find knowing instantaneous fuel pressure to be about as useful as knowing
instantaneous ambient temperature. That is, not at all.

For a car with carbs, I can see *POSSIBLY* having a mechanical
gauge mounted in the engine compartment as it  may prove
instructive in debugging some idle and off-idle problems, but
full time? If you are on the high side of the pressure regulator, 
you should see whatever the dialed-in pressure is. If you ever
see it below that, you'll know it. No gas, no go.

For a car with EFI, (you did say 914, right?) the 1.7 and 2.0 should
be rock stead at about 35 PSI, and the 1.8 will be all over the damn
place from about 30 to about 70. Again, not instructive.

Why are you doing this? Why not do something at least marginally useful
like dual head temp sensors or exhaust gas temp sensor or even Lambda?

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 21:16:41 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Full-Flow Oil Filter on 914

>         One of the mods I am considering making to my 914 motor (now
> in the shop) is installing a full-flow oil filter. 

You *HAVE* a full-flow oil filter. For counter point, see your average
VW Beetle which as NOT oil filter or 356/912 which has but a lowly
bypass oil filter.

I'll assume that you are talking about something like the Canton/Meca
unit, or the System One, or Oberg or some such that's a high-flow
fine filtration unit instead of your usually medium-flow with a built
in bypass unit that just spins onto the car...

>         How did you put it on the car?  Did you use the spin-on one
> or the remote one?  Where on the car did it go?  Where did you put
> the intake and outlet in the oil circuit?

Well, as has been discussed, I put mine up front along with the
Accusump, the oil cooler, the fuel pump and the HG41 fuel filter.
Using a regular spin-on adapter.

>         I am considering using a spin-on unit in the stock location.
> This will require disabling the pressure relief piston inside the
> filter-mounting flange.  IS THIS A BAD IDEA?  

Why exactly will this require disabling the pressure releive piston?
And yes, doing so is a VERY bad idea. I'd be really interested in knowing
who is going around giving advice like that so I can add them to The List.
(Yes. "that" List...)

> The filter is supposed
> to be able to handle the pressure of cold oil--can the seal between
> the filter and the flange?  Can the flange itself?

I've never had a problem. What I *HAVE* had a problem with is wrong
oil line. The ugly black 'murikan "oil line" that you get a Pep Boys
is only rated for 100 PSI and 200 degrees. That's *NOT* what you need
for an air cooled engine with a Melling oil pump. You need this blue
fabric covered stuff from Aeroquip that's *ONLY* about $1.50 a foot
but is rated to over 200 PSI and I think either 350 or 400 degrees.
See the archives from summer '93 for details as that's when I had the
catastrophic oil line failure and had to figure it out...

>         Another option would be tapping the inlet and outlet holes in
> the case (where the flange mounts to) and intalling AN-whatever fit-
> tings to use a remote filter.  

No. Don't do that. Please.  You have no idea what you'd get into with
that... Went down that road as part of a "gee, I guess we'll through
THIS case away" attempt at a different kind of dry sump setup...

Just use the spin-on adapter. You can hang the oil filter just about
anyplace you can run a line to -- you can even use a remote filter mount
adapter, and get a spin-on canister filter (System One and C/M both have
one). If space is a big deal, consider the Oberg, as it's also a 5 micron
filter but takes up less space that your average 5-pack of floppy disks.

Under the car, in the passenger side wheel well, whereever. I know of
at least one 914 with a 2 quart Accusump and a C/M filter hung in the
wheelwell, under the assumption that no one would see it there...

Again, use either high-temp rubber hose, and good Wurth hose clamps on
the barbed fittings, or better, use "made-up" fittings (see the Yellow 
Pages under "Hydraulic Fittings and Hoses"), or best, use the AQ
steel braided stuff. Of course, if you fuck up making the fittings for
that, you'd have been as well off using soda straws...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 22:31:33 -0400
From: dsnover@ns.fast.net (Darryl Snover)
Subject: supercharging 924 (Dave J Andruczyk)

Dave,  The supercharger you have obtained came off a G-60 Corrado, so named
because of the way the supercharger is designed.  It is a pretty neat
little unit, and would probably work very well, if your engine is built to
take it.  However, the A/C intercooler would probably not work to much
benefit, as even fantastic A/C units produce more heat than cool.  It takes
horsepower to run the compressor, so the added drag from the compressor
would kill any real advantage you obtained from added boost or timing.

Best regards,

Darryl Snover



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 20:32:06 -0600
From: qmoolla@gpu3.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: 944 leaky windshield reservoir

I had to do this on a 1984 944 and found that I had to remove the reservoir 
because the leak was from an inaccessible part of the reservoir.  You first 
have to remove the large fender mount sheet steel screws at the hood/fender 
gutter and I believe two more fasteners from below.  I also found that I had 
to have the lights up and the car jacked up on that side, in order to remove 
the reservoir from below.  There is not enough clearance below the car to 
wiggle it out. I cleaned the area of the leak and used nothing more 
sophisticated than clear silicone bathtub sealant. It was almost invisible 
on the plastic and  lasted 3 years at least (I sold the car so I dont know 
if it held longer). 
   
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S
qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 23:56:34 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: '86 944; Need some advise

Joe,

There are plastic welding tools sold, for example, by Eastwood.  You have
to match the bottle's material and use the right stick.  The tool is real
pricey, and perhaps your best option would be to use a shop which owns one.

If it were my bottle (had I a bottle...), I'd trash it and buy a good used
one from George B. at 944 Ecology.

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 23:57:48 -0400

>Are there substantial gains from increasing flow in this way??  Thanks in 
>advance for any feedback.

the vendors.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 00:05:00 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Gauge question

Pat,

We've never been able to get a straight answer from VDO on whether the oil
pressure transducers are OK for fuel.

What we put in the race car is a gauge which has, I guess you'd call it, a 
transducer or isolator.  You run a fuel line (like -3) to the isolator, which
is really just a diaphragm which translates the fuel pressure to anti-freeze
pressure.  The "out" line is filled with anti-freeze and runs to the gauge
in the cockpit.

I think the part is from Autometer.  It comes with some really crappy plastic
lines plus compression fittings for the isolator-to-cockpit run.  We replaced
them with -3 Aeroquip and a couple of NPT-to-AN adapters.  You have to
air-bleed the coolant side, which is a pain.  But once installed the set-up 
works very well.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1404                         Tue May 16 02:00:09 CDT 1995

You just need to properly air-bleed the coolant system.

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 22:23:27 -0400
From: byee@tiac.net (Brian K Yee)
Subject: Thanks all for the 911 info!!!

Wow!

I sent out one letter asking if an early 1980s 911 was right for me, and
got over 20+ responses.

Thanks everyone!!!!!!!!!(in case I missed thanking anyone individually!)

I thought that gettting some feedback would make my life easier, instead it
made my life harder. I was hoping that everyone would say - "no problem,
buy a used early 80s 911 and have fun." Instead I got in-depth responses
explaining "Here's what I like/love about the 911, here's what I
dislike/hate about it." "Here's what to watch out for, here's what to look
for."

After reading all the mail I am not going to get one, YET!!! It was not
quite right for my needs and situation (money/use/location). I will as soon
as I have a few more dollars coming in so that I can afford the regular
maintance a 911 requires.

If anyone would like a handmade digest which has all the responses to my
original email (included below), please let me know, and I will email it to
you. It is chock full of great info.

Thanks again everyone, I'll keep on the mail list, so that when I can
afford a porsche, I'll be an expert!!

 - Brian

and I know that my motorcycle fully restored is marketable at roughly my costs

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 00:40:33 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: "931" 4-valve, again

Hi Dave,

Well now you've done it.  Made me dig through the old Pano's.  I've never
seen, let alone touched, a 924GTR engine, so I sure as heck didn't know
what they had.

In the 9/81 Pano, there's a "Le Mans 1981" article which mentions a
prototype "924 GTP Le Mans... powered by a newly developed 410 DIN hp
2.5 liter turbo engine with 4-valve cylinder head."  So there you go;
I had never even heard of a 924 GTP.

Apparently the engine was based on the soon-to-be-released 944.  Nice
to finally find a racing pedigree for my humble 944S!

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 00:43:13 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 84 944 cooling question

That means 1 bar (14.7 psi).  The later cars used 1.5 bar reservoir caps.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 00:57:23 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 1987 944S Lack of power

Qassim,

If you suspect the DME, you should be able to test its operation by
looking at the injector pulses with an oscilloscope, and the spark
plug signals with a Sun analyser.

I've never heard of "burn time."  Are you measuring spark duration?
It really isn't an issue, esp. at the durations you quote.  CD ignitions
runs much shorter pulses and work OK.

When you measure the CO, are you testing pre-cat and open loop?

Have you monitored fuel rail pressure, esp. at the higher RPM's where
the car's power drops?  Replaced the fuel filter?

If the clutch is slipping, you can feel it and here it.  The engine note
and RPM's are per the higher RPM it is turning, but you sense the drop off
in speed or acceleration.

What service, if any, did you have done to the car in the time leading
up to your problem?  Clutch replaced?  Have you checked the speed and
reference mark sender for gap?  Checked its signal with a 'scope?

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 00:58:47 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 911 Hot Brakes

Ed,

>From your symptoms, you are getting material transfer from your pads
to your rotors.  The best solution is to add a rotor cooling kit.  There
are a number of sources of them for the 911's.

Kevin Gross

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 08:22:37 -0600 (CST)
From: HENSLEY@uwplatt.edu
Subject: 968 Turbo S

The June 1993 Christophorus has some interesting information about the
968 Turbo.

	Engine:
		305 HP at 5400 RPM
		Four cylinder in line
		2990 cc displacement
		Two valves per cylinder

	Performance:
		0 to 100 km/hr	5.0 s
		0 to 200 km/hr 16.4 s
		Top Speed:  280 km/hr or 174 mi/hr

Number of cars is said to have been 100 or less.

Harvey Hensley
University of Wisconsin-Platteville
E-MAIL:	hensley@uwplatt.edu
PHONE:	608-342-1657
FAX:	608-342-1566
CAR: 	PORSCHE 964

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 09:23:14 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: "Notchy" shifting, transaxle oil?

Dear Transaxle Gurus:

I am experiencing notchy shifting in my 89 944 Turbo. This only occurs when
the car is hot, ie after I have been driving for more than 15 minutes. Second
gear is the worst, and it is really only bad when I try to take it out of
second. The other gears are OK, but more effort is required to shift the trans
mission after the car is hot, as opposed to when the car is just warm.

I plan on changing the transaxle fluid, as the car has 45K miles, and it has
not been changed since 30K. Should this solve the problem? I plan on using
"Sweptco" fluid. Is this OK, or are there better things to use? Do I need an
additive because the transaxle is a limited slip (last car I owned with
limited slip required it)? I drive the car on (at least I plan to) the track
about 4-6 times per year, so I need a fluid than can stand up to track
driving.

Thanks
Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

Subject: Restored 914 2.0 for sale

I have a 1971 914 2.0 that has been restored and needs a
good home.  The two year $9000 project includes:

Engine
cc 2098
Bore 97mm
Stroke 71mm
Cam  Norris 282 degree  Competition Engineering
Valves  Intake 44mm, exhaust 35mm (Volvo)
Pistons  Arias competition big bore
Cargs  Twin Weber 40idf K&N
Crank  Counter balanced  Competition Engineering

The crank, case, combustion chambers, valves, rocker arms
are all polished, exhaust and intake ported, entire engine
balanced.

Sideshift transmission has been rebuilt with all new
bearings and seals and external oil cooler modifications.
1969 911s clutch assemply.

Fuel system consists of Holley high performace fuel pump and 
regulator with all -6 Earl's pressure fittings and stainless 
braided hoses located in front trunk.  Also has rear vapor
lock modifications.

The body has the Weltmeister chassis reingforcement kit and 
the sway bar mounts.  Tan interior, British Racing Green
paint.  Comes with Fuch polished 2.0 wheels new tires, extra 
set of Pedreni's spare parts etc.

Car has 50 hours after restoration on it.  This is a very
streetable car, and perfect club racer.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 09:52:44 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Re: 1987 944S lack of power

> Hi  Bruce & Jeffrey!
> Thanks for taking the time to reply.  My mechanic said that he took off the 
> exhaust system from the cat on - i.e. cat & muffler, and drove the car with 
> no difference in performance.

Bet that was loud


>   My own careful observations of the tach while in first and second show 
> that the rpms.  climb rapidly to 4000 in first to yield approx. 20 mph. and 
> 4500 in second to yield approx. 40 mph. Further input on the gas does make 
> the car go a little faster but not by much.

Are you taking it to 4000rpm and stomping it or slowly applying throttle?
If you are slowly applying throttle, I don't believe it's the clutch.  
Otherwise I believe the clutch is a possible diagnosis. 

Is this something
that came on all of a sudden or over time.  If it is over time, I believe
it could be the clutch.  

Did you check the intake system for possible 
blockages?  Maybe the airflow meter is getting hung up or the throttle is
not opening all the way?  

If it was the clutch, it seems to me that the 
motor would spin up real quick and the car would not follow.  From what you 
describe I can't really tell.  I don't know why the clutch would fail to slip
at a low rpm and not at a high rpm.  That engine makes a fair amount of torque
at 2500 rpm which is what causes the clutch to slip if you are applying full
throttle.  If it was the clutch, it seems to me that the slipping would start
where the torque curve had a large slope.  As I remember, that engine's torque
curve starts to flatten out at 2500 or 3000 rpm.

Are you noticing any coolant around the clutch housing?  Maybe
you have a real slow leak in the heater control valve which would drip 
coolant on the clutch, just enough to cause 
slippage.  But this is not consistent with it being better when cold and 
getting worse when hot(just throwing out ideas).

My gut is telling me that the problem is related to not enough air/fuel 
running through the motor.  


Jeffrey
jpuzas@astro.ge.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 06:50:28 -0700
From: "jim gregory" <jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: 911 Hot Brakes

sounds to me like your rotors are warping (getting too hot). can happen before
brake fade (hard brake pads). try installing a cool bake kit with air ducts to
blow air on the rotors. Or learn to carry your momentum and use the brakes less
(that's a quicker technique anyway).

cheers-

jim

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 10:10:42 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: "Notchy" shifting, transaxel

Barry,
Redline makes a transaxel fluid with friction modifiers added for limited slip
differentials.  The way it was explained to me is the friction modifiers
are necessary for proper operation of the the limited slip device.  Other 
transaxels use thier NS or "non slip" version.  I don't know anything about
Swepco.

Jeff Puzas
Jpuzas@astro.ge.com
.



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 95 10:11:30 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 84 944 cooling question

> 
> Can anyone tell me the pressure rating of the cooling system
> in an 84 944 in psi?  I have a pressure tester with a gauge that
> indicates psi and I want to use it to find a coolant leak. 
> The instruction manual for the pressure tester mentions several 
> "standard" pressure ratings, and it says that you shouldn't ever 
> exceed the rating marked on the cap.  The cap is marked with a 
> "100" (which I guess is some sort of metric rating) but I have
> no idea how to convert this over to psi.
> 

On early 944 cars (1983-1985/1) the 100 indicates 14 psi (1.00 bar). On
later cars, the cap should say 150, which indicates 21 psi (1.50 bar).
- --
Good luck,

>fine filtration unit instead of your usually medium-flow with a built

You see, that logically stems from the idea that "full-flow" means "all
the time"...  And as to Who, wellllll....  Um, I guess that's just my
own twisted imagination.  (That's why I ask The List [No, the "other"
List"] when I get ideas.  Sometimes they're totally backwards...)

to take their engine out, and that there was a "better" (somehow) way
when you had gone through the trouble...

stock filter goes, and hopefully isn't much longer or fatter.  I should
be getting the C/M catalog soon, so I can see what the difference is.

know if the remote filter is better than the spin-on version?

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 08:16:20 -0700
From: "Volney Spalding" <vol@espresso.corp.sgi.com>
Subject: Oregon Speed traps

pfiles,

Oregon is highly proactive in their revenue collection activities as
has been mentioned here:  Aircraft, radar, unmarked cars, etc.  Do
be carefull.

OTOH, Southern Oregon between Roseburg and Grant's Pass (~100-150 miles)
has some truly great driving on I-5 in low traffic conditions:  There is
a series of minor "mountain" passes around 1000-1500' ft.... ABout 4 or 5
of them.  Makes for some great winding uphill runs.  There are always two
lanes and if there are not too many big rigs, rv's and country squire wagons
on the road, it can be a wild ride.

For a serious excursion not-for-the-weak-of-stomach, take 199 between
Grant's Pass and Crescent City.  It's one of the connectors between I-5
and the coast highway (101).  Serious mountains.  Very remote.

If you take 101 and follow the coast (highly recommended on week days
for light traffic) do be carefull as it is not an interstate and is 55
the whole way :^(    The scenery is *intense* from the California border
to Port Orford.....

I have made these runs many times.  If anyone is interested in route
consultation, send me a line.

Vol

- -- 

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 11:33:43 -0400
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: 914-6 & Turbo Valve Covers

Dan

Rather than machining or grinding up a perfectly good set of new turbo valve
covers, see if you can find a set of the late 2.7 (77) or early (78-79) SC
covers.  They were aluminum like the turbo covers, but did not have the
ribbing, ergo, no more clearance problems than a set of original magnesium
covers and no lower valve cover leaks.  They don,t grow on trees, but perhaps
if you have a friend with a car sporting a set of these covers you can wangle
a trade.

Good Luck,

Pat Moyle
pm9146@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 11:44:58 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porsche was Austrian

For someone who enjoys driving in any form, a visit to Austria is well
worthwhile.  You will truly learn what is meant by the old saying, "The best
cars in the world are built within sight of the Alps".

Zell am See has Porsche Design, a beautiful lake, and magnificent mountains
to the south.  It's a resort town, so be prepared to search for a hotel room
(mostly pricey) unless you make prior reservations.  You may have better luck
if you try nearby Bruck, where there is a very nice, much-less-expensive
hotel on the main street overlooking the river.

Gmund is an OBLIGATORY stop for Porschephiles, even if you're too young to
remember that real Carreras have four cylinders.

You might also want to visit Zeltweg (southwest of Leoben) and the
Osterreichring: last time I was there, you could buy laps at a very
reasonable rate.  I spent a pleasant hour or so chasing Alfasuds (practicing
for an upcoming race on the weekend) in my rental Golf.  There's also a nice
small hotel on the hill overlooking the back-straight, with balconies
commanding a view of the entire track and the valley below.

Austria is a beautiful country, certainly one of the most scenic in Europe,
with very friendly people.  It was also interesting on my first visit there
many years ago to find they speak German with a southern accent, much the
same way that we speak English in our own South.

Bob Joyce
Knoxville, Tennessee
1965 356SC
1988 924S

>Date: Mon, 15 May 95 11:18:00 PDT

>Subject: Re: Porsche and Sex


I have to say that I am truly disgusted by the overtly sexist attitudes 
pervading this thread.  Think now:

1) Which is truly more reliable, your Porsche or your devoted S.O.? (OK, 
I'll give you this one, but only because it is a superior design)

2) From which do you consistantly derive more pleasure? (Damn, that's 
two...)

3) Which do we tend to have longer relationships with? (Uh oh.)

4) Which causes you the least grief? (Shit.  This isn't working, is it)

5) Which tends to be there when you really need it? (Well, I guess you just 
turn the key...)

6) Forget it.  I'm afraid I have to fall on the sword on this whole 
thing....

Seriously, though, isn't it rather odd that we compare the two?  My ex-wife 
had a REAL problem with my Porsche.  NEVER understood.  But she was one of 
those who just considers cars a mode of transport, you know.  My present 
S.O. on the other hand, likes P-cars, can DRIVE, and is going to Parade with 
me.  My daughter LOVES Porsches.  Pity the poor young suitor who pronounces 
the holy word as one syllable.  She will surely emasculate him on the spot.

I'd feel better of some of the female Porschephiles would relate some 
similar stories.  That way this wouldn't appear to be a Y chromosome thing. 
 You know, the KAR gene.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

To add a bit of X chromosome flavour to this thread, I'd like to make mention
that there are a lot of women out there like Bob's S.O. who like Porsches, can
drive and have gone or would like to go to a track event.  

I've always had a love for cars especially the Porsche 911, and am now the
proud owner of a 1987 911 Targa.  Most guys I meet are just as enthusiastic
about the car as I am.  Some guys I meet pronounce Porsche as one syllable,
but those also seem to be the same guys that ask why I would spend my money on
a Porsche when I could buy better things with my money... (like what?)

Andrea Pearson
apearson@newbridge.com
