Date:         Tue, 16 May 95 11:59:07 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      RE: 944 Rattle

On Mon, 15 May 95 13:47:55 EDT you said:
>
>Todd-
>
>My 87 944 had the same problem (rattle under front belt shroud that
>goes away after engine warms up).  It turned out to be the timing/cam
>belt slapping the shroud just below the cam sprocket(!).  The timing belt
>had been replaced about five months earlier, and it apparently
>"slackened" up.  If you take the front shroud off, you'll probably
>see a smooth dust-free spot on the inside of the shroud where the
>belt was hitting.  It didn't appear to damage the belt.
>
>After re-tensioning the belt (the 87 has the "self-tensioner")
>the problem went away.
>
>-Scott H.
>scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com
>87 944
>
>

Same problem here, except mine was the balance belt slapping the
housing.

Darren
'87 944S Indischrot

My hinges are ok, but last month my leather pad cracked in several
places. I gave treatments of 303 Protectant prior to the cracking
but not often enough. The rest of the dash is ok. I attribute the
cracking to my resting my arm on it. Maybe something in my skin
attacks leather.  If yours hasn't started cracking yet, you might
want to treat it often with the product of your choice (not Armor-All).

Darren

Date: Tue, 16 May 95 10:34:06 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Gauge Question

> From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
> 
> Now here's the question:  Is it acceptable to use an oil pressure gauge and 
> sender (with the proper fittings, of course) for a fuel pressure gauge that
> is isolated from the fuel?  
>

I've been running an oil pressure sender in the Control Pressure circuit
of my CIS injection since, um, early '89, and have had no problems with
it yet.  It reads out on the dash oil pressure gauge when selected by
a switch.  Oil and gas seemed of similar enough origins that I didn't think
about the materials compatibility issue for too long before I did this.
The sender's dead volume and compliance didn't have any noticeable
effect on the CIS operation.

Don't know what your application is, see Stan's comments regarding
usefulness (NOT) of fuel pressure readout in some applications.  On my
CIS car it was fairly useful in getting the warmup regulator set up
and shimmed for proper operation... since then I've hardly used it,
except for that one time that it confirmed I'd been dumb enough to run
out of gas...

Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 13:46:00 -0400
From: DH993@aol.com
Subject: Re: Turbo Valve Covers on 914/6

I went through the same exercise about two years ago. The covers were
machined evenly across the entire surface, rather than to a template just
where the interference problem exists. The remaining material, approximately
3/16" webs, is more than enough to prevent the warping and the subsequent
leakage like the original magnesium covers. For those that don't understand
the problem - if the turbo-type exhaust valve covers are not machined you
can't remove same to adjust the valves with the engine in the car!
Doug Hendrickson
Still the original owner of '71 914/6 #0389. (Very late) 

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 10:42:12 -0700
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: 356 Campagnolo wheels

     
     To all knowledgeable 356 types
     
     This question was found on the Italian car interest group
     
     ""I have a question regarding the history of a set of Campagnolo 
     magnesium wheels that were on a 1964 
     Porsche 356SC that I purchased a couple of years ago.  The car was 
     delivered in Ravenna then spotted at 
     the airport in Bari in 1970.  It was then purchased by an 
     Italian/American who imported it and drove it 
     until 1991.  The story is that the campy wheels were put on the car 
     when it was new.  They look very 
     similar to a wheel that was used on an Alfa GTV lightweight, but with 
     a five bolt pattern rather than four.  
     The lug nuts are engraved "C"
     
     Does anyone have any idea what the history of these wheels are?  Any 
     help would be greatly appreciated.""
     
     TIA
     
     Dan Swiger
     
     dswiger@qntm.com

now.

third party arranged coupling? An ol' fashioned shot gun type"Get Together"?
Or, was  it your choice to be with this person? Did you only "discover" they
are not into Porsches, Mustangs, Corvettes, or any other Sports minded
automobile, after you got "involved". 


Hmm...that's what I thought.  Maybe, just maybe, the hormonal direction
finder was tuned to a different station. You turned on classical when you
really wanted jazz! 


Now, there are a bunch of us jazzy little ol' ladies on this list. And 
I'll bet many of them grew up as a "Tom-Boy", like I did.  I wanted to play
with the same toys the boys did, only they didn't want me to. Even today
gentlemen, Yes even today, there is a stigma given to a woman who wants to
play with  the boys toys! 


Hmm... the moral of this little speech! Don't stigmatize the lady who is a
little classical and a lot of jazz.  Oh, and darlin',  grab those hormones
(not too hard now) and twist them to the right station. You'll be a lot
happier that way!

So fellas, the P-Car and the S.O. do go hand in hand. They are both jazzy,
sexy, have a superior design, pleasurable, last a long time, dole out grief
and are there when you need them!

Unka Bart, Can I have some of the little pink ones please??

Date: Tue, 16 May 95 13:29:18 CDT
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: WD40 shouldn't be used in wet locations

I have read somewhere that WD40 is hydroscopic (it likes to absorb moisture).
If so, WD40 can be used to losen up corroded parts, but should not be used as a
lubricant in wet locations, sexual or otherwise. 

What is a good marine lubricant? (nastiest environment, wet and salty)
In the past I have used lithium grease on locks near water. I have also used 
bicycle-chain lube. Any better ideas?

To the impatient: I don't need artificial lubricants in my bedroom ;-)


Theo
Theodosios Korakianitis
ourios@zeus.wustl.edu

Date:          Tue, 16 May 1995 14:51:50 EDT
From: "Asad Husain" <AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd.edu>
Subject:       Re: Help w/changing master cylinder

>  
> I am thinking of attempting to change my brake master in my 78 911SC.  Is this 
> something that the hobbyist should try or should I leave it to the 
> professionals?  Does anyone know of where to get good information on doing 
> this?  Any help is appreciated.  Thanks in advance. 

Never done it on a porsche, but will be doing it this Friday.  I 
changed the M/C on my old 1984 BMW 318i the first and last time.  It 
was very easy to do.  Too easy.  The only hard part for me was makimg 
sure I got all the air out of the M/C before I put it in the car and 
then bleeding the brakes with a helper.  That actually was the hard 
part.  We had to pump the pedal and then tighten the bleeder valve 40 
times on each of the rear brakes before we got the pedals hard.  At 
first we thought we really messed up but we did it in the end.

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 14:37:45 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Full-Flow Oil Filter on 914

> I thought that the one with the bypass wasn't full-flow...

Well, it's full flow most of the time... unless it's full or something...

>         I had figured that the adaptor was for people who weren't going
> to take their engine out, and that there was a "better" (somehow) way
> when you had gone through the trouble...

Nope. Not until you're ready for a full Dry Sump system. Ocam's Razor
and all that...

>         Okay, now I'm leaning to C/M's spin-on type.  It'll go where the
> stock filter goes, and hopefully isn't much longer or fatter.  I should
> be getting the C/M catalog soon, so I can see what the difference is.
> Other than (probably) being larger with more filter element area, do you
> know if the remote filter is better than the spin-on version?

You can get the remote with a special top plate that makes hooking up
an Accusump a snap. Not available on the screw-on version. You might
also have clearance problems with the spin-on version. You would for
sure with the System One spin on...

Stan

Date: 15 May 1995 20:49:46 GMT

Dear P'philes:
     There have been a couple threads, most recently Jerry et al's query
about Bremo brake parts. In other circumstances in the past, parts not
available in the US of A *were* available in Europe. For instance, when 914s
first came out, Porsche sent rear caliper rebuild kits in the dealer parts
stock. About three months later (I think) they recalled all these kits. The
Service Reps mumbled something about 'product liability' with improperly
rebuilt calipers. I'm pretty sure that Porsche GB offered rebuilt A-arms for
the 911s with non-replacable bushings. Is it possible that P'philes in Europe
could check out the part numbers at their end? I can't believe that the Royal
Mail (for instance) would charge more than $4.00 Air Post to get a rebuilt
kit (if available) to the US. 

Regards,

Date: Tue, 16 May 95 15:16:15 CDT
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Faster cornering by no skidding?

Here is the quick question:
We have concluded that with ABS we can stop faster BECAUSE ABS PREVENTS
SKIDDING. Some also keep talking about going faster around a corner BY SLIDING
THE CAR AROUND. Is there an inconsistency here? Would we corner faster by
obtaining the maximum centripetal (opposite to centrifugal) acceleration by 
being AT THE VERGE of sliding sideways, instead of actually sliding?

1. Fact: The maximum coefficient of static friction (just before it slides) 
is greater than the dynamic coefficient of friction (while it slides). 
Note that in dynamic friction the microscopic surface irregularities result in 
some material being scraped off. But what if there is A LOT of material scraped
off? (Like when locking the brakes and flat-spotting the tires?)
Things being NON LINEAR, one must do the individual tests to derive
further conclusions.

2. Some conclude: Therefore maximum braking is obtained just before the tires
lock. By extrapolation we also  ASSUME that ABS permit the driver to slam the
brakes, the computers do the  of/off thing at several cycles per second (kHz)
at the limit of static friction, and thus one obtains maximum braking. Locking
them is not as good, despite the extra material scraped off in the
flat-spotting action. I agree, but only because of item 3 below.

3. Experiment: People on the list have indicated that experienced drivers
driving  non ABS cars were not able to stop as fast as inexperienced drivers
stomping on their ABS. Ok, I will accept this experimental evidence. Maximum
friction from the tires is NOT WHEN SLIDING AND SCRAPING MATERIAL OFF in the
slide, it is obtained at the limit of static friction. At least with usual road
materials on usual tires. If I search hard I may find unusual tire/road
material combinations for which the opposite is true, but given where I buy
tires and where I drive, non-skid braking is the fastest. 

4. The more the centrifugal g (a measure of centripetal acceleration in
cornering) the faster the car will go around the bend. It's the basics of
circular motion.  So, if the car was a particle, it would go faster around the
corner by obtaining the maximum centripetal acceleration, ie at the limit of
sliding sideways, but without sliding. 

5. But the car is not a particle; at the cornering limit a 911 has 3 wheels on
the ground (front inside is up).  If the rear is sliding out (oversteer), all
four wheels are on the ground. So why do people imply that they will go around
the corner faster by sliding the rear end out? Why, because it will  turn the
car in the desired direction of travel, of course. But hey, if the rear is
sliding, then one can put less power on the SKIDDING rear wheels than if they
were at the verge of static friction (same logic as in items 1,2,3 above). Less
power  because of less friction between the wheels and the road means slower!

Differences may appear depending on: front vs. rear wheel drive; 2WD vs. 4WD;
limited slip differentials etc. So let's limit the discussion to 78-83 911 SCs 
and 84-89 Carreras, strictly rear wheel drives, heavy at the back, without 
limited slip differentials. What's the net wisdom? Fastest cornering by being: 
a) at the verge of sliding; or b) actually sliding? 
IF THE LATTER, WHY THE APPARENT DISCREPANCY WITH BRAKING?
What am I missing here?

If I am not satisfied with your answers I will instrument my '87 911 and
promptly go for some "experiments" in our parking lot. Do you think that the
Dept. of Transportation, or any other organization, may fund this "experimental
research project"? And can you imagine the face of the chief of campus police
when my assistants rope off the parking lot and I strap on the helmet?
This summer looks promising already!

Theo
Theodosios Korakianitis
ourios@zeus.wustl.edu

Date: Tue, 16 May 95 14:20:47 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: Painting your Porsche


One tip you might want to add to Lee Atkinson's and
Nate's excellent advice about painting, is to read
about how it's done.  There are a few very good books
on auto painting.  Look in the automobile section of
your local bookstore.  I can't recall the exact titles,
but they're the kind published in the 8 1/2 x 11
paper format.  HP is one publisher I remember.  They
have a lot of info about various 'systems' and contain
all the little things you'll keep forgetting the first
time around, like which grits to use for what, etc.

The bottom line is that it's really not that hard to get
a nice finish.  As they say, it doesn't take a rocket
scientist.  It just takes care and patience.

 -Bob Spindel

Date: Tue, 16 May 95 14:28:35 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: June 3rd and 4th Driving Event


I have been informed by the Norcal Region of the Shelby-American club 
that there are openings in the event for June 3 and 4 at Thunderhill 
Raceway. This is near Willows, California, about 2.5 hours north of 
San Francisco off I-5

The event is open to all makes and model cars with the exception of
open-wheeled cars. All convertibles and open cars MUST have roll bars, 
no exceptions.

The real good aspect of these events are the humongous track time 
that each participant gets. 

The fee is $150 per day (about 3.5 hrs of track time), you can go for 
just one day.

To get an application, call (408) 374-1298. After gaining access, punch
"34" to put your request in for an application. You can also have 
the technical info sent while in "34".

No open exhausts, but we are allowed 103dB. 

Updates through the Norcal SAAC hotline: (408) 374-1298 x"33"

There are room blocked at the Golden Pheasant Inn in Willows, for 
those people wanting to stay over.

The Norcal SAAC group puts on very nice, safe events. If you wnat 
something lower key than PCA, but would like instruction, there are 
some good instructors available that also know Porsches.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 95 14:39:15 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 temp

Mujahid asks a question very similar to one I asked a couple of weeks ago:
} From: Mujahid Mahmood  <mmmahmood@ucdavis.edu>
}
} 	i just had my water pump, thermostat, timing belt, etc done by an
} independent shop that i've been quite happy with.  my problem is that my
} temp gauge now climbs to the middle line (83 944) and stays there during
} normal highway driving.  in stop and go traffic it will rise to the 3/4
} mark, fans turn on, drops to 1/2, fans turn off.  before the water pump
} replacement, the guage would only climb to the 1/4 mark (or lower) during
} highway driving.  i just asked the mechanic about this and he said that
} the 944 engines like to run at the 1/2 mark and that my previous thermostat
} was probably opening too soon or was just staying open.  any advice?

Both questions have gotten a range of replies from "it's broken" to "it's
normal."

Kevin suggests it may be a trapped-air problem, to which I have a
question below.

However, I want to throw out something that I have been thinking about.
Could the temperature difference be due to a different concentration of
anti-freeze before and after the repairs? I know that my car probably
had very little anti-freeze before the system flush. It was refilled with a
50-50 mix of Autobahn (genuine Por$che) anti-freeze and distilled
water (plus some RedLine water wetter). Now doesn't anti-freeze
not conduct heat as well as pure water? Couldn't a higher
concentration of anti-freeze make the car run hotter than otherwise?

The somewhat higher operating temperatures don't seem to be a
problem for my car which has recently included some drivers' ed
events at relatively high speeds. I have been thinking about draining
some of the coolant and replacing with just water to bring it
closer to a 1/3-2/3 anti-freeze to water ratio (since it doesn't get that
cold here in Seattle) to improve the cooling.

Now to the cooling system bleeding question: can it be done with the
engine cold or do you have to wait until the thermostat opens? I did
the latter and it was difficult to tell when the air had been bled since
there was so much steam and splattering. BTW, hot anti-freeze sure
makes a mess of your engine; stains the intake manifold and the
cam tower. Good thing I thought to cover the fenders to protect
the paint.

Thanks again to all of the listmembers who contribute suggestions/
anecdotes!

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red
    ericb@microsoft.com



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 95 17:46:40 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Faster cornering by no skidding?

> Here is the quick question:
> We have concluded that with ABS we can stop faster BECAUSE ABS PREVENTS
> SKIDDING. Some also keep talking about going faster around a corner BY SLIDING
> THE CAR AROUND. Is there an inconsistency here? Would we corner faster by
> obtaining the maximum centripetal (opposite to centrifugal) acceleration by 
> being AT THE VERGE of sliding sideways, instead of actually sliding?
> 
> 1. Fact: The maximum coefficient of static friction (just before it slides) 
> is greater than the dynamic coefficient of friction (while it slides). 

Theo, this is your problem right here.
This is a "fact" only for very simple
frictional interactions, and the tire/asphalt
interaction is far from simple.

As it happens, the static coefficient of friction
for tires on asphalt is lower than the coefficient
at about 5% slip, and depending on the tire compound
and construction and the surface, can go on increasing
to about 15% slip for serious race tires on grippy stuff.

Under braking, if you lock up the tires, they are now
at 100% slip, and the effective coefficient of friction
is lots less than even the static value. ABS helps by
keeping the wheels from locking up. A really good driver
on dry consistent pavement can out-perform ABS by keeping
the slip rate right at the optimal value - ABS doesn't
even try to do this, it just eases off the brake whenever
lockup starts to occur.

> Note that in dynamic friction the microscopic surface irregularities result in
> some material being scraped off. 

You hit the nail right on the thumb here.
The reason that the effective coefficient
of friction goes up as the tire starts to
slip is that the material being scraped off
is initially quite firmly connected to the tire -
scraping it off requires work, which requires
force - more force than you get when there is
no slip at all. Once the slip rate passes
the optimal value, there isn't enough material
getting scraped off to compensate for the more
intense dynamic effects that are the dominant
factor in the "simple case" - in short, the
road irregularities are not in contact with
a given bit of rubber long enough to rip it
loose, at least not often enough to increase
the force sufficiently.

> But what if there is A LOT of material scraped
> off? (Like when locking the brakes and flat-spotting the tires?)
> Things being NON LINEAR, one must do the individual tests to derive
> further conclusions.

Well, it would be a mistake to think that
I can tell you how hard you can corner while
sitting here in front of the computer. But
I can tell you how to find out - get on track!
Run the corners - inch up on it. If your butt
is insensitive, get a G-analyst and use it.
But you'll most likely be able to tell where
the "edge" is - go just a bit past it, and
the traction falls off very quickly.

> 3. Experiment: People on the list have indicated that experienced drivers
> driving  non ABS cars were not able to stop as fast as inexperienced drivers
> stomping on their ABS.

In the wet, under changeable conditions. Real test drivers on dry,
consistent pavement can do so, but they have to try very hard.
In race driving, the ABS is better because you don't have to
concentrate so hard - you can think more about your tactical
and strategic situation instead of having to worry about squeezing
that last 2% out of the brakes. Or maybe 1% - it really isn't much
of a margin.

> 4. The more the centrifugal g (a measure of centripetal acceleration in
> cornering) the faster the car will go around the bend. It's the basics of
> circular motion.  So, if the car was a particle, it would go faster around the
> corner by obtaining the maximum centripetal acceleration, ie at the limit of
> sliding sideways, but without sliding. 

This is just nonsense. If the car was a particle, it wouldn't matter if it
was sliding or not - the centripetal acceleration would be omega^2 * r, 
exactly. So what? In fact, the slip rate has to be non-zero to get the
best cornering force.

> 5. But the car is not a particle; at the cornering limit a 911 has 3 wheels on
> the ground (front inside is up).  If the rear is sliding out (oversteer), all
> four wheels are on the ground. So why do people imply that they will go around
> the corner faster by sliding the rear end out? Why, because it will  turn the
> car in the desired direction of travel, of course. 

No, that effect is not related. You want the slip rate (ratio of side slip to
forward travel, or tangent of slip angle) to be the optimal value for you
tire and the surface you are on. Use of rotation to position the car for
the upcoming track features is an entirely different subject.

> But hey, if the rear is
> sliding, then one can put less power on the SKIDDING rear wheels than if they
> were at the verge of static friction (same logic as in items 1,2,3 above). 

You are confusing sliding, slipping, and skidding. They are different.

> Less
> power  because of less friction between the wheels and the road means slower!

This is another problem - you are taking a fairly simple picture and
making it even more complicated. There are two possible sources of slip:
the tire isn't going quite the direction it's pointed, and the wheel isn't
turning quite at the speed of the car. These two sources of slip sum up,
and the (vector) sum has to be at the optimal value. So if you want
to apply more power, you have to give up some cornering force. But your
total traction didn't change, just how you are trying to use it.

By the way, T*D had some interesting theories about this same subject...


> a) at the verge of sliding; or b) actually sliding? 

Neither - maximal turning force occurs at the optimal slip rate.

> IF THE LATTER, WHY THE APPARENT DISCREPANCY WITH BRAKING?

There isn't any. Maximal braking force also occurs at the optimal
slip rate. And maximal acceleration force occurs at the optimal
slip rate.

> If I am not satisfied with your answers I will instrument my '87 911 and
> promptly go for some "experiments" in our parking lot. 

Use a race track. Get some track time under your belt. That's what you
really need to learn this stuff, and besides it's about the most fun
you can have with your pants on.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 14:47:35 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Faster cornering by no skidding?

ourios@zeus.wustl.edu wrote:

>Here is the quick question:
>We have concluded that with ABS we can stop faster BECAUSE ABS PREVENTS
>SKIDDING. Some also keep talking about going faster around a corner BY SLIDING
>THE CAR AROUND. Is there an inconsistency here? Would we corner faster by
>obtaining the maximum centripetal (opposite to centrifugal) acceleration by
>being AT THE VERGE of sliding sideways, instead of actually sliding?
>
>1. Fact: The maximum coefficient of static friction (just before it slides)
>is greater than the dynamic coefficient of friction (while it slides).
>Note that in dynamic friction the microscopic surface irregularities result in
>some material being scraped off. But what if there is A LOT of material
>scraped off? (Like when locking the brakes and flat-spotting the tires?)
>Things being NON LINEAR, one must do the individual tests to derive
>further conclusions.

Actually, tires provide their best traction with a slight amount of slip.
In turn this would mean a slight slip angle. When breaking this would mean
the wheel is turning and the tire is slipping slightly. When accelerating
this would mean the tire is slightly slipping but not spinning faster than
the car is actually moving.

>2. Some conclude: Therefore maximum braking is obtained just before the tires
>lock. By extrapolation we also  ASSUME that ABS permit the driver to slam the
>brakes, the computers do the  of/off thing at several cycles per second (kHz)
>at the limit of static friction, and thus one obtains maximum braking. Locking
>them is not as good, despite the extra material scraped off in the
>flat-spotting action. I agree, but only because of item 3 below.

No. Maximum breaking is reached when there is some slippage with the wheel
still rotating.

>3. Experiment: People on the list have indicated that experienced drivers
>driving  non ABS cars were not able to stop as fast as inexperienced drivers
>stomping on their ABS. Ok, I will accept this experimental evidence. Maximum
>friction from the tires is NOT WHEN SLIDING AND SCRAPING MATERIAL OFF in the
>slide, it is obtained at the limit of static friction. At least with usual
>road materials on usual tires. If I search hard I may find unusual tire/road
>material combinations for which the opposite is true, but given where I buy
>tires and where I drive, non-skid braking is the fastest.

This may be true in some tests. The advantage of ABS is that you do not have
to worry about locking up your brakes so you can just stand on them. A great
driver that knows his car and brakes well should be able to stop faster than
the same car with ABS.

>4. The more the centrifugal g (a measure of centripetal acceleration in
>cornering) the faster the car will go around the bend. It's the basics of
>circular motion.  So, if the car was a particle, it would go faster around the
>corner by obtaining the maximum centripetal acceleration, ie at the limit of
>sliding sideways, but without sliding.

Again, this is not true. When in a turn, tires provide their best traction
with a slight amount of slip angle.

>5. But the car is not a particle; at the cornering limit a 911 has 3 wheels on
>the ground (front inside is up).  If the rear is sliding out (oversteer), all
>four wheels are on the ground. So why do people imply that they will go around
>the corner faster by sliding the rear end out? Why, because it will  turn the
>car in the desired direction of travel, of course. But hey, if the rear is
>sliding, then one can put less power on the SKIDDING rear wheels than if they
>were at the verge of static friction (same logic as in items 1,2,3 above).
>Less power because of less friction between the wheels and the road means
>slower!

A properly balanced 911 will have all four tires on the ground when at the
"cornering limit". A 911 that lifts the inside front tire in a turn is too
roll stiff in the front. Of course, the inside front tire will be lightly
load as compared to the outside front tire. Again, when in a turn, tires
provide their best traction with a slight amount of slip angle.

However, this does not mean that you want the back end of you 911 hanging
out with a major slip angle. This may look spectacular, but it is not very
fast. The lift throttle oversteer characteristic can be very good for
getting around tight turns but don't confuse this with power on oversteer.

>Differences may appear depending on: front vs. rear wheel drive; 2WD vs. 4WD;
>limited slip differentials etc. So let's limit the discussion to 78-83 911 SCs
>and 84-89 Carreras, strictly rear wheel drives, heavy at the back, without
>limited slip differentials. What's the net wisdom? Fastest cornering by being:
>a) at the verge of sliding; or b) actually sliding?
>IF THE LATTER, WHY THE APPARENT DISCREPANCY WITH BRAKING?
>What am I missing here?
>
>If I am not satisfied with your answers I will instrument my '87 911 and
>promptly go for some "experiments" in our parking lot. Do you think that the
>Dept. of Transportation, or any other organization, may fund this "experimental
>research project"? And can you imagine the face of the chief of campus police
>when my assistants rope off the parking lot and I strap on the helmet?
>This summer looks promising already!

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 17:55:27 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Painting your Porsche

On Tue, 16 May 1995, Bob Spindel wrote:

> a nice finish.  As they say, it doesn't take a rocket
> scientist.  It just takes care and patience.
I'm not sure if this was said or not, but one of the things I do, before 
embarking on any paint mission is to hang a Coke can from a useful tree 
nearby (if you don't have one, help the earth and yourself by planting 
one, or for these purposes, spear the can and stake it into the ground) 
and paint it all the way, primer on up... this is a good way to practice 
the most difficult part (curves) and masking, etc. It will also give you 
a good idea of what the color is... you don't want something that is too 
different from your mind's view... Plus, if you get it wrong... go get ya 
another one, take a break, think about what went wrong, and when you're 
done, try it again... by the time you get all practiced up, you should be 
ready... (oh, for the added realism, if for any reason you've used bondo, 
put a small amount on the can and see how the paint looks on bondo vs. 
metal... some are slightly (and unsightly) different.
 -Derek Cahill

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 15:03:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Thomas B. Smith" <toms@comtch.iea.com>
Subject: 915 transmissions

Porchephiles-
This last weekend fellow Porschephile Bill Simer and I had the pleasure 
of replacing the input shaft seal in a early style (06) 915 transmission. 
According to the manual one has to almost completely dissassemble the 
transmission to do this.  (not one of the good Doctor's best designs, as
evidenced by it's correction in later models)  After the successful 
(so-far) completion of this task, I have a couple of questions.

1.) Has anyone ever tried forcibly removing the throwout bearing support
tube, in order to replace the seal without such a radical dissassembly of
the transmission. Yes it will come out, and no you probably don't want to 
know the details.

2.) Since the location of the raised area on the input shaft where the seal
rides, and the area in the tube that has a slightly lesser diameter than 
the rest of the tube and where the seal is held do not match very well, I 
was wondering if the seal is different in the earlier transmissions.  
When I put the seal in the necked down area of the tube, both lips of the
seal did not properly contact the raised area of the shaft,  this lead to 
pretty blue $40.00 per gallon puddles under the car.  If this last 
statement leads your mind to form questions, please don't ask them.  If 
anyone has a parts catalog, would you please let me know if perhaps the
915/06 /15 uses a different seal than does a 915/08 /12 or /63.  Since 
we  had the gasket & seal kit listed for 915 transmissions in general, we 
do not know  if there might be a slight difference in seal outside diameter
on the 915/06.

3.) I may be confused as to what year and type number the 915 transmission 
was changed so that the input shaft seal could be changed from the 
bellhousing side by using tool number P 386.  Can anyone shed any light
on this, the manual is not too clear, it just says units 915/02 /08 /12
are of this type.  Not that it would make much difference, since we
did not have a "P 386".

Disclaimer:  We know for certain that this transmission has been opened 
before, since some parts, mainly the fifth speed gearset have been  
replaced.  So it may be some sort of mix and match situation.

If anyone really wants to know the grizzly details of this whole debacle
I would be happy to tell you the finer points that I have omitted here.
Suffice it to say for now that I am a lot more familiar with Porsche  
transmissions than I intended to be.  Oh well, it was sort of fun, and 
as my wife says, it keeps me out of the bars.

Thanks in advance
Tom Smith  <toms@comtch.iea.com>

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 18:20:32 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@Symtec.com>
Subject: Re: 944 CD Player Replacement

> After 8 years of faithful service, my stock blaupunkt Reno cassette deck 
> has croaked. It would be silly to replace it with another cassette deck, 
> since CD units are relatively cheap.
> 
> My question: does anyone know of a place that sells Blaupunkt CD players 
> that fit right into the console, no muss, no fuss, that are cheap? (an 
> outdated model would be fine; perhaps some place has overstocked them)

I purchased one of the Blaupunkt Monterey units from Crutchfield about 18
months ago for my 951. You tell Crutchfield what kind of car it's going
into and they'll include a wiring pigtale and the tool to get the old Reno
(mine had one too) out. Total swap time was 30 minutes. Fits like it was
made for it. Solid performance and great styling. Excellent customer service.
I have seen this same unit for sale in the back of Car&Driver and Autoweek.

Standard disclaimer applies. Shop where you want. Buy what you want.

Doug Donsbach - dld@symtec.com - Knoxville, TN

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 17:49:04 -0600 (MDT)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Slip Angles/Max G Loads

The current thread on tire slip angles is very interesting.  Let me add 2 
cents worth, and ask a question about ABS related thereto.

Some time ago BFG published a chart showing the maximum lateral load 
generated by their R1s as slip angle increases.  The R1 at that time was 
the 206 series (this was about '91 if memory serves).  At any rate, the 
maximum lateral force was available at about 12% slip angle, but was very 
near the maximum levels beginning around 8%.  After about 13% or so, the 
lateral force dropped dramatically.  This is what we all feel as the car 
"comes around".  

So the idea is to stay in the "fat" part of the slip angle, but not go 
past that optimum limit.  Some tires give a tell-tale slight loss of g's 
as you go over the peak before the big drop in g's that represent an all 
out slide.  This is what you'll hear referred to as a "forgiving" tire.  
Some don't telegragh this so well, and are referred to as "peaky".

The following explanation refers to autocrossing speeds; I'm not 
qualified to talk about higher speeds and could only guess about what you 
feel in a 100 mph corner--I haven't done then enough to be calm at those 
speeds yet!  ;-)

Typically you hit the max slip angle with one end or the other, that is, 
either you approach it by pushing the front, or by slipping the rear.  
I liken the difference to "carving" versus "pitching".  

Carving is best when you can run flat out (or nearly so) through a turn,
and is characterized by increasing loads on the front causing slight
understeer at the limit.  In this scenario, the car is generally making an
ever larger arc, due to the ever increasing speed.  Picture a skier
carving a turn with minimal slip. 

If a turn can't be negotiated full-on, then some pitching is often the
best approach.  On some cars, (most Porsches, by my experience), you can
begin a rotation with drop power oversteer.  This rotation "snaps"  the
car up the the maximum slip angle (and maximum g load) very quickly, much
more quickly than carving your way up.  This also serves to "point"  the
car down the next straight.  "Catch the slide" by applying power, and you
find yourself rocketing towards the next turn.  The trade offs are speed
and risk.  Speed: remember, you got there by lifting (and sometimes
braking simultaneously) so obviously you've slowed down.  Couple that with
the effects of "scrub" and you can see that this only works when you need
to slow down for the turn anyway.  Risk: if you go too far, you can lose
serious time or even spin.  Picture a skier doing "step turns", sliding 
the rear or his skis around to point him in his new direction.

My wife and I often identify an autocross course by a series of 
"pitches".  We consider that since a carve is simply trying to negotiate 
the turn as smoothly as possible, and usually at full throttle, there's 
not much to remember there.  But the turns that require a "pitch" are the 
ones that determine the winner since they are harder to execute well.

Either carving or pitching can produce maximum g's, at least in theory. 
(Yes, I know, I'm ignoring the possibility of using all four tires equally
well...) Which is better?  A few years ago when the G-Analyst came out there
was an article wherein the author used the G-Analyst to determine max g's
on his RX7 Turbo on a skid-pad at MIS.  When he was satisfied he had it
all, he offered the car to Little Al, who happened to be testing at MIS
that day. Little Al "carved" his way up to the limit, which was later 
confirmed to be substantially the same limit the author had reached.  
Then Al "pitched" the car, and drove around the skid pad under heavy 
throttle with the tail slightly out (maybe 12%??).  The G-Analyst showed 
nearly a 10% increase in G's!

Now my question on ABS.  Several have stated that a great driver can beat 
the ABS in a controlled situation.  I've found that my 914 (no ABS of 
course) would typically only pull about .4 braking g's and rarely go 
beyond .6 when on the autocross course.  (Obviously more is available in 
straights, but autox courses have no straights...)  In my 944 (with ABS) 
I was amazed to find that I'm braking at .8 g's almost as a matter of 
course!  I assumed that this was because in a real world application like 
autocross, you're always pulling some significant lateral g's and the 
non-abs car tends to lock the light tire(s) first, whereupon I modulate 
back, thereby not getting all that I can from the loaded tires.  
Conversely, the ABS car, being 4 channel, permits maximum braking on the 
loaded tire without locking the "light" tire.  If my guess is right, then 
wouldn't it be impossible for a driver to beat the ABS in these 
conditions unless, of course, he had a brake pedal for each wheel and 
four feet?  Or do you learn to live with the flat spots on the "light" 
tire and modulate the loaded tire?

 -- 
[]  []  []      []                []              []       Byron D. Short
  []  []   []        []                        []       bshort@AFSinc.com
[]  []  []     []             []                           (719) 531-9511
  []  []   []       []                 []                     1990 944 S2
[]  []  []    []         []           

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 19:59:24 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: 911 Brakes Overheating

>Seems to me like my rotors are warping when hot.  No big suprise... but
>most 911 people I've talked to have had their brakes go mushy or fade
>before their rotors have warped.  I'm curious what experience other 911
>track junkies here have had.  How do YOU know when your brakes are cooking?
>What have you done about it? 

What I'm about to relate isn't a modification to the brake system, but a
modification
to the driver.  

I had my brakes fade big-time at a PCA driver's ed last year.  Eye opening
experience -
can you say "Jesus H. Christ on a popsickle stick"?  This happened relatively
early
in the day, and, not wanting to quit early I went back out (the next time my
run group
was up) and was fine.  I had heard that if your brakes are overheating, the
problem
may be that you are using them *too* much.  I found that if I did all of my
braking
as hard and fast as I could, my brakes were fine (my brakes are totally
stock).
To this day, I accomplish my braking the in this same manner.  As hard as I
can
for as short a time as I can.  I'm going alot faster than I used to and have
had
no fading as a result, so I'm inclined to believe that there may be something
to
the advice.

Any experts care to comment?

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 17:44:25 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Faster cornering by no skidding?

What an entertaining thread! I had no idea that going fast depended on
understanding terms like: maximum centripetal (opposite to centrifugal)
acceleration; maximum coefficient of static friction; limit of static
friction; and, centrifugal g (a measure of centripetal acceleration in
cornering). I thought I knew slip angle, but am not sure now since much of
the context baffles me.

One thing I do know -- the principles of "cornering fast" in a parking lot
are quite different than on a race track (speed makes a world of
difference). Generalizations about "faster cornering" are not very useful
to people on the list who may be searching for ways to improve their
performance in vastly different environments, some in a parking lot and
others on a race track. For me, the "perfect autocross car" was just plain
dangerous at speed on a race track (the instant oversteer would almost
cause me heart failure in the first fast turn). Conversely, a well-set-up
race car was a pig in a parking lot event (would understeer right off the
first turn). And, I think the driving technique for faster cornering is
likewise different (and in some ways, opposite), because of the differences
of speed allowed by the course.

These theoretical terms of "fast cornering" may make for delightful
discussion, but are not very helpful in practical application. You learn to
drive faster (and in some instances by slower cornering) by instruction,
experience, and by comparing methods at the track with faster drivers who
probably couldn't begin to explain their superior performance with these
terms. They might say, however, "Yup, I pitched it, got back on the gas,
and fed a little opposite lock without scrubbing off too much speed."
That's the language I suggest you learn.



------------------------------

Date: 16 May 1995 18:17:05 U
From: "James Wong" <james_wong@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: Re: Help w/changing master 

        Reply to:   RE>>Help w/changing master cylinder


- --------------------------------------
>  
> I am thinking of attempting to change my brake master in my 78 911SC.  Is
this 
> something that the hobbyist should try or should I leave it to the 
> professionals?  Does anyone know of where to get good information on doing 
> this?  Any help is appreciated.  Thanks in advance. 

- ---------------------

I did that few months ago on my 76/911S.  I am not sure how differ it is from
a 78. The general procedure is not too bad. You need to jack up the front of
the car and remove the pan which protects against the steering rack, the
swaybars and the brake cylinder.

Also remove the front tires/wheels so that you can drain the brake fluid.
Remove all three small diamenter brass brake lines from the MC. They are left
front, right front, and the rear. Take care not to bend these lines.
Remove the two plastic hoses with brass ends that come down from the top
(from the brake fluid resevior). They are just held down by couple of rubber
grumets. Be prepare to catch any brake fluid left in the system.

Next remove the two bolts that holds the MC against the firewall.

The installation is the reverse of above procedure. :-)

Ahhh, not exactly. The problem for me was putting the two plastic hoses back
in. The new rubber grumets were so tough and the space was so cramp that I
ended up loosen up the other end of the hoses (right at the resevior). I put
the hoses down enough, lubricate the rubber with some brake fluid, heat the
rubber a bit with a heat gun, then insert the plastic hoses in.

Now bolt the MC back against the firewall. You may need another person to
assist you in guiding the brake peddle push rod into the MC from the inside
of the car.

Install the rest of the lines tightly. And don't forget to bleed the entire
brake system (all four corners). You will need at least on big bottle (maybe
equal to 4 little ones) brake fluids to flush the entire system.

These were the steps I went through. I am not sure if your 78/911 is similar
or not, so take it as reference ONLY.

 -James

Subject: 944 Cam Sprocket Bolt Removal Advice?

Greetings all,

Want to replace the front cam seal (O-ring) on my '83 944 but am having
difficulty removing the internal wrenching bolt holding the cam sprocket on.
  I've tried heating with a propane torch for ~5 minutes followed by electric
impact wrench to no avail but with slight deformation of the bolt head.

Since the bolt is shrouded by the cam sprocket and the thought of stripping
it out makes me very nervous,  it may be that I'm just not being rough enough
with it.  

Anyone have experience with this bolt and know any TRICK? 

Do I need to get it hotter with say an Oxy-Acetylene torch instead of
propane?

Should I go at it with the impact wrench while still hot or wait until cool?

Any response is greatly appreciated.

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 23:57:31 -0500
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: 944  Cam Bolt Removal  ???

At 1:43pm 15.5.95, George Beuselinck wrote:
>> I want to replace the front O-ring seal on my '83 944 but am having
>> difficulty with the cam bolt which holds the sprocket on.  I've heated it
>> with a small propane torch for ~5 minutes, let it cool overnight and
>> "hammered" on it with an electric impact wrench for several seconds with no
>> noticeable effect.
>>
>> Should I use a Oxy-Acetylene torch (which I don't have) and impact while
>> still hot?
>>
>
>If you're having this much trouble with that bolt, time to find a good
>mechanic...Or, drill out the offending bolt, and replace it with a new one...

I need to do this same operation, and after dealing with the cam bolt I
have decided that I will take the cam housing off before I take the cam
sproket off (I have to replace the cam housing gasket anyways since it also
is leaking a bit). I was **very** nervous about applying a lot of force to
the cam sprocket bolt (perhaps my fear of slipping, turning the cam shaft,
and manually mashing my valves into my pistons).

The cam sprocket bolt is very shallow and it seems to be very hard to get
the socket well seated in there while holding the cam sproket still with a
wrench. I think (hope!) this is much easier with the cam housing off of the
motor and on the bench.

Just my $.02 worth. Please correct me if I'm way off base here !!!

trev.

Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 22:46:57 -0600
From: tabel@cyberport.net (Tom Abel)
Subject: More on WD40

"Hey Mike, I betcha I can hit that ponderosa pine 100 yards away."  Montana 
logging crew at lunch time with their WD40 powered potato gun.  Bored at 
lunch?  Want to make a "hit" with your boss?  2" pvc pipe, with threaded 
coupling a screw in cap, drilled and tapped to for coleman lantern lighter.  
Stuff potato in one end, unscrew the cap and squirt in some WD40.  Close the 
cap, and twist the coleman lighter.  See if what you can hit.   I am not 
kidding.  When not cooking spotted owls for lunch, this is what the logger 
guys do for kicks.
Tom Abel
Abel Engineering
212 Segiah Way
Kalispell, Mt. 59901   (406) 752-7665

Date: 16 May 1995 16:52:15 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: Re: Faster cornering by no skidding?

Theodosios Korakianitis (ourios@zeus.wustl.edu) writes:

>Here is the quick question:
>We have concluded that with ABS we can stop faster BECAUSE ABS
>PREVENTS SKIDDING. Some also keep talking about going faster around a corner

> BY SLIDING THE CAR AROUND. Is there an inconsistency here? 
>Would we corner faster by obtaining the maximum centripetal (opposite
> to centrifugal) acceleration by being AT THE VERGE of sliding sideways, 
>instead of actually sliding?

I did read somewhere about some [professional] driver that was "hanging 
the rear end out" a lot and when asked if that technique wasn't actually
slower
than going around the corner in the conventional manner he replied:

"When making love, you are not always trying to make babies."

In other words, this wasn't trying to win a race, he was having fun.
I'm guessing now, but I think it may have been Ruf's driver giving
demo rides.


 Chris






------------------------------

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 15:03:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Thomas B. Smith" <toms@comtch.iea.com>
Subject: 915 transmissions

Porchephiles-
This last weekend fellow Porschephile Bill Simer and I had the pleasure 
of replacing the input shaft seal in a early style (06) 915 transmission. 
According to the manual one has to almost completely dissassemble the 
transmission to do this.  (not one of the good Doctor's best designs, as
evidenced by it's correction in later models)  After the successful 
(so-far) completion of this task, I have a couple of questions.

1.) Has anyone ever tried forcibly removing the throwout bearing support
tube, in order to replace the seal without such a radical dissassembly of
the transmission. Yes it will come out, and no you probably don't want to 
know the details.

2.) Since the location of the raised area on the input shaft where the seal
rides, and the area in the tube that has a slightly lesser diameter than 
the rest of the tube and where the seal is held do not match very well, I 
was wondering if the seal is different in the earlier transmissions.  
When I put the seal in the necked down area of the tube, both lips of the
seal did not properly contact the raised area of the shaft,  this lead to 
pretty blue $40.00 per gallon puddles under the car.  If this last 
statement leads your mind to form questions, please don't ask them.  If 
anyone has a parts catalog, would you please let me know if perhaps the
915/06 /15 uses a different seal than does a 915/08 /12 or /63.  Since 
we  had the gasket & seal kit listed for 915 transmissions in general, we 
do not know  if there might be a slight difference in seal outside diameter
on the 915/06.

3.) I may be confused as to what year and type number the 915 transmission 
was changed so that the input shaft seal could be changed from the 
bellhousing side by using tool number P 386.  Can anyone shed any light
on this, the manual is not too clear, it just says units 915/02 /08 /12
are of this type.  Not that it would make much difference, since we
did not have a "P 386".

Disclaimer:  We know for certain that this transmission has been opened 
before, since some parts, mainly the fifth speed gearset have been  
replaced.  So it may be some sort of mix and match situation.

If anyone really wants to know the grizzly details of this whole debacle
I would be happy to tell you the finer points that I have omitted here.
Suffice it to say for now that I am a lot more familiar with Porsche  
transmissions than I intended to be.  Oh well, it was sort of fun, and 
as my wife says, it keeps me out of the bars.

Thanks in advance
Tom Smith  <toms@comtch.iea.com>

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 18:20:32 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@Symtec.com>
Subject: Re: 944 CD Player Replacement

> After 8 years of faithful service, my stock blaupunkt Reno cassette deck 
> has croaked. It would be silly to replace it with another cassette deck, 
> since CD units are relatively cheap.
> 
> My question: does anyone know of a place that sells Blaupunkt CD players 
> that fit right into the console, no muss, no fuss, that are cheap? (an 
> outdated model would be fine; perhaps some place has overstocked them)

I purchased one of the Blaupunkt Monterey units from Crutchfield about 18
months ago for my 951. You tell Crutchfield what kind of car it's going
into and they'll include a wiring pigtale and the tool to get the old Reno
(mine had one too) out. Total swap time was 30 minutes. Fits like it was
made for it. Solid performance and great styling. Excellent customer service.
I have seen this same unit for sale in the back of Car&Driver and Autoweek.

Standard disclaimer applies. Shop where you want. Buy what you want.

Doug Donsbach - dld@symtec.com - Knoxville, TN

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 18:31:49 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Neat Uses for WD40

Excerpts from mail: 16-May-95 Neat Uses for WD40 by MLBDayton@aol.com 
> >> Jeesh. Is there anything WD40 can't do?

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 17:49:04 -0600 (MDT)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Slip Angles/Max G Loads

The current thread on tire slip angles is very interesting.  Let me add 2 
cents worth, and ask a question about ABS related thereto.

Some time ago BFG published a chart showing the maximum lateral load 
generated by their R1s as slip angle increases.  The R1 at that time was 
the 206 series (this was about '91 if memory serves).  At any rate, the 
maximum lateral force was available at about 12% slip angle, but was very 
near the maximum levels beginning around 8%.  After about 13% or so, the 
lateral force dropped dramatically.  This is what we all feel as the car 
"comes around".  

So the idea is to stay in the "fat" part of the slip angle, but not go 
past that optimum limit.  Some tires give a tell-tale slight loss of g's 
as you go over the peak before the big drop in g's that represent an all 
out slide.  This is what you'll hear referred to as a "forgiving" tire.  
Some don't telegragh this so well, and are referred to as "peaky".

The following explanation refers to autocrossing speeds; I'm not 
qualified to talk about higher speeds and could only guess about what you 
feel in a 100 mph corner--I haven't done then enough to be calm at those 
speeds yet!  ;-)

Typically you hit the max slip angle with one end or the other, that is, 
either you approach it by pushing the front, or by slipping the rear.  
I liken the difference to "carving" versus "pitching".  

Carving is best when you can run flat out (or nearly so) through a turn,
and is characterized by increasing loads on the front causing slight
understeer at the limit.  In this scenario, the car is generally making an
ever larger arc, due to the ever increasing speed.  Picture a skier
carving a turn with minimal slip. 

If a turn can't be negotiated full-on, then some pitching is often the
best approach.  On some cars, (most Porsches, by my experience), you can
begin a rotation with drop power oversteer.  This rotation "snaps"  the
car up the the maximum slip angle (and maximum g load) very quickly, much
more quickly than carving your way up.  This also serves to "point"  the
car down the next straight.  "Catch the slide" by applying power, and you
find yourself rocketing towards the next turn.  The trade offs are speed
and risk.  Speed: remember, you got there by lifting (and sometimes
braking simultaneously) so obviously you've slowed down.  Couple that with
the effects of "scrub" and you can see that this only works when you need
to slow down for the turn anyway.  Risk: if you go too far, you can lose
serious time or even spin.  Picture a skier doing "step turns", sliding 
the rear or his skis around to point him in his new direction.

My wife and I often identify an autocross course by a series of 
"pitches".  We consider that since a carve is simply trying to negotiate 
the turn as smoothly as possible, and usually at full throttle, there's 
not much to remember there.  But the turns that require a "pitch" are the 
ones that determine the winner since they are harder to execute well.

Either carving or pitching can produce maximum g's, at least in theory. 
(Yes, I know, I'm ignoring the possibility of using all four tires equally
well...) Which is better?  A few years ago when the G-Analyst came out there
was an article wherein the author used the G-Analyst to determine max g's
on his RX7 Turbo on a skid-pad at MIS.  When he was satisfied he had it
all, he offered the car to Little Al, who happened to be testing at MIS
that day. Little Al "carved" his way up to the limit, which was later 
confirmed to be substantially the same limit the author had reached.  
Then Al "pitched" the car, and drove around the skid pad under heavy 
throttle with the tail slightly out (maybe 12%??).  The G-Analyst showed 
nearly a 10% increase in G's!

Now my question on ABS.  Several have stated that a great driver can beat 
the ABS in a controlled situation.  I've found that my 914 (no ABS of 
course) would typically only pull about .4 braking g's and rarely go 
beyond .6 when on the autocross course.  (Obviously more is available in 
straights, but autox courses have no straights...)  In my 944 (with ABS) 
I was amazed to find that I'm braking at .8 g's almost as a matter of 
course!  I assumed that this was because in a real world application like 
autocross, you're always pulling some significant lateral g's and the 
non-abs car tends to lock the light tire(s) first, whereupon I modulate 
back, thereby not getting all that I can from the loaded tires.  
Conversely, the ABS car, being 4 channel, permits maximum braking on the 
loaded tire without locking the "light" tire.  If my guess is right, then 
wouldn't it be impossible for a driver to beat the ABS in these 
conditions unless, of course, he had a brake pedal for each wheel and 
four feet?  Or do you learn to live with the flat spots on the "light" 
tire and modulate the loaded tire?

 -- 
[]  []  []      []                []              []       Byron D. Short
  []  []   []        []                        []       bshort@AFSinc.com
[]  []  []     []             []                           (719) 531-9511
  []  []   []       []                 []                     1990 944 S2
[]  []  []    []         []

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 19:59:24 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: 911 Brakes Overheating

>Seems to me like my rotors are warping when hot.  No big suprise... but
>most 911 people I've talked to have had their brakes go mushy or fade
>before their rotors have warped.  I'm curious what experience other 911
>track junkies here have had.  How do YOU know when your brakes are cooking?
>What have you done about it? 

What I'm about to relate isn't a modification to the brake system, but a
modification
to the driver.  

I had my brakes fade big-time at a PCA driver's ed last year.  Eye opening
experience -
can you say "Jesus H. Christ on a popsickle stick"?  This happened relatively
early
in the day, and, not wanting to quit early I went back out (the next time my
run group
was up) and was fine.  I had heard that if your brakes are overheating, the
problem
may be that you are using them *too* much.  I found that if I did all of my
braking
as hard and fast as I could, my brakes were fine (my brakes are totally
stock).
To this day, I accomplish my braking the in this same manner.  As hard as I
can
for as short a time as I can.  I'm going alot faster than I used to and have
had
no fading as a result, so I'm inclined to believe that there may be something
to
the advice.

Any experts care to comment?

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 17:44:25 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Faster cornering by no skidding?

What an entertaining thread! I had no idea that going fast depended on
understanding terms like: maximum centripetal (opposite to centrifugal)
acceleration; maximum coefficient of static friction; limit of static
friction; and, centrifugal g (a measure of centripetal acceleration in
cornering). I thought I knew slip angle, but am not sure now since much of
the context baffles me.

One thing I do know -- the principles of "cornering fast" in a parking lot
are quite different than on a race track (speed makes a world of
difference). Generalizations about "faster cornering" are not very useful
to people on the list who may be searching for ways to improve their
performance in vastly different environments, some in a parking lot and
others on a race track. For me, the "perfect autocross car" was just plain
dangerous at speed on a race track (the instant oversteer would almost
cause me heart failure in the first fast turn). Conversely, a well-set-up
race car was a pig in a parking lot event (would understeer right off the
first turn). And, I think the driving technique for faster cornering is
likewise different (and in some ways, opposite), because of the differences
of speed allowed by the course.

These theoretical terms of "fast cornering" may make for delightful
discussion, but are not very helpful in practical application. You learn to
drive faster (and in some instances by slower cornering) by instruction,
experience, and by comparing methods at the track with faster drivers who
probably couldn't begin to explain their superior performance with these
terms. They might say, however, "Yup, I pitched it, got back on the gas,
and fed a little opposite lock without scrubbing off too much speed."
That's the language I suggest you learn.



------------------------------

Date: 16 May 1995 18:17:05 U
From: "James Wong" <james_wong@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: Re: Help w/changing master 

        Reply to:   RE>>Help w/changing master cylinder


- --------------------------------------
>  
> I am thinking of attempting to change my brake master in my 78 911SC.  Is
this 
> something that the hobbyist should try or should I leave it to the 
> professionals?  Does anyone know of where to get good information on doing 
> this?  Any help is appreciated.  Thanks in advance. 

- ---------------------

I did that few months ago on my 76/911S.  I am not sure how differ it is from
a 78. The general procedure is not too bad. You need to jack up the front of
the car and remove the pan which protects against the steering rack, the
swaybars and the brake cylinder.

Also remove the front tires/wheels so that you can drain the brake fluid.
Remove all three small diamenter brass brake lines from the MC. They are left
front, right front, and the rear. Take care not to bend these lines.
Remove the two plastic hoses with brass ends that come down from the top
(from the brake fluid resevior). They are just held down by couple of rubber
grumets. Be prepare to catch any brake fluid left in the system.

Next remove the two bolts that holds the MC against the firewall.

The installation is the reverse of above procedure. :-)

Ahhh, not exactly. The problem for me was putting the two plastic hoses back
in. The new rubber grumets were so tough and the space was so cramp that I
ended up loosen up the other end of the hoses (right at the resevior). I put
the hoses down enough, lubricate the rubber with some brake fluid, heat the
rubber a bit with a heat gun, then insert the plastic hoses in.

Now bolt the MC back against the firewall. You may need another person to
assist you in guiding the brake peddle push rod into the MC from the inside
of the car.

Install the rest of the lines tightly. And don't forget to bleed the entire
brake system (all four corners). You will need at least on big bottle (maybe
equal to 4 little ones) brake fluids to flush the entire system.

These were the steps I went through. I am not sure if your 78/911 is similar
or not, so take it as reference ONLY.

 -James

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 23:57:31 -0500
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: 944  Cam Bolt Removal  ???

At 1:43pm 15.5.95, George Beuselinck wrote:
>> I want to replace the front O-ring seal on my '83 944 but am having
>> difficulty with the cam bolt which holds the sprocket on.  I've heated it
>> with a small propane torch for ~5 minutes, let it cool overnight and
>> "hammered" on it with an electric impact wrench for several seconds with no
>> noticeable effect.
>>
>> Should I use a Oxy-Acetylene torch (which I don't have) and impact while
>> still hot?
>>
>
>If you're having this much trouble with that bolt, time to find a good
>mechanic...Or, drill out the offending bolt, and replace it with a new one...

I need to do this same operation, and after dealing with the cam bolt I
have decided that I will take the cam housing off before I take the cam
sproket off (I have to replace the cam housing gasket anyways since it also
is leaking a bit). I was **very** nervous about applying a lot of force to
the cam sprocket bolt (perhaps my fear of slipping, turning the cam shaft,
and manually mashing my valves into my pistons).

The cam sprocket bolt is very shallow and it seems to be very hard to get
the socket well seated in there while holding the cam sproket still with a
wrench. I think (hope!) this is much easier with the cam housing off of the
motor and on the bench.

Just my $.02 worth. Please correct me if I'm way off base here !!!

trev.


===============================
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

While surfing, stop at:
http://www.io.org/~cme/MIC/mic.html
and you will find a listing on trev ...

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 22:46:57 -0600
From: tabel@cyberport.net (Tom Abel)
Subject: More on WD40

"Hey Mike, I betcha I can hit that ponderosa pine 100 yards away."  Montana 
logging crew at lunch time with their WD40 powered potato gun.  Bored at 
lunch?  Want to make a "hit" with your boss?  2" pvc pipe, with threaded 
coupling a screw in cap, drilled and tapped to for coleman lantern lighter.  
Stuff potato in one end, unscrew the cap and squirt in some WD40.  Close the 
cap, and twist the coleman lighter.  See if what you can hit.   I am not 
kidding.  When not cooking spotted owls for lunch, this is what the logger 
guys do for kicks.
Tom Abel
Abel Engineering
212 Segiah Way
Kalispell, Mt. 59901   (406) 752-7665

Subject: 914 parts


Why is it that everyone who works on 914s has about twice as many headlight
motors than they need?  They must of been the single most reliable piece of
electrical equipment on the car.  In any case, since it has taken the purchase
of three 914s(one for engine, one for interior and misc., one for chassis) to
build my current car, I am naturally left with many(too many) extra parts.

I have just about anything small you might need, so let me know what you're
looking for and I will be happy to set you up with parts for rock bottom
prices(exclusively for P-philes).  

I'd also be interested in a center console with or without gauges if anyone
wants to swap.  Also, 

Jerry Haus of 914 Steucke:
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

doors, hood (one very small dent), door hardware and glass,

relay circuit board, air vents, targa top, targa latches, carpet, visors,
rear view mirror, shifter linkage(early), 2 gas tanks, washer fluid bottle, 
washer fluid lines, partial wiring harness, all kinds of dash parts and gauges, 
steering column, shift linkage, et. al.

other P-cars.

lugs and center caps).  Does anyone know of other sources such that I could
compare prices?  Are the ATS wheels a good choice?

end and putting the cleaned up mechanicals in place.  Although heavy, I do
like the style of the late rubber bumper(with the driving lights).  I had
to patch a couple holes in the front pan where the oil cooler was installed.

control vents, windshield wiper motor, et. al.  Then on to the interior and

hose and clamps.

everyone who contributes to this list.

Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 23:08:58 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: vin #9115100543

> 
> Gentlemen
> 
> I am looking for a track car, because I can not bring myself to driving my
> '88 Targa (that has only 7,000 miles) to drivers ed or pca events.
> So, my brother who knows very little about P cars found a car for $4,500 that
> he thought might interest me. The car is 2 1/2 hours  from here. I didn't
> want to take the trip for nothing, so I asked him to get the vin #. The vin #
> is 9115100543. Can anyone tell me anything about this car from this number?
> Thank you very much in anticipation of your help.
> pingiron1
>

This was the format for 911 serial numbers in the 70s.  "5" means '75,
"1" means regular 911, which did not exist as a US model.  "2" in
fourth place would be an S, "3" (I think) would be a Carrera.  The
fifth digit is "0" for coupe, "1" for targa, so it's a coupe.  The
last four digits refer to the order of manufacture.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu
9115201136

Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 17:54:56 +0200
From: Pierre Fournet-fayard <fournet@ilm.loria.fr>
Subject: My trip at Porsche (long)



Hye everyone !


It has been a marvellous holliday week.  Weather was sunny.  Usually at this
season, it's pouring in the east of France and sunny in Texas/Louisiana !

One of the best day of this week was the one a couple of friends, my wife
and I spent in Zuffenhausen (Stuttgart suburbs) in the Porsche factory.

It's easy to find the factory.  If you're coming from the highway (autobahn)
A81, you simply have to follow the direction `Porsche Museum'.  There's a
Porsche logo to help you.

For more precise informations, have a look on tta.com in
/pub/porschephiles/Images/zuff.jpg and in /pub/porschephiles/Images/zuffen.txt .

To park is not so difficult, but take care that there's no room in the factory
for visitors' cars.  But you will find a place to park at less than a 5 minutes
walk.

Last but not least: DO NOT FORGET TO BOOK !  Plan your trip as soon as you can
cause there's only arround 25 visitors a day.  This is not a big figure, but it
allows the guide to answer to everyone's question.  Our guide spoke German,
English and a few words of French.  Those few words helped us.  I wish everyone
to have the same friendly guide we had.

You first can spend half an hour in the Porsche Museum.  It's a small room, but
it contains some great stuff as the Boss' 356.  The tour starts at the Museum
meeting point.

Our visit was shorter than expected because of the coming of the new Boxster
986.  Many places were strictly forbidden to public eyes.

The first thing that you'll notice is the cleaness of the factory !  Ok, I
admit, the factory is mainly composed of assembly lines.  That helps but it's
too help for meeting higher quality.

There's around 4500 people in Zuffenhausen and the actual production per day is
arround 85 993 (over 35% of convertible, this figure includes every kind of 993)
between 1 and 3 928 and no more 968.

We saw first the motor assembly line.  Each worker is able to built an all
motor and they swap every 3 months their job on the line.  BTW, they will not
have any problem to find a job in a private Porsche mecanic garage.

Crankcases, crankshaft, con-rods, exhaust and other stuff come from other
non-Porsches factories.  But every parts is controlled and Porsche is involed
in the design of the production lines of thoses factories.

We were lucky.  We saw some GT2 motors.  Their are huge !  It also means that
Porsche have sold all the homologation dedicated cars and is building others.

Each motor pass a power test.  Every motor is over the required power, but
Porsche don't publish those tests for every motor (it's to prevent the jealousy
of owners).

We didn't saw the motor-testing room because they were testing the first
dozen 986 motors.  The only thing the guide told us was not new: the forth-
coming Mercedes SLK is a kind of sister-ship of the 986 (concerning the chassis
and the breaks).

I forget to mention that Porsche only build on demand.  At this point the
customer (yes, you !) can go to the factory and follow the production of his
very own motor and his very own car.

Then we went to the leather work-shop.  Every thing is built form scratch: they
simply buy tainted leather and cut it, glue it and sew it (this is real
hand-sew stuff) !  This is the place where they built the convertible top and
can repair yours.

We directly went to the final assembly line where motors and assembled with the
rest of cars (the rest of the factory was closed for our eyes due to the 986).

They can assemble on the same line all 993 versions, 928, and Audi RS2 and Mer-
cedes E500 (but nowdays the E500 is fully produced by Mercedes).

At the end of the production, each car have a full 30km road test.  That is why
there's so many Porsche hanging around the factory !

It was really great !


Hope it was not too long to read,

Pierre F-F.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 11:46:02 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 944 Cam Sprocket Bolt Removal Advice?

On Tue, 16 May 1995 Phyl346@aol.com wrote:

> Want to replace the front cam seal (O-ring) on my '83 944 but am having
> difficulty removing the internal wrenching bolt holding the cam sprocket on.
>   I've tried heating with a propane torch for ~5 minutes followed by electric
> impact wrench to no avail but with slight deformation of the bolt head.
> 

Phyl - you have a real dillema there, your leaky seal will be a 
non-existant seal if you get it much hotter.

my favorite method of undoing stubborn bolts is to use an L piece into a 
socket, and then as many half inch extenders as I can get hold of, its 
amazing how many bolts/nuts will move given a couple of hundred pounds/feet.

Pete

Date: Wed, 17 May 95 8:50:11 EDT
From: Martin Walker <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: going around corners faster

Theo (sorry for abbrev.)

My understanding is that the important thing is not how fast you go around
the corner, but how quickly you can accelerate out of it.  If the car
is sliding, the direction the car is pointing is several degrees ahead
of it's actual direction of travel.  So....that means compared to the
car that doesn't slide the one that does is pointing down the straight
that follows the curve sooner, which in turn means that car can accelerate
out of the turn exiting faster and pointing in the right direction.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 08:37:07 -0500
From: smaardyk@rs6000.SUGAR-LAND.WIRELINE.SLB.COM
Subject: Re: 944 Cam Sprocket Bolt Removal...

Phil,

I'm not sure heating the bolt is the right thing to do.  I would think that
heating would expand the bolt and make it even tighter.  I removed mine
with the aid of a simple jig to support the end of a crescent wrench
holding the cam shaft so I could use two hands on the wrench on the
infamous cam bolt.  Here is what I did:

1.  Spray penetrating oil on the bolt.

2.  The jig is a foot-long piece of 2x4 with a bolt sticking up at about
the mid point.  The jig is laid fore and aft just to the right (facing
forward) of the cam housing.  The jig slopes downward in the forward
direction and buts against the nose piece.  The crescent (large size)
was placed on the cam shaft and the handle rests on the jig with the
bolt keeping it from sliding downward.

3.  I wrapped a bit of Al foil on the triple square socket as discussed
in a previous posting to get a snug fit in the bolt head.  The triple
square was used with a breaker bar.  One hand supporst the socket end
to keep the socket parallel with the bolt axis and the other hand
applies the torque.

4.  After a couple of good grunts the bolt loosened.

5.  I noticed that some of the coating on the bolt had peeled off.  I
replaced the bolt on reassembly (both because of the peeled coating
and because I wanted to have 'virgin' [see previous postings on
Porsches and s*x...] socket seating area for the next removal.

By the way, a mechanic friend once remarked that since Porsches are
assembled by hand by real people they can be dissembled by had by
real people as well.  This has become a mantra on more than one 
occasion as I struggled with such things as engine mount removal,
cam bolt removal, etc.

Good luck,
John		'89 944, 8v

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 9:41:38 -0400 (EDT)
From: Darrin <LUCAS001@WCSUB.CTSTATEU.EDU>
Subject: Re: 914 Manuals on Microfiche


	I've gotten several responses regarding my hatred of microfiche
factory manuals.

	First, you need a fiche reader (preferably one that prints).

	Second, I've used my fiche on terrific readers, but they're still
nearly impossible to read w/o a ton of focusing.

	FInally, you work on cars in garages.  There is oil and dirt and
this stuff is not too good for a 3" x 5" piece of film that holds about
75 pages of info.

	
Does anyone know if the fiche manuals are complete (compared to 8 vol. paper)?

	I can't believe these things are complete.  I used a BMW factory
manual and they had every detail down to rivets in body panels.

	They're cheap (Porsche manuals on fiche, that is), but not worth it,IMHO

	Darrin Lucas
	73  914  2.0

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 10:15:21 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: 944 CD player?

> After 8 years of faithful service, my stock blaupunkt Reno cassette deck 
> has croaked. It would be silly to replace it with another cassette deck, 
> since CD units are relatively cheap.
> 
> My question: does anyone know of a place that sells Blaupunkt CD players 
> that fit right into the console, no muss, no fuss, that are cheap? (an 
> outdated model would be fine; perhaps some place has overstocked them)
> 
> george -- any 944 cadavers with CD players left in 'em? :)
> 
> adam

Adam,
You do not want anything Blaupunkt!  That Reno in particular has the worst
tuner section god ever created and is just a piece of junk.  By the way I 
have the one I took out of my 944 in perfect working order if you are a 
glutten for punishment.  

If you like a good tuner, buy a Sony.  It is superior to the Alpine, via
testing in the car for 2 months.  I sent the Alpine back but it sounded 
better due to better amps and CD.

If you like a good CD player buy an Alpine.

The best combination is a Sony with a good amplifier.  

Any DIN mount head unit will go right into the existing cut out.

Jeff 
Jpuzas@astro.ge.com

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 07:30:56 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Clear coat woes...

Re:

>Anyone else on the net have any first hand knowledge of powder coating?

All the removable sheet metal (no jokes, please) on my 914 is powder-coated
- -- rocker panels, front and rear bumpers, front and rear valences, engine
grille, instrument panel, horn "button", engine sheet metal, valve covers,
intake manifold, front and rear suspension, brake splash shields, etc.  The
type of powder is called "Vulcan Black", a semi-gloss black.  It holds up
_very well_ to the elements, and can easily be spiffed up with some
Meguilar's.

I have my powdercoating done in Redwood City, CA.
