Date: Wed, 17 May 95 07:06:32 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: A boy, his 914 and his 1st Pano

 Greetings all,
 
 I just got my first ever issue of Panorama and after looking through it I have 
 mixed feelings which have generated a question.
 
 One of the neat things about this list is that there is a good cross section of 
 all cars here -- and especially lots of people who own, say, a 911 and a 944, 
 and perhaps a 914 for autocrossing.   Accordingly, I had begun to feel part of 
 the Porsche family, me and my 914s, and decided to join PCA and 914OA.  Well, 
 after anxiously waiting for my first Pano, I am a bit disappointed. Sort of 
 reminded me of Excellence, lots of neat articles and ads for 911s, 944s, etc, 
 but almost no 914 content.
 
 I am in no way complaining -- I minored in economics and I understand all that 
 supply/demand stuff, so I know that there would be a natural focus on the cars 
 owned by the most PCA members and also that the ads would definitely be for 
 those cars with the most owners and the most $$$.  But in general, is this 
 latest issue of Panorama representative of all issues with regards to it's low 
 914 content?
 
 I do have to admit, Pano has increased my interest in the other cars and there 
 was an ad for a 914-6 for $7500.  Hmmmmm....
 
 BTW, please don't use this as a kernel for a 914s are inferior/914s rule/my car 
 is better than your car sort of thing -- all 17 year old aol'ers take note ;~)
 (just kidding)
 
 Tim Radsick
 radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil

> 
> 
> If you like a good tuner, buy a Sony.  It is superior to the Alpine, via
> testing in the car for 2 months.  I sent the Alpine back but it sounded 
> better due to better amps and CD.
> 
> If you like a good CD player buy an Alpine.
> 
> The best combination is a Sony with a good amplifier.  
> 
> Any DIN mount head unit will go right into the existing cut out.

I went looking for stereos just the other day and ended up with 
Kenwood over the Sony.  I've had a sony stereo system at home for  
yrs and it is still great.  However for the price and features,
the sound of the Kenwood was just as good as the Sony.  Alpine 
seemed much more expensive.  In any case, I settled for a Cassete 
rather than a CD player.  My reason was that I didn't want to have 
half my CD's lying in the car and half at home so I just tape my CD's 
and use the tapes in the car.  This way if I lose a few tapes its no 
big deal, plus in a porsche you'll never get the fidelity that you 
get in a LEXUS.  A porsche is a race car period.

Date: Tue, 16 May 95 10:02:24 PDT
From: Rich Glew <richgl@microsoft.com>
Subject: 911SC idle/stall problems

Hi all,
I own a 1979 911 SC with 131,000 miles.  Everything has worked great 
for the four years I've owned it, and a recent valve leak-down showed 
impressive 0-3% figures for a car this age.  Here is my problem, which 
has become predictable but worsening of late.  I'll be as specific as 
possible.  It may be relevent to note that the SC is not my daily 
driver, but I do commute in it 60 miles round trip 3-4 days per week.

In the morning it starts fine and is idling in traffic at the desired 
900 RPM after a couple minutes.  However, once it warms up, there is a 
rhythmic "cough" or hesitation in the idle that varies between about 
750 and the normal 900 RPM.  Other than that, the car runs fine.

Now, at the end of the day, the car will start fine, but for the first 
10 minutes of city driving the slowing or hesitating idle problem 
worsens significantly.  When I depress the clutch, the car's idle will 
drop from 900 RPM to 250-500 RPM --and lately the car has been 
stalling.  This requires that I start the car again, try to keep the 
RPM's high, and hope that it doesn't stall at the next intersection.  
After about 5 minutes of this, for the next 5 minutes the car idles at 
a weak 500 RPM.  Finally, after about 10-15 minutes the car's idle 
warms up to normal levels.  But the repeating hesitation or variance 
from 750-900 RPM continues.

This low idle and stalling phenomenon is frustrating and disconcerting. 
 Any suggestions from the tech experts on this group?  Thanks in advance,

 -Rich

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 11:06:49 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Belt anchor position

Actually, the sub belt should go straight down, through the cut out (which
you probably don't have) in the seat. On my recaro SRD there is both a
cutout and a steel cross bar to attach the belt in the seat. On the
passenger side I've used the cross bar which connects the two sides of the
adjusting mechanism on the factory sport seat. This isn't optimal, but
there is already a lot of slop intorduced by routing the belt over the
front of the seat. My instructors don't seem to mind; even the other four
belts are a step up from the narrow 3-pt.

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 09:27:03 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 944 Cam Sprocket Bolt Removal Advice?

In response to text from Peter Diffey:

>my favorite method of undoing stubborn bolts is to use an L piece into a 
>socket, and then as many half inch extenders as I can get hold of, its 
>amazing how many bolts/nuts will move given a couple of hundred pounds/feet.

My favorite method is to pop a universal fitting and the appropriate socket
onto my impact wrench, crank the pressure up, and viola!  Pnuematic tools 
are so satisfying.

Humor?: The first time I used it, I confused myself as to which way was
"loosen" and "tighten".  I was using it to remove the steering rack cover
bolts...bzzzzzzt - POP! "Wow, it came right off! This wrench is indispensible,"
said I to myself.  Needless to say, the bolt sheared itself in half. 
At least I got more practice using the extractors...

Date: 17 May 95 08:18
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: Re: 911SC- Pedal bushings


[Text item: Text_1]
     I just changed these bushings last night on my 73 911.  Really not 
     rocket science, but there are quite a few parts.  I recommend getting 
     an exploded-view drawing of the assembly- I used the parts manual, 
     which worked fine.  
     
     The basic steps are: 
     
     1. Remove the brake master cylinder nuts (the pedal assembly has the 
     studs that hold the m/c).  You obviously need to get under the car for 
     this step.
     
     2. remove the board around the pedals and remove the accelerator pedal
     
     3. disconnect the accelerator and clutch cable linkages (one is a ball 
     socket, one is a fitting like the removable top of Bic pen)
     
     4. remove and re-bush the pedal assembly, and reinstall.
     
     I bought the individual parts from a dealer, although the shop I 
     normally use indicated that the available kits are fine.  My mechanic 
     asked 'did you get the plastic bushings?'  I replied that I had and he 
     said 'good'.  I didn't pursue the topic, but obviously there is some 
     disagreement on what's better.
     
     BTW, remember to spread bushing lube liberally on each set of 
     bushings.  Should keep the squeaks down for many years.  Hope this 
     helps, and hope I did it right!
     
     Jeff Jensen
     jcjensen@raychem.com
     73RS

others. You'll find it as good or better than all but one of the popular
Japanese models.

working.

one by today's standards. The new units are very good and IMO the styling
is a great match for the Porsche.

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 11:41:21 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: 911SC - Pedal Bushings

Blaine questioned..
>Well, my clutch pedal has started making a sound like a couple romping on

>1. The local dealer recommended bronze bushings.  Are these the same as
>advertised by Performance Products and others, or are there distinctions
>to be made?

I did the pedal bushings on a 73 about 4 mo ago. We opted to go with the
bronze bushings. There are 2 schools of thought on this. If you go with OEM
and you have a master cyc leak, you will know it. Probably be replacing 
booth! Then you won't feel it with the bronze bushings, and you won't 
(suposedly) be replacing them for *quite* a long time. If I am not mistaken,
the OEM bushings start to bind when they heat up, do when the car I did was 
cold there was no problem.

>2. How hard are these to install?  Hand tools and an hour or two, or
>nuclear physics degree and particle accelerators (howdy Maestro)?

This is a relative question. The job in it's self is not a hard one to 
accomplish. You take the whole pedal assembly out of the car. On the one
I did, I seem to remember banging with a hammer (no press available) for
quite a while. After it was dissasembeled, reassembly was a snap. Also we
soaked the bronze bushings in oil overnight. 

Would I do it again? You bet! It's your car and you will find (at least I 
do) great satisfaction in compleating this type of repair yourself. You will
also renew your satisfaction of the enginering necessary to build a vehicle
of it's class.
Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe

Date: 17 May 1995 18:04:33 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.com (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: T-look


> From: ehab@cisco.com (Ehab Aljandali)
> Subject: For Sale, 84 911 Targa Euro, Wanted Turb look 911..Long!
> I am going to put my beloved '84 911 on the market for sale in an
> effort to buy a factory Turbo body Targa, Cab or coupe.
 [snip]
> I am looking for a 84+ Factory Turbo look Targa, Cab or Coupe in
> that order. Most colors considered (not red, love it but cops love it
> more!).

Ehab,
You may remember that I owned a factory turbo-look 88 targa for several
years.  Beautiful car in diamond blue (lavender/silver) in near perfect
condition, in spite of the 120k miles it had.  Original clutch, engine,
paint, interior, etc.  12 disk CD, polished wheels, painted crests.  Great 
car.

A couple of things to keep in mind:
1 - These cars are heavier than non T-looks.  My wife's 89 coupe was a bit
faster (acceleration and high speed).  Aerodynamics are not as good (though
it was very stable at speed because of the wheels/tires, spoilers, etc.).
2 - The T-look option was $13.7k extra!  I advertised for a few weeks at
$28k.  Had very few nibbles.  One guy bit, and we settled at $26.5k.  I
figure the T-look added about $4k to the price.  You shouldn't pay more.
3 - Obviously these are harder to find.  Although the targa is rarer, I don't
like it as much.  Usual targa problems with noise and maintenance.  Nothing
beats a coupe for rigidity and a solid feel.  And this should be a high
priority for a T-look.
4 - The early factory T-looks (84 and 85, I believe -- check Bruce's
Performance Handbook) had welded on flares.  Porsche didn't make one piece
flares until 86.  Don't know if this matters to you (it probably shouldn't). 
I don't know if the pre-86's had smaller sway bars, like the regular
Carreras.  You might check this out.  I found the difference significant,
comparing my 84 to my wife's 89.
5 - The best thing about the T-look, short of its outrageous appearance, are
the brakes.  Only the 993 can compare.  Expect some squeal, maybe a lot (I
was lucky but I hear it is very common with drilled rotors).
6 - Do not settle for a conversion.  These usually have no more than flares
and miss out on the brakes and suspension upgrades.  They're also frequently
damaged (making the conversion a good option).  Conversions should sell for
less than a stock 911.  Stating the obvious, I guess.
7 - They don't have turbo tie-rods.  Strange.  Porsche must have saved about
$20.  I'd put them on if you're not concerned about SCCA class.

There are a couple advertised in today's San Jose paper.  One looks very
good.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T coupe, guards red
85 535i, grey (stealth car)

Date: 17 May 1995 10:21:43 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: spelling

Hi everyone!

You know, I really hate to nitpick (okay, I actually enjoy 
nitpicking) but...

When you use the pedal just left of the throttle, it's called:

      BRAKING

When you fail to use the same pedal and hit something it's called:

      BREAKING

Spell checkers only catch absolute misspellings.



- --Soren

lips carefully here gang) I say, *NOTHING* else even comes close!

and married her on Graduation day from Nose-picker U (at age 22), and divorced
9 months later.   Went to Dear old Deutschland, (Verliebt, Verlopt, Verheiratet,
Gescheiden) (freely translated, wham, bam, thankee 'mam, er...hoss) and got 
married and divorced 9 months later.  (Is there an echo in here...?)

My conclusion, upon reviewing this stuff at the tender age of 24 with two
divorces under my belt, was that I had a bug in my judgement algorithm,
not that there was anything wrong with ladies as a species, so I vowed to stay
single for the next 10 years to see if that would help.  Hoo boy!  Talk
about *help*...  I *still* haven't been able to shake that goofy grin from 10
years as a batchelor... and the last 21, married to Dora have been even
*better*!  (and guess who is the daily driver of the p-car, btw...)

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 14:36:45 -0400
From: David944@aol.com
Subject: Chocking on Gas Vapors in my 944

After two trips to the dealer, and my mechanic, my '84 944 is trying to kill
me.

I have had all of the fuel lines checked for leaks, and I still get an
overwhealming gas odor in the cabin of my car.  The problem usually occurs
after refueling the car.  As the temperature of the gas changes (problem
seems to go away when the weather cools, now that it's spring....), and the
fuel system is charged, I get some real positive air presure in the tank
(removing the gas cap creates a strong "woosh" of air).  On the occassion
that the odor appears after refueling, it will stay until the tank is about
1/2 empty.  I'm trying not to end up as a speeding molitov (sp??) cocktail.

Any thoughts?

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 14:44:57 -0400
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: going around corners faster

Martin writes-

"My understanding is that the important thing is not how fast you go around
the corner, but how quickly you can accelerate out of it".

 - not completely accurate - It is exit SPEED not acceleration that is
critical- if you scrub off excessive amounts of speed in sliding round a
corner you  will likely have a speed deficit versus another car that you
cannot overcome by earlier acceleration; ie by being at a point that you can
feed in power, say,  0.3  of a second sooner, but 15mph slower,  may do you
no good if you cannot make up the 15mph in 0.3 seconds. obviously there is a
tradeoff in there somewhere, but it has to be figured out for every turn of
every track under every condition - good luck.

Date: Wed, 17 May 95 14:49:52 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Chocking on Gas Vapors in my 944

> After two trips to the dealer, and my mechanic, my '84 944 is trying to kill
> me.
> 
> I have had all of the fuel lines checked for leaks, and I still get an

Obviously, you haven't found all of the fuel lines.

Have you checked the lines in the c pillar of the passenger side???

Have you replaced the gasket in the fuel gauge sender?

Have you pressurized the system (via compressed air) and listened for air
leaks?

If not, make an effort to do so.  I hate to buy cars that have been burned
to the ground...Can't get many good parts out of them... :-)
- --
Good luck,

Date: 17 May 1995 12:02:39 -0800
From: "Rodger Keesee" <Rodger.Keesee@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re: Chocking on Gas Vapors i

Hi Dave,  FWIW
My wife had the same ailment on her Sterling.  We chased it to the
purge/charcoal canister.  (As per Haynes trouble-shooting)  

It seems that when it was supposed to vent to the intake plenum (it was
clogged or something) and instead vented to the inside of the engine
compartment (or something).   [I hate talking about emissions stuff]

In any case, there is alot of hose carying fuel vapor around the car.

Rodger

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 15:05:18 -0400
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Chocking on Gas Vapors in...

You should get a whoosh from your tank -the fuel system is pressurised. 

Your problem may be the overflow pipe that runs from the filler neck. It is
directed  down into the cavity behind the right rear wheel arch and out
through the bottom of the bodywork. If that tube is missing, damaged or
dislodged, you could be pouring gas into the cavity. check it out, carefully
pour some liquid down the overflow  hole and trace where it comes out.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 13:22:59 -0700
From: jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com (jim gregory)
Subject: Re:  Belt anchor position

Be careful on the submarine belt location for your 944. If you put it right
at the midpoint of the seat, it will put you in the middle of the box that
strenghtens the unibody. You will want to move a little bit to the side
to avoid this.

 -jim

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 14:16:12 -0700 (MDT)
From: Wade Guthrie <wade@realm2.realm.net>
Subject: How much rust is too much?

I know that any rust on a 911 is bad, but I've had some trouble finding
cars that are COMPLETELY rust free.  So, I'd like to know the hierarchy
of rust damage.  I'd guess it to be something like (on an invented scale 
from 100 to -100):

	No Rust                                      100 pts
	A little under the doors (drain holes)        50 pts
	Edges of doors, hood, trunk, fuel filler      40 pts
	Some rust showing around the windshield       30 pts
	A bubble on one or more fenders               20 pts

	A bubble around the headlights                 0 pts

	Rust around the battery box(es)              -10 pts
	Rust under floor mats (interior or trunk)    -25 pts
	Jack Receiver, tortion bar tubes             -50 pts
	Pan                                          -75 pts
	Suspension pickups                          -100 pts

Any key areas that I forgot?  What does it cost to repair rust damage
like the things listed above?  

FWIW, I put some things lower because, for example, doors are easier to
replace than fenders and that rust around the jack receiver implies
structural rust.

Thanks!

- --

wade@realm.net             |  'em away"            from 'The Hudsucker Proxy'
http://www.realm.net/~wade |

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 17:48:10 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Falken tires??

I put a set of Falkens on my wife's Nissan Stanza (obligatory family car). 
The ones we got are only H rated, so take this with a grain of salt.  They
are very good in the wet, but their dry traction seems to be lacking.  I took
a familiar clover-leaf in the above car a little quicker than I should have
and scared myself to death as the tires broke loose *very* easily.

I'm kinda interested in this thread, too, as I have heard good things about
both of the tires mentioned above.

One questionable data point...

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 18:14:06 -0400
From: Haim Levkowitz <haim@cs.uml.edu>
Subject: US-JAPAN issues

 -> Date: Wed, 17 May 95 13:59:00 PDT
 -> From: Bill Ataras <Bill_Ataras@ccm.jf.intel.com>
 -> Sender: owner-mercedes@bga.com
 -> Precedence: bulk
 -> Reply-To: mercedes@bga.com
 ->
 -> Anyone think the lockout of Japanese luxo cars will affect Porsche or Mercedes 
 -> prices. (New or used) ??
 ->

I say, `you bet'!

Though it'll probably affect MB prices more than Porsche, because the
typical Porsche buyer is not the typical Lexus/Infiniti/Acura one.

If the Japanese luxo's double in price, NOBODY is going to buy them!
These people will shop elsewhere: MB, BMW, Volvo, and Saab are
probably going to be the main winners.

And of course, whenever new cars get more expensive, the corresponding
used ones also.

If you thought of trading in your x-year old whatever for a new MB,
say, but now it's more expensive, you'll postpone that trade-in (many
people will). As a result, there is one less used car in the market
for me to buy. So, less supply, (and more demand, because others who
may have planned on buying a new car, won't be able to afford one, and
might go for a used one), yields higher prices.

So, if you are in the market, and you believe that tariffs will be
imposed, go for it now (though an Infiniti dealer in today's Boston
Globe said ``this isn't the right way to sell a high end automobile''
but since I'm not selling any, .....)

- --L'Haim

(Haim Levkowitz, Editor, Tri-Angles, Minuteman Section MBCA)

haim@cs.uml.edu
http://www.cs.uml.edu/~haim/

1981 300SD (178K)

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 17:10:54 -0700 (PDT)
From: dough@netcom.com (Douglas Holtsinger)
Subject: 944/924 stereo setups


Since we're on the subject of CD players for 944s, I was curious to know
what types of stereo setups have worked well in 944/924s.  If people send
me enough responses, I'll provide a summary.

In my 84 944, I put in a Sony EXCD-60 CD player, Polk MM series 4x6 plates
in the front doors, Polk EX series 4x6 drivers in the rear side panels,
and a 10" Blau subwoofer in a vented bandpass enclosure sitting in the
hatch. A Blau amp with 20w x 4 plus one 50w sub output drives the system.

The midbass is lacking because the Polks only go down to about 120hz, but
they sound great otherwise.  I did have to snip away parts of the plastic
mounting plate to install them in the front and I couldn't get the stock
grilles to cover them.  I'm still looking for something to cover them up.
I found that the sub works best when the port is firing at the driver's 
side wall about 6" away from it; in any other position there's virtually 
no bass output.


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 21:47:29 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Brake piston seals and sizes

Peter,
My car a turbo/s has 928 front brakes with 4 pistons. there are two different
sizes for the front caliper and the part numbers are as follows. Larger
piston has seal # 20487248 with a 44mm piston diameter. Smaller is part #
20451372 with a 36mm piston diameter. I believe, but don't know for sure,
that the rear calipers use 36mm pistons all around as do the front calipers
on all other 944 turbo's except for the 88 S model and of course the 89's.
Boy if you could buy these without having to buy the whole kit you could
start your own cottage industry.
Good Luck and many thanks.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 20:16:59 EDT
From: MDJS51A@prodigy.com ( KARL E HAUG)
Subject: 944 Gas Fumes

The '84 944 has a fuel overflow drain at the bottom of the gas filler
pocket, just below the filler opening.  Fuel overflow is drained to the
ground by a tube which seats into the bottom of the pocket with a grommet.
It's easy to dislodge the grommet when you're drying the car.  This lets
any fuel overflow enter the interior of the car.  It stinks for a while,
then evaporates.

The fix is to replace the grommet.  This can be done by removing the
plastic vent grille in the lock post and using a coathanger (or whatever),
manipulating the tube/grommet until you can snag it from above and pull it
back where it belongs.  Not easy, but do-able.

If this is too much for you, simply plug the hole with something and be
careful not to dribble fuel when you gas up.

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 19:18:01 -0700
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: US-JAPAN issues

>Anyone think the lockout of Japanese luxo cars will affect Porsche or Mercedes 
>prices. (New or used) ??

Well, speaking as the employee of a Porsche/Mercedes/BMW/Audi/Rover dealership (parts 
dep't), we were discussing it a little today...

First off, there is no lockout. There IS a "proposed" 100% tariff on thirteen 
Japanese luxury cars - no more, no less. Obviously, that means double the prices. 
>From what I've heard around the grapevine (we have affiliated Acura, Honda, and Mazda 
dealerships), sales of Acuras have been very brisk since the news story, and I'd 
assume it's the same for the other dealerships.

Infiniti is hurting bad anyways - they air-freight all parts for all customers, which 
is not cheap. They had Infiniti loaners - which means that they have old loaners with 
10-15K miles on 'em that are difficult to sell. They have nice cars, but somehow 
they've never caught on. (I've always like Infiniti more than Lexus - probably 
because I have an irrational dislike of Toyota.)

It probably would mean destruction for Infiniti, possibly for Lexus, and maybe even 
for Acura. However, it'd probably be GREAT for dealerships like ours - why buy an 
enormously expensive Japanese sedan, when you can buy a quality German sedan or coupe 
(the "real thing") for much less? I don't have numbers to back it up, but I'm going 
to guess that a Mercedes customer is going to be a lot more loyal than an Acura 
customer. Few people say "only an Acura will do!"

I doubt it'll affect Porsche at all - I don't think it'll affect anyone else's 
pricing, but it's certainly potentially good news for German cars.

Frankly, I'd be stunned if it ever went through, though - I'm sure it's just a scare 
to try to get Japan to "play ball", and if they do tariff them, it'll be a LOT less 
than 100%. Time will tell...

- --

| jeffk914@ix.netcom.com                        Do the dumb things        |
| Scottsville, NY, USA                                  I gotta do."      |
| "Katarina" 1975 Porsche 914                       -They Might Be Giants |

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 20:07:02 -0800 (PDT)
From: John Wright <jpw@reebok.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Robert Wood

Re posting excerpted below:

>Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 16:48:11 -0700
>From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)

>You may recall that last night I posted a comment re: a Design 90 wheel for
>sale to Robert Wood (the company in L.A.).  I was irked that they would only
> give me $125 for the wheel.
>Earlier today someone of the Porsche Persuassion suggested I call Robert
>Wood re:  their selling of the same wheel, 
>i.e. how much would they sell it for?
>Well, They would sell the wheel to me for $300.00.  Now,  I imagine it must be
>MUCH better than the wheel that I have, but is it worth $175 more?
>By the way, the wanted phonedial would cost $250, and no, they won't trade.
>So, there is your answer.  Although it's Business 101, I still think it sucks
>to have to deal with people like them.  So I won't.

This posting has been handled ably by a couple others, but I want to comment
anyway.

As someone that used to sell auto parts over the counter, one touchy situation
was when a customer wanted to sell the store a NOS spare part they had
lying around.

Invariably, the customer paid retail, bought it a long time ago, and had no 
receipt or bought it from a competitor.

They didn't seem to appreciate that the retailer, if he WANTS the part at all,
will certainly pay no more than wholesale for the part.

And wholesale is probably considerably less than the customer paid, if the 
business is being run for profit.

In fact, there is no reason to pay wholesale price to an "off the street
supplier" since industry wholesalers will usually accept returned parts, honor 
warrantees, provide credit and possibly give quantity discounts for larger 
orders. 

So, a "business" reasonable offering price might be customer viewed as 
"insulting".

So as a rule, the store I worked in NEVER bought NOS/used parts from a customer.

It wasn't worth the trouble and possible customer bad will.

But, at the right price, the transaction MIGHT have left both customer and 
store better off.

Businesses dealing in used parts are operating under the same constraints,
except they also will usually buy parts, AT WHOLESALE, from retail customers.

I'd guess that Robert Wood's offer of $125 for your wheel is what he
has learned over the years is a reasonable, for him, wholesale price.

Someone else might pay more, but this price attracts an adequate inventory for
him.

It's nothing personal, and judging from the years Wood has been in business,
he makes sound pricing decisions at both the wholesale and retail end.

I've bought wheels from him and had no complaints.

>p.s. I was quoted 2 different prices for BOTH wheels on 2 different calling 
>occassions.

This is not unexpected.  

There is no "correct" or "fair" price, only an estimated current market price.

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 17 May 95 12:33:01 -0400
From: "THOMAS R BRITTON" <britton@a1.esvax.umc.dupont.com>
Subject: RE: 951 sunroof problem


Yea, it's easy.

	If your sunroof is lifting up and down the motor is OK. Your 
problem is the microswitch back at the motor cam. Check to see if it's 
closed when the sunroof is closed, if the switch is open you'll have 
to adjust it until it closes. Then the sunroof lifters will retract so 
you can remove the sunroof. Warning, if your slip clutch on the 
sunroof motor is not adjusted to SLIP, the motor is strong enough to 
break the plastic teeth right off the gear lifters at the lifting 
bars. A couple hundred $ -no way- do it your self. I realize the older 
944's have a different set-up back at the motor, but I saved myself 
$250 -dealer quote, almost enough to pay for my factory manuals!!!

Good luck.
Tom Britton
88 Turbo S

Date: Wed, 17 May 1995 23:48:42 -0400
From: BeaulieuB@aol.com
Subject: Re: Falken tires?? YES!

Dear Casey, I have an '86 928 with Faulken 05G's. (225/50/16's) I have been
VERY pleased with them.  The prior set were Firestone Firehawks, which were
ok on dry roads, but the worst on wet roads. I had NO wet traction at all.
 When I looked for replacements, the Faulken's were highly recommeded. The
dry traction is excellent and the wet traction is the best I've had.  My next
set will be Faulken's unless someone can convince me Pirelli P7's are
better... Bryson.

Date: Wed, 17 May 95 21:15:19 PDT
From: steve@pyramid.com (Stephen Chan)
Subject: Re: Antennas

Jerry,

I have installed Imparts Harada antennas in both my '81 911SCs with 
no problem. However, an owner of a car stereo store once mentioned
to me that the factory antenna was superior because the factory
antenna had a waterproof body while the Harada was not as waterproof.  
However, I have had no problem with my Harada antennas yet.

In addition, I found the Harada antenna to have a smaller body than the 
factory antenna.  

Steve

'81 911SC Coupe (Platinum Metallic)
'81 911SC Widebody Coupe (Black and almost ready for the street again)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 00:29:37 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 356 Wheel Paint

> 'Tis time to replace the tires on my 64 356 Cab.  (Father-in-law put them 
> on about 15 years ago!)  I plan to repaint the wheels while the tires are 
> off and am looking for recommendations for the silver paint with which to 
> do it.  Current paint is in good shape, but is showing its age.  Thanks.

Paint is easy, tires are harder...

Use the Wurth silver lacquer, or there's some Corvette paint from a
recent vintage that also works well. I also have with some success used
powder coating, although not on 356s.

For the concours  tire look, there is always the "new" CN36s that you
can get from Eurotire in NJ. They're built on P6 carcasses, so they're
not completely the same as the old tires....

For better street performance, I dunno... I'm looking hard at AVS Intermediates
for my next set of tires (which I need now thanks to a failed front trailing
arm bushing). The A-509s are also attractive, as are AVS U+4s.

Stan

assume, if you can afford a Porsche, you can afford PCA... BTW, in order 
to join PCA, you must be the owner of a VIN number from any Porsche... 
(ie. the car, frame, at its most basic level)

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 09:02:53 -0400
From: Lou@GreenMtnSW.com (Lou Krieg)
Subject: Re: WD40:is there anything it _isn't_ good for

>WD40:is there anything it _isn't_ good for?

Anything with a live electrical connection....WD40 is flammable.

When I worked in the Boston area, one of our techs got a bad burn when he
sprayed WD-40 into a live electrical circuit (not sure what--some home
appliance) and it ignited and flashed back in his face! Close call, but he
recovered OK.

I have heard that there are non-flammable penetrants; anyone know for sure?

- --Lou

Lou Krieg                         '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
PCA Green Mountain Region         '90 VW Corrado G60 Tornado Red

Date: Thu, 18 May 95 10:24:55 EDT
From: "Bill Elwell" <B.Elwell@zds.com>
Subject: Re[1]: 87 944 sunroof problem


Paul Murphy writes:

>i would appreciate some help with my sunroof operation(or 
>lack of it). i do understand how to work it, but recently
>one of the curved "prongs" is not moving(driver's side)
>preventing the sunroof from opening. I can hear the motor
>working but to no avail. has anyone had this problem?

Yes, Paul I too have had this problem.  In a nutshell, the sunroof is 
operated by a motor over the driver side rear wheel.  A flexible cable 
runs to two small boxes in the roof of the car.  These boxes each have 
a plastic gear that translates motion of the cable to motion of the 
curved "prongs" that raise the roof.

It is very common for these plastic gears to strip.  Most Porsche 
parts places keep a healthy supply of those gears (thanks to their 
demand).

I will let someone else describe the repair procedure.  Yes, I did fix 
mine when they broke, but there has to be an easier way than the way I 
did it or the way the shop manual suggests that it be done.  If you 
really want, contact me directly and I will attempt a description of 
my procedure.

Bill Elwell
b.elwell@zds.com

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 08:48:24 -0500
From: bmidkiff@spd.state.ar.us (Brian Midkiff)
Subject: Re: 924S

>>On Wed, 17 May 1995, Brian Midkiff wrote:
>>
>>I am seriously considering buying a 1988 924S and would like to solicit any
>>advice from this group re: problems, suggestions, etc.

>Well, aside from the fact that they didn't make the 924 in 1988... :) The 
>944 maybe? or a 1978 924?
>
>-Derek Cahill
>

Thank you Scott Sanda.  A few more details.  The 924S was produced from
1987-1988 (one source says 1986-1988, anybody know why? Europe maybe?) as an
entry level porsche.  Base prices for 1987 and 1988 were $19,900 and $25,000
respectively, compared to $25,500 and $29,000 for the standard 944.  It had
the 944 underpinnings, including drivetrain, in a body more aerodynamic than
the the 944.  It came standard with a nice group of equipment including
sunroof, a/c, power windows, etc.  It proved to be slightly faster than the
944 because it was lighter and more aerodynamic.

I was really interested in comments from this group regarding overall
reliability and things to watch for.  Since then I have received the 924/944
FAQ which proved to be very informative.  Thanks for all the quick replies.

Brian

P.S.  Please ignore the signature on the original message.  I was merely
testing my e-mail software, and the only quote I could come up with was a
saying by my old college roommate.  I hope I didn't offend anyone.

Date: Thu, 18 May 95 09:00:30 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Yoko A-509



Funny you should ask about the A-509. Seem to work quite well, wet or dry. One
nice point, they ride better than the AVS over expansion joints. 

Anyway, I am using 205/55 VR 16 on my 924 and they have excellent grip. The 
market the tires are intended for is a notch below gonzo street. SO these work 
as intended for non-track and autocross tires. I have maybe 2500 miles on them,
so it's early for wear info.

Jim Pasha

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 12:19:48 -0400
From: asdunn@nytimes.com (Ashley Dunn)
Subject: marelli distributor on 71 T

   I have a 71T with a marelli distributor. One of the centrifigal advance
weights is held close to the distributor shaft by its spring. I assume this
weight is responsible for advancing the spark at higher rpms. The other
weight, however, isn't held back by the spring until it spins fairly far out
from the shaft. The spring is loose against the weight and exerts no
pressure until the weight has spun out a ways. Is this normal?  It seems
strange to me that one of the weights in the distributor is spinning loose.

Date: Thu, 18 May 95 09:32:31 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: antennas

In response to the below question:

        I bought the "Harada imitation Hirschman" from Imparts last year.
Upon receipt, I peeled off the Harada sticker, and it said something else,
made in Korea underneath the Harada sticker :(  Turns out it's an imimtation
Harada!  So I go to install it anyway.  It doesn't work.  I tried it with
clip leads to the battery and it still didn't work.  So I returned it to
Imparts for a refund, no questions asked (I've always had good service from
Imparts).

        I bought a Hirschman at a local shop, and it works great.  The relay
in the fender is identical.  It was easier to use the old relay with the new
antenna, so I have a spare relay.

        Having done this, I ripped apart (disassembled) the old Hirschman.
I was able to clean it up (terrible crud inside) and now it works also (a
spare).

        All Hirschmanns are not equal.  M-Bs have the top-of-the-line
Hirschmann, which is much nicer (and heavier) than the one from the Porsche.
BTW, I found no Japanese, Korean, Chineese, Malaysian, Taiwanese,
Yugoslavian, Mongolian, or whatever markings on any of the Hirschmanns.

Bob

> order to allow me to join PCA.

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 12:05:31
From: DENNIS DEEDS <5010.4218@trader.com>
Subject: Value of joining PCA & 914 O.A.

PCA and the 914 Owners Association are two good ways to get a wide variety 
of information about the 914.  PCA publishes a monthly magazine that 
covers all P cars.  Of special value is the ad section in the back.  
Annual fee is $36.
The 914 Owners Association and 914-6 Club USA has been around since 1978, 
publishes a quarterly magazine (approximately 160 pages of 914 information 
per year), and holds an annual Reunion for 914 owners and their cars.  
Information in issues includes 914 history, maintenance, classified ads, 
discounts from major suppliers, and restoration.  Annual fee is $22
If your budget allows, join both organizations.  You can contact the 914 
OA at: 100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116; Palm Springs, CA 92262.N          
                                                                           
Dennis Deeds 5010.4218@trader.com                                          
914-6
944

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 10:18:58 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: 924S

About the year of the 924S:  It was introduced in spring 1986 and put
on sale that summer, but as an 87 model.  In terms of how the German
model years run, it would actually be an 86 1/2.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 10:28:53 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: A boy, his 914 and his 1st Pano

> after anxiously waiting for my first Pano, I am a bit disappointed. Sort
>of >reminded me of Excellence, lots of neat articles and ads for 911s,
>944s, etc,
>but almost no 914 content.

Consider the following:

1. The 914 has been out of production for nearly 20 years.
2. The 914 was not heavily campaigned as a race car by the factory.
3. The 914 does not have many "special" cars associated with it.

Due to these facts, there is not going to be as much content as you will
find for models currently in production or famous race cars. Nor are there
a lot of historically significant versions of the 914.

Sure, there is the 914-6 GT that did quite well at Le Mans one year. Yes,
there are a few 916's and two 914-8's. But this about it.

The 914 is special for many other reasons but none of these reasons make
for great articles. Unless of course they're articles that discuss how
to make them great autocross or time trial cars. Often faster than their
911 counterparts for a lot less money.

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 14:53:49 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: 356 Wheel Paint

> 'Tis time to replace the tires on my 64 356 Cab.  (Father-in-law put them 
> on about 15 years ago!)  I plan to repaint the wheels while the tires are 
> off and am looking for recommendations for the silver paint with which to 
> do it.  Current paint is in good shape, but is showing its age.  Thanks.

Stan replies,

>For the concours  tire look, there is always the "new" CN36s that you
>can get from Eurotire in NJ. They're built on P6 carcasses, so they're
>not completely the same as the old tires...

Many of the 356Cs were delivered with Dunlop SPCB57s, a fabric-belted radial
(and a great tire) that is no longer available.  I have found the Dunlop SP4
to be close in appearance and a reasonable approximation of the CB57's
handling characteristics.  The correct size is 165-15 (if memory serves me
correctly, that's a 75 or 80 aspect ratio).

If correct appearance is important to you, stick to 165-15s.  If improved
performance is more important, look at tires with lower aspect ratios
(they'll be of more modern design).

BTW, this is one of the few instances in Porschedom where being correct is
less expensive than being incorrect!

Bob Joyce
Knoxville, Tennessee
1965 356SC
1099 924S

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 14:42:49 -0600 (CST)

The original Dunlop SPCB57 on my 356C spare is a 165-15. JMB

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 15:36:29 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Distributor & Electrical question

        To Tim (T.J.) Murphy:  My mail to you bounces.  Sorry for the
bandwidth, everyone else.

        Tim:  I would suggest you leave the seatbelt warning mechanism
disconnected.  Not only is the buzzer annoying, but the system will not
let you start the car without the seatbelts fastened!  Talk about annoy-
ing!
        I also suggest you check the Haynes book, p. 174.  This is a
wiring diagram for the 1974 US-spec cars.  It is actually incorrect for
both of my 74's as well as yours--it indicates a warning relay with in-
tegrated buzzer, and no external buzzer.  Ours have that.  The buzzer
fits in the smaller socket on the right.  So we start guessing.  Also
check the 73 diagram on p. 164.
        The socket, or at least the relay itself, should have raised/
printed numbers & letters on it.  These numbers/letters correspond to
the labels on the connections on the diagram.


>              VIEW FROM BACK WHERE WIRES CONNECT
>
>                     +-----------------------------grey/green-------+
>                     |                                              |
>                     |  green/white  brown                          |
>                     |   |white      |brown                         |
>                     |   ||          ||                             |
>                     |   || black    ||                             |
>                     |   ||  |       ||                             |
>+----------------+   |   ||  |   ?1  ||                             |
>|                |   |   ||  |   |   ||                             |
>|              +=|===|===||==|===|===||+                        +===|===+
>|              # *   *   *   *   *   * #                        #   *   #
>|              #                       #                        #       #
>| yellow/white---*                   *---green/red  brown/white---*   *----+
>|       yellow--/                     \--green/red              #       #  |
>|              # *   *   *   *   *   * #                        #   *   #  |
>|              +=|===|===|===|===|===|=+                        +===|===+  |
>|                |   |   |   |   |   |                              |      |
>|               ?2   |   |   |   ?3  grey                       grey/brown |
>|                    |   |   |                                             |
>|            green/white |   yellow/red                                    |
>|                        |                                                 |
>+---------black----------+-------------------------------------------------+
>                         |
>                         |
>                         ?4
>
>Wires remaining to be connected:
> - yellow/white (small connector, I believe this connects to ?2)

        There are two YW/WH wires listed on the diagram.  They go to and
from the right seat belt switch.  (Like the GR/WH wires go to the left
seat belt switch.)  Should be a 2-connector, I think.  One of the wires
is hooked to the relay socket at the same place as the yellow wire that
comes from the right seat pressure switch.  This should be labeled "SB".
The other one should be labeled "GB".

> - black & black/red twisted together (connector cut off)

        The BK and BK/RD wires connect together at the socket.  The BK/
RD wire goes to the interior light, the black one to the clock in the
console, if you have any.  The connector should be labeled "30".

> - 2*brown/yellow (small connector)

        One of the BR/YW lines goes to the parking brake switch.  The
other goes to the brake warning switch and the warning light.  These
two wires are directly connected to each other at the relay socket, so
so it doesn't matter which goes where.  (I think.)  Label should be "A".


        I don't think I want to speculate what goes on the unknown tabs.
I can guess that the black wire at #4 goes eventually to fuse 9, but if
I'm wrong, you could fry your relay or worse.
        If you can't puzzle out what's happening from this and the Haynes
diagram, I'll try ckecking through the spaghetti under my 1.8's seat--
but it may not help much, as the interlock/etc. has been disabled on it
as well.

        Good luck!

- --DD

Dave Darling                            + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov




------------------------------


Porschephiles #1413                         Fri May 19 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 18 May 95 14:02:41 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Alternator Light


Peter,

Porsche alternators have a failure mode where one diode goes bad, thereby
lowering the true output potential below the minimum requred for adequate
charging. Do have your battery checked to ensure that all cells are good and 
the specific gravity of the electrolyte is correct.

The one diode drops the voltage enough so the battery discharges, but is not 
catestrophic enough to make the light come on at full intensity.

I had one fail on my '73 911S when the car was only 6 months old.

Jim Pasha

same treatment.

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 18:19:42 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : US-JAPAN trade issues

Bill Ataras <Bill_Ataras@ccm.jf.intel.com> asked :

>Anyone think the lockout of Japanese luxo cars will affect Porsche or
>Mercedes prices. (New or used) ??

I guarantee that Porsche prices will not be affected, and will bet that
even Japanese luxury cars will not be affected. The Japanese (and/or
their American lawyers) are very clever, and will find a way so continue
selling cars. Remember the "truck" surcharge - then all Japanese trucks
grew 2 more doors so they were considered "cars" and 2-doors were
built here. In the worst case, they will spread the higher prices over the
whole lines (Toyotas and Nissans). Then probably the US companies will
again raise their prices, like when the Yen started rising... and lose a
great price advantage again.

Why can't we be as clever in selling our stuff in Japan? We should be
able to set up distribution there and get around their laws and "customs".
I have been able to do this on a very small level, and Toys-R-Us has on a
much
greater level, why can't the big three?

Regards, Mike Piera (Mr. Ayako) '72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0

Sorry for the small Porsche content, but this bugs me!

Date: 18 May 1995 17:23:14 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.com (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: 911 lid shocks

Last night I installed new lid shocks, front and back, in my 73.  I'm used to
having to do this every couple of years but it's always an adventure.  The
front driver's side is where the excitement lies, unless you're fingers are
10 penny skinny and hot dog long.

The engine lid strut seems to be too strong.  Not only does the lid, when
closed, sit too high on the driver's side (and too low on the left) but when
I release the lid it springs open fully with a jolt!   These are not the
double strut shocks and the lid is stock (not fiberglass) without a tail. 
The shock is new (it has an Automotion rec'd date of 5-15-95) and looks
normal in every way.

Any thoughts on why this is?  Maybe I ought to look into those rachet-type
mechanical ones advertised in Excellence.  Are they available for the rear? 
I liked the front one I used on another car.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T coupe, guards red
85 535i, grey

Subject: RE : US-JAPAN trade issues
Author:  AnalogMike@aol.com at SMTP

Bill Ataras <Bill_Ataras@ccm.jf.intel.com> asked :
     
>Anyone think the lockout of Japanese luxo cars will affect Porsche or 
>Mercedes prices. (New or used) ??
     
I guarantee that Porsche prices will not be affected, and will bet that 
even Japanese luxury cars will not be affected. The Japanese (and/or 
their American lawyers) are very clever, and will find a way so continue 
selling cars. Remember the "truck" surcharge - then all Japanese trucks 
grew 2 more doors so they were considered "cars" and 2-doors were
built here. In the worst case, they will spread the higher prices over the 
whole lines (Toyotas and Nissans). Then probably the US companies will 
again raise their prices, like when the Yen started rising... and lose a 
great price advantage again.
     
Why can't we be as clever in selling our stuff in Japan? We should be
able to set up distribution there and get around their laws and "customs". 
I have been able to do this on a very small level, and Toys-R-Us has on a 
much
greater level, why can't the big three?
     
Regards, Mike Piera (Mr. Ayako) '72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0
     
Sorry for the small Porsche content, but this bugs me!

Well, some interesting responses to my Harada inquiry.  Suffice it to 
say, some folks appear to have had better luck than others.  Just for the 
heck of it I looked at my current Hirschmann and I see a stamped "Made in 
W. Germany" on the outside, so I don't know where Imparts got their "made 
in Japan" info.  On the off chance I don't need to replace the whole 
thing (thanks for all the diagnostics guys), here's the scoop.  Mast is 
about half way up.  Does not move at all when radio/power turned on/off.  
Getting down close to the wheel well, when my wife clicks the key over to 
where the radio comes on, I hear a "click" in the wheel well and that's 
it.  Same thing when she powers off.  Am I correct that this means the 
motor is burned out and the entire unit must be replaced?  (BTW, I tried 
some WD-40 to see if it was just a lubricant problem.  Someone asked what 
can"t WD-40 do?  Well, it didn't repair the burned out motor! :-) )

forward info I receive to others.  If anyone has a problem with my doing

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 18:20:31 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 Rocker Panels

        I was forcibly reminded the other day of one important part
of cleaning and/or maintenance for all 914 owners:  The rocker panels.
        All 914 owners should remove the three screws or bolts (stock
is 8mm with a slot as well) that hold the bottom of the outer rocker
panel onto the car.  Pull the bottom of it out a bit.  Be astounded
at the quantity of crap that falls out.  Then take a small-ish blunt
instrument, and lightly scrape along the inner rocker all around the
jack-point.  You'll be even more amazed at even more crap falling out.
        Dirt and such (don't ask what!) gets picked up by the tires,
tossed around in the wheel well, and then gets funneled forward to the
rockers.  The jack point stops most of it, but not all.  Some goes
further forward until it hits a rib on the inner rocker.
        The dirt itself isn't too much of a problem--it's that the
dirt gets wet, and then doesn't dry out.  That holds water against the
inner rockers.  Which leads to rust, which leads to the good ol' flexy
flier syndrome.
        Do your 914 a favor *today*!  Open up and clean out those
rockers!

- --DD

Dave Darling                            + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 20:43:30 -0400
From: L8Apexer@aol.com
Subject: FYI 951 clutch problem

I've seen several comments about this so here's my .02 cents.  89 951 with
34k miles, about 45-50 drivers schools.  Last school was Easter weekend 95 no
problems.  After got home with car cold tranny locked up ie would not go into
any gear.  Finally got into second and limped to shop.  Guess what, worked
fine!  Brought home and drove without problem several days then locked up
again!  Mechanic questioned driver!  Slave new 1 yr ago and master looked
good.  Clutch pressure felt ok.  Bottom line-small springs near center of
clutch were disintegrating and intermittantly jamming clutch and disc.Also,
non turbo 944s use different clutch with rubber center and will give same
symptoms due to the rubber breaking up.  Hope this helps although its
painful.  Appreciate any other input.
L8Apexer-John Lochner

Date: Thu, 18 May 95 18:25:13 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: More Antennas

} From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School"  
<macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
}
} Well, some interesting responses to my Harada inquiry.  Suffice it to
} say, some folks appear to have had better luck than others.  Just for the
} heck of it I looked at my current Hirschmann and I see a stamped "Made in
} W. Germany" on the outside, so I don't know where Imparts got their "made
} in Japan" info.  On the off chance I don't need to replace the whole
} thing (thanks for all the diagnostics guys), here's the scoop.  Mast is
} about half way up.  Does not move at all when radio/power turned on/off.
} Getting down close to the wheel well, when my wife clicks the key over to
} where the radio comes on, I hear a "click" in the wheel well and that's
} it.  Same thing when she powers off.  Am I correct that this means the
} motor is burned out and the entire unit must be replaced?  (BTW, I tried
} some WD-40 to see if it was just a lubricant problem.  Someone asked what
} can"t WD-40 do?  Well, it didn't repair the burned out motor! :-) )

The Hirschmann antenna on my 944 was only extending 3 of the 4 sections,
so I took it apart to see what could be done. In the process, I discovered that
there is a small circuit board that controls the motor. Most likely a current
limiting switch to turn the motor off at the end of its travel. So, it could be
this circuit board rather than the motor that is bad. The circuit board
might be repairable by someone who knew some electronics.

In my case, I lubed everything with graphite and it now works fine. I don't
think that WD-40 is a good idea here; dirt will stick to the oily areas and
then things will get gummed up.

    Eric

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 22:33:34 -0400
From: Mrbill456@aol.com
Subject: Early 911 Battery Boxes(long)

Nick asked about ways to remediate damage from battery spills. 

The best thing to do is rinse the area liberally. This will take a lot of
patientce. If the problem battery is on the passenger side you will be much
better off as you are further from the multitude of electrical connectors and
components located in the vicinity of the driver's side battery.

I do not think using baking soda or some other base (as in acid-base
chemistry) to neutralize the acid is a good idea. Base reacts with acid to
make salts. In the case of car batteries you make sufates. Salts are known to
catalyze rust. So, if you neutralize the residual spilled acid with base then
you just have to rinse the salt residual off anway. The white stuff you see
is likely to be lead sufate and iron sulfate.

I'm not taken with the idea of using a wire brush. It seems to me this would
just spread corrosive dust around everywhere.

I would tape plastic bags (newer dry cleaning bags should do fine) in
position to protect any electrical connetors/components. Then I would rinse,
rinse .... and when I  was completely out of patience I would rinse some
more. You can not over do the rinsing.

You could use several sponges or just old wet rags. Whatever you use will be
completely worthless when you are done. You should wear disposable clothes
(the kind your wife likes to toss behind the washing mahine when you aren't
looking) and safety glases.  Perhaps you can figure out how to spray a
moderate stream of water in the area and let it drain out the pan. Warm water
will dissolve the salts quicker but this may not be worth the trouble.
Whatever you can think of to dilute and dissolve the acid/salts will work.
Don't forget to rinse off the undercarridge as well before you quit. This is
quite a bit easier because the garden hose will do the job.

Let things dry overnight and see of any white residue reappears. If it does
repeat the process. When the white residue does not comeback after a week.
The spray the area with a heavy dose of WD-40. I would not paint yet.

I would reexamine this area every few months and look for new signs of
corrosion (white powder). Then I would rinse and reapply WD-40. Sooner or
later you will have rinsed away all of the acid and salt. Then you can paint
as you see fit. I think it would cause trouble to paint before you were sure
the area was acid/salt free. 

I liberally spray my 71E's battery boxes with WD-40 at least twice a year
after a good cleaning/rinsing. When I got the car the battery box areas were
in excellent shape and I aim to keep them this way.

I know this sounds like an ordeal. I guess the only thing worse would be to
have to install a new trunk floor pan. 

Let us know what you decide to do and how it comes out.

Best wishes,

Bill Hutton
1971 911E coupe #0038

Date: Thursday, 18 May 1995 8:39pm MT
From: MARTENS%STKWWHDQ@ccsvm.stortek.com
Subject: RE: FALKENs

Pfilers,
originally had P600's on, Good dry Better Wet.
(always woke up with a flat spot that took 4 miles to heat out)
Then changed to Yokohama's AVS Intermediates
                          Better Dry, Good Wet, mileage 35000 kms.
Last swapped to Falken's FK06G's Good Dry, Good Wet,
                but very noisy on freeways.  Mileage unknown yet.
Track tyres (that is the way we spell it here in Oz)
                Yokahama A008RS  Excellent Dry, Very Good Wet.
                mileage limited, read Hard Track Use.
Comparison to Bridgestone 520S, last weekend track time, Bridgestone
very soft, rubber was scalloping to the outside, and very insestitive
to steering input, felt mushy, also squealed badly.  Yokies came up
with flying colours, 1 second per lap quicker around Lakeside Qld.
Tyres less noisy (on the road sound like diff whine) and also
more responsive letting you know the real limits of their adhesion,
Joe Martens
'86 944
bits of a 906.

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 23:52:38 -0600 (CST)
From: JMB@wuchem.wustl.edu
Subject: antenna lube

Learn from my mistakes, DO NOT use WD-40 or any such substance to 
lubricate an electric antenna, use graphite as was suggested. Not thinking
one day, or is that every day, I quickly used some liquid stuff on one, I
believe Sli*k-5* which comes in the little orange can with the pump on top.
Needless to say it worked great for about 3months until it gummed up and
burned out the electronics. Had to take it apart and replace some of them.
Jonathan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 18 May 1995 22:05:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: engine compartment pad

Dear Mike,

Definitely don't leave it in pieces.  These can get in your air intake
where they'll certainly do no good.  You might put some plastic
sheeting on the engine and do what you can to get the old pad off.  If
it's in pieces, it will just crumble off.  Then you can clean the area
with an oil-based solvent.  A new pad costs about $50, and IMHO is
worth installing.  It certainly will make the passenger compartment
quieter and somewhat cooler.  It's just foam with a hard surface and
doesn't weigh much.

I waited until mine needed a new clutch disc.  It's hard to do it
right with the engine in the car.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

Porschephiles #1414                         Fri May 19 13:05:02 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 03:56:51 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Scott Winders reply RE: A boy, his 914 etc.

> >eloquently asked, Can't we all just be friends?:-)                         

Sure we can. As long as everyone believes like I do... 8{)

> P.S.  I do belive the first ones had their engines in the back.

Well, it depends on how you count "first ones". The original prototype
of the 356 was a mid-engine car. And it *IS* a damned shame that the
production run switched to rear-engine. (The *production* 356s were
all rear-engined.) The "really neat" prototype racers -- the 550s, the 90x, 
for all positive even x < 10, the 917, 956, 962, etc -- were mid engined.

Suffice it to say I've got three non-event related Porsche T-shirts
hanging in my closet:

* "Sure they made Porsches after 1965 but who the hell cares?"
   caption under a collection of 356 pictures

* "Sure they made Porches that weren't mid-engined but who the hell cares?"
   caption under a prominent 914, with 917, 904, 550 in the background

* "Porsches should only have water in them when it rains"
  caption under picture of 550, Speedster, 914, 911 Cab

That doesn't mean I don't like the rest -- I just have my preferences.
As, I'm sure, do we all. What I can't wait for is Winders -- who's really
one of the Good Guys, BTW -- to get a ride in a hot, well setup, prepared
to the limit 914...

Stan

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 08:26:11 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: 1995 Zone 1 Concours/Swap meet May 20/21

Location: Parsippany Hilton in Parsippany, NJ 
 
>From Manhattan: Take Holland Tunnel to NJ, NJ Turnpike to Exit 14, Rt 78W,
Rt 24W, Rt 287N go 1 exit to 39B, Rt 10W, Hilton should be a mile up on the
right 
 
1 hour from Manhattan 
 
Swap meet: You can register to sell on-site. $25 for 2 days.
Pre-registration would have bought you a better spot. 
 
Concours: Saturday is prep day. Check the weather forecast first. Sunday is
judging. 
 
Time: About 7:30am to 2pm each day. Of course, all the best choices will be
at 7:00am on Saturday as everyone is setting up. Unless the other sellers
are as likely to sleep late as me.... 
 
**********My 2 cents************ 
US-Japan 
Lexus and Infiniti sold their products at below cost when they first opened
dealerships in the US in order to gain market share. The cars were much
more expensive in Japan. What makes anybody think that they want to lose
this market share? I would guess that they will reduce the wholesale price
(that's what the 100% tariff will apply to) so that the dealers can
continue to sell the cars at the same price. So long as they can keep their
dealers in business and keep their customers happpy and keep the assembly
lines rolling, they will do so. The money can be partially recouped from
the dealers in other ways which are not directly linked to new car imports.
Of course there are always unscrupulous dealers and there are suckers born
every minute..... 
********End of 2 cents, no change********* 
- -- 
Triet Le

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 08:35:21 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com

" ...Base prices for 1987 and 1988 were $19,900 and $25,000
respectively, compared to $25,500 and $29,000 for the standard 944.  It had
the 944 underpinnings, including drivetrain, in a body more aerodynamic than
the the 944.  It came standard with a nice group of equipment including
sunroof, a/c, power windows, etc...."

It also came in at least one Special Edition (of 500 units), with the M030
suspension, manual windows and seats, distinctive upholstery, and no sunroof,
intended for club sport racing.  The list for this one was about $28,800.

My car (the SE above) has been extremely reliable: repairs have included the
usual oil-cooler seal, a new water pump, new cam housing seal,and a rebuilt
starter, all in 74k miles.

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 08:38:02 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: More Antennas

>Learn from my mistakes, DO NOT use WD-40 or any such substance to 
>lubricate an electric antenna, use graphite as was suggested. Not thinking
>one day, or is that every day, I quickly used some liquid stuff on one, I
>believe Sli*k-5* which comes in the little orange can with the pump on top.
>Needless to say it worked great for about 3months until it gummed up and
>burned out the electronics. Had to take it apart and replace some of them.

Wiping your extended antenna down with WD40 or something similar (graphite,
if you like) EACH TIME YOU WASH THE CAR will prevent (or at least prolong the
time between) these problems.  Just like anything mechanical, they need
preventive maintenance.

Bob Joyce

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 08:55:38 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  928 heater stuck. (HELP!)

>>
>>My 84 928S seems to have a stuck heater.  No matter where I position the 
>>temperature knob for the climate control, only hot air comes out.  Even 
>>with the AC on, it still is very hot.  This sucks.  Before this happened, 
>>I could use hot and cold air but it was either very hot or very cold, no 
>>in between temperature.  My best guess is that the air valve that directs 
>>the hot air from a heat exchanger is stuck so that only the hot air 
>>passage is open.  Does anyone have a clue as to what could be wrong?
>>
There are lots of things to go wrong, unfortunately. Mine has had
problems with the contacts in the control box (the thing in the dash
with the levers) and the fan behind the interior temperature sensor
(behind the peculiar opening next to the glove box). Repaired the
control box, replaced the fan, and now it works quite nicely. There
is a diagnostic procedure, which might help, in the shop manual, as
well as various information on the whole system. 

If you have access to a microfiche reader (like in a library) you can
buy the shop manual for about $15. The fiche is very inconvenient, but
the paper manuals cost close to $300. You will have a very hard time
puzzling out the operation of the heating/ventilating system without
help from the manual. There are lots of solenoids, vacuum-operated
flaps, sensors, control boxes, voodoo incantations, and other
unexplainable things in there.

 -John White-

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 08:44:34 -0500
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Re: Alternator Woes...


>I seem to be having trouble with the electrical system on my '68 911L
>particularly with the charging system. I have had the alternator checked and
>apparently it is OK but the charging light in the dash comes on faintly and
>the battery is discharging slowly. Could this be a voltage regulator
>problem?, maybe I should have the battery checked? Should I have the
>alternator rechecked?

I just had this same problem.  In my case I replaced the alternator with a
rebuilt.  On my late model 911, the voltage regulator is an integrated part on
the back of the alternator, so I'm not sure if the actual cause was the VR or
the alt.  Anyway, problem is now gone.

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 09:52:05 -0400

>My 84 928S seems to have a stuck heater.  No matter where I position the 
>temperature knob for the climate control, only hot air comes out.  Even 
>with the AC on, it still is very hot.  This sucks.  Before this happened, 
>I could use hot and cold air but it was either very hot or very cold, no 
>in between temperature.  My best guess is that the air valve that directs 
>the hot air from a heat exchanger is stuck so that only the hot air

Hello,

I had the exact same problem as you!

inclined)
the outside tempature sensor replaced. It is located above the drivers front
wheel rim. It should be about $75.00-$100.00 if you have it done. The part
itself
is about $50.00.  I replaced _every_ dam part you can think of on My 928 from
the control head, to the inside temp. sensor  to the heater core and more.!
Alas it _was_
tha outside temp sensor, and not anything else.

Hope this helps.

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 09:39:40 -0500 (CDT)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu>
Subject: Re: More antennas

Well, this is not directly related to the Hirschman (sp?) antenna but I
believe it merits mentioning.  The first owner of my Mazda had to replace
the power antenna and the jokers at the repair shop left out one of the
bolts that held the motor in place(actually there might be only one bolt
holding it in place) .  Well, this bolt was also the ground lead!  Thus,
when I first bought the Mazda, many times I would hear, just like the
fellow Porschephile mentioned, a click from the antenna direction and that
would be the end it.  This only got worse as time went by.  What was
happening is the motor would get power, torque itself out of position as
it tried to extend the antenna and stop as the ground lead would
essentially get disconnected.  Then, while going around a fast curve the
connection would be reestablished and the antenna would go up. 

To sum it up, check the antenna mounting and the connections, the motor 
may be fine. (And yes, do use graphite as a lubricant). 

'85 Burgundy Ice Mazda 626LX			mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu
'87 Guard's Red Porsche 944S
'93 Red-White Miyata Five-12

Date: Fri, 19 May 95 08:12:27 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Power Antennas


Jerry-

The power antenna unit is probably one of the simpler
devices on your car, and it's one that you can fool with
all you want without really doing any harm.  The car will
still run even if you totally ruin it.  

I'd suggest that you just take the darn thing out and
take off the cover plate (the round sort of cup-like thing,
about 4" in diameter) and see what's going on inside.  Most
of the time the failure is a simple wire break or other
obvious thing that can be fixed for a nickel.  If the 
springy coil-like gizmo that pushes the antenna up and down
is broken, you can buy replacements that include the mast
for about ten bucks.

I'm sure someone is going to jump all over me for saying this,
but all the power antenna units I've seen are basically the
same, no matter what the price.  There's a little motor, and a
plastic coiled up springy gizmo that pushes the mast up and down.
That's it.  The quality of the $150 units may (I say may) be
a bit better than the $50 ones, but jeepers, we're talking about 
a cheap accessory, not important stuff like bearings or pistons,
where quality really counts.

As it is said...my $0.02 worth.

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa 
'72 911T Project

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 95 08:28:28 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Engine Pad


Mike-

I think the pad simply serves to keep the
interior a bit cooler and quieter.  I figured
that if the factory thought it worthwhile to
include, then it must do some good.  

I got the old glue off by scraping.  Didn't
take long, but I had the engine out so I could
crawl around inside the engine bay, and I didn't
have to worry about where the little pieces fell.

I actually replaced it not with the $60 OEM pad,
but with a piece of engine insulation material from
JC Whitney.  The latter costs 4 times less.  You get
twice as much material for half the price.  Doing
this was suggested by another P-philer (forgive me,
I can't remember your name.  John something?) who 
graciously sold me half of the piece he had purchased.

 -Bob Spindel

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 95 08:35:13 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: More on O2 Sensor Fuel/Air Testing


Jim wrote a few days ago that if a car had a catalytic
converter, then an O2 sensor inserted into the exhaust
stream in order to monitor fuel/air mixture should be
inserted before (upstream from) the converter.  I'm not
sure this is true.  My reasoning:

The O-2 sensor just indicates
whether it is seeing lots of oxygen in which case
it reads near 0v, or lots of fuel, in which case
it reads near 1v.  When there is neither oxygen nor
fuel, it reads 0.45v..  (This is simplified, but I
think it's substantially correct.) 

I can't see how the catalytic converter affects
air/fuel ratios.

Am I screwed up?

 -Bob Spindel

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 11:32:32 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: First Porsche

>P.S.  I do belive the first ones had their engines in the back.

        Supposedly the very first Porsche to bear the family name
was a car much like the 356 Speedster, but with the engine in the
middle.  See the "Cars of Ferry Porsche" article in Pano last year.
The engine was moved to the back either to ease production, or be-
cause they couldn't fit a top on the mid-engined version.
        Car comparison is like anatomical comparison.  It's not
the equipment, it's what you *do* with it that's important!

- --DD

Dave Darling                            + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 11:19:49 -0600 (MDT)
From: mark r gillis <mgillis@unm.edu>
Subject: Alternator questions

Having just replaced my alternator in my truck...The diaodes in the 
alternator cannot be replaced- the whole unit has to be, and I would bet 
that the regulator is suspect also. Are you shorting any of your wires? 
This can be a real nightmare, but trace you charging circuit with a 
ohmeter to make sure your not shorting and causing the diaodes to blow. 
Try checking everything out before you start spending. It cost me mucho 
$$$ at a autoelectric shop because I didn't.
Mark G, Albuq.

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 10:22:27 -0700

Subject: Early Carrera 2/4 

Hi.

Anyone besides me that have read Automotion Tech Tip on page 152?

"Some early 911 Carrera 2/4 engines are experiencing compression loss and oil
leaks. The problem is with cylinder heads not properly seating against the
cylinders. The factory feels the later-style cylinders solve the problem.
If your Carrerra 2/4 engine has a compression loss that sound like an exhaust leak,
or you not oil puddles under your engine, contact your local Porsche dealer.
Most dealers, under Technical Bulletin 9202, March 13, 1992, are dissassembling
the engines and sending the heads and cylinders to the Porsche distributor
to correct the problem"

I have no oil leaks, but over 4000 rpm i have something that sounds like an exhaust
leak, it can only be heard when the windows are open.


If this is my problem, will it get worse(runs fine)?
Has Porsche fixed it for you/ ask you to pay for it, $$$$$$$$$.
What is the best way to check this, a compression test, leak down?

I'd be grateful to anyone that can shed some light on this topic?

Date: Fri, 19 May 95 10:36:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: 928 heater stuck. (HELP!)


This could be a couple of things.  When you say hot air, I assume you mean 
heated and not just warm ambient air.

Does the A/C compressor come on?  (You can hear the clutch 'click')  If not, 
there's a very small relay in the control unit that can repaired rather than 
replacing the whole control unit ($$$!)

Also, check for loose vacuum hoses, and check the function of the vacuum 
check valve near the brake booster.  Measure vacuum with a guage at various 
locations.  You should get a reading of about 15.  10 will cause wierd 
things to happen, like some valves/doors open and some don't.

Hope this helps.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu
 ----------
>From: porschephiles-request
>To: porschephiles
>Subject: 928 heater stuck. (HELP!)
>Date: Friday, May 19, 1995 1:58AM

>
>My 84 928S seems to have a stuck heater.  No matter where I position the
>temperature knob for the climate control, only hot air comes out.  Even
>with the AC on, it still is very hot.  This sucks.  Before this happened,
>I could use hot and cold air but it was either very hot or very cold, no
>in between temperature.  My best guess is that the air valve that directs
>the hot air from a heat exchanger is stuck so that only the hot air
>passage is open.  Does anyone have a clue as to what could be wrong?
