------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 10:52:39 -0700 (PDT)
From: KN@sundog.caltech.edu
Subject: More 914 rust


The following may be of interest to 914 owners -

                     The Rust Demon Lurks

A recent post by Dave Darling inspires me to relate some 914 rust info.
There are many problem areas on these old cars and most 914 owners know
about the common problems such as the rockers, the dreaded battery acid
effects (too many cars are junk due to this one!) and the rear trunk
floor. However, there are other often overlooked areas that any 914
owner should check. Here's afew I've just finished dealing with on my recently
purchased '73, as close to "rust free" as I've seen. Check these areas
and deal with them now and your 914 will love ya for it!

1) One (well two really) lurkers are in the engine compartment. There
is a perfect water/dirt trap at the front part of the engine shelfs.
This is the part that fits next to the engine under the battery tray
and under the relay board. The problem starts because the rubber drain plugs
(one at each side) inevitably get plugged with dirt and now you have
a water/dirt trap. It's amazing how much crap can get in even if you still
have the rain tray installed on the engine compartment cover!
Reach under here and pull out any accumulated material. I removed the
rubber plug on my cars by reaching up from underneath. Flush out the area
and inspect carefully, if you're lucky there will only be some surface
rust. Replacement panels are available.

2) Have you checked your seat hinge reinforcements recently? This is easily
done and often overlooked.  Pull the seats out and notice that the
area around the seat mounting rails is a perfect water trap due to the
sound deading material that was so thoughtfully installed. This of
course is not a problem if no water ever gets into your car. Dig around
abit with a large screwdriver or similar implement. Hello, big chunks
break loose and you see surface rust underneath, I thought so...
It's time to do a little test. With the floors now exposed flush the
outside of the rear window and fire wall with lots of water, do it
for a few minutes. Now look at you floor. See water? Many of you
probably will. The first likely culprit is the rear window seal. If
it's leaking, change it. Please don't goop it up with silicon, pull
the window and install a new seal ( you need to remove the rollbar
trim first). If your window seal is OK, the problem may be the fire-
wall. If you have a later car with an pad on the firewall in the engine
compartment, this is a potential water trap, my car had a rust spot
behind the drivers seat, I found it by removing the pad behind the seats
and pulling of the sound deadening material. To repair it I also removed
the engine comparment pad (and heaved the sucker in the trash, bye, bye)
and cut out the bad spot and welded in a flat piece of sheet metal.
     OK, we've stopped the leaks. Now, lets remove any rust that has 
started (hopefully as in my case, it's just surface rust) and be sure to
strip of any of the "sound" stuff that has rust under it. Wire brush
and paint with "rust to primer" paint. Now, doesn't that feel good, you've
saved yourself an expensive floor replacement in the future!

3) Head light buckets get filled with leaves, etc. over the years.
Disconnect your battery, crank up you headlights by turning the knobs
on the back of you headlight motors, and remove the headlight surrounds
and peek into the buckets (under you headlights). Most likely there's
some crud in there. Reach in with your skinny hands or use a vacuum with
appropriate attachment to remove this junk. Flush with water and make
sure the drains are not plugged. 

May you have many more years of happy 914 motoring!

Kjell   kn@sundog.caltech.edu

'72 1.9L daily driver
'73 914/6 in the works. After the interior is done, I tackle the suspension
conversion. Still collecting engine conversion and rebuild pieces.

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 14:03:19 -0400
From: DH993@aol.com
Subject: 914 Magazine Coverage

The thread regarding the 914 not receiving enough press has been going on for
several days now. I would recommend that any new PCA member who wants a 914
history lesson contact Ruth Harte at PCA's Executive office and see if you
can purchase a back issue of the November 94 *Panorama*, in which Allen
Caldwell devoted several pages to the 25th Anniversary of the car. Even the
factory's magazine *Christophorus* recalled the Anniversary in the 4/94
issue. There also are frequent articles about significant 914's, particularly
6's, that appear in *Excellence* as well as Pano. (See Jim Pasha's 18 May
note on the subject, Digest #1413). 

BTW, My own 914/6 is going to be *Significant* one of these days! I'm the
original owner of a late '71 (#389 of 435). Three weeks after I bought it, in
August '71, I found out that *Six's* were already out of production and I
made a commitment to keep mine as original as possible. The car now has over
100K miles on it and has been maintained very well (not restored) and was
repainted once, in 1977, in the original Bahia Red. However, the 914's (4 or
6) are such an excellent platform to build a hot rod from it is so tempting
to swap up to bigger engines, etc. that truly stock ones are rare these days.
(I myself would like to create a 914/6 GT if the right donor chassis, the GT
Kit pieces, and a 901/25 motor, all came together.) I've been to 16 Porsche
Parades and there are so few *Original* 914/6's left that the 914/6
Production autocross class has only had two cars (including mine) entered at
the recent Parades! 

My car has been used for every type of event PCA conducts, including Drivers
Ed.  In '71, at the Boston Parade, the car won the Full Concours 914/6 Class,
the 914 Division and was judged for top honors, but lost out to much more
spectacular cars. Since then I put on new front rotors, a new clutch and
Koni's and mounted some A008's on 6x15 rims and it became my wife's track
car. The car still has a charmed life - never damaged bodywise and
engine/gearbox never torn down. (KOW) 
I currently own four Porsches but the SIX will be the last one I'll ever part
with! 

If any P-philers out there are trying to put a 914/6 back together and need a
reference to what one was like originally, drop me a note - I've got as good
an example as you'll probably be able to find, plus all the factory manuals
and the parts book.

Doug Hendrickson
Nashua, NH

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1415                         Fri May 19 19:00:41 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 14:01:30 -0400
From: DH993@aol.com
Subject: PCA Membership & VIN #'s

I need to thank the following for their inspiration for this note: Joe Brown,
Derek Cahill, Darrin Lucas, Ross Stites, Taka Mizutani, Alex Rozenberg,
Dennis Deeds, and anyone else I missed in the thread. 

PCA membership is unique among car clubs in that the criteria to become an
Active Member includes ownership of a Porsche. This is apparent when you see
a membership application and there is a blank to fill in the VIN. I know for
a fact that "speculation in VIN's" for acquiring membership in PCA is not
new. We have a, local, 35-year member who admits his original membership was
based on a 10% share in a car! Innovation I have witnessed includes "loaning"
a VIN number to a friend who wants to join so he can do his first Porsche
shopping. Using a VIN from a car acquired by a PCA member who joined with
another, earlier car's VIN, (and I'm sure some people have just made up a
number!) Also, once you have joined PCA, and are in between Porsches, you can
remain an Associate Member, as long as you continue paying the $36 dues each
year. Application for Associate Membership can also be made by "...any
person, employed by a Porsche-oriented business, interested in the Club and
its objectives having paid Club dues and fees as required." Associate Members
cannot, however, vote in National PCA Elections or hold National Office.
Requests for Associate Membership must be done through a local Region's
Membership chairperson, to verify their relationship to a business. 
If you need to be put in contact with your local Region's Membership
Chairperson, send me a note including your ZIP code. 

The $36 annual dues (Active or Associate) not only includes your monthly
subscription to *Panorama*, but an annual payment of $12 per member to your
local Region. Other subsidy payments to the Regions may also be voted by the
National organization.

Judy Hendrickson
Chairman, PCA National Membership Committee

Sorry for the non-Porsche related content to follow... (though this
is pfile-related)

I don't know Bob at all, but scanning through his messages I see the
fateful header line 'X-Mailer: Microsoft Mail V3.0'. I can understand
Bob's frustration, as we deal with exchanging email between the MSMail
world and the UNIX world quite a bit, and one thing we've found is that
the gateway between MSMail and UNIX mail does NOT properly handle return
addresses for messages coming from mailing lists. It's a known problem
at Mickeysoft, and they're not willing to fix it.

Suggestion... Can a list of the members of pfiles (including email addresses)
be put online (ftp, www, etc) and kept reasonably up-to-date, so that
poor unfortunates like Bob can get the info they need to respond to
messages? I'm sure he's not alone with this problem, and it'd be hard
to get everyone to include a signature with email address all the time
(though that's probably automatic for 80% of us...)

Just a thought...

Ross

out and get one.

sealed batteries good enough?

security.  Opinions?

Hopefully, nothing will melt when I test the electricals ;)

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 11:22:33 -0700
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: Re:  Revenue Collectors

I don't think people mean to belittle the officer specifically ...
it's the whole system of traffic enforcement, and how much
of the enforcement has ZERO to do with traffic safety, and
EVERYTHING to do with collecting $$$, and meeting quotas, which
the State of California finally admitted does exist.

Regardless of how we feel about all that, there is no point
to name calling, or being a general jerk to an officer who
is doing his job. He may enjoy handing out 100 tickets a day,
but so what? We elected the politicians that give him the
authority to do it, and pass the traffic laws we don't like
and the officer enforces. I've only had a couple of tickets
in the last 4 years, and both times without exception,
the conversation started like this: "I like your license
plate. GETA911. Looks like I GOTA911! May I see your license
and registration please?"

Jim Bauman

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 12:07:23 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Scott Winders reply RE: A boy, his 914 etc.

>>The 914 has been out of production for nearly 20 years.
>        True.
>>The 914 was not heavily campaigned as a race car by the factory.
>        Do the names Nurburgring, LeMans, Sebring, Bridgehampton, Summit
>Point, and Marathon de la Route ring a bell?  Even though the 914-6 was
>only made for 3 years, it made an impressive showing.  The 914 was also
>used as the pace car at the Daytona 500 and at Ontario Motor Speedway.  By
>the way, how many 912s have an impressive race history?
>>The 914 does not have many "special" cars associated with it.
>        All 914s are special in that they are the only mid-engined
>Porsches still on the road in daily use.  Actually, sine the very first
>Porsche had its engine in the middle, I feel confident in saying that 914s
>are the only *real* Porsches.
> >Nor are there a lot of historically significant versions of the 914.
>        This is where I knew your signature block would be followed by a
>list of the 911s you own.
>>The 914 is special for many reasons but none of these reasons make for
>great articles.  Unless of course they're articles that discuss how to
>make them great autocross or time trial cars.
>        Comments like this are the reason that the 914 Owners Association
>and the 914-6 Club USA were formed.  Over 2,ooo 914 owners in 21 countries
>enjoy reading about all aspects of the 914 as well as about other Porsches.
>  Our attitude is to enjoy the hobby and appreciate all cars bearing the
>Porsche name - even if their engines are in the wrong place.
>                                                               Scott, if
>you were just having a bad day when you wrote your response or if some
>Dweeb is writing flaming messages and signing your name to them, disregard
>the response to your reply.  Perhaps Rodney King said it best when he so
>eloquently asked, Can't we all just be friends?:-)

Dennis,

You have taken my statements that were in no way derogatory to the 914
and made it sound like I hate the car. If you would sit back and look
at my statements objectively, you would see every thing I said was accurate.
Here are my statements again with additional comments:

    1. The 914 has been out of production for nearly 20 years.

This statement is accurate and is the major reason you do not see many
articles on the 914.

    2. The 914 was not heavily campaigned as a race car by the factory.

Notice that I said "campaigned as a race car by the factory". This is
significantly different than saying "campaigned as a race car". Even so,
the 914 race history is not very rich when compared to the 911-based cars.
Porsche put very little effort and hardly any emphasis on the 914 as a race
car. Customers raced the care quite successfully in class but the 914 never
really proved itself as a car capable of taking overall wins. The bottom
line here is that I was not making a judgment on the cars ability; rather I
was saying the factory did not campaign the 914 and that is one of the
reasons you do not see a lot of articles about the car today.

    3. The 914 does not have many "special" cars associated with it.

Sure, the 914 in general is a special car. I said as much in my final
paragraph. When I said "special" I was referring to cars that stand out in
history. I can't think of any special race 914s except for the 914-6GT that
did so well at Le Mans one year. Maybe Peter Gregg's 914-6 race car would
qualify as well. The other "special" 914's I mentioned already. They
include all the 916's and the two 914-8's.

I was not, nor am I having now, a bad day. Your statement suggesting some
dweeb was writing flaming messages does not sound all that friendly to me.
I think you need to lighten up a little and stop being so defensive.

As a side note, I would like to point out that the 914 was marketed as a
Volkswagen-Porsche in Germany. I find it hard to believe that you
confidently say that 914s are the only *real* Porsches. I am certainly not
willing to say that 911's are the only real Porsches. This would be quite
immature on my part or any ones part.

Like I said, the 914 is special for many other reasons but none of these
reasons make for great articles. Unless of course they're articles that
discuss how to make them great autocross or time trial cars. Often faster
than their 911 counterparts for a lot less money.

I have been beaten by "underpowered" 914's enough times when autocrossing to
know not to discount their prowess at racing!!

Stan,

I would love to get a ride in a hot, well setup, prepared to the limit
914!!!!!

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 95 12:13:53 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Adhesive for Engine Pad


For those who asked what I used to affix the
engine pad, it's a 3M product that comes in
a can, not an aerosol or a tube, but a regular
quart can, called something like Vinyl Top 
Adhesive.  (I'm at work and don't have the can
in front of me.)  It's applied with a brush,
and I think it is much better than the spray
adhesive.  It's used by professionals to glue
on vinyl tops (as you would suspect) and also for
carpeting and so on.  Seems to be holding
my pad yp very well...so far...but I only have 1000
miles on the rebuild.  

I do know that I've used this stuff before for
difficult vinyl trim gluing where neither the
spray or the tube stuff held up.  This did.

Also, a can will last a lifetime.

Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa with glued in engine pad
'72 911T Project - that needs an engine pad\

Date: 19 May 95 12:14:00 -0700
From: MIFSUD_BRIAN@Tandem.COM
Subject: 914 Tuning Question

Hi, A '76 2.0 914 I'm buying flunked the smog test.  The Percentage of Carbon
Monoxide was @ 5.92%, but only 3.5% is allowed.  The seller told me her mechani
c had tweaked it for more power (runs richer) after he smogged it.  I need to
lean it out, smog it, then return it to its present state of tune.  Since this
is a constant pressure F.I. system, either I can shorten the interval the in-je
ctor is triggering, or reduce the pressure. Either way will reduce the total
volume of fuel/"squirt".  Who out there thoroughly understands this issue and
can furnish a competent response?  I want to do the adjustment myself, but if
it is not appropriate, my manliness won't feel threatened and "its O.K.".
  I have basic tools, a Fluke DMM, and a Haynes Manual (please spare me the
"Get the Factory Set" line unless absolutely necessary).   Sorry to seem like
such a Smart*ss, but I see how people are ripped to shreads out there when a
technical error is made.
  Hope this people-base will continue to be the resource I've seen it in the
past.
thanks

brian mifsud 408 285-9920 wk
  (No list of cars to affirm manliness)

Date: Fri, 19 May 95 16:37 EDT
From: darrell@iag.net (darrell cadwallader)
Subject: Re: Tinted windows etc.

Jocycle@aol.com sez:

>Just a short spew, but the only thing more annoying than being behind a car
>with tinted windows (dark) is being behind a truck. I think that the laws
>regarding the tint is basically a sound idea. Now if we could just get these
>4x4s off the road...

I beg to differ ... in Orlando, summer temperatures can reach 90 degrees or
more. If your car sits in the sun for more than an hour, temperatures inside
can reach 140 degrees! Imagine getting into your P-Car after work and
feel like you're in an oven!

As a side note, I think tinted windows offer *me* a bit of protection. I don't
want a casual passerby on foot to look inside my car and decide that he deserves
to have my audio equipment or cellular phone more than I do.

It may indeed be annoying, and I sympathize with those that don't like cars with
tinted glass -- but since I can legally drive my cars with tinted glass I 
will continue
to do so.

Just my .02, FWIW.

'71 Porsche 914-1.7
'91 VW Jetta Carat

Date: Fri, 19 May 95 16:47:40 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 914 Tuning Question

The reason that the "get the factory manuals" is such a standard answer is 
that they do tend to have the most accurate collection of pertinent 
information about the cars.

You wouldn't ask a surgeon to take your appendix out if that was the 
only thing that he knew how to do, would you?

My personal experience is that the manuals pay for themselves each and every
time I don't have to take my car to the robber barons who appoint 
themselves mechanics (at $75 per hour) and still don't get it right
the first time.

I learned my lesson the hard way?  How are you going to learn yours, 
$100 at a time to a mechanic, or $100 at a time by buying an unnecessary
part that doesn't solve the problem, or simply an hour or two at a time
of not having the right information on how to diagnose and fix that 
problem. 

The first things I buy for each of the cars that I own and care about are
an oil filter, an air filter, a fuel filter, and a set of factory manuals.

Sorry to ramble, but some of the pennywise, poundfoolish attitudes of Porsche
owners really get to me (e.g. the porschephile who called to buy a used 
thermostat - a new one is 8 bucks... )


- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (needs work)
1980 GMC Pickup (tow vehicle), 1986 Audi 5000 Wagon
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Previously Owned Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 15:49:54 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Tuning Question

>Hi, A '76 2.0 914 I'm buying flunked the smog test.  The Percentage of Carbon
>Monoxide was @ 5.92%, but only 3.5% is allowed.  The seller told me her mechani
>c had tweaked it for more power (runs richer) after he smogged it.

        The easy tweak is on the FI "brain".  There's a knob/screw on the top
side, by the corner poking out into the engine compartment.  I beleive that
CCW is lean and CW is rich.
        If you need to tweak the fuel pressure as well, the fuel pressure
regulator is on the LHS of the engine compartment, toward the rear.  It's an
odd-shaped metal can that has one end poked through a bracket sticking up from
the engine tin on that side.  A fuel line connects to the part that sticks
through, and (I think!) there's another fuel line that hooks to the side.
There's a hex-nut on one end or the other that you turn to increase or de-
crease the fuel pressure.  It is *highly* recommended to use a fuel pressure
gauge when you do this.  The tap point is on the RHS fuel rail.  Get a gauge
that can measure 50+ PSI, because the system runs as 45-50.
        I believe that the 3.5% is the state-specified limit--the actual
number before the cat should be about 3%, and after the cat should be < 1%.
Your numbers may or may not indicate additional modifications and/or problems.
They may also reflect an out-of-calibration smog tester--I've seen that very
frequently, even on machines with "X00 to go until calibration" where X was
a large-ish number...
        Good luck!

- --DD

Dave Darling                            + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

about not using the best oil on a freshly rebuilt engine because
if there isn't enough friction, the rings, etc may not seat correctly.

Does this apply to a 915 tranny?  At first I thought it might so
I'm using Pennzoil lube at the moment, with plans to switch
to Swepco 201 when things are "broken in".  If this doesn't apply
to the tranny, then I'll grab some Swepco next week.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 95 19:51:37 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: RE: More on O2 Sensor Fuel/Air Testing

Bob Spindel wrote:

>converter, then an O2 sensor inserted into the exhaust
>stream in order to monitor fuel/air mixture should be
>inserted before (upstream from) the converter.  I'm not
>sure this is true.  My reasoning:

>I can't see how the catalytic converter affects
>air/fuel ratios.

Bob,

The catalytic converter is designed to reduce emissions: NOx
CO (?), and unburned hydrocarbons.  It does this by using a 
chemical catalyst that supports the reaction of these pollutants
with the exhaust gases.

So, if the O2 sensor were after the converter and the unburned 
HC were reduced, it would be a lot more difficult to accurately 
determine the amount of HC coming from the engine exhaust, and
subsequently report this to the fuel injection computer so it
can adjust the amount of fuel it is injecting.


Matt Carpenter
'84 928S 62k
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com

Porschephiles #1416                         Sat May 20 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 19 May 95 20:11:23 EDT

> >It all comes down to whether you consider your car a

> >to be more of a privilege.
> 
> This "right" vs. "privilege" crapolla burns me up! I know the state
> governments LOVE to hold that bit of propoganda over our heads,
> but in fact, driving is a right. If a person is of age and can
> demonstrate a limited amount of competance, the state MUST grant
> the individual a driving license.

Ok, perhaps the "privilege" part is a bit extreme.
But where is this "MUST" written?  Doesn't West Virginia 
prevent teenagers from getting licenses if their grades are
too low?

> Only when a person demonstrates
> total irresponsibility or incompetance does the person no longer
> have the right to drive.  

And you actually like that state of affairs?  I would much rather
have more difficult training/licensing requirements AND extended
privileges, e.g. higher speed limits, unrestricted areas out west, etc.,
than have to put up with blind, handicapped 80+ year olds, and 
multplie-offense drunk drivers on the roads.  In other words, I'd 
like to see more prevention, and a greater emphasis on and
appreciation for driving discipline.  (Of course, I live in South
Florida, where the concept of "driving discipline" is unheard of.)

Where do we draw the line between "freedom" and "regulation" ?
This is not and easy question, especially when it comes to legislating
out things like window-tinting because it "might be dangerous to someone."

 -Scott H.
scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 20:40:12 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: engine compartment pad

>What's some good advice on whether to leave this
>pad in or take it out? 

I vote to take it out.  I removed mine because it was falling 
apart anyway.  I didn't notice any real increase in noise, but
I like listening to the engine anyway:>).  I think also looks
better in the engine compartment to see the body color
(bright orange in my case) back behind the engine.  

As for weight savings, etc, I wouldn't count on a performance
increase.  I was a little concerned about my engine ingesting
some of the crumbling foam coming off of this pad, although
I doubt that is a real concern.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: 20 May 1995 01:35:38 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.COM (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: Re Early C2/4 heads (and clutch)

> "Some early 911 Carrera 2/4 engines are experiencing compression loss and
oil
> leaks. The problem is with cylinder heads not properly seating against the
> cylinders. The factory feels the later-style cylinders solve the problem.
> If your Carrerra 2/4 engine has a compression loss that sound like an
exhaust leak,
> or you not oil puddles under your engine, contact your local Porsche
dealer.
> Most dealers, under Technical Bulletin 9202, March 13, 1992, are
dissassembling
> the engines and sending the heads and cylinders to the Porsche
distributor...

Henrik,

I believe this is a pretty well known problem.  I have read that Porsche has
been very open-minded about goodwill fixes.  This is probably essential,
since the repair work requires disassembly, replacement of pistons and
cylinders, and the cylinder heads must be resurfaced to accommodate the new
cylinder design and new head gasket.  Figure $7-8k.  If I were you I'd take
to Porsche now and have them look it over.  BTW, I think the production fix
was implemented in mid 1991.  So check your build date first.

The other problem to watch out for is the clutch and flywheel.  If your pedal
action is very stiff I'd look into this too.

I'd push hard to get both these updates.  It may not be a problem today but
could be tomorrow when Porsche is less goodwill minded.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T coupe, guards red
85 535i, grey 

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 21:18:33 -0400
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: A Boy, his 914, .......

You're ight Bob Joyce - you did generate a THREAD!

I don't think the 914 is lowest on the totem pole, but I won't flame the
model(s) that I think are.  However, let's point asomething that IS
significant to all of us - resale value.  An early 914, preserved well, or
taken care of - not screwed up by removing a perfectly good fuel injection
system - not screwed up by Automotion-mania plastic parts, etc, etc. is a
relatively good investment (sorry Stan).

I can't tell you how many offers I get monthly for my 23 year old 914 -
unsolicited!  They come from 2 sources, people who want to win Parade
concours(and it can win again at any time), and those who want to go racing
with a sturdy chassis.  Typical offers are 2.5 to 3 times what I paid for the
car in '72, and it is box stock.  It is a pefect platform for either venture,
but NOT for sale.

I do, however, take pride in knowing that the car is sought after, for either
purpose (and, by the way - I would sell it to a racer FIRST!).  I also sleep
well at night knowing that I sold my water Porsche before it turned me upside
down.  Don't get me wrong - I loved it for what it was.... but I was one of
the few. I also lived through the period when 911 and 356 owners would not
flash their lights at a LOWLY 914.

TMHO

Pat Garvey

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 21:53:12 -0400
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: More 914 Rust

Great tips, guys - let me ad another.

The Infamous Sail Panels!
  If you are the rare person who has an untouched sail panel, be ready for
action - it will go bad.

Let's examine the design.  A hollow, thin box, with drains on the top, and
underneath the rear quarters. Filled inside with dense composite foam.  Wash
it, drive it - water's going to get inside it.  Where does the water go -
NOWHERE!  It it absorbed by the foam, and rest against marginally protected
metal.  Poor design? You bet!

When your sail panels rust(and the will, if they haven't) make certain that
you remove all that foam crap before repairing - it doesn't do any good at
absorbing sound anyway.  Then, be certain you drill access holes underneath
the trim strips.  You can inspect and flush through these on a periodic
basis.  Fill the cavity with rustproofing (use Wurth's), and forget.  I did
this with mine in '79 - still perfect and will pass any concours judging,
since the plugs are underneath the trim!

Pat Garvey

Date: Fri, 19 May 95 20:12:05 PDT
From: hbrandt@InterServ.Com
Subject: Early Carrera 2/4 


<---- Begin Included Message ---->
Return-Path: <porschephiles-request@tta.com>
Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 10:22:27 -0700
>From: Henrik Eriksson <henrik@chronologic.com>
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: Early Carrera 2/4 

Hi.

Anyone besides me that have read Automotion Tech Tip on page 152?

"Some early 911 Carrera 2/4 engines are experiencing compression loss and oil
leaks. The problem is with cylinder heads not properly seating against the
cylinders. The factory feels the later-style cylinders solve the problem.
If your Carrerra 2/4 engine has a compression loss that sound like an exhaust 
leak,
or you not oil puddles under your engine, contact your local Porsche dealer.
Most dealers, under Technical Bulletin 9202, March 13, 1992, are 
dissassembling
the engines and sending the heads and cylinders to the Porsche distributor
to correct the problem"

I have no oil leaks, but over 4000 rpm i have something that sounds like an 
exhaust
leak, it can only be heard when the windows are open.


If this is my problem, will it get worse(runs fine)?
Has Porsche fixed it for you/ ask you to pay for it, $$$$$$$$$.
What is the best way to check this, a compression test, leak down?

I'd be grateful to anyone that can shed some light on this topic?

Thanks

Henrik


<---- End Included Message ---->
I had a similar problem.  At 8000 miles my 89' Carrera 4 developed excessive 
valve chatter.  Initally, my mechanic felt the car needed an early valve 
adjustment, but after adjustment the valve noise in the right bank actually 
increased.  After the engine was dissembled, it turned out that there was 
significant premature valve guide wear.

Porsche paid for all parts in the repair (guides, pistons, cylinders, cylinder 
head resurfacing etc.).  I was happy Porsche picked up the tab for parts, but 
I had to pay for all labor which ended up costing around $6k.  Ouch!!!

Anyway, the car is running beautifully now, and the engine purrrrrrs!!!!

Good luck!!

Harry Brandt
1989 Carrera 4 (with complete engine rebuild!!!!!)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 22:27:44
From: DENNIS DEEDS <5010.4218@trader.com>
Subject: What is a real Porsche?

On June 11th , 1947, Dr. Porsche began to design the first car to carry 
the Porsche name.  It was the Type 356 and the engine was in the *middle*. 
 The story goes that in 1948 the car was sold and work began on the Type 
356/2.  It had its engine in the *rear*.  In due time, it too was sold.  
One day, shortly thereafter, the owner of Porsche #1 happened to be 
driving  down a Bavarian back road with his wife and came upon Porsche #2 
which was parked by the side of the road in a beautiful setting.  The 
owner of Porsche #1 stopped, examined the car, noted the engine location, 
got back in his car, and drove away.  After a few miles, his wife asked 
him what he thought of the 356/2.   He replied, Its a nice car, but its 
not a *real* Porsche.  And so, the legend begins...                        
                                                                           
Dennis Deeds        5010.4218@trader.com                                   
914 Owners Association & 914-6 Club USA

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 18 May 95 09:22:01 -0400
From: "THOMAS R BRITTON" <britton@a1.esvax.umc.dupont.com>
Subject: RE: 87 944 sunroof prob


It sounds like the teeth on the plastic gear that moves the lifter 
bar is broken. Disassemble the back roof cover to expose the two black 
boxes that house the lifters, unscrew the cover plate and install a 
new gear. Dealer has them for about $3 each.

Be careful to put the lifting bar back the same way as the other one, 
ex. count the teeth and align equally. 

Tom Britton

Date: Sat, 20 May 1995 00:00:33 -0400

Subject: Re: J*ff P*z*s?

Stan,

Porschephiles #1417                         Sun May 21 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Sat, 20 May 95 08:38:35 PDT
From: Tom Craney <tom@craney.demon.co.uk>
Subject: PC Great Britain

PCGB:
If your are a Porsche addict is there ever enough? 
Consider joining the Porsche Club Great Britain, now 18,000 members strong.  
The quarterly 100 page PCGB magazine "Porsche Post" won the 1994 "Classic Cars" club mag. 
award of the year. Steve Carr is our editor recently replacing Peter Morgan, who is a regular 
contributor to the post and well known for his books on the marque. We regularly have top
Porsche journalist Michael Cotton writing pieces. Bruce Anderson wrote an extensive story
in our Autumn 94 issue about the two Sam Bardor racing 356's built for the Carrera Panamericana,
with a full description of the engine rebuild by Jerry Woods for example. 
Besides the feature articles, members contribute their own 2p with running reports and 
helpful hints "I learned about Porsches from that", full Race Report round up and
extensive articles about race rebuilds both rally and track.  We have 15 model registers, 
so if you are looking for that difficult to find part for your RS you have someone to call.
In addition to the Mag. we have a monthly 35 page Newsletter and Advertiser where you
can advertise your Porsche, or anything for sale, free. 

Tom Craney 
tom@craney.demon.co.uk

Porsche Club GB
Ayton House,
West End, Northleach
Gloucestershire GL54 3HG
Tel: 0451-860-792
Fax: 0451-860-011
$56 approx.




Tom Craney

Date: Sat, 20 May 1995 01:11:10 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: What is a real Porsche?

>On June 11th , 1947, Dr. Porsche began to design the first car to carry
>the Porsche name.  It was the Type 356 and the engine was in the *middle*.
> The story goes that in 1948 the car was sold and work began on the Type
>356/2.  It had its engine in the *rear*.  In due time, it too was sold.
>One day, shortly thereafter, the owner of Porsche #1 happened to be
>driving  down a Bavarian back road with his wife and came upon Porsche #2
>which was parked by the side of the road in a beautiful setting.  The
>owner of Porsche #1 stopped, examined the car, noted the engine location,
>got back in his car, and drove away.  After a few miles, his wife asked
>him what he thought of the 356/2.   He replied, Its a nice car, but its
>not a *real* Porsche.  And so, the legend begins...

Dennis,

Are you trying to start a flame war here?  What is the point of telling
this bit of folklore (that is probably not even true)? And who really
cares what the guy thought anyway? The original 356 had more VW parts in
it than any other Porsche ever produced. What does that prove? Nothing.

I strongly suggest you sit back and see what this list is all about
before you go causing problems.

A 914 is not any less a Porsche than a 944 is or any less a Porsche
than the 911. The fact is that people have preferences when it comes
to Porsches. Some people like the water pumpers best. Others the 914.
Some like the 356 the best. Still others prefer the 911. This is what
makes the world go around. But to say that the 914 is is more a Porsche
than the 911 because it is mid-engined is assanine and immature. So
please, go spout this stupidity someplace else!!

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Sat, 20 May 95 09:15:50 PDT
From: Tom Craney <tom@craney.demon.co.uk>
Subject: Driving in GB

I couldn't imagine driving a well sorted Porsche in the USA with
the strict speed restrictions/enforcement! As an American living
in GB 8yrs I am truly liberated to drive as I please within comon sense.
This means 85-90mph on the Freeway and whatever suits on the beautiful
A and B roads across the countryside.  The only real radar enforcement is 
in the Cities with GATSO detectors (flashes the plate and sends the bill).
Although the official Highway speed is 70mph the Police always drive in
the slow lane and as long as you are driving sensibly, they don't bother you.
Because GB is relatively small there are 5 race tracks within 3hrs drive of 
London to really blow it out if necessary.

Tom Craney
 
- ---------------Original Message---------------
I don't think people mean to belittle the officer specifically ...
it's the whole system of traffic enforcement, and how much
of the enforcement has ZERO to do with traffic safety, and
EVERYTHING to do with collecting $$$, and meeting quotas, which
the State of California finally admitted does exist.

Regardless of how we feel about all that, there is no point
to name calling, or being a general jerk to an officer who
is doing his job. He may enjoy handing out 100 tickets a day,
but so what? We elected the politicians that give him the
authority to do it, and pass the traffic laws we don't like
and the officer enforces. I've only had a couple of tickets
in the last 4 years, and both times without exception,
the conversation started like this: "I like your license
plate. GETA911. Looks like I GOTA911! May I see your license
and registration please?"

Jim Bauman


- ----------End of Original Message----------

Tom Craney

Date: Sat, 20 May 1995 08:52:24 -0400
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Re: Revenue Collectors

Hi Bill,

> I wanted to voice a concern here...

It's a free country (well, ok, *pretty* free...)

> flame on

Where?  Where?  (darn, you get my hopes up and leave me danglin'...)
Well, OK, you didn't flame anyone, but, I say, *BUT* you did hit Yer Kindly 
ol' Unka Bart's soapbox button (I'll bet you never do *that* again...)

> I'm tired of seeing belittling, derogatory references and attitude to the 
> police. 'revenue collectors', 'pig' etc.

I, for one, am tired of police that *earn* these little sobriquets.  There
are many policemen who are noble public servants.  Alas, they tend to turn
a blind eye at the scum in uniform who foul the waters for them all.  Other
wise, things would be markedly different than they are today, and they wouldn't
be called such names by mature adults (or even by Porschephiles).
 
> These guys need to be respected. 

They need to *earn* that respect!  And for the good ones to turn a blind eye
on the scum, loses them the respect that they would otherwise have earned, and
earns them, instead, *contempt*.

When a policeman stops me, I will deal with him respectfully.  He's armed,
and frequently a hostile, paranoid bully, looking for an excuse to exercise
*control* through the use of physical force.  Do you think I would want to
give him any excuse to "do his thing?"

An officer who is polite and respectful to me, will get my respect.  Do you
see any of the terms you find so distasteful, in any of *my* text?  Does that
imply that I agree with you?

> When they pull someone over, they're doing their job.

I disagree.  It is their duty to uphold the law, but they are given (or take)
certain lattitude as whether they ticket or warn offenders.  Thus giving a 
ticket becomes a prerogrative of their job and when they ticket, they are 
exercising the *Prerogatives* of their job. 

The police are as contemptuous of the speed laws as you or I.  They do not 
apply the prerogatives equally, but as the spirit moves them.  Their *job* is 
(first to *Obey* the law, and then) to enforce the law impartially.  They 
universally ignore the speedlimits themselves, fail to cite each other, and 
are quite accurately and correctly scorned as "revenoors."

> And as they walk up to the window of whoever they pulled over, 
> they're risking their lives. Cops have been shot in situations like that.

This is true, and very unfortunate.  It's a hazardous line of work.  That
fact excuses exactly *zero* percent of the type of behavior that has earned
them the widely percieved image that they currently bear.

> I don't care if the police man is a rookie enforcing stupid traffic laws, or 
> an  experienced detective catching murderers.
> Lets cut out the 'revenue-collector', 'pig', etc b*llsh*t.

Neither do I.  Lets demand that the police treat the public with respect, and 
cut out the powertrip bullsh*t that has so well earned them the names you
object to.

Yer Kindly (if somewhat, testy) ol' Unka Bart (when it comes to this subject)

My Dad was an 85ish 928 that was in for general maintainence and a look-see
and the mechanic dicovered a loose wheel bearing on the right rear wheel

the car back, it makes a loud whirring shound begining around 40 mph
and proceeds to get louder at higher speeds.

Question:  Is the bearing shot and he needs to get a new one?  I've talked to
some of the more highly recommed 928 sources on this list and the tech
rep seems to to think it may not be the bearing.

Oh, my Dad lives in mid-east and only gets to go shopping for parts once a
year when he comes home.  Should he look for the bearing?

One company told me that if they had to pick only part on the planet that
was over-engineered, it would be the 928 rar wheel bearing  :^)

Any ideas?

thanks!

Date: Sat, 20 May 1995 21:01:53 GMT
From: kam@sandwell.demon.co.uk (Keith A Matthews)
Subject: Heater and Clutch Help

I'd like to thank all the 'philes who offered help with my
stuck-on-hot heater and my not-disengaging-when-cold clutch on
my '86 944. I couldn't face getting dirty and took it to the
repair shop. They got the heater to 'work' by replacing a control
tap. They said that this was leaking water over the bellhousing
and that this may have been causing the clutch to stick since they
cannot find enything else wrong. Has anyone else had this clutch
problem solved in this way?

I now have a small residual problem in that the heater is either
full on or blowing cold air only with nothing in between. I assume
that I need further attention to whatever controls the water or air
mixing. Can anyone tell me what 'the whatever' is and what needs to
be done.

It is a basic heater, not A/C and the temperature goes from cold
to hot with a slight clockwise turn of the temperature control
dial. I assume that this dial should give a gradual increase in
temperature over its full arc. 

In the meantime I'll look on the bright side since HOT or COLD
is a better choice than HOT or HOT. :-)

- -- 
Keith A Matthews
1986 944 (Great White Tadpole)

Date: Sat, 20 May 1995 18:39:33 -0400
From: Philip3118@aol.com
Subject: 930 front lights wiring mess

I could use the "net's" help in figuring out the correct wiring for my front
lights.

Some backround on the problem:
To help your understanding of the story; I bought this 1984 930 (my first
Porsche) about a month ago from somebody in San Jose, CA. As I give attention
to various areas of the car I have been making some interesting little
discoveries. What follows is one of them for which I could use your help
figuring out:   
It started routinely enough with my trying to adjust the front lights so I
could see the road a little better.

The first discovery of the day was that underneath the car's color matching
(anthracite) headlight rim was another headlight rim with adjusting screws
showing. The color of this second rim is black and the texture is somewhat
rough. It looks pretty sporty and I am wondering if this was the showroom
look. Does anyone now?

The second discovery has less to do with cosmetics and more with electrical
puzzlement. As I removed the front light assembly I noticed that the nylon
where the positive wire (brown) connects on the main bulb tri-plug was brown
from having overheated.I also observed that from that connection another
brown wire was providing the positive lead for the front parking lights (next
to the turn signal).

Looking further (I had never taken a Porsche headlight apart before), I
noticed that a second smaller bulb just below the main one not connected.
Left and right headlights have the same setup. 

 
The car was repainted and the shop did a nice job but my suspicion is that
wiring was not their forte.


Here are my questions:

1. Where should the power come from for the parking lights? Obviously the
current setup is causing the nylon to melt and that leads me to believe that
it is wrong.

2. What is the purpose of the second smaller light bulb and how should it be
connected?

Thanks for any advice.

Philippe Bourguet
Kansas City

Date: Sat, 20 May 95 20:43 EDT

hbrandt@InterServ.Com writes:

>I'm with you Darrell.

>I got my car tinted DARK after my briefcase and stereo were stolen in broad
>daylight. What's the problem with tinting, anyway???

It's merely a matter of personal choice. Just like any controversial 
subject, there will be division. Unfortunately, like most controversial 
subjects, emotion gets in the way of reason.

I will defend anyone's right to regard tinted windows with contempt as long 
as they will defend my right to keep my belongings safe and upholstery 
fade-free.

I had no idea that a simple reply to a message regarding tinted windows 
would bring out so many angry protests -- from both sides.

Glad we're all educated and relatively sane ...

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 20 May 1995 21:54:45 -0500
From: stamper@interaccess.com (scott sanda)
Subject: Re: 944 Burning/loosing oil?

>Hi all
>    I have an 85.5 944 with 85k miles, I have noticed that it has been
>loosing oil somwhere, seems like a quart every few hundred miles, this is
>unacceptable I think, I dont see any leaks and havent noticed any smoke
>behind the car, where is it going? what can I Check?
>
>
Look in thine coolent for oil scum, look in your overflow tank, and pray.

If you see oil in the coolent, gettest thou to a mechanic and replace the
seals on your oil cooler.

Scott Sanda

P.S. sorry for the biblical tone, but it's late and I'm tired. Check yoiur
oil as well, if it looks like a frothy milkshake, your getting coolent in
the oil as well. This is bad, but not uncommon, and is usually repaired by
the above mentioned seals.

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 01:35:48 -0400
From: FiewVinder@aol.com
Subject: Of Falkens and clocks

A hearty thankyou to everyone who responded to my inquiries recently.

Update:  Turns out the Tri Flow on my analog clock worked after all.  It's
been about a week and is dead accurate again.

I purchased the set of VR Falkens yesterday.  Thanks for the advice,
everyone.  Though they seem to *float* a bit more than the gatorbacks that
were on previously, they seem to  hold the road much better--very sticky.  I
suspect the *floating* is due to the wealth of tread (compared to the nearly
depleted goodyears).  The Goodyears had more *snap* but were very
unforgiving.  When they decided to realease, there was no warning. The
Falkens are much more progressive.  Anyway, I'm very impressed so
far--especially with price--turns out I received a discount I wasn't
expecting, and got them for less than $70/tire!  Not bad.
Thanks again,
Casey Fox
FiewVinder@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 01:35:53 -0400
From: FiewVinder@aol.com
Subject: In defense of window tinting

     Another benefit for the greens:  I find myself  rolling down the windows
alot less  as well as running the AC less with tinted windows.  Both helping
to conserve natural resources.
     Also, if you're following a car so closely that their tinted windows
prevent you from staying aware of traffic conditions, then you are simply too
close (IMHO).
Casey Fox
FiewVinder@aol.com

Date: Sat, 20 May 1995 23:46:52 -0700 (PDT)

(sorry, Leonard, this one isn't directed at you - I don't have the 
original message, but this line of reasoning really burns me)

> >These guys need to be respected. When they pull someone over, they're doing 
> >their job. And as they walk up to the window of whoever they pulled over, 
> >they're risking their lives. Cops have been shot in situations like that.

I feel compelled to ask: so what? I spent much of my youth training to be 
a cop (Explorers, summer courses, etc.) but once I started driving and 
DEALING with cops in the real world, I came to my senses. But believe me, 
being a cop isn't rocket science - nearly anyone with the will to do so 
can become a police officer. (if that ain't the truth...)

I grew up in Flint, Michigan. Lots of factories and automotive plants; 
nothing much but, actually. Plenty of good people get injured and killed 
working in factories. Lots of decent people die doing their jobs; an 
aircraft carrier never returns to port with the same number of people it 
left with, for example. Why is a dead cop worth more respect than a kid 
who got sucked into a jet intake?!? WHY?!? It is a **JOB** like any 
other, and if they didn't LIKE it - and believe me, most LOVE it - they 
wouldn't DO it.

They earn my respect like everyone else - by treating me decently and 
fairly. Guess what? Plenty of them haven't, and I have NEVER been 
anything but polite with them, and I have NEVER committed any crime more 
serious than exceeding the speed limit on a deserted highway - and not by 
much, I might add; I drive a 924!  :-)  (note P-car content)

Hence - "revenue collectors" and "pigs." 'Nuff said. Sorry about the 
wasted bandwidth, fellers, but, boy, that feels good to say.

Personally, I'd like to see Unka Bart's reply on this subject become part 
of the official Porschephiles FAQ. A police/traffic law reform plank of 
our party platform, so to speak...

Christopher Kirk
Evergreen State College, Olympia, WA
81 True Blue 924 (humble but beloved)

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 09:16:04 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: no porsche content-just spewing

Solutions 
 
Tinted windows-Tinting is legal. Certain percentages of tint are not. If
you want to protect your interior and stay legal, let the shop doing the
tint know that. For obvious reasons, it is illegal to drive with an
obstructed view. Regulations on tinting stem from that. I personally find
tint a pain in the ass for night driving. 
 
Pigs-If you have a problem with cops, don't get pulled over. I have found
that if you are not the fastest or most reckless driver on the road, and
try not to run lights or stop signs, you will rarely get pulled over. Of
course there are lots of Porsches where I live. 
 
Cops are bad-I only know 2 NYC cops. One broke his leg playing football,
and made a effort to make it appear to be a job-related injury (fraud). He
smokes pot, but not much else. Ironic, as he is a narc. The other is an
old, married guy now, but used to be in a Chinese gang when he was a kid.
Basically, in JHS and HS, he shot at people and they shot at him. Both
these guys are perfectly good cops, and I would be very happy to have them
around if I ever needed a cop. They deal with scum every day, and develop a
different sort of attitude towards people than those who have more
white-collar jobs. If they do OT, they might make $70K a year. For that,
and having to deal with hostile people everyday, and being placed into a
possible life-threatening situation every time I stopped a speeder,
especially one with the "drug dealer look" (tinted windows, gold package,
bra and tough looking passengers), I would be looking for a different job.
Gives cops credit for doing the job you wouldn't want on your worst day. 
 
Scam-It has been said that being a cop is like being a member of a big
gang. If you want favored treatment, join the gang. If you have a local
business, make it easier for local cops to use your services. Get to know
them. Ask for some id that shows you know cops. Anything from a PBA card to
a small wallet shield to a shield for the back of your car. If you get
pulled over, do so quickly and safely, be polite, show the id with your
valid DL/insurance card/registration/inspection and ask if it helps. Tell
the cop that you are related to the guy that you got the id from. Be
prepared to state the name, precinct number and badge number. You WILL be
treated with respect. This is not kissing ass any more than telling your
manager's manager that his kids are smart or mowing your girlfriend's
father's lawn when you would rather be watching TV and it pays off better. 
 
Common sense-Like it or not, that is the system. Learn it, and hack it to
your advantage like you would anything else. Live stupid and expect the
consequences. 
 
Flame away....... 
- -- 
Triet Le

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 07:54:59 -0701
From: dem@best.com (Dennis Mitsch)
Subject: Rebuilding alternators? (2nd attempt?)


Since everyone is so busy imitating rec.autos.driving, perhaps my original
message about rebuilding alternators was lost in the muck.

Briefly, my 944S' alternator is making an annoying whining noise.  For
the past 6 months or so.  Several mechanics I talked to say "No big deal."
as long as the noise doesn't change, the alternator will remain functional.

However, it is annoying.

After posting here asking about alternator rebuilds I proceeded to call
a few local alternator shops.

After giving them the year and model of my car and the Bosch alternator
p/n they all quoted roughly the same price:  $60 for the bearings, $120 
for a complete rebuild.

No warranty for the bearings, 90 day warranty for the rebuild.

This sounds... cheap.  Downsides to this?  Obviously I, or someone, will
have to pluck the alternator out and bring it to them, but that's no
big deal.

Wondering if this is too good to be true..

Dennis Mitsch

74 914 2.0 Special Edition

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 12:33:09 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 Burning/loosing oil?

Matt,

It may be that you have worn valve guides, and you are losing oil from
the head, down the guides, where it is burned in the combustion chamber.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 12:47:26 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: More on O2 Sensor Fuel/Air Testing

At 08:35 AM 5/19/95 PDT, Bob Spindel wrote:
>I can't see how the catalytic converter affects
>air/fuel ratios.

It doesn't, but it does affect the exhaust gas content.  One thing it
does is free up oxygen from NOx molecules, which is then combined with
CO to produce carbon dioxide.  Depending on the amount of NOx going into
the cat, there may remain excess O2 in the post-cat gasses, which is not
helpful to the lambda loop.

Bottom line is that the lambda sensor is there to monitor the output of
the engine, not the engine+cat combination.  I know that race engine
developers who use lambda try to locate the sender as close to the
engine (in terms of runner length) as possible to get as true a reading,
because there are chemical changes going on after gasses leave the
engine.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 12:49:10 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Alternator Woes...

Peter,

Start by checking and cleaning your ground connections.  If I recall, early
911's and 924's benefited from an additional ground strap or two... memory
is hazy.

Kevin Gross

Doug,

sure sign of a head gasket on the way out the door.

Kevin Gross

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 12:06:06 -0600
From: dkelly@iquest.com (David Kelly)
Subject: Re: 928 Noises...

Scott S <CAMELJOCKEY@delphi.com> writes:
> My Dad was an 85ish 928 that was in for general maintainence and a look-see
> and the mechanic dicovered a loose wheel bearing on the right rear wheel
>
> It (the bearing) was taken apart cleaned and repacked.  After getting
> the car back, it makes a loud whirring shound begining around 40 mph
> and proceeds to get louder at higher speeds.

The rear wheel bearings on my '83 928 were not the type that could be taken
apart and cleaned. They are (large) sealed dual race ball bearing
assemblies. Needless to say there is nothing to adjust. The large casting
the bearing fits into has to be heated to install/relace the bearing.
Bearings cost somewhere between $50 and $100 each, (I've been trying to
forget how much I've spent.)

Maybe the '85 model is different but I doubt it.

'83 928S
(6) cats

David Kelly N4HHE,   n4hhe@amsat.org,    dkelly@iquest.com

Here in Illinois, we are also required to carry the obscene front plate.  My
current vehicle is missing the front plate bracket, and it is currently on
back-order from my local dealer.  A recent encounter with one of our fine law
enforcement officials  went as follows:

Me:  What's the problem officer?

Officer:  Did you know that in Illinois we require you to have a front
license plate?

Me:  Yes, officer.  You see, the front bracket was damaged and I have ordered
a new one from my dealer.

Officer:  That's no excuse.  You are  required to have a front license plate
on your car if it's registered in this state.

Me:  Yes, officer, I'm sorry, but my dealer won't have the part I need to
properly mount the plate for at least 4 to 6 weeks.  I have the plate in the
trunk if you need to see it.

Officer:  No- I don't want to see your plate.  There must be other dealers
around that have the part you need.

Me:  I checked, and so did my dealer.  That's why he had to back order it for
me.  

Officer:  Here is your ticket, payable within 10 days,  $15.00. If you do not
pay within this period, a warrant will be issued for your arrest.

Me: Thank you officer.  I'll try not to be such a hazard to public safety in
the future.

Revenue collection at it's finest!

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 22:16:22 -0400
From: Ckull@aol.com
Subject: 911 Headroom and 5pt Harness

A couple of months ago I mailed in about headroom in 911's.  I
couldn't fit into my 911 with a helmet on for racing.

Well, I solved the problem, sort of.  I guess I should say I improved
the situation.  I bought a Sparco Supersport, Sparco seat rails, and
a Corbeau seat mount adapter.  After the installation, I gained 
about 1.5 inches of additional headroom.  It is enough to make
a BIG difference.

I didn't really want to spend the money, but the seat I had was
not modifiable.  I gained 1.5 inches of headroom and a much
more supportive seat.  The Sparco Supersport is a nice seat,
but I'm not convinced it is as nice as a Recaro.  It is less expensive
though.

Now, I have a question about the mounting points for the right-
hand side lap belt of the 5pt harness.  The options are: 1)
drill a hole through floor board slightly behind the seat and
mounting an eye bolt, 2) putting an eye bolt into the side of the
seat where the factory belt mounts.  Any other options or opinions?

If anyone has any questions about the seat installation, just
let me know.  I can give you all the info.

Corbett Kull
'85 911 with a little more headroom

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 22:40:57 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: replacing a shift boot on...

Bill,
It is relatively easy to replace the shift boot on late model (after 85 1/2)
944 series cars which are the only ones I have attempted. First order a new
boot in the appropriate color. I forget exactly who sells them but they are
advertised in Pano and Excellence. 
Next carefully pry off the plastic shift pattern plate from the shifter
handle. This needs care because the little fingers that hold them are
somewhat fragile.
Then remove the old cover by pulling the sides together at the base. This
will allow it to be freed from the console. It is not necessary to take off
the console.
Reassembly is the reverse.
I have made this sound somewhat easier than it is because the replacement
kits have much more detailed explanations. The bottom line is it can be done
with no major disassembly and the end result is very satisfying. You are
going to need a bit of patience.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
10:25 pm

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 23:26:57 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Slip Angles, Fast Cornering, Etc

I have been following the recent thread on tire slip angles, fast cornering,
etc, with obvious interest.  Everyone has well though out positions, and alot
of good information has been discussed.  I would like to try and pull all of
the arguments together to form cohesive statements about the subject:

1) A tire responds differently to braking and cornering forces.  This is due
to the construction of the tire, and the dynamics of the forces that are at
work.  Braking tends to mash the tire into the road, and increase it's
contact patch.  Cornering tends to distort the tire, and it's contact patch,
as it tries to alter the course of the vehicle.  You cannot make inferences
from braking and relate them to cornering.

2) The relationship of the tire to the road under braking would be more
straightforward with respect to static and sliding co-efficients of friction.
 Therefore, in most conditions, braking with the tire at the verge of lockup,
the point of maximum static friction, should result in the shortest stopping
distances.  Once the tire starts to slide, on most surfaces, it has a lower
co-efficient of sliding friction, and stopping distances will get longer.

3) A tire generates cornering force through slip angles. In order to get a
vehicle to change direction, you must turn the front tires away from straight
ahead.  At slow speeds and low cornering forces, the tire (and the vehicle)
will follow the arc that you have steered exactly.  As cornering forces rise,
the tire will begin to "slip", and it will follow an arc that is somewhat
greater than the arc that the wheels are turned.  The angle between the
"steered arc", and the "actual arc" is the slip angle.  As was stated by
Byron Short, BF Goodrich suggests a slip angle "window" of between 8% to 12%
for maximum cornering using their R1s.  This means that the tires will be
sliding a small amount to generate maximum cornering force.

So how does this all relate to faster cornering?  In order to corner at the
maximum G force, you must utilize all of the tire's slip angle at both ends
of the car.  This means that the front tires must be understeering slightly
to get maximum loading.  As stated, the slip angle must be between 8% and
12%.  In order for the back of the car to generate slip angle, it must be
oversteering.  The back of the car must be sliding as well!  That is how it
develops slip angle.  The rear tires slide in a wider arc than the car is
pointed at.  

So the front is understeering and the rear is oversteering??? (Herman's
really lost it now, out of control, spinning off of the logic track, crash
and burn, fire up the flame throwers, let's finish him off!).  No, this is
REALLY what happens, it's called a 4 wheel drift, and both the front end, and
the back end are sliding, and the car is developing maximum cornering power.
 If only the front end were sliding, the car would be understeering, and not
using the rear to full potential.  And if only the rear were sliding, it
would be oversteering, and not using the front to full potential.  In an
extreme case of oversteer, where the driver has to countersteer to keep up
with the slide, the front develops no slip angle at all, and like it or not,
this is slow.  It may feel neat, but....

A few final thoughts to convey here:

4) Tires have a slip angle range that they work with-in.  If you are
cornering with a 12% front slip angle, and an 8% rear slip angle, the car
will feel like it has slight understeer.  If you are cornering with an 8%
front slip angle, and a 12% rear slip angle, the car will feel like it has
slight oversteer.  So a car can have understeer or oversteer tendencies, even
while generating maximum cornering.

5) On slower corners, it is most important to get the car pointed around the
turn right away, and so "pitching the car"  will help to quickly setup a
slight oversteering drift.  This will allow you to get into the power as soon
as the car starts to come around.

6) On higher speed corners, keeping up maximum speed and stability through
the corner is most important, and so "carving" up to an understeering drift
will allow you to get through the corner the quickest.

I hope that this has helped to clear things up a little.  One thing that I
have always believed  is that you must think about driving in order to drive
better.  Keep up the driving threads!

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Sun, 21 May 1995 23:25:46 -0600
From: qmoolla@gpu3.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1404 Tue May 16 02:00:07 CDT 1995

                
>Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 00:57:23 -0400
>From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
>Subject: Re: 1987 944S Lack of power
>
>If you suspect the DME, you should be able to test its operation by
>looking at the injector pulses with an oscilloscope, and the spark
>plug signals with a Sun analyser.
>
>I've never heard of "burn time."  Are you measuring spark duration?
>It really isn't an issue, esp. at the durations you quote.  CD ignitions
>runs much shorter pulses and work OK.
>
>When you measure the CO, are you testing pre-cat and open loop?
>
>Have you monitored fuel rail pressure, esp. at the higher RPM's where
>the car's power drops?  Replaced the fuel filter?
>
>If the clutch is slipping, you can feel it and here it.  The engine note
>and RPM's are per the higher RPM it is turning, but you sense the drop off
>in speed or acceleration.
>
>What service, if any, did you have done to the car in the time leading
>up to your problem?  Clutch replaced?  Have you checked the speed and
>reference mark sender for gap?  Checked its signal with a 'scope?
>
>Kevin Gross
>
To Kevin and all of you on the list who took the time to reply.
Thanks for the help, sorry for the delay but I waited to respond until my 
clutch was replaced.  This has now been done and guess what? Problem solved. 
 The clutch was slipping as evidenced on the flywheel.  The Flywheel was 
turned and the disk, pressure plate, release bearing, pilot bearing and main 
seal replaced.  The car drives like it should.  I can now go back to auto-X-ing.
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S
qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 13:22:01 +0200
From: Kristian Simsarian <kristian@sics.se>
Subject: 924/944 steering column ground connection??



	I have a 1980 924 with a horn problem.  I have traced this to 
be a flakey ground connection between the steering wheel hub contacts
and the chassis ground.  It seems that the column is isolated from the
chassis at the column suspension points, is there a single ground 
lead somewhere from column unit to chassis that may be insecure?  Any
hints on where to look for this would be helpful! I have made a decent
inspection underneath the instrument area with not much success.

	More detail on symptom: there is continuity between the steering
wheel's horn ground contact points and the steering column through to the
engine bay area, but not from the contacts to a metal point on the chasis.
If I ground the horn lead that comes out the middle of the column (originating
at the relay) I get a nice clean toot, as expected.


Thanks,
Kristian

PS this is a rush job as the car has to go through inspection before the
end of the month(!).  ;)

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 09:03:56 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: 911 SC electric / oil leak problems.


Hello,

Since law school ended last week, I have been driving my 1981 911SC
quite a bit lately.  I have come upon a few problems.  

First, I changed the oil, and oil plug which is under the engine block
(the one almost in the center of the car) now leaks very very slightly.
I think this bolt used to have a washer along with it, but I no longer
have the washer.  It may have fallen off in my driveway somewhere, but I
cannot find it.  Is there a washer that takes up some space with this 
center oil drain bolt?  The bolt seems almost stripped now when I tighten
it in place, and therefore is leaking about 20-20 drips after the car is
shut off.  Then it stops, I assume since the oil has cooled at this point
and then thickens slightly.  Is there a washer with this bolt?  If not,
and its slightly stripped, what may help fix it?  Teflon Tape?

My second, and probably more serious problem is with my electrical system.
When I step on the brakes sometimes, or other time it seems while the car
is just idleing, there is some sort of surge in the slectrical system and
the tachometor fluters quickly up and down, up to about the 6000 RPM
line.  The engine idle does not change, only the tach needle moves.  Also,
the hand brake light flickers on.  All this only last for a second or two,
and then the elctraonics seem normal again.  This also makes my Sony CD
changer system Which I installed in the car about 2 years ago turn off, and 
on again.  This is powered off of the radio.  This surge seems to happen
as I am slowing to a stop for an intersection, while the car is in neutral,
or coasting.  I have not seen it while accelerating.  And if I tap the
gas, it seems to stop immediately.  The other gauges seem fine, and the
green alternator light does not come on.  Does this sound like a loose
wire somewhere, a short, or is there some fuse that my be blown.   How 
should I diagnose this?

Thanks.

 -Barry Chapin	chapin@draper.com
1981 911SC Euro-Targa

I had the same problem (and still do, but alas! I have found the 
solution! Put NO plates on the car at all and REALLY screw 'em up! :) )

Indiana for more than 2 days, with never a front tag, and no holes, 
regardless of what Porsche says, still HAS to have front plates... no 
exemptions for us, they told us in not so kind words... But, it doesn't 
seem to matter, as we can't get insurance for it anyways... but if you 
really miss driving it, do what we do, have a friend follow CLOSE behind 
and hide the rear plate, such that the police don't see your expired out 
of state plate... :)
Unfortunately, there doesn't appear to be any good solution for this 
situation, although, my neighbor suggested something somewhat useful... 
You know how dealers have those dealer tags with magnets that they just 
slap on the car? Do the same... Unfortunately, I had to tell him that I 
didn't believe that those magnets would hold on to a rippled surface 
(like the underside of a Porsche front) at 60 mph on bumpy roads...
Hmph... just my 2 cents.

From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: Re: 911 SC electric / oil leak problems.


On your oil leak problem:

There is a brass (?)(maybe copper) ring which should go on the oil plug.  
Amazingly, these are fairly cheap (.59).  I was advised to change this 
ring and the one on the oil pan plug every time I change the oil.  This 
of course is on a Carrera engine, but I doubt its any different on the 
SC.  Sorry no help on the electrical problem.

on their time.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 11:11:15 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 911 SC electric / oil leak problems.

In response to text from Barry Chapin:

>First, I changed the oil, and oil plug which is under the engine block
>(the one almost in the center of the car) now leaks very very slightly.
>I think this bolt used to have a washer along with it, but I no longer
>have the washer.  It may have fallen off in my driveway somewhere, but I
>cannot find it.  Is there a washer that takes up some space with this 
>center oil drain bolt?  The bolt seems almost stripped now when I tighten
>it in place, and therefore is leaking about 20-20 drips after the car is
>shut off.  Then it stops, I assume since the oil has cooled at this point
>and then thickens slightly.  Is there a washer with this bolt?  If not,
>and its slightly stripped, what may help fix it?  Teflon Tape?

Stripped how?  At the head or at the thread?  If your case is aluminum(like
the 914s) then over-torqueing the drain plug will cause the threads in 
the case to fail.  If this is the case, you should install a Helicoil 
so the original bolt can be used(and do get another washer). 

Sometimes, tighter isn't better, so always be sure to follow the torque
recommendations in the manuals.

Regards,
- -- 
- ------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady -
 - '76 914 1.9    -
- ------------------

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 08:22:56 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Re: PCA Cal-Inland Region Members and P-Car Rivalry


> if you're talking about the Tribute to Le Mans event at Willow Springs June
> 2-3, it's run by the POC (Porsche Owners Club), not the PCA (PCAers always
> welcome) It's a giant event that includes Time Trials, Sprint Races, Car
> Show, Le Mans-type car exhibition and the main event- a 3 hour night Enduro.

> you're not driving, come out and watch! There are quite a few race 914's
> around.

> Royce
> 87 930 Daimond Blue

Please post some more specific information about this; it sounds like
fun.  I'm tempted to come up from San Diego for it.

now..."
