Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 13:33:24 -0400
From: HSpiva@aol.com
Subject: $20 to smooth shifting

If you have a pre-87 911 with a 915 transmission, then you have probably gone
through various procedures to make the the clutch, trans, gear linkage
situation more friendly. I wrote about my problems a few months back, and was
told to basically "change the fluid and learn to love it". I had already
replaced snychros and "dog teeth" just to return to the status quo. One
mechanic suggested that I replace the "bushings". 

This last suggestion could have saved me thousands in cost, miles of bad
shifting, and quite a measure of frustration. There are two plastic pieces in
the shift linkage that can be replaced with about $20 in cost and about an
hour of labor.

The parts needed are a "ball socket" [#91142413900] and a "shift
ring"[#91442422400]. I believe that these are year and model specific. After
removing the console, and unbolting the gear shift housing and the rear
coupling to the transmission, it is a simple matter of pressing out the old
parts and pressing in the new ones [hand pressure suffices].

Be sure to grease the connections liberally, and to spend some time fine
tuning the connection at the rear coupling. I found minute changes had a
large effect on smoothness of shifting and driveability.

This procedure is not detailed in the shop manuals [except the rear
adjustment], but exploded views are available. I found the hardest part was
freeing up corroded hex head bolts [thank you Louisiana].

Although I didn't get to put many miles on the new set up [thanks again
Louisiana], I noticed improvement in ease and consistency of shifting
immediately.

Good Luck.
Harlan
HSpiva@aol.com
'86 911 [totaled in flood]
'95 Ford Ranger [temporary replacement]

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 10:21:59 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Re: '76 2.0 Positive I.D.

Brian -
> 
>    Great assistance so far in the purchase of a '76 914 2.0.  I have the VIN
> (and engine Number)  Can anyone out there verify that this car is a 2.0 rather
> than a 1.8?  The VIN is 47629025211.  I have had limited time to inspect the
> car before we finish the transaction so I'm scrambling to get all my info
> straight before I write the check.  What other models were available in '76?
> Was the 1.7 still offered?  What's pricing like out there for a rust free car
> with 18K on engine rebuild and 40K on tranny rebuild?
> thanks  brian
> 

Well, the VIN indicates that it is a 76 model.  To discover which engine, 
check the engine block (main case) on the passenger side where the 
trannie mounts up.  If the engine number is visible stamped onto a 
diag stripe to the rear of the airbox, it's a 1.8.  If your number is in 
from of the oil filler/vent (front part of the compartment) on the 
driver's side of the split, it's a 2.0.

If the car is true and doesn't smoke, you could pull an easy $3,500 for 
the vehicle in the Phoenix area.  In Florida, you could probably get 
$4,000.  In Texas or California, it'll probably net $2,500-$2700.

These numbers come from ads that I've seen followed by checks on what the 
car sold for (after I'd missed out!).

Tim Jones
timjones@indirect.com
keeper of the 914 Fan web page	http://www.indirect.com/www/timjones/porsche/


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 22 May 95 12:44:37 CDT
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Slipping/sliding/turning/"quick ones"


As Stan keeps saying, DIVERSITY IS A FEATURE.

Thanks to all who contributed constructively (with physical explanations and/or
with hand waving) that BEST TRACTION BETWEEN TIRES AND ROAD IS USUALLY AT A
SMALL SLIP, and that tire friction may be anisotropic. Most of your
explanations agreed with my personal observations, until Larry Herman's post on
slipping and sliding. Larry, I was hoping you were going to write something on
my questions. With your answers all is now crystal clear. Thank you very much. 

I have experienced the fun factor of sliding more than you need for the fun of
it (but it isn't faster). I agree the best way to learn to drive faster is by
practicing. But I never said that the only purpose of the question was to drive
faster. I wanted to understand the physical mechanisms better. That's a
prerequisite (for me); now I can try to learn to drive faster through practice.
(Thanks again, Larry).
       
I do not agree that I should not try to understand the physical principles
that govern my car's behavior, or that I should not try to explain "carve",
"pitch", and other hand waving terms with correct physics. Notice, I am willing
to learn this "language" and relate it to something I understand. Also notice,
I do not demand that everyone else learns my terms. If you can not follow my
terms,  do what I do when I am bored with your hand waving: move on to the next
message. 


Now some minor non-important excursions for the "quick ones":

1. At the end of the original post I said I was going to strap my helmet on and
go for some experiments. Read again, I have a helmet. It is not a desk
ornament. Over and out on this one. 

2. I have not been to as many track events as some of the people  who replied
to the post.  Unlike some on the list, I can not go to all of these events
offered around here (I chose to spend some of my time on other interests).     
I also make part of my living by asking questions others don't usually think
about, then using theory and experiments to give correct answers to them. 
Unlike my training, in the auto-X and drivers ed events I relied on "seat of
the pants measurements", because  I am not serious enough about these events to
buy a g analyst.  That's my choice. But I still wanted to understand the
answers to the questions I posted. That's also MY choice. Thanks to your
replies, I now have some of the answers. Isn't that one of the main goals of
this list? 

3. I think I now know my car's limit, and the only way to go faster around
corners with the present suspension setup is to improve my line and to learn to
keep the car at the limit longer and at the right times/locations through the
curves. But I can assure you, if  I ever chose to accomplish this, it will not
be the biggest accomplishment of my life. My Porsche (or driving it or racing
it) is not my main reason for living. It is an interesting and fun, but SMALL
part of my life that I LOVE,  no more and no less. I think it's the same for
many members of the list. 

4. In circular motion: 
Centripetal acceleration = omega**2 X r = (car velocity)**2 / r 
(because car velocity = omega X r). 
That means that the higher the centripetal acceleration the higher the car
velocity with which one exits a turn of radius r. That's what! Usually  one
wants to exit the turn pointing in the "right" direction for the next turn 
(that determines the *instantaneous* radius) with maximum possible velocity, ie
maximum centripetal acceleration, while still able to put traction down to
accelerate/decelerate/turn as needed. Same is true with vectors (accounting for
the slip angles etc). Your mileage may vary depending on car, track etc, but
when all the hand waving is done, and all is accounted for, the physical
explanation  will always be the same. Correct application of F=ma and  of 
Torque= Inertia X angular acceleration, in vector form.

Theo
Theodosios Korakianitis
ourios@zeus.wustl.edu

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 10:51:07 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Mike Willis)
Subject: Re: '76 2.0 Positive I.D.

> Hi All,
>   Great assistance so far in the purchase of a '76 914 2.0.  I have the VIN
>(and engine Number)  Can anyone out there verify that this car is a 2.0 rather
>than a 1.8?  The VIN is 47629025211.  I have had limited time to inspect the
>car before we finish the transaction so I'm scrambling to get all my info
>straight before I write the check.  What other models were available in '76?
>Was the 1.7 still offered?  What's pricing like out there for a rust free car
>with 18K on engine rebuild and 40K on tranny rebuild?
>thanks  brian
>

There is no way to tell from the chassis vin. what is the leading alpha on
the engine serial number. For a 2.0 should be a GC Also easy way to tell are
the sparks plugs coming out of the top of the heads, then it is a 1.8. If
plugs are coming out of the side toward the outside of the car then it is a 2.0.

Never buy any porsche until you have a p-car mechanic ck it out. These cars
are expensive to repair. 

mike
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

windshield is busted and the car is rustred in the usual
places...rockers..trunk. Also there is a little damage to the FT RT
fender...I think it's from light contact with a snow plow....very

star effect to them. '75 or=20

one of the two because of the bumper style. This cars is in running
condition...but, not roadworthy. It is very rusty in the rockers, but
that's it.  It would make for a good restoration project...if you like
to weld...like my dad!  Most everything is there!=20

the interest. It can we say has been slightly modified.  916 flares
(glass), 916 read, IMSA Front dam, wide rockers.  This has potential to
be a very nice custom conversion.  No expense was spared.  All custom
work was done by my dad...Oh, I forgot to mention we owned a body

reworked, but I don't have the details...and, it has been sitting for a
while (5-6 years) so I would say "open it up!"  I know that it is 2.4
liters now...so use your imagination.  I have new Dellorto 45's and
other misc STUFF to finish the engine. The car is sitting on 8X15

Date: Mon, 22 May 95 15:01:55 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Slipping/sliding/turning/"quick ones"

> As Stan keeps saying, DIVERSITY IS A FEATURE.

Yes it certainly is!

> I do not agree that I should not try to understand the physical principles
> that govern my car's behavior, or that I should not try to explain "carve",
>"pitch", and other hand waving terms with correct physics. 

I'm not sure how many negatives to stack up while parsing this, but
I think that you and I are in agreement on this point. If you understand
the theory behind the vehicle dynamics of interest, then you have the
opportunity to become a better driver without having to actually drive!
Of course, practice is the only thing that makes "perfect" - actually
it's making the doing of the right thing "automatic" that makes practice
so essential. That, and, of course, the opportunity to verify or debunk
the theory.

> 2. I have not been to as many track events as some of the people  who replied
> to the post.  Unlike some on the list, I can not go to all of these events
> offered around here (I chose to spend some of my time on other interests).

This is one of those unavoidable subjects. Like, why haven't I been on
track for two years? The answer is clear - I have no life. I traded it
for a house three years back. I tried to pretend I had a life the first
year, and actually improved my lap times by 4% over the year before.
But reality came flooding in, and I can no longer deny it. I have no life,
and I will be painting walls this weekend.

> 4. In circular motion: 
> Centripetal acceleration = omega**2 X r = (car velocity)**2 / r 
> (because car velocity = omega X r). 
> That means that the higher the centripetal acceleration the higher the car
> velocity with which one exits a turn of radius r. That's what!

This rather sounds like a response to my question of "so what?" - the
fact is that the centripetal acceleration is the same for given r & v
whether you are "carving", "slipping", "skidding", spinning, dancing,
or whatever. That's not the point: the point is, how high can you make
the v given the r? That comes from an entirely different set of equations.

> Usually  one
> wants to exit the turn pointing in the "right" direction for the next turn 

Hardly ever, except in autox. Normally, one wants to think about the
next turn, but the exit of this one is more important in terms of
the speed with which you enter the straight. 

For a concrete (well asphalt anyway) example, Big Bend at Lime Rock is taken
in such a way that you track out all the way driver's left onto the short
chute. However, the next turn is a left-hander (the only one that counts).
So you have to crab back over to the right to set up for it. But you don't
care about that much, because if you come out of Big Bend on driver's right,
you have no speed. Those who track out and then crab over will eat your
lunch. 




- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

> them. Ask for some id that shows you know cops. Anything from a PBA card to
> a small wallet shield to a shield for the back of your car. If you get

> valid DL/insurance card/registration/inspection and ask if it helps. Tell
> the cop that you are related to the guy that you got the id from. Be
> prepared to state the name, precinct number and badge number. You WILL be

Hi Triet, here in the USA we are expected to aim a little higher.  The
concept has the quaint name of "equal justice under law", and is highly
enough thought of to be chiseled into the marble outside of the Supreme
Court.  Through our history there are obviously MANY examples of falling
short of this ideal... and nobody could pretend we're anywhere close to
it even now.  The important thing (the thing that made the U.S. absolutely
unique in 1776, and relatively unique today) is that we KEEP AIMING FOR
THIS IDEAL.  It's part of the social contract here.  That contract is
sadly weakened each time someone advocates playing a more opportunistic
game, as you have done above.  

No ethnic comparison intended, I'd respond the same if your sig said "Joe
Bob".  EVERYONE has a role to play in keeping the ideal alive. 

Now let's get back to Porsches.

Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 19:33:35 GMT
From: spelk@bert.arc.nasa.gov (Steve Elkins)
Subject: RE: M474 Suspension kits


Just wanted to thank Jim Pasha for the post on the M474
suspention from Denny Kahler.

I just put these KONI's on my '87 944S and it made an 
amazing difference in the handeling.  If you own a 944
with standard suspension you should really look into the
M474 parts.  

When I ordered the parts from Denny he still had quite a
few sets left.

(from Jim's original post):
Here's what you get for $399.00:

        2 Koni Adjustable gas front struts (not inserts)
        2 Koni Adjustable gas rear shocks
        2 Eibach 250 lb coil springs (fit the new struts)
        2 Upper spring mounts
        2 Front shock boots.

This will fit all 85.5 and later 944, 924S, 951 and 968 with no 
modifications. 

If you have an earlier 924, 924 turbo (four wheel disc brake only) or 
944, the front struts can be modified. Rear shocks for the steel rear 
trailing arms require the rubber center from your present shock to be 
pressed in.

Call Denny Kahler at (510) 829-2050 for info and details.

Steve '87 944S

Steve Elkins
Sterling Software
NASA Ames Research Center
spelk@bert.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 15:08:54 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 belt buzzer et. al.

          Okay, I got a chance to crawl into my 74's, and discovered that my
  2.0 still has all the wires connected...  Someone must have disabled the
  starter inhibitor some other way...  The only things disconnected were the
  seat-cushion switches...

          I'm forwarding this to the list because at least one other
  person expressed interest in this stuff.

  >              VIEW FROM BACK WHERE WIRES CONNECT
  >
  >                     +-----------------------------grey/green-------+
  >                     |                                              |
  >                     |  green/white  brown                          |
  >                     |   |white      |brown                         |
  >                     |   ||          ||                             |
  >                     |   || black    ||                             |
  >                     |   ||  |       ||                             |
  >+----------------+   |   ||  |   ?1  ||                             |
  >|                |   |   ||  |   |   ||                             |
  >|              +=|===|===||==|===|===||+                        +===|===+
  >|              # *   *   *   *   *   * #                        #   *   #
  >|              #                       #                        #       #
  >| yellow/white---*                   *---green/red  brown/white---*   *----+
  >|       yellow--/                     \--green/red              #       #  |
  >|              # *   *   *   *   *   * #                        #   *   #  |
  >|              +=|===|===|===|===|===|=+                        +===|===+  |
  >|                |   |   |   |   |   |                              |      |
  >|               ?2   |   |   |   ?3  grey                       grey/brown |
  >|                    |   |   |                                             |
  >|            green/white |   yellow/red                                    |
  >|                        |                                                 |
  >+---------black----------+-------------------------------------------------+
  >                         |
  >                         |
  >                         ?4
  >
  >Tabs remaining:
  > - ?1 large tab
          Large YW/RD wire (yellow with red tracer)
  > - ?2 small tab (I believe ths yellow/white one is connected here)
          Correct.  YW/WH
  > - ?3 large tab
          Large YW wire
  > - ?4 large tab
          The BK and BK/RD wires are connected together at a spade lug
  (male).  #4 is inside one of those box-connectors that has a (female)
  spade lug inside.  1/4" lugs will work.

          Have fun!

  --DD

Dave Darling                            + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Mon, 22 May 95 16:23:14 EDT

     I have run two of my cars (a Porsche and a Ford) without front tags 
     for over 2 years here in Virginia where front plates are required.  
     One co-worker and some member of the local Porsche Club also run 
     without front plates.
     
     Most of us have been stopped for speeding or at roadside check points. 
     None of us have gotten at ticket for the lack of plate yet.
     
     Now, I am not advocating that you run without your front plate.  I 
     believe that you will find, though, that most officers don't pay 
     attention and don't really care about your front plate.

turns in the same direction should have a limited slip.

pre-law student would do. The fine is so high because it is counted as a 
moving violation, the vehicle being in motion brings the fine to $75 as 
opposed to $25 had it been parked. The ticket doesn't carry any points on

place as well as the astronomical fine.

the *pigs* one more reason to hastle you.

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 17:55:23 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Slip Angles, Fast Cornering, Etc

lots of good stuff deleted...

>The back of the car must be sliding as well!  That is how it
>develops slip angle.  The rear tires slide in a wider arc than the car is
>pointed at.  

I have a "novice" observation to make on this subject.  I am familiar
with the above discourse on slip angles (I have the worn out tires
to prove it :>0).  My car noticably "drifts" at speed on the track.  OK.
Watching alot of F1 races, though, I never seem to notice those cars'
tires developing large slip angles.  The car seems to follow the 
tires really closely (seemingly very small slip angles).  Of course,
they go through tires faster than I do, so there must be some decent
slip going on there.  

Is this an optical illusion, or are race cars in general not "drifting"
as much as the rest of us?

Just curious...

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 15:23:38 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Re: 914 2.0L new motor

> The rods are knocking! Thats what couple of mechanics have told me. So Now I
> want a 914 long block for a 2.0l. I having a hard time tracking one down so I
> must not be reading the rights mags. Auto atlanta wants $3500 for a rebuilt

The key here is the warranty that AA supplies.  You are getting a 
complete REBUILD, not an overhaul.

> motor with like core. Parts heaven has a engine for 900 but they are calling
> me back to tell me what it is like. I had Parts Werke quote me a price of 800
> dollars. What the heck. What is the right price range for a stock 914 rebuild?

These are both good prices, but I'd wager that they are from 
wrecked/junked cars and are of dubious heritage.  If you were planning to 
rebuild it yourself, the cheaper plants would be a good deal.  If you're 
looking for something that can just be bolted in, then the AA engine is 
the way to go.

Date: 22 May 95 17:39:00 -0500
From: KEN.HOUSE%MSFC10PO@x400gw.msfc.nasa.gov
Subject: BOSCH Control Units

     Would anyone out there have a supply of Bosch fuel injection 
     control units (black boxes, brain boxes, jetronics, 
     motronics,etc) that are damaged; salvaged; of unknown 
     condition; spare; etc. that they would care to dispose of 
     properly?  The make or model of vehicle doesn't matter as 
     long as the control unit is Bosch.  
     
     These items are needed in order to get electronic parts 
     necessary to salvage Porsche 911 and 944 Motronics units 
     that have been damaged.  Bosch units use some proprietary 
     integrated circuits that can not be purchased anywhere--and 
     i'm getting desperate for parts.
     
     The dealerships have a $50 core charge on DME units--i will 
     gladly pay shipping plus $75 for useable cores.  Contact me 
     directly-- ken.house@msfc.nasa.gov.  800-752-9574
     
     
     

------------------------------

Date: 22 May 95 18:00:00 -0500
From: KEN.HOUSE%MSFC10PO@x400gw.msfc.nasa.gov
Subject: 3.2 911 vacuum leaks

     A friend asked me to fix his DME unit-it seems the idle was 
     jumping around and the cruise control no longer held a 
     steady speed.
     
     Before probing into the electronics i had him crank it up in 
     order to observe the symptoms and check for obvious stuff 
     like loose ground wires.  During the exam i found a cracked 
     vacuum hose coming off the back side of the throttle.  There 
     is a brass tube out the back of the rubber boot that runs to 
     the left side of the engine toward the cruise control 
     'motor'.  At the end of the 12" long brass tube is a 2" long 
     piece of molded rubber hose, and this hose was cracked and 
     leaking air.  Its easy to find and fix.  Just replace the 
     rubber with hose from autoshack--Very cheap$$$.
     
     Just for fun i checked my own and about 8 other 911s--and to 
     my surprise they were all cracked in the same place!  It 
     looks like a case where the rubber has gotten hard and 
     brittle.  Now, go out and check you rubber and let me know 
     what you find.
     
     --ken.house@msfc.nasa.gov

------------------------------

Date: 22 May 95 18:11:00 -0500
From: KEN.HOUSE%MSFC10PO@x400gw.msfc.nasa.gov
Subject: 911 Oil Leak

     Here is another hard rubber story.  This time i was at the 
     Parade in Dallas cleaning the 911 for the concours when i 
     noticed a few drops of oil under the right rear.  It turns 
     out to be the "S-hose"--from the oil tank to the engine oil 
     cooler.  The hose gets hard and brittle and cracks in the 90 
     degree bend.  Later during the Parade i was squatting and 
     looking under all the 911's i could find--and to my surprise 
     there were cracks in nearly 50% of the 911's. 
     
     It seems the rubber problems get worse with age--if you 
     haven't changed your S-hose recently, then at least go out 
     and check it, before it dumps an oil tank out while you are 
     driving.  You might be surprised--let me know what you find.
     
     --ken.house@msfc.nasa.gov

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 19:42:50 -0400 (EDT)
From: DNEL@delphi.com
Subject: 911 tach repair

Back in '92 I sent my 911-T VDO speedometer, on which the odometer had 
failed, to:
 
                           Williamson Instrument
                                Highway 282
                             Chester, AR 72934
                              (501) 369-2551
 
They repaired and returned it promptly for $80, including $5 freight, 
insurance and COD charge (UPS).  I had telephoned them for the price.  
They work on all VDO instruments.
 
It's worked fine since.

------------------------------

Date: 22 May 95 18:51:00 -0500
From: KEN.HOUSE%MSFC10PO@x400gw.msfc.nasa.gov
Subject: 944 Clutch Story

     This Spring i bought and repaired an '86 944 that suffered 
     the worst case of a lack of maintenance blues.
     
     The owner called and asked me to go down to the repair shop 
     where he had towed the car.  They had told him the repairs 
     would cost about $8k and he had nearly shat on himself. 
     
     "For want of a nail the shoe was lost."
     
     This 944 needed everything replaced from the flywheel back-- 
     the clutch,pp,t.o. bearing, Torque Tube and drive shaft, and 
     transaxle.  And the reason--his brake/clutch  reservoir got 
     low and he didn't know, and he didn't replace the flywheel 
     pilot bearing when he had the clutch replaced.
     
     But it wasn't entirely his fault.  He had help.
     
     Open up your Haynes Manuals to p142.   (Congregation is 
     flipping pages)  to Figure 8.3,  where they show the vise 
     grip pliers used to clamp the fluid line to the clutch 
     master cylinder.  Yes someone used vise grips to clamp the 
     line and yes it cut little slices into the line which leaked 
     fluid and allowed air into the system.  
     
     i don't know how he could have driven without a full throw 
     of the clutch, but he did.  i asked him if he didn't notice 
     any noises and grinding, grumbling etc., but he had a killer 
     radio and said he never heard a thing.  
     
     The splines on the end of the driveshaft were wallowed out 
     to nubs, and big chunks of ringinpinion gears washed out of 
     the transaxle drain.
     
     So pay attention to those noises, keep your fluid levels up, 
     and don't skimp on pilot bearings (i know the clutches are 
     expensive).
     
     And one final note to those that need to know--yes a 944 
     turbo transaxle will fit perfectly in a non-turbo 944, and 
     the limited slip differential is really nice too.
     
     --ken.house@msfc.nasa.gov

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 20:00:03 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Slip Angles, Fast Corneri...


>with the above discourse on slip angles (I have the worn out tires
>to prove it :>0).  My car noticably "drifts" at speed on the track.  OK.
>Watching alot of F1 races, though, I never seem to notice those cars'
>tires developing large slip angles.  The car seems to follow the 
>tires really closely (seemingly very small slip angles).  Of course,
>they go through tires faster than I do, so there must be some decent
>slip going on there.  
>
>Is this an optical illusion, or are race cars in general not "drifting"
>as much as the rest of us?
>
>Just curious...
>
>Mike Dayton
>76 Euro 911

Mike,

I would say that your observations are quite correct.  F1 cars, as well as
Indy cars and other lightweight, ground-effected, winged cars do corner with
a minimum of slide.  Don't forget that they have hundreds of pounds of
aerodynamic downforce to give the tires extra grip, and according to a Penske
Race Engineer/Crew Chief that I know, the tires that they run are designed to
work with less slip angle than typical tires.  Even with the lack of sliding,
they are really leaning on the tires to develop the 2.5+ G forces that they
do under hard cornering.  Larger sedans without wings do corner more like
what we are driving.  BTW, if you want to see some real slip angles, just
watch a NASCAR race 8{).

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer





------------------------------

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 20:45:06 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: 944 stub axle bolts-warning

I had a dangerous experience this weekend at the Brain Redman Jefferson 500
which, BTW is an event that no one should miss if they are on the right
coast. Millions of $$ of exotic machinery. Where else can you watch a guy
totally destroy a GT40 Ford, but that's another story.
Anyway while traveling down the main straight I suddenly became aware that
the car started to steer itself. Though a tire was going down so I pitted and
did the usual walk around. Nothing obvious until I wiggled all the wheels. To
my horror the left rear wheel could be moved easily in any direction. Seems
that the stub axle nut had come loose. In later model 944's there is no
castellated nut and cotter pin that is familiar to 911 drivers. The nut is
totally dependent on torque and allot of it (over 360 ft lbs I believe). The
scary part is that as part of my teching for the weekend I had checked that
nut and it was tight.
Because of the direction of rotation the left side is prone to this loosening
while the right side will stay snug. 
Bottom line is that if you run a 944 based car please check that nut. It
could be catastrophic. People who do Tech at drivers Ed please take note and
add this to you check list

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
8:38 pm

Porschephiles #1421                         Tue May 23 02:00:17 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 17:58:46 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Slip Angles, Fast Cornering, Etc

By golly, Larry, I think you've almost got it!

Larry Herman says: "So the front is understeering and the rear is
oversteering??? (Herman's really lost it now, out of control, spinning off
of the logic track, crash and burn, fire up the flame throwers, let's
finish him off!). No, this is REALLY what happens, it's called a 4 wheel
drift, and both the front end, and the back end are sliding, and the car is
developing maximum cornering power. If only the front end were sliding, the
car would be understeering, and not using the rear to full potential.  And
if only the rear were sliding, it would be oversteering, and not using the
front to full potential. In an extreme case of oversteer, where the driver
has to countersteer to keep up with the slide, the front develops no slip
angle at all, and like it or not, this is slow. It may feel neat, but...."

The old 4-wheel drift -- funny, no one mentioned it before -- but that's
where it at! Higher speed is a prerequisite to a 4-wheel drift, and it's a
very unnatural act because it doesn't come naturally by itself. Unlike
understeer or oversteer, or a frightening sequence of one and then suddenly
the other when entering a high speed turn, the car will not conveniently
take a 4-wheel drift without help. I think you've got to create it -- like,
by pitching the car (I don't know "carving," maybe in this situation it
means the same thing). By "pitching the car" to achieve a 4-wheel drift, I
don't mean you yank on the steering wheel to send the car into a gross
slip-angle and then try to correct with gobs of opposite-lock steering
correction. An early turn-in combined with cracking the throttle to cause
over-steer followed by immediate opposite-lock throttle steering will begin
a 4-wheel drift. Once a drift is begun, skilled car-control with constant
and subtle steering change (sawing) is required to maintain it through the
turn onto the next straight.

The really good drivers can provoke a drift well in advance of the normal
turn-in point so that, once they reach the turn, they can take a late apex
while maintaining the drift. I didn't really understand "drift" until I saw
Jody Scheckter in a Formula 5000 at Laguna Seca going through Turn 2 (the
old course) at very high speed. It was the most awesome, blazing 4-wheel
drift I'd ever seen. At first I thought he'd lost it, but he did it lap
after lap without losing the tires. Among contemporary drivers, Hans Stuck
comes to mind as a great "drifter."

If you want to see drifting up close and personal, go to a kart race on a
fast track and watch the 80-shifters. The winner will be a "pitch 'n catch"
artist. But I doubt he (or she) can tell you the percentage of slip angle,
or even cares, for that matter.



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 18:17:02 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Fw: waaay stupid tricks

I just got this from a friend ... enjoy!


>Stupid Human Trick ...
>
>OUCH!  don't try this one at home, now, kiddies!
>
>"Darwin award" Nominee: You all know about the Darwin awards -- it's
>an annual honor given to the person who did the gene pool the biggest
>service by killing themselves in the most extraordinarily stupid way.
>Last year's winner was the fellow who was killed by a Coke (tm)
>machine, which toppled over on top of him as he was attempting to tip
>a free soda out of it.
>
>And the nominee is:
>
>The Arizona (U.S.) Highway Patrol came upon a pile of smoldering metal
>imbedded into the side of a cliff rising above the road, at the apex
>of a curve.
>
>The wreckage resembled the site of an airplane crash, but it was a
>car.  The type of car was unidentifiable at the scene.  The boys in
>the lab finally figured out what it was, and what had happened.
>
>It seems that a guy had somehow got hold of a JATO unit, (Jet Assisted
>Take Off, actually a solid-fuel rocket) that is used to give heavy
>military transport planes an extra `push' for taking off from short
>airfields.  He had driven his Chevy Impala out into the desert, and
>found a long, straight stretch of road.  Then he attached the JATO
>unit to his car, jumped in, got up some speed, and fired off the
>JATO!!  Best as they could determine, he was doing somewhere between
>250 and 300 mph (350-420kph) when he came to that curve....  The
>brakes were completely burned away, apparently from trying to slow the
>car.
>
>(NOTE: Solid-fuel rockets don't have an 'off'... once started, they
>burn at full thrust 'till the fuel is all gone.)
>
>

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 21:18:34 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 tires...Cooper?

> I've been price shopping for some new 165 SR15's for use on a daily 
> driver/occasional autocrosser.  Yokos and Pirellis that I've found start 
> at $80, kinda out of my range.  I found a set of 4 Coopers that are speed 
> rated T and labelled "performance" for $50.  Is this a deal?  What should 
> this poor starving grad student do?  Thanks!   Rick  '72 914-3 1/2

Sigh. If you're *REALLY* starving, then $50 a tire is not a bad price, 
but don't expect any more performance out of the tires. Believe me,
putting that much rubber in one place for $50 all the performanance *THAT*
vendor can manage...

Have you looked at mail order tires? Discount Direct and The Tire Rack
routinely have the best prices in the known universe. Also, your choice
of size is *SEVERELY* limiting your choices and inflating the price. Try
looking in 185/70x15 or even 195/65x15. You should be able to buy *GREAT*
tires in the $68-80 range...

Stan

sitting in the puddle, and didn't plug the seat cushion switch in.  Lo, and
behold, no starter interlock.  Never got around to plugging it back in...

to be taken off and resealed as well. The problem with the car now is cold
starting. My friend claims it takes almost 10 minutes of cranking to get
the car started. Once warm the car runs great and it starts without a
hitch. The mechanic told him just to drive the car for a while to let some
of the build-up burn out.....Does this make sense given the car runs great
once started and starts fine at operating temp????? any ideas? Thanks.

Marc Loomis
1965 911



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 23:12:42 EDT
From: MDJS51A@prodigy.com ( KARL E HAUG)
Subject: Stub Axle Nuts

Jerry's warning re stub axle nuts loosening on 944s actually applies to any
Porsche using an "upset" (i.e., non-castellated) rear stub axle nut.  I'm
safety chair for our PCA region and do about 90% of the pre-event tech
inspections.  Last year, our region began having an epidemic of rear axle
nuts loosening on 911s of '84 and newer vintage. Upon investigation, it
turned out these had all happened on cars which had needed rear wheel
bearings replaced (including my '88 911).  I bit the bullet and purchased
Arnie, my 600 lb/ft yard-long torque wrench, properly torqued the nuts and
the problem disappeared.  Apparently the shops (including our local dealer)
which had done the wheel bearing replacements hadn't properly torqued the
nuts when they were done.

If you have a car using non-castellated stub axle nuts and have had a rear
wheel bearing replaced, be sure to find someone with the proper tool and
have the torque checked.  The proper torque is 330 lb/ft on the 3.2 Carrera
series cars.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 00:14:51 -0400
From: Louis914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 Burning/loosing oil?

I own a Porsche repair shop in Fl. and encounter 944's loosing oil all of the
time it is usually either those oil cooler seals, which an updated part has
been manufactured for made out of viton and should last forever, or it can be
valve guides and seals but only usually on high mileage cars, or last it can
be the cam tower to head gasket, which will leak down on to the exhaust and
you will usually smell it, but not see it in the ddrivway because it burns
off as you drive. If it is oil cooler seals have it repaired Pronto because
it will take out your rod bearings $$$$$$$$ big bucks fix. Good luck any
questions dont hesitate to ask, I can also tell you what you should expect to
pay for such a service.

louis914

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 00:35:53 -0400
From: Louis914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Help:rear wheel bearing 951

I do the all the time, and dont use a press. First take the new bearing over
to your freezer, and drop it in your ice box, then dissassemble the rear
t-arm hammer out the hub with a large driver, if you dont have one that big
use a piece of 1.5 in o.d. bar stock. next remove the bearing retaining
bolts, and hammer out the bearing and its races, one of the races may have
come off with the hub, maybe if you were lucky the entire bearing came off
with the hub. next with some 220 emry cloth lightly polish out the inside of
the t-arm. next heat up the t-arm where the bearing will go back in, heat it
quite a bit dont be afraid to heat it this will temporareily expand the id of
the arm and remember the bearing is doing the opp. in the frig. when the arm
is good and hot go grab the bearing with pliers, not your hands or they will
warm it up, and have a brass hammer and a block of wood ready.  if you got
the t-arm hot enough, the bearing will slide right in, then give it time to
cool before you do anything else.  if it only slides half way or so grab the
bolck and hammer and bang it in the rest of the way. then reassemble and use
red locktite on those bearing ret. screws, and the stub nut.  ps dont hit the
center of the bearing under any circ. while driving it in, thats why you need
the block so it hammers on the outer edge of the bearing.  and use the stub
axel and nut to pull the hub back in.

good luck!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 22:41:41 -0700
From: paulm@kestrel.engr.sgi.com (Paul Mielke)
Subject:  Re: PCA Membership & VIN #'s

I don't think any of the regions work that way.  You join the National
PCA and pay the dues there.  Doing that gets you into the local region
automatically, I believe.  In some geographical areas (like the SF
Bay Area) there are several local regions to choose from.

|
...
| 
| I guess I've run out of patience and so for lack of ease, I havent
| joined.  I'm sure there are great regions out there, nice people,
| fun to be had,  and my experience is a statistical blip.    I do 
| realize that the PCA folk are probably non-paid volunteers and
| extra patience/understanding is needed since they're doing this
| on their time.
| 
| So please dont flame me - its just *my* reason for why I havent joined
| yet, add this note to further your perspective.  Maybe I'll try again
| sometime and have better luck.
| 
| Ron
| '66 912

No need to be frustrated.  You've already got the hard part
accomplished (the VIN).  All you need to do is to call or write
the PCA national office and ask for the application.  Fill it out,
send in the $36 with your VIN and you're in like flint.  Here's
the address and phone:

PCA Executive Office
PO Box 30100
Alexandria, VA  22310-8100
703-922-9300

Cheers,



Paul Mielke (paulm@sgi.com)
Silicon Graphics, Inc.

Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 23:17:20 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Don't Feed The Bears

Just thought I'd share this -- it's a compilation of several of the P'phile
posts that went to PCA regional newsletter editors.

Going To The '95 Parade? Don't Feed The Bears!
by various Porschephiles

Planning your trip to the 1995 Porsche Parade in Portland? If so, no matter
which route you take, you'll see wonderful country once you reach Oregon, a
state also famous for its bear population. The four-legged variety have
long, shaggy fur and a five-toed foot. The two-legged variety also have a
five-toed foot, wear a flat-brimmed hat, and are terribly skilled at using
devices like radar, airplanes, and unmarked cars. In either case, please do
not feed the bears!

Recently on Porschephiles, an Internet mail list, we had a "discussion"
about the consequences of exceeding the posted speed limits in Oregon. The
consensus was, Don't Exceed The Posted Speed Limit! Save your extra cash
for the Parade Goodie Store. Here's some of the contributed tidbits.

Jim Bauman: "Having run the gauntlet of I-5 through Oregon for the last 26
years, I can attest to the proactive attitude of the Oregon Highway Patrol.
Especially around a place called Cottage Grove. They will use an airplane
and about 8 to 10 cars in their revenue collecting efforts. They line up on
the on ramp like taxis at an airport. It's really quite a sight!"

Jim goes on to say, "If anyone is looking for an alternative for I-5, I
highly recommend Highway 395 north out of Reno, Nevada, all the way to the
Columbia River, then west on the freeway. It's quite incredible, especially
through southern Oregon where it's basically a desert. Or, go north on
Highway 395 from Reno and cut over towards Mt. Shasta, California. Another
incredible journey."

Mike Lommatzsch added to the discussion, "And to those driving through the
state of Oregon to get to the Parade, be especially aware of your speed. I
understand tickets for only 65 mph can cost in the two hundred dollar range
and out of state plates are a magnetic for the officers. In March, my
mother (who lives in Oregon) sent me a clipping from a local newspaper
about this poor guy from Idaho Falls who was doing 85 mph when he was
stopped near Baker (eastern Oregon). The actual bail amount printed on his
ticket was $334. Elsewhere in the article it states that the new, steep
fines for doing between 11 to 20 mph over the speed limit are $329."

Bob Pentecost reported, "I was in Oregon a couple of weeks ago during the
Inland Northwest Region/Pacific Northwest Region Yakima Valley Winery Tour
and saw a billboard that showed the fines for speeding. I recall something
like: 1-10 mph over the limit is $180; 11-20 over is $350. I think there
were four lines of figures. This was on I-84 in the eastern part of the
state."

Local Steve Poole gave this advice: "I drive between Seattle and Newberg
(south of Portland) fairly often and am now pretty careful in Oregon
because they recently DOUBLED the price of tickets! I haven't had one, so
can't say what the exact amounts are, but I believe that 20 or 30 mph over
the I-5 limit can now cost you several hundred dollars. I-205 around
Portland seems to be pretty heavily patrolled, and there are numerous sweet
spots for speed traps, especially for those of us who like high speed
sweeping curves. Washington ticket prices are doubled if the ticket is
issued in a work zone. Oregon does something similar."

Steve also gave his first-hand report: "I just returned yesterday from my
first Seattle-Newberg-Seattle run in the 911. Great weather both ways, and
it was a blast! My favorite moment was being passed on a slight downhill by
some ratty Honda boltbucket. About seven seconds later the BEL shrieked
twice and I hit the brakes hard to drop to about 65. At almost exactly the
same time, a Washington patrol car came smoking off the left shoulder just
ahead of me, where it had been hiding behind some bridge struts. I thought
he was going to nab me, but he accelerated past and the next time I saw him
was on the right shoulder where he was looking with extreme displeasure at
a certain Honda driver. Wahoo!"

And, finally, Volney Spalding had this to share: "Oregon is highly
proactive in their revenue collection activities as has been mentioned here
- -- aircraft, radar, and unmarked cars. On the other hand, much of the state
is rural and 65 mph is in effect a healthy percentage of the time. Watch
out for the temporary 55 mph zones when you approach populated areas.
Southern Oregon between Roseburg and Grant's Pass (about 100 miles) has
some fun driving (for an Interstate) on I-5 in low traffic conditions.
There is a series of minor 'mountain' passes around 1000 to 1500' -- about
4 or 5 of them. Makes for some great winding uphill runs. There are always
two lanes in your direction and it can be a fun ride if not too many big
rigs, RV's and country squire wagons are on the road."

Volney continues, "I-5 from Redding California to the Oregon Border is also
a lot of fun and is also 65 mph. The Northern CA CHP in this region can be
quite attentive and will line up several Mustang pursuit cars. You'll have
at least two lanes each way and the scenery is great all through the
Siskiyou Mountains with Mt. Shasta, Lake Shasta, and Castle Crags all in
easy view from the Interstate. Just north of the Oregon border on I-5, be
careful going past Medford. It's one of those temporary 55 mph zones and it
seems the State Police are always around."

Volney has this advice for coffee fans: "Take note that you are never far
away from excellent coffee! The Northwest has come to take their coffee
seriously in the last ten years, and you can find espresso even in remote,
small towns. Stores with names like, 'Dave's Bait, Tackle and Espresso,'
(I'm not making this up) are not uncommon. You can get great coffee almost
anywhere to help you stay awake and watchful for speed traps."

Volney also has a favorite alternate route. "For a serious excursion,
not-for-the-weak-of-stomach, take Highway 199 between Grant's Pass, Oregon,
and the California Coast. It's one of the connectors between I-5 and the
coast highway (Highway 101). It's actually backtracking as you have to go
way south to go north, but we're talking serious mountains -- very remote.
No matter what route you take to get to 101, you won't be disappointed as
the southern Oregon coast is stunning, particularly between the California
border and Port Orford, Oregon. Be aware that 101 is not an interstate and
is 55 mph the whole way."

So, there you have it. Go to the Parade -- don't speed -- and don't feed
the bears.

(Editor's note: Porschephiles is an electronic mail list on the Internet
active since 1990 and now with well over 1,400 subscribers worldwide.
Membership is free, provided you have access to electronic mail and the
Internet. For more information about Porschephiles, send Email to:
porschephiles-request@tta.com)





------------------------------

Date: Tue, 9 May 1995 17:56:36 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 FAQ version 2.1

        This is a copy of the latest version of the 914 FAQ.  It has
been thoroughly revised from the version that currently resides on
tta.com.  Comments are welcome, as are more questions!

- --DD

 - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

914 FAQ v. 2.1
5/9/95          Dave Darling (darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov)
                With help from George Hussey (Dr914@aol.com) and
                much of the Pfiles mailing list

1) What the Heck is a 914, anyway?
        914 is the designation given to several types of production cars
made by Karmann, VW, and Porsche in the early- and mid-70's.  All had mid-
mounted engines, for good weight distribution and low polar moment.  Most
were roadsters, with a detachable Targa top.  All have excellent cornering
ability.  Many people have called it "the square Porsche," since it
departs from the traditional (Porsche) curved look of the 356es and 911s.
I have also received some ribbing about not being able to tell the back
of the car from the front.

2) So what is this "-4" or "1.8" or "/6" designation, then?
        When it was introduced in 1969 (1970?), there were two types
available.  The 914/4 used a fuel-injected 1.7 liter "pancake" four-
cylinder engine derived from that used in the VW 411.  The 914/6 came
with a de-tuned carbeurated 2.0 liter engine derived from that used by
the 1969 911T.  The /6 did not sell very well, and was dropped after
the 1972 model year.  The 1972 914/6 is somewhat rare--only about 240
were made--and was never exported to the US.
        In 1973, Porsche introduced a 2.0 liter four-cylinder model.
Early information labeled it as the "914 S", but this was dropped
shortly before or shortly after the model became available in the US.
The two versions were labeled by their displacement--the 914/1.7 and the
914/2.0.
        For 1974, the 1.7 was replaced by a 1.8, which used a different
type of fuel injection system in the US, and carbeurators elsewhere.
Power was lower than the earlier 1.7s, due primarily to emissions con-
trols.

3) Didn't I hear about a 914/8 somewhere?
        Yes, you probably did.  There were two very special 914s made by
the factory, using air-cooled eight-cylinder engines from the 908 race
car.  You can sometimes see one of them at the Porsche factory museum.
        The other type of 914/8 is a "regular" 914 which has had a water-
cooled V-8 engine, usually a Chevy, wedged into it.  We don't talk about
these cars because we're snobs.   8)   The V8 question has been debated a
number of times on Porschephiles.  The "official" consensus is that it
may be possible to do the conversion "right", but it is difficult and
there are many, many bad ones out there.  Also, a number of people object
to the generally inelegant way of dealing with the (water) radiator.

4) Okay, smart guy, what's a 916?
        In 1972, the Porsche factory made a number of cars that were
intended to be a prototype for a "super-car" 914.  These were the 916s.
They had the mechanically-injected 2.4 liter engine used in the 72-73
911 S, the large, boxy flared fenders from the 914/6 GT race car, fixed
steel roofs, and modified front and rear styling.  Some mounted front-
located oil coolers and a version of the 915 gearbox converted to run in
a mid-engined car.  They had super-plush interiors (leather or leather and
op-art fabric!) and some had power windows.  They were intended to be as
luxurious and top-of-the-line as possible.  One even had air conditioning
with the compressor behind the drivers seat!  There is some disagreement
over the exact number built, but the most authoritative source says that
there were 11 of them.

5) How hard is it to work on the engine?  That space looks awfully small!
        It is possible to perform all regular maintenance on a 914/4 with
the engine in the car.  The Sixes are supposed to be about twice as time
consuming as the Fours.  [Anyone want to loan me one for a year so I can
verify this?  8) ]  Spark plugs, timing, adding oil, and changing the air
filter are all straight-forward to do from the top.  Replacing plug wires
may require removing the air filter box, but that is either one bolt and a
hose clamp, or a couple of wire clips and a hose clamp.
        Transmission, oil filter, oil drain plug, sump screen, all are
easily acessed from underneath the car.  It is awkward to fit a standard
oil filter wrench on the 914's filter, but a BIG ol' pair of Channel-
Locks works just fine!
        Adjusting the valves is a chore.  At times, it seems as if *every-
thing* is in the way of getting to the valve covers!  However, it  is
possible to reach around everything and get to the adjusters.  Use a long
feeler gauge to check and set the clearance.  Have patience, and try sev-
eral different angles.  Removing the roadwheel on the side you are working
on can help.
        There are some things you just can't do with the engine in the
car.  Fortunately, it is not a difficult operation.  It only took me
about five hours my first time, and I'm a *complete* idiot!  An experienced
914 mechanic should be able to do it in as little as 30 minutes.  Most of
the time is spent "getting things out of the way."  Then remove four big
bolts, and carefully lower the engine and tranny down and out of the car.
(They come out as a unit--it's possible to do them separately, but just
about as easy to do both.)
        I'll let you know about putting it all back together when I've
actually done it myself.

6) What sort of options came on the 914 originally?
        Aah--I'll let someone with more experience than myself, George
Hussey of Automobile Atlanta (Dr914@aol.com), answer that in is own
words.

>Much confusion has occurred over the so-called appearance group offered
>as a 914 option. Packages were as follows:
>
>  1. Appearance group package '70-'72 and '73 1.7 models:  side vinyl,
>loop carpeting, chrome bumpers, leather wrapped wheel and shift knob,
>center deposit box, dual horns, driving lights and pedrinni alloy wheels
>  2. Appearance group '73 914 2.0 "S":  center console with gauges,
>armrest, storage box, loop carpeting, dual horns, chrome bumpers, fuchs
>alloy wheels, driving lights, front and rear sway bars, leather wrapped
>wheel and shift boot
>  3. Appearance group '74-'76 models:  center console with gauges,
>leather wrapped wheel and shift boot, side vinyl, dual horns, loop
>carpeting, armrest and storage box
>
>To keep the price lower in the later years, most equipment became
>optional.

        The 70-72 optional equipment was standard on the 914/6.
        Other information that I have indicates that the Factory split up
the 73 group into two separate groups for 74 and later.  One was the
"Sport Group" and comprised of alloy wheels, Bilstein shock absorbers,
and front and rear sway bars.  The other was the "Appearance Group" and
included all the rest of the 73 "S" stuff.
        In 1974, Porsche created a "Special Edition" or "Can-Am" version of
the 2.0L 914.  This car had all of the "regular" options, above, with one or
two differences.  There were three choices of paint scheme--white with orange
trim, white with green trim, or black with yellow trim.  A different front
spoiler was added below the front bumper.  Specially painted alloy wheels
were used, with accents matched to the trim color of the car.  They had
bumpers painted the trim color instead of chrome or black, as on the other
74 914s.  They did not have the vinyl rollbar trim, but did come with the
center console, leather shift boot, leather steering wheel, dual horns, and
the swaybars and Bilstein shocks which were optional on the other 914s.
These cars  are less common than other 914/4s, and are somewhat more valua-
ble as a result.

7) Can you compare the various 914/4's for me?

        A quick run-down of the US models:
Year  Displ  HP   F.I.   Comments
70,71 1.7L  80HP  D-Jet  Spartan interior, non-adjustable passenger
                         seat, non-retracting seat-belts, sloppy
                         shift linkage, cranky window winders . . .
72    1.7L  80HP  D-Jet  Some interior improvements.  Adjustable seat.
                         Late 72 first gets retractable seat belts.
                         Fuel pump moved lower in engine compartment
                         for less chance of vapor lock.
73    1.7L  80HP  D-Jet  "Late 914" introduced.  Side-shift transmission
                         shortens linkage, less sloppy.  Improved window
                         winders, better interior.
73    1.7L  72HP  D-Jet  Ditto, but with California emissions crap.
                         Lower HP from lower compression--to deal with
                         lower-octane gas.
73    2.0L  95HP  D-Jet  "914S" in some early ads.  Improved performance
                         from 2.0L engine.  All the optional goodies
                         were standard.  This is the one everyone wants.
74    1.8L  76HP  L-Jet  1.8 engine replaces 1.7.  Lower HP from lower
                         compression.  L-jetronic FI, viewed by many
                         as less reliable than 1.7 or 2.0 D-jet FI.
74    2.0L  95HP  D-Jet  Same as 73 2.0, but options weren't standard.
75    1.8L  76HP  L-Jet  Catalytic converter added for California.  5MPH
                         bumpers add weight, distributed toward ends.  EGR
                         on some  cars.  Fuel pump relocated to front of
                         car to reduce chance of vapor lock.
75-76 2.0L  90HP  D-Jet  Re-worked exhaust and heat exchangers lose power
                         and possibly engine longevity.  California models
                         get catalytic converter, 49-state get an air pump.
                         EGR may be on some cars.  Adds 5MPH bumpers as in
                         75 1.8L.  Fuel pump in front as in 75 1.8L.


8) What should I watch out for when looking to buy one?
        I'll try to run down the problem areas--my 1.8 pretty much has
all of them.  (Anyone wanna buy a 914, *cheap*?)
        Rust.  George Hussey has said, "There's no such thing as a rust-
free 914."  There might be one or two in the world, but they've probably
just gotten back from the body shop.  Particularly prone are the battery
box, on the right hand (passenger, in US) side of the engine compartment,
everything below that--which includes the right-rear suspension!  The
firewall in front of the battery, the jack points on the sides of the car,
the longitudinal members of the frame (the inner rockers), the rear of
the rear trunk floor, and just in front of the windscreen.
        Rust is the most common cause of body flex.  You can check for
flex with the "Dave's Big Butt Test."  Take the roof off the car.  Then,
get someone of Dave's size (230 lbs) or larger to sit in the passenger's
seat (the side with the battery!).  With the door closed, roll the window
up.  Then try to open the door.  If the window sticks at the top, the body
is flexing.  Also try the driver's seat.  Body flex is fairly bad news.
It can be cured, but it is generally time-consuming and expensive.
        Oil leaks are relatively common.  Some of the cures are cheap in
parts, but expensive in labor--e.g., oil galley plugs.  The oil pressure
idiot light sender, on top near the distributor, can leak.  Push rod tube
seals commonly leak--but can be replaced with the engine in the car!  Oil
cooler seals, the galley plugs, and the front or rear main seals are also
not uncommon.  The engine may need to be removed to fix these.
        The 914 is quasi-legendary for transmission woes.  Sloppy shifting
is part of the car's character, especially on the pre-73 cars.  Replacing
shift linkage bushings can help.  Short shift kits are also supposed to
help with this problem.  Many cars will crunch going into first gear.  Some
will also crunch going into second.  This may mean a rebuild is in the near
future.
        Tops leak--where the top seals join together.  Not always, but
frequently.  Check for signs of previous flooding.

9) How about carbeurators for a 914/4?  After all, the Sixes came
with 'em!
        Not if you live in California!  Other places are now following
the Left Coast's lead in emissions testing, so carb'ed 914s may soon
become illegal for street use in many places.
        A well-designed, properly-maintained FI system will give you
better performance, better start-up behavior, and better fuel economy.
Always.  The problems are in the "well-designed" (if you make changes to
your engine) and in the "properly-maintained" parts of that sentance.
        However, if you have modified your engine--for example with
higher displacement and compression, a wild cam, and killer exhaust--
the stock FI may not be able to keep up anymore.  Tweaking the FI is
difficult and time-consuming, and is illegal in many racing venues.
Therefore, carbs are the quick and easy answer.  After all, there are a lot
of people out there who know how to tweak carbs.
        A question you should ask yourself if you are thinking about
buying a carbed 914, even when it's street-legal, is "Why'd they do
that?"  Most frequently the answer is that the car had an FI problem
that the owner did not feel like dealing with, so he/she replaced the
whole induction system.  This sort of attitude *may* be indicative of
sloppy maintenance in general, and frequently these cars are in much
rougher shape overall than cars with operational FI.

10) So, which one should I buy?
        The 73 2.0, obviously.  But since it is so obvious, the price
is higher for these cars.  The 74 2.0, if it has the optional equipment,
is essentially identical.  Parts prices for the items unique to the
earlier 2.0, such as heads, exhaust and some FI parts, are more expensive
as well.
        Second choice would be either a later (75-76) 2.0 or a 49-state
73 1.7.  The former have more power and the front-mounted fuel pump, but
more weight and, higher polar moment, and seem to wear engines out
faster because the factory made them run hotter to pollute less.  The 76
2.0 is the very last of the 914s, and is fairly rare--only 4200 or so were
built.  These factors may drive the price up relative to the 75 models.
        Bringing up the rear are the rest.  This is mostly a matter of
taste.  The CA-emissions 1.7 is the weakling of the lot, but it does
have the interior improvements and the better transmission.  The 1.8 is
next in power, with all the refinements of the 1.7, but with a fuel
system that is less fault-tolerant.  In some ways, the L-Jetronic system
is superior to the D-Jet, but careful attention must be paid to avoid vac-
cuum leaks, backfires, and corroded relays.  The early 1.7 has more power,
but is less civilized and has the vague tail-shifter transmission.

11) What's this about Side-shifters?
        Up until the 73 model year, the shift forks on the 914 transmis-
sions were on the end of the tranny case, all the way at the back of the
car.  This meant that the linkage had to go from about 2/3 of the length
of the car and through numerous interconnected parts.  This is the so-
called "tail-shifter" transmission.
        In 73, the shift forks were moved to the side of the tranny case.
The linkage only had to travel about 1/2 the length of the car, and didn't
have as many angles to reach around.  It also had far fewer interconnected
parts to break or go out of adjustment.  This improved the shifting
dramatically.  This is called the "side-shifter" transmission.

Date: Tue, 23 May 95 11:47:04 +0200
From: Kari Eloranta <eloranta@lammio.hut.fi>
Subject: Re: slip angles

In a bit different context of rally racing one can see rather  
spectacular 4-wheel drift. Indeed seems that the way to drive an  
all-wheel drive car really fast on unpaved roads is what they call  
something like "leaning on the door". This means that the car heads  
to where the front right corner points (the co-pilots may not  
necessarily like this so they are just encouraged to watch the  
map...) The drivers practice this on straight pieces of road as  
well. As the traction isn't great i.e. there is some slip anyway by  
enforcing it the driver keeps the revs at the best part of the  
torque/power curve.

Kari Eloranta

Date: Mon, 22 May 95 14:12:57 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: Bleeding ABS equipped 951 brakes

Hello Fellow Porschephiles;

This message did not make it through last time so hewre it goes again.  I 
promise I will send in my $50 this week.

During my last Driver's Ed event in April I noticed increasing brake pedal 
effort was required as the event progressed.  I assumed this was due to some 
brake fade and normal pad wear.  I have stock pads.

After the event I bought a Mity-Vac brake bleeding tool because my SO got tired 
of pumping the brake pedal when I needed to bleed the brakes.  I assumed I could 
get back the normal hard pedal feel by bleeding the brakes and adding new fluid.  
After using my new tool, the brake pedal is still not as firm as it was before 
the track event.

Is there a secret to bleeding an ABS equipped 951 that I might have missed, or 
is increased pedal effort a fact of life as pads wear?  I bled out several 
ounces of fluid and bled both valves on each caliper.  I did not bleed the 
clutch.  Is there another way to get back the firm brake pedal feeling?  Any 
pointers would be appreciated.  TIA.

Tracy Meyer

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 10:34:32 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Help:rear wheel bearing 951

Hi Jerry,

Lou's posting pretty much sums it up.  I would heat the trailing arm
before pushing out the old bearing, though, and not just for the new
one.

The factory would have you take the arm off the car and use a press
to remove and replace.  This is fine but is a lot of extra labor.

Regarding the stub axle nut, this is sort of a known problem and seems
to particularly affect turbos -- no idea why.  My technique, for want
of a better description, for checking has been to jump up and down a
little bit on a breaker bar.  I also mark my nut/stub with a slash of
paint, making it pretty clear when/if the nut has loosened.

Porsche's lock nuts seem to be good for only a couple of uses, then they
no longer lock and will back off.  This is true, for example, of the
M14's they use at the top of the front strut.  It is certainly true of
the M12's used on the front strut camber bolts.  My advice would be to
always replace them, rather than reuse.  They're cheap enough.

This may be a feature of the type of lock nut Porsche uses, which gets
an interference fit by virtue of an oval distortion of the far end.
Carroll Smith claims that Nylocks, on the other hand, can be reused
indefinitely.

I don't know too many people with torque wrenches that will read 330
ft lbs.  I think everyone pretty much eyeballs it with an airgun.  We
picked up such a torque wrench last week, though.  The 944GTR now under
our care has titanium 90 mm centre-lock nuts that want to be torqued
to 440 ft lbs, thank you.

Kevin Gross

Porschephiles #1423                         Tue May 23 20:55:07 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 08:15:45 -0700
From: "    John Jones" <J.Jones@az05.bull.com>
Subject: Tach 911

I posted a fix it message a few months back. I had exactly the same problem
my solution and fix was to remove the bezel and invert the face glass. It would
appear the thermal expansion of the glass (plastic) makes it more concave and
it fouls the needle spindle. The Tach does not fall apart when its is
dissassembled.

Date: Tue, 23 May 95 12:19:00 PDT
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: Re: Front Plates and Revenuers


Two plates stories.
I also live in NYC and last year during one of the big storms my car was 
embalmed in snow. When the snow/ice melted, the resulting glacier drift slid 
off the hood of the car taking the front plate with it. The plate was 
clearly lying on the ground in front of the car and I received a $25 ticket 
anyway. Fought it and won.

On another occasion several years ago when NY changed from yellow and blue 
plates to the red, white and blue plates, I changed my rear plate and 
decided to keep the front plate the old series (vanity plates so both were 
the same). While waiting to cross and turn left at the busy intersection, a 
cop spotted the old plate and flagged me to make the turn (ending up in 
front of him). He promptly pulled me over and after a pleasant conversation 
I went home and changed the other plate.

Arthur E. Golden
AGolden@Pepsi.com
1988 944S

Date: Tue, 23 May 95 10:01:08 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Nuts


The mechanical distortion lock nuts, as used on the late 944 and 911
stub axles, are ONE-USE nuts. DO NOT re-use. Buy new, throw the old ones 
in the trash.

Kevin Gross makes a good point by marking the location and inspecting to 
see if the nut is backing off on a regular basis.

Nylocks may be reused if the nylon insert is not distorted or damaged. For
mission critical components, always use new locking fasteners (nuts and
wavy washers). Wavy washersa are good for two uses, then toss them. 

If the original fastener had Loctite or similar compound, find out what it
was, but it and use it. This is where Haynes manuals fall on their butts,
they don't tell what it was used nor do they put it in the procedure.

I will repost this in my next installment in Excellence.

Jim Pasha

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 14:38:12 -0400
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: M474 Suspension kits


spelk@bert.arc.nasa.gov (Steve Elkins) wrote:

>Just wanted to thank Jim Pasha for the post on the M474
>suspention from Denny Kahler.

Ditto, thanks Jim!

>I just put these KONI's on my '87 944S and it made an 
>amazing difference in the handeling.  If you own a 944
>with standard suspension you should really look into the
>M474 parts.  

I have a little play in my front wheels which I (and NNJR tech inspectors) 
diagnosed as loose wheel bearings.  I tightened but still had slight play.
The car drove fine on the track until my last event at Bridgehampton when I
started getting camber changes when cornering aggressively.  Kevin G. 
suggested bad struts but I did not want to break out the credit card since the
struts passed the rebound test.  At last Sunday's autox, I heard/felt a 
distinct loud thunk from the front end on hard right turns through slaloms.
I'm hoping changing struts will cure this.

I just ordered a set from Denny and waiting for it to arrive.  If you did the 
job yourself, how tough are the struts/springs to install?  Any 
gotchas/special tools other than spring compressors? How stiff did you set 
front/rear?  What is the difference in ride height before/after?  

Any other recommendations from the list for stiffness for an '87 951 with 
17" wheels?  I've heard 75% stiff front, 50% stiff rear is a good set-up for 
a street-driven car which also does autox/track duty.  Note, these are
NOT externally-adjustable, you set them when you install so I'd like to avoid
experimenting with different settings.

BTW, the M474 was the stock sport suspension on '87 951.

TIA,

Date: Tue, 23 May 95 14:43:44 EST

Date:          Tue, 23 May 1995 15:01:15 EDT
From: "Asad Husain" <AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd.edu>
Subject:       bleeding brakes

Hello all,

I installed a new Master Cylinder on my 1980 911SC.  What a pain.  The 
Haynes manual never mentioned the heater vent cable and other 
cardboard hoses etc had to be removed as well.  In any case I finally 
got the new M/C installed and bled the brakes twice but the brakes 
are still very spongey and don't stop the car as well.  I have 
checked for leaks etc but can't find any.  The Haynes manual does say 
that the inner and outer bleeder valve on the rear brakes should be 
bled.  I found the outer ones and bled through those, but I haven't 
found the inner ones.  Do they exist on  '80 911SC?  If so where are 
they?  I can't find them and the manual doesn't have any pictures.  
Maybe this might be why the brakes are still spongey.

we took it home without incident.

(tomorrow), but I would like to know a little more going in.

why would the alternator warning light come on?

2) What would cause such a malfunction?

3) What are the implications, if any?

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 14:06:17 -0500
From: TODD.COHEN@rrd.com
Subject: Bleeding Brakes using Vacuum

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
          TO:        OAS     -00000002 *porschephiles@tta.com
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      05/23/95
          TIME:      14:01:00
 
          SUBJECT:   Bleeding Brakes using Vacuum
 
 
Tracy,
 
I purchased a Mity-Vac vacuum bleeding kit and was dissatisfied with the
results.  From what I understand, when you pull the brake fluid out of the
bleed nipples, using vacuum, air comes in around the threads.  I
understand alot of people have the same problem with this tool.  I even
tried to wrap teflon plumbing tape around the threads to maybe fix the
problem, and this did not help.
 
I ended up going back to my old standby.  A $10 plastic tube with a oneway
valve on the end to prevent air from entering.  This allows me to bleed my
brakes by myself.  I understand that the Ezebleed (sp) system works great,
and fast.  I wish I had put the $25 that the Mity-Vac cost, toward the
cost of the $35 Ezebleed system.
 
Todd
1972 911T

Date: 23 May 1995 13:03:42 U
From: "John Lucas GRC" <John_Lucas_GRC@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re:  928 heater stuck. (HELP

                      Subject:                              Time:  12:46 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         RE> 928 heater stuck. (HELP!)         Date:  5/23/95

Kevin,

You wrote that 
> My 84 928S seems to have a stuck heater
<snip>

Sorry I didn't respond sooner, but I've been away for a few days.

I had the same problem on my '84 928S.  Porsche has a service 
bulletin that details how to trouble shoot this particular problem.
Your Porsche dealer ought to be able to provide you with a copy
if you ask them for it.

The most obvious possibility is the outside air temperature sensor
in the left front wheelwell.  On my car, a wire had broken and I
had to splice it back together.  That fixed the problem for about 
four months and then it occured again.  This time it was the servo
mechanism under the dash to the right of the steering column.  

I took the servo out and found that a circuit board inside had a 
burned out resistor.  I replaced the resistor and things worked OK
for a week or two and then the servo went belly up again.  Same 
test/fault isolation procedures as before (by now I'm pretty good
at this!) and I decided to scrap the servo.  I bought a *NEW* one 
from 928 International (just under $400 if I remember correctly) and
everythings been fine since.  Notice I stressed that it should be 
new:   they gave me a used one (you could tell by the marks on
the circuit edge connectors and the outside of the servo case), but
promptly changed it for a brand new unit when I pointed out the
problem.  

The Porsche diagnostics are absolutely critical.  They lead you 
through the fault isolation process to the point where you can
do a repair yourself or know what part you need to buy.  Get this
bulletin!  It will save you a lot of repair costs!

Let me know if you need any help.  I've worked on the frapping 
heater/cooling controls so many times I sometimes dream about
them!

John
'84 928S

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 16:38:35 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Autocross information - part1

Hi all,

I have been asked to submit my columns on autocrossing Porsches
to the archives. Here is the first of nine columns. Please let
me know if there are any mistakes or omissions, or other questions
that I should answer. I am editing and submitting them one at a time,
and will upload the whole thing after final editing.

Three Wheeling, By Mike Piera, CT valley region PCA. #1 of 9
	
This series of articles is specifically about Porsche car selection
and preparation for autocrossing. I will stress that car
preparation can be done at minimal cost with minimal modifications
(mods). I believe that most people should not modify their cars much.
Mods do little to improve times and can often make your car slower if
they are not thought out correctly. Mods are a very poor investment,
and will actually lower the value of many Porsches. Also mods will not
make you a better driver. You cannot improve your driving if your
mind is set on buying speed. 

Most Porsches are designed quite well and can be made competitive with
minor mods and adjustments. We see so many "Project cars" in
magazines, and ads and catalogs for great new parts, that many of us
are "romanced" into purchases that we may later regret. I am not
trying to damage the business of the many Porsche shops and parts
dealers. I do recommend several mods and upgraded parts that are
needed to be competitive, and I recommend that those without the
needed mechanical skills or tools take their cars to someone who can
do the job right.

I will concentrate on "SCCA Stock class" Porsches, with much fewer
mods than allowed even in the lowest of the Porsche Club rules (PCRs).
The PCR's are a chinese menu of allowable mods with
random points given to different mods. I think these rules were
created by someone from the federal government on acid. Setting up
a car to SCCA stock specs will allow you to run in the "stock" classes
in almost any car club, without being terribly outclassed. For example,
in SCCA the next step up from stock is Street Prepared. Someone from
the PCA with only larger springs or other small modifications would
be forced to compete against cars modified to the limits of SP (engine
swap, big wheels, flares, suspension updates, etc). Unless you
are willing to go all the way to the limits of the class you intend
to compete in, you are best off in a nearly Stock Porsche. 

I will try to outline the Porsches which have high autocross
potential with small modifications. Even if you have no plans on
trading or buying a car, it should help you see the potential of
your current car. These suggestions should also apply to track events,
but will be geared specifically for winning autocross.

To introduce myself, I have been autocrossing in Porsches seriously
for over twelve years, the last ten years in a Stock class 1972 911S
Targa. I am a two time SCCA Solo-II A-Stock National Champion ('85
and '90). In my two Porsche Club of America "Porsche Parades"
('91 and '94) I was the fastest of any of the stock "P"roduction
classes. 

More to come!

Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com
'72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0 (last two for sale?)

Date: Tue, 23 May 95 14:28:35 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Head temp

} From:  <FiewVinder@aol.com>
}
} The temperarure gauge in my 83
} 944--does it measure the temp of the head itself (and if so, where) or does
} it measure water temp.

Yes, it is in the head and it measures the temperature of the water in the
head. The sender is just to the left (driver's left) of the radiator hose
nozzle at the top of the head.

}   What is the optimum temp for long engine life?

Ideal temp is probably close to straight up (between the first and
second tick mark). Oil lubricates best when it is between 180 and
200 degrees Fahrenheit. I believe that the air cooled motors can
have the oil safely go up to about 220 degrees.

    Eric, who's owned 5 air cooled cars, all VWs, and one p-car,
           water cooled. hmmmm...
