Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 08:21:17 -0700
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: Re: 911 SC Valve Train Clatter

     Karl Haug writes: 
     
     >A friend's '83 SC with 91K miles has developed a loud clatter in 
     >the right side of the engine that sounds like a single valve with 
     >10X the clearance it should have.  The valves have been adjusted 
     >with no improvement.
     
     >-Any thoughts on what the noise might be?
     
     Sounds like a collapsed tensioner. Unless this model came with, or 
     was updated to, the Carrera tensioner, I'd check that out.  The 
     right side seems to go first.  Don't ask how I know.

Asad,
   It seems to me that you need to bleed more than twice. What I have had to
do to get good pedal is to bleed it at least 10 times. Accualy what we do
is to install pads that are almost shot, bleed the brakes then reinstall the 
new pads. Some reason this has allways worked. Getting good pedal is not 
easy with out many cycles of bleeding.

Date: Tue, 23 May 95 18:46:19 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: 911 Oil Leak/Electrical Problems

          Regarding the leaking oil drain plug on your crankcase:  If
          your threads are stripped, you might want to shop around for
          a replacement sump plate.  My threads were partly stripped,
          and although there was no leakage, I wasn't comfortable with
          how loose the drain plug appeared to be.

          I tried to buy a new sump plate, but found out they are NLA.
          I ended up buying a nice used plate from Foreign Intrigue in
          Berwick, Maine for $10 plus shipping.  Most of the
          other typical used parts sources wanted $25 to $30.

          If you go this route, you'll also need two new sump cover
          gaskets and new spring washers under each nut holding the
          plate on.

          Mark_Salvetti@abbsmtp.abb.com
          1979 911SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 23 May 95 18:46:21 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: 911 Tach Repair


          This is a response to the question regarding the sticking
          tach needle.  My 911SC has this problem when it's really
          warm out and the car's been in the sun.  Even when I shut
          off the engine, the needle sticks between 3,000 and 4,000.

          I asked about this at a tech session at last year's Parade.
          Apparently, hot weather can distort the plastic window on
          the tach so that it bows in and touches the needle.  When
          the car cools, the window pops back out and the tach works
          fine.  Next time your tach sticks, try using a small suction
          cup to pull out the window and see if this cures the
          problem.

          Mark_Salvetti@abbsmtp.abb.com
          1979 911SC Targa

O.K., I'm going to finally take the plunge and buy my first Porsche.  I'd like
some advice and get a sanity check.  First off, I've read every back issue of
EXCELLENCE and PANO...FIX'N Up...on and on.....I've bugged my poor Porsche
owning friends to death.  But I still have questions.  I know Brian Yee asked
for advice on this topic not long before I got on the list and I'd like to
read a digest of the responses to his questions if anyone could pass that
along....

I think I'm looking for a stock '84 911 coupe w/sunroof and maybe the factory
spoilers or turbo look if I can afford it.  Please read the items below and
tell me, am I on the right track?(pun intended)...

Here are the facts/requirements/constraints:
Budget of about 20K(25K if the S.O. is in a good humor) plus 1k per year for
Maintenance.
I'm 6'4" 210, will I fit?! The RX-7 we have now is a torture device on trips!
Nearest (decent) Porsche Shop is two hours, I'm in the middle of the desert!
I'm mechanically inclined and willing to do minor work, lube, oil, filters,
etc.
This car will be a Daily Driver for my S.O. and a Weekend Trip/Fun Car for me.
Reliability is more important than absolute performance.( As Ferrari found out
at Daytona! :-))
Need aComfortable Trip car-> good seats, A/C, quiet(except for the purr of 3.2
liters)
What is Rotary A/C and why is it good? 
Maybe driven in Driver's Ed, but no autocross or racing for now, what tire and
wheel combo should I look for?  What's "Stock" on '84 911's?
What's the difference between a car with "factory tubo look" and car's with
only "factory spoilers".
Are the spoilers worth having? One nice thing about the desert is, there are
places to let the car "stretch it's legs" do the spoilers really help?
Is engine cooling going to be a problem in the desert?....it can get hot, damn
hot, Tarzan couldn't take this kind'a hot here in Ridgecrest.
Is the oil cooler in the Tail onTurbo LOOK cars? Would this help cooling? 
I seem to be reading a lot lately about relatively low mile 3.2's in need of
top ends because the intake valve guides are worn, is this a problem with this
engine?  Another 3k for a top end shortly after getting the car would not be
fun.
Is the Porsche Market Letter worth the money?
I'm looking in the LA., SanJose, Reno  areas... if I find a car in San Jose I
thought I'd take it to Bruce Anderson's for inspection, but *who* can I trust
in LA and Reno?
How much should the inspection cost?
I've tring to convice the S.O. that a well cared for 911 will be a good,
reliable car for a long time to come, Am I telling the truth? (blatant ploy
for testimonials to show the S.O.)

Well that's enough for now, thanks for the bandwidth.

Date: 23 May 95 21:53:23 EDT
From: "Jay S. Karolyi" <102062.710@compuserve.com>
Subject: Got ticket in The Bast*rd-Too Loud!

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	I was cruising two weekends ago in The Bastard (my '75 Corvair
powered 914) having a nice drive.  It was on its first outing back from 
my brother's body shop, where it had its flares and 916 bumpers installed
and gorgeous fly yellow paint applied.  Really looks like the "Sunoco" 
914 in an old Panorama of mine.  I let my brother "work off" the $1000
he borrowed for his 914.  He did a show quaility paint job that took 
hours of prep.  He's also going to respray my mist green 924, which is
starting to look faded.
	Anyway, I was descending a small incline when The Bastard starts
ripping backfires loud enough to make people draw their Ak-47s.  Of 
course a revenue collector was nearby, and he pulls me over.  He says
"Gee son, thats quite a car you got there, you got this thing registered
for the road?"  Uh, yes. "Well you sure ain't got much mufflin' on it, 
I'm goin to hafta write chew up for makin two much noiz, What year is 
this vee-dubya?"  Uh, sir, it's a '75 and it's actually a Porsche.  
"Same difference" he chuckles.  Funny.  He finishes writing the ticket
and tells me to "hav a good wun".  
	He wrote me a ticket for a city offense (Charlotte, NC) for
"excessive noise in a residential area"  I hate to just pay the fine,
$100(!), even though I know I'm guilty.  What can I say in my defense?
One idea is to say I was on my way to get a muffler installed.  Any 
better ideas?  Oh yeah, I've really got to quiet down The Bastard, its
basically a straight pipe now.  Any suggestions as to mufflers?  Thanks
for any suggestions.
			Jay Karolyi
'75 Corvair/914 "The Bastard"
'77 924 w/NC plate "NOSBST2T"
'80 Toy 'rolla w/322,000 miles and counting!

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 23:18:15 -0400

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 23:28:54 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: M474 Suspension kits

At 02:38 PM 5/23/95 -0400, Stephen I Jagernauth wrote:

>I just ordered a set from Denny and waiting for it to arrive.  If you did the 
>job yourself, how tough are the struts/springs to install?  Any 
>gotchas/special tools other than spring compressors? How stiff did you set 
>front/rear?  What is the difference in ride height before/after?  

Steve,

I *highly* recommend that you replace the camber bolts and all associated
hardware.  That is,

 - the eccentric camber bolt,
 - the other bolt, M12 x 55
 - their lock nuts
 - the eccentric washer.

I also recommend that you add thick washers under the head and nut
of the plain bolt.  All this hardware gets real tired and tends to
gall.  The result is that it can be very hard to adjust the alignment,
and it can be impossible to make the camber stay put.

If you have a Cool Brake kit, be sure to put the bolt heads on the back
of the strut, so that they can be replace in future without pulling off
the hub.  (Yep, I fluffed this on my own car a few weeks ago.  Grr.)

>I just ordered a set from Denny and waiting for it to arrive.  If you did the 
>job yourself, how tough are the struts/springs to install?  Any 
>gotchas/special tools other than spring compressors? How stiff did you set 
>front/rear?  What is the difference in ride height before/after?

Not real hard to do.  You do need a spring compressor, and a big wrench
or airgun to get the M14 nut off the top.  Of course, you do need to
realign the car afterwards.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 23:38:37 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: bleeding brakes

Asad,

Chris Musante and I popped a new MC in Steve Curland's SC at the
Lime Rock club race.  So the knuckles are still scraped and the memory
fresh...  Steve had the courtesy afterwards to go out and win his
class, which is all that I ask.

Yep, it's a real pain to get to.  With all that room in the front,
you have to wonder why the factory chose to leave zero clearance between
the sheet metal and the MC.  What worked was to remove the two Bowden
cables from the heater valve, then unfasten the paper hose.  I could
then turn the valve out of the way enough to remove the MC.

All the callipers on Steve's car had single bleed valves on the inboard
side.  I borrowed someone's SO to pump the pedal, and she and I purged
the system the old-fashioned way without any difficulty.

Check the rubber hoses and make sure that they are not swollen and are
otherwise OK.  If they swell, or are clogged/constricted, you can get
a spongey pedal.  If this is the case, replace them with new OE rubber
hoses.

Kevin Gross

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 23:47:10 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine saga

> First I have never rebuilt an engine but have done all the work on
> the 914 that doesn't include welding. Is it possible to rebuild as a DIY or
> are specialzed tool purchases going to make that prohibitive as well as
> specialized knowlege. 

Well, you *CAN* do this yourself....

Couple of places to start: there's a book called something like 
"Rebuild Your Air Cooled VW Engine" that has a very, very good first
time step-by-step for building the 914 engine, including getting the
damn thing out of the car.

There's ALSO this thing called the "Spec Book". You gotta have one. It
has all of the critical measurements for wear tolerances, torques, etc.

Tools wise, you gotta have a good -- and I mean *GOOD* torque wrench,
basic hand tools, and some very fine measuring tools. It's also very 
handy to have a bench, a big bench vise, a parts washer, an air compressor,
and about three cases of spray carb cleaner... If you have the "hard stuff"
done at a machine shop -- which you need to do anyway, typically -- then
you don't really have to have anything special. 

As to experience, all of us remember staring at that First Engine with a
wrench in one hand going "Now What?". All of us.

> Second a coupe of places have suggested a mild cam and a combo of euro pistons
> and decking to make compresion 9:1 is this a good idea and do I need more oil
> cooling for this?

I routinely use the Euro 2.0 pistons, with a zero deck height, and have
the combustion chambers CC'd to give me 9.5:1 --- FOR RACING PURPOSES. For
a street car, I dunno, 9:1 is fine. In your part of the world it's not
that much of a need for added cooling. Down here in Texas, though, it would
be a requirement.

I also use a FAT cam, their "mild performance for fuel injection" part,
on a regular basis.

Stan

Date: Tue, 23 May 1995 11:01:00 -0500
From: david.stroop@asacomp.com (David Stroop)
Subject: Re: Those *#$&@ 914 sunvisors!


Wrote jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)

> Has anyone figured out a way to keep the 914 sunvisors tight and
> well in their slots in the retaining clips?


The following modification to the pins, if done properly, will
not be visible.  And, the pins will stay snug in their clips.

Remove the pins.  Note about where the tightening screws should
squeeze the pins.  Remove plastic from the pins such that they
taper from the inner end to just beyond the place where they are
squeezed by the screws.  The pins should not come to a point
but should still be somewhat narrower at their inner ends.
A resultant diameter at the inner ends of about one half of
original should be OK.

Be sure to preserve a circular cross section along the pin so
that the visor can still turn on the pin.

This taper will tend to cause the pins to be squeezed outward
instead of creeping inward as before.  This should keep the pins
snug in their clips.


One way to remove the necessary plastic from the pins is to use
a low speed drill.  Chuck a pin in the drill and spin the pin's
inner end against an abrasive surface at an appropriate angle.
Don't apply enough force to break the pin.

- --

Inventors Network - A non-profit serving Ohio inventors for 20 years.
Send "Request IN" in the subject and your name and city to my address
for a monthly E-newsletter.

david.stroop@asacomp.com
74 914 2.0, Black.  Original owner and clutch.

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 08:04:29 -0400
From: JWilli911@aol.com
Subject: Re: Short Shifters??

James,

While I believe you can buy a short shifter kit for the '72, you might want
to consider replacing your '72 linkage with the improved shifter from a '73
or later.  All other things being equal (bushings ,etc.) I think the '73
shifter was inherently a better design and may give you the improvemnt you
are looking for.

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 08:24:35 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: 911SC Alternator/Elec. problems/Parts Pricing


Hi,

I posted a few days ago about electrical problems with my tachometer
fluttering around and the seatbelt light coming on.   Well while
driving last night, I noticed the red generator light glowing slightly
while driving normally.  When I come to a stop (idliing) it stops
glowing and goes black.  The tach needle still has the problems of
fluttering up to 6000 RPM's intermittenly, and the seat belt light
comes on when this happens.  

A few people responded back saying it may be the ground strap, the
alternator, the voltage regulator, and possibly a bad brake light bulb.
But now since IU notice the generator light glowing ever so slightly
I think it may be the ground strap or alternator.  I do not know where
the voltage regulator is.  Tonight I have time off to look into this
problem.  How should I start to diagnose it?  I have a set of ramps I
can put the car on.  I would like to this repair myself.  How expensive
is an alternator (if that needs replacing), and are the rebuilt ones
ok to use?  (This is a 1981 911SC).   More importantly, how difficult
is it to replace the alternator?  Does it require dropping the engine
or any serious, serious dismanteling of the car?  Any hints thankful.

What about the voltage regulators?
Where is that thing and how can I check its workablility?

On another note: (This is about pricing of parts:)
Since it is national 911 repair week for me, I had a crack in a pipe
in the muffler system.  It was called the connecting pipe and runs
from the heat exchanger on one side, to the heat exchanger on the
other.  Running parralel to the axle of the car, and under the bell
housing.  It is about 1.5 feet long, has a triangular flange on each
end with 3 bolts for each flange.  It has a slight S-curvature to it
to fit under the housing and over another pipe.  Well after much effort 
wrestling with the 3 16-year old corroded bolts on either end, I managed 
to get the old pipe loose.  A used one is coming in the mail on Friday 
from PartsHeaven for $50, with gaskets and bolts.   

Now when I went mail order shopping from parts suppliers in the back of 
Panaorama and Excellence I got an EXTREME range of prices for this  
pipe.  Two places: Partsheaven and Kempton Brothers wanted $50 used, 
this was my lowest.  A dealer wanted $580 for a new one.  Vertex wanted 
$180 for a new one, but after I told them all this pricing bullshit 
they said they would give me the new one for $140.  Another place wanted 
$100 used, and $320 new.  What the hell is going on here with parts 
prices?????  I find the same thing to be true every time I want to buy 
a part.  I have to call 6-10 places and get ranges that vary by 300 
percent.  I usually find German Parts and Restoration to have the 
lowest prices - they were out of this part.

My point is (I think most people get my point), where do the people that
buy parts regularly get them from?  The people like Pete Albrecht - don't
you build porsches from parts daily (or you must know people that do?)?
I cannot imagine people that regularly buy parts call 6-10 places each time
they want something!  I realize that it IS a Porsche, but screw that
mentality, I am on a shoestring budget, and it pisses me off there is such 
a markup or mark down in the marketplace.  I am going to have a great time
finding an alternator!

Also, I fixed the oil leak I had by getting some new washers for the bolt, 
thanks to all who replied.  

Any advice with the electrical stuff is greatly appriciated.

 -Barry Chapin	chapin@draper.com
1981 Euro-911SC Targa
Engineer	Draper Laboratory, Cambridge, MA
Law Student	Evenings, Suffolk University, Boston, MA

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 06:43:55 -0700
From: "jim gregory" <jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Ring & Pinions

On May 22, 11:32pm, Afsar Husain (N3564) wrote:
> Subject: 944 Ring & Pinions
>
>
>     Who sells better ( strong, light weight??? ) Ring & Pinions?
>     Are these R & P interchangeable between later models of 944.
>     i.e. can I buy a stock 89-951 R & P and through that into my
>     existing unit.
>
>
> Thanks,
> Afsar
>
> --
> e-mail: husain@zeus1.issc.com
>-- End of excerpt from Afsar Husain (N3564)

Afsar-

You would not be happy with a 951 R&P in your 944. It is a taller ratio...(less
torque). If you were going to change it you may want to look into the R&P from
a 944S - it had a shorter gear ratio (what 944 turbo guys often put in for more
torque, until Porsche issued a statement advising against it).

I would go for a rebuilt transaxle, IMHO.

good luck.

 -jim

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 11:09:43 -0400 (EDT)
From: "H. Wilson Busby" <m950870@watkins.nadn.navy.mil>
Subject: alternator pulling for morons (LONG :)

I apologize in advance for the spelling, grammar, etc- but this is LONG, 
and is written by and for the weekend mechanic who doesn't know much proper 
terminology (so please excuse my use of: thingy, do-dad, etc...)  but, it 
works- and if anyone knows an easier way to pull an alternator. please 
tell me :)

Barry, my man- today is your lucky day!
Sitting on my desk is an alternator from my '81 SC targa- just pulled it 
last nite (second time I've done the job!)  It'll take less time to do 
than you might think, after I give you some hints- took me about 5 hours 
the first time since I only had a hanes manual, and nuthin else :(.
(relax! I pulled it in less than an hour last nite with poor lighting!!)
Ok, look at the engine- i'm calling the fan side the back- and get a 
ratchet to fit the nut on the alternator.  oops! first disconnect that 
(-) battery lead- heck, put a charger on it while it sits there :)
If you have something you can 
stick in the holes on the alternator pulley to keep it from turning while 
you loosen the nut, more power to ya', but i didn't, so i just a soft 
piece of wood in the fan (to bind between the fan and the fan housing- 
just stick it in the left side of the fan, and it should bind against one 
of the fixed vanes...) the nut only has 28lbs of torque on it so it 
shouldn't be too tight.  loosen it, and be careful to get all the 
washers, and note how many are on which side of the pulley.  that's how 
you adjust the belt tension, and it's probably best to leave the washers 
in the same way you found 'em... unless your belt's a lil' loose.  the 
more washers on the outside of the pulley-half, the tighter the belt.  
ok, now make sure you've done the battery- then loosen the two nuts on the 
coil (the round cylinder thingy on the fan housing- not that i don't 
think you know what it is :)  and push it outta the way, and then loosen 
one of the clamps from the heater blower to get the hose loose.  remove 
the other bolt holding the heater hose to the fan housing and just push 
it up and outta the way- it bends real easy like & doesn't mind as long 
as you're gentle and don't try to put 90 degree bends in it...
ok, look down near the distributor and pull that last bolt, it's in a 
funny place, but it's easy to see.  ok, now to get that ac belt and that 
alternator belt outta your way.  look at the lower left corner of your 
compressor.  you'll see a bolt with a nut on it pointing out sideways- 
this is used to tighten the compressor belt- loosen this nut so it's 
about to fall off- no need to take it off, ya' might lose it :)  look at 
the side of the compressor facing you, and beneath the clutch/wheel 
thingy, you'll see two bolts facing you.  loosen these just enough to 
make 'em loose on their slides.  look behind the compressor (twds the 
front of the car) and you'll see the head of a bolt (near the right 
corner of the comprsr) loosen it.  if all these are loose enuff, she'll 
slide easily to the left.  she'll be smushing against the heater hose a 
lil', but she won't hurt it.  you may hafta force her against the hose a 
lil, putting a "dent" in the hose (don't worry, just don't ram it, gently 
force it)  the belt on the a/c comprsr will be a lil' tight to get off, i 
usu. start at the to, pull it off with my hands and then use a 
screwdriver to GENTLY pry the rest of the belt off- just be sure not to 
cut or pull any threads off the belt- or you'll be on your way to a belt 
failure... i'm not saying you gotta be a surgeon while doing all this, 
but just don't get pissed and start banging things around=- they'll break 
(i know :) ok, now just push the belt down into it's lil' well and after 
a lil' wiggling and tugging it should come off, same for alt. belt... just 
an aside, if you do any autocross, etc, i hear that pulling your a/c 
belt gives ya' an extra 5hp...
anyway- on to the real nasty stuff.........
loosen the allen wrench bolt with a 7/32 allen wrench- watch out! that 
clamp thingy may spring out and getcha (mine did-ouch!!)  ok, GENTLY 
slide the whole housing out (fan, big round housing, etc)  be careful, 
since there are wires attached to that baby and we don't wanna break 'em.
it won't come out too far, just enough for you to see the the nuts going 
around a funny cone shaped piece with two fins on it.  be careful- those 
damn fins will break off (again, I KNOW :)  ok, gently remove each nut 
turning the whole thing to get to them.  you can get most of them by 
turning to the left, but you've got  get the last two by turning to the 
right (this is where i broke my fin off) it won't go too far b/c of the 
left fin, DO NOT FORCE IT- let your hand get a few scrapes and bend in a 
funny way, it beats the hell outta reattaching one of those fins :)
oh yeah- don't forget those washers- keep 'em all!  slide that plastic 
thingy back and you should be staring at "five" wires- actually five sets 
of wires-  three red, two brown, one blue, and one BIG red wire, and the 
one small black wire.  draw a 
picture of this thing so you know what goes where when ya' put in the new 
one.  (whew- long ain't it folks :)
loosen all them bad boys, and viola! (or something like that)- and you've 
got an alternator assembly sitting in your lap! 
ok- now the fun part.  turn that baby over, get a rubber mallet, and 
GENTLY get that thing knocked out (it should slide out the front, fan and 
all- unless you could already get the fan off, i couldn't...)  the fan is 
also a lil' snug- just have LOTS of patience and take some time to get 
those things tapped out.  just remember-you're dealing with cast 
aluminum- not too hard to break or damage, and since it's to pretty close 
tolerances (not to mention balance) just take some time- these things are 
in tight and will eventually come loose.  the installation is just like 
the removal- and about as tricky.  I'm a 22 yr. old computer scientist 
getting ready to graduate from the U.S. Naval Academy- and if I can do 
the following in a parking lot... anybody can :)
The voltage regulator- look behind that piece of black plastic held on 
with two wing nuts- you'll see fuses, relays, etc.  it's the big thingy, 
towards the front, it'll be black plastic, mounted by itself to the 
firewall, and will probably have some kinda figure on top- it'll say 
"14v" and then 'made in france'- the 14v part is a lil' artsy looking. 
but you'll know it when you see it- it's about 2" x 2" x 2.5", with a 
singe, 3 pronged plug coming from it.
if you get a new alternator, it'll probably have a built in voltage 
regulator- so all you do is pull the old regulator out and ditch it.  as 
for the alternator wires, just clip and tape up the small black wire 
(there won't be anywhre to attach it on the new one...)- that's it!
as for what to get, i recommend going thru Europroducts (1-800-962-0911).
you could get a rebuilt for about $180, but the guys at euro can get you 
a new one for $239- and all the mechanics I've talked to say it's worth 
the money to get new- since rebuilts sometimes have problems (as well as 
a shorter life- and once you've pulled the damn thing, you won't want to 
do it again anytime soon!!)  as for europroducts credentials- they supply 
automotion with alot of their stuff- and they've told me anything in 
automotion, they can get you the same exact part for LESS :)
so, happy tooling- and remember, if you see some young punk driving a 
white 911, no his daddy didn't buy it- and he does his own work too :)
(sorry Barry- couldn't resist :)
call me at my # and leave a message if you have any questions, and I'll 
get ahold of you ASAP.
good luck- you'll need it,
buZZ  


**********************************

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 08:14:43 -0700
From: "    John Jones" <J.Jones@az05.bull.com>
Subject: Re: Tach 911

I'll look or the original. The TACH is only held in by the rubber gromet in the
dash. It's a push fit! Ease it out and disconnect the wires. To remove the
bezel you have to bend the bezel up using a small screwdriver. Ease it a little
at a time, going round more than once if necessary and changing to a larger
screw driver. This piece is against the gromet so it doesn't show afterwards if
you are careful. Bend the bezel back using two pieces of wood so it doesn't
mark the bezel face.

Cross Section

           ----
           |============ Glass
   bezel   |===
           -- |
            ^ | body
            | |
    bend here |

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 16:36:46 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 930 front lights wiring mess

On Tue, 23 May 1995 Philip3118@aol.com wrote:

> 
> I am not sure I understand what purpose would be served by installing a
> relay. It seems to me that the amount of current drained through the wire is
> causing the copper female connector in the nylon housing to overheat. I

Philip

If you have a connector melting it is because you have a poor connection 
at that point - you only need to be dropping 2 volts accross the 
connector to develop a couple of watts of heat, this will be sufficient 
to melt plastic connectors, because they are good insulators and keep the 
heat in.
	clean the contacts, and for spade type connections you can give 
them a gentle squeeze in a pair of pliers.


Pete
+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 11:15:53 -0500
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Misc 356 woes....

I've had a very, very hard to diagnose front end problem on my '64 SC.
Finally, I have an answer: the bearings that support the upper right
trailing arm are shot.

OK, fine. I look in the Stoddard catalog, yup, they're there. And there's
a supercession part number. OK, I can deal with that...

I call Zim's. They tell me these little guys are NLA. Plus, if they
*ARE* available, they're hand-hammered from the gold of the gods by
Bavarian virgins only on nights with a full moon and as a result cost
the earth. I'm wished luck in my search, but don't get much help...

So I call Stoddard. I cringe, knowing that if they have them, and if
Zim's is right... well, if you've done business with them, you know
the rest. OK, it's not TOO bad -- the whole deal is like $110 per
trailing arm, but of course there ARE four trailing arms...

So, before I send the order to scenic Willoughby, OH, I figured that this
would be the perfect forum in which to seek help/advise/commentary. Anyone
out there have any OTHER suggestions? I hear rumor that at least on 
pre-A and A cars you can use some late VW Beetle part instead. How about
on the Cs? And given that this is going to require removal of the whole
front end, who does a good job reinforcing the trailing arms and C-link,
and what should I expect to pay for that?

On the other hand, this is refreshing -- it's a part of the car I haven't
taken apart yet... Oh joy...

Stan

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 13:07:17 -0400
From: Jolcycle@aol.com
Subject: Re: Rear View Mirror for Racing

After long deliberation, I proceeded to instal a five panel "wink" mirror in
my 85 Targa. This of course eliminates the sun visors, but the mirror now
blocks the sun glare, so it doesn't matter. It works so well that I hardly
need the side mirrors.
I don't know how I went all this time with one of those dinky little center
mirrors, and when I drive my wife's car (without the wink) I feel blind! 
On the track, the big mirror is great, and I don't get "surprised"
anymore-maybe I'm just getting faster.
You just need to get past the cosmetics, cause it does look a little tacky,
but the results are worth it.

Hopelessly addicted, 
Jolcycle

------------------------------

before the Porsche polize got after him.

jomart1".

Just a word of warning - I lived in Jackson for two years and the winters are 
vicious, the amount of sand and salt on the roads in the spring and early summer 
is incredible.  Most of the backroads around town are in terrible shape (dirt). 
 I would recommend to anyone to go to Jackson Hole - It is a beautiful place to 
ski, hike, camp and hunt, but to buy an older porsche?  I would look in S. Cal. 
or Arizona.  Hey but if you need an excuse to go on vacation go for it.  Just be 
prepared to fly back once you see the car!  If you want any recommendations on 
where to go let me know!

Scott

66 912

Date: Wed, 24 May 95 13:15:59 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: Setting Deck Height -- 914

 Greetings,
 
 914 case is going to FAT Performance tomorrow.  Recent suggestions have been to 
 machine the case for zero deck height and then to set the compression by ccing 
 the comb. chambers.  OK, sounds good.  Does this require me to get the euro 
 pistons and liners first or can I just go down to FAT and say "Here's some $$$, 
 make it so!" ?  (i.e. will they know how much to take off to get the deck 
 height to be zero -- I suspect not!)
 
 Also,  recent suggestions have pointed toward a 9.0 compression ratio.  The 
 engine is for "spirited" street driving and 9.0 tells me that I may not be able 
 to run on pump gas... certainly not 87 octane.  Anyone have any comments as too 
 a good compression ratio for stock gas (87 or 92 octane options?)  I was 
 thinking that an 8.5 CR would be a pretty good compromise.  Any comments?
 
 Engine will be run with D-Jet FI, FAT 440HP cam, remote mounted Accusump and 
 Canton/Meca filter, euro 2.0 cylinders, etc.
 
 Thanks!
 Tim
 radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 16:51:55 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Autocross information - part2 (911 stuff)

Hi,

I have been asked to submit my columns on autocrossing Porsches
to the archives. Here is the second of nine columns. Please let
me know if there are any mistakes or omissions, or other questions
that I should answer. I am editing and submitting them one at a time,
and will upload the whole thing after final editing.

There have been several requests for permission to use this material
in PCA newsletters, etc. Please ask before using it, but basically
any PCA use will be granted if the author is noted, and I would like
a copy of the publication with my material in it.


Three Wheeling, By Mike Piera, CT valley region PCA  #2 of 9

This article will discuss the selection of Porsches based on their
competitiveness in autocrossing with minimal modifications. I will
start with the 911 models. I don't mean to leave out the 356's, but
I have not seen too many 356s autocross on the East Coast lately.

The models that I do not recommend can usually be updated to the
better performing models, but it is better (and usually cheaper) 
to start out with the right car. And updating a car will often 
move you to another class unless the rules are followed closely.

The very early 911s ('65-'68) are good for collecting but are not well
suited for competition. They have short wheelbases with too much rear
overhang, narrow wheels, and low torque engines which fouled up too
easily. Notice that I mentioned torque rather than horsepower. There
have been numerous battles between people who claim that horsepower is
more important than torque and vice-versa. I will not get into this
argument, but I think what you should look for is "highest torque at
useable autocross RPM". A high horsepower road racing-type engine with
hot cams will not be able to accelerate well out of a low speed
autocross turn without using first gear. You need to have good torque
at about 3000 RPM to have a good autocross car. But it is still nice 
to have high RPM horsepower for the longer straights, and be able 
to avoid upshifts which require downshifting a few seconds later.

Starting in '69 the 911 wheelbase was increased, wheels and fenders were
widened, brakes improved, and engines improved somewhat. The chassis
on a '69 with the S options (sway bars, 6" wide 15" wheels, etc) is
adequate if it is not structurally weakened by rust.
But these 2.0 Liter engines were still a bit low on useable torque.
The E and S engines had "mechanical" fuel injection, which is
better than the original weber carbs when it is working correctly.
Unfortunately it is expensive to maintain and many cars have
carburetor replacements. It is hard to believe that people are still
putting carbs on 911 engines, as no Porsche since 1971 has used 
them. As usual, I recommend stock Fuel Injection (FI), but if you
must modify the fuel system for a special engine, there are several
excellent computer-controlled fuel injection systems now available.
Haltech is the most successful and seems perfect for any modified
engine since it can be custom programmed with a Personal Computer.
But figure the total cost of several times your initial estimate
to get a programmable FI running correctly.

In '70 and '71 the engines were "bored" to 2.2 liter displacement for
better power. These are slightly better than the previous 2.0 engines.
About this time the CD ignition was added to help the fouling problems.
The 911S was available with lighweight aluminum engine cover
and other options to give it an excellent power to weight ratio.
But the S engine was still somewhat weak on low-RPM torque. These
are really the oldest 911s that have been competitive in stock classes.
The T was still carbureted, but with Zenith carbs which work fine for
autocrossing. Some people prefer the Zeniths to Webers, but they are
not as tuneable to different engine configurations.

For '72 and '73 the engines were "stroked" to 2.4 liters and
compression was lowered to meet pollution standards without 
sacrificing performance. Now FI was standard even on the T engine.
The 2.4 T is about as fast as than the original 2.0 S, with much 
improved driveability. Some people believe the 2.4 E engine is better
suited to autocross than the 2.4 S, but after plotting the torque
curves I have determined that the S engine is better due to a much
stronger top end, higher redline, and only slightly less torque at 
lower speeds. Only the T engine would show any real low RPM benefits,
but only at very low RPM where you should not be driving anyway.

The '72 model was the only year that had the oil tank moved forward
with an external oil filler like the 959, offering marginally better
weight distribution. Starting in '73 "crash bars" were welded in the
doors.  The other big change in '72 was that the transmission changed
from a 901 to a 915. It was beefed-up, and the shift pattern changed 
to a normal pattern with first gear easier to find. Also the '72 S
was the first Porsche offered with a spoiler (front only, by '73 most
911 models had them). In '73 the shift linkage was improved slightly,
but the '72 is not bad with good bushings. I may be biased, but I think
a 2.4S (or E) is one of the best cars Porsche ever built. About 2300 
pounds and 190 HP make for lots of fun, with a light feeling that is 
missing from the late model cars. 

The biggest visual change in the 911 came in 1974 when the larger
bumpers were added. Engines were bored out again, this time to 2.7.
Unfortunately, in the USA smog laws were getting tougher so the
fuel injection was changed to CIS, which meant a change to very
mild cams. But the power was still very good (especially on the S)
and the torque was even better than before. Also the weight in '74
was not much more than the '73, due to aluminum bumpers which lasted
only one year. Also lasting only one more year was the early style
tuned-exhaust. 

The US models continued to diverge from their European brothers, which
started with the '73 Carrera RS which was not legal in the USA. A 
special '74-'75 911 was sold in the USA as the Carrera model. This
was similar to European models, except for the standard CIS S engine.
But it did include the famous "duck tail" rear spoiler, front spoiler,
rear fender flares, and bigger wheels and sway bars. This was the
first 911 offered in America with bigger wheels standard :
6" front and 7" rear originally, followed in late '74 by 7" and 8"
wheels, all of 15" diameter. In autocross, wide wheels are one of
the most important features a car can have. This makes the '74 
Carrera a killer car in stock class. Few of these were made, but 
they are often for sale at reasonable prices. Also it is easy (and 
sometimes cheaper) to make one from a normal '74 S. A problem with 
the 2.7 engines was that they tended to pull themselves apart. This 
can be prevented with a modern rebuild with updated studs and 
timeserts to keep them together. But beware of an old 2.7 engine 
with noise!

In 1975 the 911 really went downhill (yet it was still the fastest
car you could buy in America at the time!). Thermal reactors were
added to the exhaust system for pollution control. Power went down,
and problems went up. Also the bumpers grew heavier. These '75 -'77
cars are not desireable in stock form. Rust was no longer a big
problem starting in '76 when most sheet metal was galvanized. But
partial galvanization had actually started much earlier, and early
seventies models that were not exposed to salt can hold up well.
Be sure to check the front suspension pans, rocker panels, and
rear torsion tube area on any older 911.

Finally in '78 things improved with the SC model, which received
a big 3.0 liter aluminum engine with 180 HP and good
torque. Also the rear fenders were flared to accept 8" rims in the 
back like the earlier Carrera models. But the 3.0 engine was 
heavier than the earlier magnesium case engines, and the cars were
gaining heavy standard features like AC, sunroofs, and power
assists. 16" diameter rims were introduced, but for autocrossing the
15" rims are actually better, lowering the car and allowing wider
tires without clearance problems. The 7 and 8x15" is the hot setup,
and was available as a factory option so they are legal in stock
classes. 
	
The 911 carrera replaced the SC in 1984. These had an improved
DME computer controlled fuel injection, and larger stroke 3.2 liter
engine with about 210 HP and good torque. The turbo-look option was
available, which used 911 turbo wide fender flares front and rear, 
turbo wheel sizes, and other turbo parts. They had most of the 
benefits of the turbo without the troublesome and expensive turbo 
engine. These can be very fast autocrossers, except on very narrow 
courses. The '89 speedster has similar potential. The suspension 
was stiffened on all 911s in '86 to make the now even heavier car 
handle better, with bigger sway bars and torsion bars. The '87-'89 
models were even better, with a new G50 transmission which shifts 
much better than the notchy 915. The engine specs also claimed a tad
more power in '87. The very rare '88 "Club Sport" model is a great 
autocrosser, with a higher redline, more power, and a bit lighter.

In '89 the carrera 4 arrived, with a totally new chassis with
coil-spring suspension and a powerful 250 HP 3.6 liter engine, but
hundreds of pounds more weight. These cars also have "off-road-
look suspension" with a very high ride height, even though
Porsche insists the 4 wheel drive is for normal roads. These
cars have great power and acceleration, but have not proven to be well
suited to autocrossing. In '90 the carrera 2 replaced the original
911 for good. It is basically a carrera 4 without all wheel drive.
This car should be a good autocrosser, but unfortunately is still
overweight by a few hundred pounds. The best carrera 2 is the RS
America model which comes standard with all the performance options
(sport suspension, huge wheels, etc). This RS model is a bit lighter
(less heavy?) and actually costed less. And finally you could order a
Porsche without air conditioning! An RS is not meant to be a luxury
car. Have I offended anyone yet?
	
The 993 was introduced for the 1995 model year, with the first
major change to the 911 shape. The 3.6 engine was further refined
to produce about 270 HP and more torque. But the biggest
advantage to autocrossers (except the lower price!) is the rear
suspension. It is now mounted in a subframe with modern links which
keep the suspension pointed in the right direction. This allowed
Porsche to make a much better balanced car, which does not understeer
as much as the previous 911. The 993 will prove to be the fastest 
Porsche ever on the autocross course, and should be able to keep up
with any other production car.

I have not mentioned the different body configurations. Theoretically,
the best body for autocrossing is a coupe without a sunroof (sunroofs
add weight in exactly the wrong place). But for a basically stock
Porsche, the body style does not matter much. A Targa or Cabriolet
with stock springs (torsion bars) will handle fine, although they are
slightly heavier. It seems that the fastest stock 911s are often open
cars. That about wraps it up for the 911 line. Next I will cover
the other Porsche models.



More to come!

Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com
'72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0 (last two for sale?)

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 14:24:13 -0700
From: dab@hyperion.engr.sgi.com (David Brown)
Subject: 914 1.8 liter FI: broken air box temp sensor

I've got a '74 1.8 liter 914 that I'm trying to get into tune, and
found a (possible) problem *within* my intake air sensor.

Do any 1.8 liter FI wizards out there have any advice on this?

My intake air Temperature Sensor is broken.  This is a very small
device made from a couple of pieces of metal and a spring; it's
*inside* the air box, sticking out into the airflow just before the
sensor flap.  Two leads from this device stick up into compartment
with the PC board and potentiometer, and plug into the connector going
to the FI wiring harness.

I found my temp sensor was physically broken; the metal parts are
dangling loose, I can't tell what the spring was supposed to do, and
there may even be some missing plastic pieces.

The Previous Owner shorted the leads from the sensor together,
probably thinking that a temp sensor resistance of zero was "normal".
This seems to work *somewhat* well; the car runs okay (but not great)
like this, and won't run at all if the temp sensor resistance is
infinity!

Does anyone know how this sensor really works?  What are the metal
contacts and that tiny spring supposed to do as the temperature
changes?  And most important: anyone know the nominal "cold" and
"warm" resistance values that this device is supposed to report?

Thanks very much for any advice or suggestions...

 - David

Date: Wed, 24 May 95 17:21:09 EDT
From: "John Hora" <jhora@VNET.IBM.COM>
Subject: 914 Bumpers

For great looking Bead Strip and Rubber Horns (Factory names for the rubber
parts on the 70-74 bumpers) try using Meguiar's #42 Rubber Treatment.
Best stuff I have found yet for these rubber parts. It not only cleans
but protects also. Use exactly as directed and try cleaning with a
soft brush the first time. It has made mine look just a good as a brand
new Rubber Horn I got at a swap meet that was in the original wrapper.
It doesn't make them shiny like some products, just a nice matte finish.
If you can't get locally, try our P-philes buddy Larry Reynolds at
Car Care Specialties 201-796-8300 he has the whole Meguiar line....

John  73/74 914s

Date: Wed, 24 May 95 10:57:56 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Ring & Pinions

| From: Afsar Husain N3564  <husain@zeus1.issc.com>
|
|     Yes, I have got a set of these babies that have to be
| replaced.
|
| I know I can buy a used transaxle, but right now I am only
| interest in replacing the ring & pinions on the current one
| ( this way I can still have matching number, I don't know
| what that is worth ). So let me take some time to  pose
| the following questions:
|
|     Is the amount of efforts required in replacing the  R & P is
|     the same as rebuilding the trans, completely?

Caveat #1: I've never rebuilt a tranxaxle. The following is what
I have gleaned from the factory service manual plus talking to
others.

That said, my understanding is that the R&P is the hardest
part of the trans to do, with several precise adjustments/shims
to be made (pinion gear lash).

|     Is there a alternative i.e. replace R & P with absolute minimum
|     amount of transaxle disassembly.

Hmm, if your R&P is shredded, the tranny probably has metal
fragments throughout. You would want to completely disassemble
just to clean and inspect everything. You might have bearings that
are scored from metal particles.

|     Who sells better ( strong, light weight??? ) Ring & Pinions?
|     Are these R & P interchangeable between later models of 944.
|     i.e. can I buy a stock 89-951 R & P and through that into my
|     existing unit.

Special purpose R&P will most likely cost more than stock, but I've
never priced them.

|     Haynes Manual is very vague about rebuilding the Transaxle. Does
|     the shop manual cover this subject in more detail.

The shop manual is an absolute pre-requisite. It devotes a full volume
to the transaxle and has the entire proceedure detailed. Some special
tools are required and access to a hydraulic press is probably a good
idea. Some of the special tools are press mandrels and some are
measuring gauges. I'd buy, beg, or borrow a shop manual and take a
look to see if this is something that you want to attempt. I know folks
who have done 901/915 transaxles who say that it is not really all that
hard. Perhaps this also applies to 944 transaxles.

    Eric



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 18:45:39 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: re: Porsche Alarms

Hi,

If you are going to get an alarm installed in a 911,  make sure you have the
installer show you where the brain is installed. My parents had a Clifford
installed in their '87 911 targa about 5 years ago. Only now after having had
the A/C checked (never really needed it in the Bay Area, Miami is a different
story), did we find out that the brain was installed behind the floor boards
covering the A/C air intake giving us less cold air output.  I didn't want to
fool around with the wiring so I just screwed to the back of the floor board.


In my '73 911 targa, the alarm was installed in the trunk which is great
because the trunk can be locked and there is no easy way for a thief to get
to it.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa
neilk356@aol.com

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 18:43:07 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: 911 A/C and rotary compressors

Hi,

I wrote about Porsche alarms in an earlier post and mentioned that we had the
A/C checked out. The A/C mechanic told us that we had a leaking evaporator
and wanted to replace it for $1275  (including dryer and freon). He said that
he could see it dripping it oil, which he didn't point out to me and I
couldn't see, and the whole unit looked like it had not been taken out to be
examined- still had dust all over it.  Furthermore, he wanted to charge me
around $1000 for an evaporator that Linda at Carleson Porsche can sell me for
$420. I know that he make money off parts, but that was really ridiculous.
Needless to say, we went to an even more disreputable place and had the car
recharged w/o a leak test for $60. 

Anyway, I see advertisements for rotary changeover kits at varying prices.
Which compressor is good and which one should be avoided at all costs
 (Nippondenso, Sanden, etc) ?  Will a bracket from a late model 911  fit a
'73 911 2.4 engine?  Also, if I take out my piston compressor and put in a
rotary, which reciever/dryer do I need to buy- i.e. an '83 or before or an
'84 and after? I don't want to mix and match stuff and come out with a
mismatched A/C system that doesn't run well. 

Lastly, does anybody know the lengths of the different A/C hoses that run all
over the car? I would like to have some made and install them myself, but I
would prefer not to have to take out the old ones until I'm ready to put the
new ones in. That way I know where everything belongs and am less likely to
lose any hose brackets.

Thanks for your help,

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa
neilk356@aol.com  

p.s. any personal experiences would be appreciated.

Date: Wed, 24 May 95 15:48:15 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: 69 912 Starting Problems


Marc-

Had a similar problem with my first car, an old Plymouth.
Turned out to be bad rings.  Really bad.  When the engine
is cold there's not muchg compression, and starting is hard.
When it's hot, things expand, the compression gets a bit
better, and in general it's easier to start.

If that's the problem, I bet your burning oil.

 -Bob Spindel

Date: Wed, 24 May 95 11:05:04 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: ?911 C2/C4 Factory Manual Question

| From: Scott Kelly  <scokelly@netcom.com>
|
| I purchased the C2/C4 manuals from local Porsche dealer for about
| $240.00.  I got volumes 1(Engine maint), 2(Trans man), 3(Trans auto),
| 4(Chassis), 6.1(Body), 6.2(Heat&A/C), 7(Electrics).
|
| But I did not get Volume 5(whatever that is) and many of the sections are
| not present, like Vol6, Sec60 Sunroof.  I suspect that this is because it
| is the same as pre-1990 cars - but wasn't sure.
|
| The box has the following info: WKD482520 english.
|
| What's up?  I sent a letter to PCNA and they sent a card saying that
| Supplement WKD482520.22 for the 911 Carrera 2&4 repair Manual has been
| published...blah blah.
|
| Can anyone shed any light on this?  If I need another manual - what do I buy?

Porsche manuals are cumulative. Any info that is covered in a previous
model's manual is not reproduced in the later manuals. So, you need the
manual for a prior years model, but I am not sure which. Perhaps what
you need is in the '84-'89 manual. Ask the dealer if they have that manual
in stock and if they would let you look at it. Does anyone on the list have
this manual? Does it have the info that Scott seeks? Hmm, what info is it
that you need, Scott? Was it in a prior message?

    Eric

Subject:       951 balance shaft belt loose?

  My recently purchased 1987 951 (with 25,000 miles) is about to do 
it's first track event.  I was told that the belts were fine and the 
car was serviced well by it's past owner.  As part of my pre-event 
checking, I decided to get crazy and look at the belts.  They look 
fine, but I will be replacing them anyways sometime this summer.
  Anyways, to make a long story short, the timing belt is tensioned 
o.k. (I did the self tensioning thing because it's an '87)  The 
balance shaft belt seems quite loose.......I don't have the 9201 
tool, but someone else on P-files once said that he set the tension 
on this balance shaft belt with the proper tool and after he was done 
it could be twisted 180 degrees.  If that is the case, mine is fine.  
  Any words of wisdom?  Is it normal for this belt to seem much 
looser than the others? 
Any thoughts are greatly apreciated and as always, thanks in advance.....
Don Thompson
'87 951 (black)

shaft belt with the 9201 tool and when they were done the belt could 
be twisted 180 degrees at the midpoint of the long stretch of belt.

degrees.  Any words or wisdom?  Does this belt seem much looser than

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 17:15:42 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: Stolen 911 2.2 motor

Followup on my posting 2 weeks ago re. my stolen motor:

Description of suspect:

White male, approx 30-35 yrs old
shoulder length sandy brown or reddish-brown hair
185-195 lbs
approx 5'10"
crooked yellow teeth
no beard

driving off-white Toyota pickup with camper shell
blue license plates

Last seen May 10 in another burglarized storage shed in the same facility
where mine was broken into.

I wrote:

> My rebuilt 911 E 2.2 motor and all my tools were stolen Sunday night 
> or Monday, May 7-8 from a locked garage in a public storage facility 
> in Dublin, Ca.
>  
> Description of the motor:
>  
> Serial number: 6210165  (stamped on engine case near alternator stand)
> Just rebuilt, never run, very clean.
> New Ps&Cs
> Air deflector plates that fit around cylinders are painted grey
> 4 new time serts in top of RH timing chain housing.
>  
> May be missing the following parts:
> upper pair of valve covers, timing chain housing covers,
> timing chain tensioners, 10 valve rockers, induction system (fuel 
> injection pump, injectors, throttle bodies, intake manifolds), 
>  

If you are aware of any information regarding the suspect or this motor,
please contact Mitchell Craig 
(510) 842-0809 (work) or
(510) 833-8397 (home). San Francisco Bay area.

I had an error in my home phone number when I originally posted this.
The correct number is now listed.

  -Mitch

p.s. Lessons learned:

1.  Think twice about working in a public storage facility.  Thieves may
roam the premises looking for people who work there, and once they know
that you have a shop set up there, they figure that you must have tools.
What apparently happened in my case was that the thief (or thieves) were
following legitimate tenants into the facility (thus getting through
the security gate) then waiting until after everyone left, then going to
work cutting locks and loading up their truck (or trucks).

2. Get comprehensive insurance on your project car, even if you're not
driving it. If parts of the car are ripped off, your homeowner's or
renter's insurance probably won't cover it.

3. Inventory your tools. Probably the easiest way is with a video camera.
Save and annotate all your receipts, even if they aren't tax deductible.

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 20:12:25 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Setting Deck Height -- 914

>  914 case is going to FAT Performance tomorrow.  Recent suggestions have been to 
>  machine the case for zero deck height and then to set the compression by ccing 
>  the comb. chambers.  OK, sounds good.  Does this require me to get the euro 
>  pistons and liners first or can I just go down to FAT and say "Here's some $$$, 
>  make it so!" ?  (i.e. will they know how much to take off to get the deck 
>  height to be zero -- I suspect not!)


No.. They machine the CASE for and *EVEN* deck (i.e. all of the cylinder spigots
the same distance from the case centerline). *THEN* you build the short
block, and measure the deck height of the installed pistons. You *MAY* have to
machine the pistons or shim the cylinders to get the deck height you want.
>  
>  Also,  recent suggestions have pointed toward a 9.0 compression ratio.  The 
>  engine is for "spirited" street driving and 9.0 tells me that I may not be able 
>  to run on pump gas... certainly not 87 octane.  Anyone have any comments as too 
>  a good compression ratio for stock gas (87 or 92 octane options?)  I was 
>  thinking that an 8.5 CR would be a pretty good compromise.  Any comments?

I run all my air cooled cars at between 8.5:1 and 12:1. I run pump
super unleaded (92 or 93) in everything until I get to 10:1, then
run between 101 and 110 octane unleaded race gas in anything higher. You'll
be just fine at 9:1 on super unleaded. *IF* it's really 9:1 (MEASURE
EVERYTHING TWICE!!!)

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 21:34:26 -0400
From: dsnover@po.fast.net (Darryl Snover)
Subject: Bleeding Brakes

I have replaced several master cylinders in various brands of automobile,
and without exception, the only way to get a good pedal when replacing the
master is to bench bleed the unit.  So far I have not heard anyone mention
this procedure being done, so I guess I'll add my 2 cents worth.  Attach
some sort of reseviour to the master cylinder, and buy a couple of lengths
of brake line that fit the ports on the master.  Attach the said brake
lines to the master cylinder, and bend them so that they end up in the
reseviour (spelling doesn't look right<g>).  After you have the lines in
both places, put the whole unit on a vise or some similar holding fixture,
and figure out some way of pushing the piston in on the master.  I
typically use a phillips screwdriver with a vaccuum line cap over the end. 
Then do several full strokes of the master cylinder, and several small
strokes, near the beginning, middle, and end of the pistons travel, then do
the full strokes again.  You will be amazed at how much air you get out of
the unit in those little strokes.  Don't stroke too fast or brake fluid
will squirt out and get you.  If you can, cap the ends of the brake lines
going into the reseviour.  This way you won't get any air back into the
piston chambers.  On cars with an integral reseviour, you can leave the
whole setup together, and bolt the unit into the car.  If you have a
separate res., just do your best to keep the fluid inlets from draining. 
After you have the unit bolted in the car, with whatever reseviour you have
filled and attached, then remove the bent brake lines, attach the car's
brake lines, letting a little fluid run between the threads of the master
and car brake lines.  Unless you have air in your car's brake system, you
should already have a firm pedal, and will just have to flush the old fluid
from the rest of the system.  Be sure to rinse any brake fluid you spilled
thouroghly, and double check all fittings for tightness, observing
reccomended torque specs.

Standard disclaimer:  These are proceedures taken from various
manufacture's brake systems manuals, and may not be applicable to every
car, particularly with ABS brake systems.  Always consult your service
manual to check if your car has different steps for master cylinder bench
bleeding.

Maybe this will all help someone, or if I am sounding silly or such, flame
me and I'll stop<g>.

Darryl Snover (dsnover@fast.net)
80 931
87 Fiero GT
89 ZX-7



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 21:34:36 -0400
From: dsnover@po.fast.net (Darryl Snover)
Subject: 944 Ring and pinions

 Yes, un fortunatly, replacing the ring and pinion on ANY transaxle is a
major job, with special tools up the you-know-what required.  The pinion is
one of the main shafts on these things, and will require complete
dismatling.  Setting up a ring and pinion is a real b*tch without ALL the
right tools (and can be a real pain even with the tools).  As to brands,
????.  You are probably better off with a rebuilt unit.

Best Regards,

Darryl Snover (dsnover@fast.net)
80 931 (with stinky trans)
87 Fiero GT (muncie/getrag trans)
89 ZX-7 (who cares about the trans, you only need first gear in the US)

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 22:04:13 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: 911 brakes, bearings and wheel painting

Hey,

I had intended to re-pack my front wheel bearings today after
work, but when I loosened the brake line connection at the 
caliper, the hard line was turning along with the nut.  My
incredible deductive powers enabled me to decide that twisting 
the hard line in half falls into the category of "bad things".  I
coated the thing with Liquid Wrench and gently worked it
back and forth, but no go.  Has anyone run into this problem
before?  Is this a problem?  Should I attack the other end of
the hard line that attaches to the strut?

Since my bearing packing was a bust, I went ahead and replaced
my squeaky brake pads with MetalMasters.  No more squeaks.

I also painted the black centers of my 7x15 Fuchs.  I use the
Wurth "Matte Black" wheel paint.  Contrary to public opinion,
I think matte black is the correct color to replicate the factory
shade of black.  It turned out great.  The centers of my wheels
look like new, the aluminum outer rims looks 20 years old (because
they are). 

I've wasted enough bandwidth...

Cheers,

Mike Dayton
76 Euro 911

Date:          Wed, 24 May 1995 23:19:47 +0000
From: "DonThompson" <ptsulouf@mailbox.syr.edu>
Subject:       m474 option for 944

  Just wanted to throw in my 2 cents on some of the confusion on what 
the m474 option code was on 944 or 951 models.  I have an entire list 
of option codes and m474 is the sport shock option.  This is NOT the 
sport suspension kit.  The sport suspension option was 030 or "club 
sport package."  The m474 option was indeed standard on the 951, 
according to my list.  There was also a 637 code which was 
"Performance handling package" for 944/944s/951.  Again according to 
my list this code had to be ordered with the 030 code.
  Also, according to my fiche, the turbo S spec  Koni shocks are 
stiffer on their softest setting(they are externally adjustable) than 
the m474 sport shocks..........
  Anyone know what the spring rates were (ft/pds) on the turbo S 951?
Don Thompson
'87 951 (black and Zymol shiny) 
turbo S spec koni's

Date: Wed, 24 May 95 20:16:54 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: More on O2 Sensors (for those who can stand it)


I've gotta thank a lot of you for telling me where I went wrong in
assuming that the catalytic converter didn't affect the "measured"
air/fuel ratio.  It's a lesson I've been taught a thousand times,
but still haven't learned (apparently).  Think before you speak.

Everyone's right.  The measured O2/fuel ratio downstream from the cat
is different from upstream.  So...if you're using an O2 sensor to adjust
your FI or carbs, which is what this was all about, if you have a late
model car you need to insert it upstream of the cat.  On the other hand,
if you have a good old fashioned car that was produced before all the
exotic emission control paraphenalia was hung all over perfectly good
engines, like all my cars, then you don't have a cat, and you can stick
the O2 sensor right up the tailpipe and measure the fuel/air ration
with abandon and accuracy.

It really is a good way of seeing what your engine is doing. 

Bob Spindel
'72 911E
'72 911T
'72 240Z

(It was a wonderful year!)

Date: Wed, 24 May 1995 23:42:35 -0400 (EDT)
From: vtl@ejv.com (Victor Lee)
Subject: Re: 911 Child Booster Seats

Mark Salvetti writes:

          I was wondering if anyone has found a child booster seat
          that will fit into the back of a 911SC?  All the seats that
          I have found that are suitable for a 30lb kid are too wide
          to fit the rear seats properly.

Try the Century Breverra booster seat.  It looks like a mini
Recaro seat and holds a 30 - 45 lb child with its internal shoulder
harness or a 30 - 60 lb kid with the car's lap/shoulder belt (lotta
good that does in an older 911).  I just yanked one out of the jeep
and fit it into the back seat of my '78 911SC coupe and it fits very
well.  I couldn't belt it in because I too am looking for a set of
back belts.

The seat I've got has been discontinued and replaced with a model
that has a revamped internal seatbelt system and a clip to hold
an external shoulder belt in place.  I don't know if the new model
has a different name.  The old one is a good deal as local stores are
closing them out at $21.  I think the new one goes for $55.

I hope this helps,
Vic Lee, vtl@ejv.com

Date: Thu, 25 May 95 08:30:13 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: Child Seats and Rear Seat Belts

          Thanks to everyone that has been replying to my child seat
          question.

          I noticed that Vic Lee is also looking for rear belts.  My
          1979 911 also came without belts, and since I didn't want
          retractables I went and bought a pair from Automotion.
          They're OK, but I wish I had also tried Professionally
          Engineered Products (800-593-8787).  They are on page 38 of
          the May Pano.

          I had assumed that the bolts needed to fit the threads in
          the stock rear seat belt anchors were metric.  Stoddard
          wanted something like $15 each.  It was the folks at the
          above company that told me the threads were Standard, either
          7/16 or 9/16 (I can't remember).  Anyway, Grade 8 bolts from
          my local hardware store cost me about $1 each.  I just had
          to cut off about 1/2 inch with a Dremel tool and they fit
          fine.  BTW, the parts manual also shows a number of spacers
          and washers between the body, the belt, and the bolt.  These
          I did buy from Stoddards.

          Just a tip.

          Mark_Salvetti@abbsmtp.abb.com
          1979 911SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 08:59:11 -0400
From: Lou@GreenMtnSW.com (Lou Krieg)
Subject: Re: m474 option for 944

>  Just wanted to throw in my 2 cents on some of the confusion on what
>the m474 option code was on 944 or 951 models.  I have an entire list
>of option codes and m474 is the sport shock option.  This is NOT the
>sport suspension kit.  The sport suspension option was 030 or "club
>sport package."  The m474 option was indeed standard on the 951,
>according to my list.

Oh good, a chance for me to contribute to entropy by adding more confusion.

My '87 951's sticker (yes, I still have it) indicates $260 extra for "Sport
Shock Absorbers". These were yellow Boge shocks, non-adjustable (at least
as far as I ever knew).  FWIW, I replaced them with the yellow Koni gas
adjustables, and the Konis (at softest setting) are definitely _not_
stiffer in jounce than the Boges were. Although, since the Konis are
gas-pressurized, it may be just a difference in the subjective feel of the
gas shock.

In any event, the Konis (and perhaps any gas-filled shock) are a definite
improvement over non-gas pressurized shocks. On or off the track, IMHO.

  --Lou

Lou Krieg                         '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
PCA Green Mountain Region         '90 VW Corrado G60 Tornado Red
Internet: Lou@GreenMtnSW.com      '95 Grand Cherokee V-8 Moss Green



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 09:47:11 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 brakes, bearings and ...



>I had intended to re-pack my front wheel bearings today after
>work, but when I loosened the brake line connection at the 
>caliper, the hard line was turning along with the nut.  My
>incredible deductive powers enabled me to decide that twisting 
>the hard line in half falls into the category of "bad things".  I
>coated the thing with Liquid Wrench and gently worked it
>back and forth, but no go.  Has anyone run into this problem
>before?  Is this a problem?  Should I attack the other end of
>the hard line that attaches to the strut?
>
>MLBDayton@aol.com

Mike,

That always seems to happen as the lines get older.  The steel lines corrode
and freeze to the brake line nuts.  My advice is to get new lines (they're
cheap) and just turn the old ones out, even if they break.  Then lightly coat
the outside of the new line that is covered by the nut with antiseize.  Don't
get any on the flare, or into the line itself, I'm not to sure that brake
fluid and antiseize "get along".  This will prevent future corrosion, and the
nuts will spin freely the next time you disassemble them.  Don't waste your
time taking the old lines off and freeing up the old nuts.  Once the cad
plating is gone, they'll freeze up again no matter what you do; I know...once
burned, twice learned!

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 10:40:39 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porsches (long)

Hi Baxter,

Now you've done it, you have gotten me started!

In a message dated 95-05-25 01:16:10 EDT, you write:

>Thanks for your note, it was really helpful.  I'm a little worried
>about getting an SC just because they're so old.  I don't work on
>cars (besides oil changes and the like) and I'm not particularly
>anxious to start.

I wouldn't worry about the age of the car so much. The SC's really do have a
tremendous reputation for longevity. I personally would prefer a good
condition, well maintained (and documented) SC over a worse condition,
unknown maintenance history 84+ Carerra. Don't misunderstand me, the 84+
Carerra is a better car.

>Since I made the post you saw I've eliminated the 928 because I've
>been told it's the most expensive car to repair ever made.  I've also
>decided against the 924 as just a bad idea.

A good idea. The 928, while a great automobile, is not really a sports car.
It's too big and heavy. Since it was not made in the same numbers as the 944
and the 911 parts and service are MUCH more expensive.

>So it's the 911 or a 944.  The 944 seems to be a good car and it's
>certainly more affordable.  On the other the 911 is the 911 and I
>have a fever for this car.  Any advice you can give me on which might
>be the better first Porsche would be most appreciated.

I'll answer this later.

>I also have some specific questions about the 911 which maybe you can
>help me with.
>
>I've been told that I should eliminate considering anything prior to
>84 (something about a new and better engine being used as well as an
>updated FI system).  What do you think of this?  And, just for
>curiosity's sake, what is an FI system?

FI is Fuel Injection. All 911's since the early 70's have had FI. Almost all
cars today have it (FI replaces carburators, and are now computer
controlled).

In 1984 the 911 was changed from the SC to the 911 Carerra. The engine was
increased in size from 3.0l to 3.2l. The FI system was changed to DME
(Digital Motronic Engection [Injection in German], a Bosche system).
Horsepower went from 180 to 200. Other things on the car were changed as
well. There is no doubt that the 84+ cars are better than the SC, it's just
that they are more expensive. The 84-89 cars have the same excellent
reliability of the 78-83 911 SC cars.

>Are documents available on-line anywhere (the net, AOL, CIS, etc.)
>that list the running changes from year to year?

There is the Porschephiles computer, available on the WWW at 
   http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html
or you can use FTP to connect to tta.com, and then go to porschephiles. There
is an unbelievable amount of information, including FAQs on most Porsche
models.

>I've been told that the A/C on older Porsche models is pathetic.  Any
>truth to this?  When, if ever, did Prosche get the A/C right?

I Don't know about AC.

>And, finally, I'm going to look at an '85 911 targa next week (if
>it's not sold while I'm away for the weekend - unfortunately it's 2
>1/2 hours away and I can't make it before that).  It's got 75,000
>miles and the guy is asking $13,900.  Sounds like a good deal to me.
>What do you think?  Any specific questions I should ask about this
>particular model?

This sounds like an excellent deal. One very important fact that you  will
hear again and again it to have the car checked by a Porsche mechanic prior
to  purchase. These cars are complicated, and a problem that would escape an
average mechanic can cost big $$$ to correct. An exam should cost around
$100, and can save you many $$$ more than that. It can also give you
negotiation room.

>Again, thanks for your help.  I really appreciate it.
>
>Baxter Taylor
>Boston, Mass.
>
>P.S.  I'm looking to spend in the mid-teens but if I found the right
>car for $20,000 I don't think I'd be able to resist it.  I should
>also mention that I kind of have my heart set on a targa (the cab I
>figure is out of reach).  But I'd take a coupe without too much
>complaining.
>
>P.P.S. Also, maybe I'm shortchanging the 944.  Why do you prefer this
>model to the 911?
>
I have always liked the 944. I bought an 86 944 last year. After driving it
for a year, I was very happy with the car, but I wanted more performance. I
thought about buying an 84+ 911, or a 944 Turbo. I drove one SC, and one
Carerra. I was very disappointed in the 911. After driving the 944, the 911
felt very primitive. It had a very heavy clutch, and a very loose
transmission. Finding the right gear was very difficult. I also didn't like
the interior layout, I couldn't see the gauges through the steering wheel.
The car was quick, but not a rocket.  I then drove a 944 Turbo. What a blast!
The car was amazingly fast, noticable faster than the 911. It also shifted
muich easier. The car was just much more comfortable. After that I decided
against the 911, and concentrated on the 944.
I eventually found an 89 944 TurboS. The last year of the 944 Turbo. I spent
$17K for a car with 43K miles, in excellent condition. This car has 250HP,
and is much faster than the 84-89 Carerra's.

I am not against the 911, they certainly have their advantages. When people
think of Porsche, they think 911. The 911 also has a tremendous resale value.
If you really want a 911, then by all means buy one. They are great cars,
just not for me.

Reasons why I like the 944 over the 911:

The 944 is an easier car to drive fast than a 911. The 944 has 50/50 weight
distribution. The 944 has 60% of the wight behind the rear wheels. This makes
that car very tail happy, and difficult to drive at the limit. 

I like to drive on the track. As a member of the Porsche Club of America, you
can take part in Driver Education days, which take place on a race track.
This is where you get to drive your car as it was meant to be driven. You
will have an instructor, but there are no police, speed limits, etc. This is
the most fun part about owning a Porsche. The 944 is perfectly set for the
track, while the 911 will make you work much harder.

Then there's the price factor. For a normally aspirated, mint condition 944,
you can expect to pay less than $10K. For $15-18K you should be able to find
a 1989+ 944S2 or TurboS model. These cars have ABS and dual airbags. The
TurboS model has 250HP. The 944 S2 has 210HP. Both have more HP than the
911SC (180) or the Carerra (200). The 911 will not have ABS or airbags. 

You might be able to find a 944S2 Cabriolet for less than $20K. If you really
want a Cab, this might be the car for you. All 944s come with removable
sunroofs, but there was no Targa model.

Anyway, good luck in your search. If you want/need any more information just
let me know. As you can see (or read) I love Porsches, and could go on and on
about them (I think I just did). If you REALLY want info on Porsches, there
is an internet mailing list that generates about 100 posts a day. Let me know
if you are interested, and I'll tell you how to join. I can also find a
mechanic in your area for you through the list.

Enjoy
Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

Mark

Date: Thu, 25 May 95 08:39:42 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  m474 option for 944

Don't know the spring rates off hand (a good question for the spec
book - if I could only find that one...) but I know I've got the
highest rate springs listed on my car. 8-)

As for the Konis.  Remember that the sport yellow units for the M030
package for the turbo S is a special unit.  These units are set up to
handle a threaded sleave so that the spring pearch is adjustable.  The
soft setting is really quite comfortable, but a little too much so for
agressive driving.  For rallies I turn them up to pretty much full
stiff - the rear shocks are set just down from full stiff.

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com
'86 944 (with goodies from a turbo S M030 package)

Date: Thu, 25 May 95 08:56:36 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  914 engine rebuild book

Hummm.  Looks like yet another missing book.  The title is something
closer to "How to rebuild your air cooled Volkswagon", has a red cover
and is about 9"x12".  Check with a local VW shop.  I've found them at
bookstores in the automotive section.  As for the spec book (I've got
my 914 book handy...) yes, buy them from the local P-car dealer.  They
are good to own for working on many parts of the car, and interesting 
reading.

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com
