Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 11:23:19 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re m474 option for 944

Lou writes:
>Oh good, a chance for me to contribute to entropy by adding more confusion.

My turn.:)

These are from the 1987 944 options list that was posted some time back:

030     Club Sport Package                      1,982
220     Limited Slip Differential                 741
404*    Stabilizer Bars Front&Rear                164
414     External Transmission Oil Cooler (Turbo)  281
474*    Sport Shock Absorbers                     267
637     Performance Handling Package (944/944S) 5,115
                                     (944 Turbo)  677
Option 637 must be ordered with option 030.
*Standard Equipment 944 Turbo.

Maybe this list is in error.  The shocks that my car has
are black and I assume they are the originals.  According to
the shop manuals the standard shocks for '87 951s are black
F&S with the Boges and Konis being options.  So, the shocks
in the M474 package that started this whole discusion are
definitely not the standard base level shock offered for
951s.  I assume they are better for performance purposes,
and assuming my shocks are original it's about time to 
replace them at 85k miles...

>In any event, the Konis (and perhaps any gas-filled shock) are a definite
>improvement over non-gas pressurized shocks. On or off the track, IMHO.

Ross Stites
'87 951

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 10:04:29 -0700
From: ehab@cisco.com (Ehab Aljandali)
Subject: 911 brakes, bearings and wheel painting

Hey;

Had the exact same problem with my 84 911. You can try the other end of the
line and loosen it. Chances are you will get the same results.. no go! I
recommend replacing these lines anyway. They are about $10 each. Use anti
seize on the new lines and bleed the brakes as usual. A chancy way is to
leave it alone (if you have not damaged the lines) and very gently and
carefully (while praying) move the caliper with the line connected away
from the disk. Then you can remove the disk and replace the caliper back on
the strut using one screw to hold it in place till done. I really do not
recommend this last note since it can weaken the lines (which have already
been tweaked by your masterful hands).

        Hope this helps, Ehab :))

84 911 Euro, San Jose CA.


Hey,

I had intended to re-pack my front wheel bearings today after
work, but when I loosened the brake line connection at the
caliper, the hard line was turning along with the nut.  My
incredible deductive powers enabled me to decide that twisting
the hard line in half falls into the category of "bad things".  I
coated the thing with Liquid Wrench and gently worked it
back and forth, but no go.  Has anyone run into this problem
before?  Is this a problem?  Should I attack the other end of
the hard line that attaches to the strut?

Since my bearing packing was a bust, I went ahead and replaced
my squeaky brake pads with MetalMasters.  No more squeaks.

I also painted the black centers of my 7x15 Fuchs.  I use the
Wurth "Matte Black" wheel paint.  Contrary to public opinion,
I think matte black is the correct color to replicate the factory
shade of black.  It turned out great.  The centers of my wheels
look like new, the aluminum outer rims looks 20 years old (because
they are).

I've wasted enough bandwidth...

Cheers,

Mike Dayton
76 Euro 911

My earlier response was garbled, so here's what it should have said:

I have a '74 1.8 with Riviera's and have put 195/60 15 Yokohama 388's on 
with no problems.  I have over 8,500 miles with no evidence of wear.  
They stick a lot better than my old P6's.  I've had no problems with the 
fit under the stock fenders.  I got the set with road hazard, mounting, 
balancing, new stems and lifetime rotations for $285 at Price Club.

driving (and my wife doesn't complain about the stiffness).

Date: Thu, 25 May 95 10:44:28 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: M11 bolts (was Re: Child Seats and Rear Seat Belts)

} From: mark salvetti  <mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com>
}
}           I had assumed that the bolts needed to fit the threads in
}           the stock rear seat belt anchors were metric.  Stoddard
}           wanted something like $15 each.  It was the folks at the
}           above company that told me the threads were Standard, either
}           7/16 or 9/16 (I can't remember).  Anyway, Grade 8 bolts from
}           my local hardware store cost me about $1 each.

Well, actually they are metric, M11, but my local bolt supplier told me
that 7/16" NF (national fine) bolts are an exact match for M11 metric
bolts. Thread pitch and diameter are the same, Weird, who'da thunk...

    Eric

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 13:55:31 -0500
From: TODD.COHEN@rrd.com
Subject: Childs Safety Seat in a 911

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *porschephiles@tta.com
          TO:        OAS     -00000002 *vtl@ejv.com
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      05/25/95
          TIME:      13:52:00
 
          SUBJECT:   Childs Safety Seat in a 911
 
 
Vic Lee writes about a Century Breverra booster seat that fits the 911
rear seat.  After reading his post this morning, and since I am looking
for a better child seat myself.  I when over to Toy-R-Us to see what they
had.
 
The seat that Vic has, is two generations old.  Toy-R-Us had two
Breverra's.  One (last one they had of that model, for $59) has the
built-in shoulder and lap belt.  The seat is strapped to the car by using
the lap belt threaded through the backside of the seat.  So, if it fits in
the back seat of a 911, then it would work.
 
The newer seat that they have uses the car's 3 point seat belt to strap
the child to the seat (with a shoulder clip to make sure the shoulder
strap is placed properly on the child), and therefore the seat to the car.
So, this seat would not work in most 911 with only a lap belt.  And the
instructions state that the seat should only be used with a 3 point seat
belt.
 
I plan to run by Toys-R-Us tonight with the 911 and make sure that the
discontinued Breverra will fit my car, and buy it if it does.
 
 
Todd Cohen
1972 911T (Leaf Green)

Date: Thu, 25 May 95 12:57:22 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Cooling Fan

After more observation and thinking, I see a way for the variation in fan
startup temps. There are two different temperature sending units. The
fan temperature sensor is on the radiator. The temp gauge sending unit
is in the head. There is a thermostat between the two. So, a sticking
thermostat could be one explanation of the water in the head getting
much hotter than the radiator. This could also be caused by coming
to an idle after running at speed for a while. The rate at which water
flows from the engine to the radiator is RPM dependent (the water
pump is driven by the engine), so at idle, the head could rise in
temparature much more quickly than the radiator. Since I have
a new thermostat, I am attibuting the variations in fan startup
"observed" temperature to the different rates at which water
circulates through the engine. In fact, the fans may always be
starting at the same temperature; the same radiator temperature
that is. The car seems to be runnign fine, so I am going to stop
worrying about it!

    Eric
- ----------
} From: Doug Donsbach  <dld@symtec.com>
} To: Eric Brown (SYS)
} Subject: 944 Cooling Fan
} Date: Wednesday, April 26, 1995 10:30AM
}
} Eric,
}
} I think the cooling fans are controlled by a box located in the
} relay box under the hood. The control box is labled something like
} "fan control relay", but it is clear that it is more than a relay.
} I also think that the input to this box is the water temperature
} thermostat, so that if your temperature gauge is working right
} the fans should come on at the same temperature all of the time.
}
} I am interested in this because I have been playing with the cooling
} system on my 951 as of late and yesterday afternoon after a hard
} drive I pulled the car into my driveway, popped the hood and noticed
} that the fans were not running. The temperature gauge went ABOVE
} the top tick (I've never seen it there before) before the fans
} started.
}
} When I get time I want to crack the control box and see what's up
} in there. This at some point has to be an analog threshold comparision
} and I see lots of different ways in which a robust circuit could
} "age" over time to increase the fan turn-on point, given the harsh
} environment under the hood.
}
} Please let me know if you find anything and I'll do the same for you.
}
} Doug Donsbach
} '88 951
} '88 735i
} 



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 12:58:36 -0700 (PDT)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: Best Hydraulic Jack

On Thu, 25 May 1995, Lai, Hubert wrote:

> Within the last month or so, someone posted a message describing what he 
> thought was the best jack available.  I printed that message out and 
> promptly misplaced it.  I'm going to be dropping by my local Canadian Tire 
> store after work today to buy a jack and I wonder what I should get.  Any 
> advice?  Thanks.

I bought mine from the Price Club (Costco). Most I've seen in the $30-$40 
CDN range are made in China (which is not to say there is anything wrong 
with that). When I bought mine (actually my second one as the first seem 
weak),I considered :

1. The minimum height the cup will go. I've found that on my '86 944, I have
   to drive up on a board just to give it the extra 0.5 cm clearance to slide
   the jack in. Also, I'm using the 'jack-plate' from Automotion,
   designed to protect the bottom of the car. In all the work I've done on
   the car, I've only jacked it up using the jack-point at the center of the
   rocker panel (Is this ok for the car?). There is usually no problem
   sliding the jack out after you lower the car as the suspension hasn't
   been loaded yet.

2. The thickness of the steel used for the jack. Of course the thicker the
   better. My first jack was made of thinner steel and I didn't want to take
   a chance.

Joe '86 944

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 16:02:19 +0059 (EDT)
From: robin hansen <rhansen@world.std.com>
Subject: Re: 356 in LA help needed/Cab question



On Wed, 24 May 1995 Z356@aol.com wrote:

> I was contacted by the original owner of a 64 SC coupe silver with 200K,
> completely restored. Newer engine swap with out matching numbers.
> In my search for that perfect car has left me without a  car and I think it's
> time to get a nice driver to learn with and about 356s.
> So, I would appreciate it if someone could take a first look at the car for
> me . I'll then know whether to proceed. The car is parked in storage in
> downtown LA.
> Please Email direct if any assiistance can be given.
> Thanks
> Denny Zamler in MIchigan
Denny.
I am certainly no expert, but I have experience. I bought a "restored 
356B cabrio in 1991 for $24k and spent the next year and $10k in 
restoring it, plus another 4k for an engine rebuild. It is a good driver 
but some distance below concours. I could probably get maybe $25k to $30k 
and it is a good-looking car. $40k should get you a really good cabrio. 
Before you decide on any 356, spend the money (do as I say not as I did) 
and get a 356 restorer to look at it from top to bottom. Don't  use any 
restorer, but one who has done 356s. There are things that a non-356 
restorer will not catch. If you intend to drive it be sure that the 
suspension, steering, and brakes are ok. You can get good advice from MI 
Ron Roland, 28140 26 Mile Road in Chesterfield and Vic Skirmants at 27244 
Ryan Road, Warren (at that address you can join the 356 Registry which 
you should do even before you own a 356. Pay no attention to mileage or 
what anyone tells you about the engine rebuild. As the Maestro (Harry 
Pellow) maestro@aol.com says "There are a lot of turkeys out there and 
most of them are rebuilding 356 engines" . IMHO there is no reason other 
than driving a 356 frequently for buying one. By the way, you are in the 
middle of a minefield and need all the help you can get and not just from 
anyone who volunteers to look at the LA car for you. 
robin hansen> 
> ps I was shown a 65C cab ,original bottom, 75,000 miles, top end of engine
> redone ,repainted,new top and leather interior, no tools, or radio. Owner
> WANTS!!! $40,000. Is this in line or are there others out there for sale at
> or near that price that can be considered?
>

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 16:32:42 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Autocross info - part3 (more air cooled)

Hi again,

I have been asked to submit my columns on autocrossing Porsches
to the archives. Here is the third of nine columns. Please let
me know if there are any mistakes or omissions, or other questions
that I should answer. I am editing and submitting them one at a time,
and will upload the whole thing after final editing.

There have been several requests for permission to use this material
in PCA newsletters, etc. Please ask before using it, but basically
any PCA use will be granted if the author is noted. If not too
difficult, I would like a copy of the publication with my material.

Three Wheeling By Mike Piera, CT valley region PCA, #3 of 9

The last chapters covered the 911 models. All of these non-turbo
911 models are in the same SCCA class - A stock. That is why it is
very important to pick a good year and model. The other cars in A
Stock include the Lotus Elans (originals are incredibly light and fast),
BMW M3 (better balanced than a 911, can win on a flowing course)
and the Toyota MR-2 turbo. In '92 - '94 the Porsches were destroyed
by the RX-7 twin-turbo, but the RX-7 is now in Super Stock with the 
Corvettes.
	
Your best bet in an A-Stock 911 would be the 993 (maybe for
'95 : in '96 it will probably move to Super Stock). Other
contenders would be the ever popular '72-'73 911S. These have
won AS as often as any other car, and since they were fairly new!
John Fergus, noted IMSA racer, won from '77 to '79 in one, and
I added wins in '85 and '90. E. Paul Dickinson won from '73 to '76
in a 911T (2.4?), so they seem competitive too. A 2.4 E should be
faster than the 2.4T, and the '74 Carrera could also win.
A Carrera-2 RS America could be a wildcard with the new BFG tires
which will work great on the stock 17" rims.

SCCA classes are used by almost every sports car
club in America, not just SCCA regions. In the Northeast there are
several smaller clubs which all use these rules. One of the best
small sports car clubs for autocrossing in the northeast is the
Fairfield County Sports car club in Connecticut. In the
Porsche Club there are seven classes for 911s, so many more
models are competitive. In P11, I would choose the 2.4 liter 911T, it
should be much faster than the 2.0 (T and E) and 2.2 T cars. In
P12, the 911E 2.4 or 911S 2.2 should be faster than the E 2.2, S 2.0,
or normal 2.7. In P13, the 911S 2.4, or '74 Carrera are the best bets,
and should also be able to beat the cars in P14 (easily) and
P15! In P14, there is only the 911SC, but the later models should be
slightly better unless you can find an early one without sunroof
and A/C. In P15, the Carrera 3.2 class, I would choose an '87 or 
newer car. In P16, the Carrera 2 should beat the Carrera 4 
(unless it rains or snows!) with the RS America the best bet.
The 993 competes in P17, and should be faster than any other stock 
Porsche. Seems like there are some neat options available on the
993 (no rear seats, no sunroof, etc).

I will continue covering Porsche models and their
potential for autocross competition with minimal modifications. 
No matter which Porsche you have, you should get the
factory shop manual and spec books for it. This is the only
documentation acceptable to SCCA for proving a car's legality.
This will also show you the best options available for your car.
In SCCA Stock class, any option available from the Porsche FACTORY
for your year and model may be used. This does not include dealer
installed options. If a limited slip differential was available
for your car, you can use it with no penalty. In the Porsche Club 
Rules (PCR's) you are usually penalized for a LSD or optional
wider wheels even if they were factory options.

The 911 Turbo or 930 variants should be covered now, here they are 
in a  nutshell. The first "Turbo Carrera" was offered in 1976, 
replacing the '75 Carrera 2.7. It had 245 HP and an aluminum 3.0 
engine. In '78 the "930" was improved with a bigger 3.3 liter 
intercooled engine producing 265 Horsepower, and with large 917
brakes. The 930 was discontinued in the USA after '79 until it was 
re-introduced in '86 (although these were the peak years of the 
"gray market" cars). The '86-'89 turbo had about 280 HP, with the 
'89 finally offering a 5-speed transmission. In '91 the Carrera 2
turbo was introduced, with the new chassis. It used the old engine,
but re-tuned to 315 HP. From '93 to '95 this car was available with 
the new version of the 3.6 engine, with about 355 HP. The latest 
993-based 911 twin-turbo has about 400HP and all wheel drive.
What can I say about this car, except "let me drive one"!

In SCCA all these 911 turbos compete in "Super Stock" against the 
very fast Corvette, RX-7 twin turbo, and 928 S4. So basically the 
newer the turbo model, the faster it will be. But these cars are not 
easy to autocross, so I would not advise them for a novice. Also, 
the Corvettes and Mazdas are hard to beat (but I would love to 
see someone finally do it!).

Getting back to our chronology, the 912 model was only built
for a few years ('65 to '69) aside the 911 as a more
affordable Porsche, until the 914 was released in 1970.
The best 912 was the last year, the '69. As with the 911, the '69
had a longer wheelbase and fenders flared for 6" rims. I believe
sway bars were also available (check those manuals!). A rust-free
'69 912 would be an interesting autocross car, but they are hard to
find with the original Solex carbs and original pistons and cylinders.
The 912 used the later 356 engine, not a VW based engine like the
914, so parts and rebuilds are not cheap (especially the fragile
crankshafts). Check the same areas as 911s for rust, as 912 rust
repair is very expensive compared to the value of the car.

In '76, the 912 was brought back for a year to fill the gap
as an affordable Porsche before the 924 was ready. The 912E was
a 911 with a 914/2.0 VW type engine, providing less than spectacular
acceleration. The 2.0 used was the worst of the 2.0 engines, with
low power and thermal reactors (which were often removed by owners).
These can be competitive in their class. But they are quite heavy
for their power, and clean ones are selling for about the price 
of a similar year 911. All 912s run in SCCA E-Stock
class, which is mostly small-size medium-powered FWD cars like GTIs,
Jettas, Saturns, etc. (also the 356 and 924). The FWD econoboxes can
out-accelerate a 912 but a 912 can put power down better (no wheelspin)
and handle better in most corners. Also the FDW cars can slalom better.
The 912 runs against the small-engined 914 in the PCA, which should
be hard to beat.

The 914 was the first mass-produced mid-engined sports car. It was
introduced as a 1970 model as the 914/4 1.7 liter and 914/6 2.0 liter.
914s used thinner sheet metal than 911s and are very light, about 2000
pounds for the early models. The front suspension is basically the
same as a 911. Several VW components were used to hold down costs,
such as the 4 cylinder engine. These have always been very popular and
competitive autocross cars, and are now approaching cult-car status.

The early 1.7 cars had no sway bars and a transmission with a terrible
shift linkage. But the worst feature was the 4 1/2" wide wheels.
In 1973, there were great improvements with the "side-shifter"
transmission, and optional sway bars and 5 1/2" by 15" alloy wheels.
The '73 is the best small-engine (1.7 or 1.8) 914. The '74 1.8 model
may be good also, but they used a different fuel injection
which was only used in that model. These small engine 914s are in
SCCA D-Stock class, which is mostly higher powered small cars like
the Dodge Neon, CRX-Si, etc. (also the 924 Turbo). 

The 914/2.0 four-cylinder offered in '73 was what the 914 should have
been all along. The engine was very torquey with about 95 horsepower.
It came with appearance group, 5 1/2" mags, sway bars, etc. The '74
model could be ordered without some options (appearance group) to make
it lighter. In '75-'76 the 914 1.8 and 2.0 went downhill with heavy
bumpers, low power engines with thermal reactors, etc (just like the
911). These should be avoided for competition even in PCA classes. The
'73-'74 914/2.0 are great autocross cars, and were SCCA
C-Stock champions for a few years. The competition in CS
includes Mazda RX-7 non-turbo, Miata, Fiero formula, and 944 8-valve
models. This is a fun class for small rear-wheel drive sports cars.

The 914/6 was only available for a few years ('70-'72) and never sold
in high volumes. These have been very competitive in autocross, even
though they compete against the more powerful 911 in A-Stock. They
are lighter than the 911 and handle better in most situations. The
engines are very torquey but have low power and a low redline. The
engine used was from the '69 911T, the weakest 911 engine ever.
They also have the poor early shifter. The 914/6 was only available
with 5 1/2" wide rims, in either 14" or 15" diameter. No sways bars
or other performance options were available. The 914-6 GT is not
legal in Stock class because it was not imported from the factory,
it was a dealer installed kit. A good clean rust-free 'sixer' with
original mechanics is hard to find, and tend to be expensive. Most
have been updated due to the ease of upgrading to 911 parts and the
great performance potential. If you don't mind fiddling with Weber
carbs, a 914/6 can be a fun autocrosser.

All 914's tend to rust very badly. Check for rust in the rear
suspension mounts near the engine, the rocker panels, and under
the rear trunk mat. Be careful of poorly repaired rust, as the 914
can fold in half when the doors are opened with the top off! Check
door fitment for signs of sagging, and take the car to a good Porsche
repair shop for a professional opinion.

More to come!

Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com
'72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0 (last two for sale?)

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 17:20:00 -500 (EST)
From: "WILLIAM AUGUSTINE" <S1014097@cedarnet.cedarville.edu>
Subject: 924 Problem (warm start)- reply


To the guy that has the problem starting his 924 when it is warm
(.5-2 hours after driving).  I had the same problem with mine and
after inspecting the injectors, cold start valve, aux. air intake, I
found out that my mixture was off, get this fixed and it should start
up fine (like mine).  I think that the adjustment for this is on the
front of the throttle body???           Bill Augustine 

79' 924 (working towards a 911)

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 16:41:14 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: Re: Shipping agents in SF.

Trond,
Not to raise red flags, but I shipped my car to the UK without doing my
homework first.  This resulted in the car being lost (read stolen, but 
without proof).  After seven months, two lawyers (I SHOULD have hired
the guy with the baseball bat and a penchant for swinging at knees...)
I finally found the car with the help of the State Police.

Ther is a LOT more to the story, but in the end, I finally shipped with a 
LARGE MAJOR carrier who had good references, GOOD INSURANCE, and obviously
cost more.  To me it was worth it.

I urge you to stay away from any small freight forwarders who will just 
subcontract the transport, and deal directly with a shipping company.  I also
recommend putting it in a container.  This is how I shipped mine back to the
US.  No problems with the container method (still with a reputable carrier).

Be VERY clear on the valuation and insurance, and if possible insure it through
anyone but the carrier.  Taking the carrier's insurance is not a bad idea, but
for me, the (first) carrier just ignored my efforts to file a claim.  A third
party insurance company would certainly launch a full investigation prior to
paying a claim, and that is exactly what I needed to have done.

Good luck.
 -chuck

1983 911 Cabriolet (Guards Red)
Been across the atlantic more than most of 'em too <g>

Mateo resident, then Redwood City, then Saratoga, and now Millbrae resident. I
looked at four cars and talked to about 9 prospects via telephone & E-Mail (tha
nks Porschephiles).  ALL had holes in body, or areas ready to become holes. I
am overwhelmed with this one 'cause I assumed (and was informed by some "expert
s") that I wouldn't find a Rust Free Car, even if it was Californian.  Well, I
just thought I'd pass it along to keep the hope up.  The rest of the vitals are
as follows:
Rebuilt top end and new Pistons/Cylinder aprox. 20K ago
Meticulous maintenance (all receipts from 2nd, and 3rd owners)
[ by the way, the second owner bought the car in 1977 for $8000 purchase
 price at %15.4 financing, Jimmy Carter in office?? (I was 12 years old, couldn
't vote)]
One small dent in rt, rear fender, rest of body straight like arrow.
EVERYTHING WORKS!!!!! (you must realize, I've owned a '72 Wisconsin Car..bad
news)
Rebuilt tranny aprox 40K ago (156K on odom)
No appearance group, but killer black BBS-Style Enkei Mags w/ polished rims.
"Spank Me" Yellow paint over Yellow original.
Tan Interior, Good Shape and again EVERYTHING WORKS!!!
Ok Ok Ok, I'll shut up.  Thanks for all replies, keep this People-Base the
excellent source of information it is, and please quit hacking each other!

silk and will outlast you and your kids.

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 20:37:40 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: M11 bolts (was Re: Child Seats and Rear Seat Belts)

>Well, actually they are metric, M11, but my local bolt supplier told me
>that 7/16" NF (national fine) bolts are an exact match for M11 metric
>bolts. Thread pitch and diameter are the same, Weird, who'da thunk...

(Insert sound byte of Otto from "A Fish Named Wanda": "I'm *disappointed*!")

They are not the same; they are different.  They may be close, but they
are not the same.

Ditto to the person who bought an almost-right hardware store 7/16"
bolt.  Yes, the threads of seatbelt bolts are 7/16 x 20, just like an
airframe bolt.  But the grip (unthreaded section) is different.  With
the hardware store bolt, instead of tightening down against the oversize
grip, allowing the belt anchor to pivot, you have probably tightened
against the anchor tab, which will lead to the bolt's backing out over
time.  Not to mention hardware stores' ability to stock counterfeit
junk bolts.

This is a *safety* item.  Someone's life may well depend on the quality
of the part you install.  Get the right part, please.  If I can help
by looking up the p/n on a fiche, happy to do so.  Just let me know
the application.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 25 May 95 17:23:59 PDT
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: 022 dist. rebuild questions

I just bought a used 022 distributor for my 66 912.  (the car had a 009)  The 
drive gear on the 022 is somewhat loose and it looks like I could pull the one 
off of my 009 and put it on the 022.  The problem is I can't get the pin that 
holds the drive gear onto the distributor shaft out!  It looks like it should 
just press out.  I have pressed as hard as I dare but she won't budge.  Am I 
doing the right thing?  I put the distributor in my 912 and set static timing 
for 3 degrees BTDC.  I then checked the amount of advance at 1000 through 3500 
rpm with my friends big buck Snap-On timing light.  The amount of advance was 
low at the low end and about 38 degrees BTDC at 3500 rpm.  The reading were  
nice and stable.  I was not overly surprised to see the curve off on such an old 
distributor.  I know I can get rebuild parts from Stoddard and was planning on 
buying the shim kit, new springs, and the teflon sliding plate.  Has anyone else 
out there done this and if so did using these three things bring your advance 
curve back into spec?  The distributor shaft has no "noticeable" play, but the 
drive gear does wobble and the shaft can move up and down about a 1/16 of an 
inch.  The thread on distributors about a month or so ago convinced me to go for 
the 022 instead of the 050.  Don't let me down now!  TIA

Scott

66 912

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 19:26:00 +0000
From: Barbara.Strayer.INSBAS01@nt.com
Subject: Adding an Oil Cooler - 911T

I need some advice about adding an external oil cooler to a '72 911T.
I have been offered an aftermarket oil cooler.  Are there any pros
or cons to using particular oil coolers?  The oil cooler has AN12
fittings, and will be mounted in the normal right front fender
location.  Oil lines and fittings are available from a local shop.

Does the '72T oil filter housing contain a pressure relief valve and
thermostat?  This is mentioned in Bruce Anderson's 911 Performance
Handbook, but it isn't clear if these are items are physically in
place, or only an allowance for them to be added.  This car has never
had an external front oil cooler.

Also, how do I make the connections to the housing, tank, and cooler?
Any information would be appreciated.


Coco Strayer
'84 911 Carrera (Euro)
'72 911T


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 18:45:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: 924 stereo

Dennis Bredemann wrote:
> 
>     If anyone has installed a kick-*** stereo in a 924, please tell me how
>  you did it.  I don't want to use up much space but I need some sound to 
>  overcome the wind noise with sunroof off/windows down.  

You can put an amp on the driveline shelf behind the tuner (though the
heater makes this space hot), or under a seat.  If the amp is really
big, it can go in the rear well.

By cutting some sheet metal, you can fit some good 6" round speakers
in the stock spots, though the interior panels deaden it a bit.  Door
speakers will work too but they have to be thin if they're flush
mounted.  Otherwise, you can use 6x9s in boxes behind the back seat,
if you can stand the bite out of your cargo space.

And the stock front center speaker works well for the ham radio...

 -mike
___________________________________________________________________
mikew@sr.hp.com                       mailstop 1UR-M

Mike Weihman                          Microwave Instruments Division
Hewlett-Packard Company               1212 Valley House Drive

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 19:32:57 -0700
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: 928 cam removal (long)

Removal of cam towers from '79 928 with engine still in car

1. Tools needed:
17mm box-end wrench
15mm box-end wrench
13mm box-end wrench
12mm box-end wrench
11mm box-end wrench
10mm box-end wrench
3/8 inch drive rachet
3/8 inch drive extensions, short
3/8 inch drive extensions, long
3/8 inch drive universal
3/8 inch drive metric sockets
6mm long handle Allen wrench
6mm short handle Allen wrench
6mm Allen wrench socket
screwdrivers, slotted and Phillips
3-inch gear puller
wrench to fit puller
oil catch pan
coolant catch pan

Gaskets needed:
- ---------------


step one 
- --------
driver side (The Easy Side) This should take about 3 hours 

remove cool air distributor from top of radiator (10mm wrench and 2 bolts.
remove airbox (13mm wrench is needed) and cool air intakes.
remove distributor from cam tower with 15mm wrench.  Plug up the hole with a 
	rag.  
remove cam drive gear with 17mm wrench and use puller to remove cam drive gear.
remove woodruff key from cam.
remove coil and let hang.
remove 3 10mm bolts that hold on the end cam bearing.  Use puller to carefully
	remove bearing carrier.
remove the 6 rubber oil plugs in cam tower top (don't loose them; they're $5 
	a piece). 
disconnect brake booster vacuum line and assorted vacuum lines in the area and 
	remember where they go.
remove the power steering line to the PS pump.  Use the oil catch pan to get 
	most of the mess.
*****************************************************************************
*****************************************************************************
Now pay close attention hear; the 6 allen bolts are inside the cam tower.  If
you drop one into the cam tower and are very lucky, you MIGHT be able to get it
out with a magnet.  However, if you're like everone else, you won't.  This 
means that the cam or followers and cups will have to come out to get these
bolts.  I'll remind you of this again when it is time to put the cam towers
back on.  Since I had to take the cams out anyway, I let them fall inside the
cam tower.
****************************************************************************
****************************************************************************

remove the bolts holding on the cam tower; 6 on top and 12 (?) on the bottom.
	Do the bottom bolts first so if the tower flexes and binds (it does)
	it won't make it too difficult to get the bolts out.  All the bolts
	(top and bottom) are 6 mm allen bolts, and you'll need an assortment
	of 6mm allen wrenches, L's and socket types to get all of them out.
	Space below the cam tower is the real pain.
Remove the top of the power steering resevoir.
Remove the cam tower.  Pay very close attention here because the followers
	will head south to the floor.  If you need to, remove the followers
	from the tower as you pull the tower out through the front of the
	engine.  Just remember which one went where.  Also, the assembly is
	HEAVY.  Be careful not to drop it on your $1200 radiator.
Remove the gasket and cover the area with clean towels.  It is off!  Have 
	many beers and apologize to whatever critters you kicked or swore
	at (including S.O.'s).

***************************************************************************
***************************************************************************
***************************************************************************
***************************************************************************
***************************************************************************

Step Two
- --------
Passenger Side (The Hard Side) This should take about 4 hours

remove the 3-inch water hose to the radiator.
remove the 1/2-inch water line from the resevoir to the thermostat back.
remove the 1-inch water hose from the resevoir collector to the engine front.
Try and catch most of the water with the pans.
remove the smog pump air delivery tube on the cam tower (2-10mm bolts).
disconnect the hoses to said tube and move out of the way.
remove vacuum lines that are in the way.
remove the 10mm bolt that holds the electrical wire harness to the tower.
disconnect the distributor lead near computer module and move out of the way.
tie the wiring harness to the strut brace so the cam tower can be moved out
	under the wires.
remove the rubber plugs (6).
remove the bottom bolts first (12(?) really hard ones to get to).
remove the upper bolts (6) after ALL of the bolts have been removed.
remove the cam tower with out pinching the A/C lines on the side of the engine
	bay by tilting the top out just a little.  This also helps keep the
	cups from falling earth-ward.  Maneuver under the wires and out the
	front without hitting your radiator again.
Both are out.  Drink heavily and clean your wrenches.

****************************************************************************
****************************************************************************
****************************************************************************
Again, if you drop one of the upper bolts into the cam tower, you are basically
screwed, and will have to remove the cups and followers to get the bolt(s) and
washer(s) out.  I used stainless steel clamps from a medical supply store to
grab onto and push the bolt into its hole before I started tightening them
up.  Are they called suitures?  They're the things all the Stoners used to
hold their roaches.  Anyhow, they work great and are thin enough and strong
enough to grab the bolt and maneuver blindly in the tower looking for their 
respective hole.
************************************************************************
************************************************************************
************************************************************************

If you are going to replace the cams, remove all cups and followers, and the
rear seal cup (3-10mm bolts and a cork gasket) and remove the cam.  When the
cam is out, clean thoroughly.  Don't forget to buy lots of gaskets.


Installation is basically the reverse of removal, except for the gaskets.
Use new ones, and make sure that the oil gallyies (sp?) that supply the lifters
are both open.

What I found wrong on my engine:
1. 1 bolt inside left and right cam tower was loose
2. Both cam tower gaskets were covering my lifter supply holes on both sides

I would say that if you do not know who fixed your car/engine, take it apart
yourself and VERIFY that it was done right.  The schmuck who worked on your
car last probably doesn't love it like you do.

Any questions, please call or write.

bill

billv@retix.com

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 22:49:13 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 924 problem...

Glen,

The 924 hot start problem was solved by updating the 20 cc fuel
accumulator to a 40 cc unit.  Actually, they first tried to add a
second 20 cc unit.  But the single 40 cc unit was the ultimate
cure (or so the factory felt).

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 11:14:00 +0800
From: omsnyk1!sg.fp.cibcwg.com!jb@cibc.com (Justin Beech)
Subject: Re: 911 tunes


> I am in the process of finalizing a deal to purchase a burgandy metallic 87
> 911.  I have been so emersed in mechanical issues that it just occurred to me
> that I need to investigate whether or not a CD player can be installed.  Any
> thoughts or recommendations?
> 

The CD player is not the problem - its the CD changer. On the C2/C4s, it
is possible to mount a 6-disc changer in the glovebox, but I was told that
the pre '89 car dash internals makes that pretty tricky, so it goes in the
trunk. Sony have a mini-size 6-disc changer (CDX T60) that doesnt take so
much of a bite out of that already tiny space - get it side-mounted at the
front-right, screwed onto a board installed vertically under the carpet
as far towards the back as possible. Get a dash unit with a CD slot (the
Sony CDX900 is great) so you can bring more CDs to use after you get
through the 6 upfront.

I just got it done... 3 Carver amps under the seats, two fibreglass
enclosures replacing the rear-seat side panels that hold the subs, sounds
great! the factory Atlanta was lousy.

- ---
Justin.

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 21:33:39 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: More on O2 Sensors (for those who can stand it)

In response to text from Bob Spindel:

>Everyone's right.  The measured O2/fuel ratio downstream from the cat
>is different from upstream.  So...if you're using an O2 sensor to adjust
>your FI or carbs, which is what this was all about, if you have a late
>model car you need to insert it upstream of the cat.  On the other hand,
>if you have a good old fashioned car that was produced before all the
>exotic emission control paraphenalia was hung all over perfectly good
>engines, like all my cars, then you don't have a cat, and you can stick
>the O2 sensor right up the tailpipe and measure the fuel/air ration
>with abandon and accuracy.
>
>It really is a good way of seeing what your engine is doing. 
>

Bob: I'd like to know in detail your method, parts and procedures used.
     E-mail me direct.

All: Has anyone ever considered installing an O2 sensor, say, in a 914 and
     using it to regulate the resistence of the cyl. head temp. sensor?
     (Just curious)

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 21:23:34 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 914 engine saga (fwd)


This got lost and I'm not letting all that typing go to waste.

>In response to text from Nicholas Cole:
>
>>   The cost of the rebuild is going to hurt, maybe a lot. A couple of
>>questions. First I have never rebuilt an engine but have done all the work on
>>the 914 that doesn't include welding. Is it possible to rebuild as a DIY or
>>are specialzed tool purchases going to make that prohibitive as well as
>>specialized knowlege. 
>>Second a coupe of places have suggested a mild cam and a combo of euro pistons
>>and decking to make compresion 9:1 is this a good idea and do I need more oil
>>cooling for this?
>
>I can tell you what I did/am doing.  I came across a 914 that had a passenger
>compartment fire and was left out in the elements for some time.  For $200
>I couldn't resist the temptation of a) owning a Porsche and b) getting into
>a rebuild [completely over my head].
>
>Over the course of the past year, I stripped the car clean and bought a few
>more 914s in the hopes of getting one on the road.  I used the engine(a 1.7)
>from the $200 starter car and spent the winter rebuilding it.  I had *never*
>done anything more than brakes and oil before.
>
>With much patience and through the advise of the list in general, I was able
>to get the engine completely rebuilt over the winter.  If you take your time
>and are *patient* (being able to handle resplitting the case if something
>doesn't work out, etc) you can do just fine.  Putting an engine together was
>a very satisfying experience for me; I developed a deep appretiation for
>the engineering skills required to design a powerplant.
>
>After I install the engine and it sits in the middle of my "baby" pushing 
>me down the road, purring away, I anticipate euphoria at my personal 
>accomplishment.  I know I'll never look at an engine the same way again.
>
>Although I haven't run my engine yet, I can tell you what I decided to do
>(many thanks to Stan) during the rebuild:
>
>Heads: New keepers, springs, stems, and valves (stock); work done by 
>       local machine shop (I supplied the parts).
>
>P&Cs : 96mm NPR kit(included rings and wrist pins) displ. ~2.0L
>       (used kit for 1.8 due to thicker cylinder walls)  
>
>Case : Sent to machine shop for cleaning and inspection; JB Weld on 
>       oil galley plugs; new main bearings; 
>       Sent complete crank, flywheel, rods and fan in for inspection
>       and balancing(rods indivually, rest as a unit)
>       New FAT Performance FI Performance Cam(FC440HP), cam gear and
>       followers, high volume oil pump, reused oil cooler
>
>FI   : New 2.0L injectors, cyl. head temp. sensor, throttle switch, and
>       cold start value(original was broken).
>
>Misc : all new seals, grommets, thermostat, etc.  Had sheet metal sandblasted.
>
>>From the discussions I have had with people on the list, what I ended up with
>is a decent engine rebuild(accepting the fact that the NPR kits may be
>short-lived) with some *mild* performance increases over stock(since I
>didn't opt to have extensive head porting work done for the high RPM range).
>
>The safest path to travel is a tried-and-true stock rebuild. The path I 
>followed, well that remains to be seen, I let everyone know in a few
>months when I post my big grin. ;)  The no-holds-barred, spare-no-expense,
>re-engineering of the engine was out of the question.  As it is, I may have
>pushed the envelope myself.  
>
>But I did learn that to a significant increase in performance can only be
>assured through extensive re-engineering of the engine, which requires
>external oil cooling, full-flow oil filtering, porting, flow-benches and
>all that jazz.
>
>I've seen people build 914/4s into 2.4L racing engines with some 100+mm
>kit, but haven't seen one of those engines live very long either.  
>(My current chassis was such a beast).
>
>In short, you can and should do it if you have the time and the patience.
>I feel confident that I could do my second rebuilt in about half the time
>it took for the first.
>
>Regards,
>--

>- Open Networks Engineering    fax:313 996 9908             abaris@msen.com -

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 03:29:02 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: Defunct .022 Distributor

Re: Original .022 Distributor-
       Let's see, your nice, Original .022 Distributor has too much timing
advance, a wobbly shaft and a worn drive unit. How surprising! It sounds like
one of the hundred or so I've been keeping around for spare parts when the
time comes. As you have found, replacing the drive portion of the distributor
is not a trivial task. Failure to remove the drive locking pin properly wll
result, of course, in a ruined drive and/or shaft and/or  distributor. It is
best done using a press with proper support by  someone  who's done it
(successfully) before.
     Should you be fortunate enough to remove it successfully (or have it
removed successfully) and continue  with the rebuild, once done there is
still a high probability that it won't work right. (.022's  are fiendishly
clever like that.)
     It is for these reasons (and more) that a new .050, with smooooth
advance up and down, stable spark timing, decent high speed advance,
reasonable cost, and ease of installation (as long as your distributor drive
has been installed correctly, the .050 will fit in and its capacitor will
clear the oil return line from the oil  filter can), is a better deal..
    You oughta give the .050 a second thought. And I'd be curious how your
.022 distributor rebuild turns out.
   KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
  The Maestro

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 03:54:03 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Re: Front Plates and Revenuers

Even the Nazis can't make you wear a plate your own state
doesn't requre.  When I used to run the (agh urr, horror) front
plate on mine, I'd almost always pull it off in the first rest stop
past the state line.  Run unencumbered, be free.  Also, be aware
that the fact that you are not running a front plate is the first 
sign that you are an out-of-towner (read, potential revenue source).
Makes their laser and radar harder to hit, but, it still can be done.
>From what I hear on the list, I'd be hard pressed to drive in Oregon
ever again.

Non P-File content

The last time I drove through Oregon (from Eureka, CA to Eugene 
for the Oregon Country Fair, I rented a New Yorker from Avis.
The sucker took a shit on me about halfway through the drive
(brake vacuum booster & power steering unit went South).  Avis 
was nice enough (after arguing for an hour that there was NOTHING
wrong with the car) to give me a cab ride to the fair and back.
I specified that I wanted either a Caddy or a Lincoln with
Oregon plates.  When I went back to pick up the car I asked them
where my Lincoln was.  Girl said, "We couldn't get you a Lincoln
but you'll like this so much better".  It was a Lebaron drop top,
arrest me red, with California plates.  Might as well painted a
bullseye on my head.  Took about half an hour in the airport
parking lot to figure out the top (you can just imagine my condition-
dark night, no owners manual, and me, well... enhanced)
Need I say I drove to Grant's Pass in a perfectly straight
line at or under the speed limit?

The fun came in after I hit CA.  Redwood forest with the top down
on a vert is cool (remind me to buy a vert one of these days).
What really pissed me off is the fact that sucker wouldn't curl
the speedo (140 mph) with the top down.  And I really tried.

If was a lot of fun anyway (Tagamet really helps those stress
driven ulcers).


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

Date:     Fri, 26 May 95 13:33:07 CETDST (1233Z)

Subject:  Option Codes

   I currently own a 1983, 944. It is Euro spec as I live in Germany. (The true
way to appreciate a Porsche!) I am the third owner and am trying to figure out 
what options the car came with. The tag in the right rear wheel well is

various options under the Ausstattungen (Options). Some of the codes I have 
identified through the 944 FAQ, but the others I am drawing a blank on. The 
codes are:  164, 261, 404, 410, 429, 431, 440, 423, 650, 657. If you can 
provided assistance I would certainly thank you.

------------------------------

Date:     Fri, 26 May 95 13:33:07 CETDST (1233Z)
From: "James T. Moder" <aeusg-k-aer@email.kaiserslautern.army.mil>
Subject:  Option Codes

   I currently own a 1983, 944. It is Euro spec as I live in Germany. (The true
way to appreciate a Porsche!) I am the third owner and am trying to figure out 
what options the car came with. The tag in the right rear wheel well is 
virtually unreadable. I do have the original warranty book which list the 
various options under the Ausstattungen (Options). Some of the codes I have 
identified through the 944 FAQ, but the others I am drawing a blank on. The 
codes are:  164, 261, 404, 410, 429, 431, 440, 423, 650, 657. If you can 
provided assistance I would certainly thank you.

Jim Moder
aeusg-k-aer@email.kaiserslautern.army.mil

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 07:24:32 -0500
From: TODD.COHEN@rrd.com
Subject: 911 Turbo-Tierods and other Front Suspension Questions

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *porschephiles@tta.com
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      05/26/95
          TIME:      07:21:00
 
          SUBJECT:   911 Turbo-Tierods and other Front Suspension Questions
 
 
Well, I am about to tackle the front suspension on the 911, I have already
installed new Koni struts and shocks.  Now, I plan to replace the ball
joints, upgrade to the Turbo Tie-rods, and install the steering rack spacer
kit.  Are there any items that I need to look out for while doing this, or
anything to make the job easier.
 
A friend with a 1971 911T, who has been through all this, said that the
tie-rods can be difficult to remove.  He was talking about one of two bolts,
the bolt that goes though the rubber bushing by the rack, or maybe the
threaded part of the tie-rod that is screwed in to the rack.
 
After replacing these parts, I plan to lower the front ride height.  The car
with the original torsion bars, sits with the rear lower than the front (I
measured ~27 1/2" front, ~25 1/4" rear to the top of the fender lip).  I
know that I should replace all the torsion bars and set the ride height of
the front and rear of the car.  But, should it be OK to just adjust the
front and then replace the bars and reset the the ride height later?  And
yes, I read the factory manual about corner balancing and the fact that
changing the ride height will affect the opposite corner.
 
When I do set the ride height, should the instructions in the factory manual
be followed to the letter, or are there other ways to get the same result.
Should the car be loaded how I plan to Autox or Track the car, like 1/2 tank
of gas, spare tire installed or not, and the weight of the driver in the
drivers seat?

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 9:09:17 -0400 (EDT)

Subject: Front Plate Attachment

Jees, you Porsche guys! I've had the same problem when switching states
or when the state's law changed. The solution? Half a tube of 
construction adhesive (e.g. Liquid Nails). Quick, easy, and will survive
a 360 degree rollover.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 10:49:19 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: Why Dry Sump???

Hi Mike,

In a message dated 95-05-26 03:20:35 EDT, you write:

>What is the advantage of a dry sump lubrication system as implemented
>on the 911??  I know that it is used in racing, but I know of no other
>consumer car that utilizes this system...
>

A dry sump oil system means that the oil is stored in a tank, not in pan, or
sump at the bottom of the engine. The dry sump oil system sucks the oil up
from a pick up at the bottom of the engine, and pumps it to a tank. The tank
is used to provide oil to the engine.

The benefits of a dry sump oil system is that oil is always available for
lubrication, regardless of what the car is doing. In other words, during high
G turns, there is no chance of oil sloshing to one side of the oil pan and
exposing the oil pump pickup, and leaving the car without any oil for a short
time.

The 944 model has a wet sump oil system, and there have been reports of
engine failures on cars that have has suspension modifications that allowed
higher G turns then the designers intended. This allowed the oil to slosh
away from the oil pickup in the oil pan, resulting in oil starvation, and
"bad things" to the engine. The 944 TurboS, and 89 Turbo solved this problem
by adding special baffles in the pan to prevent the oil from sloshing away.

The BMW M3 model uses a wet sump oil system, and this caused ALL of the M3's
racing in the 24 hours of Daytona to break down, and not complete the race.
The M3 (at least the race engine) has since been modified to use a dry sump
oil system.

I guess a dry sump system is not normally used because it is not required for
street driving, and because it is more complex (additional oil lines, tank,
etc).

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

Date: Fri, 26 May 95 12:35:23 EDT
From: weltyc@cs.vassar.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: June Porsching Column


Permission is given to use this material in any publication as long
as my name and affiliation are left intact.  If you can, send me the
issue.  Previous Porsching columns are available at
http://www.cs.vassar.edu/faculty/welty/porsching

PORSCHING  by Chris Welty
Hudson-Champlain Region, PCA

When You Wish Upon A Star - Part VI


A wave of calm passed over me as I accepted the imminence of death.  I
rolled over to gaze the reaper straight in the eyes.  Much to my
surprise, Karl was actually talking to Carlos, and they were walking
over to the car.  As far as I could tell, there had been no deaths up
to this point.  John was giving me a puzzled look. 

"I...errrr...lost my pocketknife.  I thought maybe it was under the
seat," I said.  Knowing how much my pocketknife meant to me, John
accepted this explanation without comment. 

I exited the car and went with John to observe the situation.  While
John didn't seem to recognize Carlos for who he was, it was clear that
he was at least mildly sympathetic to my slightly more intense
suspicion.  Karl had just finished a quick inspection of the outside
of the car, and had opened the trunk.  The three of us moved to the
back of the car, and John opened the deck lid.  We gasped in unison.
There, on top of the engine, was one of the creatures from "Alien."
I'm referring here to the "first stage" Alien that attaches itself to
your face and deposits its offspring in your stomach.  I backed away
slowly, remembering the acid in the blood. 

Karl and John looked confused, their eyes tracing every shiny metallic
tentacle of the creature's body, which had wrapped itself around the
poor boxer engine.  "Is this thing turbocharged?" John asked. 

Carlos lit up like a flame, his smile revealing a really bad dental
plan.  "Tweeen Torbo!  Tweeen Torbo!" he exclaimed. 

"That's an aftermarket job if I've ever seen one," John said.  Karl
nodded.  I ducked down under the car and found an active oil rig, in
full production. 

"You're leaking a little oil," I noted.

"All these cars leak oil," the owner scoffed.

Karl looked skeptical.  "Well, can I drive it?" 

"Sure, sure."  Carlos grinned again, and handed Karl the keys.  The
two got in and Karl started the car.  I think an F-16 passed overhead
at that moment, because I wasn't able to really make out the sound of
a car starting.  They backed out of the parking spot, and blasted
away. 

I looked at John, and he shook his head.  "Is this the most suspicious
situation you've ever been in?" he asked. 

"What if he doesn't come back?" I responded.

"What I find strange is that he is listing the car as a 79 SC, and
that he made no mention of the turbo until we noticed it.  You know,
the factory only uses a four-speed transmission on the turbos, they
find the horsepower eats up the 915." 

"What I find strange is that he looks like..."  I stopped talking as
two of Carlos' buddies emerged from the building.  We smiled and
nodded a greeting, as they approached. 

"You are testing driving car?" one asked.

"Well, our friend is, yes.  We are waiting for them."  They seemed
docile enough, so I thought I'd try to do some digging.  Perhaps I
could gather some information that would be useful for InterPol.  "How
come he's selling the car?" 

"He is leaving for Iraq this week, and he can't take it with him," he
responded. 

Now, don't panic here.  At this time, Iraq was a little known country
somewhere in the middle east.  It did fit in with our terrorist
picture, and John and I managed to exchange nervous glances.  The two
went back inside, and only moments later the car returned.  Karl was,
to our relief, still alive and at the helm.   

When he emerged, however, we realized that something was very wrong.
His eyes were completely glazed over, and he had a Joker-like grin on
his face.  I had always believed brainwashing took a few more
minutes. 

Karl suddenly exploded.  "That was incRRRREDible!  It had so much
POWER!!!!!!  I've never driven anything like it!  I just put my foot
to the floor and I have to shift before it gets there!  We took off
from a red light and we were over a hundred before I could realize
it!" 

Brainwashing, hell.  I was to learn later on in the course of my
relationship with Karl that his most intense emotions involved
horsepower.  People came and went in his life, but cars...for Karl
cars were more than a mere obsession, more than a religion.  True,
every morning and evening at eleven minutes after nine he would kneel
down and face Stuttgart, but it didn't end there.  

"Karl, Karl, calm down," I said.

"It was fanTAStic!"  he was gushing.

"OK. OK.  Karl, get a hold of yourself," said John.  "You can't buy
this car.  It's about to fall apart.  That engine was never meant to
take this kind of horsepower." 

Karl deflated a bit.  "Ja.  You think so?"

"Karl," I said.  "We have to drive the cars we get across the entire
country.  Do you honestly think that one will make it?" 

"But it is so FAST!"

Carlos approached.  Somehow he maneuvered himself between Karl and us.
"What do you think?" he asked. 

"How much are you asking?" Karl said, shakily.

The assassin turned used car salesman shrugged.  "Make me an offer."
(You know, to put it in racing terms, the "turn" from assassin to used
car salesman can be taken at full throttle). 

Karl paused a moment, he eyed me over Carlos' shoulder.  "Twelve
thousand?"  The car had been listed for fourteen. 

Without hesitation, and in a voice so sinister a chill went up my
spine, he responded, "Are you paying cash?"  The last word hung in the
air like the mist of your breath on a cold northeastern morning. 

Like an idiot, like a total moron, like a brainless zombie that had
just emerged from the crypt, Karl said, "Of course." 

"It's a deal."

I looked in horror at John.  "NO NO NO!" we screamed soundlessly at
Karl from behind Carlos' back.  Karl was smiling, and in a deep
trance.  In his eyes I could see him reliving the acceleration.  His
mouth began forming "OK." All seemed lost.   

Suddenly a ray of light streamed down from overhead onto Karl's face,
and he woke up.  Seeing John and me gesticulating frantically at him
for the first time, he said, "I will have to think about it.  I
... errr ... don't have the money here anyway." 

We reflected on our narrow escape later on while ingesting
carbohydrates, saturated fat, and cholesterol at a fine diner.  I
decided not to mention either the true identity of our previous host
nor the miraculous ray of light that had awakened Karl.  The former
because I figured it would be better for the two of them not to know
in case we were captured and tortured by some rival terrorist group,
and the latter because I was now becoming actively aware that
something or someone was helping us, and I needed to consider it
more. 

Day and night are discrete events in L.A.  It's either one or the
other, there is no "dusk" or "dawn"  (There had once been a dawn in
L.A., but then Tony Orlando had some kind of problems and they all
went their separate ways).  Someone on the Santa Monica pier throws a
switch every night and the sky just shuts off.  I must have been in
the bathroom when the switch was thrown because I never noticed it
happen.   

John was busy further convincing Karl that purchasing this butchered
aftermarket turbo was not a good idea.  I could hear their
conversation, but I was lost in thought, and their voices began to
merge with the background noise of the restaurant.  I gazed out the
window into the night.  Overhead I could see the stars glimmering and
I began to orient myself in order to identify them.  I was momentarily
blinded by headlights as a car pulled into the restaurant parking lot
 - it was a 911.  I surprised myself by recognizing it as an 84 or 85
Carrera.  Smiling, I returned my gaze to the sky, and picked out the
three corners of a triangle formed by the stars Altair, Deneb, and
Vega.  With recognition came recollection, and I could now hear my own
voice echoing back across the span of time, "I wish I had a Porsche." 


=====

Christopher Welty                        Vassar College Computer Science Dept
SIGART Information Director                            Poughkeepsie, NY 12601
weltyc@sigart.acm.org                                    weltyc@cs.vassar.edu

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 13:38:38 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: 911 Electrical problems continue...


Hello again,

I was driving my 1981 911SC home from work last night and my alternator
light was glowing ever so slightly (as it has been all week).  When I 
rounded the last coner of my street, 300 yards from my driveway, the
car completely cut out.  The engine stopped, and all the electrical
devices stop.  I pulled over and had to have my buddy pull me into the
driveway with his Jeep.

Nothing works now.  Not the hazards, no lights, no ignition, no nothing.
Turning the key in the ignition does not do anything.  It is as if I
removed the battery from the car.  10 minutes before hand, the car
started normally.

For the past week or so, I had been having eratci electrical problems.
The Tachomter would flutter around, and the seat belt light would come
on.  Many people suggested a bad alternator or ground strap, and since
the alternator (red) light would come on, I suspected such.  

My question I guess is how to start to diagnose this problem.  What would
make the car, while driving down the road just fine, all of a sudden
just stop running?  Does the cable from the battery + terminal run to
the alternator or the starter?  If the alternator failed completely,
would the car stall out like this - maybe if finally shorted out?  
If the voltage regulator failed completely, would this also cause the
symtoms?   It is startnge since none of any of the electrical things
work in the car now.

If it was just the alternator, would this also make the hazards lights
or the headlights not work.  I will attempt this weekend to trace the
problem down, but since nothing in the car works, and thus I cannot
start the car, I will have trouble checking to see if the alternator 
puts out juice.  My battery is brand new by the way, and I check the
negative cable and it is fine.  I also checked the fuse box and there
are no blown fuses.  I have yet to see if the battery positive cable 
came unattached somehow from wherever it leads to.  I thought the battery
cable runs to the starter motr first?  Maybe this is corodded?
Any suggestions???

Thanks in advance.

 -Barry Chapin
chapin@draper.com
1981 Euro-911SC Targa.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 95 10:44:00 PDT
From: "Lai, Hubert" <hl@msmail.orsil.ubc.ca>
Subject: RE: 944/924 stereo setups



 > Since we're on the subject of CD players for 944s, I was curious to know
 > what types of stereo setups have worked well in 944/924s.  If people send
 > me enough responses, I'll provide a summary.
 >
 > In my 84 944, I put in a Sony EXCD-60 CD player, Polk MM series 4x6 
plates
 > in the front doors, Polk EX series 4x6 drivers in the rear side panels,
 > and a 10" Blau subwoofer in a vented bandpass enclosure sitting in the
 > hatch. A Blau amp with 20w x 4 plus one 50w sub output drives the system.

Last year, I installed a new setup in my '83 944.  I was more or less forced 
to buy a new stereo system because the old stereo (which had crappy sound to 
begin with) gave up the ghost.  Since the car was over a decade old, I was 
neither surprised nor particularly disappointed.

I left the speakers alone, since they were fine (though I'm sure modern 
replacements would be noticeably better).  I replaced the head unit with a 
Sony XRU-660, which is an AM/FM cassette deck with controls for multiple CD 
changers, a television, and a VCR.  Of course, there's no room in my car for 
a television and VCR, nor do I have the need.  As for the CD changers, I 
only have one, which is installed at the rear of the car in the spare tire 
compartment.  It would be kind of neat to daisy-chain a bunch of changer 
units and have my entire CD collection on-line at once, but I figured a 
single 10-disc changer would be sufficient.  8-)  I think the model number 
is the CDX-303, though I could be mistaken.  It was over a year ago that I 
bought all this stuff.

The neat thing about the system that I really like is that I can assign 
names to CDs.  The system has enough memory to memorize about a 100 CDs, 
associating the name with the unique digital identifier on each disc.  When 
you put a new magazine of CDs into the changer and then leave it alone for a 
few moments, it will actually load each disc sequentially to read the 
identifiers so that later you can just scroll through the list of loaded CDs 
by name without having to wait for the delay of loading and unloading each 
disc.

The system also has the ability to name radio stations, which I find 
invaluable since I can never remember which stations are on which 
frequencies.

The sound quality is so vastly improved over what was there before (even 
when it was working) that I wish I hadn't waited until the old system had 
given up the ghost before replacing it.  One of the big improvements is the 
increase in power from 0.7 Watts to about 4 Watts.  It used to be that even 
at low listening levels, the system would break up with low drumbeats due to 
insufficient power.  Having seen the major improvement in sound quality 
attributable to more power, I would go with an external amplifier the next 
time around and get real power -- like at least 20 Watts.

<=- Hubert

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 10:47:06 -0700
From: kmayer@eskimo.com (Kevin Mayer)
Subject: 911 Purchase

Hi,

A friend of mine is planning on purchasing a 911. The vehicle is a 1984
Carrera Cab factory wide-body.  He is seeking input as to fair price etc. 

Details:  37k miles, red (repainted nicely), VG cond but not excellent,
Euro-spec I believe, Florida car, no rust, 1st gear sycnhro to be replaced.
Some specific
questions:  What's fair value?  What is Euro-spec? How resalable?  Any items
that should be checked out?  Comments?

Thanks much!
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------
Kevin Mayer
Woodinville, WA
kmayer@eskimo.com     CIS 72162,1377     Fax 206-788-2389      


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 10:56:55 -0700 (PDT)
From: allanh@handmadesw.com (Allan N. Hessenflow)
Subject: Re: 911 Electrical problems continue...

> My question I guess is how to start to diagnose this problem.  What would
> make the car, while driving down the road just fine, all of a sudden
> just stop running?  Does the cable from the battery + terminal run to
> the alternator or the starter?  If the alternator failed completely,
> would the car stall out like this - maybe if finally shorted out?  
> If the voltage regulator failed completely, would this also cause the
> symtoms?   It is startnge since none of any of the electrical things
> work in the car now.

I haven't looked much at the electrical system in a 911, as mine hasn't
given any problems, but I've done way too much electrical work on other
cars...  The big cable from the battery will go just to the starter, so
it isn't really a suspect (unless it shorted to the chassis somewhere,
which you would probably know because it would have welded itself there
and probably created a pretty strong odor as everything in the vicinity
burned).  There will be a smaller wire going to the fusebox, probably
with a fusible link in it.  That link is the most likely problem when
everything electrical fails (including the starter motor, as the starter
solenoid runs off that too).  The next would be the connections between
it and the battery on one side and the fuse box on the other.  This
would not explain the erratic electrical problems you had before this
though - perhaps whatever the problem was finally failed shorted (thereby
burning out that link).  Assuming the link is blown, definitely
check to see if there's a short before just replacing it...

allan

- -- 
Allan N. Hessenflow     allanh@handmadesw.com

------------------------------



Porschephiles #1432                         Fri May 26 22:40:06 CDT 1995
Porschephiles #1432                         Fri May 26 22:40:06 CDT 1995

Linda Grigsby (at Carlsen's Porsche-Audi in Palo Alto, CA) does not
have internet access.  But she thinks it's a great idea and is taking it to
the boss today.

She offers "internet guys" cost+20% on parts.  On big ticket items this
is a substantial discount.  If you're "just" a PCA member she offers
10% off list officially, but usually makes it 15%.

She can be reached at 415-856-0611, 8-4:30 PST.  She's a great source
for parts trivia.  BTW, it's her 63 Super90 husband Bob restored recently.
Incredible job and only $22k.  (I need a bigger garage.)  She doesn't
mind losing it.  She's got a 300E for her lazy moments and a nice old
Speedster when she feels frisky.

For those of you P-filers in Northern California:

On Sunday, 28 May there will be a Porsche Wash and Shine Concours
hosted by John Kinsfather's Auto Enthusiast car botique.
The Site is in front of John's shop in the Danville Livery and 
Mercantile Shopping Center. It is a closed off area, there are usually 
between 50 and 70 entrants, the prizes are very nice. The event opens 
at 8 AM. The Indy 500 will be on television at the site, so you 
won't miss a thing.

All Porsche's are elgible. If you haven't planned anything for the 
weekend, drop by.

Directions: Get to I-680 and head for Danville. Take the Sycamore
Valley Road-West exits from either North or South. Head West on
Sycamore Valley Road to San Ramon Valley RD (there are gas stations 
on each corner), cross over and turn into the second driveway on the 
right. Signs will direct you to the site.

10 AM-6 PM, daily. The shop will be open on Sunday.

Despite the fact that Carlsen offers some of the best prices around, I 
have to question how genuine this 'internet' deal really is. On more than 
one occasion I was told that the quoted price WAS the internet discount 
AFTER I asked what additional discount I could get as an 'internet guy'. 
How could she know to quote me the internet price if I hadn't identified 
myself as such? Either this deal isn't as exclusive as we're led to 
believe or there is really no discount on top of what the regular 
mail-order guy gets.
 
Joe

Date: Fri, 26 May 95 19:38:47 UTC
From: gashw@crusher.gan.nf.doe.ca
Subject: 993 Turbo Rims


Browsing through the latest auto magazines, containing the new 911 Turbo, I
noticed the hollow rims Porsche is using on it. I like the twisted spoke
design of the wheel. Anyway, Porsche being a company of function over form,
I remember reading something about the old Turbo indicating that the design
of the wheel aided brake cooling. True/False who am I to say.

This being the case, I would assume the same considerations were given to the
new wheels. Now, the driver's side rims have a sort of swept back look to them.
The passenger's side rims (using the exact same rims) have a swept forward look
much like a boomerang. Question: Would there be any braking/performance 
consequences, resulting from this "opposition", as great as the aesthetic ones?

It just seems a little strange, that's all. Personally, I like the look of the
passenger's side. Maybe there were cost considerations that limited the 
production of separate left and right side rims. (shrug)

Cheers,

Warren Gash
gashw@crusher.gan.nf.doe.ca

We're up to 993, what's Porsche going to do when they run out of 900 series
numbers? ~8^) ~8^)

Sounds like classic ground interrupt.
Check the ground connections on the battery and the engine.

Rich

> devices stop.  I pulled over and had to have my buddy pull me into the
> driveway with his Jeep.
>

> Turning the key in the ignition does not do anything.  It is as if I
> removed the battery from the car.  10 minutes before hand, the car
> started normally.
>

> The Tachomter would flutter around, and the seat belt light would come
> on.  Many people suggested a bad alternator or ground strap, and since
> the alternator (red) light would come on, I suspected such.

> make the car, while driving down the road just fine, all of a sudden

> would the car stall out like this - maybe if finally shorted out?

> symtoms?   It is startnge since none of any of the electrical things
> work in the car now.

> or the headlights not work.  I will attempt this weekend to trace the
> problem down, but since nothing in the car works, and thus I cannot

> puts out juice.  My battery is brand new by the way, and I check the
> negative cable and it is fine.  I also checked the fuse box and there

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 13:52:29 -0700
From: dab@hyperion.engr.sgi.com (David Brown)
Subject: Re: 914 1.8 liter FI: broken air box temp sensor

   Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 09:04:42 -0500
   From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>

Wow!  Thanks for the great detailed info!

   I looked at my '75 1.8L last night.  Looking in towards the flap from the air cleaner
   end, I see a short (1/2 inch or so), slightly tapered, tan colored cone about the
   same diameter as a pencil.  I can't tell what might be inside it.  Does it look as
   if the metal parts you see would fit into something this size?  My guess is that the
   spring is a temperature sensitive wire resistor.

Ok, this makes sense.  I guess the whole plastic "housing" must have
broken off from mine (uh oh, I wonder where it went :-(  ).  Yup, it's
officially called Temp Sensor I, although there's really no point in
giving it a separate name since you can't test it by itself!

   The sensor is connected to pins 6 and 27 on the airflow sensor.  I took some
   rough measurements for you:
       At about 40 degrees I measured 4500 ohms
       At about 70 degrees I measured  2300 ohms
       At about 100 degrees I measured 1300 ohms

Wow!  Thanks for doing all this testing!  How did you do the different
temperature measurements?  (with a heat gun?  putting the air box in
the fridge??)

However it seems we have slightly different air boxes ('74 versus
'75?)...  In my air box, the terminals on the connector to the FI
harness are labeled: [ 39 36 6 9 8 7 ]

Only ONE of the 2 leads from the temperature sensor is brought
directly out to a terminal ("9").  The other lead connects to the PC
board (through a contact right *near* the FI harness connector),
connecting the temperature sensor to a series resistor (one of those
resistors applied right to the surface of the PC board).  The other
side of the resistor is brought out to terminal 8 of the FI connector.

In fact, here's the rough block diagram of my air box:

     36
     o        
     |     +--/\/\/\/--+--/\/\/\--[***]--+    
    \      |     ^     |                 |          
     |     |     |     |                 |            
     o     o     o     o                 o            
     39    6     7     8                 9            
                                                   
Terminal 7 is the wiper of the potentiometer.  Between 8 and 9 are the
temp sensor ([***]) and its series resistor.  Between 36 and 39 is the
switch that closes when the air flap first moves.

So does your air box have a series resistor for the temp sensor also?
Or were those 1300 to 4500 ohm values really *direct* readings from
the sensor itself?

   Perhaps you can put a 5000 or 10000 ohm potentiometer in the circuit and adjust
   it to see if you can get the engine to run better.

This is a great suggestion.  Even if our air boxes are different (and
I can't use your values exactly) it's worth experimenting a bit while
the car's running.  I'll try to check it out this weekend.

Thanks again for your help,

 - David Brown                          dab@sgi.com
  Silicon Graphics Inc.                415.390.5571

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 16:03:54 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: TurboS vs. 911

>Given 20k$ worth of 944 TurboS at a decent bargain (probably '89ish w/50k ?),
>how much would one have to spend on a 911 to match performance and/or
>ammenities.

        Why would you want to?  They're apples and oranges.  F'rinstance, the
911 is a much better autocrosser, the 951 a much better big-track car.  Each
has its good and not-so-good features.  I don't know if you'll *ever* match
the "amenities" on the 951 in a 911 ("amenities" AKA "luxo-fat").  They were
not intended to ever "match" each other.
        You get the one that makes your blood sing.  If you're really lucky
and like both, you get both.

        Vroom.

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

On Fri, 26 May 1995, Barry Chapin wrote:
