> I was driving my 1981 911SC home from work last night and my alternator
> light was glowing ever so slightly (as it has been all week).  When I 
> rounded the last coner of my street, 300 yards from my driveway, the
> car completely cut out.  The engine stopped, and all the electrical
> devices stop.  I pulled over and had to have my buddy pull me into the
> driveway with his Jeep.
> 
> Nothing works now.  Not the hazards, no lights, no ignition, no nothing.
> Turning the key in the ignition does not do anything.  It is as if I
> removed the battery from the car.  10 minutes before hand, the car
> started normally.
> 
> For the past week or so, I had been having eratci electrical problems.
> The Tachomter would flutter around, and the seat belt light would come
> on.  Many people suggested a bad alternator or ground strap, and since
> the alternator (red) light would come on, I suspected such.  
> 
> My question I guess is how to start to diagnose this problem.  What would
> make the car, while driving down the road just fine, all of a sudden
> just stop running?  Does the cable from the battery + terminal run to
> the alternator or the starter?  If the alternator failed completely,
> would the car stall out like this - maybe if finally shorted out?  
> If the voltage regulator failed completely, would this also cause the
> symtoms?   It is startnge since none of any of the electrical things
> work in the car now.
> 
> If it was just the alternator, would this also make the hazards lights
> or the headlights not work.  I will attempt this weekend to trace the
> problem down, but since nothing in the car works, and thus I cannot
> start the car, I will have trouble checking to see if the alternator 
> puts out juice.  My battery is brand new by the way, and I check the
> negative cable and it is fine.  I also checked the fuse box and there
> are no blown fuses.  I have yet to see if the battery positive cable 
> came unattached somehow from wherever it leads to.  I thought the battery
> cable runs to the starter motr first?  Maybe this is corodded?

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 13:52:29 -0700
From: dab@hyperion.engr.sgi.com (David Brown)
Subject: Re: 914 1.8 liter FI: broken air box temp sensor

   Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 09:04:42 -0500
   From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>

Wow!  Thanks for the great detailed info!

   I looked at my '75 1.8L last night.  Looking in towards the flap from the air cleaner
   end, I see a short (1/2 inch or so), slightly tapered, tan colored cone about the
   same diameter as a pencil.  I can't tell what might be inside it.  Does it look as
   if the metal parts you see would fit into something this size?  My guess is that the
   spring is a temperature sensitive wire resistor.

Ok, this makes sense.  I guess the whole plastic "housing" must have
broken off from mine (uh oh, I wonder where it went :-(  ).  Yup, it's
officially called Temp Sensor I, although there's really no point in
giving it a separate name since you can't test it by itself!

   The sensor is connected to pins 6 and 27 on the airflow sensor.  I took some
   rough measurements for you:
       At about 40 degrees I measured 4500 ohms
       At about 70 degrees I measured  2300 ohms
       At about 100 degrees I measured 1300 ohms

Wow!  Thanks for doing all this testing!  How did you do the different
temperature measurements?  (with a heat gun?  putting the air box in
the fridge??)

However it seems we have slightly different air boxes ('74 versus
'75?)...  In my air box, the terminals on the connector to the FI
harness are labeled: [ 39 36 6 9 8 7 ]

Only ONE of the 2 leads from the temperature sensor is brought
directly out to a terminal ("9").  The other lead connects to the PC
board (through a contact right *near* the FI harness connector),
connecting the temperature sensor to a series resistor (one of those
resistors applied right to the surface of the PC board).  The other
side of the resistor is brought out to terminal 8 of the FI connector.

In fact, here's the rough block diagram of my air box:

     36
     o        
     |     +--/\/\/\/--+--/\/\/\--[***]--+    
    \      |     ^     |                 |          
     |     |     |     |                 |            
     o     o     o     o                 o            
     39    6     7     8                 9            
                                                   
Terminal 7 is the wiper of the potentiometer.  Between 8 and 9 are the
temp sensor ([***]) and its series resistor.  Between 36 and 39 is the
switch that closes when the air flap first moves.

So does your air box have a series resistor for the temp sensor also?
Or were those 1300 to 4500 ohm values really *direct* readings from
the sensor itself?

   Perhaps you can put a 5000 or 10000 ohm potentiometer in the circuit and adjust
   it to see if you can get the engine to run better.

This is a great suggestion.  Even if our air boxes are different (and
I can't use your values exactly) it's worth experimenting a bit while
the car's running.  I'll try to check it out this weekend.

Thanks again for your help,

 - David Brown                          dab@sgi.com
  Silicon Graphics Inc.                415.390.5571

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 16:03:54 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: TurboS vs. 911

>Given 20k$ worth of 944 TurboS at a decent bargain (probably '89ish w/50k ?),
>how much would one have to spend on a 911 to match performance and/or
>ammenities.

        Why would you want to?  They're apples and oranges.  F'rinstance, the
911 is a much better autocrosser, the 951 a much better big-track car.  Each
has its good and not-so-good features.  I don't know if you'll *ever* match
the "amenities" on the 951 in a 911 ("amenities" AKA "luxo-fat").  They were
not intended to ever "match" each other.
        You get the one that makes your blood sing.  If you're really lucky
and like both, you get both.

        Vroom.

- --DD

Date: 26 May 1995 21:53:41 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.COM (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: 73 vs 95 911

> Congratulations on your "new"  '73.5 911.  How is it in comparison to your
> 993? I have a '73 911S targa and my parents have an '87 911 turbo-look
targa
> and the difference between the two is rather large.  Mine feels much more
> agile and tossable, whereas my parents' car feels heavy and much more
planted
> to the road.  The Carrera engine is also much smoother.  What are your
> impressions?
>
> Anyway, I have the same problem with the engine lid shocks. It seems that
> shocks were designed for new cars with a tail. You really have to watch out
> when you open the back up for a mechanic. If you don't warn them, they are
> probably going to get hit in the face. What did you end up doing with that
> shock? Is there a correct one that exerts less force?
>
> Neil Kumpers
> '73 911S targa

> P.S. You used to have an '88 911 turbo look cab, right? Did you happen to
> live in Hillsborough, CA? If so I saw your car.
- --------------
Neil,
If the difference between a 73 and 87 is "rather large", it is night and day
between a 73 and 95.  Other than the outward appearance and basic interior
layout (among the best features of a 911!) there is almost no similarity. 
Okay, that stretches the truth a little, but if you ever get a chance to
drive a 993 you'll agree immediately.  The 73 is hard drivin'.  It is loud,
steering is heavy (but tight), creature comforts are nil (like fresh air
vents, modern comfortable but supportive seats), shifting builds muscles (as
does braking), gauges can't be read at night, radios are almost useless, AC
is either missing or ineffective, engines run very warm, tires/wheels are
prehistoric and contribute to quirky handling, you feel every flaw in the
pavement, it is not especially fast by modern stds, etc..  Everything is
exactly the opposite on a 993.  You can whisper to a passanger and be heard,
road sounds are muffled, the 10-speaker stereo rivals the best sounds of any
factory unit, the steering is precise *and* easy, brakes are outrageously
good (even better than the 930), it's hard to lose control (even if you are a
bit careless), acceleration is neck snapping (God...I wonder what the 96
turbo is like!), the seats are great (they've even been lengthened for more
thigh support), and it's perfect in all kinds of weather (no more defrost
woes, foggy or dark gauges, inadequate wipers, marginal headlights, etc.). 
Basically Porsche did its homework to build at a car that is every bit a 911
in its configuration and performance, but a wonderfully comfortable luxury
car as well.  I've cruised quite comfortably at 135mph.  Scary how easy it is
to do.  And its track capabilities are pretty clear.

Still, everything everyone says about the pre-74 911's is true.  They *do*
feel more nimble.  When I drive the 73 I feel like I'm driving a race car
(duh).  I get absorbed by it.  My mind doesn't wonder.  I'm thinking about
the next turn, or the next gear, or the next set of tires I'll mount.  I
don't mind the hard ride; I *like* it.  This really is the 911 experience. 
In the 993 I feel like I'm driving the best damned sports car the world ever
produced.  Sure compromises were made.  But I can't find a single one to
argue about. There's so much torque across the band that it's easy to get
lazy about gear selection.  And I spend more time thinking about issues other
than the car. 8^(

My wife, who's owned her own Carreras, doesn't especially like the 73.  She
finds the 993 just too good to turn away from.  She likes that I like it,
probably because it gives her more time in the 993.  But she'll drive our 3rd
car before she'll reach for the 73 keys.

As far as those lid shocks are concerned, I swapped the rear for a somewhat
more used one and the problem is not as bad.  Do you have AC in your 73S?  I
don't, so there's not even a condensor to add to the lid weight.  Stand
back...lid's about to blow!  I'm learning to live with it.  I've adjusted the
rubber stops so at least the lid sits straight now.

I had an 88 turbo look but it was a targa.  The new owner lives in Capitola
(near Santa Cruz) and commutes north to Freemont (east bay) every day.  I've
talked with him.  First 911.  He's addicted.  Another convert.

Regards
Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T coupe, guards red
85 535i, grey

Date: Fri, 26 May 95 15:07:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: ac & inspection question


On the a/c question:  there is a small relay in the control unit in the dash 
that may be the culprit.

Remove stereo.

Remove control unit and open.  Small relay on board will have burned and 
discolored contacts.  Clean contacts with emory cloth/similar and hopefully 
you will save yourself lots of $$$.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

mediate brethren?  Due to the fact that I can't really afford to

functions.  A guy at the TireRack told me that the AVSs would be

my rear tires at the first track event I go to.

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 19:28:47 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Front Suspension Questions

>After replacing these parts, I plan to lower the front ride height.  The car
>with the original torsion bars, sits with the rear lower than the front (I
>measured ~27 1/2" front, ~25 1/4" rear to the top of the fender lip).  I
>know that I should replace all the torsion bars and set the ride height of
>the front and rear of the car.  But, should it be OK to just adjust the
>front and then replace the bars and reset the the ride height later?

I would adjust the front first and recheck the rears a few days after
you adjust the fronts.  When I raised the rear of my '76, I noticed that
my previously high front end came down a little (and right into spec
for a Euro model - 108mm) so I left it alone.

Just a thought...

Mike Dayton

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 22:10:30 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: Carseats for 911 - Search and Report


Well, I tried the Century Braverra booster seat tonite in the back of the 
911.  The base is about .5 to .75" too wide to fit all the way back 
flush against the back of the seat.  Also, because the rear seat belts 
are set forward, i.e. they do not come from behind you like most cars, 
there is no way to keep the seat from lurching forward and backward the 
distance the seat belt is set forward from the back of the seat.  (The 
seat belt slips through two slots on the back of the car seat).  This 
seat belt configuratiopn problem also eliminated the car seat that is 
just a back with should harnesses and a sub-belt attached because the 
seat belt anchoring position was in the back of the seat.  I can't 
believe no one has designed a carseat to fit the rear seats of the 911 
(and, I think the 944 - aren't they the same dimensions?)  Perhaps I will 
put my artistic hand to work and come up with a design upon which my 
early retirement will be built! :-)

Until then, I remain in search of the rear 911 carseat.

Jerry Mac
84 911 Targa (Rauschquarzmettalick)
Motor-stadt Region PCA



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 22:47:06 -0400
From: PIAUDIO@aol.com
Subject: Re: Hard Starting 924

My 924 did the same thing until I replaced the fuel line check valve on the
outlet of the second fuel pump (outside the gas tank) and the fuel
accumulator. Another possibility is fuel pressure leakdown from tired
injectors.

Paul Ingebrigtsen
79 924
piaudio@aol.com

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 22:09:01 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 911 SC Valve Train Clatter

Dear Karl,

I recently replaced a spray bar.  It was pretty simple.  I drilled and 
tapped the plug in the cam tower and pulled the plug with the appropriate 
sized bolt. I slid the bent tube out and replaced it.  In this case I 
would spray or pour car cleaner through the spray bar first.  Then pull 
the plug and use a wire to probe it.   You could carefully remove it and 
then clean it with a rifle bore cleaning brush.  The plugs and spray bar 
have part numbers.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 22:32:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Best Hydraulic Jack

Hello Hubert,

I posted a medium sized treaste on the "Walker" Floor Jack.  There are 
several advantages to this jack that you wont find with other floor 
jacks.  Among them:

1.  They have resale value because they can be rebuilt.
2.  Parts can be bought from dealers and jack rebuilders.
3.  They are pricey however there are a lot of used ones out there.
4.  They are sold used in the newspaper classifieds, pawn shops, auctions etc
5.  No other imported jacks nor very few american made jacks are as 
    universialy used by most professional mechanics or garages.
6.  This jack uses an external pump.  When it is worn out you simply buy 
    another pump and screw it into the base of the casting.  The rest of 
    the jacks I am familiar with have the pump as an intregal portion of 
    the casting.  When the casting is worn out the jack is virtually 
    nothing but a large wheel chock.

Good luck with all of your projects. 


David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

flap inside the unit in the cabin, I think it's probably a major pain.

On Thu, 25 May 1995, Joe Hunter wrote:

> On Thu, 25 May 1995, Lai, Hubert wrote:
> 
> > Within the last month or so, someone posted a message describing what he 
> > thought was the best jack available.  I printed that message out and 
> > promptly misplaced it.  I'm going to be dropping by my local Canadian Tire 
> > store after work today to buy a jack and I wonder what I should get.  Any 
> > advice?  Thanks.
> 
> I bought mine from the Price Club (Costco). Most I've seen in the $30-$40 
> CDN range are made in China (which is not to say there is anything wrong 
> with that). When I bought mine (actually my second one as the first seem 
> weak),I considered :
> 
> 1. The minimum height the cup will go. I've found that on my '86 944, I have
>    to drive up on a board just to give it the extra 0.5 cm clearance to slide
>    the jack in. Also, I'm using the 'jack-plate' from Automotion,
>    designed to protect the bottom of the car. In all the work I've done on
>    the car, I've only jacked it up using the jack-point at the center of the
>    rocker panel (Is this ok for the car?). There is usually no problem
>    sliding the jack out after you lower the car as the suspension hasn't
>    been loaded yet.
> 
> 2. The thickness of the steel used for the jack. Of course the thicker the
>    better. My first jack was made of thinner steel and I didn't want to take
>    a chance.
> 
> Joe '86 944
> 

------------------------------

turbo-look
targa
> and the difference between the two is rather large.  Mine feels much more
> agile and tossable, whereas my parents' car feels heavy and much more
planted
> to the road.  The Carrera engine is also much smoother.  What are your
> impressions?
>
> Anyway, I have the same problem with the engine lid shocks. It seems that
> shocks were designed for new cars with a tail. You really have to watch out
> when you open the back up for a mechanic. If you don't warn them, they are
> probably going to get hit in the face. What did you end up doing with that
> shock? Is there a correct one that exerts less force?

> Neil Kumpers
> '73 911S targa

> P.S. You used to have an '88 911 turbo look cab, right? Did you happen to
> live in Hillsborough, CA? If so I saw your car.
- --------------
Neil,
If the difference between a 73 and 87 is "rather large", it is night and day
between a 73 and 95.  Other than the outward appearance and basic interior
layout (among the best features of a 911!) there is almost no similarity. 
Okay, that stretches the truth a little, but if you ever get a chance to
drive a 993 you'll agree immediately.  The 73 is hard drivin'.  It is loud,
steering is heavy (but tight), creature comforts are nil (like fresh air
vents, modern comfortable but supportive seats), shifting builds muscles (as
does braking), gauges can't be read at night, radios are almost useless, AC
is either missing or ineffective, engines run very warm, tires/wheels are
prehistoric and contribute to quirky handling, you feel every flaw in the
pavement, it is not especially fast by modern stds, etc..  Everything is
exactly the opposite on a 993.  You can whisper to a passanger and be heard,
road sounds are muffled, the 10-speaker stereo rivals the best sounds of any
factory unit, the steering is precise *and* easy, brakes are outrageously
good (even better than the 930), it's hard to lose control (even if you are a
bit careless), acceleration is neck snapping (God...I wonder what the 96
turbo is like!), the seats are great (they've even been lengthened for more
thigh support), and it's perfect in all kinds of weather (no more defrost
woes, foggy or dark gauges, inadequate wipers, marginal headlights, etc.). 
Basically Porsche did its homework to build at a car that is every bit a 911
in its configuration and performance, but a wonderfully comfortable luxury
car as well.  I've cruised quite comfortably at 135mph.  Scary how easy it is
to do.  And its track capabilities are pretty clear.

Still, everything everyone says about the pre-74 911's is true.  They *do*
feel more nimble.  When I drive the 73 I feel like I'm driving a race car
(duh).  I get absorbed by it.  My mind doesn't wonder.  I'm thinking about
the next turn, or the next gear, or the next set of tires I'll mount.  I
don't mind the hard ride; I *like* it.  This really is the 911 experience. 
In the 993 I feel like I'm driving the best damned sports car the world ever
produced.  Sure compromises were made.  But I can't find a single one to
argue about. There's so much torque across the band that it's easy to get
lazy about gear selection.  And I spend more time thinking about issues other
than the car. 8^(

My wife, who's owned her own Carreras, doesn't especially like the 73.  She
finds the 993 just too good to turn away from.  She likes that I like it,
probably because it gives her more time in the 993.  But she'll drive our 3rd
car before she'll reach for the 73 keys.

As far as those lid shocks are concerned, I swapped the rear for a somewhat
more used one and the problem is not as bad.  Do you have AC in your 73S?  I
don't, so there's not even a condensor to add to the lid weight.  Stand
back...lid's about to blow!  I'm learning to live with it.  I've adjusted the
rubber stops so at least the lid sits straight now.

I had an 88 turbo look but it was a targa.  The new owner lives in Capitola
(near Santa Cruz) and commutes north to Freemont (east bay) every day.  I've
talked with him.  First 911.  He's addicted.  Another convert.

Regards
Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T coupe, guards red
85 535i, grey

Date: Fri, 26 May 95 15:07:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: ac & inspection question


On the a/c question:  there is a small relay in the control unit in the dash 
that may be the culprit.

Remove stereo.

Remove control unit and open.  Small relay on board will have burned and 
discolored contacts.  Clean contacts with emory cloth/similar and hopefully 
you will save yourself lots of $$$.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 19:28:47 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Front Suspension Questions

>After replacing these parts, I plan to lower the front ride height.  The car
>with the original torsion bars, sits with the rear lower than the front (I
>measured ~27 1/2" front, ~25 1/4" rear to the top of the fender lip).  I
>know that I should replace all the torsion bars and set the ride height of
>the front and rear of the car.  But, should it be OK to just adjust the
>front and then replace the bars and reset the the ride height later?

I would adjust the front first and recheck the rears a few days after
you adjust the fronts.  When I raised the rear of my '76, I noticed that
my previously high front end came down a little (and right into spec
for a Euro model - 108mm) so I left it alone.

Just a thought...

Mike Dayton

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 22:10:30 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: Carseats for 911 - Search and Report


Well, I tried the Century Braverra booster seat tonite in the back of the 
911.  The base is about .5 to .75" too wide to fit all the way back 
flush against the back of the seat.  Also, because the rear seat belts 
are set forward, i.e. they do not come from behind you like most cars, 
there is no way to keep the seat from lurching forward and backward the 
distance the seat belt is set forward from the back of the seat.  (The 
seat belt slips through two slots on the back of the car seat).  This 
seat belt configuratiopn problem also eliminated the car seat that is 
just a back with should harnesses and a sub-belt attached because the 
seat belt anchoring position was in the back of the seat.  I can't 
believe no one has designed a carseat to fit the rear seats of the 911 
(and, I think the 944 - aren't they the same dimensions?)  Perhaps I will 
put my artistic hand to work and come up with a design upon which my 
early retirement will be built! :-)

Until then, I remain in search of the rear 911 carseat.

Jerry Mac
84 911 Targa (Rauschquarzmettalick)
Motor-stadt Region PCA

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 22:47:06 -0400
From: PIAUDIO@aol.com
Subject: Re: Hard Starting 924

My 924 did the same thing until I replaced the fuel line check valve on the
outlet of the second fuel pump (outside the gas tank) and the fuel
accumulator. Another possibility is fuel pressure leakdown from tired
injectors.

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 22:09:01 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 911 SC Valve Train Clatter

Dear Karl,

I recently replaced a spray bar.  It was pretty simple.  I drilled and 
tapped the plug in the cam tower and pulled the plug with the appropriate 
sized bolt. I slid the bent tube out and replaced it.  In this case I 
would spray or pour car cleaner through the spray bar first.  Then pull 
the plug and use a wire to probe it.   You could carefully remove it and 
then clean it with a rifle bore cleaning brush.  The plugs and spray bar 
have part numbers.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 22:32:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Best Hydraulic Jack

Hello Hubert,

I posted a medium sized treaste on the "Walker" Floor Jack.  There are 
several advantages to this jack that you wont find with other floor 
jacks.  Among them:

1.  They have resale value because they can be rebuilt.
2.  Parts can be bought from dealers and jack rebuilders.
3.  They are pricey however there are a lot of used ones out there.
4.  They are sold used in the newspaper classifieds, pawn shops, auctions etc
5.  No other imported jacks nor very few american made jacks are as 
    universialy used by most professional mechanics or garages.
6.  This jack uses an external pump.  When it is worn out you simply buy 
    another pump and screw it into the base of the casting.  The rest of 
    the jacks I am familiar with have the pump as an intregal portion of 
    the casting.  When the casting is worn out the jack is virtually 
    nothing but a large wheel chock.

Good luck with all of your projects. 


David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

> weak),I considered :

>    the jack in. Also, I'm using the 'jack-plate' from Automotion,
>    designed to protect the bottom of the car. In all the work I've done on
>    the car, I've only jacked it up using the jack-point at the center of the
>    rocker panel (Is this ok for the car?). There is usually no problem
>    sliding the jack out after you lower the car as the suspension hasn't
>    been loaded yet.
> 
> 2. The thickness of the steel used for the jack. Of course the thicker the
>    better. My first jack was made of thinner steel and I didn't want to take
>    a chance.

Porschephiles #1433                         Sat May 27 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 23:46:21 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Why Dry Sump???

Barry,

Two other reasons for dry sump spring to mind.  The first is that, in
any race car, you want to get the engine and everything else as low as
possible.  Eliminate a wet sump, and you pick up a couple of inches.

The second reason is that a dry sump keeps the crank from ever sitting
in oil.  If it sits in oil, that costs you a bit of horsepower.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 23:27:56 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: re: Re: Best Hydraulic Jack

Hey Scott,

Thank you for the endorsement of purchasing that jack from my advice.

Here's some more advice thats universally applicable to floor jacks. 
1.  Depress them when rolling the jack across unpaved or graveled areas.
When you do this the outer seal/wiper cleans off the jack ram which is on 
the bottom of the jack.
2.  Turn the jack on its side after raising the pad to its fullest 
extension.  Then inspect the ram and the seal.  Inspect the seal/wiper 
for gravel that would scar the ram and lead to early seal failure.  Early 
jacks used a felt wiper here.  If equipped clean and re-oil it.
3.  Use real hydraulic jack oil.  I have found brake fluid in jacks!
4.  Since you have the luxury of replaceable wheels and casters with real 
bearings, grease them.

I love my 1950's model.  It's only 40 years old and it works every day.  
Its smooth as silk as you say.  I would like to add that I think that the 
one you bought has the widest lifting range of any floor jacks and is 
definately the strongest for its size.  I forgot that it was rerated to 
two tons.

Good luck with your projects.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Sat, 27 May 1995 08:29:40 -0400

for you. You cannot get a feel for an auto by reading the spec sheets.

Date: Sat, 27 May 1995 08:42:11 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Why Dry Sump???

> What is the advantage of a dry sump lubrication system as implemented on the
> 911??  I know that it is used in racing, but I know of no other consumer car
> that utilizes this system...

Kevin and others pretty well hit the "why use dry sump", but I'll recap
before moving to Part Two...

1) insure that you never, ever try to pump air to the main bearings instead
   of oil

2) reduce pumping losses due to sloshing the crank through the oil (BTW, in
   certain 'merikun engines over the years, this was seen as a *FEATURE*
   as the splashing helped lower-end lubrication)

3) added oil cooling as the oil is only really *IN* the engine while it's
   "doing something", and is sitting in a nice (relatively) cool tank or
   the to/from lines the rest of the time.

Now, why *NOT* do it in regular production cars:

First off, there *ARE* cars that have dry sump systems. Most of them are
the other exotics, like Ferraris and such. I can't think of any  mass-market
car that has a dry sump off the top of my head though... 

Second, the 911 is *NOT* a mass-production car. Note that there are what?
about 200,000 911s made, *EVER*??? Shit, GM does that in *ONE DAY* if you 
look at world-wide production. Think about it.

Now that we have that part of the equation straight: to add a dry sump system
for racing purposes is hellishly expensive. You have to change the internal
oil pump and some of the oil galley routing, the pan, and then you add an
external pump, lots of oil line, and a tank. When I dry-sumped a Toyota
4A engine (C Sports Racer application), it cost about $2800 using parts
from TRD. If you look at the cost for a dry sump for a Pinto engine for use
in a Formula Ford, you'll see similar numbers. If you look at a dry sump
for a Winston Cup type application, it's a LOT higher.

Let's assume we can apply normal "more is cheaper" economics, and can get
the *PARTS COST* down to kilobuck, and the per-car labor charge at initial
assembly down to only $500 per car in extra labor. That would push the
retail consumer price up by close to $6k. And move your oil change costs
from $20 at Jiffy Lube to close to $100 at a slightly more sophisictated
place. *THAT'S* why no one uses this stuff for mass production cars.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 27 May 1995 09:20:01 -0500
From: TODD.COHEN@rrd.com
Subject: Child Seats in a 911

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *porschephiles@tta.com
          TO:        INTERNET-MACDONAG *macdonag
          TO:        INTERNET-VTL      *vtl
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      05/27/95
          TIME:      09:16:00
 
          SUBJECT:   Child Seats in a 911
 
 
 
I said that I would go to Toys-R-Us and see if the Century Breverra booster
seat would fit into my 1972 911.  Well it DOES NOT.  The rear seat belts
that I purchased from Performance Engineered Products has the push-button
buckle on too short of a length of webbing.  I have never measured the belts
from a later model 911 so I do not know if it is any different.  But anyway,
the buckle part of the belt binds against the slot in the back of the child
seat, and the child seat will not sit flush against the back of the seat.
If the belt buckle was on a longer length of webbing then it may work.  I
believe Vic may have a later model 911 than I do, so his seat works.
 
As for the model of the seats, I was wrong.  I said that the store had only
one left of the style of seat with the built in harness.  When I got to the
store that night they had refilled the shelves.  So it seems there are two
models available, one with the harness that has slots in the back to thread
the cars belt through.  And one without a harness that uses the cars 3-point
belt to hold the seat and child to the car (which can only be used with
3-point belts).
 
I plan to keep looking around town and see what I can find.  My daughter is
3 1/2 years old and the child seat that I use in the 911 is becoming too
small for her.  Hopefully I can find something to use.

Date: Sat, 27 May 1995 12:56:29 -0400
From: DH993@aol.com
Subject: Membership in Porsche Club of America (PCA)

For those of you on p-philes who own a Porsche and are not already a member
of PCA, here's the deal:
*Largest single marque car club in the world! (over 34.000 members)
*Award winning monthly magazine - Porsche Panorama.
*Local Regions with local newsletters and events.
*Vast technical publications - Up-Fixin- Vols 1-8 (reprints of all technical
articles ever appearing in PANO, vols organized by year of original
publication).
*Tech Committee (of renowned credentials) available to answer your questions.
Specialists for all models plus exteriors/interiors and historic race cars.
*Valuation committee to help you establish the value of your car.
*Access to specialized insurance for Porsches that are second autos/pleasure
only/limited mileage =$saved (Leland-West Ins -must be a PCA member)
*Annual National Convention (Porsche Parade) gathers in different location
each year. Over 600 Porsches and 1500 folks gather for a week of nothing but
Porscheing. This year in Portland Oregon Aug 6-12.
*Dues are $36 per year. MC/VISA accepted. Must provide VIN# for application
to be processed.

For further information or to join contact one of the following:

Judy Hendrickson
National Membership Chair
email: DH993@aol.com

Nashua NH 03063
(603) 881-7576
or

Date: Sat, 27 May 1995 15:40:23 -0400
From: Z356@aol.com
Subject: News on Lotus/Kia

No Flaming please.
I thought some of you might be interested in this news flash about Lotus.
Another small speciality company going up against the biggies.


Lotus News Release

Lotus Elan has not been sold to Kia           Date: 19 May 1995
Contact: Patrick G. Peal                      Embargo: Immediate

Only 200 of the limited-production Lotus Elan S2 remain to be
completed at the Hethel plant of Lotus Cars Ltd. - and Lotus dealers
world-wide, reacting to customer demand, have placed orders for
every one.

At the recent Seoul Motor Show, Kia presented their new high-
technology L96 sports car which is the first fruit of the technology
transfer agreement signed between Lotus and Kia last March.  Lotus
is supplying expertise, as well as some components and tooling for
prototypes and initial production.

While there are broad similarities in the external appearance of the
Kia L96 show car and the Lotus Elan S2, there will be no mistaking
the production L96 for the Lotus Elan in appearance, character,
performance, or image.

Well over 80% (by value) of the parts of the L96 will be either unique
or respecified for local sourcing.  Kia will supply the 130 bhp
normally aspirated engine, transmission, brakes, suspension, as well
as interior and exterior hard and soft trim items.

The L96 will go into production for the 1997 model year, specified and
homologated for the Korean home market only.  Senior management at Kia
confirm that they have no export plans at present, nor has a price for
the L96 been set, pending completion of the engineering development
programme.


Denny Zamler
Still looking for my 356-feel I am getting close

Date: Sat, 27 May 1995 23:18:58 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: re: 911 engine control units

Someone asked about the blue (sometimes black) switch on the back of a 
European 911 control unit.  This is an eight position switch which gives 
the control unit some small range of adjustment to timing and fuel.  
Typically on 911's the fully counterclockwise position is the standard 
baseline position. The next click clockwise adds a small amount to the 
pulsewidth, maybe a few percent.  I don't remember which is which on the 
next two; one takes out a little fuel, one adds more fuel. 

Position five (four "clicks" from fully counterclockwise, return fuel to 
the baseline, but takes out about 2 degrees of ignition timing. It varied 
from chip to chip, but was usually only kicked in over 1500. the final 
three positions duplicated the fuel changes of the first, but included 
the retarded timing.

The box the person asked about was a 911.618.111.09.  I don't remember 
this being the correct number for an '84 Euro 911; these came with .00 
DME units.

Another item to look for is the "country code" jumper in the wiring 
harness going to the DME.  Each chip had several sets of maps, and these 
jumpers told the DME which set to look at.  There are three choices: 
open, no jumper, a shorted jumper, or one with a resistor. 

Hope this is of some help.

Larry Bershtein

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 28 May 95 05:37:38 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: my 944's  Clutch is Toast! (I think)


> Seems like the pressure 
> plate let go? Is this a normal 944 clutch failure?  How much should a 
> clutch job run?


Hi, Marc,

Sounds like the pressure plate, or release arm, or slave cylinder.

Probably the quickest way to check would be to remove the starter to take a
look at the flywheel/pressure plate area. See if you get any motion while
someone else is depressing the clutch pedal.

New parts for a clutch job are roughly $450 (disk, pp, to bearing) and the
labor is about 8-10 hours for a rookie, 5-8 hours for a pro.  It is
definitely a job you can do yourself, without too many special tools.

Good luck,
- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (needs work)
1980 GMC Pickup (tow vehicle), 1986 Audi 5000 Wagon
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Previously Owned Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Sun, 28 May 95 05:45:07 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 924S cam/balance belt whine

> Hi 
> I have just replaced the belts in my 1987 924S.  When I started it, I noticed
> quite a lot of belt whine (more than before -- I think)
> Anyway, I used the proper tool to tension the balance belt (# 9021 or
> something) and the cam belt itself has the (1987 and on) mechanical self
> tensioner.  The power steering and alternator/AC belts are (maybe) slightly
> looser than before.  Any ideas?

Some aftermarket belts have a noticeable tendency to whine or whistle.

If that bothers you (it's not going to hurt the motor), get thee to the
dealer and buy the Porsche original belts...

(I know about the whining belt problem, I have one in my 83 right now...)


- --

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 28 May 95 05:59:11 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: EDITORS: PMNA Statement on 944 Aluminum Control Arms

The following is a statement released by Porsche Motorsports North America
concerning the 944 Aluminum Control Arms:

To all Porsche 944 & 968 Competitors
Re: 944 & 958 Control Arm Usage In Racing Applications

The following A arms should be installed in 944 and 968 Series
vehicles according to the conditions noted:


944 341 027 02 L/S Production version arm
           (round groove 360  degrees on ball joint)
944 341 028 02 R/S Production version arm
These parts are good for moderate competition. (Time trials etc.)

951 341 027 32 L/S Competition version arm
                  (slotted groove on side of ball joint)
951 341 028 32 R/S Competition version arm
These parts are recommended for long distance races or heavy competition.


Neither set of arms noted above pose a problem, as long as 1)
the ride height is not lowered beyond the point which causes
binding of the ball joint when the suspension reaches full
travel, 2) the front sway bar is not greater than the M030
package sway bar in either 0.D. or wall thickness, 3) the lower
bore in the strut is not worn out and 4) the parts are
assembled following the steps outlined in the Porsche Service
Manual. (Despite the fact that this may be slightly contrary to
the Service Manual, it is imperative that the bolt and nut
(original Porsche Parts) be replaced each time they are
removed.

As always in racing, it is important to inspect the arms for
nicks or cuts from road debris after each event to avoid
development of any cracks. Please note that the leading cause
of failure we have seen on both the Production and Competition
version arms, in racing applications, is the failure to follow
the instructions I have listed above. Please call PMNA with any
racing preparation issues.

Alwin Springer
Director of Porsche Motorsport N. A.

3203 South Shannon St. Santa Ana. CA 92704
(714)546-6939/ FAX (714) 957-1386

- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------


- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
1983 944 Track Car, 1987 944S Track Car (motor being fixed)
1980 GMC Pickup (tow vehicle), 1986 Audi 5000 Wagon
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Previously Campaigned Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 28 May 1995 12:41:50 -0400
From: craig@newforce.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: Re: my 944's  Clutch is Toast! (I think)

>plate let go? Is this a normal 944 clutch failure?  How much should a 
>clutch job run?

Hmm. Well, the clutch slave cylinder could by dying (easy to replace,
relatively cheap, thus, check it first). The pedal would (normally) lose all
its "feel" that way.

Replacing the clutch components, etc. is a major pain-in-the-ass job in a
944 (compared to "normal" RWD (or rear-engined) cars), though I've done it
in my driveway. Figure on a much higher-than-usual number of hours if you
get a mechanic to do it (which is why I ended up doing it in my driveway).

One thing to do: check the pilot bearing and make sure it is properly
lubricated. I just had what seemed to be a pressure plate failure in my
"other" car, which turned out to be a siezed pilot bearing. *Very* annoying.

Craig.

Date: Sun, 28 May 1995 19:42:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Engine Pre-Oiler??

> 	Is a system like this good or stupid.

Yes. (don't you love answers like that?)

It's based on sound engineering and the company that makes it, Canton/Meca
makes a ton of other wonderful stuff. However, the benefit has never clearly
been demonstrated to me based on real-world usage.

Stan

Date: Thu, 25 May 1995 09:04:42 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re: 914 1.8 liter FI: broken air box temp sensor

David Brown <dab@hyperion.engr.sgi.com> writes:

>I've got a '74 1.8 liter 914 that I'm trying to get into tune, and found a
>(possible) problem *within* my intake air sensor.
>
>My intake air Temperature Sensor is broken.  This is a very small device
>made from a couple of pieces of metal and a spring; it's *inside* the air box,
>sticking out into the airflow just before the sensor flap.  Two leads from this
>device stick up into compartment with the PC board and potentiometer, and
>plug into the connector going to the FI wiring harness.
>
>I found my temp sensor was physically broken; the metal parts are dangling
>loose, I can't tell what the spring was supposed to do, and there may even be
>some missing plastic pieces.

I think this is what is referred to as "Temperature Sensor I" in the Bosch L-Jetronic
and Haynes manuals.

I looked at my '75 1.8L last night.  Looking in towards the flap from the air cleaner
end, I see a short (1/2 inch or so), slightly tapered, tan colored cone about the
same diameter as a pencil.  I can't tell what might be inside it.  Does it look as
if the metal parts you see would fit into something this size?  My guess is that the
spring is a temperature sensitive wire resistor.

>The Previous Owner shorted the leads from the sensor together, probably
>thinking that a temp sensor resistance of zero was "normal".  This seems to
>work *somewhat* well; the car runs okay (but not great) like this, and won't run
>at all if the temp sensor resistance is infinity!
>
>Does anyone know how this sensor really works?  What are the metal contacts
>and that tiny spring supposed to do as the temperature changes?  And most
>important: anyone know the nominal "cold" and "warm" resistance values that
>this device is supposed to report?

The sensor is connected to pins 6 and 27 on the airflow sensor.  I took some
rough measurements for you:
    At about 40 degrees I measured 4500 ohms
    At about 70 degrees I measured  2300 ohms
    At about 100 degrees I measured 1300 ohms

Perhaps you can put a 5000 or 10000 ohm potentiometer in the circuit and adjust
it to see if you can get the engine to run better.

Hope this helps,

Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L

Date: Sun, 28 May 1995 18:02:30 -0700
From: nms@slip.net (Nicholas Silva)
Subject: Re: 993 Turbo rims

>Porsche claims that the center section and the rim of the wheel
>are joined using a "new patented friction welding technique".
>Friction welding of components like this is nothing new.  What
>is Porsche doing that warrants modifiers like "new" and "patented"?


I have heard that the wheels are hollow spoked, the spokes are made
separately from the rims, and they are joined using a counter-rotating
friction process. Whether this is new and patentable is beyond my
expertise, but I also do not like the angled design being different on both
sides of the car. I prefer the slanted-backwards look of the driver's side,
and wish Porsche had made 4 different wheels. (or 8, so one could choose
forwards or backwards!)

Nick Silva
95 C4

was still an open allocation so I could get it the way I want it before the

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 09:08:37 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re: Advice on: 914 Rear Calipers / 911 kit ?

Lee C. Jacobs  <LJacobs@Calvin.HSC.Colorado.EDU> writes:
>Since there's a lot of brake discussions about, and I'm a newbie,
>I'll throw my questions into the mix ....
>
>Car: 72 914 ( with 73 2.0 and tranny / weber carb ).
>
>#1) Rear left caliper is leaking fluid through the threaded hole that goes
>    against the trailing arm.  Can't seem to see any bleed valves / adjusters
>    in that hole.  What's it for ?  Brakes are bled from an outer valve.
>    Should there be a bolt through the trailing arm into the caliper?
>    (but the right one doesn't leak, just the left).

If you are really seeing a threaded hole, then you have lost the threaded cap
that is supposed to fit in there.  Behind the cap is supposed to be a piston
clearance adjuster.  Looking in throught the hole in the trailing arm you should
see the cap.  If the cap is gone, you should see the end of a threaded shaft into
which an allen wrench should fit.  If you lost the cap, then you may have lost the
adjuster as well, since I think that the cap is the only thing that holds it in place.
For a comparison, see what the right side looks like.

>#2) If I need to rebuild, I might consider getting the 911 Master Cylinder
>    and 911 calipers from Automobile Atlanta.  But their catalog doesn't
>    say if these calipers are for the front or the rear.  Anyone out there
>    with any knowledge on this ?  Also - would MOST appreciate any advice
>    or tips on this setup.  (Thanks to Dave Darling, Too !!!!).

If you're talking about the kit on page 25 of AA's latest catalog (6 cars in the
gravel pit on the cover), then these calipers are for the front.  It's the front brakes
that do most of the work would benefit the most from an upgrade.

If you have in fact lost the cap and adjusting mechanism, you might see if you can
find a used one somewhere (AA or some other parts house).

Hope this helps,

Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L

Date: Mon, 29 May 95 09:18:59 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Mail order Purchase

> Hi,
> 
> I am in the market for a used or rebuild 944 transaxle. The price quotes
> varies from $600 ( with 80K miles) to $1500 (with 32k miles). I
> am interested in finding a method to determine, that the trans I 
> receive is the one that I paid for i.e. whether the transmission is
> from 944, S, S2 or a 951. 

The best method (short of tearing the thing apart) is to check the
transmission code (stamped on the top front of the transmission) and date
code. The service manuals and the specification books translate the codes
for you.

> 
> Second thing is the amount of miles the unit have. Do I just take
> their word on this or is there any thing I can do to confirm
> it.

You have to take their word for it.  It helps if you deal with a reputable
firm. I know of a couple... :-)

- --
Good luck,

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 11:50:23 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: attn: ummm.... whoever.

    Some p-phile called my house over the weekend, apperently in search
of my email address.  Well, having just moved in, the message promptly
got lost and I don't know who it was.  Sorry for taking so long to post

The vapors coming into your car a most likley from the rear hatch seal, 
check above the latch and I'll bet you find your hatch seal is split. 
This will cause fumes to enter the car.
Replacing the seal should fix the problem, the seals about $85 and not 
diffucult to install

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 13:04:38 -0400
From: Beverly514@aol.com
Subject: Re: #1(2) Porschephiles #1435 Mon May 29 02:00:06 CDT 1995

P-Philers,

In a message dated 95-05-29 03:19:03 EDT, someone  wrote:

>> After a few minutes of holding the steeing wheel of my 944 in
>> the same position, it becomes sticky to release my grip. 
[stuff deleted]
>> how should I do this, or should I apply something to the leather
>> to reduce the problem. The wheel feels great until it becomes 
>> sticky.
>> 
>How about washing it with soap and water. Perhaps a leather or saddle shop
>might have a detergent that is appropriate for leather...

I had this problem with my 911 some years ago. I had to resort to a rather
uncoventional product to reduce the stickiness. Dow Bathroom Cleaner. Uh Huh,
it cuts greasy films like you wuldn't believe. The stickiness could be from
built up "stuff" from your hands. Over time this builds up and depending on
the weather conditions in your area, becomes a sticky yucky film on your
steering wheel.

But before you have to resort to this, try a leather hide cleaner or food. I
have used this on my Jaguar (sorry, but yes I have one of "those") with
fantastic results. Your results will probably depend on the product but give
that a try. 

What ever you try -the Dow bathroom cleaner, soap & water, or any other
grease cutting product - MAKE SURE YOU TREAT THE LEATHER. I cannot stress
this enough. The leather is a natural product that needs to have upkeep. The
position of the steering wheel is such that it bakes in the sun more than you
do and will dry out. 

Good luck, try the Dow if the other sugesstions do not work. It worked on
mine and now I treat it with leather conditioner frequently.


Bev Frohm

70 911E 350,000 miles and going strong
74 914 2.0 - RoadRunner Racing Team (R3 - cubed)
'48 Hubby Lars
The Fur Balls - '86 Freckles and '89 Elmer

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 15:13:02 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Mail order Purchase

Asfar,

You said:

>Oh Yeah! If rebuilding a transaxle is as hard as they tell me, then
>why should I buy a rebuild unit.

A 944 transaxle is a bear to take apart and repair.  You MUST have a
hydraulic press to do it, and you need the factory manuals to tell you how.
 This constrasts with 901/914 gear boxes where you can literally rebuild them
with special tools such as an old clutch disk, a bent nail, and a rubber
mallet. I know, I've rebuilt both successfully.

Since the 944 transaxle is a modified Audi unit, you might be able to find a
mechanic familiar with them who could help you.

Jon Lowe

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 18:46:29 -0700
From: jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com (jim gregory)
Subject: Re:  951 Rear Brake Question


step one: jack car
step two: remove rear wheel
step three: squeeze retaining spring with a pair of channel locks
Step four: rotate retaining spring out of the way
step five: grab pad with channel locks and pull out
step six: press pistons back into caliper
step seven: slide in new pads
step eight: replace retaining spring clip
step nine: put wheel back on, lower jack
step ten: PUMP brake pedal before trying to drive car to reseat pistons
	 against pads

VEry simple, designed to be replaced during a pit stop.
All the work is in R&R of the wheel. Takes me about 5 minutes
per wheel when all tools are handy.

 -jim


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 18:55:13 -0700
From: jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com (jim gregory)
Subject: Re: 944 Ring & Pinions


Generally speaking, at every driver's school that I have participated
in for the last nine years has grouped students according to
experience and proven capability. *NEVER* by car.

BTW, there are some *BRAND NEW* Porsche *FACTORY REBUILT* transaxles
available for 944's. Contact Jon Diederle at Johnston Motorsport
(610) 436-8575. Seems that when Porsche had to go thru certication
and testing for various government compliances, that they could
not sell the cars as new (since motors and transaxles were used). The
cars then got new motors and transaxles. The removed transaxles were
rebuilt by Porsche. Apparently some wholesaler bought up all of these
transaxles (were about 40 of them they were saying). Cost is
slightly more than a rebuild but would be the way to go. Certainly
worth paying a little bit more for, IMHO.

jim-

87 944t

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 19:12:42 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: 951 Stuck On Hot

I've read several posts on this with interest because recently my 951 began
to sometimes pump out hot air at start-up in warm temperatures even though
climate control was set to have it on air conditioning. Other times it
would behave correctly.

I had my genius son, the mechanic, look at it today. He found the problem
in less than one minute. Of course he knew what he was looking for which
was a tiny broken piece of white plastic and a brass clip laying on the the
driver's-side floor mat which fell from underneath the dash. He says this
is a common problem with 944s. The pieces formerly attached to a now
free-hanging rod which hooked to a motor which inturn would open and close
a hot-cold duct door.

The replacement white plastic piece will cost about 85 cents, and when he
brings it over will take about 5 minutes to install. The brass clip will be
re-used.

It sure pays to have kids.

Larry Wilson

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 22:29:50 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: re: 911 engine control units (fwd)



Someone asked about the blue (sometimes black) switch on the back of a 
European 911 control unit.  This is an eight position switch which gives 
the control unit some small range of adjustment to timing and fuel.  
Typically on 911's the fully counterclockwise position is the standard 
baseline position. The next click clockwise adds a small amount to the 
pulsewidth, maybe a few percent.  I don't remember which is which on the 
next two; one takes out a little fuel, one adds more fuel. 

Position five (four "clicks" from fully counterclockwise, return fuel to 
the baseline, but takes out about 2 degrees of ignition timing. It varied 
from chip to chip, but was usually only kicked in over 1500. the final 
three positions duplicated the fuel changes of the first, but included 
the retarded timing.

The box the person asked about was a 911.618.111.09.  I don't remember 
this being the correct number for an '84 Euro 911; these came with .00 
DME units.

Another item to look for is the "country code" jumper in the wiring 
harness going to the DME.  Each chip had several sets of maps, and these 
jumpers told the DME which set to look at.  There are three choices: 
open, no jumper, a shorted jumper, or one with a resistor. 

Hope this is of some help.

Larry Bershtein


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 22:55:54 -0400
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: Factory tour (longish)


Hi, 'philes,

   I got to tour the Factory in Stuttgart last week!  Very interesting. I
realize this has been covered before (and even recently) so I will *try* to
keep it brief.

   Those of us touring gathered in the Porsche Museum.  I didn't have a 
lot of time to look things over, but there were a lot of nice examples of
904's, 908's and 917's.  In fact, over half the space was devoted to various 
race cars, with balance going to "special" road cars.  One of the 914/8's was 
there, a '73 Carrera RS, the 550 Spyder from the 1954 Carrera Panamericana, 
a 1951 356 Aluminum racing coupe, the "Studie" for the next 911, etc.  Perhaps 
my favorite (okay, besides the 550!) was the 993 C4 drivetrain that you could
get up-close-and-personal with.  It was interesting to see the multilink 
suspension laid bare.  There was a group of German high school kids touring
the works, too, and I had to laugh when one of the pubescent girls swooned
at the picture above the 550: "Das ist JAMES DEAN!!!"

  The "unwashed" (those of us who were NOT picking up our new 993's) then went 
upstairs to join up with those who were, and from there to the main assembly
plant.  I was amazed at how much they let us get in the way of things!!  We
were poking about right at the assembly line.  Our guide told us that Porsche
had brought consultants in from an unnamed Japanese auto firm to streamline
the process.  Things have apparently changed almost yearly as a result.  One
major departure was the creation of a rack for each car, that holds all the
necessary parts, and moves along with the engine being assembled; it bears a
flag of the destination country, mostly stars-and-bars and German flags.  The
guide said the third largest destination was Japan.  Another change was the
tactic of requiring employees come up with suggestions for improvements.  Each
employee must contribute 6 suggestions this year, and next year the ante is
raised to 12 suggestions.  For each implemented suggestion, the employee gets
DM100, plus is eligible for a drawing worth DM28,000!  The bean counters say
that this program has saved the company DM 4M, and they have paid back DM 1.3M
to the employees. Production times are down from about 124 hrs/car to about 
82 hrs/car.  There were all kinds of inspirational-type signs hanging up
about improving quaility, which, between my SO and the guide, got translated 
into rather Orwellian-sounding messages urging employees to improve.  Perhaps 
it sounds better in the mutter tongue.

   For some reason, they bragged (?) to the German kids about how much of their 
parts came from outside suppliers, but not to us! Nevertheless, it was 
really neat to see large BINS of various expensive parts shuttling around.  
Most were easy to spot: con rods, cranks, spark plugs by the gross, twin 
ignitions, cams by the bushel, fans.  The large box marked "kolben (sp?) 
and zylinders" gave me some insight as to the origin of the name of 
Kolbenschmidt (sp?).  I was stumped for a moment, however, as a trolley 
of something that looked like squirrel-cage fan blowers came by: large 
hollow disks, maybe 12" diameter, couple of inches thick, with vanes 
around the circumference.  "I dunno, honey, maybe they are some sort of 
fan... Holy Sh*t, they are BRAKE ROTORS!!!"  Turbo and Carrera RS brakes 
are huge!  

   The old-model wasserpumpers are assembled by hand in a separate area.  
They are down to 2 to 3 928's per day, and one to 2 968's.  I knew the 
end was near, but I was surprised to learn that no new 968 parts are being 
made/ordered.  Cars for pending orders were being assembled from existing 
parts stocks.

  Unfortunately, the dyno room was off-limits due to testing of the Boxster
engine!!  (They are getting serious!)  As has been discussed here before, 
each engine is dynoed to be within 2% of the quoted HP; about 3% of the engines
fail and must be reworked.

  Final assembly, mating the drivetrain and body, was a neat sight.  Time after
mesmerizing time, a gorgeous, naked drivetrain was raised up into an empty
body shell, and a 993 resulted.  It looked too easy and organic.

   We happened across a pile of thick, square radiators, each being mated to a 
cooling fan.  Puzzled, I ventured to guess that they were for the air 
conditioning??  No, the guide pointed to the internal part number -- these 
were for the Boxster!!  He went on to tell us that, although the body shape
has not been finalized, 5,000 blind orders have been placed from the US alone.
At an employee bulletin board, near the Bavarian workers on break drinking beer,
someone had tacked up a picture of the Revell model of the Boxster, along 
with some Auto Motor und Sport artist's renderings.  The guide seemed 
optimistic, but worried about the competeition from BMW and MB.
 
   About this time, the four couples on the tour together began to open up.
One of the two lucky ones (buying 993's) told me the last 911 he owned was
a '72 -- since then they had "never changed."  But he had owned about 40 
356's through the years!  The 993 reminded him of the 356 => instant sale.
He asked what color I bought, saying I must be young and successful.  Had to 
admit that I was neither that young nor that successful!!  After I asked, 
he said he would have bought a Turbo, but they will not accept orders for
Tourist Delivery for 6 months, and he didn't want to wait.  Might trade in
on one later.  Must be nice... 

   The paint shop is now off-limits, due to the amount of dirt tracked in
by customers.  I guess we customers have been responsible for that orange 
peel all these years? <g>  Seriously, I didn't look too carefully, but I 
don't think they have orange peel problems anymore.

   We went to the upholstery shop (yawn).  It turns out that there is the 
equivalent of 6 cows in your average 993 leather interior! We were told 
that the arm rests took 4 hours apiece for a master upholsterer to cover 
in leather!!  I can't say that I think that is justified, but they did 
look nice.  We passed a pile of Targa tops being covered.  One of the 
993 owners-to-be asked "What are those?"  I answered "Targa tops, of 
course" (I have a Targa.)  He said "I know, but they don't MAKE them 
anymore."  Oh, right.  The guide asked the guy assembling them, and, 
of course, they were old ones being recovered.  Damn tempting to try 
and steal a Targa skin from the 2-foot-thick pile!  

   Perhaps the most amazing thing was seeing all these beasts zipping about 
the grounds getting tested.  "Oh, look, a yellow C4 cabriolet.  Wow, a Turbo.
Hey, there goes either a GTS or a Carrera RS!!  There is one of those 315 HP
Audi wagons.  Oh, darn, that one is 'only' a new C2...."  One gets easily 
jaded!  I frantically took a picture of a GTS, only to find out it was "only"
a Carrera RS.

   Weissach is off limits.  Apparently, one of a group of Swedish tourists took
a photo of a Volvo under development there, and sold it to the press.  Volvo
was not pleased.

   All in all, it was very titillating.  Call Karen Evans at PCNA at 
702-348-3244 for arrangements (before they shut down for Boxster retooling).  
Pete Albrecht's new what-to-do-in-germany.FAQ was very useful (thanks Pete),
check it out.  (Tried the choucroute -- it was decadent!)

Paul Lyman    lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov
'82 911SC Targa (and new, grand ambitions!)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 23:06:32 -0500
From: sarsfld@tiac.net (Steve Sarsfield)
Subject: 944 Puzzler

This is a little mystery I encountered this weekend.  My mild-mannered, yet
very well qualified mechanic is on the job and should have a solution soon.
 But I though I might pose this mystery to all.

Driving home this Friday night, my 1983 944 suddenly began bucking.  With
seemingly no regular pattern, the car would feel like you were slamming on
the brakes for a split second, then jammimg on the gas peddle - two or two
times a second.  No backfire occurred,  but just a random series of quick
surges (and anti-surges).

I pulled over, and left the car running as I decided to peek under the
hood.  The car idled perfectly, but a new "groan" was coming from the rear
underside of the 944.  Since the car was idling, and not in gear, I
suspected that the groan may be coming from the fuel pump, but it was
uncertain.

Although tough to drive, I managed to continue on my journey by keeping the
RPM low.  The car seemed to surge less when the RPM was low.

I parked the car at my destination and came back later to start 'er up. 
The car would barely start would barely run.  After a few minutes of smoke,
the car ran smoothly again.  Next, under the advice of my mechanic, I
removed the throttle control valve sensor.  It's apparently common for this
sensor to go bad and cut out the gas supply to the engine at about 3000
rpm.  Removing it temporarily makes the engine rev higher, but should solve
the problem if you have a bad sensor.  This had almost no effect on the
surging, however.

Finally, a quick wipe in the tailpipe indicated that the engine was running
rich.

The current hypothesis is:

A) Bad fuel pump (ouch!)
B) Fuel line blockage
C) Throttle control valve sensor
D) Other

Steve Sarsfield
1983 - 944  Metallic Gray
sarsfld@tiac.net

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 95 21:40:43 -0700
From: mike_s@encoreengineering.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: The 928

>Have been offered the opportunity to buy a 1985 928 (55k miles). Most I speak
>with say these have little resale value, not built well, etc. This had major
>electronic work done under the hood in 1992 because of an encounter with a
>major water puddle during an LA storm. Repaired w/o incident, looks great and
>would satisfy a long felt carnal desire. Owner asking $14k. Any thoughts on
>the matter? I have also looked at a 1988 911 in great condition for $26k.
>Dave Sne
>

Little resale value--True.  The one you are considering is priced about
right, although you might get them to knock off 1k to 1.5k.

Not built well--Not true at all.  They are built like a tank, have many
features that were state of the art at the time, and feel fantastic.

I would have an experienced mechanic look at this one.  The water damage
is something to worry about.  928's can start to have wiring trouble at
about 10 to 15 years, and water damage can only accelerate the process.

One word of warning.  I think the low resale value may have a lot to do
with the high cost of repair and maintenance.

Do not consider this car an investment.  Buy it only if you enjoy it,
and plan on keeping it for a while.  I personally love mine, and would
never sell it.  However, if it turned out after a year or two that I
didn't like it, I would have no hope of recuperating the money spent
on repairs and maintenance.

Drive it, go home and think about it, then drive it again.  Then, if
you love it, have a mechanic look at it.  Then buy it.


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 21:50:21 -0700 (MST)
From: Scott D Ellingsen <sde@GAS.UUG.Arizona.EDU>
Subject: Re: Defense of 911



On Mon, 29 May 1995, H. Wilson Busby wrote:

> it- anybody got any good comebacks for my 911's defense?

First of all, I just bought a 1987 944 Turbo about a month ago.  It's 
dark blue with a beige interior...it's an absolutely gorgeous car.

It's my very first Porsche...and certainly not my last!  I've already 
told the wife that we WILL have a 911 (or hybrid) some day.

Corvette?  I saw two dead on the side of the road between Phoenix and 
Tucson last week.  Toyota Supra?  Well, that spoiler looks stupid and 
the car is over-priced when all things are considered...$52,000 ?...I'm 
sorry, but I'm not about to pay that much for a Toyota. 

Somebody else mentioned Mustangs, but those cars have such an up-and-down 
history that it's a crap shoot from one year to the next.  Frankly, my 
wife's '94 Corolla handles MUCH better than the Mustang one 
'intellectually challenged' salesperson attempted to dump on us.

Your car needs no defense...it's a Porsche, and everybody who puts it 
down probably wishes they could drive it. 

 ;)


Scott


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 22:17:18 -0700 (MDT)
From: Wade Guthrie <wade@realm2.realm.net>
Subject: Paradise Lost

I had found the one.  It had been fifteen months (!) of pouring through
the Porsche Market Letter, Hemmings, Pano, the Autotrader, various
newspapers, and scads of other documentation.  Then, finally, the
elusive 1973 911S Targa appeared -- waiting for me in Jackson Wyoming.

I knew what I wanted.  If the finger of God had seen fit to produce for
me the perfect Porsche, it would have been a straight, all-original
(including the MFI everyone keeps swapping-out for webers) '73S Targa
with AC and sport seats.  Who was I to quibble over venue?

Since I'd been searching for so long, I had assembled all the correct
questions from all the right books (hey, I even built a FAQ from what
I'd learned).  My fingers fumbled for the buttons on the phone.  The
owner told me that the car had receipts, a recent (in mileage, if not
months) overhaul, Carrera tensioners, the works.  I was ready for the
next step so I asked for Xeroxed receipts, photos, and a videotape.

The package took three torturous days to come but when it did, it was
all there.  And it was all tremendous!  My co-workers, including
several bona-fide car buffs, extended their premature congratulations
based upon the marvel they saw in the photos.  The video covered all
the areas that I had asked; I ran and re-ran it looking for the
slightest imperfection.  Time for stage three: the mechanic.

Finding a wrench prooved to be an arduous process.  Phoning a local
dealer netted me the unpleasant information that no Porsche dealers
existed in the entire state of Wyoming.  Probing the net yielded the
name of the head of the local PCA region with whom I *still* haven't
been able to communicate.  My local mechanic told me that he had
contacts in nearly every state in the Union. . .except Wyoming.  The
only possible name was given to me by the owner of the car itself.  But
that was okay, I guess, since PCNA told me that he had been trained at
Porsche and his previous employer (Porsche a dealer) told me that he
was a good mechanic.

So I gave the guy my list of questions.  You know, the standard stuff:
what's the compression, is there any structural rust, do the numbers
match, that sort of thing.  He was going to go over the car pretty
well, he was to devote four hours to the car.

The chit came back with the usual laundry list of problems.  There were
assorted oil leaks, parts that needed rework, a sway bar needed some
refitting, and a few other things of a similar nature.  The compression
was a bit low but, more importantly, it was even across all the
cylindars.  Finally, pre-eminently, there was no structural rust.  I
asked a second time and got the same glorious answer: the only rust was
found on three small spots on the surface skin of the car.

Again, I dialed the phone.  I wanted the car, only I needed the
following list of things fixed (blah blah blah, yadda yadda yadda).
The owner agreed and, actually, included a couple of things for which I
had not asked.  Everything was going well.  I was experiencing a few
disappointments, but none with which I couldn't cope.

I was actually going to get my car.  My wife made plane, rental car,
and hotel reservations.  It was Memorial Day weekend and I made
arrangements to get an extra day off.  I was taking my family and a
cashier's check (only one of which I planned to hand-over to the car's
current owner) to the great state of Wyoming.

So, let's fast-forward a little.  There was a plane trip through San
Francisco to Salt Lake City.  The rental car took us six hours up to
our wonderful hotel in Alpine Wyoming.  A new day and a short drive to
Jackson to meet the wonderful man who owns the car that Wade buys.  The
owner and my family caravan to the mechanic's shop where the car is
waiting, beckoning, to me.

I explain that I'm just going to give the car a once-over.  Check it
out to make sure I'm not making a mistake.  I whip-out my tiny
flashlight and a pocket knife and walk to the driver's side door.  I
drop to the floor to start the examination from the ground-up.  And
there it is, staring me right in the face.  A thousand miles and
countless phone calls only to see ribbons of rust running over the
rocker panel accompanied by two giant cracks on either side of the jack
point.

It's Saturday; there's no way I can check to see what fixing this would
cost, though, I *knew* it would be expensive.  Besides, the mechanic
had just told me that there was NO STRUCTURAL RUST.  Everything else he
said must also be suspect.

Devastated, I retreat with my family from the scene.  Still searching
for that perfect, all-original 2.4 911S Targa.

- -- 
Wade Guthrie               | "If you fold 'em, they fire ya, so I just throw 
wade@realm.net             |  'em away"            from 'The Hudsucker Proxy'
http://www.realm.net/~wade |

------------------------------

From: Trond Vidar Olsen <Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no>
Subject: Chain Tensioners.

Since I am about to become 911 owner, I'm starting to get the
'hydraulic-tensioner-failure-fobia'. This is a decease that primarily
hit pre -84 non-pressure-fed 911 owners I understand.

This will of course not happen!! We want to be at least a couple of
steps ahead of total failure,..want we?

I have seen and read about various solutions for the 2.0 litre
engines. I understand that these are impossible to update with the
pressure feed system, and wonder wether HP tensioners (non
collapsible), or these small 'tensioner-clamps' (go around the
'piston' to avoid total collapse) will be better than mechanichal
tensioners?

Another question is where to find K&N air filters for the Zenith (Solex?)
carburatored 2.0 litres?

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 08:31:47 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: 911 Electrical  new alternator questions.



Hello once more, 911 elctrical questions continue...

Thanks to all who responded about my 1981 911SC electrical problems.
I ordered and put in a new alternator this Mem. Day weekend.  A few
qeustions remain.

First, before I reconnect the battery cables and try to start the
car, can someone please read the following few paragraphs and make
sure I wired the new alternator correctly.  Thanks a million.

My old original alternator had 5 connectoins coming off of the back
of it.  The new alternator only has bolts stemming from it for 
connecting 3 sets of wires.  

The old one had 2 brown wires coming from a B+ terminal, one small blue wire
coming from a terminal labeled 61, one big red wire from D- terminal,
3 red wires from another D- terminal, and a small black wire going
to a slot type connector at the bottom of the old alternator.

The new alternator only has a B+ terminal, a D- terminal, and a terminal
labeled 61.  I took the 2 browns from the old B+ and connected them to the 
B+ terminal of the new alternator.  Then I took the small blue wire and
connected it to the new 61 terminal.  Next, I took the BIG red wire AND
the 3 smaller (but all connected) brown wires, and put all 4 on the new
terminal labeld D-.  Thus I have wires on all 3 new terminals.  I am
assuming this is correct.  Is it ok to pair the big red wire with the
3 brown wires?  THIS IS MY KEY QESTION.  Are the two terminals labeled
D- from the old alternator the same so that I can pair the 3 smaller red
wires and the big red wire all onto the same terminal?  Why did the old
alternator have 2 seperate terminals, both labeld D-, one for the big red,
and the other for the 3 wires together???  Before I reconnect the battery,
Is this ok to do what I have done, the pairing of the D- wires?

The new alternator does have another bolt on the back, but it is screwed
all the way in, and is a screw, not really a terminal bolt.  It is on the
same metal back plate as the B+ terminal bolt, and is not labeld in any
way.  Is this used for something?  The reason I am a little confused is
that someone sent me email saying that the new alternator would have
a place for all the wires except the small black volt. reg. wire.  Well
this is true ONLY if I pair up the wire from the old D- terminals onto
the new single D- terminal.  Is this what he meant?

Also, I taped up the small black wire, as I was told this goes to the 
voltage reg., and the new alternator has a volt. reg. built in.  I then
unpluged the 3 prong plug from underneath the old voltage regultor which
is mounted to the left rear sidewall of the engine compartment.  I could
not find out how to get the old regulator out of the car, so I left it
mounted, but unplugged.

Also, as a side issue, the shaft of the new alternator was about .5mm
larger in diameter than the old alternator.  Thus the thick washer that
holds the fan belt pulley in place would not slide over this new alternator
shaft.  This really pissed me off, I spent 1/2 hours with a small drill
bit in a drill filling the indie hole to make it larger so it would fit
on the new shaft.

I have another issue related to the muffler connecting pipe installation
which I will put in another message.  Thanks again.

 -Barry Chapin	chapin@draper.com	617-258-2809
1981 Euro-911SC Targa.
