Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 09:45:45 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: 911 crossover muffler pipe installation.


Hi again, 

Not only do I have electrical problems, I have a muffler pipe
installation problem as well.  I love old cars.

I am replacing my crossover pipe on my 1981 Euro-911SC, mine rusted. The
crossover pipe is an exhaust system pipe which runs from the right
hand side heat exchanger, across the under side of the car (parrallel
to the axles), over the other heat exchanger, and connects to 
the muffler part that runs to the rear of the car.  This crossover
pipe has a 3-bolt flange on each end and has a slight S-type curvature
to it.  It goes under the motor bell housing, and curves up to run over
the top of the left heat exchanger, where it then connects to the
part of the muffler that runs to the rear of the car (is this rear
running fat pipe the cat. converter?).  When installed, it runs neatly
in between the motor/transmission/engineblock/bell housing (whatever) and
the left heat exchanger.  The original (1981) version is actually two
pipes, which connect via a clamp above the left hand heat exchanger.
Thus each original side, has its corresponding 3-bolt flange, and a
stub of pipe at the other end.  When joined with the clamp, one piece
fits inside the other.  

I ordered a used one from PartsHeaven.  Nice shape, not corrosion or
rust.  But it is a new style of crossover pipe.  Instead of two seperate
interconnecting pipes, is is one contiguous pipe.  The end which connects
above the left heat exchanger has accordian like folds in the pipe to
allow for some adjustment when attaching it.  My problem is that since
it is all one piece, with large flanges on either end, I cannot fit either
end of this new pipe through the opening or space that this pipe runs. This
space I need to run this pipe through is the space which exists between the
heat exchanger and the bell housing.   The flange one each end makes it
too big to fit through the gap which would accomodate just the pipe
alone.  (Does anyone have a clue as to what I am writing about now, or am
I just babbaling? :-))  This is my problem.

Well you may say, just remove the left heat exchanger, then install the
pipe, and put the heat exchanger back on.  Well this is easier said than
done.  I attempted this, but the bolts connecting the heat exchanger to
the cylinder head exhaust ports are very frozen and corroded.  I sprayed
WD-40 on them, and waited a few hours, then attempted to loosen the nuts.
They would not move.  Then I heated them somewhat with a torch, and tried
again on only the nuts (using a rachet and universal joint to allow a bend 
around the edge of the heat exchanger).  Well this was a BIG mistake and
I ended up snapping off one nut along with its bolt head which attached
to the cylinder head.  Ouch!  After this little incident I said F--- this.
I did not even get to the problem of how to lossen the hex head bolts on
the other side of these 3 exhaust flanges (I guess there is a special 
tool that you buy, that goes up through the holes on the under side of
the heat exchnager, and fits into the hex head bolts.)  

A few questions:
1.  How bad is it to leave the snapped off exhaust port cylinder head bolt 
in place, and hope that the exhaust gasket from the cylider head remains in 
place?  Only the hex head bolt remains holding this tube in place below the
head.  Is head replacement now eminent, or can this be retapped in place?

2. Next, Someone told me that heating the nuts will make them come off
easily.  I tried this.  But how much do you heat them?  I left my propane
torch on them for about 10-15 seconds.  Do I have to get stuck bolts red
hot before they come loose, or should it only take heating just somewhat?
Is it bad to heat these to a red hot condition - this probably would take
a minute or two from the torch - would the heat from the torch going up
through the heat fins on the cylinder head effect other engine parts in
a bad way?  Heating the nut expands it (I was a Physics major), so you
would think it would be bigger than the bolt and thus looser.  But would'nt
the bolt heat almost the same amount and exapnd as well, thus keeping the
force to release the nut about the same?

3. Finally, how do you get the damn crossover pipe installed?  I think I
may have to resort to cutting it in half with a hacksaw, installing each 
end, and then joining the cut pieces with some sort of clamp (I prefer this
over snapping all the heat exchanger cylinder head bolts.)  Should I
attach the cut pieces of this new crossover pipe, and take the car to a
welding shop and have them weld the pipe together, or would a clamp
work as well?  I am thinking of buying a short 2 inch extension pipe
from a local lauto parts store.  The kind of pipe segment which is fater
on one end, and tapers to a thinner diameter on the opther end.  This
could join the two ends of cut crossover pipe, and a few muffler clamps 
wold keep them secure.  Am I the only person in the world with these
problems?

 -Barry Chapin	chapin@draper.com	617-258-2809
1981 Euro 911SC Targa.


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 30 May 95 08:50:51 cst
From: "emontgo" <emontgo@cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: 944 Production Run

     
     Hello All,
     
     I have heard recently from Stan in a thread a day or two ago that only 
     approx.. 200,000 911s have been produced. I also read in European Car 
     that the total is just over 350,000, and they had a break down of 
     exactly how many cars of each discipline were produced on every year. 
     17,000 being the most for any one year. If I remember correctly, that 
     was one of the years some where between '72-'76. By the way they are 
     trying to break that record with a production run of over 20,000 with 
     the 993 in FY96. That's why you now see a barrage of 993 ad's and 
     commercials. The thing is all you find are stats on the 911. 
     
     My question is what are the runs for the 944. Does anyone here know?
     I realize it would be tough to figure since they used the Audi 
     physicality during heavy production. But maybe someone has found the 
     stats in a magazine or book out there.
     
     If someone has a quality ballpark figure, I would like to know.
     Thanks in advance.
     
     Ed Montgomery
     '86 944 Alpine White

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 09:14:08 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Chain Tensioners.

> I have seen and read about various solutions for the 2.0 litre
> engines. I understand that these are impossible to update with the
> pressure feed system, and wonder wether HP tensioners (non
> collapsible), or these small 'tensioner-clamps' (go around the
> 'piston' to avoid total collapse) will be better than mechanichal
> tensioners?

Anything -- *ANYTHING* -- (including mice with toothpicks, or small
rubber bands, or whatever) is better than the purely mechanical
tensioners you see advertised. They are *ONLY* useful in racing applications
where (1) the engine comes apart every few hours and (2) the range of
operating temperatures is very, very narrow (i.e. no stop-and-go).

I have no knowlege of the HP tensioners (something I suppose I should
correct) but the tensioner clamps are usually a very adequate solution.

Stan

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 09:52:55 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)

Why were you trying to do that? I usually just take the CVs off from the
back, and don't screw with that nut unless trying to replace/repack the
wheel bearings... And, BTW, the real answer is an Ingersol-Rand double
hammer high impact air wrench...

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 10:51:11 -0500 (CDT)

Subject: Re: 993 Turbo Rims

> are joined using a "new patented friction welding technique".  
> Friction welding of components like this is nothing new.  What
> is Porsche doing that warrants modifiers like "new" and "patented"?

According to the March, 1995 Christophorus:

"The spider [center section] is produced in hollow star shape by
this new Porsche, low-pressure casting technology, ..."

"Friction welding as a principle is no novelty in the automobile
industry but it had never been used before in the realm of
production wheel manufacture."

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 09:24:46 -0400 (EDT)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: Blau Reno Questions

The ARI button used to be used for the reception of ARI-encoded traffic 
information, which Blaupunkt tried to get stations to use. It was 
supposed to interrupt your cassette--or your radio--listening to inform 
you of traffic news. It didn't become too popular. Zone just tells ARI 
where it is, and what stations to receive info from. 

I just ripped my Reno outta my 951 and installed a Blaupunkt Ventura 
CD--it's ten times the radio. Get it, don't waste $ on an amp when you've 
got a crappy Reno.


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 11:22:44 -0500
From: "Richard Hocking" <hocking@cig.mot.com>
Subject: Leaky S-Hose

After spending the (memorial day) weekend claining up the engine I
noted a minor crack in the S-hose (between (oil tank and cooler).
So I figured nect oil change, I will change the hose.

Of course I come out to the car Monday morning and there is a nicely
sized puddle of oil (about .25 of a pint) right there under the cracked
hose.

So I better get it fixed ASAP.  I call all the local dealers and none of them
have the hose in stock - s**t !

The car is still leaking and I am wondering what people think about :-

1.  Just driving as is and topping up the oil (for a few days 'til I can get
a hose).

Or,

2.  Wrapping a goodly amount of tape around the hose and driving as little
as possible for a few days.

Or should I take no chances and not drive the car at all until I can get
the hose and get the car fixed ?  Some opinions please.  I no this could
be catastrophic if it bursts while I am driving (hopefully these hoses
don't burst, but I don't really want to rely on luck !).

Thanks for any quick responses.

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 12:06:10 -0500

>I have seen and read about various solutions for the 2.0 litre
>engines. I understand that these are impossible to update with the
>pressure feed system, and wonder wether HP tensioners (non
>collapsible), or these small 'tensioner-clamps' (go around the

 I went with 930 tensioners on my 2.0 and used the "tensioner-clamps"
for saftey. I have read that the arm was the weak part in that setup.
If you go with the newer style tensioners you need spacers. If you update 
the arm the spacers are unnecessary. 

  Will someone explain about the diffrence in using  solid tensioners verses
what is used on street cars?

240 is too hot) during the summer months.  This happens when I am in slow
traffic or if I am "cruising" about 3.6 K to 5.0 K revs through the hills.

FACTORY MOD rumor

I understand that Porsche offers a kit that includes a larger crank pulley,
longer fan belt and different rear engine mounts (so pulley will clear sheet
metal).  I am told this mod will increase fan rpm by about 30%

The engine (top & bottom) is clean.... R&R'd alternator to clean top of case and
polish fan.  Oil tank is clean (at least outside)
Outside of Oil cooler has been routinly cleaned with carb cleaner of simple
green.
Car is in tune, spark and a/f mix

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 11:33:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: banders@netcom.com (Brad Anders)
Subject: 914: GA-Series '73 2.0L CO Level

One more question about my 914's '73 2.0L engine...

My mechanic told me that the CO needs to be quite high to achieve good
idle and running performance. The Porsche workshp manual says to set the 
idle CO to 1.5%, but my engine is currently set to about 4.5%. Idling is
good (see my eariler message), performance is smooth to redline and the
engine runs quite cool (as you might expect). Note that the car has 
European pistons and slightly milled heads (I think my mechanic said the 
compression test he did showed a consistant 150 psi on all cylinders). 

Is this similar to other 914 2.0L owner's experiences? Are there owners
out there who are able to run at 1.5% CO without problems?

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 11:21:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: banders@netcom.com (Brad Anders)
Subject: 914: Clutch, Shifting, and Idling Help Needed


This is my first message to the list, please bear with me and steer me
to some sources of information.

I have a 1970 914 with a '73 GA-series 2.0 L engine, and a '73 side-shifter
transmission. The engine is a recent rebuild, with about 30K miles on it. 
The engine has European pistons, slightly milled heads, and a high-output
oil pump. The clutch pressure plate is stock, but the car has a lightened
flywheel.

Here are my questions/problems:

What can I do to get the best clutch operation? I'm looking for suggestions
all the way from the pedal back to the clutch assembly. What is the best
cable? What is the best pressure plate available? Are there any tricks I
can do with the pulley to get better action? Can someone give me a suggestion
on the best way to adjust the free play? I know it will probably never be 
like the clutch on my G20, but some improvement would be great.

What can I do to get the best shift operation? Again, I'm looking for full-
system suggestions. The car has been converted over to the side shifter, 
and has the stock shift lever and mount. Are the short-shift kits worth it?
BTW, the tranny was rebuilt about 40-50K miles ago, and seems to be in 
fine condition. 

I recently found a <great> mechanic who was able to go through my engine and
work wonders with regard to idle stability and smoothness. We both believe
that the lightened flywheel has got to go at the next clutch job, as it is
probably the cause of some of the idle roughness and instability. I still have
one problem remaining that I'd like some suggestions on. The idle drops about
300-350 rpm when I turn on the headlights (H4 halogen lamps, 100W I think). 
Are there any suggestions on how to decrease this idle drop? 

One more thing my mechanic suggested was to remove the ballast resistor
that is in series with the head temperature sensor to improve my cold start
performance. He believes that the mixture is too rich for the first 15-20 
seconds and removing the resistor may help. Also, he has suggested that I
replace the auxillary air regulator, as he thinks it is not fully open when
cold (it does pass some air by). Any comments on these suggestions?

Again, thanks for any help here.... 

- -- 
*******************************
* Brad Anders / Sunnyvale, CA *
*     banders@netcom.com      *
*******************************

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 14:45:13 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Autocross information - part4

Hi,

I have been asked to submit my columns on autocrossing Porsches
to the archives. Here is the fourth of nine (?) columns. Please let
me know if there are any mistakes or omissions, or other questions
that I should answer. I am editing and submitting them one at a time,
and will upload the whole thing after final editing.

There have been several requests for permission to use this material
in PCA newsletters, etc. Please ask before using it, but basically
any PCA use will be granted if the author is noted. If not too
difficult, I would like a copy of the publication with my material.

"Three Wheeling" by Mike Piera #4 of 9

This chapter will finally cover the water-cooled Porsches.
I do not have as much first-hand knowledge in these cars
as the 911's and 914's, so this information has been
combined from several different sources.

   In 1976 the 924 was offered as an entry level Porsche.
It used many off-the-shelf VW and Audi parts to keep the
price down : Rabbit A-arms, Beetle rear suspension, Audi engine
and 4-speed transmission, etc. This compromised the performance.
In '79 a 5-Speed Porsche transmission was available, but the
'80 and later 5-Speed with normal shift pattern is the best. The
original 924S model (not to be confused with the late '80s 944-
engined 924S) was introduced about 1980, and could be ordered with
4-wheel disk brakes, 15" alloy wheels, and a rear spoiler. This
"Sport Package" made it much like a 924 turbo. Also a limited slip
differential was available, which is needed for serious autocrossing
on all water-cooled Porsches. Without a LSD, much time will be lost
exiting corners with the inside-rear wheel spinning. These '80-'82
924s are the best years for autocrossing, and run in the same class
as the earlier 924 in both PCA and SCCA. In SCCA they are classed
in E-Stock against the 912, 356, and small medium-powered front
wheel drive cars such as the Neon sedan, Saturn, VW GTI, Integra,
etc. A 924 with the right options could have fun in this class.

    The 924 Turbo was a method of giving some much-needed power
to the 924. Although not a bad car, I recommend staying away from this
model for autocrossing. Maintenance costs are very high (Turbo, exhaust,
etc) and autocross potential is only fair. In PCA classes it should be
beaten by a 944 or 944-engined 924S, and in SCCA it is in DS against
some very quick little cars like the Neon ACR and Honda CRX-Si.

   In '83 the introduction of the 944 signalled the end of the
original 924 line in America. The 944 was a big improvement to the 924
platform. The 944 had a true Porsche designed 2.5 liter engine rather
than the VW/Audi/AMC engine of the 924. These had about the same
performance as the 924 Turbo without the turbo lag or other turbo
drawbacks. The handling and steering were highly praised at the time,
and power and torque were adequate. They have never been extremely
competitive in SCCA autocrossing, maybe due to being in tough classes.
The running changes over the years generally improved performance.
As I mentioned above, a limited slip differential is mandatory. Try
to find a car that already has one, otherwise it is very expensive
to add. The 'mid-85 and newer 944 is considered better than the early
ones, with the same 150 HP engine until about '86. The '87-'88 engine
was a little stronger (160 HP), and the final engine in '89 was slightly
larger (2.7 liters). Anti-Lock brakes (ABS) were available since '87, and
standard in '89. In PCA the '83 to '88 944 models are classed together, 
with the '89 running against the 944S. The '88 would seem the best bet, 
and could be ordered with an M030 sport package which deleted accessories
and added better suspension. But the earlier models with 15" x 7" rims
have an advantage in gearing by using 50 series tires (225/50/15).

   In SCCA, all 8-valve 944 models ('83-'89) run in C-Stock against the
914-4 2.0 and various Mazdas. The '88 or '89 is probably best for
SCCA also. Remember that in SCCA you can use any options that were
available from the factory for that year and model, while in PCA you
must check the rules for option points. I should also cover the '87-'88
924S here, which is basically a 944 with the pre-85 interior and 924
non-flared body (with narrower 6" wheels). This could be an autocross
"sleeper", since it has the same performance as a 944 but is lighter.
In '88 a special "M030" option package was available with no options
(wind-up windows, etc), wider 7x15" rear wheels and stiffer adjustable
suspension. In PCA the 924S should beat the 924 Turbo. In SCCA, the
924S has been quite competitive in C-Stock against the 944, 914-2.0
and non-turbo Mazdas.

    The 16-valve 944S was available starting in '87, at 188 HP. It
had Anti-Lock brakes, and could be ordered with the Sport Package.
In '89 it also got a bigger 2.7 engine. These are competitive in PCA,
where the only other car is the '89 944. But in SCCA they are in
B-Stock against the faster 944 S2, and 944 Turbo. The 944 S2 was
available from '89 to '91, with a huge 3.0 liter, 208 HP version of
the 944 4-cylinder engine. The S2 is very well suited to autocrossing,
with a wonderful engine which is stronger than the Turbo at the low
end (coming out of slow turns). The S2 competes in PCA against the 968
and late model 944 Turbos. The 968 is the latest and greatest version
of the original 924 platform. The 3.0 liter engine was tweeked
to 236 HP, and new bodywork was featured. All of the improvements
in performance, safety, and comfort over the years have added hundreds
of pounds to the 924/944/968 line. But hopefully the weight has been
more than offset by the improved engines, brakes, and suspension.
Unfortunately, the 968 competes in SCCA A-stock against the 911. But
in the PCA it could win it's class.

    The 944 turbo was added to the line in '86, and production stopped
after the '89 models. There were many improvements over the standard
944 in addition to the 217 HP engine. These can now be purchased at
very reasonable prices in the depressed used sports car market.
They seem to be worth more than the "blue book" values. There are
plenty of good ones available so you should be able to find one
with the right options (Sport package, cloth sport seats, largest
available wheels, Limited Slip) at a good price. These are even
better cars for track events. The '88 944 Turbo S and all '89
models have powerful 247 HP engines, stiffer suspension, huge ABS
brakes, and stronger transmissions with Limited slip standard. They
could be ordered with Sport options and huge 8" and 9"x16 wheels.
This gives true supercar performance for about the price of an average
new car. The SCCA has re-re-classed the '88S and '89 out of the earlier
944 Turbo's class (B-Stock) into A-Stock, where they have very little
chance of winning. The older 944 Turbos have had some success
in SCCA autocrossing, but the 944S2 seems faster. In PCA, the '86-'88
turbos run in their own class, while the '88S and '89 run with the
944 S2 and 968. The turbo should have an advantage on a course with
long straights, but the S2 or 968 could win on tighter courses.
	
    Most people do not think of the 928 as an autocross car,
but it can be! They may be big and heavy, but so are Corvettes,
which are about the fastest stock autocross car. And used 928s
are a bargain. Bruce Domeck, an excellent Porsche mechanic
from the Kentucky (?) area, autocrossed his early 928 "Land
Shark" successfully and later used it as a tow-car for his
Formula race car! That is a true dual-purpose vehicle. I have also
seen an '84 928S with stock height-adjustable suspension autocrossed
competitively. The 928 was first offered in '78 with a 4.5 Liter, 230
HP V8 engine. The 928S came to the USA in '83, with the 4.7 liter
engine giving 242 HP. For '85 and '86, the 928S had a 5.0 liter engine
with 290 HP. Finally the 928S4 twin-cam engine arrived in '87 
with 320 HP, and was continued in the 928GT and GTS. Competition
packages were available around '81. The earlier cars are lighter
but have narrower wheels and less power. The automatic transmission
option should not be overlooked! Auto transmissions are very popular
in V8 Corvettes and Camaros, with many of the fastest cars in the
country going shiftless. Auto transmissions are especially good
for Pro-Solo starts, where the car is launched by a series of timed
starting lights. As with all front-engined rear-wheel drive
cars, a limited slip differential is a must. 

The PCA puts all 928 models before the S4 ('86 and earlier) together, 
and the S4/GT/GTS together in their own class. It seems the later models
of both groups would be the best. The SCCA classes the 928 and 928S in 
B-Stock against the 944 S2 and Turbo. The 928S4, GT, and GTS go to the 
SCCA A-Stock class against the 911, Toyota MR-2 turbo, etc. Either SCCA
class  would be tough to win, but it would be interesting to see a 
928 GTS up against an early 911 - Massive torque mismatch!

   That about wraps up all Porsche models and their potential
for autocrossing success. By now you know how your current Porsche
fits in the various classes, and what it competes against. You may
also have your eye on another model that seems like it would be
better suited and more enjoyable to compete in. Whichever car you
choose, be sure to get all the necessary rule books, owners manuals,
etc. before proceeding with any modifications. The next articles will
deal with preparing your car for Stock class competition.

More to come!

Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com
'72S and '73E (sold?) Targas, '73 914/2.0

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 15:10:33 -0400 (EDT)

Subject: 911 tranny

Hey all,

I want to install a set of those air shocks in my 911 so I can make it
jump up and down at stop lights....anybody have any ideas for me ?

Ok, Ok I'm just kidding....

Actually I'm soliciting input on a "rebuild" of the 915 tranny ('82 SC).
I have considerable trouble going into 1st, in fact it's basically impossible
unless the car is at rest or I double clutch (once tranny is warm).  Down
shifting into second is a little rough too, upshifting to second and third
is also getting worse.  Basically I think that 1st, 2nd and 3rd gear
synchros and probably dog teeth are worn and need replacing.  I'm
also considering (still) the rack-pinion swap out to 7:31.

I was originally thinking of doing this myself, but my projected travel
schedule and projected inclination to do the job indicate I'd better
have someone else do it.  I'm willing to drop the tranny out, ship it and
bolt the new one back in.

Does anyone have any info/experience on the folks that advertise in pano
et al on $1k tranny rebuilds...what gets replaced for example ?  What
*SHOULD* be replaced ?  What to look out for ?  

Also, I've got some roughness in the rear pulling from rest.  It's sort
of a groaning that I feel in my butt (no rude comments thank you!).  It
seems like it might be worse pulling away turning (either side) than
straight....diff ?  CV's ?  No clicking from the CV's.

speeds and the grinding noise doesn't seem to be there.

people driving the same cars don't seem to experience it.

Do I need a tranny rebuild or driving lessons?

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 12:44:41 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: 911 Wheel/Tire sizes

>I am posting this for a friend that wants to find out what the best
>(biggest?) tire sizes to use on a 1988 911 with stock wheels.
>
>What if he goes to a 17 or 18 inch wheel?
>
>Or should he just stick with the stock size, he wants improve (ha!) handling
>and looks.
>
>Thanks to you all.

On the '78 through '89 911's you can do the following:

Front: 8x16 Fuchs (944 Turbo (951) part number with 225/45ZR16 tires.
Rear: 9x16 Fuchs (from 911 Turbo) with 245/45ZR16 tires.

Fuchs are by far and away the best wheels you can put on your '88 911.
8x16 944 Turbo offset Fuchs will cost you around $600 for a pair in
excellent condition. The 9x16 fuchs will cost you about $1200 for the
pair.

The only drawback to this setup is that there are not many tires made in
the 225/45ZR16 size. Dunlop SP 8000s, Pirelli P-Zero, P-700, and Yoko AVS
Intermediate come to mind.

Depending on the particular car, you may want to roll the front fender
lips. My car did not require this until I tried using and 8x15 wheels
with 225/50ZR15 tires for autocross.

The 9x16 setup on the rear is not a problem.


Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Tue, 30 May 95 16:12:14 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; dry sumps

Subject: Re: Why Dry Sump???

>> What is the advantage of a dry sump lubrication system as implemented on 
>> the 911??  I know that it is used in racing, but I know of no other 
>> consumer car that utilizes this system...

>I think the first part has been answered already however for part 2,
>about any post mid 70's Ferrari you care to think of. Not the 308GT4 I
>grant you, however the same engine used in the GTB and any later cars
>is. Mondiel anybody ? I think so. 512s. etc. go with out saying.

>Interestingly enough I gather if you stand on the outside of a tight
>apex at a Ferrari challenge meet you can watch the oil light come on
>on the GT4s....sounds like an expensive pastime to me.

      You are right in that none of the GT4s had dry sump from the factory,
 but I think only the Euro model GTB and GTS had dry sumps, and probably
 not any of the Mondials. Trap doors and baffles notwithstanding, Non-dry
 sumped cars will starve on right turns. Luckily for carbureted cars (until
 1980) fuel bowl starvation will save the engine. Injected cars will continue
 to power up thru corners and cause damage. When piston rings are $75 a
 piston and bearings are $500 a set, this becomes inconvenient...
      The article I've got in front of me says the 308 at 8000 rpm will pump
 400 gallons per hour, or a quart every 2-3 seconds (the oil pump is driven
 at 0.9 times engine speed, unlike most other cars which are 0.5 times).
      Adding dry sump to just about any car is $$$, just one of those lucky
  side benefits of a 911.....

          -Lee A.  sn 15346 (gt4 w/wet sump)

Date: 30 May 1995 16:49:08 U
From: "Chrisman Andrew" <Chrisman.Andrew@mail.ndhm.gtegsc.com>
Subject: Boston Area Service Alert

Caution:  Boston Area Service

I  ordered some new Bridgestone tires from the Tire Rack and asked them to be
delivered to European Performance Engineering at 10 Cochituate St in Natic,
Ma.  Well to make a long story short they ended up at European Engineering at
16 Cochituate (Road ?) in Framingham.  I can understand how the mistake was
made but it sure made for a stressful day tracking them down.  Someone should
change their name or at least move to another street.  So be sure you know
which is which if you plan on having service done or are having parts shipped
to them.  It turns out that the Tire Rack addressed them wrong.  Thanks to Jim
at EPE and Mike at EP the tires were recovered and yesterday they were mounted
and now my 968 is happy in the rain again :-)  

Andy

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 16:28:09 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Problems with changing gears

> Is there a secret to changing from 1st to second gear on a 911SC? 
> 
> Do I need a tranny rebuild or driving lessons?

Ummmm. Yes.

If you're built like me, just pull *REAL HARD* and it will only make
that noise a few more times... 8{)

If you're not, try "bumping" the shifter into the 3rd gear detent
before heading into 2nd. Works every time.

915s wear out their 2nd synchros at about 10k miles. You can either
keep replacing them, or learn to drive in the new mode. Most of us just
deal with it...

Stan

hi Sean,

I bought the my turbo tie rods from Vertex and had no problems with them. The
kit includes the boot and spacers as well. Just make sure you buy a pickle
fork from your local auto parts store (under $10- performance products sells
a non destructive remover for $90, but you are going to put new ones on
anyway). I didn't have one and it took me an hour of banging and prying with
assorted tools to get my first tie rod end off, the second one took 2
minutes. 

The parts from Vertex were German and had Porsche type part numbers. They
seemed to be of good quality.

I was just wondering, my mechanic calls places like Vertex, bandits or some
weird name like that implying that they sell inferior parts. If I were to buy
a Sachs clutch package from Vertex and one from Porsche, besides the price,
 would there be a difference. I know about economics, but are there different
specs between a Porsche clutch and an oem clutch to lead to such a price
difference or is it all pricing?

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 17:50:14 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Baby seat idea for early 911s

Hi,

With all this talk about baby seats, I thought I would tell you about the
"integrated baby seat" that came with my car- a '73 targa.  One of the PO had
a child and made a seatbelt out of vinyl and seatbelt material and attached
it using the rear seatbelt and the metal loops* above and below the seats.

*(In my car, which I assume is similar to everyone elses, there are metal
loops above and below each seat. These metal loops are screwed into special
plates not just sheet metal and seem rather strong.) 

I don't have a kid, so I don't know the regulations regarding child seats,
but this "seat" seems pretty good and strong, perhaps not legal. However
there is no upper body restraint but that could probably be incorporated into
the seat. I tried making a diagram of the seat, but it might not be clear. If
anybody has any questions, feel free to e-mail me

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 17:05:07 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Chain Tensioners.

>   Will someone explain about the diffrence in using  solid tensioners verses
> what is used on street cars?

Can be summed up in four words: Thermal Rate Of Expansion.

Why do you need tensioners in the first place? Because the centerline of
the cam is NOT a constant distance from the centerline of the crank.
Given that, how can a solid *ANYTHING* be able to take up that slack
for a cold engine *AND* a hot engine??

The solid tensioner is *POSSIBLY* useful in endurance racing, where the
engine comes up to temp and stays there roughly forever (well, at
least in terms of the net engine life). You do have to pre-calculate
the size of the tensioner give the specific engine configuration and
anticiapted heat range, and the material from which the tensioner is
made. Leading to that old question of "WHY?". What you'd really do is
use a *NEW* late 930 tensioner with a guard, or use pressure-fed units
instead. Then throw them away at the end of the race, and rebuild next
time. 

Like I said, we do things different when you're racing for keeps...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 17:38:02 EDT
From: FNVS87A@prodigy.com (MR BERNIE PAVLICK)
Subject: 924S/944 engine vibration.

I have a 1987 924S that has a vibration in the engine.  It
starts at about 3000 RPM and stops at 3200 RPM.  It can be
felt throught the shifter and it causes the shifter to
rattle.  At any other RPM the engine is very smooth.  I just 
got back from the Indy 500 and this was the first real trip 
that I took with this car.  The vibration has always been
there since I've owned the car (Aprox 1 year) it was very
anoying since 3000 RPM is 70MPH a relative ticket free
crusing speed but 3400 is 80 MPH and this is not in the
ticket free zone.  Anyone else have this vibration? First
sign of motor mount failure? Any cures for the problem?
Thanks to all.
Bernie Allegheny Region PCA

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 17:19:24 -0500
From: jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: 914: Where there's smoke, there's problems.

Greetings again all. I've been quite for a couple weeks, but now I've got
914 problems again...
(In case anyone remembers, I had the rusted left suspension console - my
restoration guy managed to bend up some thick-thick metal to repair what was
already in the car - looks good and seems to work fine, if not the 100%
"proper" solution.)

Anyways, I was driving home a few days ago, and suddenly it seemed that the
car was running on three cylinders - bucking, backfiring, etc. It didn't
stall, or exhibit any other problems, except rough and less-power running.

Next time I tried it, it still ran poor, and it seemed to have electrical
problems - when I stepped on the brake, the generator light came on, and the
tach dipped sharply (just the tach, not the actual rpms.) Ditto for the turn
signals...

Now the generator isn't lighting up, but it's running very poorly still -
constant backfiring at all rpms, but more so under load. Light blue smoke is
coming out the exhaust - the warmer the car, the more smoke. The inside of
the tailpipe is wet with raw gas, and there's a small amount of gas that
sprays onto the ground from where the heat exchangers and muffler meet (I
guess I've got a leak!). *sigh*  My first thought was valve problems, but
could it just be running exceptionally rich for some reason?

Waahh... I just want my 914 to stay running right all summer, I PROMISE I'll
do serious work all around her this winter... :(

Oh well. Such are the joys of owning a sports car. :)

Jeff Kyle
jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com
formerly jeffk914@ix.netcom.com
"Katarina" 1975 Porsche 914

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 18:37:10 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 924S/944 engine vibration.

>I have a 1987 924S that has a vibration in the engine.  It
>starts at about 3000 RPM and stops at 3200 RPM.  It can be
>felt throught the shifter and it causes the shifter to
>rattle.  At any other RPM the engine is very smooth.  I just 
>got back from the Indy 500 and this was the first real trip 
>that I took with this car.  The vibration has always been
>there since I've owned the car (Aprox 1 year) it was very
>anoying since 3000 RPM is 70MPH a relative ticket free
>crusing speed but 3400 is 80 MPH and this is not in the
>ticket free zone.  Anyone else have this vibration? First
>sign of motor mount failure? Any cures for the problem?

I would look for balance shafts that are not timed quite right.

If they are severely out of time, this kind of vibration will start
at about 2000 rpm and not get any better.

I have also heard of a case or two in which failure to fix this
problem quickly resulted in oil pickup breakage, and more
recently, broken exhaust manifolds.

Good luck,
GB
George Beuselinck, Test signature.....

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 17:56:13 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Vertex Tie Rod Kit and mail oder places.

> If I were to buy
> a Sachs clutch package from Vertex and one from Porsche, besides the price,
>  would there be a difference. I know about economics, but are there different
> specs between a Porsche clutch and an oem clutch to lead to such a price
> difference or is it all pricing? 

Well, that's a good question....

I remember back in the mid-80s, when as a Sun OEM I asked what the difference
was between the Fujitsu disk drives that I sold and the Fujitsu disk drives
that they sold. I was taken to a place with some thermal cycle chambers and
other misc electronic gear and told that each drive sold by Sun had some
large number of hours running a complex surface failure analysis pattern
while being heat cycled through the entire operating range on a continual
basis, while I just sold the drives the way the came off the boat. OK, that
explained the *huge* price difference.

Later we got into it about memory (I'd paid someone to engineer my own
private-label Sun-2 memory boards and it was STILL cheaper.) Roughly the
same thing happened, except this time I didn't see the testing -- it was
all done at the chip level by the manufacturer "to a certain level of 
specification". Whereas I used off-the-shelf memory chips. Implying that
maybe I had a higher per-chip failure rate (which was actually true).

How does this apply? Well, maybe it does, and maybe it doesn't. Maybe
Porsche has very, very high standards and statistical QA techniques that
insure that the parts are essentially perfect and defect free, and
that the "OEM parts" that you buy on the open market are the *same* parts
that haven't been "qualified.". And maybe the new EuroSelect line is 
a collection of "partially qualified" parts that are good enough for them
to feel OK about selling, but not good enough to put the Porsche name on.
Or maybe there *IS* no difference, and they're just profiteering bastards.

I have a pretty good idea what the party line is, and know why I tend
to buy lots of the "important" stuff via dealer channels... On the other
hand, I tend to qualify my own parts a lot, and will shop price on those.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 30 May 95 16:45:17 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: problems changing gears

>
> From: "Asad Husain" <AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd.edu>
> 
> Is there a secret to changing from 1st to second gear on a 911SC? 
>

I don't claim to posess any Revealed Knowledge, but with my SC, you have
to stop thinking about selecting gears based on stick position, and
start thinking in terms of stick force.  *Gentle* stick force. 
(If it makes you feel any better, F-16 control sticks also work on
force input rather than position input.  Okay, okay, I'm
reaching...)  On your first-second shift for example, pop the stick from
first to neutral, then pull steadily and gently until the stick slides
into second... may take from a half to a full second, which as I
understand it is basically the time it takes your tired synchronizer to
do its thing... shouldn't take much force at all, maybe a few pounds at
most.   This is hard to do consistently, especially in the heat of
combat, but it works 95-98% of the time for me, and it sure costs less
than a tranny rebuild.

Speaking of tranny rebuilds, hasn't anyone done this recently?  I'm
still waiting for some Voices of Experience to answer Martin Walker's
recent query re: 915 box rebuild shops!

 -Ed

meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 20:39:19 -0400
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: Re;porsches for autocrossing

mike; a few corrections on your superb overview of the various porsche models
in scca and pca autocrossing;
  
  1. I believe cis injection was standard on '73 911t's while mechanical
injection came on the e and s, then 74 saw cis become the standard injection
on all 911s.

   2.  914's especially 2 liters were exceptionally competitive in the 70's
as new england drivers Ed and Pam Sanborn and Lowell Peabody all took
national championships in C stock.  In fact Pam's win in the '76 Nationals in
Columbus Ohio, set a time in the women's class which beat all the men in c
stock, a feat not repeated for many years.

  3. The 944S had abs optional not standard, the S2 which came out in 89 had
standard abs.

   4.  There was no 89 944S it was a 2 year car both years at 2.5 liter.

        Keep up the good work


                       Steve

                        90 944S2

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 20:55:38 -0400 (EDT)
From: "James L. Fry" <JFRY@UOFT02.UTOLEDO.EDU>
Subject: The 928

Dave Snell inquired about the desirability of purchasing a 1985 
928S(55K miles) for $14K.  As an owner of such a beast, I am 
willing to contribute my $0.02.

Dave, 

Let me first say that I know of no Porsche model, regardless
of what the initial purchase price is, that is not expensive to
properly maintain.  Furthermore, unless you have a good deal of
disposable income AND a lot of time to research the (constantly
changing) market, I do not feel that one should purchase a P-car
for any reason other than personal enjoyment [gratification :-)].
Hence, if you can get through to the bottom line, my advice to you
is to drive the car, consider what you have experienced, then, if
you decide to continue, pay a reputable PORSCHE mechanic to give
you a complete status report on the car (this will cost you at
least $100).  Following this, if you are still interested, drive
the car again and be prepared to negotiate the best price you can
from a position of knowledge.

Last year I bought a car very similar to the one you have
described.  Mine is a 1986 928S that spend most of its life stored
in a garage in Florida when it was not being driven by its
original female owner.  Except for the normal small paint chips,
etc., it was in nearly perfect visual condition.  All important
records, including the original sales receipts, etc., were
available.  It passed inspection by a (trusted) P-car mechanic
with only a few minor items being noted (needed front brake pads).
The car had 41K miles on it.  The asking price was $21K.  I got it
for $17K.

Within a couple of thousand miles, the dreaded water
pump failure had struck.  (This should be no surprise.  They are
as well known as the early chain tensioned failures in the air-
cooled engines).  I decided to do a major preventative mainten-
nance at this point and replaced ALL of the belts, hoses,
thermostat, etc. at the same time the water pump was replaced.  It
cost me about $1500.

Was it all worth it for me?  Absolutely!  I love this car.  It has
essentially the same 4-cam, 32-valve engine as the 87 928 S4 and
following models do and with about as much performance, except at
the top end (who needs 165 mph?  152 is enough for me!)  The 1985
928S is virtually the same as the 1986 with the exception of the
big (huge!) S4 brakes that went on the 1986.5  It is not super
quick off the line for the first 100 feet or so, but it is
ferocious after that.  It has really incredible acceleration
between 50 mph and way beyond 100 mph.  It is not simply a "luxo
cruiser" as some (very likely not very familiar with it) have
described.  Take it into some challenging turns and you have no
question about its P-car heritage.  Brakes are superb!  A blast!

Would it be worth it for you?  I dont know.  The 928 is probably
the most misunderstood of all the modern P-cars.  Keep in mind
that only a very few 928 models of any kind have ever been
produced.  No more than a couple of thousand a year have ever
made it into this country.  They had very high initial costs and
did not sustain their value.  Hence, in my simple way of 
thinking, you can get an awful lot of car now for a relatively
small amount of money, IF you really want one and can afford
to keep it maintained.  Dont even think of getting it if you
cant afford to keep it running properly!

I will mention in passing that my only regret in buying the
928 was that I then had to part with my dearly beloved (and 
also frequently misunderstood) 1982 931 (AKA 924 turbo) which I
had owned for 5 years.  The two cars were as different as night
and day, but they were both Porsches, without a doubt.

So, good luck in making your decision!

Jim Fry

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 14:48:27 -0400
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: M474 Suspension

Lou Krieg wrote:

>My '87 951's sticker (yes, I still have it) indicates $260 extra for "Sport
>Shock Absorbers". These were yellow Boge shocks, non-adjustable (at least

...and Ross Stites chimed in with:

>474*    Sport Shock Absorbers                     267
>637     Performance Handling Package (944/944S) 5,115
                                     (944 Turbo)  677
>*Standard Equipment 944 Turbo.

>Maybe this list is in error.  The shocks that my car has
>are black and I assume they are the originals.  According to
>the shop manuals the standard shocks for '87 951s are black
>F&S with the Boges and Konis being options.  So, the shocks
>in the M474 package that started this whole discusion are
>definitely not the standard base level shock offered for
>951s.  I assume they are better for performance purposes,

Allow me to muddy the waters further with another data point:

I have the 474 'option' code listed in my spare wheelwell which is standard 
equipment for '87 951.  BTW, the option list in the FAQ was sent to me from 
Mark Sundt who said it was scanned it in from an 1987 Porsche sales brochure
so I believe this is correct.  I have the original shocks on the car which
are yellow Konis and are labelled 'adjustable' with a 951.xxx.xxx part no.
So we've got 1 set of yellow Boge, yellow Koni and black F&S.  Sounds like 
Porsche, 'er.. Audi, put in whatever was available at the time.   

Anyone else with an '87 951 want to help us settle this burning question: 
what was the stock struts/shocks supplied on your car and do you have the 474 
'option' code?

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 18:06:22 -0700
From: dem@best.com (Dennis Mitsch)
Subject: happy 914 shifting & rocker/valance resto ?'s

Hi folks.  A few weeks back I posted a question about how to get my
silly 914 into 1st gear at a stop light.  When I tried to get it into
first - no go.  If I put it into any other gear first, I'd get a grind
and then it still wouldn't go into first.  Several others replied back
with "Well, me too.".  Gary Pighetti had the answer.  I've included
his original message (by permission) at the end of my post.  But briefly:

While at stop light, in neutral.  Nudge the shifter toward second until
you feel things happening, then go for first.  Goes right in!  a-mazing!
Takes a bit of practice, but once you get it going it works every time.

Other questions:

What do I do about my rocker panels?  They were originally orange.
Painted black.  Then had decals applied to them.  They look awful. :(

Should I buy new ones (metal, of course) and have them painted?  powder
coated? or should I have the old ones redone (what am I asking for if
I call a shop? do they sand blast them or what?)  If anyone has northern
california (bay area) shop recommendations, fire 'em my way.  The rockers
themselves aren't dented/rusted (well, a few dots of rust, but nothing
much), they're just really ugly.

Similarly, does any place sell metal rear valances?  Automotion,
Performance Products and Automobile Atlanta don't seem to carry them?
Mine is dented and bashed up pretty nasty.  All I see are fiberglass
repro's.

I'm not "restoring" the car, but I do want to keep it in as near
original condition as possible.

Thanks much.

Dennis Mitsch
88 944S (speeding ticket this weekend, bummer.  Couldn't have that perfect
no-points record forever.  My insurance company will be in heaven!)
74 914 2.0 Special Edition (no tickets in this one, yet.)


==== BEGIN INCLUDE ====

>From: Gary_Pighetti@freeport.maine.com (Gary Pighetti)
>Reply-To: Gary_Pighetti@freeport.maine.com
>To: dem@best.com
>Subject: 9
14 shifting
>Date: 11 May 1995 17:39:38 GMT
>Organization: Freeport Middle School
>
>Hi:
>
>    You have asked the ultimate 914 question. I hope I can shed some light on
>it. First, my qualifications (as such <g>): I worked as an assistant service
>manager and warranty geek at a Porsche Audi dealer during the time 914s were
>new. If I had a buck for every warranty claim and every service order I wrote
>for "adjust shifter and linkage" I would have beaucoup change right now.
>Porsche did a lot of the 914 development "on the fly" and shift linkage was
>no exception.They finally ended up with a cute little tool which looked like
>a 1" square piece of 1/4" thick steel with two 1/16" diameter 1" long
>cylinders sticking out perpendicular to the square's surface. Anyway, the
>technician would read the service bulletin, shove this 'tool' up into the
>shifter linkage, pour holy water on the trunk, move the shifter around. You
>get the picture: most 914s still shifted in a most vague and intriguing
>manner. Side shifters (you've got one) were infinitely better, but everyone
>still caught reverse instead of second at least twice and hardly anybody
>could get the damn thing into first.
>      Those of us who drove lots of different cars every day (I road-tested
>every car that went through the shop) got pretty good at working around the
>recalcitrant shifter. It'll be hard to explain it through e-mail, but I'll
>try: first you've got to understand that the Porsche transaxle sees every
>shift from neutral into first as an 'upshift' and the synchros don't work.
>Therefore, you get that incredible 'graunch' when you shift from neutral
>directly into first. So don't do it.  What you have to do (and you can get
>quite adept at it with practice) is when you're coming to a stop shift into
>second and then, deftly with not a lot of force, but with a whole lot of
>authority, shift it slickly into first. The trans sees a 'downshift' into
>first and it goes in. 
>     If you sit at a light in neutral, that's okay. When the light is about
>to change, shift into second. Actually, you'll only have to shift towards
>second, and then deftly, quickly, with authority, finesse that sucker right
>into first. It's definitely a 'feel' thing.
>     Now, maybe, DR914 or others who have worked on 914s for twenty-five
>years have come up with a solution to your problem and can tell you how to
>adjust the linkage so that it'll work most wonderfully. I have hope that it's
>possible, but I'm not holding my breath <g>. I think the linkage stinks. I
>think most 914s and 911s have vague and balky shifters. That being said, you
>can get really good at looking like there's no problem whatsoever. Remember:
>deftness, authority, quickness, without forcing. It'll go, you'll look like a
>shifter hero. And nobody else who drives it will be able to get into first
>(or second without nicking reverse!)
>Regards,
>GP
>
>

  The 2.0 (newly acquired) and I are beginning to get aquainted.  I hope to
become old friends, much like my '69 Bug and I were.  The Bug and I had a very
strong trust bond between us, I understood what made it go, and vice versa, in
fact, it was love.  I had a troubling relationship with a seductive but rotten
'72 914, and she up and died on me (permanent-like).  Since the '72 and I parte
d, I went out and got me a shiny new Mechanical Engineering Degree, and more
importantly, 10 years of car/street-smarts.  I now am a confident-kind of guy
in that no car scares me any more, However in order to trust this new '76 2.0,
I want that old Bug trust relationship.  I want to go through every part of the
F.I. system and understand how/why it works?  I want to be cockey once again as
with the old bug, where I could fix any problem on the road, in the dark, with
bubble gum and my trusty 10 and 13mm wrenches.  This is alot to ask?  To all of
the 914 F.I. (Bosch-D) veterans, I would appreciate a list of your horrors/joys
where to look first, when to cry, when to rejoice, etc.
  I'm planning to order the Manuals and Tips books from Auto. Atlanta. If there
is a better source, please sing out.  My only regret is that John Muir had not
continued his VW series and expanded into Porsches....sometimes these Porsche-T
ypes are just a bit too uptight...everyone can use a giggle now and then.

out there beat the $79 price?
I appreciate and respect this People-Base
thanks,   brian

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 20:33:42 -0500
From: jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: 914: Where there's smoke, there's problems.

>        Point one:  FIX THE BACKFIRE!  This can warp the flap inside your
>air meter, which will then cause all kinds of problems.  Like a $200 hole
>in your wallet for a rebuilt one.
>        Two:  Since the FI is electronic, electrical problems can very
>easily f*ck up the FI.
>        A rich mixture sounds like *maybe* the head temp sensor.  Check
>to see if it's still connected.
>        You probably should check out all the FI input components (flapper
>box, head temp sensor, etc.).  Sorry for the bad news.

Much as I'd like to do it all myself, I just don't have the time, and it's
sitting at the resto shop now awaiting being looked at tomorrow. I just want
to probe the various 914 gurus for any hints that might help us all out...
As it is, I'm just waiting to hear that there's a problem with the heads and
the engine'll have to be dropped... Which I almost wouldn't mind, so we
could fix those damn leaky pushrod tube o-rings that leak oil noisily all
over the heat exchangers! :)

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 21:00:48 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Chain Tensioners.

Dear Trond,

I have put together several motors with mechanical tensioners.  Actually 
I gutted the original tensioners and installed some Aluminum inserts I 
made on my lathe.  I have to agree wih Stan that almost anything on a 
street car is better than that!  Particularly on a street driven car.  I 
once found some stock tensioners with large rubber shock absorber bushings 
installed over the stems in a 911.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy

   A hopefully-not-inflammatory tire question.  My '82 SC presently is
sooo stock that it has P7's on it!  That is about to change, as it needs 
new fronts.  However, the rears are only ~ 1 year old. (*Please* no flames!
I was naive a year ago!  I thought P7's were the best thing since the 
Chia Pet! :-)  At the time, I figured the rears would wear quickly enough that 
I would have to buy 4 tires next go 'round, but the rears are still in quite 
good shape (guess I am not getting the rear end out enough, huh?).

   The question:  Can I put decent tires on the front without creating a
mismatched, oversteering monster that you-know-who would be proud of?  Are 
some combos better than others?  Application is street driving only, daily
driver (so wet performance is a consideration).

   <Warning: Religious issue approaching> I am leaning towards Yoko A509's.
I may still pop for AVS-I's, but the differential seems a little too
$teep.  (I guess that, in Stan's accurate categorization of Quality-oriented,

personality.")  Other tires in the 509 price range include BFG Comp T/A3, 
Dunlop D40's, and (stretching a bit) Conti CZ 91's.  Any 
thoughts/recommendations?  Private e-mail is welcome if the which-tire-is-best 
thread should be avoided.

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 11:21:04 +0800
From: omsnyk1!sg.fp.cibcwg.com!jb@cibc.com (Justin Beech)
Subject: Re: 924S/944 engine vibration.


Sorry, This is a related question, not an answer.

I have a similar symptom, but with my 3.2 911 engine. There is a deep
low frequency vibration that peaks at 3400-ish, and is most noticeable
when the throttle is completely closed - off the gas, engine braking,
in gear, as the rev needle passes slowly down through the mid 3000s,
the vibration (and distant rumble) rises to max at ~3400 and then falls
to nothing by 2800 - and I can feel it through the gearbox.
It doesnt seem to be getting worse, and its not related
to the gear I am in. It seems odd that it feels worse when the engine is
being driven by the wheels rather than when on the gas, I would have
thought it would feel the same either way.
Is this the same problem (balancing) and is it expensive/difficult 
to fix?

 -Justin.

> 
> >I have a 1987 924S that has a vibration in the engine.  It
> >starts at about 3000 RPM and stops at 3200 RPM.  It can be
> >felt throught the shifter and it causes the shifter to
> >rattle.  At any other RPM the engine is very smooth.  I just 
> >got back from the Indy 500 and this was the first real trip 
> >that I took with this car.  The vibration has always been
> >there since I've owned the car (Aprox 1 year) it was very
> >anoying since 3000 RPM is 70MPH a relative ticket free
> >crusing speed but 3400 is 80 MPH and this is not in the
> >ticket free zone.  Anyone else have this vibration? First
> >sign of motor mount failure? Any cures for the problem?
> 
> I would look for balance shafts that are not timed quite right.
> 
> If they are severely out of time, this kind of vibration will start
> at about 2000 rpm and not get any better.
> 
> I have also heard of a case or two in which failure to fix this
> problem quickly resulted in oil pickup breakage, and more
> recently, broken exhaust manifolds.
> 
> Good luck,
> GB
> George Beuselinck, Test signature.....
>

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 23:26:22 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: ABS & racing/ Personal experience

Earlier this year there was a thread going about the advantages/disadvantages
of ABS on race cars. Since my track car (89 951) has ABS, and since I
recently left a race course at a high rate of speed, I have a bit of input
into this matter.
While attending the Brian Redman Jefferson 500 at Summit Point I was tooling
down the main straight at 140MPH trying to figure out how to pass a worthy
opponent. I followed for 2 laps, noting his braking point, and figured that I
could out brake him going into turn 1. Several factors played into the
failure of my plan. The first problem was that it had rained and the track
was still damp. Secondly for some inexplicable reason my friend decided to
brake earlier than he had done on the previous laps, and thirdly and
certainly not least a 917 closed on me with a considerable discrepancy in
speed. By the time I processed all this information I was just about into the
trunk of the 911 in front of me with no chance of avoiding a mishap.
So I stood on my brakes and steered left, off the course and into the wet mud
and Virginia red water soaked clay. I did pass the 911 but in a way that I
hadn't planned. Anyway here I was with both a lateral and forward vector. The
car car really wanted to rotate and I'm sure that if it had I would have
rolled many times but with my foot firmly planted on the brakes I was able to
correct the yawing and keep the car straight, all the time sliding forwards
and sideways towards a dirt bank that keeps you in that particular county.
The car lost it's lateral velocity about 5 feet from the bank and finally
came to a stop about 200 feet beyond the first turn. After driving around in
the mud I located the escape road and made my way back to the course where a
SCCA worker directed me back onto the circuit. I told him I'd rather think
about what happened for a second or two if he didn't mind. He then told me he
saw the whole incident and for the life of him he couldn't figure out why the
car didn't spin, flip and crash. 
Of course I was delighted that it didn't and had a great time the rest of the
weekend. I would like to attribute the happy ending to my superior driving
skills but I don't think I'll get away with that.
 What I'm really thinking is that the ABS saved my ass in this particular
instance and any thoughts of disabling it for racing have vanished. I'm also
thinking that you should always expect the unexpected in a racing situation
but of course I should have learned that lesson a long time ago.
Glad to be here to tell the tale!!

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)covered with red mud
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
11:23 pm

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 23:32:27 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Chain Tensioners.

Hi Trond,

The 2.0 litre engines can indeed use the pressure-fed tensioners, unless
I am very much mistaken.  We replaced a broken feed line on a '69 911T
last year, somewhere along the New York State Turnpike, as we drove out
to the Watkins Glen race track.

It may be that the first series of engines cannot use the pressurized
tensioners.  That is, the first 3,000 or so engines which had centre-
lubricated camshafts rather than the spray bar.  I am not sure.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 22:31:14 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: More 914 Bosch D Fuel Injection Questions

> For the D-Jetronic information, get the Bible:
> 
>    "Bosch Fuel Injection and Engine Management"
>    Probst, Charles O.

Excellent suggestion!! And, in case you missed it (I had to go back and
check myself) the *late* editions of the Muir book *DO* have the D-jet
EFI stuff documented. See the '81 edition or later, p. 135 talks about
"Electronic Fuel Injection" and *differentiates it from AFC*. This is nothing
but the good ol' D-jet system you're trying to know and love. Honest.

> >  Stainless Steel Brakelines...Auto Atlanta and Tweeks sell them, can anyone
> >out there beat the $79 price?
> 
> Try Imparts.

See also "Bad Idea, Part 2".

This gets asked a lot; I try to speak up every time. The braided lines are 
designed as a less-than-one-year "consumable" item for road racing. They're
good for probably less than 2000 *TRACK MILES*. They do *NOT* appreciably
improve the performance except for those odd situations where mean fluid
pressure is enormous (like dual 2" I.D. master cylinders driving stock
two-piston "M" front calipers -- and yes, I *HAVE* seen that one!). And I
can just about guarantee that you won't replace them every 2000 miles. Hell,
that could be once a month!!! And track miles are a lot easier on the car
than street miles, too... So maybe you should just plan on replacing them
once a month...

What they *DO* is cause accidents. You think "cool racing part -- this will
REALLY work well" and then you don't think about it again. Three years
later, the inner teflon line has abraded a hole or a weak spot by rubbing
on the *inside* of the outer steel braid, and when you grab the brakes,
there's nothing there. Then we get to the real fun part. They're NOT rated
as "OK to use on the street" by the DOT. Your insurance company finds out. 
They don't pay off because it's *YOUR* fault from gross negligence due to
installed parts not rated for street use.

Instead, try replacing the lines with nice stock rubber lines. Do it every
five years or so if it makes you happier. I've even started using them for
racing cars, particularly the IMSA endurance cars, and I think I'm not
alone on that one...

Stan
