------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 00:58:01 -0400
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Leather/Vinyl Care/Refinishing

The care and feeding of the leather and the vinyl components of your
automotive interior are two very different processes.  If you are using one
product on both, that is somewhat like using gasoline as a lubricant. It will
work, but not for long.  I will cover the care and feeding of leather and
vinyl separately.

Leather having once been used to keep the insides of a cow from falling out
was designed to pass moisture through tiny pores.  These tiny pores absorb
human perspiration and as the water evaporates, salts contained therein
remain to absorb the essential oils in the leather.  This accumulation of
salts and other grunge should be cleaned from the leather about twice a year
(more often if the seats get more than their fair share of your leftover
sweat).  The loss of oils within the leather is the first step to hardening,
cracking and shrinkage.  Leather dashes are very prone to hardening and
shrinking.  Your dash is subjected to the destructive UV rays and heat
concentrated by the windshield.  The leather (or vinyl) of your dash rests
upon a metal backing that acts like a frying pan.  This "frying" drives the
essential oils from the leather causing premature shrinkage, cracking and
hardening.  Thus a dash should be treated more often than the seats or door
panels.

Cleaning leather may be accomplished by using a mild soap and water, or a
specifically designed leather cleaner.  Of all the products I have tried, I
still like Lexol pH Cleaner.  It is pH balanced, and gentle. All cleaners
will rehydrate the leftover salts and grime and wash them from the leather
fibers.  Use only leather products on leather, do not use vinyl cleaners as
these products tend to be much harsher and may not be that beneficial to the
leather.  Any cleaner should be rinsed thoroughly from the leather.  I have
tried spraying off with a hose, but that just seemed to fill the car with
soapy water (a hole drilled in the floor was needed to drain it out - just
kidding).  I went back to using a damp cloth and repeatedly wiping down the
leather.  Once the leather is clean, a conditioner should be used to restore
lost oils and emollients.  There are several conditioners on the market.  Two
of my favorites over the years are Lexol Conditioner and Tony Nancy Leather
Conditioner.  These two seem to be the most easily absorbed into the leather
fibers and tend to leave a relatively less "greasy" finish than any of the
other products I have tried.  Another good product is Connoly Hide Food.
 This product is made from rendered animal parts and will turn rancid in
about two years.  This and the distinctive "cow" smell removes it from my top
two list (I spent too much time milking the south end of a north pointing
cow, so am not a fan of cow smells).  Zymol makes a product called "Leather
Treat".  It does not,  in my humble opinion,  do any better job than the much
less expensive Lexol or Tony Nancy products.  Again, do not use a vinyl
product as a conditioner on leather and above all try to avoid silicone based
products.  The silicone oil will dissolve out the leather's natural oils and
tend make the leather sticky.  Silicone has a very high electrostatic
attraction, so will invite every dust particle within miles to set up camp in
your interior.  Apply the conditioner to a soft cloth and work into the
leather, allow to be absorbed into the fibers and then buff off the excess.
 You may condition the leather as often as you wish.  The leather will tell
you if you apply too much or apply to often.  The leather fibers will just
not absorb the excess.

If your leather has hardened or needs some intensive softening, there is a
really nifty product called "Surflex Leather Soffener".  This product is made
from natural and synthetic oils that restore the natural softness to
neglected leather.  Clean the leather and then apply a liberal coat of
Soffener.  Allow to penetrate the leather for about 24 hours.  Wipe off the
excess.  If it needs an additional application, repeat the above.  For really
bad areas, cover with plastic and allow to sit for a few days.  Once the
leather is sufficiently softened, allow to "cure" for another 24 hours and
buff off any excess. You are done.  I jokingly say this product will turn a
dog's rawhide chew into a kid glove.  I have had some luck with leather
dashes with this method.  Once the leather has softened, I have been able to
gently tuck it back under the edges of the trim and windshield clips.  This
is a lot cheaper than a new dash and may be worth a try before spending a ton
of money.

If your leather or vinyl has scuff marks, scratches or areas that the surface
color had been removed, you may refinish it yourself  The key is another
Suflex product.  The Suflex Colorant & Finish for Flexible Surfaces may be
matched to the exact color required.  Any interior leather or vinyl surface
may be refinished.  It is not recommended to spot finish any area.  If your
seat bolsters have belt loop scuff marks, you should refinish the entire
front of the seat.  I usually do from welting to welting.  This provides a
visual break that does not make the non refinished areas appear quite as
shabby.  But then why not do the whole seat, dash, or door panel?  Start by
cleaning the area(s) to be refinished with a suitable Organic Solvent.  I
prefer Wurth Citrus Degreaser or P21S Total Auto Wash.  Prior to usage, test
all solvents on an area that does not show.  I use the excess on the
underside of the seat to test colorfastness of the finish.  Spray the solvent
on a soft lint free cloth, and then wipe down the surface(s).  Repeat after a
few minutes.  Rinse with a damp cloth and allow to dry thoroughly (at least
24 hours).  The manufacturer of Surflex says to strip the old finish off
using lacquer thinner, commercial paint remover or C-P Stripper.  I don't,
because most interiors are not in that bad a shape and I have never found it
necessary (They also recommend lightly sanding the area prior to usage, I
don't do that either - no guts).  Mix the Surflex completely and use it like
a wood stain.  I use a small piece of lint free cloth and work the Surflex
into the leather or vinyl just as if I were staining wood.  Once the desired
color of finish is achieved,  allow to dry undisturbed for at least 24 hours.
 I allow the surface to "harden off" for about 2 weeks before applying any
conditioners to leather or vinyl protectants to vinyl parts. I have not had a
lot of luck refinishing a dark leather or vinyl a lighter color.  The old
color tends to show through in small "cracks" and the whole panel seems to be
"muddy".  Maybe if you strip off all the old finish, it would look better.
 Someday, I will get an old seat and give it a try.              

The Surflex Black Colorant works great on black bumpers, black spoilers or
black rubber/vinyl trim that has been scratched or scuffed. Clean the entire
part thoroughly with Wurth Citrus Degreaser, rinse and dry thoroughly.  Stain
the area with the Colorant and allow to dry.  It will look like new.  After
about 3 weeks hardening off, coat with a protective coating of Mequiar #42
Rubber Treatment or Black Again.

Small cuts, cracks or holes in leather may be partially repaired using
another Surflex product called Flex-Fill.  This is a semi-flexible cosmetic
filling material.  You use it like a spackle compound.  It will take the
Surflex colorant similar to leather or vinyl.  I have been able to repair
several damaged areas and hide them so they are not visible to the casual
observer.  Will it make a three inch crack in your dash look like new?  No,
but it may help hide it so that it isn't quite so obvious.  I have found that
forcing Flex-Fill under the repaired area and forming an inverted T patch
works best.  Once the patch is dry, sand lightly to blend in with the leather
or vinyl.  Clean the area thoroughly and refinish with the Surflex Colorant.
 This is a learned skill, so you should practice on a test piece of leather
or vinyl.  Perfect your techniques before you tackle your expensive interior.

Vinyl is the carefully prepared hydes of virgin pampered Arctic Naugas.  Many
Naugas must die to furnish enough material for just one interior panel. 

The dash, door panels, seat backs, and numerous other
interior/exterior trim pieces are usually vinyl.  Vinyl may be viewed as raw
semi-liquid vinyls that are held in place by a solid vinyl "skin" (this
description is for illustration only and not a PhD chemical dissertation ).
The dash and other vinyl parts of your car are constantly bombarded by UV
that breaks down the molecules of the skin, allowing the raw vinyls to escape
(off-gassing).  These free vinyls then may deposit themselves on the glass,
forming a haze that is difficult to remove.  If you have such a haze, it is
probably your dash that has decided to pick up stakes and migrate.  Silicone
based vinyl dressing products do not usually contain UV protectants,
and the silicone may act as a magnifying glass, intensifying the UV
degradation.  Silicone oil may also dissolve the essential oils in the vinyl
skin, hastening the premature formation of cracks in the vinyl skin.  A
quality vinyl protectant will contain a UV protectant and essential oils to
replace lost oils from the vinyl.  These protectants are expensive, so the
K-Mart specials may do more harm than good. Silicone also has very strong
electrostatic attraction which may be considered beneficial in that it will
tend to stay where it is placed, but will also attract every dust particle in
the surrounding three counties.

Any vinyl protectant should be applied to a soft cloth and worked into the
surface.  After a few moments of allowing it to work into the surface, buff
off the excess.  The dash should be treated more often than any other area,
as it is subject to the most severe attack by UV and heat
. 
My personal favorite vinyl protectant is Lexol Vinyex Spray.  This in my
humble opinion has it all.  A very strong UV protectant, essential oils,
anti-static (helps keep dust off) and a soft patina finish.   Harly Polyguard
 - This used to be my favorite, till I lost my heart to Vinylex. Leaves a
touch more shine to the finish than Vinylex.  Somethin' Else - This is the
sister to Black Again.  Has all the right ingredients and people who love it
are died in the wool.  I prefer the Vinylex, but that only a subjective
opinion.  It leaves a "new car" smell.  I think that is why it is not my
favorite.  I am not a fan of artificial smells.  Harly Interior Magic - An
old standby that leaves a lemon scent.  Some people love it.  I don't think a
car should smell like lemons, but that's my opinion and I could be wrong.
 Zymol Vinyl - Another tropical oil product.  Leaves a pina colada smell.
 Diehards will defend this product to the death.  I just think it is to much
$. Meguiar #40 - A great product that cleans and protects.  Does not leave a
slippery finish.  Meguiar #39 - A very strong cleaner.  This should be used
carefully and very infrequently.  It will clean just about anything out of
vinyl.  Must be followed by #40 or other vinyl protectant.  A great cleaner
for plastic Targa tops.  Tony Nancy Rubber/Vinyl Cleaner- I don't recommend
use on the inside.  The smell is a bit much for me (reminds me of dead rats).
 Some people do and swear by it.  Sonax Cockpit Spray - This is a German
product that is designed for German vinyl.  Does a great job, but leaves a
little more shine to the surface than I care for.  There are a gaggle of
users who love it.  Wurth Cockpit Spray - ditto above. Wurth people don't
like Sonax and vice versa.  Formula 303 - This leaves an Armour All type of
high gloss shine to the vinyl.  I personally don't like this type of finish.
 Some people do, so feel comfortable using it.  All of the above products do
not contain silicone.

I hope that the above has shed some light on the subject leather and vinyl
care.  If there are any questions, please do not hesitate to call or write.
 If you can't find the products locally, I stock all of them except the
Formula 303 and would be glad to send a product description/price package by
mail.

Thank you,

Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specialties, Inc.
"We will sell no silicone... except for Yugos"
Post Office Box 535
Saddle Brook,  NJ  07663-0535
Phone (201) 796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 00:12:14 -0500
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: 944 Puzzler

At 11:06pm 29.5.95, Steve Sarsfield wrote:
>Driving home this Friday night, my 1983 944 suddenly began bucking.  With
>seemingly no regular pattern, the car would feel like you were slamming on
>the brakes for a split second, then jammimg on the gas peddle - two or two
>times a second.  No backfire occurred,  but just a random series of quick
>surges (and anti-surges).
>
>The current hypothesis is:
>
>A) Bad fuel pump (ouch!)
>B) Fuel line blockage
>C) Throttle control valve sensor
>D) Other

Hey Steve,

        I had almost the exact same problem on my '84 944. My problem was
that it would only start to surge for about 10 minutes every 3 months, so
it was hard to track down until it got worse. It turns out the airflow
meter was not reading correctly, and that was causing the problems. A
couple suggestions:

1) if the car was still surging when you disconnected the throttle control
valve sensor, I would count that out.

2) I would check the fuel pressure, but I doubt the pump or a fuel line
blockage is your problem.

3) Carefully check all hoses connecting to the air intake after the airflow
meter (particularly the rings which hold the large black boot that connects
the airflow meter to the throttle body). If these rings are lose they will
let excess air into the engine.

I found that when the car was surging (and anti-surging) that it was
closely related to **change** in the throttle. If I kept my foot on the
accelerator very still at a constant rpm, the engine would run fine. As
soon as I moved my foot (or hit a bump, which would cause my foot to shift
a tiny bit) the engine would surge (a change in throttle = a change in
position on the airflow meter). So, I figured that there was a problem with
the meter because of this. A variable resistor (which is what the airflow
meter seems to be) will wear after a period of time, and the readings from
it will get more sporadic and will jump around instead of having a smooth
progession. Following some very good advice from Kevin Gross (and my own
ideas) I took the black cover off of my airflow meter and bent the little
"wiper" a bit so that it followed a fresh path across the resistive pad.
The car has run fine ever since. I would not recommend doing this unless
you are familliar dealing with electronic devices. I did it beacuse I
wasn't into spending several hundred dollars for a new/rebuilt airflow
meter.

The barn door in the meter could also be hanging up on something, causing
false readings. You will want to look at this by pressing the barn door
back with your fingers (remember though that what may seem like smooth
travel to your fingers may not be for the air collum that has to keep the
meter open).

In any case, I hope this helps.

trev.


===============================
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

While surfing, stop at:
http://www.io.org/~cme/MIC/mic.html
and you will find a listing on trev ...

Date: Tue, 30 May 95 22:28:30 PDT
From: hbrandt@InterServ.Com
Subject: Beware of HRE Wheels!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Fellow Porschephiles:

I recently had a disasterous mail-order experience with HRE Performance Wheels 
of Vista California.  I liked the look of their wheels from an ad in 
Excellence and ordered a set at over $3000.  That's where the nightmare 
begins:

(1)  I was initially promised delivery within three weeks.  I didn't receive 
the wheels for over 2 months.  They were then sent to my home, instead of to 
the address of my mechanic, where I asked that they be sent.

(2)  The wheels were sent with the wrong center caps (chrome instead of GPX 
white), and the center caps protruded from the wheel as opposed to the way 
they appeared in pictures they sent me in which they were machined flush with 
the wheel.  When I discussed this with HRE, they told me that "different 
center caps have a different fit" and that if I wanted them to look like they 
did in the picture, I would have to send the 4 wheels back to California for 
lathe machining.

(3)  After a couple of months on my car, the valve stems in 2 of the 4 wheels 
began to leak leading to flat tires, and requiring that I send the wheels back 
to HRE.

(4)  Since I had to send the wheels back to HRE for the valve stem repair, I 
asked that they fix the faulty center caps so they would appear as they did in 
the literature they had sent me. They told me I would have to pay for this.  
They didn't even offer to pay the shipping to get the valve stems repaired 
even though the wheels were still under warranty and less than 3 months old.

(5)  I didn't get the wheels back for 2 months.  Then they sent back the 
wheels, but didn't send back the tires.  I still haven't gotten my tires 
back!!!!!

(6)  The people at HRE have been rude, discourteous and obnoxious.  I had to 
threaten to reverse credit card charges to get any service at all.

In summary,  this has been the worst mail order experience of my life.  I've 
ordered Porsche parts and equipment from numerous companies and have never had 
problems like this.  If I could turn back the clock.......needless to 
say.....I'd order from elsewhere!!!!!!!!!!!

Harry Brandt
'89 911 Carrera 4 sss

Porschephiles #1442                         Wed May 31 11:42:02 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 10:04:14 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Chain Tensioner Wisdom (Wit?).

A big thanks to;
stan@tta.com, BrucePor@aol.com, dswiger@qntm.com, fhess@free.org, 
kgross@centra.net for filling the subject of 911 chain tensioners...

Let's see if I got it right,.....

Mechanichal Tensioners; ...unless you're racing your car, or have a 
super-mint pre hydraulic tensioner show car seeing about 0 (ZERO) miles a 
year, you better think twice......(...at *least* twice, actually keep on 
thinking 'till mechanichal tensioners are as hard (and expensive) to find as 
bikinis in Bagdad.)

Hydraulic Tensioners; ...in contrary to good wine their usefulness is the 
inverted of their fabrication date (relative that is). If you got to have 
them, you should get the '80-'84 model (maybe 930 models too) tensioners, 
and do use the chain tensioner clamps that are sold aftermarket.

Pressure Fed system;...this is the way to go, pre '84 stuff, fits all and 
every 911 engine after approx. '68, they will also fit the engines back to 
'65 with some more modifications to the oil lines/covers.

That's about it,.....thanks.


Trond V.

PS: as for rails, 5 black and 1 brown.

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 08:12:26 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Beware of HRE Wheels? Opposite Experience!


We here in Delaware have had the opposite experience.

Gene at HRE has been extreemly flexible with regard to fittments.  3 of
us ordfered three sets of 9, 9.5 and 10.5, 11, and 11.5 x 17" wheels
for our turbo bodied 911 cars.

The first set I ordered had the wrong offset in the rear.  I called and
asked, and asked that while they were at it they widen the fronts by
1/2" (to 9.5") on my set only, and they the offset on the rear be
changed by 1", with 1/2" added to the inside half.  They did this and
paid return shipping, plus shipped the second and third sets within a
week. 

They also sent the first set along for fitment, and made changes to the
two other orders to accomodate differences in suspension and flare
width (amazing how much differenc between an early car fited with
pre-89 flares and a late car fitted with 89 on flares).

The entire transaction took about 4 weeks, from order to final
delivery of all sets.

We all paid "a lot" less (sworn to secrecy on the racer program), and
all skipped the center caps to save money.

They were good on the phone, and returned calls promptly.  I plan to
order another set for the street, now that I've sold almost all of my
original 6 sets of wheels.

Maybe the Carrera 4 sss needs a special fitment.  My RSR 3.4 was pretty
close off the rack.


Steve

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 08:25:06 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re:HRE Wheels- Counterpoint

Sorry to hear about your experience with HRE. I, also, bought some wheels
from them and found them cooperative and prompt. They also did some research
for me so that I could fit oversize wheels on my car. When I received the
wheels, with custom offset, they fit perfectly.
I also think that they were reasonably priced, compared to all other wheels
that I shopped. It's hard to imagine how you spent $3000 on 4 wheels when I
spent about $730 for two 10 x 17 forged wheels. Of course this was with a
racer's discount. (HINT) They will give you a huge discount if you let them
know that you are using them on the track and that you are willing to wear
their decal.
I certainly hope that you resolve your problems and that for some reason your
experience is an isolated one.

Regards,
Jerry

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 8:33:49 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: 911 tranny

Hi Ted,

<discussion of 911 SC shifting problems, and request for tranny rebuild input>

Yes, my clutch has been replaced.  Once during a prior life, and once
last spring shortly after I purchased the car.  I replaced with a
complete F&S package (TO bearing, p-plate, clutch plate, flywheel
w/all new bolts and hardware plus a new cable).  I adjusted it
carefully according to the Haynes manual (in chap 11 I think for
later models) at the time, checked it again just before and just
after my track session last month (about 8k on the clutch by then).
It appeared perfect.

Whats the story on these bushings I keep hearing about ?

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 09:31:06 -0400 (EDT)
From: Michell Feig <mitchsf@shadow.net>
Subject: Re: Leather/Vinyl Care/Refinishing

Dear Larry:
Your experience with leather and vinyl restoration and 
preservation are appreciated.

I had a 1986 928 with pearlescent leather interior - which became 
YELLOWescent in a year, and snowflakes a year after that.  I used 
Color Plus products to restore the interior.  They matched the color ( not 
the pearl finish, though), and I used the leather conditioner first before 
dying the leather.  It worked great.  I initially made the mistake of 
using an airbrush to apply the finish, until I realized that it is a dye, 
not a paint!  
Thanks.
Mitch Feig
1976 911S

Subject: Bosch electric radio antennas and catalytic converter to sell.

I spent yesterday cleaning out the basement and found some items
of possible interest here.

6 each Bosch electric radio antennas. Self erecting as it were.
They are unused but a bit grimey from 10 years in the basement.

It looks like all the mounting hardware is there with 4 of them 
and most with two.

I'd like to sell them.

$35/each plus shipping for the ones with hardware. $30/each for the
ones missing some hardware.

The application sheet that came with them shows installation in 911 and
924 models. I'll include a copy of the sheet.

Also, I found an Engelhard catalytic converter. It has 2" inlet and outlet.
It looks like it came of a stationary engine with a vertical stack as it
has one of those hinged rain sheilds on one end. The element is replaceable
although the one in place looks O.K. It is approximately 7" OD by 14" long
including end pieces. Center piece holding the element is approx. 6"x6"dia.
plus 1/2" flanges for disassembly.
$35 plus shipping.

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 08:40:08 -0600 (CST)
From: HENSLEY@uwplatt.edu
Subject: Import numbers for the 944, 1983 to 1991

Hi All:
	The following is from the '944 Driver':

	Below is a table the sumarizes the number of cars imported
by PCNA from 1983 though 1991.  The records for some years and models
were not available because they were lost or discarded in the transfer
from VW.

		1983	944	15,506
		1984	944	16,618
		1985	Not Available
		1986	944	10,901
			TRUBO	 7,513
		1987	944	 8,246
			944S	 3,127
			TURBO	 3,210
		1988	944	 3,731
			944S	 5,561
			TURBOS	 1,000(Worldwide)
		1989	9445sp	 1,119
			944Auto	   381
			TURBO	 1,201
			944S2	   970
			944S2Cab    16
		1990	944S2	   285
			944S2Cab 1,673
		1991	944S2      395
			944S2Cab   455

The '944 Driver' was a publication of the 944 Registry that is no
longer around.  Steve Gotthard, Gottard Publishing, Portland, OR, was
the person doing the 944 Regustry.  

Harvey Hensley
University of Wisconsin-Platteville
E-MAIL:	hensley@uwplatt.edu
PHONE:	608-342-1657
FAX:	608-342-1566
CAR: 	PORSCHE 964

out of hyperdrive and are down to warp speed or less.  Iffen yer still
cookin' Yer Kindly ol' Unka Bart still maintains that 110% vigilence remains

devils for an instant an' it'll reach up and bite you in the ass, *hard*.

evaluating every foot of highway for a soft place to land when Murphy
arrives.  It leads to the same kind of consciousness alteration that meditation
does, or running (I'm told).

Date: Wed, 31 May 95 10:30:48 EDT
From: "Chuck Olson PKO3-2/Q21; DTN: 223-4816  31-May-1995 1002" <olson@lando.ENET.dec.com>
Subject: 928 belt tension

Hi all,

	I recently purchased a 87 928s4 (my dream car) with 61 K miles
	on it.  I had it checked out initially by a mechanic - there were
	a few small things, but it looked to be in really good shape.

	A problem came up the first time I really tried to accellerate 
	quickly: the belt tension light came on.  I immediately pulled over, 
	shut off the car and when I put it back on, it was out.  I've been 
	driving it for the past few days, but it's obviously concerning.
	I have no record of the belt being done and I know it's generally 
	done at around 60 K miles.  The records of maintenance are incomplete 
	for the last 20K miles.

	Has this happened to anyone out there?  Is it safe to be driving
	it before I replace it?  I'm trying to get a feel for whether it's
	something that happens to 928s or if it's a dangerous thing.  I
	know the consequences are severe for a broken belt so I don't want
	to take any chances - I plan to fix it in the next week or so.

	Also, I was planning on doing this myself, just not so soon as I won't
	have the manuals for a few weeks.  I've done timing belts on other 
 	cars, so I'm not a total novice to it.  Having read the Chilton's 
	manual, two of the four cams are driven by the belt and two by a 
	chain in the back, so alignment shouldn't be too bad.

	Is there a way to check the condition of the belt without removing the
	cover (via a hole or something)?  

	Are there special tools required to do it?  

	Is it recommended to replace the water pump at the same time?


TIA for any help or advice,

Chuck Olson

slightly against a vertically oriented cylindrical object mounted on the rear
of the wheel well, making a groaning noise. I'm guessing that this thing is
some kind of pump. I can see that two hoses run to it, but without getting it
off the ground it's hard to see where they go, and I can't figure out from my
Haynes manual what it could be. Is it something to do with the air
conditioning? 

The front wheels are 7x16 Fuchs. Is this the stock size? The tires are
Pirelli Cinturato P7s, which I was given to understand is a popular choice.
What's goofy here? Do I need lower profile tires? Should the wheels be
smaller? Or is something else out of whack?

Date: Tue, 30 May 95 15:59:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Re: Linda Grigsby & Parts


Folks,

In fairness to Linda and Carlsens, from whom I have not had the opportunity 
to purchase anything, I should point out that the margin varies with the 
type of part,  i.e., rotors will have bigger margins and a bigger discount 
can be had, if the dealer is willing.  On other parts, ANY discount will put 
it at what the dealer might consider basement margin for operations and PCA 
discount = Internet discount = Joe Beer Can Off the Street discount.

I did call Linda looking for a dash, and although she couldn't provide me 
with the part, she gave me the name/phone of the person who bought the last 
one available from PCNA.

FWIW.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu
>---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 11:05:57 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: Chain Tensioner Wisdom (Wit?).


>
>Pressure Fed system;...this is the way to go, pre '84 stuff, fits all and 
>every 911 engine after approx. '68, they will also fit the engines back to 
>'65 with some more modifications to the oil lines/covers.

Trond,
  I beleive that in order to use a pressure fed system in the 2.0ltr motors
(at least mine). I would need to change the cam tower and the covers. No 
problem with my 66 as far as oil sprayer is concerned, the lines are there.
The problem lies in the fact that the cover is diffrent from the later 
motors. Not super sure that the cam tower is up-datable, but would be 
necessary in order to fit new style covers. Even the lower valve covers are 
diffrent in the older cars (no 930 cover upgrade available;-).

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 11:10:44 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: M474 Suspension

Steve Jagernauth writes:

>Allow me to muddy the waters further with another data point:

(Steve succeeds.)

>I have the 474 'option' code listed in my spare wheelwell which is standard 
>equipment for '87 951 according to the option list in the FAQ.  (BTW, the 
>option list in the FAQ was sent to me from Mark Sundt who scanned 
>it in from a 1987 Porsche sales brochure so I believe this is correct. )
>I have the original shocks on the car which are yellow Konis and are labelled 
>'adjustable' with a 951.xxx.xxx part no. 

I didn't mention this before, but my car does not list the 474 option
in the spare wheelwell.  The only options that are listed are non-performance
options - leather adjustable sport seats, etc.  I really wish I would have
known more about this before I bought my first Porsche.  Now I would 
definitely look for all the sports options...

>So far we've got 1 set of yellow Boge, yellow Koni and black F&S.  Sounds like
>Porsche, 'er.. Audi, put in whatever was available at the time.   

It's starting to sound like that.  It probably has to do with what time of the
year the car was built.  I know of a couple of '87 951s without airbags,
but all of the literature I've read says that all '87+ 951s came with 
airbags standard...

Ross Stites
'87 951

Date: Wed, 31 May 95 12:40:04 EST
From: "Thwen Chaloemtiarana" <chaloemt@vrinet.com>
Subject: 914 2nd gear synchro going or is it op error?

Porsche-pholks,

When the PO had my 1.7 engine rebuilt, he/she apparently swapped in a '72 
transmission.  Ugh.  Questions follow re: what to do now, and what to do for 
the future.

1]  Downshifting from 3 to 2 is grind city, unless I'm going < 30mph.  Anything 
over 30, no dice.  From what I can tell, 2nd takes me up to at least 33+ mph 
before I upshift to 3.  So why can't I downshift at 33 mph or so?  This makes 
coming into a turn a crapshoot.  More often than not, I end up riding through 
it in neutral.  Is this a double-clutch or bring the rpms up before going for 
it thing?  No problems at all downshifting 3 to 2 under 30 mph.

2]  Is it a really bad idea to downshift 4 to 2 sometimes?  (not that I can, 
currently)  I've always been under the impression that (when street driving) 
slowing down with your brake pads is cheaper than with your transmission.

3]  Someone mentioned a few days ago that the front engine mount was modified 
between 72 and 73 for the side shifter set up.  Mine needs welding, currently, 
but given that I now have (supposedly) a 72, and won't be able to upgrade back 
to a '73 for a year or so, can I fix it such that it will work for now but 
won't require rework for the side shifter trans?

Well, that's it for now.
TIA for advice.  Thwen.

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1443                         Wed May 31 16:03:01 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 31 May 95 13:12:35 EDT
From: "Chuck Olson PKO3-2/Q21; DTN: 223-4816  31-May-1995 1309" <olson@lando.enet.dec.com>
Subject: RE: Wax Residue

I'd try something called PreCleen-O.

Found at paint stores.

I was painting the house, and some latex paint from the brushes somehow 
splattered on a friends car parked outside.  Before I noticed, it dried 
overnight.  Water wouldn't clean it up and I didn't want to scratch - but 
this stuff worked pretty well.  It will remove wax also according to the can.
I just used a clean rag dipped in it and wiped it slightly - no problem -
came right off without damaging the car paint.

Of course, you'll have to rewax the area you removed the wax from.


Chuck O
87 928s4 (needing a timing belt)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 95 10:53:33 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: 914 Axle Nut + VW Engine Rebuild Book Comment

 Greeting,
 
 Regarding the recent question on the 914 Axle Nut, I present my experiences....
 
 I decided to pull entire half-shaft while doing engine rebuild.  Why?  Hmmm... 
 As Stan hinted, perhaps I shouldn't have done so, but my intention is to 
 install new rear wheel bearings in an attempt to make the old car new again.  
 The whole process is a little more complicated than I had hoped.  Anyway, first 
 attempt was with an average, everyday Craftsman 1/2" breaker bar. Stood on it 
 and sort of jumped. No dice.  P-Phile suggestion #1 said use big-*ss pipe 
 wrench on a short 1/2" extention supported by a jackstand.  I liked the 
 innovative, Rube-Goldberg solution but my big-*ss pipe wrench would never bite 
 onto the extention.  P-Phile suggestion #2 said to get a Ubangi: a piece of 
 black iron with a 30mm six-sided closed end wrench-like hole for the nut, a 
 1/2" square hole for a breaker bar and a large hammer pad for a hammer.  
 Process is to put steady pressure on the nut with th ebreaker bar and then 
 hammer on the pad to add some impact force.  Ubangis are available form all the 
 local VW folks, most likely, and I bet these things work really well, but I 
 never did find a local guy.  P-Phile suggestion #3 was to use an impact wrench. 
  I bought one for use on the rusty triumph GT6, so I figured I'd give it a 
 shot.  Nope -- not enought guts.  Then again, not a double impact IR.  
 Penultimate P-Phile suggestion: Use a really long cheater pipe on the Craftsman 
 breaker bar.  With the extra 3' of pipe, I was able to dind out more about the 
 grain structure of the Craftman tool steel than I would have liked.  In other 
 words -- neato catastrophic Fast Fracture! Final P-Phile Suggestion:  Get a 
 better breaker bar.  SO I went and plunked down the $50 required to get a 1/2" 
 breaker bar made by Armstrong and combined with the cheater pipe and gradual, 
 steady force application the nuts came loose!  Of course only one stub axle 
 decide to come free despite lots of hammering....
 
 
 Now, regarding the VW engine rebuild book by Tom Wilson (?):  I have it and I 
 agree that for the most part it is good.  On the other hand, I was warned about 
 a few possible suggestions by Mr. Wilson that uh...how should I put this... 
 well, they aren't universally accepted as being correct.  They are:
 
 Ease of removing engine and tranny vs removing them separately:  I believe he 
 states somewhere that it is easier to remove each separately but then also 
 shows how to remove as a unit.  I'm pretty sure it was in this book....
 
 Use of sealant on pushrod tube O-rings:  I believe that he suggests using 
 Permatex 3H or equiv. on the O-rings -- I have always heard that it is better 
 to install them dry, allowing more movement to ease thermal expansion mismatch 
 problems.
 
 Start-Up procedure:  He suggests using the spin-the-engine-over- with-the- 
 starter-until-the-oil-pressure- comes-up-and-then-hook-up- 
 the-coil-wire-so-that- it-runs method.  Stan (correct me if I am wrong) also 
 suggests this, so it may be a good idea but I have heard that it is not a good 
 one.  On the other hand, the only option presented to me was to presurize the 
 system with an extermal oiler.
 
 
 Now a couple of questions:
 
 Case sealant: What Kind?  Curil K2 (my old favorite)?  Permatex Orange (I guess 
 that's what Porsche uses)?
 
 O-Ring Seals:  Regular or Viton?
 
 Start-Up procedure:  When spinning with the starter to build oil pressure, 
 should the plugs also be removed?
 
 
 -Tim
 radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 95 13:49:21 CDT
From: Steve=Putnam%Prod=Qual%Mfg=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re: 928 belt warning

>Date: Wed, 31 May 95 10:30:48 EDT
>From: "Chuck Olson <olson@lando.ENET.dec.com>
>
>RE: 928 belt tension
>
>     I recently purchased a 87 928s4 (my dream car) with 61 K miles on it.

Congratulations!  at least it was driven with 61K.

>     A problem came up the first time I really tried to accelerate
>     quickly: the belt tension light came on.  I immediately pulled over,
>     shut off the car and when I put it back on, it was out.

As you probably know, there is a sensor checking for belt deflection.  This
resets on power up until the next infraction (hopefully minor without valves
as a lunch)

>   I have no record of the belt being done and I know it's generally done
>     at around 60 K miles.  The records of maintenance are incomplete for
>     the last 20K miles.

Obviously the previous owner choked on the thought of the 60k service $$.

>     Has this happened to anyone out there?  Is it safe to be driving
>     it before I replace it?  I'm trying to get a feel for whether it's
>     something that happens to 928s or if it's a dangerous thing.

When I hit 59k on my '86 928S the warning came on.   Drove it moderately for
a few days until a chance for a service event.

>      Is there a way to check the condition of the belt without removing
>      the cover (via a hole or something)?

Yes, at least on the '86 there is a peep hole under the drivers side
air pipe that leads to the air cleaner.   You will be able to check for
visible damage, etc, but I doubt you will see any stretch marks.

>Chuck Olson


Regards, Steve

Internet- SPutnam@bangate.compaq.com
Lone Star Region PCA
'86 928S  Meteor Metallic

GO ROCKETS (hoping to play all games in San Antonio)

Date:          Wed, 31 May 1995 15:13:27 EDT
From: "Asad Husain" <AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd.edu>
Subject:       Re: 914 Axle Nut + VW Engine Rebuild Book Comment

>  The whole process is a little more complicated than I had hoped.  Anyway, first 
>  attempt was with an average, everyday Craftsman 1/2" breaker bar. Stood on it 
>  and sort of jumped. No dice.  P-Phile suggestion #1 said use big-*ss pipe 
>  wrench on a short 1/2" extention supported by a jackstand.  I liked the 
>  innovative, Rube-Goldberg solution but my big-*ss pipe wrench would never bite 
>  onto the extention.  P-Phile suggestion #2 said to get a Ubangi: a piece of 
>  black iron with a 30mm six-sided closed end wrench-like hole for the nut, a 
>  1/2" square hole for a breaker bar and a large hammer pad for a hammer.  
>  Process is to put steady pressure on the nut with th ebreaker bar and then 
>  hammer on the pad to add some impact force.  Ubangis are available form all the 
>  local VW folks, most likely, and I bet these things work really well, but I 
>  never did find a local guy.  P-Phile suggestion #3 was to use an impact wrench. 
> 

I've had to deal with many rusty bolts in the past and very tight 
ones as well.  What I have found to work well is this:

Use a 1/2" socket wrench with 1/2" sockets.  From your local plumbers 
shop or Home depot purchase one of those long black steel pipes that 
fit snuggly over the handle of your 1/2" socket wrench.   The pipe I 
have is about 2' long but you can try longer or shorter ones.  Mine 
cost $4.00.  I now have an air compressor but I still use my pipe 
method 'cause is quicker than setting up the compressor.  I found 
this method with even pressure will open almost any nut. 


BTW any porschephile who wants to borrow my air compressor in the 
Baltimore area is welcome to do so.  It's a 5hp 220V Sears.







**********************************************************************
Asad Husain, Director Technical Services     Phone: (410)706-3971
School of Medicine                           Fax  : (410)706-2043
University of Maryland at Baltimore
655 W. Baltimore Street 
Baltimore, MD 21201

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 16:03:02 -0400 (EDT)
From: Michell Feig <mitchsf@shadow.net>
Subject: Re: Leather/Vinyl Care/Refinishing

Dear Chuck:
A few years ago I was shown a great way to test for leather vs vinyl.  
Push a finger nail into the material.  If the "dent" is gone immediately 
after removing finger, it's vinyl.  If it takes a little time to go 
away, it's leather.

Mitch Feig 
1976 911S

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 14:59:18 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: CIS injection

>Was there a '73E?  I'm not sure.  But I do know that CIS came on the
>late 73's.  Early T's had mechanical injection, same as early S's.

        Check the 911 FAQ (thanks, Wade!).  MFI was offered on the 69-
73 911S, all the E's (69? - 73) and on the 72-73 T's.  Earlier T's
and S's all had carbs.  Starting with the "73.5" model, the 911T had
CIS injection.  That's what was used on all 911s from 74 through 83
(except the race cars and lightweight homologation types).

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 16:16:09 -0400 (EDT)
From: Michell Feig <mitchsf@shadow.net>
Subject: Re: 944/911 Porsche in Israel



On Wed, 31 May 1995, ilia bunin wrote:

> 
>      I live in Israel, Jerusalem. At present time there is absolutely no
> any Porshe dealers / suppliers in country. Porsche park of Israel - 30-40
> cars. Now I think about to import a Porsche from Germany ( 944S2 model 90
> or 911C2 model 87). 
>      I'd like to ask which car is better to bye and which one has less
> problems in repair and support, and which one is more reliable.
>      Is I can operate them without a Porsche specialist?
> 
> Thanking you all in advance
>   Michael Perlov.
>   
> 
Dear Michael:
The 944S2 is probably a 1987, and the 911C2 is a 1990.  I think that the 
condition of the car that you are looking for, and personal preference, 
are most important, because the cars are probably equally reliable.  The 
911 will certainly be more expensive to maintain.  My guess is that a 
mechanic who has no familiarity with Porsche will probably have an easier 
time with the 944 than the 911, but I think that getting the car repaired 
will be difficult either way.  

Do they still drive around those plastic cars in Israel?  And Mercedes Taxis
with wind-up windows?

Mitch Feig
1976 911S

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 15:01:02 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Queer Ride Height 


P-philes,

As my 914 saga continues(fast approaching powertrain installation - yes!), I
am concerned about the current ride height.  The ride height is significantly 
lower on the drivers side front than it is on the rest of the car.  As a 
result, by visual inspection, it seems to "tilt" toward the drivers side.

I made some actual measurements and the driver's side front sits about 1"
lower than the left.  Although there may be a similiar problem in the rear, 
it is not as pronouced as in the front of the car.

Since getting the car, I've been in it, on it, under it, etc. and have not
noticed anything glaringly obvious.  The longitudinals are in fine shape
(re-enforced by PO) and rust damage is confined to non-structural areas.

Someone suggested to me that it may be the torsion bar up front that is the
culprit.  If so, how do I go about inspecting it?  Is it somehow located
under the A-arm?  I didn't notice it visually, but I didn't hunt for it 
extensively either.

The car has adjustible perch shocks in the rear, original boge struts up front
with indeterminate inserts.  In general, what controls ride height on most
P-cars?

Thanks in advance for any information y'all may have in your heads...

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 15:18:49 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 914 2nd gear synchro going

In response to text from Thwen Chaloemtiarana:
>
>1]  Downshifting from 3 to 2 is grind city, unless I'm going < 30mph.  
>Anything over 30, no dice.  So why can't I downshift at 33 mph or so?  

Tried-and-true worn syncromesh problems[and I've been with you in the car 
watching you "hunt" for 1st and 2nd].  Time to have the transmission 
rebuilt.  Most probably new 1st gear, maybe 2nd, new syncros.  Just hope
that your ring and pinion is in good shape; I hear its a good 10 hours
of labor for ring and pinion work since alignment is crucial and tolerances
are so tight.

>2]  Is it a really bad idea to downshift 4 to 2 sometimes?  (not that I can, 
>currently)  I've always been under the impression that (when street driving) 
>slowing down with your brake pads is cheaper than with your transmission.

New pads are cheaper than transaxle repair.  It may be tough on your clutch
to use the transaxle as a brake, especially if you get the RPM jump, body
slam into seat-belt effect.

>3]  Someone mentioned a few days ago that the front engine mount was modified 
>between 72 and 73 for the side shifter set up.  Mine needs welding, currently, 
>but given that I now have (supposedly) a 72, and won't be able to upgrade back 
>to a '73 for a year or so, can I fix it such that it will work for now but 
>won't require rework for the side shifter trans?

The physical mounts(part of the chassis) remained the same for the 914.  The
insert engine and transimission mounts changed design(went to solid in 
later years - less expensive to replace).  The only issue of concern in your
case(I believe) is the engine mounting bar itself.  When the 914 changed over
to the side-shift transaxle, the mounting bar was redesigned to permit the
shifter linkage to pass through.  This wasn't a problem on the earlier 
914s since the shifter linkage passed under the bar and attached to the 
bottom end of the transaxle.

Fabrication to shore up rust damaged engine mounts(on chassis) will not 
affect your options as far as motor mounts, engines or transaxle selection
is concern.  That is, if it is done properly.

Regards,
- -- [ my opinion are just that, opinions and not fact. ]

 - Jerry R. Brady               vox:313 996 9900   internet: jrb@one.com     -
 - Open Networks Engineering    fax:313 996 9908             abaris@msen.com -

 - '76 914 1.9                                                               -

Date: Wed, 31 May 95 13:43:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: Unsticking stuck heat exchanger bolts.


Bummer.  I, unfortunately, had the not-so-pleasant experience of pulling 
heat exchangers off of my 73 when I bought it.  It had been parked for 10 
years.  I broke 6, even after soaking the sh*t out of them.

I used a torch, and it helped get the others out.  Get it really hot, but 
try not to heat the stud.

Use the hex tool, which can be had from Snap-On or Mac as well.  Actually, I 
think the Snap-On tool was a bit short, which must be why I bought the Mac.

You may break more.  That's just life, I guess.  Pendergrass Tools USED to 
sell a very cool jig (I got the last one!)for drilling out the old studs and 
and threading for Time-Serts, which you will be using as an insert for your 
new studs now.  Great product.

Wurth makes an anti-sieze product called CU-200, or something like that (I'm 
at work so I don't have access to it presently) and it's copper-based. 
 Works really well.  I've pulled the exchangers off after using this and 
experienced no problems.  Wish the last guy had used it.

If you need more specific info, email me directly.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

>Hello,
>
>While trying to remove my left heat exchanger from my '81 911SC, I
>snapped off a nut (and part of the bolt) going into the cylinder
>head.  Oh Well!  Does anyone have any reccomendations on how to
>unstick these nuts, as well as other frozen nuts on the underside
>of the car?
>

>cylinder flanges give me as much trouble?  I am considering ordering
>that special hex tool which extends through the heat exchanger and
>into the hex head bolt for ease of removal.  Does anyone have experience
>or hints in how to unstick these nuts and bolts?  I tried some torch
>heating but this gave me the broken bolt.  How much heating is needed?
>

>1981 Euro-911SC Widebody Targa, Northeast PCA Region Member

Date:         Wed, 31 May 95 16:35:51 EDT
From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SEAN@american.edu>
Subject:      Head gasket?...


Recently I turned my 1980 928 over to a kind mechanic to do a pre-track
inspection.  To my surprise he told me that the car had no major
problems, only a slightly leaky head gasket.  He said that it would be
fine for a while and only $150 to fix it when I wanted to.  Not having
$150 to spare, I told him I'd do it later.  This weekend I went to the
track and had a great time- I am amazed at the 928's performance (I
can't believe it's 15 years old!).  However, I had one very scary
experience:  On the straight I was passing another car and had the tach.
needle just up into the red before I was going to shift.  I looked into
the rear view mirror to see if it was clear to get back over and saw a
BIG cloud of smoke!  It was coming from my tailpipe!  I have seen this
in my rear view mirror before, but not smoke this dense and abundant.
As I let offthe gas it slowly tapered off and,to make a long story
short, was fine for the rest of the day (I did not take it to red ever
again!)  My instructor said that it was the leak in the head gasket
letting a little bit of oil into the combustion chamber.  He said that
when oil ignites it creates a big cloud like my car did.  Does this
sound right?  If I fix the head gasket should that take care of the
puffs of smoke I see in the rear view mirror when accelerating hard?  Or
does this have nothing to do with a leaking head gasket?  This is
probably the most important post I have ever put to the list(for me!),
so could I get more than a 2 replies even though I'm a 928?  :)
Thanks in advance, Sean

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 95 13:04:48 PDT

Before the IRS takes it for taxes, <g> I need to unload some

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 15:58:53 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Seen on Kansas Turnpike

Porschephiles,

This last Friday I found myself sitting behind a pickup pulling a
trailor while waiting at the west bound ticket booth for I-70 at 
Kansas City.  On the trailor was a VW race car.  In bright yellow
letters across the hatch it said, "Wabbit Wacing".  I found it
fairly humorous.  I assumed he was headed to Heartland Park, but
I don't know for sure.

Ross Stites
'87 951

Subject:      What's SCCA?

know that you have to do a lot of driving schools to do Club Racing, but
I heard that it's relatively easy to do SCCA racing.  How do people feel
about it?  What are the reqirements for your car?  It it cut-throat or
do people have fun with it?  Thanks for any replies, Sean  '80 928
